column2: For Rekha Malhotra, one of the first DJs to  introduce New York audiences to bhangra, music has always been a cultural thing.
Rock Band is an evolutionary jump forward from Guitar Hero, the interactive video game played with a guitar-shaped controller.
Derrick Rose is the starting point guard for No. 2 Memphis and is one of the most highly regarded freshmen in college basketball.
Ol’ Blue Eyes will be traveling first class.
Josh Groban’s album “Noël” (Reprise) held onto the top spot on the Billboard 200 chart for a second consecutive week with sales of 539,000 copies, compared with the 405,000 it tallied last week.
Evel Knievel will go out in a burst of fireworks and a funeral officiated by the televangelist Robert H. Schuller at the Civic Center in Mr. Knievel’s hometown, Butte, Mont.
The National Board of Review named “No Country for Old Men” its best picture yesterday as speculation season began shifting into the bestowing of actual awards.
A 5,000-year-old Mesopotamian sculpture of a lioness standing only 3 1/4 inches high sold at Sotheby’s in New York yesterday for $57.1 million.
The British government has granted $101 million toward a $435 million extension of the Tate Modern in London.

In the tradition-rich world of classical music, it was fitting that Gustavo Dudamel, the latest young lion of conducting, got to use one of Leonard Bernstein’s batons in leading the New York Philharmonic as a guest conductor this week.
Dorothy Kosinski, senior curator of painting and sculpture at the Dallas Museum of Art, has been appointed director of the Phillips Collection in Washington.
The Christmas classic “Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer”  led CBS to a Tuesday night victory in the ratings as the special delivered 14.4 million viewers at 8 p.m.,
The Mets’ shortstop José Reyes returns to the Dominican Republic in the off season to process the lessons of last season and prepare for a new start in 2008.
Nearly all of William D. Walsh’s 200 antiquities are to go on view at Fordham University in the Bronx as a permanent gift from Mr. Walsh, a financier and philanthropist.
Sesame Workshop will unveil a nonprofit research and production institute named after Joan Ganz  Cooney that will try to inject educational standards into digital media for older children.
Manhattan.
Miramax may be a smaller and calmer organization under Daniel Battsek, but the studio has nonetheless remained in the thick of the awards race.
The palm-size antenna provides faster and more solid connections by combining a sensitive decoding circuit with a directional antenna that amplifies the signal.
Millions of adults in interfaith marriages face the December dilemma: the annual conflict over how to decorate homes, how and when to give gifts and which rituals to celebrate.
What do the photographers who took the original pictures think of these pictures of their pictures, apotheosized into art but without their names anywhere in sight?

To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
Three concerts, part of Valery Gergiev’s Perspectives series, offered a selective tour of the Russian opera and ballet repertory.

After the season we just completed, only those people with a bcsfootball.org e-mail address can argue with a straight face that the postseason system in place for college football is even remotely acceptable. But let’s ignore the ridiculousness of trying to determine the two best teams for a moment; take a look at how the other B.C.S. games were chosen.

“No matter how how you jump, how fast you run or swim, how powerfully you row, you can do better,” Gina Kolata writes today in The Times. “But sometimes your mind gets in the way.” Since most people can do better, no matter how good their performance, the challenge is to find a safe way to push a little harder.

He’s 38 and graying, but that hasn’t stopped Brett Favre from having a remarkable, resurgent season, playing his way into contention for the Most Valuable Player award. Besides Tom Brady and Peyton Manning, is there a quarterback in the N.F.L. who you’d rather have leading your team in a big game? If so, whom?.

There may be good news for the indolent as well as the fit in the latest research on exercise and the brain. A new study from Yale University suggests that physical activity encourages the brain’s neural pathways to work more efficiently — benefits that one day may come from the contents of a bottle.
Building Sensors.
Harry Partch, the eclectic, visionary and self-taught California-born composer who died at 73 in 1974, was primarily an inventor, in the most creative sense of the term.
On Tuesday night, at the first of two sold-out shows at the Nokia Theater, Chris Daughtry seemed hard working and humble.
The year’s oddest musical tribute belongs to Dirty Projectors, the Brooklyn band that brought its lapidary, wayward constructions to the Bowery Ballroom on Tuesday night.
Drama and grandeur were deftly illuminated by the violinist Christian Tetzlaff and the pianist Alexander Lonquich at the 92nd Street Y on Tuesday night.
Peter Parnell’s play is a tightly focused study of Darwin, his family and his intellectual circles.
Images that once were considered second-class work for hire have earned their place on the gallery wall.
While much of Cuba’s infrastructure has crumbled, more than 300 of the city’s landmark buildings have been refurbished.

The Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams, the premier event of the Fall North American Championships in San Francisco, ended Sunday in victory for Jimmy Cayne of New York; Michael Seamon of Hollywood, Fla.; and four Italians: Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace.
The designers Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana celebrate the $15 million renovation of their Madison Avenue store.
Rings with the structure (and punch) of brass knuckles are giving the old diamond solitaire a poke in the eye.
At the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night the Dave Douglas Quintet brushed against facets of modal jazz, nascent fusion and polyphonic funk.
How do I replace the built-in metal hamper in my 1950s bathroom?
Two of the members of Hamas were preparing to fire mortar into Israel.
Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas will ask for $5.8 billion in aid through 2010 to help with a huge deficit run up in years of strife. He also will promise to curb spending.

Dogster, a Facebook for canines, has roughly 350,000 four-legged members with their own profile pages that list their likes and dislikes, personal mottoes and best tricks (“catching seedless grapes in mid-air”).
The company announced a major overhaul that will eliminate about half of its 27 manufacturing sites worldwide and cut its work force of 43,000 employees by more than 10 percent.
Many entrepreneurs have started businesses selling candy, cookies and other sweets that are free of potential allergens.
John Darwin was declared dead over four years ago, so it was a shock when he walked into a London police station.
The outcome was expected to boost the already high chances of restoring a conservative government to power.
Iran’s president hailed a U.S. intelligence report as a victory on Wednesday, but President Bush said that Iran still had questions to answer.
Giving birth may be its own reward, but today many new mothers are likely to want some sort of tangible bonus as well.
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has decided against shifting Marine Corps forces from Iraq to take the lead in Afghanistan, officials said.
Using mental tricks, or dissociating, can get you to the finish line faster.
The attack in Kabul injured 17 others and came as Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates was visiting the city.

Q. My rabbit’s foot fern has grown too large for its hanging pot. The rhizomes are draped all over the outside. How do I re-pot without destroying the plant? I live in zone 10 and the plant stays outdoors year round.
The inability of lawmakers to agree on exactly how to limit the alternative minimum tax is threatening to throw filing season into chaos.
American intelligence agencies obtained notes last summer from deliberations of Iranian military officials involved in the nuclear weapons program.
Battered by a year of personal and political hardships, Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey is struggling to catch a second wind.
On the island of Sumatra, about 1,200 miles from the global climate talks under way on Bali, are some of the world’s fastest-disappearing forests.
In a new advertisement, Rudolph W. Giuliani casts his peace-through-strength vision of foreign policy as a continuation of the policies of Ronald Reagan.
The agreement would freeze interest rates for up to five years for some of the two million homeowners who bought houses recently with subprime loans.
Thomas Hays is an interior designer whose life has taken nearly as many journeys as his possessions.
A man taking care of his two children and an autistic brother is unable to keep working after a car accident.
For the holidays, a summary of digital cameras, all priced below $300.
The Knicks and the Nets both have grandiose plans to move to proposed arenas in the near future, but at the moment they are not going anywhere special.
It seems that the fashion elves have been especially generous in bestowing accolades this season, to the point of depreciating their value.

Police Chief Thomas Warren of Omaha identified the eight people who were killed in a shooting spree at a shopping mall on Wednesday. They included five women and three men who ranged in age from 24 to 66 years old. Six of the victims were employees of the Von Maur department store and two were customers:.
Knicks guard Stephon Marbury was not with the team Wednesday night, remaining instead with his family to mourn the death of his father, Donald E. Marbury.
The Knicks rallied around Jamal Crawford and Zach Randolph, fought off a late charge by the Nets and left the Izod Center with their first road victory in eight games this season.
The Yankees do not have Johan Santana, but they have their prospects, and General Manager Brian Cashman’s plan to build from within remains intact.
Should the Mets fail to obtain an ace like Johan Santana, they might seek an “innings eater” who can work in the third, fourth or fifth slot in the rotation.
A Guantánamo detainee who is charged as Osama bin Laden’s driver argued that he should be treated as a prisoner of war and should not be tried by military commission.
An officer who pleaded not guilty to the illegal killing of an unarmed man in May was taunted as he walked out of the courtroom on Wednesday after his arraignment.
The Mets are hoping to benefit from the stagnant discussions between the Boston Red Sox and the Twins and swoop in and acquire Johan Santana.
The McDonald’s restaurants in Seminole County, Fla., and the county school board have agreed to reward good grades and attendance with Happy Meals.
Mitt Romney’s advisers say that in his address he will emphasize religious liberty and make a case for the robust role of faith in public life.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey plans to go to Iowa to campaign for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, but when it comes to governing he is actually following a path blazed by former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas.
A tree meets a dog walker at the start of “Gods Behaving Badly,” Marie Phillips’s flossy, high-concept comic novel.
The killings served as a vicious reminder that the months-long decline in daily violence was not a sure harbinger of any lasting peace.
A visit to Billionaire Boys Club and Ice Cream, which offers top-end hip-hop garb that is anything but subtle.
Hairdressers who don’t want their clients to tell them their troubles are as rare as those who believe in natural blondes.
How is a stylist to gauge whether a client wants their cut with a side of gossip?
In rejecting Hugo Chávez’s referendum, Venezuelans gave a civic example from which George W. Bush’s battered and blathering democracy can learn.
Personally, I would love to be able to vote for a presidential candidate who’s spent his/her life preparing to serve the country as competently as possible.

GARLAND--Stanley (Sira)/d. A kind, loving, devoted man of great wit. We will miss him dearly. Our love and deepest sympathy to the entire Garland extended family. Love Stacey, Donald and Joanna Novick

STEINGESSER--Mary Es ther, (nee Selinger), 97, died Monday, December 3, 2007. Devoted wife of the late William Steingesser; beloved mother of Stephanie Hamburg and Richard Steingesser. Cherished mother-in-law of Charles Bruce Hamburg; grandmother of Jeanne Hamburg Schechtman, Louise Hamburg and Deborah and David Steingesser; greatgrandmother of Kara and Grant Schechtman. She remains in our hearts forever. Service at 12 noon on Thursday, December 6, 2007 at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. (at 76th Rd.), Forest Hills, NY 11375.

COOPER--Herman A., passed away December 4th, just 4 short months after his loving wife Beatrice died. Herman was born May 23, 1920 in Manhattan. He was the son of Bertha Cooper. Hy, as he was called by his friends, always had a joke to tell and was a relentless teaser. Fittingly, one of his first jobs was as a radio comedy writer. He wrote for Jackie Gleason, Milton Berle, Fred Allen and Arthur Gottfried to name a few. When he married Beatrice in 1945, he moved into the business world. He was one of the first to lease air conditioners and televisions to hospitals and hotels. That grew into the installations of security systems. He was also a pioneer in the world of cable television which is where he achieved financial success. Additionally, he opened a women's health clinic, TLC Women's Services, in the early 1970s. He was an avid golfer, and he and Bea split their time between Palmas del Mar, Puerto Rico and North Shore Towers, Queens. They were married for 62 years and spent the last five years of their lives in Edgewater, New Jersey. Herman leaves behind his son Brian, daughter Michele, and son-inlaw Dr. Kenneth Glassberg. He was adored by his five grandchildren, Lola, Chloe, Lauren, Larry and Andrew, and Andrew's fiance Mia. They will remember his generosity, his humor and his favorite made-up words and nicknames. Contributions may be made in Herman's name to Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital of NYPresbyterian, c/o Emily Taub, Office of Development, 654 West 170th Street, NY, NY 10032. A private graveside service was held. Shiva will be observed at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Glassberg through Friday.

An article last Thursday about Lynn DeJac, a Buffalo woman who is the first in the nation to have her conviction for committing a murder overturned based on DNA evidence, misspelled the surname of a spokesman for the Innocence Project, a legal clinic that works on such exonerations. He is Eric Ferrero, not Ferraro.

Blu Dot, a Minneapolis furniture company, has opened Dot Spot, its first Manhattan store, on the fourth floor of ABC Carpet & Home. Among the pieces on display are the molded plywood stackable Chair Chair ($129), upper left, and the Dodu bed ($1,099 to $1,499), above, designed for a mattress whose top sits just 12 inches off the floor. ''The low height is not so good for older people,'' said John Christakos, inset, who founded Blu Dot with Maurice Blanks and Charles Lazor in 1996, and, at 42, is ''getting old.'' Nook ($1,099 to $1,499), a new bed, is 18 inches high, like a chair, Mr. Christakos said, which makes getting in and out of it easier. ABC Carpet & Home, 888 Broadway (19th Street), (646) 602-3206. ELAINE LOUIE

An article on Friday about a decision by President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan to lift the state of emergency on Dec. 16 reversed the first and middle names of the Supreme Court chief justice dismissed by Mr. Musharraf when he declared the emergency on Nov. 3, and misspelled the justice's middle name. He is Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, not Mohammed Iftikhar Chaudhry.

LOW--Cecily, 63, of Cresskill, NJ passed away peacefully at home after a courageous battle with cancer on Wednesday, December 5, 2007. Survived by her beloved husband Stephen Spector. Mother of Rachel Low and Elizabeth Honig. Also survived by her parents Erna and Daniel Goldstein, brothers Jonathan Goldstein and Richard Goldstein, sisters-in-law Carla Goldstein and Joanne Goldstein, son-in-law Jonathan Honig, and grandchildren Jett, Skylar and Morgan Honig. Funeral Services will be held on Friday, December 7, 2007 at 11:30am at Gutterman and Musicant Memorial Chapel in Hackensack, NJ.

10 P.M. (NBC) ER For its 300th episode, this series treats 300 patients in an overflowing emergency room. Peter Fonda, left, makes a guest appearance as a husband who rushes to the hospital when he hears that his wife has been in a car accident and unexpectedly meets up with someone from his past. 8 P.M. (ABC) UGLY BETTY Henry (Christopher Gorham) and Betty (America Ferrera) double date with Hilda (Ana Ortiz) and Gio (Freddy Rodriguez). Wilhelmina (Vanessa Williams) fails to change her image as the queen of mean when she tangles with a golden girl (the guest star Betty White).

Gov. Jon S. Corzine plans to go to Iowa on Thursday to campaign for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, but when it comes to governing he is actually following a path blazed by another presidential candidate who lived in the Arkansas governor's mansion: former Gov. Mike Huckabee. Even though Mr. Corzine is a liberal Democrat and Mr. Huckabee is a conservative Republican, the two have displayed similar reflexes on such issues as taxes, education and transportation. The parallels are so compelling, said Ross K. Baker, a political scientist at Rutgers, that ''they're sort of like twins separated at birth.''

A brief report with an artist's rendering on Nov. 19 about a proposal for the Hudson Yards real estate project on the Far West Side of Manhattan gave incomplete information from the developers, the Durst Organization and Vornado Realty Trust, about the 7,000 apartments planned. An unspecified portion would be condominiums, and 20 percent of the remainder, rental units, would be set aside for low- and moderate-income families. The developers do not plan to set aside 20 percent of the total.

In the debate of Democratic presidential candidates on National Public Radio on Tuesday, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware twice mentioned the rise in oil prices when speaking about Iran. Referring to President Bush, Mr. Biden said, ''He has caused oil to go up roughly $25 a barrel, with a security premium, because of his threat of war.'' Later, criticizing a Senate resolution passed Sept. 26 that urged the administration to describe the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps in Iran as a foreign terrorist organization, Mr. Biden, who voted against the resolution, said, ''The moment that declaration was made, oil prices jumped over $18 a barrel.''

Two Christmas trees, gift boxes and a bucket filled with holiday decorations, all made of sand, are on display in the windows of Homenature, above, a home furnishings shop in Southampton, N.Y. ''I wanted the Christmas display to be surprising,'' said John Heilmann, the store's owner, ''and to be made of natural materials.'' Being on the coast, he thought of sand, and soon found Matt Long, a sand sculptor based in Staten Island. Two tons of sand, lots of water and a light coating of glue later, the window displays were finished. For those who want to try sand sculpturing, Mr. Long sells a kit for $34.99 at (800) 541-6715 or sandtools.com. Homenature, 6 Main Street, Southampton, N.Y., (631) 287-6277. MARIANNE ROHRLICH Good deals and secret sources may be reported to rohrlich@nytimes.com.

GOLDSTEIN--Nathan. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Nathan Goldstein, husband of Edye, father of Diane Wohl, and father-in-law of Howard Wohl. The Goldstein and Wohl families' devotion to Jewish causes is an expression of their passion and boundless generosity, fueled by an overwhelming dedication to tikkun olam, enriching the lives of millions in New York, in Israel, and around the world. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Nathan's children, Diane and Howard Wohl, Howard and Susan Goldstein, and Sandra Goldstein; to his grandchildren, Alex and Allison, Hilary and Zack, Pamela, Eric, and Jonathan; to his great-grandchildren; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. GOLDSTEIN--Nathan. Hillel expresses its deepest condolences to International Board of Governors member Diane Wohl on the loss of her beloved father, Nathan Goldstein. He is mourned by his devoted son-in-law Howard and his adored grandchildren and great - grandchildren Pamela, Hilary, Alex, Zachary and Sasha Zalon; and Allison, Miles, Aiden and Russell Wohl. May the memory of the righteous be a blessing. Edgar M. Bronfman, Chairman

Israeli forces on Wednesday killed two members of Hamas and wounded four others as they prepared to fire a mortar shell into Israel, and killed at least one Palestinian security officer in Bethlehem after Israeli forces in civilian clothing were fired upon as they tried to carry out an arrest raid. Israeli forces have killed 32 Palestinians in the past 10 days. Since January, Palestinians have fired over 2,000 rockets and mortar shells toward Israel from Gaza, Israel said.

An article on Nov. 22 about a team of researchers who surreptitiously measured levels of particulate matter in the air at the Big Smoke cigar party and trade show misstated the average level inside the sixth-floor ballroom at the Marriott Marquis in Manhattan, where the event was held. It was 1,943 micrograms per cubic meter, not 1,193. (Under Environmental Protection Agency guidelines, air with more than 251 micrograms per cubic meter is considered hazardous.)

LIEBMAN--Irving H., of Roslyn, NY and Lantana, FL. Beloved husband of 58 years to Louise. Father of Amy Leibman-Rapp and Stephen Shapiro, Jed and Su Liebman, Lisa M. Liebman, and Meg and Howard Kahn; grandfather of Alexander L. Rapp, Zachary Kahn and Danielle Kahn. Services: Thursday, December 6th, 10am at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

A chart with an article in some editions on Saturday about possible complications in Gov. Jon S. Corzine's plan to refinance New Jersey's toll roads referred imprecisely to the length of the New Jersey Turnpike. Although it is indeed 113 miles from tollbooth to tollbooth, the turnpike is 122 miles along the main stretch, excluding spurs.
KALAT--Peter. Forever in our hearts and memories. Laura & Rick, Janet & Steve, Mimi & Joel
INTERNATIONALA3-15 Notes Revealed That Iran Stalled Its Nuclear Efforts

HAFT--Abraham S., M.D., 97. Died peacefully on December 5, 2007 at his home in Bronxville, NY. Beloved husband of the late Ethel Passman Haft, father of Judith Saunders, David Haft, M.D. and Jonathan Haft, grandfather of Jennifer and Marla Saunders, Benjamin Haft and Julian Haft. He had a long and satisfying career as an ophthalmologist in the Bronx. Funeral services will be held on Friday, December 7 at 10:00am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mount Vernon, NY.

ALOT of thought is required to choose the right gifts. Often the best approach is to pass over the generic but to consider ordinary objects -- particularly useful ones -- with a twist, which can be every bit as exciting as more esoteric gifts. A director's chair, for example, with a frame made by a company that has been producing them for more than 100 years, looks brand new with a seat and back in indoor-outdoor material in a modern pattern. It could be a welcome addition to a friend's porch or den.
Smoothing Out Web Video

SAMLER--Morris, of Huntington on November 30th, 2007. Morris was active in the advertising business in NYC as Owner/President of Frank Best Advertising. Butcher Block, Gracious Home Hoffritz, Jensen-Lewis, Leathercrafter, Wim & Karen, and Workbench were his clients. He helped many clients to grow and run successful businesses. Beloved husband of Joan, father of Steven, Eric, and Bebe. Memorial Donations to National Parkinson Foundation.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign distanced itself yesterday from an Iowa volunteer who forwarded an e-mail message falsely stating that Senator Barack Obama was Muslim and was running for president as a Manchurian candidate. ''This was wholly unauthorized, and we were totally unaware of it,'' said Patti Solis Doyle, Mrs. Clinton's campaign manager. ''Let me be clear: No one should be engaging in this.''

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Nov. 24 about a group of Web publishers who started 8020 Publishing to produce user-generated print magazines referred imprecisely to the contributions of Paul Cloutier, 8020's chief executive, to one such publication, JPG magazine. He joined after the first issue; he was not involved in starting the magazine. Also because of an editing error, the article referred imprecisely to the magazine's content. Only one early issue accepted direct e-mail submissions; subsequent submissions have been taken from JPGmag.com. The article also misstated the current ownership status of Derek Powazek, a founder of the online magazine. He still owns a small percentage of 8020 Publishing, not JPG.com.

Early Wednesday, Mets Manager Willie Randolph baited the hook and cast the line. He spoke specifically of Johan Santana of the Minnesota Twins, a left-handed starter and one of baseball's best pitchers, who is on the trade market. ''The big fish are out there,'' Randolph said. ''Santana is still out there. I don't think that we're necessarily out of the picture, even though I think Boston and the Yankees get most of the play.''
HAYMAN--Dorothy, passed away December 4, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Seymour Hayman. Loving mother of Valerie and Jonathan. Rest well Dots.

The holiday season is the time of the pop-up shop, and one of the happiest is Home Candy, which appeared last weekend on Manhattan's Lower East Side and will exist until Dec. 23. It's a mix of household items, jewelry and knitted goods that vibrate with colors: dishes from Zak Designs, top left, including assorted bowls ($12 for a set of four); fluffy mittens in a fabric that looks like something Big Bird would wear ($60 to $70); and pillows and throws made of vintage fabrics from the 1940s and 50s. (The pillow at bottom right is $125, and throws shown are $235 to $300.) ''It's all about color -- I love really clean white surfaces and accent pieces that really pop,'' said Nancy Booke, an interior designer and Home Candy's co-owner, at the store's opening on Saturday. Ms. Booke, second from left at bottom left, was surrounded by a gregarious gang that included, from left, her design partner, Brenda Derfner; her mother, Gail Reiss, who does the jewelry and knitted goods; and her business partner, Elayne Kling.

I've never even heard gunshots here before. Honestly, I didn't know what they sounded like until today, and I thought I never would. Kevin Kleine, of Omaha, after a gunman killed eight people at a mall. [A38 ]

Car bombs in Baghdad and three northern Iraqi cities killed at least 22 people and wounded more than 60 others on Wednesday, as Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived for an unannounced visit with senior Iraqi officials. Taken together, the killings, including a suicide car bomb attack that killed 14 people on a crowded street in a relatively safe Baghdad neighborhood, accounted for the highest daily death toll in several weeks and served as a vicious reminder that the months-long decline in violence was not a sure harbinger of any lasting peace.

The Triennale Design Museum, Italy's first museum dedicated solely to Italian design, opens today in Milan. Designed by Michele De Lucchi, the 20,000-square-foot space was built inside the Triennale di Milano, above, a museum devoted to international decorative arts and design; its entrance is accessible from a bamboo bridge that spans the existing museum's main hall. Italo Rota, an architect, and the British filmmaker Peter Greenaway collaborated on the interiors. ''The Obsessions of Italian Design,'' the inaugural exhibit, runs through April 2009; it includes 100 objects, like Vittoriano Viganò's 1951 chair, left, as well as new films by Mr. Greenaway and six Italian filmmakers, interpreting Italian design. The museum is at Viale Alemagna 6; 011-39-02-724341. LIZ ARNOLD

Misfortune of varying degrees forced the Knicks to revamp their starting lineup and their mind-set, and to push aside several days worth of tough emotions Wednesday. The evening ended with their first good feelings of the week. The Knicks rallied around Jamal Crawford and Zach Randolph, fought off a late charge by the Nets and left the Izod Center with a 100-93 victory -- their first road victory in eight games this season.

The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about the hedge fund manager William Ackman's pursuit of MBIA Inc., a holding company whose main subsidiary is the nation's largest bond insurer, misstated his forecast about the company's financial health. Mr. Ackman predicted the company could be bankrupt by the second quarter of 2008, not by February. The article also referred incorrectly to the company's liabilities. It has $80 million in annual debt service, not in corporate debt.

IF outdoor enthusiasts could design the perfect jacket, it might be something like this: it would have the wind-stopping power of a stiff jacket, feel like a snugly fleece and look like something that would pass muster on the streets of Aspen. This season, more manufacturers have made this jacket a reality. Windproof jackets aren't new, but creating one that is streamlined, breathable and drapes well is a delicate proposition. By incorporating thin membranes from Gore or Polartec between the outer and inner layers, the latest crop of jackets prevent wind from permeating while letting sweat escape.

Forgive the young children of John Edwards of North Carolina if they're not hip to the latest plotlines on ''Hannah Montana.'' ''Beyond U.N.C. games,'' Mr. Edwards, of North Carolina, wrote recently in response to a survey on children's media, ''watching television isn't a favorite pastime in our house.''

Hank Steinbrenner has not attended the winter meetings, but his voice is among the most powerful here. Absent from the Yankees' media guide a year ago, he is now the final authority on matters related to the marquee team in the major leagues. There have been no prepared statements from the principal owner, George Steinbrenner, who has ceded control of the team to Hank, 50, and his other son, Hal, 38. There has been little candor from the Yankees at the meetings, but plenty of confidence from Hank Steinbrenner over the telephone.

GRISS--Pauline Wenger, 103, of New York City, died on December 3rd. She was predeceased by her beloved husband, Samuel, and her daughter, Joan Griss Ziegler, and is survived by her daughter, Harriet, four grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. The family thanks Florence Hinds and Lila Watti Kaloo for their loving care. Donations can be made to the Visiting Doctors Program of Mount Sinai Hospital.

Johan Santana has not been told to begin shopping for a new place to live in Boston. That may never happen. Not in Boston, New York or anywhere. Santana is still a pitcher for the Minnesota Twins and is still the most-talked-about player available on the trade market. The Mets are hoping to benefit from the stagnant discussions between the Boston Red Sox and the Twins and swoop in and acquire Santana, but that seems to be a long shot. The Red Sox have made proposals centered on pitcher Jon Lester and center fielder Jacoby Ellsbury, but they will not include both in a trade. The Twins are still mulling those three- and four-player packages.

Pierre Paulin, the renowned French designer, was in New York on Monday for the opening of an exhibition of his furniture at the French Embassy's Cultural Services building. It was something of a homecoming for Mr. Paulin, 80, who said he is ''very thankful to the United States'' -- particularly the Museum of Modern Art and American designers like Charles and Ray Eames -- for inspiring him and helping his career. The exhibition includes about a dozen pieces, like his Ribbon chair (right, sold at M2Lcollection.com), and photographs of his circa-1970 renovation of Georges Pompidou's private apartments at the Élysée Palace. Through Jan. 25 at 972 Fifth Avenue (79th Street), (212) 439-1400 or frenchculture.org. ARIC CHEN

VAN SLYCK--Rosemary O'Brien, of Lyme, CT, on December 4, 2007. Beloved wife of Peter Van Slyck, sister of Patricia Shaw (deceased); mother of Charlotte Lyman and Huntington Lyman; stepmother of Katherine Van Slyck, Ashley Schofield, and Nicholas Van Slyck; grandmother of eight. A graduate of Chapin School, she worked as a real estate agent for many years. Service to be held at noon on December 8, 2007, at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, CT. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the American Cancer Society, P.O. Box 22718, Oklahoma City, OK 73123-1718 or the First Congregational Church located on 2 Ferry Road, Old Lyme, CT 06371

BLUM--Linda A., a beloved and loving wife, mother, grandmother and friend, passed away on Wednesday night, November 28, 2007, due to complications from bile duct cancer. She was 60 years old. Linda was born in New York City to Terese and Ernst Bitzer. She married Melvyn H. Blum in 1970 and moved to Houston in 1977. She received her Bachelors degree from St. John's University and her Masters degree from St. Thomas University. She taught Spanish at Goddard Junior High School and St. Mark's Episcopal School. She was a Reading Education Specialist, working with students in Houston and New York. She volunteered for many years in Central Park and was a supporter of the Central Park Conservancy. She lived her life for her family, her friends and her gardens. She appreciated everything in nature: the birds, the flowers, the sky and the earth. She never took any part of life for granted. She treasured every moment on this earth, and she brought love and joy to all who knew her. Linda is survived by her husband, Melvyn Blum; her son, Daniel Blum, and daughter, Amy Cole; her grandson, Brooke Blum; her mother-inlaw, Nancy Blum; her daughter-in-law, Jennifer Blum and son - in - law, David Cole. Friends may make memorial contributions to CanLiv -The Hepatobiliary Cancers Foundation, 331 West 57th Street #

Challenging one of the central pillars of the Bush administration's detention policies, lawyers for a detainee who is charged as Osama bin Laden's driver argued here Wednesday that he should be treated as a prisoner of war and should not be tried by military commission. The military judge at a pretrial hearing of the former driver, Salim Ahmed Hamdan, did not rule on the request but opened the way for the defense to present evidence on the issue at a hearing that is to begin Thursday.

BELSKY--Florence (Florry), was born September 18, 1921 in a walk-up apartment on 4th Street in Manhattan, the daughter of Bachia (Becky) Baer Baerdichefsky and Bernard (Beryl) Belsky. An alumni of the Henry Street Settlement, she began working at 13, supporting her parents and her sister, Estelle Rose. She worked her way through and graduated from Hunter College and Brooklyn Law School. During World War II she worked for the Department of Labor. After the War she returned to Manhattan, where she practiced law for more than 50 years. In the late 1970s Ms. Belsky was appointed a Special Referee of the New York Supreme Court where she remained until her retirement. She was active in Democratic politics. She was an avid traveler and is mourned by friends throughout the world. She was both a teacher and a student at the New School Institute for Retired Professionals, a Mentor for Brooklyn Law School students and a lifelong champion of educational opportunities. Ms. Belsky was foremost a philanthropist. She was a patron of the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Public Library, Ellis Island Wall of Honor and the Metropolitan Museum and many others. She established scholarships at Hunter College, Elderhostel, the New School Institute for Retired Professionals, Julliard School of Music, the Guilio Gari Opera Foundation. She was the founder of the Florence Belsky Charitable Foundation supporting such diverse projects as opera scholarships and children's arts programs to new theatrical productions. She is survived by cousins Morris, Joel, Carole, Sidney, Susan and Jonathan Kramer, Ruth Broch, Debra Moore, Karen and Al Broner and Linda and Aubrey Keller. Family, friends and colleagues throughout the world will miss her wit, her wisdom and her generosity. Memorial Services will be held Thursday December 6th at 7:00pm at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, in Manhattan. BELSKY--Florence. Remi Arts, Inc. and its Board of Directors profoundly mourn the loss of their esteemed friend and benefactress, Florence Belsky. Regina Resnik, President Michael Philip Davis, Vice President

OF TWO MINDS ON SECURITIES Late last year Goldman Sachs began reducing its inventory of mortgages and mortgage securities as concerns grew about a looming meltdown. Even so, Goldman went on to package and sell more than $6 billion of new securities backed by subprime mortgages during the first nine months of this year. A FREEZE ON MORTGAGE RATES The Bush administration reached an agreement with the mortgage industry on a plan to freeze interest rates for up to five years for some of the 2 million homeowners who bought houses using subprime loans. [A1.]

NORTON--Shelley. Brain cancer, December 3, age 51. A tragic loss. Beloved wife of David Krane; daughter of Jeannette Norton, sister of Richard Norton, Sally (Durrell), Shirley (Hanlon), Peggy (Withrow). Brilliant costume designer: Tada!, Journey Company, Wright State. Dedicated professional: ParsonsMeares, ''Cats'', Ringling Bros. Ardent naturalist. Loyal friend. Memorial open-house Saturday December 8, 3p-7p, 116 W. 14th St, #

GALLAGHER--William J., was special Counsel to the Inspector General in the NYS office of Court Administration. Died on December 3, 2007. Bill was with the Office of the Inspector General for the last 20 years. Prior to this he was Director of Administration for the Courts of New York. Bill has also held the position of Deputy Attorney and Chief, Legal Aid Society, Attorney in charge, Legal Aid Society, New York City, from 1974 to 1977. He was a graduate of Fordham University receiving a BS in 1959 . He received his law degree from Brooklyn Law School in 1963. Bill belonged to many outstanding organizations and clubs. He has been a recipient of many awards. One award that he was proud of having received is the Police Department Honor Legion Award for Heroism. Another award he was very proud of was The Man of the Year award presented by the Emerald Society, New York State Courts. Bill had many memorable moments in his life that he was proud of. One of them was the time he worked at the Vacation Camp for the Blind and learned to sign. He was the owner/manager of the famous St. George Hotel Pool for many years in Downtown Brooklyn. Bill is survived by his children Elizabeth, Dawn Marie, Sean, Matthew, his sister Maureen Gallagher and aunt Alice Walsh. Wake service will be held at F. G. Guido Funeral home at 440 Clinton St., Brooklyn, NY 11231 on the corner of Carroll, Wednesday 6-9pm, and Thursday 4-9pm. Mass of Christian burial Friday, 9:45am, at St. Charles Borromeo R. C. Church. Interment immediately following at Greenwood Cemetery.

An article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day yesterday about the cultural district planned for the area around the Brooklyn Academy of Music misstated the estimated cost of a planned residential tower and dance center. It is about $85 million -- not $385 million, the amount of all the developments planned for the area.

HARDWICK--Elizabeth. The board, staff and artists of The MacDowell Colony mourn the loss of our dear friend and longtime supporter Elizabeth Hardwick, who served on the MacDowell board of directors since 1980. Elizabeth was a devoted advocate of the colony and a trusted advisor. She delivered her incisive opinions with wit and a ready smile. Our heartfelt condolences to her family. The MacDowell Colony

ROMEROVSKI NEWMAN-Hannah. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of the kind, gentle, caring and beloved daughter of Rose Romerovski and her late, revered husband, Martin, YU Guardians, who have provided major scholarship support and leadership for Stern College for Women, the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS), the Yeshiva University High Schools, & other YU divisions. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her mother Rose, her sister Rebecca (and Dr. Jacob) Rosenbaum and her entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman, YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman, RIETS Board of Trustees

MULCAHY--Eileen, died peacefully at her home in New York on December 5th. She was predeceased by her beloved parents, Alice and Michael Mulcahy and her sister Alice. Visiting at Frank E. Campbell ''The Funeral Chapel'' 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. on Friday December 7th from 3-5pm and from 7-9pm. A memorial mass will be held at a later date.

It took only about 10 minutes for Officer Rafael Lora of the New York City police to be arraigned yesterday on a charge that he illegally killed an unarmed man while investigating a car accident outside his home this spring. Dressed in a dark suit and tie, the officer stood and listened as a prosecutor told a judge in State Supreme Court in the Bronx that the fatal shooting had ''no justification.'' He pleaded not guilty to first-degree manslaughter and quickly left.

Maybe it isn't so sweet to be this week's news media sweetheart. Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor who is seeking the Republican presidential nomination, had an embarrassing moment on the campaign trail, his first since sprinting up in the Iowa polls.

Updated, Dec. 9 | Two brothers who worked together as window-washers fell from the roof of a 45-story luxury apartment building on the Upper East Side of Manhattan around 10:15 a.m. today when the scaffold they were standing upon gave way. One brother was killed immediately, and the other was in critical condition at the Weill Cornell Medical College of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, according to the Fire Department.

For public officials interested in running for mayor, there seems to be a ritual these days of presenting policy speeches at breakfasts run by the Association for a Better New York. And today, it was United States Representative Anthony D. Weiner’s turn.

If you’re decking the halls on Long Island this season, make sure those boughs of holly are chained down. A man walked around his neighborhood with a shopping cart and filled it with holiday decorations stolen from several neighbors in Brentwood, according to the Suffolk County Police who arrested the man, Pedro Fournier, this morning. Mr. Fournier, 47, of Brentwood, had holiday lights and ornaments including a snowman, reindeer and tree, said the police, who responded to a 911 call at 7:38 a.m. The neighbors identified the stolen property.

A construction worker died this afternoon in the Bronx after his head got pinned between the side of a dump truck and the rear end of a backhoe around 12:45 p.m. today, according to city officials and a hospital spokesman.

The pilot of Freedom, a ferry that served Alcatraz, blogs about his journey from San Francisco to New York, where the ferry will be used for transportation to Liberty Island starting in 2008. Circle Line lost the contract to Hornblower Cruises and Events. [Ferry Pilot’s Blog]

Joseph S. Hydrusko was a 22-year-old Navy seaman, working on board a hospital ship, the U.S.S. Solace, at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, on Dec. 7, 1941. He was helping to paint the vessel when six planes flew overhead; he assumed they were American planes flying ahead of a carrier. Instead, the planes began to drop bombs. Hundreds of Japanese planes followed them. Mr. Hydrusko rowed over to save wounded and dying men from the U.S.S. Oklahoma, a battleship that was sunk that day.

Former President Bill Clinton and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg joined the federal housing secretary this morning in the Bronx to announce a wide-ranging plan to help New York City’s public housing system — the nation’s largest, with 2,600 buildings and 408,000 residents — reduce emissions of the greenhouse gases that contribute to global warming. In what the officials called a “first-ever sustainability partnership,” the New York City Housing Authority will put into place an array of plans to make its properties more environmentally friendly by reducing energy use.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is about to travel to Asia for a series of meetings culminating in a speech next Friday before the United Nations Frameworks of Convention for Climate Change Conference in Bali, Indonesia. In his weekly radio call-in program this morning, the mayor said that he hoped to use the forum to draw attention to the pronounced health effects of global warming in big cities.According to an itinerary released by City Hall, Mayor Bloomberg is to spend two days in Beijing, one in Shanghai and two in Bali. On Monday, he will participate in the China-United States Innovation Conference in Beijing; meet with the United States ambassador, Clark T. Randt Jr., and Cheng Siwei, vice chairman of the National People’s Congress; and attend a dinner run by the Chinese People’s Institute of Foreign Affairs. On Tuesday, Mr. Bloomberg will speak at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences in Beijing.

You're inundated with calls from campaigns if you live in Iowa or New Hampshire right now. But if you're a Democrat, it might be harder for you to hang up without feeling guilty. A new survey by the Pew Research Center and The Associated Press found that while the vast majority of likely voters in those states have received automated voice messages, or "robo-calls," registered Democrats are significantly more likely to have received a campaign pitch from a real, live person.

With the artists and other creative types that used to call Prenzlauer Berg home slowly getting priced out of the neighborhood, places like the Weinerei are welcome holdouts. A wine bar that's based on the honor system, the Weinerei at Zionskirchplatz (map) has a charming, if naively misplaced, faith in mankind's honesty. For the price of one euro, you "rent" yourself a glass and get to sample as many of the wines as you want. At the end of the night you throw some bills or coins into a big jar, the amount based on how much you think you spent.

In a year that has proved volatile for hedge fund returns, November appears to be one of the down months -- except for one investment strategy.

For the second year in a row, the pool at The Raleigh is proving too inviting to resist. At Jeffrey Deitch's late-night party, there were so many skinny-dipping galleristas that the scene resembled a Spencer Tunick photo Turns out the ripped-from-the-Colosseum Roman soldiers clanking around town are not here for a sword-and-sandals convention but to hype a freshman fair, Roma Contemporary, making its debut in February It seems there's safety in numbers at this year's fair. More and more dealers are sharing spaces, forging "Survivor"-like alliances to avoid being voted off next year, when the fought-after spots are reassessed by the new regime. Mary Boone and Rafael Jablonka from Cologne have the smartest set-up: a room each to do with as they will and a third make-nice space for Eric Fischl, the one artist the two galleries share Massive steroid-charged artwork is not limited to the main fair. It also gets a workout at Pulse, where there is a courtyard stocked with jacked-up sculptures by Jurgen Mayer, Chris Larson and the tattooist-cum-fine artist Duke Reilly. Reilly's work is a replica of a revolutionary war submarine called the "Turtle," which in truth looks more like an old whisky barrel. The larkish Reilly submerged his work in the Hudson River early this year and "attacked" the QM2, an offence which got him arrested (the $120,000 tag for the piece includes a video of his capture) It's not just the wholesale appropriation trend that is trying the patience of gallerists. As the circuit hits 23 fairs and counting, FedEx and other couriers cannot handle the volume of art that's zipping round the world. Galleries will soon have to find alternative methods, with many acknowledging that delivery delays have been worse than ever. Some shipments failed to arrive. For the first day, Berlin's Galerie Michael Schultz had to make do with a minimalist set up of two canvases (the rest of the booth showed up last night); while a Danish gallery canceled completely when they received word that its shipment wouldn't make it in time. That was good news for on person at least: the booth-less Aussie art collective The Glue Society was promoted into the space to exhibit its waggish light boxes, which show satellite images of what appear to be ancient Biblical scenes. Divine intervention?
Arraignments do not, by their nature, produce compelling television. There are no arguments and no testimony and no witnesses.

At least six of the eight late-night television hosts who have stayed off the air during the writers' strike are paying the salaries of their nonwriting staff members, Bill Carter notes in today's Times. The diplomats and officials gathered in Bali to shape talks leading to a new climate treaty are beginning to feel the heat. In public conference rooms and private hotel suites, they are (in theory at least) trying to prepare a two-year "road map" for updating the faltering 1992 Framework Convention on Climate Change, the world's first experiment in common action to limit global warming.
I have every right to be cranky.

One of the quirkier twists for the Rangers this season has been the presence of Brandon Dubinsky as the first-line center between Jaromir Jagr and Martin Straka. The Rangers went out this offseason and spent $14 million on centers Chris Drury and Scott Gomez, only to have neither of them centering their top line and instead handing the job to a 20-year-old rookie.

It seems to be open season on Eddie Lampert. The hedge-fund firm he runs, ESL Investments, has already taken some big hits this year, and now Herb Greenberg, the MarketWatch columnist, has selected him for that dubious annual honor: "Worst C.E.O. of the Year."

The Associated Press is reporting that Syria has blocked its citizens' access to the popular Facebook social networking web site. No official reason has yet been given, but the A.P. report suggests that it may have to do with Damascus worrying that Israelis were using the site to somehow infiltrate Syrian social networks.

India's auto market is growing fast, and drivers will soon be able to go faster, too. On Wednesday, the national government raised the speed limit on private cars to 100 kilometers an hour from 80 -- roughly, to 60 miles an hour from 48. Commercial traffic and vehicles carrying eight or more passengers will be held to lower limits. The higher speed limits would not apply to city streets, but on the country's growing highways.
