Fred D. Thompson may not campaign very much, but when he does, he can expect a crowd in South Carolina: protesters who are angry over his disapproval of the public display of the Confederate flag.
Ted Conover's most recent book is "Newjack: Guarding Sing Sing."

On Oct. 12, retired Lt. Gen. Ricardo S. Sanchez, the former top military commander of American forces in Iraq, delivered a scathing denunciation of the Bush administration's "incompetent" management of the war - and an equally blistering denunciation of the news media.
Judging by the two companies' stock prices on Friday, it seems shareholders are tuning out Macrovision's $2.8 billion offer for Gemstar-TV Guide International.
The Rutgers Coach Greg Schiano met with his team at 7 a.m. on Friday morning to inform them that he was not taking the head coaching position at the University of Michigan.
On Wednesday night, it felt like a sizable portion of Wall Street had moved uptown.
The Fox competition "American Idol" proved its musical value again on Thursday, as three "Idol" alums picked up Grammy Award nominations.

Writing at Balkinization, the group legal blog, Georgetown law professor Marty Lederman criticizes two Democrats in Congress who knew about the C.I.A.'s destruction of interrogation videotapes. "Jay Rockefeller claims that the Intel Committees were not 'consulted' on the use of the tapes 'nor the decision to destroy the tapes.' But he does not deny that he was informed of the agency's intent to dispose of the tapes, and he acknowledges that he learned of the destruction one year ago, in November 2006," Lederman writes. He continues:
The employment report today is not impressive. But it almost certainly is overstated.

Those of you who have traveled lo these many miles with the Bagger know that when it comes to films, he is basically a homer, through and through. He loves them all, even when he doesn't, in part because he understands just enough about the process to know that simply getting a film made is the equivalent of juggling chainsaws and new-born babies. The benefit of the doubt is always stipulated.

The Bagger stole a couple of Daily Variety's out of the shop to catch up on real, industrial-grade news and found himself in receipt of a bunch of music. There, salted amid the For Your Consideration ads and all sorts of people ankling hither and yon, were a bunch of CD's. Just this week, the haul included "Le Fistin" from "Ratatouille," the original score from "Eastern Promises," and the score for "Atonement."

In a world where two billion people still squint by the light of a kerosene lamp (at best) at night, any kind of electrical illumination is a gift beyond measure. But as long as coal is a big source of electricity, finding efficient, cheap, usable alternatives to the incandescent bulb will be a vital enterprise, experts say.

So there the Bagger was, surfing along in search of balls of lint he could leverage into blog items, when he checked in at Awards Daily. It listed some significant ommisions -- "American Gangster," "'Before the Devil Knows You're Dead," "Charlie Wilson's War" -- in the National Board of Review's ten best list this year, before offering someone else's smart, historical take on that organization's picks.
Mitt Romney's religious speech is being dissected and reviewed, with some of his rivals weighing in on his decision to address how his religious beliefs would affect his presidency.

Whatever their brains may tell them, human hearts are strongly prone to read meaning and intention into what happens around them, and not be satisfied with "coincidence" as an explanation. It's just natural to anthropomorphise.
In this week's reading, I stumbled onto a few articles all having to do with the way our career choices can affect our well-being, physically, mentally and emotionally.
Bear Stearns said on Friday that shareholder Joseph Lewis raised his stake in the company to 8.01 percent.

Digital security company Macrovision said on Friday it agreed to buy Gemstar-TV Guide in a cash-and-stock deal worth about $2.8 billion, a move that it says will help speed up the delivery of home entertainment services.

House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Charles Rangel agreed to drop a proposed tax increase on "carried interest," a measure bitterly opposed by the private equity and hedge fund industries, from hotly disputed tax legislation. "Score one for the barbarians," The New York Post wrote, noting the intense lobbying from the largest buyout firms that helped defeat the measure, at least for now.
With a week to go before the News Corporation takes control of Dow Jones & Company, there are already management changes under way at the top of Dow Jones -- and Rupert Murdoch's empire itself.

British investment group Olivant came forward with a detailed rescue offer for mortgage lender Northern Rock on Friday as J.C. Flowers, the American private equity firm, reportedly pulled out of the bidding process.
This is described on YouTube as a Ukrainian Army recruitment ad:
MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

Investors in real estate partnerships evade billions of dollars in federal taxes each year, even though detecting this type of cheating is easy, a former specialist in partnerships for the Internal Revenue Service said Thursday.
The founder of the company took in more than half a billion dollars by selling most of his stock to the public. Three weeks later, the company fell apart.
Back when Hillary Clinton described Dick Cheney as Darth Vader, a number of people pointed out that this was an unfair comparison. For example, Darth Vader once served in the military.

Morgan Stanley plans an investment banking joint venture with China Fortune Securities, one of the country's oldest brokers, to expand its business and win clients in the fastest-growing major capital market, Reuters reported Friday citing unnamed sources.
It's beginning to feel a lot like Spitzer.
From Consumerist.com:

The credit squeeze has forced HarbourVest, one of the biggest private equity fund of funds, to scale back its initial public offering of a new fund, which started trading on Thursday on NYSE Euronext in Amsterdam, The Financial Times reported.
Morgan Stanley's two new co-presidents, Walid Chammah and James Gorman, disclosed in regulatory filings that they own a combined total of more than $57 million worth of the investment bank's shares.

Vikram Pandit's star has been rising ever since he joined Citigroup in July. But Old Lane Partners, the hedge fund that he co-founded and that Citigroup bought earlier this year, hasn't enjoyed the same kind of success, according to Dow Jones.

Genzyme's stock fell slightly Thursday after the biotech company's chief executive, Henri Termeer, said he had no interest in selling the company, despite speculation that billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, who owns stock in the company, could push it to find a buyer.

In one of the largest corporate pay give-backs ever, William W. McGuire, the former chief executive of UnitedHealth Group, has agreed to forfeit at least $418 million to settle claims related to back-dated stock options.

Hedge fund asset levels jumped 11 percent in the six months from April to November, while the industry's combined assets under administration have reached the $4 trillion milestone, according to a new survey.

William H. Theodore has posted a thoughtful comment noting Adams's anti-Semitism. Edmund Morris, who wrote the introduction to Modern Library edition of "The Education," described Adams as being "paranoid about Jews," and even his bosom friend, John Hay, once remarked that when Henry "saw Vesuvius reddening ... [he] searched for a Jew stoking the fire." Some of Adams's letters have overtly anti-Jewish observations and descriptions.
NetSuite's dreams of an initial public offering are coming to fruition-with a twist.
Solar installation and distribution startup GroSolar announced Thursday that it secured $10 million in its second round of funding.

Chrysalis Group, a British independent music company long coveted by a number of the major labels including Warner Music Group, has officially put itself up for sale with the hopes of raising as much as $300 million, The New York Post reported.
Emap, the British publisher of Grazia and Heat magazines, agreed to sell its consumer magazine and radio units to Germany's Heinrich Bauer Verlag for 1.14 billion pounds ($2.3 billion).

The owners of hipster music Web site Stereogum, which include former AOL executive Robert Pittman, former MTV digital guru Jason Hirschhorn and founder Scott Lapatine, have signed a deal to flip their equity stakes in the company to BuzzNet.com, The New York Post reported.
The Politico reports on plans to

Cevian Capital, a Swedish investment fund backed by Carl C. Icahn, has bought a stake of nearly 3 percent in Munich Re, the reinsurer, making it the latest activist investor to target a German blue chip, The Financial Times reported.
Not everyone, it seems, is happy about the bidding war for Italian airline Alitalia.
China Railway Group, the world's third-biggest construction company, rose 27 percent in its Hong Kong debut as investors bet the country's investment in transport systems will boost earnings.
Swiss drug firm Roche said Thursday that it will launch a proxy fight in its campaign to acquire the cancer test-kit maker Ventana Medical Systems.
The federal government Thursday approved Finnish cell-phone maker Nokia's $8.1 billion acquisition of Chicago-based digital mapmaker Navteq.

Graphite Capital Management, a London-based private equity shop, announced the buyout Thursday of Advent International's outsourced recruitment services business, Alexander Mann Solutions, for 100 million pounds ($205 million).

While the music industry remains perpetually confused in trying to figure out the best ways to make money through digital offerings, there are plenty of entrepreneurs seeking success where the big players have failed, The Deal.com notes.

Florida's state-run investment pool reopened, and local governments quickly withdrew more than $1.1 billion. The pool was frozen last week amid a run that withdrew almost $10 billion because of worries about investments in mortgage-backed securities.
The subprime mortgage lender Delta Financial said Thursday that it planned to file soon for bankruptcy protection, after losses mounted and an agreement to obtain financing fell apart.

While I wish that all I did 24/7 was write about fantasy football, sadly, I have another real job (advertising creative director), one that, because they pay me actual American currency, often requires more attention than I'd like to give it. Translation: I've been living at work night and day this week and, therefore, am unable to give you good people a Week 14 Playoff start-bench edition.
Not since “Thelma & Louise” (1991) and “Free Willy” (1993) has Michael Madsen played someone as huggable as the tragic hero of “Strength and Honor.”
If you were not at the Newport Folk Festival in the ’60s — or, for that matter, if you were — “The Other Side of the Mirror” places you in perfect seats.
For evidence of the role international buyers are playing in Miami's troubled market, look no further than CIMA, the latest tower project on the Miami River from NEO, the local developer.

Playing in front of a goaltender making his N.H.L. debut, the Los Angeles Kings, challenged for offense since their big line went dry, erupted for an octet of goals in an 8-2 win over Buffalo. Mike Cammalleri opened the scoring, with his second in two games. Cammalleri had had the early goal-scoring lead in the N.H.L., but hit a drought and was switched off a line with Dustin Brown and Anze Kopitar. Now he appears to be back, and the line is coming back to life. Brown had two goals in the beat-down of Buffalo.
Serious art lovers can still find moments of transcendence at the contemporary art fair.
A Hong Kong-registered oil tanker leaked 10,810 tons, or 66,000 barrels, of crude oil off South Korea’s west coast.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

There are always a few games during the course of a season that need to get filed into the "Please Disregard, Move on to Next Game" folder. And make no mistake, the Rangers game last night against the Maple Leafs fits that description. Team wide, there were breakdowns or a lack of spark in virtually every area, and Toronto seemed to pounce on every opportunity.
With “The Walker,” the director Paul Schrader likes his decadence ripe and toxic, seeping through the gold-trimmed furniture and into the water supply.
“The Band’s Visit,” the first feature by the Israeli writer and director Eran Kolirin, flirts recklessly with obviousness, cuteness too.
There’s precious little to laugh at in “The Sasquatch Gang,” a sad attempt to board the loser-nerd comedy bandwagon.
By turns clever, impassioned, incoherent and silly, “Revolver,” is a macho parable of a fallen man striving for grace.
As much the chronicle of an era as of a band, “The Holy Modal Rounders ... Bound to Lose” casts an affectionate eye on the kind of hedonism no one is meant to survive.
For most of its 85 minutes “Grace Is Gone,” a small, tender film about contemporary parenthood in wartime, carries off a delicate balancing act.
“Dirty Laundry”is a back-to-your-roots film about a gay African-American named Sheldon who meets a young son (Aaron Grady Shaw) he didn’t know he had.
“The Golden Compass” has many of the virtues of a faithful screen adaptation and many of the predictable flaws.
In “Man in the Chair” Christopher Plummer, an actor typecast nowadays as a suave, smiling cobra, sheds his scales to play a tippling old curmudgeon.
Part tribute, part musical mystery, “ ’Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris” shines an overdue spotlight on a great who got away.
“Atonement” is an almost classical example of how pointless, how diminishing, the transmutation of literature into film can be.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine said that sufficient reforms had been made in the eight years since its troopers were found to be engaging in racial profiling at traffic stops.
A bill that would have drastically increased fuel economy standards stalled as expected in the Senate.
Democratic lawmakers reacted with anger today to the disclosure that the C.I.A. in 2005 destroyed at least two videotapes showing the interrogation of two Qaeda operatives.
The Labor Department report may ease fears of a recession but open the door for more rate cuts from the Fed.
Rutgers Coach Greg Schiano interviewed for the coaching vacancy at Michigan on Wednesday but has yet to receive a job offer, according to a person briefed on the meeting.

Ending a long fight over legal fees for administering a $1.25 billion settlement to Holocaust survivors, United States District Court Judge Frederic Block awarded $3,095,325 yesterday to a lawyer in the case, Burt Neuborne. He and other lawyers had worked pro bono in the 1990s litigating a suit against Swiss banks, accusing them of looting millions of dollars of Jewish assets. A judge placed Mr. Neuborne in charge of follow-up litigation. In 2005, Mr. Neuborne submitted the hours he worked in that phase for payment without setting a price. When two other lawyers in the case opposed any payment to him, Mr. Neuborne valued his services at $5.7 million but discounted the bill to $4.1 million. Later he withdrew the discount. A court magistrate recommended the final figure, Judge Block said.

The police said yesterday that they were justified in shooting 20 times at an unarmed woman who led them on a car chase through northern New Jersey. The woman, Michelle M. Moleti, 34, was at St. Joseph’s Regional Medical Center in Paterson, recovering from six gunshot wounds, said James Avigliano, the Passaic County prosecutor. He said officers fired at the woman when she tried to run them over. The officers who fired the shots were from Clifton, where the chase began, according to Clifton Detective Capt. Robert Rowan. Mr. Avigliano said charges would be filed against Ms. Moleti. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Japan’s revised third-quarter growth downward on Friday, surprising markets that had expected an upward revision, prompting many to suggest it might now be late next year before the Bank of Japan can raise rates.
China said on Thursday that it had demolished the facilities of more than 2,800 rural food makers as part of its effort to crack down on shoddy, fake or substandard food.
The Knicks remained the N.B.A.’s most valuable franchise for the third straight year, according to Forbes magazine. They were valued at $608 million, up 3 percent from 2006.
Jerome Dyson had 16 points and 10 rebounds as host Connecticut defeated Northeastern, 69-60, last night, overcoming a 29-point effort from Matt Janning.
The Rangers’ goalie had his second consecutive dismal outing, and was pulled from the game after giving up four goals in the first two periods.

An article in some editions on Nov. 28 about a hearing on whether WWOR, a New Jersey-based TV station owned by Fox Television Stations, covers New Jersey sufficiently to merit renewal of its broadcast license referred incorrectly to a WWOR video camera that recorded the proceedings. Although there was a piece of masking tape on the camera, it was not in fact covering the letters NY. Fox says that the station’s cameras are labeled My9 and do not have the letters NY on them. (Fox uses “My9NY” as a slogan and as partof its Web site address.).
Duke avenged a loss from March’s N.C.A.A. tournament and snapped a three-game losing streak by beating the Scarlet Knights at home on Thursday.
The Montreal Canadiens scored three goals in the first period Thursday night and beat the host Boston Bruins, 4-2.

Jurors in Somerset County yesterday convicted the former coach of a high school girls basketball team of sexually assaulting a player but acquitted her of the most serious charge, aggravated sexual assault. Pamela Balogh, the former coach at Immaculata High School in Somerville, was found guilty on four counts: aggravated criminal sexual contact, sexual assault, child endangerment and criminal sexual contact. Ms. Balogh faces up to 10 years in prison when she is sentenced. A sentencing date was not set. According to prosecutors, Ms. Balogh had a relationship with a student that went on for more than nine months, beginning in 2004 when the girl was 15. Ms. Balogh resigned in 2005. Compiled by John Sullivan.

The defense lawyer for Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City police commissioner, has accused federal prosecutors of trying to taint the jury pool in his case and said they “irreparably harmed” his ability to get a fair trial. The federal prosecutors, Perry A. Carbone and Elliott B. Jacobson, called the allegations by the lawyer, Kenneth M. Breen, “entirely baseless and unfounded.” The exchange came out in court papers filed by Mr. Breen on Wednesday. In the papers, he asked the judge in the case, Stephen C. Robinson of United States District Court, to order the prosecutors to give him more information so he could respond to the government’s request that Judge Robinson consider disqualifying him from the case. The prosecutors asked the judge to consider the move because they said Mr. Breen could be called as a witness to testify about what the government contends was obstruction by Mr. Kerik in an earlier state case. Judge Robinson ruled yesterday that Mr. Breen was not entitled to the additional information, but he has not ruled on whether to disqualify him.

The New York Civil Liberties Union sued the Police Department yesterday in an attempt to stop its officers from detaining and questioning photographers and filmmakers who take pictures of city landmarks. The suit was filed on behalf of Arun Wiita, 26, a Columbia University graduate student who the civil liberties union said was handcuffed in July after an officer spotted him photographing a Manhattan subway station. The police released Mr. Wiita after about a half hour, and he was never charged with a crime, but he said he was humiliated by the encounter. The civil liberties union said the primary goal of the lawsuit was to push the department to train its officers not to bother law-abiding photographers. Police officials said officers only rarely question people photographing the city’s rail infrastructure and defended the step as necessary for preventing terrorism.

A 23-year-old man suspected in the 2004 shooting death of an off-duty correction officer has been arrested in Ecuador, where he was in a hospital being treated for a gunshot wound, the authorities said yesterday. The man, George Saravanos, who the police said would be brought back to New York today to face charges, is suspected in the killing of the correction officer, Richard Ross, who was shot in a botched robbery attempt outside a hotel in Flushing at 2:30 a.m. on Dec. 4, 2004. Investigators began to suspect Mr. Saravanos was hiding in Ecuador after they learned in 2005 that his father, Andonas Saravanos, was wiring money there. George Saravanos’s arrest by United States marshals in Ecuador was disclosed by the police in New York City.

The third of three brothers was convicted yesterday of gang assault in the beating of a veteran city firefighter returning from a Sept. 11 memorial service last year. On Wednesday, Darrell and Darian Taylor, 26, who are twins, were found guilty of first-degree assault in the attack in Mastic Beach on Firefighter Richard Berkhout, a 13-year veteran. Yesterday, their half brother, Christopher Robinson, who was tried separately, was found guilty in Suffolk County Supreme Court. Firefighter Berkhout, 47, was walking with his wife in Mastic Beach on the evening of Sept. 11, 2006, and yelled to the men to slow their car. The men got out and beat him, prosecutors said.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced the formation yesterday of a state panel to develop strategies to allow all New Yorkers to get access to high-speed Internet service. The panel, the New York State Council for Universal Broadband, will recommend ways to extend high-speed access beyond traditional methods and to extend broadband connections to underserved rural and urban areas, the governor said. The panel will be led by the state’s chief information officer, Melodie Mayberry-Stewart, Mr. Spitzer said.

An Army sergeant from Bergen County was one of three soldiers who died in Iraq after their vehicle was hit by a roadside bomb, the Pentagon announced yesterday. The sergeant, Eric J. Hernandez, 25, of Waldwick, was killed in Baiji on Tuesday. He was a member of the First Battalion, 327th Infantry Regiment, First Brigade Combat Team, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault), based in Fort Campbell, Ky. Sergeant Hernandez joined the Army in October 2003. He is survived by his father, Craig Hernandez of Garnerville, N.Y., and mother, June Augusta of Waldwick.

The Department of Education said yesterday that it would close two elementary schools — Public School 156, the Benjamin Banneker School, in the Bronx, and Public School 304, Casimir Pulaski, in Brooklyn — after both received F’s on the school report cards released last month. The announcement brings to 10 the number of schools scheduled to close so far, with a handful of additional closing announcements expected by early next week. The schools will close at the end of the school year.
The authorities in Omaha scoured surveillance tapes and studied text messages, voice mail and letters that a gunman sent before he killed eight people at a shopping mall.
Starting next week and over the next few months, several United States airlines will test Internet service on their planes.

A chart on Sunday about improvements in Malawi’s agricultural production, using erroneous information from a study by researchers at Imperial College London and Michigan State University, misstated the size of recent corn harvests. (Because of an editing error, the article also included the wrong figures.) The increase in production was in millions of metric tons, not billions. (Estimates show that corn production rose to 2.7 million metric tons in 2006 and 3.4 million in 2007 from 1.2 million in 2005.).
Now that Broadway shows have gone on again, theater owners in Midtown Manhattan have turned their attention back to another way of making money: selling the rights to the air above their roofs.

A man who spent nearly 14 years behind bars for killing a bouncer at the Palladium nightclub in Manhattan was acquitted yesterday by a jury at a second trial, in a case in which he claimed that he and another man had been wrongly convicted while the real killers went free.
The founder of UnitedHealth Group, William W. McGuire, reached a settlement with regulators over the backdating of stock options and will forfeit $418 million in options and retirement benefits.
Two Republican House members resigned from the board supervising teenage pages, accusing a Democratic official of failing to inform them about sexual and criminal activity by at least four pages.
Mortgage experts say that although the exact guidelines of the mortgage rescue plan are still fuzzy, it is clear that many of those who need aid the most will not get it.
The Knicks put aside their locker-room divisions as they consoled a grief-stricken Stephon Marbury at his father’s funeral.

OMAHA, Dec. 6 — To many people who live around Omaha, the Von Maur department store is a special destination for shopping, a retailer and respite at once, offering serenity along with its upscale goods in the Westroads Mall, the largest and busiest in Nebraska.

A man was jailed for failing to take his tuberculosis medication after officials said he was a serious health risk. The man, James R. Pearson, 49, remained at the Pima County Jail on a tuberculosis violation, more than two weeks after the county health department petitioned to have him taken into custody. “He is now being held in isolation,” said Deputy Dawn Hanke, a sheriff’s department spokeswoman. “The court will decide when he will be released.” Mr. Pearson is taking his medication while in custody, the authorities said.

The American Civil Liberties Union released a report claiming a pattern of “gross medical abuse” at Nevada’s maximum-security Ely State Prison and called for a meeting with the governor and the prison director. The report, written by Dr. William Noel, was based on the medical records of 35 prisoners. It said a death row inmate, Patrick Cavanaugh, was denied insulin for three years, which caused him to develop gangrene. Dr. Noel said medical workers left Mr. Cavanaugh “to rot to death.” The report states that another inmate, Charles Randolph, said he was told that he had been taken off a heart medicine because the medicine had “resulted in increased cardiac deaths,” but that he could go back on it “so that your chances of expiring sooner are increased.” The prison director, Howard Skolnik, said the report would be reviewed.

The Roman Catholic Bishop of Los Angeles told the police that he was assaulted by a man who shouted angry statements about the scandal of sexual abuse by members of the clergy but does not plan to file a report. The bishop, Cardinal Roger Mahony, first reported the attack to fellow priests at a gathering in October, but not the police. After new reports of the alleged attack came out this week, the police contacted him. A spokeswoman for the Los Angeles Police Department, Lt. Roger Mora, said Cardinal Mahoney told the police by telephone that he had been dressed in a sports shirt and slacks on an evening in July when a man walked toward him outside Our Lady of the Angels Cathedral downtown, asking in a threatening tone if he was the cardinal. Cardinal Mahony, 71, told the police that the man pushed him to the ground and kicked him before running away.

The Army will establish a top-level command and hire 1,400 new acquisition personnel to improve its contracting operations, senior service officials said, a move that follows heavy criticism over the way supplies and equipment were bought for combat forces. At a Congressional hearing, Claude Bolton, the Army’s top acquisition executive, said the command would be led by a two-star general who would have two one-star deputies. It is expected to take two years to hire the additional 1,400 personnel — 400 military personnel and 1,000 civilians — and 5 to 10 years before they have gained the proper experience, Lt. Gen. Ross Thompson, Mr. Bolton’s deputy, told the Senate Armed Services readiness subcommittee.

Part of a parking deck at a Charlotte shopping mall collapsed, and a motorist who may have caused the accident by crashing into the structure died, the police said. The woman’s car crashed into the edge of the top level of the parking deck at the SouthPark Mall, said Julie Hill, a spokeswoman for the Charlotte-Mecklenburg police. A small part of the three-tier deck then collapsed, and the driver’s car fell through the opening, Ms. Hill said. The woman was pronounced dead at the scene. The authorities said there were no other injuries. Meanwhile, a parking garage under construction in Jacksonville, Fla., partly collapsed, injuring about two dozen people, officials said. One worker was missing.

Two former Milwaukee police officers were each sentenced to more than two years in federal prison for their roles in a racially charged attack involving a group of white off-duty officers. One of the former officers, Jon Clausing, pleaded guilty last year to conspiring to violate the civil rights of the victims, Frank Jude Jr., who is biracial, and Lovell Harris, who is black. The other former officer, Joseph Schabel, admitted stomping on Mr. Jude’s head and kicking him while Mr. Jude was being held down. He had pleaded guilty to depriving Mr. Jude of his civil rights and use of intimidation. Judge J. P. Stadtmueller sentenced Mr. Clausing to 28 months in prison and Mr. Schabel to 32 months.

The Oak Ridge National Laboratory said a “sophisticated cyber attack” over the last few weeks might have allowed personal information about thousands of laboratory visitors to be stolen. The attack appeared “to be part of a coordinated effort to gain access to computer networks at numerous laboratories and other institutions across the country,” the laboratory’s director, Thom Mason, said in a memorandum to the 4,200 employees of the facility, part of the Department of Energy. Laboratory officials said hackers might have infiltrated a database of names, Social Security numbers and birth dates of every laboratory visitor from 1990 to 2004. Officials have sent letters to about 12,000 potential victims. The assault was in the form of phony e-mail messages containing attachments, which when opened allowed hackers to penetrate the laboratory’s computer security.
A behind-the-scenes battle in Congress over fuel economy standards has ended with automakers cheering the rules.
Major League Baseball suspended Jay Gibbons and José Guillén for receiving performance-enhancing drugs, perhaps creating a template for future strategy to pursue steroid users.
With the clock ticking swiftly toward the end of the year and a stack of stalled legislation piling up, little is getting done in the Senate these days. And tempers are starting to boil over.
Several issues stand in the path of a plan to improve subway service by assigning separate managers to individual lines.
Women will be allowed to work as bartenders in New Delhi, India’s Supreme Court ruled, upholding a lower court’s decision that an earlier ban was unconstitutional, local television reports said.
Carlos Gómez and Fernando Martínez — both on the roster for Escogido in the Dominican Republic — could become the outfield equivalent of David Wright and José  Reyes.
Murders, rapes and robberies fell from April through September compared with the same period in 2006.

Samina Malik, a 23-year-old who last month became the first Muslim woman to be convicted of a terrorism offense in Britain, was given a suspended nine-month prison sentence and 100 hours of community service.
The Millennium Challenge Corporation has taken longer than expected to help poor, well-governed countries.
The National Assembly has taken a step toward making the teaching of Mandarin compulsory in all schools, the BBC reported.

The government again sought the power to jail terrorism suspects without charge for up to 42 days, and the proposal brought immediate pledges of defeat from opposition parties and outrage from civil rights groups.
Health workers are among the dead in an Ebola outbreak, spreading panic among doctors and nurses needed to help treat victims of the highly contagious disease, officials said.
Rupert Murdoch’s younger son, James, will step down as chief executive of British Sky Broadcasting to take on a broader role within his father’s media empire.
The Roman Catholic archbishop of Santiago, is seeking an explanation from the government for the reported beating and arrest of dissidents in a parish hall on Tuesday, a spokesman said.

Imax and AMC Entertainment are teaming up to open 100 Imax theaters, doubling the number of large-format 3-D outlets in the United States and adding momentum to Hollywood’s growing interest in the genre.
It was a distressing moment to witness Mitt Romney cowed into defending his faith by a powerful minority determined to impose its religious tenets.
A Congressional conference committee has voted to outlaw the harsh interrogation techniques used by the Central Intelligence Agency against suspected high-level terrorists.
A driver for Osama bin Laden in Afghanistan has been cast by lawyers as a simple, low-level employee but prosecutors say the driver could barely repress his approval of the terror leader.
Jason Kidd said that he did not miss Wednesday night’s game because he was unhappy with the Nets, explaining his absence by saying he had a migraine.

TRENTON, Dec. 6 — Four days before the State Senate is to vote on a bill that would make New Jersey the first state in a generation to abolish the death penalty, the parents of the young girl whose rape and murder led to Megan’s Law urged legislators to oppose the measure.
The measure pushes the issue of taxation to the forefront of the debate over how to compensate the wrongly convicted properly for the years they spent behind bars.
NASA officials delayed the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis at least until Saturday after canceling Thursday’s attempt because of problems with a pair of fuel sensors.
Coca-Cola has set up shop in a virtual world called there.com, creating an island shaped like a Coke bottle where fans can hang out and soar around.
The strike by the Writers Guild has become a serious financial drain for most late-night hosts because they have stepped in to pay the salaries of their nonwriting staff members.
Hunger relief and nutrition programs have been inextricably tied to helping farmers, but recent actions on the farm bill shows that this no longer works.
A proposal to decentralize New York City subway lines is not a throwback to the old days - it is something close to an underground revolution.
A measure to change how California apportions its 55 electoral votes will not be eligible for the June primary ballot, its sponsors said.
The onetime other woman in Hillary Rodham Clinton’s life said that she was undecided but had long wanted to see a female president.
Andrew M. Cuomo has been handing out subpoenas to Wall Street in an effort to find out how banks bought subprime home loans and packaged them into complex securities.
Daniel L. Doctoroff’s departure could signal the twilight of an administration still bursting with grand visions.
The case of a video of a beating on a New York subway car illustrates the power of  the Internet to magnify events that make their way into the public eye.
A battle is being waged for the heart of the American Christmas tree customer, pitting the real evergreen against the once-lowly artificial tree.
The European Central Bank walked a middle ground on Thursday, leaving interest rates unchanged, but across the channel, the Bank of England opted to take action.
Passengers weighed in Thursday on New York City Transit’s plan to decentralize the way it runs the subways in an effort to improve service.

John F. Krimsky Jr., a former top fund-raiser for the United States Olympic Committee, faces child pornography charges in Connecticut. The 68-year-old Krimsky, an executive in the YankeesNets business merger that eventually led to the formation of the YES Network, pleaded not guilty in state court this week to four counts, including promoting a minor in an obscene performance, criminal attempt at possession of child pornography and third-degree possession of child pornography.Investigators seized his home computers and found 329 images that appeared to be child pornography. Some were of children who appeared to be from ages 5 to 15 posing or involved in sexual acts, according to a warrant.
New Medicare rules for a small but promising class of cancer drugs may cause thousands of lymphoma patients to lose access to the treatment.
Only days removed from burying a teammate, and without the benefit of a full practice, the Washington Redskins managed to win thanks to a backup quarterback who last completed a pass in 2004.
Trade talks will continue after baseball’s winter meetings ended Thursday with fewer players switching teams than expected.

The Southeast Missouri State women’s basketball team should lose all 79 of its victories during the four-year tenure of the former coach B. J. Smith, an N.C.A.A. committee has ruled. The Committee on Infractions also decided that Southeast should have its 2006 N.C.A.A. tournament appearance taken away, according to a letter released yesterday. The university is appealing the ruling and has asked for a full hearing.

Louisiana State Coach Les Miles has signed a contract extension that will keep him with the Tigers through 2012. The deal was approved yesterday by the L.S.U. board’s athletic committee, apparently ending any chance of Miles leaving for Michigan to replace Lloyd Carr, who retired last month.

The College of William and Mary’s new logo sheds the two feathers that the N.C.A.A. deemed offensive to American Indians. The logo, revealed yesterday, updates the familiar W&M monogram and uses the school’s more traditional colors of green and gold instead of the more recent green and yellow. Last year, the N.C.A.A. ruled William and Mary could keep its Tribe nickname but could not display its athletic logo with feathers at N.C.A.A. championship events or play host to N.C.A.A. tournament games at which the logo would be shown.

Zach Lund edged his fellow American Eric Bernotas to win the skeleton event on the first day of the Bobsleigh and Skeleton World Cup in Park City, Utah. Lund finished in 1 minute 38.41 seconds, beating Bernotas by .25 of a second. Lund has won the event in Park City two straight years. Michelle Kelly of Canada won the women’s event in 1:40.43.

Robert Byron, the first driver to win a Nascar points championship, is among a diverse group to be inducted into the International Motorsports Hall of Fame. The six-person class of 2008 also includes Art Arfons, Bill Jenkins, Frank Kurtis, Everett Owens and Ralph Seagraves.

Alexandre Vinokourov was barred from cycling for one year for doping. Vinokourov, from Kazakhstan, was barred by his country’s cycling federation, Vinokourov’s former Astana team said in a statement on its Web site. Vinokourov and his Astana teammates were forced out of this year’s Tour de France when he tested positive for a banned blood transfusion.

Renault was not penalized despite being found guilty of having confidential information about its Formula One rival McLaren. In September, McLaren was fined $100 million for using confidential data from Ferrari. In the latest allegations in Formula One’s spy scandal, the World Motor Sport Council summoned Renault officials to face accusations that the team had unauthorized access to details on McLaren’s cars.

500 CLOWN ''Think of Buster Keaton and Chaplin, not Bozo,'' said Adrian Danzig, the producing artistic director of 500 Clown, describing the performance style of his Chicago-based company. ''Clown is a totally dirty word -- no one uses clown in their title,'' he said. ''It sets you up to defend that you're not doing children's work.'' But 500 Clown uses that word in its name and in the titles of back-to-back productions coming to Performance Space 122 this month. And these are not children's shows. ''500 Clown Frankenstein'' and ''500 Clown Christmas'' will each offer an unusual and acrobatic take on a classic story. In ''Frankenstein,'' above, the three clowns (Mr. Danzig, far right, with Paul Kalina and Molly Brennan) try to construct Dr. Frankenstein's laboratory, leading to feats both comic and gymnastic, until things take a harsh turn. When one is forced into the role of the creature, the novel's darker themes begin to surface.

ABC led a close race for No. 1 in the ratings on Wednesday, as the network's 9 p.m. medical show spinoff of ''Grey's Anatomy,'' ''Private Practice,'' delivered 10.4 million viewers, Nielsen estimated, and the night's top ratings among adults 18 to 49. ABC also led the 8 o'clock hour in that demographic with its holiday special ''Santa Claus Is Comin' to Town'' (9.4 million). NBC, meanwhile, finished first for the night in total viewers and second to ABC in the 18-to-49 set, largely because of a two-hour edition of ''Deal or No Deal'' from 8 to 10 (11.5 million). In the 10 o'clock hour, NBC's ''Life'' was second (7.6 million), ahead of ABC's ''Dirty Sexy Money'' (6.9 million) but behind CBS's ''CSI: NY'' rerun (10.3 million). CBS was third over all in the 18-to-49 demographic, earning modest numbers in that age group from ''Kid Nation'' at 8 (7.2 million) followed by a repeat of ''Criminal Minds'' at 9 (9.4 million). Fox finished fourth with repeats.

An article on Nov. 29 about the Nixon administration's alarm over Israel's nuclear weapons program described incorrectly the process that prompted the Richard Nixon Presidential Library and Museum to release previously classified documents. The release was the result of declassification requests by researchers at the National Security Archive of George Washington University and elsewhere; it was not because of a regulation requiring review and possible declassification of documents after 25 years.

BERGTRAUM--Howard . It is with tremendous sorrow that we announce the passing of esteemed O'Melveny & Myers LLP partner, Howard Bergtraum, at the age of 61 after a difficult battle with cancer. Howard was loved and admired as a partner, mentor, advisor and friend who will be sorely missed. As co-head of our Private Equity Fund practice and member of the Tax and Transactions practice, Howard was a force in the profession and within our Firm. He was recognized by both his peers and various publications as one of the premier attorneys in these fields. In addition to being a brilliant lawyer, Howard was a man of decency, character, and effortless compassion. He was a committed husband, dedicated father, loving brother, and proud uncle. He was a central figure and role model to his family, and generous with his time and unparalleled knowledge. Our heartfelt condolences and sympathy go to Howard's wife Susan, their three children, Jordan, Matthew and Andrea, his sisters Judy and Marcia and his son and daughter-in-law, Jared and Randi. For those who wish to make a donation to the fund Howard's family has set up, donations may be made to Queens College Foundation/ Howard Bergtraum Fund.

FOR CHILDREN 'AMAHL AND THE NIGHT VISITORS' (Tomorrow) A disabled boy offers the baby Jesus the gift of his crutches in this 1951 opera by Gian Carlo Menotti, which has become a Christmas favorite. The Little Orchestra Society's annual production features not only the child, the Magi and the other star players, but also live animals onstage. At 11 a.m. and 1 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 971-9500, littleorchestra.org; $10 to $40.

Supporters of Mumia Abu-Jamal, a black journalist convicted of killing a Philadelphia police officer in 1981, assembled outside the ''Today'' studio yesterday morning during a television appearance by Maureen Faulkner, the murdered officer's widow. Mrs. Faulkner's new book, ''Murdered by Mumia: A Life Sentence of Loss, Pain and Injustice'' (the Lyons Press), lays out the case against Mr. Abu-Jamal, known for his death-row writings on racial and social justice. Mrs. Faulkner appeared yesterday on the program to promote the book with her co-author, the radio talk show host Michael Smerconish. Police promptly corralled the protesters into a metal barricaded pen across the street from the Rockefeller Center studio. As the segment on the book was broadcast, NBC briefly showed the protest live on a split screen alongside Mrs. Faulkner. The case is before the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia.

Designed with horse lovers in mind, this 1,650-square-foot house in Galena Territory is offered furnished and is decorated with a western motif. It is on more than two acres zoned for horses and is near the Territory's riding center. Agent: Jon Checker, Coldwell Banker Network Realty, (877) 722-6537; www.coldwellbanker.com/for/network.realty.

An article in The Arts yesterday about the photographer Jim Krantz and his views on the use of some of his pictures made for Marlboro advertisements by the artist Richard Prince referred incorrectly to the copyrights for his pictures. While the copyrights for his Marlboro photographs are owned by Philip Morris, Mr. Krantz retains the copyrights to most of his work; his clients do not generally own the rights.

Beloved wife of Peter Van Slyck, sister of Patricia Shaw (deceased); mother of Charlotte Lyman and Huntington Lyman; stepmother of Katherine Van Slyck, Ashley Schofield, and Nicholas Van Slyck; grandmother of eight. An article in Week in Review on Sunday about an increase in the Senate's use of the filibuster referred incorrectly to the American Enterprise Institute, one of whose members commented on the filibuster. The institute is a conservative research group based in Washington; it is not a nonpartisan group. (The error was repeated on Wednesday in an article comparing the health care proposals of Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama.)

WOLFSON--Norman L. , of Pt. Pleasant, NJ, died Wednesday, December 5th at the age of 85. Born October 4th, 1922, in Newark, NJ, Mr. Wolfson served in the U.S. Navy during WWII. In the late 1940s, he began a lifelong communications career as a columnist for the Newark Evening News. He then served as Administrative Assistant to the late Representative Robert W. Kean, of New Jersey, father of former Governor Thomas Kean. In the 1980s, Mr. Wolfson retired from a successful career in public relations during which he advised heads of corporations as well as heads of state. He went on to author several books, and his writings have been published in magazines and newspapers, including The National Review and The New York Times. For the past two years, Mr. Wolfson's weekly column, Life's Moments, ran in the Parker syndicate of newspapers, of Morris County, NJ. He is survived by two sons, Thomas of Del Mar, CA, and Michael of Brooklyn, NY, a daughter, Amy Bigerna of South Orange, NJ, and two grandchildren. Services will be held Saturday, December 8th at 9:00am at Van Hise & Callaghan Funeral Home, Pt. Pleasant Beach, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the A.L.S. Association or The Humane Society.

Bang on a Can, the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, Harlem Stage and the Museum of the Moving Image are among the 16 organizations chosen to receive the first grants, ranging from $50,000 to $250,000, from the Rockefeller Foundation's $2.6 million New York City Cultural Innovation Fund to promote new directions in the arts.

A J. M. W. Turner watercolor masterpiece, above, unseen in public for nearly 120 years, was sold to an unidentified American collector for $5.9 million at an auction late on Wednesday at Sotheby's in London, the BBC reported. The painting, dating from the 1830s, was last seen in public 17 years after it was bought in 1872 by the Earl of Dudley. It eventually was sold to the Vanderbilt family and passed through generations before being placed on the open market for the first time in 135 years. The watercolor depicts Bamborough Castle, perched on an outcrop at the edge of the North Sea, during a storm that has driven a ship onto the rocks.

TONER--Dr. Lisa Marie , 41, died December 4, 2007 in New York City. She was born on December 4, 1966. Funeral services will be held December 7 at the College of Mount St. Vincent in the Bronx with graveside rites in Leesport, PA, on Saturday, December 8. She is survived by her parents, Hugh and Carol Toner, Leesport, PA, her brother and sister-in-law, her nephew, Hugh, aunts, uncles,and cousins. One brother preceded her in death. Dr. Toner was a member of the faculty and former department chair of the English Department at Tri-State University where she taught technical writing, international communication, and English courses. She also taught at Wheeling Jesuit University and at the University of Kentucky. She attended the College of Mount St. Vincent in New York City, receiving her B.A. in 1989. She received her Ph.D. from Purdue University in Rhetoric and Composition in 1996. She presented her academic research at national conferences. She loved animals and was interested in drama and Irish music and culture. Condolences may be sent to the Toner family, 269 Gernants Church Rd., Leesport, PA 19533. Memorial donations may be sent to The Lymphoma Foundation, PO Box 286236, New York, NY 10128-0012 (LymphomaFoundation.org).

After performing for 25 years in dimly lighted bars in the Philippines, Arnel Pineda, 40, has been hired as the new singer for the 1980s rock band Journey. The band's guitarist, Neal Schon, was impressed by footage of Mr. Pineda performing Journey covers on YouTube and flew him to California for an audition. He is Journey's third vocalist since Steve Perry left in the late '90s; Mr. Pineda replaces Jeff Scott Soto, who departed earlier this year. ''It'll be a lot of hard work on my part, and I'm actually looking forward to the scrutiny I'll get from the hard-core Journey fans,'' Mr. Pineda, who also fronts the Manila band the Zoo, said in a statement. ''I know they'll expect me to sound exactly like the voice,'' he added, referring to Mr. Perry's, ''but that will never happen. I know there's only one Steve Perry in this world.'' Journey is working on an album with Mr. Pineda, and the band is scheduled to tour early next year.

Kiefer Sutherland, below, who plays the dashing federal counterterrorism agent Jack Bauer on the Fox television drama ''24,'' reported to the Glendale, Calif., city jail yesterday after being sentenced to 48 days on his plea of no contest in October to driving with a blood alcohol level above the legal limit of .08, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Sutherland, 40, was already on probation for a 2004 drunken-driving arrest when he was halted by the police as he left a Hollywood party at the Area nightclub on Sept. 25. Assistant City Attorney Dan Jeffries said that under the terms of Mr. Sutherland's plea, he must also serve five years of probation, pay a $510 fine, enroll in an alcohol-education class and attend weekly alcohol-therapy sessions for six months.

An article and a subheading in some editions on Monday about the retrial of David Lemus in connection with a 1990 homicide at the Palladium nightclub referred imprecisely to the prosecution's case. The theory that there were three gunmen is not in fact a new one. The transcript of Mr. Lemus's 1992 trial shows that the prosecution referred to a possible third gunman in closing arguments.

DALY--Donald Francis , of Bryn Mawr, PA, passed away on December 5, 2007 at the Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 79. Son of the late Christopher and Anne Kelleher Daly, he was born in Bridgeport, CT, in 1928. Donald was a Captain U.S. Army (Ret.) serving during the Korean War. He received a Distinguished Service Cross, Purple Heart and two Bronze Stars with ''V'' for Valor. He was a graduate of Yale University, class of 1950. He worked as a Vice President for Scudder, Stevens & Clark in New York, NY; was a partner in Brundage, Story & Rose in New York, NY, and later was an Executive VicePresident of Mellon Bank in Philadelphia. Donald was the beloved husband of Sandra Godfrey Daly. Devoted father of Candace D. Scottow and Jacqueline D. Valicenti of Charleston, SC, Elizabeth D. de Verteuil of France, Patrick K. of Louisville, KY, Samuel R. of Bryn Mawr and the late Jennifer A. Daly. Loving brother of Russell J. Daly of Washington, D.C. He is also survived by seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Funeral services are private with a memorial service to follow at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Planned Lifetime Assistance Network of Pennsylvania (PLAN of PA), 110 W. Lancaster Ave., Wayne, PA 19087.

Calling all state workers in New Mexico: Gov. Bill Richardson -- who hopes to be President Bill Richardson -- needs your help. The Richardson campaign is asking government appointees and state employees to travel to Iowa over the holidays to knock on doors and speak on behalf of Mr. Richardson, a Democrat.

FILATOV--Geri Brown . We mourn the death of Geri. She lived her life with grace and dignity. 'IMPERMANENT COLLECTION' Going to look at art in a museum usually produces immediate impressions: ''I hate it,'' ''I love it,'' ''I don't get it.'' Then we move on -- apparently the average time spent looking at a work of art is five seconds. Watching a performance, on the other hand, demands that we accept a slower accrual of thoughts and feelings during an event; we know -- in fact, we hope -- that our first and last impressions could be very different. In ''Impermanent Collection,'' to be performed tonight and next Friday as part of the Whitney Museum of American Art's Whitney Live series, the Moving Theater directors Brennan Gerard and Ryan Kelly use five dancers, the new-music group International Contemporary Ensemble and a series of videos by Brock Labrenz to blur the boundaries between those experiences: permanence and impermanence, art object and live performance, the historical and the contemporary.

'MAGIC, MUSIC, AND EARLY MOVIES' When Brian Selznick was writing ''The Invention of Hugo Cabret,'' he was warned that the premise was less than promising. ''Someone said, 'You're writing a book for kids about silent French films?''' he recalled. '''That sounds terrible.''' Fortunately, readers didn't agree. This ''novel in words and pictures,'' published by Scholastic last winter, became a children's best seller. Set in Paris in 1931, it centers on the adventures of its title character, a 12-year-old orphan solving a mystery involving his own past and that of the cinema -- specifically the work of the early French filmmaker Georges Méliès. The novel teems with cinematic references, and this weekend Mr. Selznick will visit the Museum of the Moving Image for its ''Magic, Music, and Early Movies,'' a festival including an ''Invention of Hugo Cabret'' celebration.

Last week, for the first time since Hurricane Katrina overwhelmed the news airwaves two years ago -- and for the first time sinceTed Koppel retired from network television shortly thereafter -- ABC's ''Nightline'' drew more viewers in a week than ''The Tonight Show With Jay Leno'' and ''Late Show With David Letterman,'' according to Nielsen estimates released yesterday by ABC. ''Tonight'' and ''Late Show'' were in repeats last week, casualties of the Hollywood writers' strike, but the ratings for ''Nightline'' were nonetheless a milestone in the post-Koppel era. ''Nightline'' drew an average of 4 million viewers each night last week, about a half million, or 14 percent, more than Mr. Leno (3.5 million) and nearly a million, or 30 percent, more than Mr. Letterman (3.1 million), Nielsen estimated. Figures provided by ABC show that over all, the viewership of ''Nightline'' was up 4 percent over the same week last year, while that of ''Tonight'' was down 43 percent, and that of ''Late Show'' 30 percent. James Goldston, the executive producer of ''Nightline,'' said, ''I guess the test will be whether we can keep it up once the strike ends.'' Even with the strike, the viewership of ''Nightline'' lagged behind that of ''Tonight'' during the recently concluded November sweeps, Nielsen figures from ABC showed. But ''Nightline'' did overtake ''Late Show'' and attract its biggest November audience since 2004.

'ADEL ABDESSEMED: DEAD OR ALIVE' For more than a century, artists have given up on idealization, the dominant aesthetic vision at least since the Renaissance. Instead of showing us what we could be, artists have reflected back to us an imperfect image of who we are and the world in which we live. This shifting attitude has resulted in a variety of artwork that is troubling, ugly and rooted in the baser instincts of human nature, as demonstrated by the Algerian-born artist Adel Abdessemed in his first solo New York exhibition, now at P.S.1 Contemporary Art Center. It is a rough ride consisting of sculpture and video that will test even the most hardened contemporary-art aficionado, and it begins with a video close-up of a cat tearing up and eating a street mouse. This is followed by another video of a man putting a snake in his mouth, though the tape cuts out at this point, and you never see what happens next.

A chart on Sunday about improvements in Malawi's agricultural production, using erroneous information from a study by researchers at Imperial College London and Michigan State University, misstated the size of recent corn harvests. (Because of an editing error, the article also included the wrong figures.) The increase in production was in millions of metric tons, not billions. NEW YORK ANIME FESTIVAL This celebration of Japanese anime culture -- the first of what's planned to be an annual event -- is intended to be even more interactive than most pop culture conventions. The festival, to be held this weekend at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, includes exclusive screenings, autograph signings, video games, live-action Japanese cinema and panel discussions. ''There are a lot of anime events across the country, but New York has a void,'' said John P. McGeary, a show manager with Reed Exhibitions, which organized this festival as well as the New York Comic Con. Appreciation of anime also ''gets so much deeper than what you can do at a comic-based show,'' he said. That deeper interaction includes cosplay -- costume play -- in which fans dress up and act as their favorite characters. Tonight die-hard cosplayers will compete at a masquerade in which registered teams will show off their outfits for a chance to win a photo spread in Anime Insider and a trip to Japan to represent the United States in the World Cosplay Summit Championships. Another chance at fame comes with ''Who Wants to Be a Voice Actor?'' The winner of this three-round open audition (Sunday at 12:30) will receive a paid acting role in a forthcoming production from NYAV Post or TripWire Productions, the two biggest anime dubbing studios in New York.

KARPEL--Sylvia , died peacefully at her home in the Bronx on December 5th. Born in 1917 in New York City, She was a devoted daughter to Minnie and Louis Rubin and a loving sister to Martha and Phyllis. She shared 54 years with Kermit Karpel whom she married in 1939. The beloved mother of Kenneth and his partner Ira Rosenblum, Sylvia was embraced by their friends as well, who were drawn to her vitality and wisdom. Sylvia earner her B.A. at Hunter College at night while working at Macy's. She was justifiably proud of her teaching career at PS99 Bronx where in addition to commitment to her pupils, she ultimately trained many of the young inexperienced teachers that had joined the system because of the war in Vietnam. After retiring she volunteered in neighborhood schools and taught adults English as a second language. She had a lifelong love of language and words. Travels to Europe, Israel, North Africa and throughout the US with Kermit fed her perpetual curiosity and desire to learn. Sylvia loved her time at the bridge table, but more than the game, she treasured her friends with whom she shared this time. We mourn her death and celebrate her life, she is survived by her sister Phyllis, a foster sister Harriet, her son Kenneth and his partner Ira, and her nieces and nephews Roslyn, Lewis, Gary, Lauren, Karen, Joel, and Andrea. Funeral services will be held on Sunday December 9th at 2:00pm at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. in Manhattan. Following services, family and friends are invited to gather at Kenneth and Ira's 240 West 98th St, Apt 13F where Shiva will be observed.

SHALEN--Robert Ellis , died peacefully in Boca Raton after a brief illness, on December 5, 2007, at the age of 90 (but way too soon). He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Marcia Heatter Shalen; their daughter Cynthia Willett and her husband Thomas of Claremont, California; their son Peter Shalen and his wife Catherine of Chicago, Illinois; their son Stephen Shalen and his wife Wendy of Waccabuc, New York; grandchildren Samantha, Luke, David, Eve and her husband Moshe; great - granddaughters Abi gail, Miriam and Judith; and his sister Jean Moscow of New York City and Putnam Valley. Bob's brother Howard died earlier this year at his home in Sebastopol, California. After graduating from Boys High in Brooklyn, Bob was in the class of 1937 at Harvard, where he was a member of the Glee Club, was elected to phi beta kappa in his junior year and was graduated summa cum laude in mathematics. In World War II, he served as Lieutenant on a destroyer escort in the South Pacific and was awarded the Purple Heart after narrowly surviving a kamikaze attack. He was an actuary with Prudential and with Equitable Life, retiring as Senior Vice President (International) of Equitable in the 1970's to become a private investor. Bob cherished his family and loved music, good conversation and the many friends he made over the years in New York; Washington, Connecticut; Houston, Texas; and Boca Raton. Services will be private.

A theory on documentaries that strip-mine the 1960s: The less fresh insight the program has to offer, the earlier the Buffalo Springfield song “For What It’s Worth” will turn up on the soundtrack. Written by Stephen Stills, that astonishing song (“There’s something happening here/What it is ain’t exactly clear”) came to encapsulate ’60s turmoil so perfectly that resorting to it is a subconscious admission by a documentarian: “I have nothing to say that Stephen Stills didn’t say better in 2 minutes 41 seconds.”

Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the C.I.A.’s destruction of two videotapes documenting the interrogations of agents of Al Qaeda rendered incorrectly a quotation from Gen. Michael V. Hayden, the director of intelligence, in which he explained to C.I.A. employees why he was informing them of the destruction. General Hayden said, “The press has learned that back in 2002, during the initial stage of our terrorist detention program, C.I.A. videotaped interrogations, and destroyed the tapes in 2005.” He did not say he was informing them “because” the press has learned about the episode.

A picture caption with an article in some editions on Tuesday about a charity project called the Penny Harvest Field, to be unveiled on Monday in Rockefeller Plaza, reversed the identities of the two leaders of the project. Teddy Gross, of the nonprofit education group Common Cents, was second from left, and James S. Polshek, an architect, was at the right.

The Advertising column in Business Day on Monday, about a campaign for Dr. Martens boots, referred incorrectly to one designer’s use of the footwear and to the fashion show at which they were featured. While the designer Yohji Yamamoto used actual Dr. Martens shoes, the designer Chloé featured boots that were inspired by Dr. Martens; both showed their designs at the ready-to-wear show in Paris in February this year, not during New York Fashion Week in September. The article also misstated the headquarters of Dr. Martens’s advertising agency, Exposure Communications. It is based in New York, not London. (Its parent company, Exposure Promotions, is based in London, and the campaign was photographed there.).
If it has wheels, Carl Edwards will race it. He is game for anything, anytime — even a lawn mower race on the infield.

A picture caption on Tuesday with the continuation of a theater review of “The Farnsworth Invention,” at the Music Box Theater, misidentified the actor standing at the left. He is Spencer Moses — not Kyle Fabel, another actor in the play.

A Spare Times listing in Weekend yesterday about a winter festival at Riverside Church today misstated the church’s address. It is 490 Riverside Drive, not 91. (The entrance for today’s event is at 91 Claremont Avenue, between 120th and 122nd Streets.).

A picture caption with an article in some editions on Tuesday about a charity project called the Penny Harvest Field, to be unveiled on Monday in Rockefeller Plaza, reversed the identities of the two leaders of the project. Teddy Gross, of the nonprofit education group Common Cents, was second from left, and James S. Polshek, an architect, was at the right.

An article in Weekend yesterday about the Grammy nominations omitted part of the title of an album, by the Foo Fighters, that was nominated for the album of the year award. It is “Echoes, Silence, Patience & Grace,” not “Echoes, Patience & Grace.”.
Kevin Garnett scored 23 points and the Boston Celtics improved to 10-0 at home with a 112-84 victory against the Toronto Raptors Friday night.

Manchester United will mark the 50th anniversary of the plane crash that wiped out its famed team with a Premier League match against Manchester City. United has been given special permission by the league and its sponsors to wear the team’s old-style plain red jerseys and baggy shorts for the Feb. 10 home matchEight players were among 23 people killed on Feb. 6, 1958, when a plane carrying United home from a match at Red Star Belgrade crashed in Munich after refueling.

Woody Austin and Mark Calcavecchia shot an eight-under 64 in modified alternate-shot play for a share of the first-round lead with Fred Funk and Jeff Sluman in the Merrill Lynch Shootout in Naples, Fla. The tournament host Greg Norman and Bubba Watson were a stroke back, and the defending champions Jerry Kelly and Rod Pampling opened with a 66 on the Norman-designed Tiburon Golf Club course.

The Texas A&M regents approved a contract buyout yesterday for the former coach Dennis Franchione that is worth up to $4.4 million over three years. A spokesman for the athletic department said Franchione, who resigned Nov. 23, would be paid up to $1.7 million for each of the next two years. He would receive another $1 million in the third and final year of the agreement. Before he resigned, Franchione’s contract had five years remaining at $2 million a year.Franchione went 32-28 at A&M, far short of the expectations when he replaced R. C. Slocum in December 2002. Off the field, Franchione was reprimanded for selling inside information about the team to boosters.

The St. John’s women’s team dropped a five-game match against Southern California yesterday and was eliminated from the N.C.A.A. tournament in the Round of 16 in Gainesville, Fla.The defeat ended the best season in the 14-year history of the program. After losing the first two games, the 12th-seeded Red Storm (33-4) battled back behind the senior Hui Ping Huang, who had a match- and career-high 29 kills. Asia Kaczor led fifth-seeded U.S.C. (28-4) with 25 kills. U.S.C will next face Texas, which beat Florida in four games.

A marine was charged a second time with murdering a detainee three years ago in Falluja, Iraq, the military said. The marine, Sgt. Jermaine A. Nelson, was charged with murder and dereliction of duty, charges that were earlier dismissed to give a general time to review the case. Sergeant Nelson, whose age and hometown were not released, is the second person charged in the case centering on accusations that a Marine squad shot a group of unarmed captives. The squad leader, José Nazario Jr., has been charged with one count of voluntary manslaughter in the killing of two captives. Because Sergeant Nelson completed his military service, he faces charges in federal court.

Former Speaker Pete Kott, left, of the Alaska House was sentenced to six years in a federal prison for accepting $9,000 in bribes from the founder of an oil field services company. Judge John Sedwick of Federal District Court lengthened the sentence beyond the guidelines after concluding that Mr. Kott committed perjury during his trial. Mr. Kott, Republican of Eagle River, was convicted in September of bribery, extortion and conspiracy for his dealings with executives of the VECO Corporation. The case has wide implications because the F.B.I. is investigating whether Senator Ted Stevens, the chamber’s longest-serving Republican, received illegal gifts from the head of the company. Mr. Stevens has not been charged and has denied wrongdoing.

Transit officials said they were investigating as a possible hate crime in the beating of a white woman by nine black middle school students on a Baltimore city bus. The woman, Sarah Kreager, 26, suffered broken facial bones and other injuries after she was punched, kicked and dragged off the bus on Tuesday. Her companion, Troy Ellis, was also beaten, but not as severely. The students, six boys and three girls ages 14 to 15, have been charged with aggravated assault and destruction of property. Officials said no evidence had been found to support claims by the students’ parents that Ms. Kreager or Mr. Ellis provoked the attack by spitting or displaying a knife.

Using a simplified technique, the hurricane researcher William M. Gray is predicting an above-average hurricane season in the Atlantic next year, with seven hurricanes, three of them major. Dr. Gray’s team at Colorado State University had called for above-average storm seasons the past two Decembers, and both turned out to be wrong. But Dr. Gray said his team based the new extended-range forecast, issued six months before the June-to-November season begins, on three predictors instead of six, water temperatures in the Atlantic and the Pacific and the relationship between barometric pressure and altitude over the Atlantic.

The onetime chief of staff to former Representative Curt Weldon pleaded guilty in federal court to a conspiracy charge as part of a plea agreement. The aide, Russell J. Caso Jr., 34, acknowledged that he intentionally did not report to the House income his wife made for doing work for a nonprofit company tied to Mr. Weldon, Republican of Pennsylvania. Howard Sklamberg, an assistant United States attorney, told Judge Henry H. Kennedy Jr. of Federal District Court that Mr. Caso had agreed to cooperate with prosecutors in an investigation.

It will be illegal for hunters to possess or fire lead ammunition when they are in California condor habitat under regulations adopted by a state commission. By a vote of 3 to 1, the California Fish and Game Commission expanded the state’s lead ammunition ban in an effort to safeguard North America’s largest flying bird. “It’s pretty clear lead poisoning is one of the major factors preventing recovery of the species,” said Jeff Miller, a conservation advocate at the Center for Biological Diversity. The federal government declared the bird endangered in 1967. Scientists for years have said condors were poisoned when they ingested lead while feeding on bullet-ridden carcasses of other animals.
Robert A. Hawkins made a five-year journey through a maze of juvenile services before killing eight people and himself in a mall.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s wealth and sprawling business interests make him a novel mayor.
Congressional leaders plan to provide President Bush with war money in return for spending on domestic programs.
What began with an undercover F.B.I. agent’s posing as a corrupt hedge fund manager led to the arrest of six people  on charges of fraud in the shadowy world of penny stocks.
Karlheinz Stockhausen, a German composer, made operas to express his spiritual vision of the cosmos.
NASA officials on Friday again postponed the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis as they continued to discuss how to deal with a fuel sensor problem.
The City of Chicago says it is preparing to pay nearly $20 million to four men who were subjected to interrogations that they say amounted to torture.
The widow of Larry Manzanares, who committed suicide while facing criminal charges, says that the conduct of officials involved in the investigation contributed to her husband’s death.
The police continued to question John Darwin, the man who suddenly reappeared more than five years after he was thought to have drowned after a kayaking accident.
Consumer Reports, a monthly magazine, continues to thrive with a subscription-only model, even on the Web.
The police were holding a 45-year-old architect as a suspect in the package bomb explosion at a Paris law office on Thursday, a judicial police official said.

The United Nations Tribunal for Rwanda sentenced François Karera, a former mayor of the capital, Kigali, who is considered a central figure in the genocidal attacks on Tutsi and moderate Hutu in the spring of 1994, to life in prison.

Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the leader of Libya, will bring a heated Bedouin tent to Paris for receiving visitors when he arrives next week for a state visit, a spokesman for the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, said.
A parliamentary session to elect a new president was postponed for a seventh time, with a new date set for Tuesday.
Citing a lack of evidence, prosecutors in Poland dropped a libel investigation against the German newspaper Tageszeitung for likening President Lech Kaczynski to a potato.

The interior ministers of the nation’s 16 states as well as the federal interior minister, Wolfgang Schäuble, “consider Scientology to be an organization that is not compatible with the Constitution” and will work to ban the organization, Berlin’s interior minister, Erhart Körting, told reporters after a meeting.
Barry Bonds has spent the last couple of weeks interviewing top-tier defense lawyers in the Bay Area. By all accounts, he ended up with an all-star lineup.

Gyude Bryant, left, a businessman who led the transitional government that operated from the exile of Charles Taylor in 2003 to the inauguration of Ellen Johnson Sirleaf last year, was arrested for violating conditions of his bail while on trial on charges of embezzling $1.3 million from the government.

Indians who neglect parents over the age of 60 face three months in jail under a new law passed by Parliament. The legislation also provides for the state to set up centers that Meira Kumar, the social justice minister, told Parliament should be the “last resort for the poor and the childless.”
The Justice Department said it would consider an investigation into the destruction of interrogation tapes, and Congressional committees said that they would begin their own.
Pittsburgh Penguins center Sidney Crosby is expected to reach a milestone of sorts tomorrow in Vancouver. He will have finally played in all 30 N.H.L. cities.

Federal officials are warning landowners along the southern border that they have to give the government access to their property as it considers where to build a fence intended to block illegal immigration.
Wall Street paused from its big rally Friday, with shares closing narrowly mixed after the government’s November labor report showed tepid job growth as well as a pickup in inflation.
One man died and another was gravely injured when they plunged from the roof of an Upper East Side apartment building.
In some cases, litigation can look more like a racket for income redistribution than a search for fairness.
The Supreme Court accepted two cases that test whether judges have the authority to prevent military officials from turning U.S. citizens over to the Iraqis for criminal prosecution or punishment.
The Rhode Island Supreme Court ruled that same-sex couples who marry in Massachusetts, the only state that allows same-sex marriage, may not divorce in Rhode Island.

With his plans for the next America’s Cup scuppered by losing in court, Alinghi’s president, Ernesto Bertarelli, has expressed interest in making radical changes to the world’s oldest major sporting event.
Arizona Coach Lute Olson is extending his leave from the team through the end of the season after filing for divorce earlier this week, Olson’s lawyer, Leonard Karp, said Friday.
