Salomón Torres was traded Friday by the Pittsburgh Pirates to the division rival Milwaukee Brewers for the pitching prospects Marino Salas and Kevin Roberts.
Both Presidents Evo Morales of Bolivia and Rafael Correa of Ecuador  are playing a very dangerous game, lunging for power in the name of social reform.

The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, an agency created to root out corruption on the docks that was immortalized by Marlon Brando, is itself now at the center of a wide-ranging investigation.
Science fiction of Doris Lessing’s sort is the comparative study of civilizations, and that is one of Lady Mary Wortley Montagu’s purposes, too.

Mike Huckabee pledged to complete a border fence between the United States and Mexico by July 2010 and ruled out a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants unless they returned first to their country of origin.
Rutgers Coach Greg Schiano has rejected overtures to become the next coach at Michigan, providing another public blow to that university’s search for a successor to Lloyd Carr.
The employment picture offered assurance that the economy was not plummeting, but the Federal Reserve may feel less pressure to aggressively ease interest rates.

A line of water bottles that had become a symbol of environmental responsibility has been removed from the shelves of Canada’s leading outdoor gear retailer over concerns about a chemical used in its manufacture.
Mr. Morrisseau, also known as Copper Thunderbird, was one of Canada’s most celebrated painters.
A ferryboat named Freedom left San Francisco last month bound for New York Harbor, where it will join a fleet that will carry sightseers to the Statue of Liberty.
The National Football League fined four Baltimore Ravens players yesterday for violating rules prohibiting verbal abuse of game officials during the Ravens’ loss to the Patriots on Monday night.
City education officials said that they planned to close three additional schools that received poor marks on the Department of Education’s new report cards.
Last-minute listings on www.digsville.com is one of the many home-exchange Web sites where people offer to swap their houses to spend their winter vacation in the United States.
In the coastal Northwest, the dispute over plans to use waves to generate electricity has become intense before the first megawatt has been transmitted to shore.
A strike at a Ford Motor Company assembly line in St. Petersburg highlights the tightening labor market in Russia, a problem that would have seemed inconceivable a few years ago.

The Museum of Modern Art and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation jointly asked a federal court yesterday to declare them the owners of two Picasso paintings that a claimant says were sold under duress in Nazi Germany.

Tobias Levkovich, Citigroup’s chief United States equity strategist, has created an index of stocks of businesses that cater to affluent consumers - a group of people who tend to spend even in hard times.
A worker was killed Friday at a construction site in the Bronx after he was pinned between two pieces of heavy equipment and then fell into an eight-foot-deep hole, the authorities said.
The authorities in Omaha released surveillance photographs and notes written by the gunman who killed eight people in a mall rampage this week.
A judge denied a request Friday to raise the bail of Anthony D. Marshall, son of Brooke Astor, who is accused of looting her $198 million estate.
Paul Johnson, who had been Navy’s coach for the past six seasons, was hired Friday to replace Chan Gailey at Georgia Tech.
Amanda DaCosta scored the winning goal in the 71st minute Friday to help Florida State advance to its first N.C.A.A. Women’s College Cup final.
Jim Manzi, a longtime software executive, says that economically speaking, carbon taxes could be worse than global warming itself.
Despite breaking Jerry Rice’s receiving record in college, David Ball has drifted around since draft day. Now he’s with the Jets, who signed Ball to their practice squad last week.
Expectations are high among ethnic Albanians that Kosovo will declare independence, even as its probable new prime minister said Kosovo would wait until early next year.
A proposed school financing formula for New Jersey may direct a larger share of the $1 billion the state spends on special education to students in poor districts.
There’s a five-film pile-up on Saturday and Sunday night, which means that with judicious use of a DVR, you could spend 10 hours  having your heart tugged and your tear ducts massaged.

A California maritime agency has filed misconduct charges against the captain at the helm of a ship that hit the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge on Nov. 7, spilling 58,000 gallons of fuel and fouling 40 miles of shore.
Because of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations in New York City will be suspended today. Other regulations remain in effect.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine says the New Jersey State Police have made progress on racial profiling and no longer need federal oversight.
The two companies said the deal will allow consumers to pull up a guide on their TV and receive personalized content and information.
The Vatican broadcasts a Christmas Mass for shut-ins; HGTV offers a tour of the nation’s most elaborately lighted and decorated houses.
Shares of Amgen had their biggest decline in seven months on Nasdaq Friday after the company reported it might revise the safety information on its biggest product.
A bouncer who said he was the victim of a conspiracy by police assassins was convicted Friday of two 2005 murders but acquitted of a third.
The law of large numbers is frustrating for big companies. As a result, huge firms often end up paying for their success.
Donald J. Trump’s plan for a 100,000-square-foot restaurant and catering hall at Jones Beach State Park, the center of numerous controversies, is currently stalled.

Interviews with Gerard Mortier, the incoming general manager of the New York City Opera, and Susan L. Baker, its chairwoman, have yielded new details in response to reports that the opera may shut down for the 2008-9 season .
A film about migrants in Australia has won that country’s top movie award, while Eric Bana and Joan Chen, above, won the top acting honors.

“Die Soldaten,” an opera by the German composer Bernd Alois Zimmermann, was first performed in Germany in a former power plant.
The first 10 minutes of “Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story,” a new comedy co-produced by Judd Apatow, will be available online this weekend.
CBS earned the most viewers in every hour of prime time on Thursday, but ABC ranked first among viewers 18 to 49. CBS kicked off with “Survivor: China.”

In her acceptance speech for the 2007 Nobel Prize in Literature, Doris Lessing lamented a “fragmenting culture” in which “it is common for young men and women who have had years of education to know nothing about the world, to have read nothing, knowing only some specialty or other, for instance computers.”

EZRATTY--Pearl. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Ezratty family on the loss of Pearl. Growing up she kept us all in line and was always there to lend advice. She will be missed by many but live on in our hearts forever. Bill and Jessica Koenigsberg

GIROUX--Vera, of Manhattan, died peacefully December 7, 2007. Beloved wife of the late John Giroux, adored mother of Paul and Noelle of Manhattan and Leigh of Rye, New York. She is also survived by five grandchildren, James, Hilary, Alexandra, Charlotte and Olivia and her sister Nancy Craigmyle of Carmel, California. Selfless, loving, known to all as ''Saint Vera,'' she will be deeply missed. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the NY Times Neediest Fund.

10 P.M. (HBO) DAVE ATTELL: CAPTAIN MISERABLE He's no happy camper. In this stand-up special filmed at the Lincoln Theater in Washington, his first solo show for HBO in more than a decade, Mr. Attell, left, muses about things that disturb him -- like global warming, pot smokers and female celebrities -- and things that don't, like psychedelic mushrooms and his pornography collection.

ROTHKOPF--Selma (nee Fastenberg), died on December 4, 2007. Born and raised in New York City, she resided in Philadelphia with her husband, Hyman D. Rothkopf. She was a graduate of Hunter College, and was a beloved kindergarten teacher for almost 40 years at the Abigail Vare Elementary School in Philadelphia. In addition to her husband, she is survived by one daughter, Nancy Rothkopf Cantor, two grandchildren, Anthony Cantor, Caitlin Cantor, and three brothers, Abner Fastenberg, Marvin Fastenberg, and Dr. William Fastenberg, as well as many nieces and nephews. Contributions in her memory may be made to Hadassah or Temple Beth Zion Beth Israel, 300 South 18 St., Philadelphia, PA 19103.

SHALEN--Robert Ellis, died peacefully in Boca Raton after a brief illness, on December 5, 2007, at the age of 90 (but way too soon). He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Marcia Heatter Shalen; their daughter Cynthia Willett and her husband Thomas of Claremont, California; their son Peter Shalen and his wife Catherine of Chicago, Illinois; their son Stephen Shalen and his wife Wendy of Waccabuc, New York; grandchildren Samantha, Luke, David, Eve and her husband Moshe; great - granddaughters Abi gail, Miriam and Judith; and his sister Jean Moscow of New York City and Putnam Valley. Bob's brother Howard died earlier this year at his home in Sebastopol, California. After graduating from Boys High in Brooklyn, Bob was in the class of 1937 at Harvard, where he was a member of the Glee Club, was elected to phi beta kappa in his junior year and was graduated summa cum laude in mathematics. In World War II, he served as Lieutenant on a destroyer escort in the South Pacific and was awarded the Purple Heart after narrowly surviving a kamikaze attack. He was an actuary with Prudential and with Equitable Life, retiring as Senior Vice President (International) of Equitable in the 1970's to become a private investor. Bob cherished his family and loved music, good conversation and the many friends he made over the years in New York; Washington, Connecticut; Houston, Texas; and Boca Raton. Services will be private.
DUBILIER--Miriam, December 8th, 1980. Beloved aunt, blithe spirit, always loved and remembered. Larry and Betty

DONOVAN--Lauren Geisler, 55, died peacefully on December 5, 2007 after a courageous battle with cancer. Daughter of the late Frances and Marvin Geisler, loving sister of Bruce Geisler and devoted aunt of Sarah Geisler, Lauren was beloved and admired by her many godchildren and her enormous circle of friends, including her colleagues at NBC and CNBC, where she was senior vice president and general counsel. A graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and Columbia Law School, she was a brilliant lawyer, generous friend, witty, feisty and full of life. She will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved her. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to the breast cancer charity of your choice. Services will be held on Monday, December 10th at 1:15pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY.

WATSKY--Sydelle, ''Syde'' (nee Siegel). November 20, 2007 at age 99. Died in San Rasael, CA, but a proud New Yorker for 97 years. Widow of Seymour (died 1985, after 51 years of marriage), mother of Paul and mother-in-law of Clare, of San Francisco, CA. Syde had great energy and humor, and was deeply devoted to her family, especially her twin grandsons Simon and George.

HERTZ--Lawrence M., on December 5, 2007 of North Hills, New York. Partner at Hall, Dickler, Kent, Friedman and Wood LLP and Council at Reed Smith LLP. Author of Computer Law Strategies. Beloved husband of Bettina. Loving father of Jordan Lowell and Arianna Paige. Cherished son of Robert F. and the late Joan L. Hertz. Brother of John Anthony and Katherine Hertz of Lancaster, PA. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY, Sunday 3-5 and 79pm. Funeral Mass Monday 10:00am St. Mary's RC Church Manhasset. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

Hot air will be infused into the presidential campaign early next week. Supporters of Ron Paul, the Texas congressman who is seeking the Republican nomination, will be launching a blimp to help promote his campaign. Mr. Paul, not surprisingly, is the first of the 2008 presidential candidates to be promoted in this way.

HADLEY--John Michael, of Boulder, Colorado died on December 3, 2007 due to neurological degeneration. He was 80. Michael was born on September 23, 1927 to Leo George Hadley Jr. and Marsulite Nolker Hadley in St. Louis, Missouri. He also resided in Evanston, IL and Greenwich, CT. Michael married Gladys Pauline (Polly) Rolwing on October 16, 1954 at the Annunziata Catholic Church in St Louis, Missouri. He graduated from New Trier High School in Evanston, Illinois and received his undergraduate degree from Washington University in St. Louis. He then went on to work: in the Foreign Service in West Berlin and Moscow, Hadley Dean Glass Company in St. Louis, Curtis Publishing Company in St. Louis, Times Mirror Magazines, Inc. in New York City, The Sporting News in St. Louis, and Veronis Suhler and Associates in New York City. He was also a member of the Magazine Publishers Association and served on the Board of Directors for the Falstaff Brewery in St. Louis. He also served on the Board of Directors for the Animas Foundation in southern New Mexico. When Michael was editor of his grammar school yearbook he won an award for best layout and design. It was an award he treasured all his life. It foreshadowed his success in Publishing. He was also an avid swimmer and was on the Varsity Swim team at New Trier High School. He also enjoyed sailing and body surfing. He is survived by his children Martha Christine (Polly) Ruff, Nancy Stewart Hadley, Sally Catherine Hadley, and Laura Nolker Hadley. His siblings Leo George Hadley III, Ann Schmick Jewett and Mary Schmick. Grandchildren Jeremy David Ruff, Jacob Michael Ruff, Chelsea Christine Ruff, Boyd Easton Bissell Jr. and Hadley Brodhead Bissell. Other survivors include Edward G. Rolwing and John M. Rolwing. He is preceded in death by his wife Gladys Pauline (Polly) who passed away on September 2, 1971, and his brother William Schmick. Michael was more than a father to his four daughters: he was a ''daddy''. He was always ready to shop, get ice cream, go to the beach, and help with homework. The neighborhood was often at the house. He was a mentor, peacemaker and problem solver. He made each day, no matter how hectic or ordinary, extraordinary and fun. Visitation will be on Friday, December 14 at 10:00am at Our Lady of Lourdes Catholic Church, 7148 Forsyth Blvd., St. Louis, MO, 63105. Catholic services will follow. Reverend Monsignor Edward J. Sudekum will be officiating. Interment will be at Calvary Cemetery in St. Louis, MO. Contributions may be made at www.malpaiborderlandsgroup.org or The Animas Foundation, 14 Diamond A Drive, Animas, NM 88020. A formal obituary will follow at a later date.

BRANTON--Tim M., age 80, passed away Thursday evening in his home on the Upper East side of Manhattan. At the age of 17 he enlisted and proudly served in the US Navy from 1944 to 1946 where he saw combat on the shores of Okinawa as a medic attached to the Sixth Marine Corp. Following his education at the University of Connecticut he became a commissioned Second Lieutenant in the US Army, and went on to pursue his Masters in geopolitical science at the Sorbonne in Paris, France. In 1948 he was a voluntary ambulance driver between Tel Aviv and Jerusalem. His extensive career in public relations saw him in a senior capacity at such firms as Westinghouse, American Standard and the Flexi-Van Corporation. He is predeceased by his parents Michel and Lyda Birnbaum and is survived by his son Matthew, wife Blanche, and sister Gerry Weltman of Adventura, Florida. His extraordinary presence, vivacity and character will be sorely missed. Service Sunday 9:45am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

SUSSMAN--Robert A. There'll be an empty chair at lunch. We will all miss you. Bernie, Irving, Marty, Norman and Sig SUSSMAN--Robert A./d, of Great Neck, NY, died on December 6, 2007 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital after a long struggle with cancer. Devoted husband of Ruth, loving father of Karen and Daniel, father-in-law of Jeff Gilchrist and Beth Barry, grandfather of Matthew, Jake and Sophie, and brother of Millie Fenster. His love for his family and friends was the cornerstone of his life. His love of travel took him all over the world, and his love of flowers and nature made his backyard a source of endless pleasure. His smile, wit, warmth and kindness, his compassion and concern for others never waned, no matter how much he suffered. The world was a better place for his having been a part of it; he will be missed.

GILBERT--Zena. December 7th, 2007. Beloved wife of Richard, devoted and loving mother of Lindsay, Chris, Piama, Alex and her husband Scott. Cherished grandmother of Charlie, devoted sister of Piama, Elary, Jeannie, Alice and Angelina. Loving daughter of the late Father Elary Gromoff and the late Elizabeth Gromoff. She will be profoundly missed by all who knew and loved her. Family will receive friends, Sunday, December 9, 3-5pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st Street, NYC. Funeral is private.

EHRENFELD--Anne, (Moses), formerly of New Rochelle, NY on Thursday, December 6, 2007. Wife of the late Dr. Irving D. Ehrenfeld. Mother of Ellen and Barry Mintzer of Concord, MA and Howard and Terri Ehrenfeld of Baltimore, MD. Grandmother of Mara Mintzer and great-grandmother of Kaya Surden. Graveside services at the Beth Israel Memorial Park, Woodbridge, NJ on Sunday, December 9 at 11:00am. Shiva will be private. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the National MS Society, P.O. Box 4527, New York, NY 10163.

HERROLD--Dr. Kenneth, professor emeritus at Teachers College, Columbia University, passed away on November 22 at age 94. Devoted husband of the late Elizabeth McMahan, father of Carolann, Edmund, William and John. An expert on group dynamics, he taught at Columbia for 30 years, advised industry and government, and helped bring banking into under served areas of the Bronx. Eagle Scout and WWII Veteran, he studied at Bucknell, Yale, University of Michigan, and Columbia. He will be deeply missed by family and friends.

BUYER TO CLOSE COMPUSA CompUSA, the consumer-electronics retailer owned by the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim, said it was acquired by the restructuring firm Gordon Brothers Group, which plans to close or sell its 103 stores. CompUSA stores will remain open during the holiday season, the company, based in Dallas, said. Financial terms were not disclosed. ''An orderly and expedited wind-down and asset sale process is the best option for CompUSA and its creditors at this juncture,'' Bill Weinstein, principal at Gordon Brothers, said. Mr. Weinstein will serve as interim president of CompUSA, which was founded in 1984. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

BEDRICK--Peter, 12/8/04. In loving memory of a remarkable man whose integrity, keen intellect, dry wit, unfailing kindness, and grace continue to inspire us daily. Our love for you is without end. Family, friends and colleagues

LEVIS--Margaret (Geb. Dreyfuss), born July 21, 1915. On December 6, 2007 after a 20 year battle with Alzheimer's, now joins her beloved husband Carl, devoted brother Rolf, younger brother Walter (lost to Holocaust), and all her other relatives and friends of a unique era gone by. Orphaned at 12, refugee of WWII, widow at 55, she always enjoyed the good times in-between with a smile, a helping hand and never an unkind word. She leaves behind her spoiled only child Donald, loving granddaughters Caron and Emily, devoted friend of 60 years Maria and many others who will miss her presence. ''Flowers are for the living'' -Donations to NY Alzheimer's Association appreciated. Chapel service at 11am on Sunday at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NY. (212)769-4400. Burial at Mount Hope Cemetery, Westchester.

FRIEDMAN--Hilda. JBI International, established as The Jewish Braille Institute, deeply regrets the passing of Hilda Friedman, beloved mother of Stephen Friedman and mother-in-law of Barbara B. Friedman, Honorary Chairman of JBI. All of us at JBI feel honored by our association with the Friedman family and extend our deepest condolences to Steve, Barbara and all of the other members of their very special family. Judy E. Tenney, Chairman of the Board Dr. Ellen Isler, President and CEO

ANDERSON--Robert O. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Aspen Institute mourn the loss of Lifetime Trustee and longtime leader Robert O. Anderson, who presided over the Institute for three decades. He was an entrepreneur, visionary, environmentalist, and humanist whose ideas remain an indelible part of the Institute's mission of fostering enlightened leadership and open-minded dialogue. Our deepest condolences go to his wife, Barbara, and his family. William E. Mayer, Chairman, and Walter Isaacson, President and CEO, The Aspen Institute

The highly anticipated combination of Oprah and Obama descends upon Des Moines this afternoon, and there are still tickets available for the rally. And they are free. The event at the Hy-Vee Hall is Oprah Winfrey's first official stop on the trail for Senator Barack Obama of Illinois in his bid for the 2008 Democratic presidential nomination.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has reversed a decision to remove the elevator operators from five subway stations in Upper Manhattan, an official said yesterday. The initial operator cutback, intended to save $1.7 million a year, was quietly included in a batch of belt-tightening measures in the authority's proposed 2008 budget, which was released last month.

GROSSMAN--Janice. Be loved sons Stephen and Elliot Grossman mourn the loss of their mother, Janice Grossman who passed away December 5th, at 91 years old. She is survived by her two sons, daughter-in-law Rita Grossman, grandchildren Carolyn and Robert Grossman, and brother Justin Bisgyer. She shall be remembered and missed by many.

PERLES--David R., M.D. Born May 24, 1936, departed this life on November 18, 2007, surrounded by loved ones at home in Los Alamitos, CA, following an extended illness. David was born in New York to Esther and Nathan Perles, and sister Elizabeth was born in 1938. His impressive medical career in radiology spanned 50 years practicing in New York, New Jersey, Korea and California. He attended Lincoln High School 1952, Amherst College 1957, and Albert Einstein College of Medicine 1961. David and Heran moved with their only child, Lisa, to California in 1970. He worked at Woodruff Community Hospital and became Chief of Radiology in 1980 and Chief of Staff (1981-1984). He also provided Locum Tenens services throughout the U.S. and Kindred Hospitals California. David belonged to the American College of Radiology and the American Medical Association. David is missed for his kind, warm heart, sparkling wit, verbal skill, intellectual curiosity, musical talent and artistic spirit. He was a true Renaissance man and had a philosopher's sensibility regarding the universe, mankind and the foibles of the everyday. He was a prankster, scrabble aficionado and had passion for a hearty spaghetti dinner. He is lovingly remembered by his daughter, Lisa, son-in-law, Don, only grandchild, Olivia, two dearly loved stepsons, Matthew (Denise) and Alex and friends Heran and Tony who were always family through and through. To my teleological, existential atheist. Love, Bug. Contributions in David's memory to SPCA-LA Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, 5026 West Jefferson Blvd., LA, CA 90016 (323) 730-5300.

The Boston Society of Film Critics joined their brethren down the coast in D.C. by deciding that "No Country for Old Men" was the feature film achievement of the year. Julian Schnabel won best director for "The Diving Bell and the Butterfly."

The Coen brothers had a nice day inside the Beltway. "No Country for Old Men" won the best picture award from the Washington D.C. Area Film Critics, who also named them best director. This, according to And the Winner Is ..., which also broke the news that George Clooney had picked up his first best actor nod of the season for his portrayal of a conflicted lawyer/fixer named Michael Clayton.

And the Winner Is has the 411 on the Los Angeles Film Critics Association awards, and boy or boy, do they love "There Will Be Blood." Picture, director, actor, and design. Big love for a big picture. Marion Cotillard, from "La Vie en Rose," won for best actress. And Amy Ryan got an interesting supporting actress citation, winning for her work in both "Gone Baby Gone" and "Before the Devil Knows You're Dead."

The New York Film Critics Online came, saw and awarded, with Paul Thomas Anderson picking up best director for "There Will Be Blood," which shared best picture honors with "The Diving Bell and the Butterfly." Daniel Day Lewis picked up best actor for his work in Mr. Anderson's film, while Julie Christie, starring in "Away From Her," won best actress.

The America’s Cup appears headed toward a Deed of Gift race, a best-of-three duel between the champion Alinghi and BMW Oracle Racing next summer. That possibility drew nearer yesterday when Ernesto Bertarelli, the president of the Swiss syndicate that owns Alinghi, said it would be impossible to stage a full race with a challengers series in 2009. A day after he proposed changing the Deed of Gift — the 156-year-old document that governs the event — he said a 33rd edition could not be held before 2011.

An article on Nov. 11 about Tayrona National Park in Colombia misstated the extent to which kidnappings have been reduced since the Colombian president, Álvaro Uribe, initiated his new security policy in late 2003. According to the Vice Presidency and Ministry of Defense of Colombia and the U.S. State Department, kidnappings have been reduced from about 2,000 in 2003 to 687 last year and 393 from January to September 2007. The number of kidnappings was not brought down from 3,000 in 2003 to 100 a year.

RIVERSIDE COTTAGE $899,000

D'AGOSTINO--Alfred A. Sr. Age 88, died Monday, December 3, 2007 at home. He was born in Brooklyn, New York, September 1919, and graduated Boys High School, Brooklyn, in 1935. He continued his education at Pratt Institute, graduating in 1939 at 18 years of age, with a degree in Chemical Engineering. During WWII he worked on the Manhattan Project in Los Alamos, New Mexico. After the war, he went back to work at the family business, Alberts Plating Works in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, founded by his father Albert. He was a benefactor to both the New York Athletic Club and the Queen of Peace Church. Upon retirement in 2001, he relocated to Norwalk, Connecticut, where he volunteered at The St. Vincent de Paul Society, St. Thomas Parish, and The Sons of Italy. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Sylvia; his four children Lucille, Alfred, Michael, Mary Sue and their spouses; his seven grandchildren; one brother, Gerald, and four sisters, Anna, Eileen, and Joan. He was predeceased by his sister Caroline. Funeral Services were held Thursday, December 6th, at Queen of Peace Church, Kew Garden Hills, NY. Contributions in his name can be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461.

Jersey City, Dec. 4.

SHAW--Frances Fort, of a heart attack, November 19. An editor and writer, she provided services to architects, city planners, governmental agencies and foundations. Frances was happiest when giving, helping and caring for others; not only to friends, but to many whom she could never know. She contributed significant time and money to the Prospect Park Alliance, and to social welfare and dance organizations. Her husband Kendall adored her. THE NEWS Two years after saying Iran was working to build a nuclear bomb, America's intelligence agencies reported last week that Iran halted its nuclear weapons program in 2003. BEHIND THE NEWS The reversal threatened to weaken support abroad for tougher sanctions against Iran and raised questions about the credibility of the intelligence community. But President Bush said he remained worried that Iran could acquire a nuclear weapon because it continues to enrich uranium, supposedly for civilian purposes. ''Look, Iran was dangerous, Iran is dangerous and Iran will be dangerous, if they have the knowledge necessary to make a nuclear weapon,'' he said.

HADLEY--John Michael, of Boulder, Colorado died on December 3, 2007 due to neurological degeneration. He was 80. Michael was born on September 23, 1927 to Leo George Hadley Jr. and Marsulite Nolker Hadley in St. Louis, Missouri. He also resided in Evanston, IL and Greenwich, CT. Michael married Gladys Pauline (Polly) Rolwing on October 16, 1954 at the Annunziata Catholic Church in St Louis, Missouri. He graduated from New Trier High School in Evanston, Illinois and received his undergraduate degree from Washington University in St. Louis. He then went on to work: in the Foreign Service in West Berlin and Moscow, Hadley Dean Glass Company in St. Louis, Curtis Publishing Company in St. Louis, Times Mirror Magazines, Inc. in New York City, The Sporting News in St. Louis, and Veronis Suhler and Associates in New York City. He was also a member of the Magazine Publishers Association and served on the Board of Directors for the Falstaff Brewery in St. Louis. He also served on the Board of Directors for the Animas Foundation in southern New Mexico. When Michael was editor of his grammar school yearbook he won an award for best layout and design. It was an award he treasured all his life. It foreshadowed his success in Publishing. He was also an avid swimmer and was on the Varsity Swim team at New Trier High School. He also enjoyed sailing and body surfing. He is survived by his children Martha Christine (Polly) Ruff, Nancy Stewart Hadley, Sally Catherine Hadley, and Laura Nolker Hadley. His siblings Leo George Hadley III, Ann Schmick Jewett and Mary Schmick. Grandchildren Jeremy David Ruff, Jacob Michael Ruff, Chelsea Christine Ruff, Boyd Easton Bissell Jr. and Hadley Brodhead Bissell. Other survivors include Edward G. Rolwing and John M. Rolwing. He is preceded in death by his wife Gladys Pauline (Polly) who passed away on September 2, 1971, and his brother William Schmick. Michael was more than a father to his four daughters: he was a ''daddy''. He was always ready to shop, get ice cream, go to the beach, and help with homework. The neighborhood was often at the house. He was a mentor, peacemaker and problem solver. He made each day, no matter how hectic or ordinary, extraordinary and fun. Visitation will be on Friday, December 14 at 10:00am at Our Lady of Lourdes Catholic Church, 7148 Forsyth Blvd., St. Louis, MO, 63105. Catholic services will follow. Reverend Monsignor Edward J. Sudekum will be officiating. Interment will be at Calvary Cemetery in St. Louis, MO. Contributions may be made at www.malpaiborderlandsgroup.org or The Animas Foundation, 14 Diamond A Drive, Animas, NM 88020. A formal obituary will follow at a later date.

9 P.M. (History) 1968 WITH TOM BROKAW It was a year of burning cities, marching students and murdered leaders, not to mention sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll. But just how revolutionary was 1968? In this two-hour special, Mr. Brokaw draws on his new book, ''Boom! Voices of the '60s,'' as well as archival film and recent interviews with musicians, politicians, black-power activists and antiwar protesters to examine some of the year's key events and their impact today. Andrew Young, Rafer Johnson, Stewart Brand, Tommy Smothers, Jon Stewart, Pat Buchanan, Robin Morgan, Arlo Guthrie, James Taylor and Bruce Springsteen reminisce. (Above, protesters at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago in 1968.) 8 P.M. (Animal Planet) ARCTIC EXPOSURE WITH NIGEL MARVEN In this new series, Mr. Marven, an adventurer and zoologist, spends nine months exploring the Canadian Arctic from the icy wasteland of the far north to the boreal forest of the south. He begins his journey in Wapusk National Park on Hudson Bay, where he marvels at the Northern Lights in minus-30-degree weather. At 9, he enjoys the warmer months with the first polar bears of summer and witnesses wolves attacking a musk ox herd near Cambridge Bay.

PIXELATED STAINED GLASS In late August, at the unveiling of the massive, awe-inspiring stained-glass window [37] designed by the artist Gerhard Richter for Cologne Cathedral in Germany, the city's conservative archbishop, Cardinal Joachim Meisner, was notably absent. Though Meisner claimed a prior engagement, skeptics suspected otherwise. Meisner had insisted that only a figurative depiction of 20th-century Catholic martyrs could substitute for the original Gothic window, which was destroyed by Allied bombing during World War II and never suitably replaced. Richter, however, delivered something wholly unexpected: an abstract composition of 11,500 identically sized units -- at 14.5 square inches each, they are frequently compared to pixels -- in 72 colors, the arrangement of which was determined randomly by a computer program. Richter originally produced two drafts for the window, each portraying the Nazi execution of innocents. But he ultimately concluded that ''figurative'' was something he simply could not do. ''I was not able to make something of it,'' he says. Any representational image would have been tiresomely dissected for meanings religious, political, symbolic. There were also more mundane reasons. As the cathedral's master builder, Barbara Schock-Werner, writes in a catalog essay for the window, ''How could such a depiction be realized other than in gloomy, oppressive colors?'' This was not a frivolous matter of interior decoration but a practical concern: the prismatic 1,200-square-foot window would bathe the cathedral (and congregation) in a significant amount of light.

CULINARY ORIENTALISM ''Tell me what you eat,'' wrote the 19th-century French gastronome Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin, ''and I shall tell you what you are.'' In other words, an understanding of a community's cuisine entails an understanding of the community itself. Of late, the cookbook industry seems to have made -- perhaps unwittingly -- a case that understanding Middle Eastern cuisine is the path to resolving the world's geopolitical crises. Consider Claudia Roden's ''Arabesque,'' a cookbook that takes in the variant cuisines of Turkey, Morocco and Lebanon [13, 14]. In a review in Slate, Michael Lukas, an American living in Turkey, points out that ''Arabesque'' is not just -- is not even primarily -- an excellent cookbook: by socially, politically and historically contextualizing the three cuisines, he argues, Roden has also written an effective primer on the diversity of the Middle East. Lukas even goes so far as to suggest that the late scholar and activist Edward Said (the author of ''Orientalism,'' an influential critique of traditional scholarship about the Middle East) might have recommended Roden's book as a reliable guide to the region.

WEAPON-PROOF SCHOOL GEAR [53] Mike Pelonzi and Joe Curran aren't paranoid; they just have a few rules when it comes to their kids' safety. No bike riding without a helmet. No boating without a life vest. And no going to school without a bulletproof backpack. Only problem: the backpack didn't seem to exist. So they invented My Child's Pack, a bag with a back panel as bulletproof as a police vest that kids can use as a shield. It comes in four colors and costs $195. Since August, they have sold more than 1,000.

An article on Nov. 11 about Tayrona National Park in Colombia misstated the extent to which kidnappings have been reduced since the Colombian president, Álvaro Uribe, initiated his new security policy in late 2003. According to the Vice Presidency and Ministry of Defense of Colombia and the U.S. State Department, kidnappings have been reduced from about 2,000 in 2003 to 687 last year and 393 from January to September 2007. The number of kidnappings was not brought down from 3,000 in 2003 to 100 a year.

Editorial: The Crisis of Faith We believe democracy cannot exist without separation of church and state, not that public displays of faith are anathema. We believe, as did the founding fathers, that no specific religion should be elevated above all others by the government. The authors of the Constitution knew that requiring specific declarations of religious belief (like Mitt Romney saying he believes Jesus was the son of God) is a step toward imposing that belief on all Americans. That is why they wrote in Article VI that ''no religious test shall ever be required as a qualification to any office or public trust under the United States.''

Airborne Wind Turbines Traditional wind turbines can be unreliable sources of energy because, well, the wind blows where it will. Not the case 1,000 feet up. ''At a thousand feet, there is steady wind anywhere in the world,'' says Mac Brown, chief operating officer of Ottawa-based Magenn Power. To take advantage of this constant breeze, Brown has developed a lighter-than-air wind turbine capable of powering a rural village. ''Picture a spinning Goodyear blimp,'' Brown says. Filled with helium, outfitted with electrical generators and tethered to the ground by a conductive copper cable, the 100-foot-wide Magenn Air Rotor System (MARS) [1] will produce 10 kilowatts of energy anywhere on earth. As the turbine spins around a horizontal axis, the generators convert the mechanical energy of the wind into electrical energy, then send it down for immediate use or battery storage.

HONEYCOMB VASE, THE [22] How many workers does it take to make a vase? To devotees of the Arts and Crafts Movement, it's one. But in the case of the Honeycomb Vase, it's 40,000 -- because the ''workers'' who made it were bees toiling in their hive. The vase was conceived by Tomás Gabzdil Libertiny, a young Slovakian product designer. Eager to explore the relationship between design and nature, he settled upon beeswax as a suitable material and chose the vase as an appropriate object to make from it. ''Beeswax comes from flowers and, in the form of a vase, it ends up containing flowers before they die,'' Libertiny says. ''It's a beautiful story.''

SELF-RIGHTING OBJECT, THE The Gomboc is a roundish piece of clear synthetic material with gently peaked, organic curves. It looks like a piece of modern art. But if you tip it over, something unusual happens: it rights itself. It leans off to one side, rocks to and fro as if gathering strength and then, presto, tips itself back into a ''standing'' position as if by magic. It doesn't have a hidden counterweight inside that helps it perform this trick, like an inflatable punching-bag doll that uses ballast to bob upright after you whack it. No, the Gomboc is something new: the world's first self-righting object.

Cardboard Bridge, The When the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban was asked to build a footbridge over the Gardon River in the south of France, he designed one that was keenly sensitive to its surroundings. He constructed it from locally available materials and based its geometry on the nearby Pont du Gard, a historic Roman aqueduct. But instead of stones or concrete, Ban used a mixture of cardboard tubes, recycled labels and creative engineering. This summer, the surprisingly strong structure -- it can withstand the load of at least 20 people -- rose triumphantly against the backdrop of the ancient monument. The 72-foot-long frame was made primarily from 281 cardboard tubes -- each four and a half inches in diameter and about three-quarters of an inch thick. The tubes were held together by steel joints. For the steps, Ban used a new material called ProFi, assembled from paper and plastic left over from the manufacture of self-adhesive labels. Wooden boxes buried underground and packed with local sand formed the foundations.

COMMUNITY URINALYSIS Everyone knows how a drug test works: You urinate into a cup and your employer (or prospective employer) has the sample tested to see if you've been using any illegal substances. This year, though, Jennifer Field, an environmental chemist at Oregon State University, experimented with an unusual variation on this process. She found out what illicit drugs the population of an entire city was ingesting. How? By collecting and then testing water from the city's sewage-treatment plant. Since all drug users urinate, and since the urine eventually winds up in the sewers, Field and her fellow researchers figured that sewer water would contain traces of whatever drugs the citizens were using.

FRIEDLANDER--Ralph M.D., 94, on November 14, 2007 at his Florida home in Tamarac. A distinguished Cardio-Thoracic surgeon, every path he took led to extraordinary achievements. Summa Cum Laude from Columbia, Ph.D. in Physics from University of Chicago and Alpha Omega Alpha from Rush Medical. His brilliance was also recognized when General Mark Clark of the 5th Army selected him as his personal physician and promoted him to Lt. Col. during WWII. After heading two V.A. chest surgery hospitals, he spent the next 40 years as Director of Surgery at Bronx Lebanon, Professor of Anatomy and Surgery at Einstein Medical School and attending at Mt. Sinai and Beth Israel Hospitals. Upon retiring at the age 78, he continued showing his passion for knowledge by accepting an offer to teach physics at Columbia. To the scores of students and residents he trained, and the thousands of lives he affected, this modest, kind and lovely man was a gift to humanity. Survived by his wife, two daughters, grandson, two stepsons, stepdaughter, stepgrandson and five siblings.

There is no way that any reasonable person can argue that this Legislature has actuallyearned a pay raise. So for months now, Gov. PERLES--David R., M.D. Born May 24, 1936, departed this life on November 18, 2007, surrounded by loved ones at home in Los Alamitos, CA, following an extended illness. David was born in New York to Esther and Nathan Perles, and sister Elizabeth was born in 1938. His impressive medical career in radiology spanned 50 years practicing in New York, New Jersey, Korea and California. He attended Lincoln High School 1952, Amherst College 1957, and Albert Einstein College of Medicine 1961. David and Heran moved with their only child, Lisa, to California in 1970. He worked at Woodruff Community Hospital and became Chief of Radiology in 1980 and Chief of Staff (1981-1984). He also provided Locum Tenens services throughout the U.S. and Kindred Hospitals California. David belonged to the American College of Radiology and the American Medical Association. David is missed for his kind, warm heart, sparkling wit, verbal skill, intellectual curiosity, musical talent and artistic spirit. He was a true Renaissance man and had a philosopher's sensibility regarding the universe, mankind and the foibles of the everyday. He was a prankster, scrabble aficionado and had passion for a hearty spaghetti dinner. He is lovingly remembered by his daughter, Lisa, son-in-law, Don, only grandchild, Olivia, two dearly loved stepsons, Matthew (Denise) and Alex and friends Heran and Tony who were always family through and through. To my teleological, existential atheist. Love, Bug. Contributions in David's memory to SPCA-LA Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, 5026 West Jefferson Blvd., LA, CA 90016 (323) 730-5300.

KARNOFF--Martin. With profound grief the family announces his untimely death. Marty was the cherished husband of Elaine (Seaton) Wyden. Father of Robert, fatherin-law to Jennifer, and grandfather to his beloved Rachel. Predeceased by Arlene Karnoff. Stepfather of Phillip Karnoff and his family, wife Karen and daughters Catherine and Alexandra, and a step daughter Jodie. Also stepfather to James Seaton, Andrea Miller and her husband Jon, and loving grandfather to their respective children Philip Seaton, Catherine Miller Hardy, Julia Miller. Martin was born in New York on November 24th 1930, he served in Korea in the criminal investigation division. A graduate of City College, he also studied film at NYU were he worked with Marcel Duchamp on the Hans Richter film ''8x8''. A job at Manufacturers Hanover in their new computer department led to his becoming one of the pioneers of the computer leasing industry, when he joined LevinTownsend Computer Corporation in the early 1960s. By 1970 he was CEO of a greatly expanded company whose assets included a Las Vegas hotel and the Boston Celtics. In 1978 he formed Equion Computer from which he ultimately retired. A dedicated sailor he was also enamored of older BMW motor cycles and rode a R50 across Europe in his youth. A voracious reader with broad knowledge and interests, Martin was known for his phenomenal memory, his story telling and his astonishingly quick wit. A man of depth and integrity he will be forever missed.

You've just been named the next editor of Commentary, which became the voice of the neoconservative movement in the '70s under the stewardship of your famous father, Norman. Did you always want to be the editor of Commentary? I never wanted to be editor of Commentary, at least not after the age of 7, when children seem to think, largely because of fairy tales, that they ascend to the position their parents hold upon their parents' death. But you did get into the magazine field early on. In 1995, you were among the three founders of The Weekly Standard, which is snappier than Commentary and quickly surpassed it circulation-wise. In the '90s, the Clinton years, conservative magazines exploded. The classic rule of thumb is that if you are an intellectual ideological magazine, you do better in opposition than you do if your views are reflected by people in power.

TRIOLO--Ignatius A. (''Nat''), of Glen Cove, LI, and Brooklyn, NY, passed away peacefully and surrounded by love on December 5, 2007 at the age of 75. Beloved father of Gianna. Loving big brother of Jean Triolo Murphy, Sadie Irwin, and the late Salvatore. A very special uncle to his devoted niece Mimi (Jean Marie) Murphy and his late nephew Marty Murphy. Cherished friend to his personal care companion Christina Seetahal, who along with Jean and Mimi provided tender loving care to the end; reflective of both his courage and their exceptional care. The family wishes to extend their gratitude to Dr. Alan Nelson and Donna Donnelly, RN, whose generous spirit and kindness to Nat during his illness was monumental. Nat was a graduate of New York University and New York Law School. He's a proud veteran of the U.S. Army during the Korean conflict. Nat dedicated his professional life to the great city of New York and concluded his career as the Director of the Blue Collar Division for District Counsel 37 and Associate Administrator for District Counsel 37 Health and Security Plan. Early on in his career he was Recreation Director for the City of New York Parks and Recreation. Nat was a largerthan-life personality and will always be remembered as a leader in his field and an inspiration to those who had the pleasure of knowing him. A no-nonsense principled man of integrity with a tremendous humor and wit. He will be missed terribly and forever in our hearts. A prayer service officiated by Father Fred of St. Boniface Martyr Church, Sea Cliff, LI was held at the Funeral Home of Dodge-Thomas, Glen Cove, LI followed by an interment at St. John's Cemetery, Queens, NY.

HERROLD--Dr. Kenneth, professor emeritus at Teachers College, Columbia University, passed away on November 22 at age 94. Devoted husband of the late Elizabeth McMahan, father of Carolann, Edmund, William and John. An expert on group dynamics, he taught at Columbia for 30 years, advised industry and government, and helped bring banking into under served areas of the Bronx. Eagle Scout and WWII Veteran, he studied at Bucknell, Yale, University of Michigan, and Columbia. He will be deeply missed by family and friends.

Nature and fashion in Manhattan underwent a spectacular 10-day metamorphosis from late November's golden foliage to winter's minimalist tones, with freezing winds, dustings of snow and icy lakes in Central Park. Women on Fifth Avenue did not miss a beat, wearing snowy white coats, some with fox-portrait collars recalling Hollywood's glamour stars of the 1930s. But one woman welcomed the season by wearing a pencil-slim coat of silvery brocade -- chinchilla fur at the collar, cuffs and hem -- with gray flannel narrow trousers and an envelope bag tucked under the arm.

LEFT-HAND-TURN ELIMINATION [28] It seems that sitting in the left lane, engine idling, waiting for oncoming traffic to clear so you can make a left-hand turn, is minutely wasteful -- of time and peace of mind, for sure, but also of gas and therefore money. Not a ton of gas and money if we're talking about just you and your Windstar, say, but immensely wasteful if we're talking about more than 95,000 big square brown trucks delivering packages every day. And this realization -- that when you operate a gigantic fleet of vehicles, tiny improvements in the efficiency of each one will translate to huge savings overall -- is what led U.P.S. to limit further the number of left-hand turns its drivers make. The company employs what it calls a ''package flow'' software program, which among other hyperefficient practices involving the packing and sorting of its cargo, maps out routes for every one of its drivers, drastically reducing the number of left-hand turns they make (taking into consideration, of course, those instances where not to make the left-hand turn would result in a ridiculously circuitous route).

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority this morning proposed raising the cost of a 30-day MetroCard to $81 from $76, a 6.6 percent increase. Also, a 14-day MetroCard would be created, with a cost of $47.

Under the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s fare-increase proposal, the base fare would stay at $2. But 86 percent of riders buy some form of discounted or unlimited-ride MetroCard, and for those people, fares would increase by 4 to 7 percent early next year if the increases are approved. Those MetroCard buyers might be wondering, “What should I do if the fare goes up?” Fortunately, there’s a simple answer. We did the math. Whatever you are doing now is what you should do in the event of a fare hike.

I love the morning after a party and the girlfriends call to discuss the food, the conversation, the clothes and, of course, the men folk. I gave a little party on Saturday night - I'm sorry I didn't invite y'all - and the guests trooped through the darkness and the muddy snow, with bottles of wine, cakes and a bunch of white roses. I had brought together two separate worlds, friends and cousins, city and country people, and everyone got along and stayed until midnight. I cooked a fresh ham (thanks to James Beard, the calmest and funniest of authorities, I think), and my brother sent scallops from Nantucket, which I turned into a kind of pie. We had a potato gratin and a tossed salad. I dug out my mother's recipe for chocolate pot de crème, and I used her old "Good Housekeeping Picture Cookbook" for the coconut layered cake. I cooked a batch of the Swedish ginger cookies, the ones made with bacon fat. Freddy the Jack stayed close to the ham all night, and Toby the Lab gave every pair of gray flannels a nice comet of hair. It was fun, the girlfriends said, sounding almost surprised.

After several false starts, the Toronto Stock Exchange and the Montreal Exchange announced a merger on Monday valued at 1.31 billion Canadian dollars ($1.3 billion).
What you don't know could be costing you dearly.

If you are someone who suspects that what is billed as "aviation security" is often more show than substance, you are not alone. In fact, you are part of what Nixon aides used to call the "silent majority." The security bureaucracy seems to think that as long as it is seen as doing something, and so long as another terror attack does not occur, the public will at least feel secure enough not to insist that it do whatever needs to be done actually to make us secure. Any number of examples could be cited to support this proposition, but let's focus first on the foiled plot in the summer of 2006 to blow up several jetliners over the United States with liquid explosives. Because no technology had been developed to detect or thwart liquid explosives, the Transportation Security Administration was forced to take, for a time, the draconian step of banning all liquids and gels. We were told at the time that even liquids and gels that are harmless in and of themselves could become incendiary when combined in sufficient quantity.

Jonathan Gray is becoming a fixture of the Wall Street power list. In recent months, Mr. Gray, the co-head of the Blackstone Group's real estate investment group, appeared in DealBook's "Facebook of Wall Street's Future" feature and got a spot on Vanity Fair's "Next Establishment" list, which was a sidebar to its annual "New New Establishment" list of media moguls, financial heavyweights and other power brokers.
A former vice president and an unpaid network of climate scientists laboring in obscurity for nearly 20 years shared the Nobel Peace Prize today.

"This has not been my week," Press Secretary Dana Perino joked over the weekend, a few days after a widely-circulated dust-up with Helen Thomas, a longtime White House correspondent who believes there's no such thing as a rude question. In the video, Ms. Perino strongly disagreed.
From DealBook's colleague, Micheline Maynard:

The award love this far in the season has been, as they say, highly distributed, with "No Country" and "There Will Be Blood" sitting on top of a very jumbled heap. Notable absences so far include "Atonement," "Into the Wild" and "Charlie Wilson's War."

Are you, like the Bagger, wondering why the negotiations between the writers and the producers are in the ditch, with no sign of improvement? Michael Cieply, an experienced Hollywood reporter and a colleague at the House of Many Doors, comes up with some analytics that suggest we all should have seen it coming.

The trial of Jeffrey Epstein, an intensely private New York money manager with several billionaire clients, is scheduled for early next month in Palm Beach, Fla. But in an encounter with Philip Weiss, who profiles Mr. Epstein in this week's issue of New York magazine, Mr. Epstein sounded remarkably relaxed for someone facing a seamy felony charge.
MBIA, the bond insurer, said on Monday that it had received a $1 billion investment from the private equity firm Warburg Pincus amid fears that the company would face a capital shortfall.
Tom O'Neil and Jeffrey Wells, crown princes in the Kingdom of Kudos, spend time deconstructing the critics' awards last night.

Variety points out that a great performance will pull a so-so movie into contention, in part because the Academy likes to reward significant work by significant actors. Film critic and historian David Thomson says the voters can look past flaws in a film and reward great work within.

We begin today with an interesting story from the Palm Beach Post's Marcus Nelson. Florida Atlantic is receiving a payout of $350,000 from the New Orleans Bowl. But most of that will be spent on team expenses surrounding the bowl game, with little of it making its way back to the university. Also, any money made from the bowl game will go into a pool that Florida Atlantic will share with the other Sun Belt Conference schools, even the four that don't sponsor football.

My erudite colleagues have disclosed certain Adamsian qualities that would greatly disturb a student of Adams and yet would be difficult to refute. He was a mid-19th-century equivalent of a Vietnam-era draft dodger, hiding behind his father's diplomatic frock coat during a war whose outcome had to do with nothing less than the character and destiny of his nation. He all too casually adopted crude stereotypes, especially where Jews were concerned, and evidenced a detachment from the colossal moral issue of slavery unbecoming to an enlightened and perceptive mind. He occasionally revealed himself to be, or to seem to be, an elitist, self-absorbed twit callously indifferent to the cares and woes of lesser mortals. And his outlook on the phenomenon and intricate operation of democracy itself was languid, to say the least, as if previous Adamses had said all that needed to be said on the subject and anything that might follow was mere froth.
Bolton, left, and Koda

During the month of December, for Democrats and Republicans alike, Iowa is the center of the universe. Beginning today, The Caucus presents a look at what's going on in the Hawkeye State, for those of you not lucky enough to be there.

Foreign governments often get portrayed as interlopers -- or something even more sinister -- when they take big stakes in domestic icons. But the subprime mortgage meltdown seems to have turned this tradition on its head. Now, foreign-owned firms and so-called sovereign wealth funds are being cast in the role of rescuer, stepping in with big buckets of money to cushion the blow of multibillion-dollar writedowns.

Of the four broadcast networks, ABC is the only one that has not announced plans for its January and February schedule, which will probably have to change because of the writers' strike. In Sunday's New York Times, Michael Cieply wrote that the alphabet network "could significantly increase its reality programming from the five to six hours it has run this fall":
Avista Capital Partners said on Monday that it had hired the former chief executive of Trico Marine Services to advise its energy practice.

-- In Sunday's Times Dave Itzkoff revisits the much-maligned ABC series "Cavemen" and finds glimmers of hope for the sitcom. "I voted for the strike... purely to try to save 'Cavemen,'" co-creator Bill Martin jokes.
The Southern California women's soccer team won the school's 107th national team title and 21st women's championship thanks to endurance, stifling defense and outstanding goalkeeping.

It turns out that the Nobel-winning geneticist who was "inherently gloomy about the prospect of Africa" is inherently 16 percent African, or an amount of "someone who had a great-grandparent who was African," according to a scientist who made the discovery.
One of Pete Seeger's songs has become something of an anthem for climate campaigners because it explores the "one blue sky above us."

Today we have more answers to your questions from Hongyan He Oliver, a research fellow at Harvard who is an expert on sustainable transportation in China. Ms Oliver's research focuses on technologies and policies concerning vehicle pollution control.

I have a feeling it's going to be a fun week: the Republicans have gone bilingual, Senators Clinton and Obama have taken off the gloves, and now The Wall Street Journal editorial board is singing the praises (well, kinda) of Harry Reid and company:

Be it a work of fashion, art or home design, in an era of hyper-vigilant P.R., a designer's "inspirations" aren't nearly as fun - or accurate - as guessing at them. Here, in The Moment's The Style Equation column, we use a rudimentary calculation to reduce a new design object to the sum of its parts. This week, the new Prada clutch.

The Bagger was down in Bagger HQ last night, working to reclaim his workspace from the tangle of broken Styrofoam, used ink cartridges and random bits of yarn that had overwhelmed it. While he was debating whether to throw out the power cord for a cellphone he lost three years ago, the critics in New York (the online variety), Washington, Boston and Los Angeles were concerning themselves with more pressing matters -- like whether the Coens or Paul Thomas Anderson had this year's most riveting take on the consequences of greed.

On Saturday night, the Bagger talked Shorty Bagger, age 11, into seeing "Starting Out in the Evening" by promising a huge spread of Vietnamese food. Never mind that the movie was not age-appropriate, sometimes the Bagger hates being that weird dude all by himself in the aisle seat of row three.

"Away From Her" got away from the Bagger when it was in theaters, but he caught up with a screener this week. At first, he was so grossed out by the gooeyness of the love story that he almost gave up and grabbed a Netflix copy of "Paris, Texas" he has had hanging around for a while. But then the movie began to pivot and turn in unexpected ways.

Investors everywhere should applaud the deal struck last week by the UnitedHealth Group to recover nearly $1 billion in pay from former executives involved in the company's option backdating mess, writes Gretchen Morgenson in The New York Times.
Careful to avoid alienating their audience, Republican presidential candidates kept the immigration policy talk light during yesterday's Spanish-language debate broadcast on Univision.

This week's Shifting Careers column is part of my "one on one" series, where I've been interviewing experts who bring creative thinking to the conversation about careers. This one is an interview with Jean Chatzky, a personal finance guru. (To catch up on the series, see earlier One on Ones with Dan Pink and Herminia Ibarra.)

The $60 billion Qatar Investment Authority said on Monday it saw "tremendous opportunities" for sovereign wealth funds like itself to invest in financial-services firms in the United States that had been battered by a mortgage market crisis.
Some of the country's largest banks are scaling back a plan set in motion by the Treasury Department to shore up troubled investment vehicles and calm the debt markets.

For years, the founders of CellCyte Genetics relied on infusions from angel investors to keep their tiny start-up afloat. But, The Seattle Times reports, after CellCyte combined with a moribund public company, its shares caught fire this fall in the loosely regulated over-the-counter market and on Germany's Frankfurt Stock Exchange.
Update: The Blackstone Group in a statement (PDF) Monday denied the rumor.

Two hedge funds that are the largest shareholders of Northern Rock are reportedly backing a proposal from a private investment company, Olivant, over one from the Virgin Group as returning the best shareholder value.

Two hedge funds appear to be taking aim at a cash pile held by Royal Philips Electronics. Jana Partners and the D.E. Shaw Group, which own about 1.6 percent of the company, announced that they have teamed up to review Philips's results and capital structure.
Travelport, the travel services group owned by buyout shop the Blackstone Group, has mandated five banks for its 1.4 billion euro ($2 billion) initial public offering, the Financial News reported.
Lafarge, the world's biggest cement maker, said it would buy the cement unit of Orascom Construction Industries of Egypt for 8.8 billion euros ($12.9 billion).

Private equity firms are being forced to put more of their own money into their struggling companies as the credit crunch has left banks and investors less willing to refinance ailing firms, according to a report from Reuters.

Barron's apparently likes the looks of JPMorgan Chase's prospects. In a bullish feature on Chase, the nation's third-largest bank, the publication noted that JPMorgan avoided most of the losses suffered by other investment banks and its growth could now "really accelerate."
Societe Generale, the French bank, will bail out its structured investment vehicle by taking on $4.3 billion of assets to avoid a fire sale.

Venture capital investments in the United States, Europe, China and Israel this year have passed the $30 billion mark and the industry is on course to post its highest investment total since 2001, according to a new report.

Kelso & Company, a private equity firm, said it would sell Del Laboratories, which makes Sally Hansen nail care products, to the fragrance giant Coty in a deal valued at about $800 million, according to The Deal.com.

Tribune is asking a federal appeals court to strike down an order by the Federal Communications Commission that would eventually require the company to break up newspaper-TV station combinations it operates in four markets.
An antitrust lawyer and former Federal Trade Commission official said that the Department of Justice should get tougher if it wants more timely compliance with merger divestiture orders.

The former newspaper mogul Conrad Black, convicted of swindling shareholders in his Hollinger International media empire out of millions of dollars, is due to learn just how steep a price he must pay.

Although weak demand forced Entropic Communications, a semiconductor company based in San Diego, to cut the size of its initial public offering, its stock rose 40 percent in its Nasdaq debut on Friday.
Gander Mountain, an operator of outdoor sports supply stores, said it will acquire a boating gear retailer Overton's for $70 million in cash.

Conduit Capital Partners said Friday that it had sold its stake in Inelec, a portfolio of three hydroelectric power plants in Mexico, to a Dutch subsidiary of the Italian utility Enel in a deal valuing the facilities at $193 million, including debt.

A medical device developer, NeuroVasx, raised $8.5 million in follow-on investment from previous backers to support completion of regulatory trials and a commercial introduction of implant technology to treat strokes in patients with brain aneurysms.

A Japanese drugmaker, Eisai, said on Monday it would buy a biotech firm in the United States, MGI Pharma, for $3.9 billion to expand in the United States and strengthen its pipeline in cancer treatments.

Henry Blodget, who was barred from the securities industry for the misdeeds he committed as a research analyst at Merrill Lynch, may be getting another shot at picking hot tech offerings for a big firm. But instead of using his experience to enrich an investment bank, this time Mr. Blodget would be working for Yahoo.
When it comes to the Congressional end game, one lawmaker's compromise is another's extortion.

UBS said on Monday that it would write down its subprime mortgage investments by $10 billion but would replenish its capital by selling stakes worth 13 billion Swiss francs to the Singapore government and an unnamed Middle Eastern investor.
