If you're in Soho this week and feel like seeing larger-than-life nude portraits of Bobby Orr and Derek Sanderson, you can. Kurt Kauper's realistic figurative paintings of the two Bruins icons of the early '70s are on exhibit at the Deitch Projects gallery on Grand Street through Dec. 15, and they're well worth the visit. But be forewarned: a couple of the paintings are full frontal nudes.
A suicide bomber drove a car full of explosives into a truck near an air force base. Five of the wounded were children.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Thousands of fishermen, soldiers and volunteers struggled on Sunday to clean up the worst oil spill in South Korea's history.
The police in Colorado Springs have identified a young man who they say shot and killed two people at an evangelical megachurch there.
In its first full concert since 1980, the band performed in tempos more graceful than those on its old live recordings.
A vast majority of Republican voters say they have not made a final decision about who to support in the primaries, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
Expanding on efforts to help low-income students, Harvard today announced aid increases for students from middle-class and upper-middle-class families.
Conrad M. Black was convicted of fleecing shareholders of Hollinger International out of millions of dollars.
In two decisions, the court said federal district judges have broad discretion to impose what they think are reasonable sentences, even if federal guidelines call for different sentences.
The settlement stems from accusations that the firm botched an audit of a pharmaceutical company by entrusting it to a partner it knew to be a poor auditor.

College students may be the targets of more marketing efforts than any other group of consumers. That’s why one recent campaign aimed at them took a nontraditional approach with a pitch that at first glance seems to be personal, hand-written notes rather than advertising.
After several false starts, the Toronto Stock Exchange and the Montreal Exchange announced a merger today valued at 1.31 billion Canadian dollars.
UBS became the latest bank to seek a lifeline from the East as it wrote down $10 billion in mortgage-related assets.

Twenty-six people were injured last night in a fire in an apartment building at 2334 Boston Road in the Bronxdale neighborhood, fire officials said. Most of the injuries were from smoke inhalation and were minor. But three people were seriously injured. One had a life-threatening heart attack, fire officials said. Of those affected, 14 were occupants, 11 were firefighters and one was an emergency medical technician. The cause of the fire was under investigation.
Drivers went on strike today at four companies that provide van rides for up to 9,000 passengers a day across New York City.
Another game, another loss, and the questions that haunt the Jets continue.
In a series of interviews, Tom Wolfe, the Rev. Al Sharpton and others discuss “The Bonfire of the Vanities” and the era it portrayed.

Giant Moon held off Spanky Fischbein by one and three-quarter lengths to win the $78,950 Damon Runyon Stakes for New York-bred 2-year-olds at Aqueduct.The colt, trained by Rich Schosberg, remained unbeaten in three starts by pulling clear in the deep stretch. His time was 1 minute 46.07 seconds for a mile and a sixteenth.

Floyd Mayweather Jr. is again saying that he will take an extended break from boxing, insisting he is “bored with the sport” after he stopped Ricky Hatton in the 10th round of their 147-pound title fight in Las Vegas on Saturday night. The end came after Mayweather landed a crushing left hook that dropped Hatton on his back. Hatton got up at the count of eight, but Mayweather (39-0) almost immediately put him on the ropes and landed another flurry of punches to the head.Hatton went down while the referee Joe Cortez moved in to stop the fight, and Hatton’s corner threw in the towel.“He was definitely the toughest competitor I’ve ever faced,” said Mayweather, who was ahead by 89-81 on two ringside scorecards and by 88-82 on the other when the fight was stopped.

Ohio State scored four goals in a 12-minute span in the second half to defeat visiting Bradley, 4-0, and advance to the N.C.A.A. College Cup. UMass also reached the College Cup, the Final Four of men’s soccer, by defeating visiting Illinois-Chicago, 2-1.

Arsenal lost its first game of the English Premier League season, falling at Middlesbrough, 2-1. Arsenal still has a one-point lead in the standings.Stewart Downing and Tuncay Sanli scored to give Middlesbrough its first win in any competition since Sept. 1. Tomas Rosicky scored in injury time for Arsenal.Arsenal leads the league with 37 points, followed by Manchester United with 36 and Chelsea with 34.

Woody Austin made a 35-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole to win the Merrill Lynch Shootout with his teammate Mark Calcavecchia in Naples, Fla. The two won by a shot over the tournament host, Greg Norman, and Bubba Watson.The putt gave the team a final-round nine-under-par 63 in the scramble format and a 29-under 187 total.Norman and Watson barely missed birdie tries from 25 feet after Austin made his putt. Norman’s ball ended up inches right of the hole, and Watson’s putt faded and broke in front of the hole to the left.Norman was trying to win for the first time since the 2001 Skins Game. Watson has not won as a professional.
Caron Butler scored 20 of his 28 points in the second half Sunday night, leading the Washington Wizards to a 104-89 victory over the Nets.
The cost of monthly unlimited-ride MetroCards would rise to $81 from $76, according to a memo sent to Metropolitan Transportation Authority board members.
Shootings at an evangelical missionary training center northwest of Denver and a megachurch 70 miles away left four people and a gunman dead and several wounded.
Pittsburgh Steelers safety Anthony Smith last week guaranteed a Steelers victory, learned a lesson in the Steelers’ loss Sunday: the Patriots will embarrass whoever doubts them.
An article on Saturday about efforts to harvest energy from ocean waves omitted a reporting credit. Erik Olsen contributed reporting to the article.
The Giants put just enough digits on the scoreboard to beat the Eagles and improve their record to 9-4, a mark that nearly guarantees a postseason slot.

The gantlet of abuse continued during halftime of the Jets’ game against the Cleveland Browns on Sunday at Giants Stadium, with hundreds of men chanting obscenities at a handful of women in the crowd.
Peyton Manning threw four touchdown passes, including the 300th of his career, and the Colts coasted past the Ravens, 44-20.
Craig Dahl and another rookie, Michael Johnson, started at safety for the Giants because of injuries to Gibril Wilson and James Butler.
Rudolph W. Giuliani plainly displayed the rawness of his promise and drive as U.S. attorney in the 1980s.
If Tim Tebow produces the same kind of breathtaking performances as he did this season, he will be among the favorites for the 2008 Heisman.

Friends and colleagues of Bob Kohler, a veteran gay rights activist who died at 81 on Wednesday, took to the streets of the West Village last evening, celebrating the life of the man they called a hero, a griot and a legend of the gay community.
Tony Romo and Jason Witten put mistakes behind them quickly enough to give the Dallas Cowboys the N.F.C. East title.
The Yankees added a veteran to their young bullpen Sunday, agreeing to terms with the right-hander LaTroy Hawkins on a one-year contract worth about $3.75 million.
Twenty years after the publication of “The Bonfire of the Vanities,” the milestone provides a moment to consider how the city’s own narrative has (so far) turned out.
In this, the third season of Wayne Gretzky’s Act II as a coach, the Coyotes are still expected to lose more often than they win. But this has been a year of major adjustments for Gretzky.

A man who spent a career in the shadows as head of the Central Intelligence Agency’s clandestine service has been thrust into the spotlight for his role in the destruction of interrogation videotapes.
A brutal murder case renews focus on issues of justice and morality in the debate over capital punishment in New Jersey.
As more Orthodox Jews move to Lakewood, N.J., drawn to its yeshiva, tension has arisen in a traditionally black neighborhood where new Jewish families are moving.
Hundreds of students at the University of Southern Maine have been barred from its campuses over mumps vaccinations.
Nicole Hosp of Austria raced to her first women’s World Cup slalom victory of the season Sunday, beating Tanja Poutiainen of Finland by 1.19 seconds in Aspen, Colo.

The Saints’ visions of a return to the N.F.C. title game seem like a distant memory after a season that has included a four-game winning streak and a four-game losing streak. The Saints’ latest loss is the all-purpose star Reggie Bush, who is out with a knee injury, but Drew Brees has enough options to cover for him. Three is the magic number for the Falcons, as in three wins, three years since their last playofff berth and three starting quarterbacks. Chris Redman will replace Joey Harrington, who has been benched — you guessed it — three times in 12 games. The good news? After tonight, only three games remain in the Falcons’ season. ANDREW DAS.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi must find a way to make the Matthew Shepard Act the law.
A weekly confrontation at a parking lot in Phoenix perfectly mimics the national debate over immigration.
Western investors are suing the Congo Republic to recover old debts that they bought for pennies on the dollar.
The change is part of a set of announcements in recent days showing that President Chávez is pressing ahead with policy initiatives despite losing last week’s referendum.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 — The Giants were already scampering to a celebration near their bench late in the fourth quarter when Philadelphia receiver Jason Avant raised his arm to make a last-ditch appeal for an official — any official — to pull out his yellow flag and fling it.
Kosovo, which has a majority of ethnic Albanians, has been trying to break away from Serbia, but Serbia is vehemently fighting to keep the province.
Mr. King helped make national stars of talents like Oprah Winfrey, Alex Trebek and Dr. Phil McGraw through King World productions, a company he co-founded.
An ice storm grounded flights and cut power to tens of thousands of people on Sunday from the Southern Plains to the Great Lakes.

A hearing was scheduled today for three men held in Trinidad who have been ordered to be extradited to the United States to face terrorism charges related to what prosecutors said was a planned attack on Kennedy Airport. The men, Kareem Ibrahim, Abdul Kadir and Abdel Nur, were charged in the summer by the United States attorney in Brooklyn of conspiring with a former airport cargo worker to attack jet fuel storage tanks and fuel lines at Kennedy. On Aug. 6, officials in Trinidad approved their extradition. Lawyers for the three men have appealed that ruling and will challenge the extradition order in San Fernando, Trinidad. Their lawyers were expected to argue the extradition would be a breach of the men’s rights.

The body of a woman found floating in the Narrasketuck River on Saturday morning has been identified, the Nassau County police said yesterday. The Nassau County medical examiner identified the woman as Yvonne Boykin, 46, of Lake Street, Massapequa, the police said. The body was discovered by a dog walker about 11 a.m., and the cause of death remained under investigation yesterday evening. Compiled by John Sullivan.

The Federal Aviation Administration should hurry its efforts to deploy new technology designed to prevent airplane collisions at New York area airports, Senator Charles E. Schumer said yesterday. Mr. Schumer said that despite the busyness of the area’s airports, it could be years before the new technology, which alerts air traffic controllers to potential collisions, including those on runways, is installed at all of the airports. A spokesman for the F.A.A. said the schedule for deploying the new equipment was based on several factors, including the business of airports and the complexity of the runway systems and procedures.
In Phoenix, mug shots of convicted drunken drivers are available to the entire world via a Web site started by the county attorney.

Four suspects were arrested yesterday after an early-morning robbery at an Applebee’s restaurant and a car chase that ended at the George Washington Bridge, the police said. Police officers began chasing the car after a robbery was reported at the restaurant, on Route 59 in Airmont, about 7:20 a.m., the Ramapo Police Department said. Officers from several departments joined the pursuit, which ended when the suspects’ car crashed into another car as it entered the upper deck of the bridge. One suspect was injured when he tried to escape by leaping to the bridge’s lower deck; a second was hit by a police car while trying to carjack another vehicle, the police said. Two other suspects were arrested in Fort Lee, N.J., one while hiding inside a trash bin, the police said. None of the suspects were identified yesterday evening.

Mr. Nolte was a Middle East expert whose three-week tenure as American ambassador to Egypt in 1967 ended when the country expelled him during the 1967 Middle East War, even though he had sympathized with the Arab cause.
No team in the 52-year history of the Big 5 has ever been on a winning streak like Villanova’s.
The “Fire Isiah” chants from the game crowd Saturday were as intense as ever, but Knicks ownership remains “emphatically behind” Coach Isiah Thomas.
Milan Hejduk had three goals and three assists, and Paul Stastny added two goals and three assists Sunday night to help the Colorado Avalanche to a 9-5 victory over the visiting St. Louis Blues.
Iranian students held a protest on Sunday at Tehran University to demand the release of fellow students who have been jailed in recent months.
President Alberto K. Fujimori will be the country’s first former head of state to be tried on human rights violations, including murder and kidnapping, on Monday.
Indiana Pacers guard Jamaal Tinsley and several companions were the apparent targets of a shooting Sunday morning that wounded one person outside a downtown Indianapolis hotel.
Mr. Golub developed early techniques for using computers to solve scientific and engineering problems.
State officials — struggling with escalating costs, competing demands and limited land — have had to shrink their ambitions with plans to expand the Javits Convention Center.
The world’s leaders say they care desperately about Darfur’s suffering, until they get distracted.
A worthy but imperfect amendment now pending in Congress would help curb junk foods sold in too many of the nation’s schools.
Federal officials have reached a new pact with several Western states on how to allocate water if the Colorado River runs short.
Rangers forward Brendan Shanahan broke through 30 seconds into overtime, sending a shot into the top corner of the goal for a victory.
Despite committing themselves to a new partnership of equals, European and African leaders conflicted over trade and human rights violations in Zimbabwe.
NASA on Sunday delayed the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis until at least Jan. 2 to give engineers time to diagnose and fix its balky fuel tank sensors.
Members of the stagehands’ union voted Sunday to ratify an agreement that includes a series of raises in return for some rules changes that theater producers had sought.
Peter Davi, a renowned big-wave surfer from Monterey, Calif., died Tuesday while riding giant waves at a spot he had helped pioneer off Pebble Beach. He was 45.
Steadily lengthening delays in the resolution of Social Security disability claims have left hundreds of thousands of people in a kind of purgatory, now waiting as long as three years for a decision.
The Jets earned their 10th defeat this season while the Browns, the surprise story in the N.F.L. this season, improved their playoff chances with the win.
Mr. Kracher was a visionary winemaker whose luscious sweet wines and forceful personality were instrumental in restoring the Austrian wine industry’s international reputation after a scandal in 1985.
Mr. Fiscuteanu was known to international audiences for his role in “The Death of Mr. Lazarescu.”
Having already won a Super Bowl ring in New England, Lawyer Milloy came south eager to pick up another championship before his career was done. What did he get himself into?
Michael Vick, the suspended Atlanta Falcons quarterback, faces a maximum of five years in prison for his involvement in an illegal dog fighting operation.
The Miami Dolphins are now so terrible that even their division rivals, the Buffalo Bills, are feeling sorry for them.

While standing on a corner waiting to cross a street, I found myself next to a toddler in a stroller jabbering to himself. Then I noticed that the little boy was actually playing with a colorful toy cellphone.
The move by the two main opposition parties led by Benazir Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif came as a call to boycott the elections foundered Sunday.
Dictionary publishers have discovered that announcing words of the year can be a valuable tool for attracting publicity.

Some of the country’s largest banks are scaling back a plan to calm the debt markets, making the new superfund look increasingly irrelevant.
Taiwan’s native son Ang Lee and his spy thriller “Lust, Caution” won seven prizes.
A revolving, lighted bronze statue of Ray Charles was unveiled on Friday in Albany, Ga., in the middle of a $2 million downtown plaza that bears his name.
Fans in London waited to be the first in line for Monday’s Led Zepplein concert.
Victoria Clark stars in an Encores! production of “Juno,” and David Hyde Pierce extends his engagement in “Curtains.”
Symphony Space will celebrate its 30th anniversary on Jan. 10.
The town of Monteleone di Spoleto, Italy, is suing three successive Italian culture ministers in its latest effort to recover a 2,600-year-old Etruscan chariot.
Led Zeppelin reunites in London, a new lawsuit is filed over an Etruscan chariot and more culture news.
The producers of three Broadway plays have come up with what they call a commercial subscription series.
Looking for ways to ease the complicated relationship between newspaper publishers and giant search engines like Google and Yahoo.
Ethan Coen makes his debut as a playwright, a Richard Nelson play premieres at the Public and more theater news.
A museum dedicated to the Swedish disco group Abba is to open in Stockholm in June 2009.
TiVo is trying to climb into the black by working with the companies it once threatened and moving away from the hardware that it pioneered.
Camille A. Brown celebrates the captive community of New York subway riders in her delicious “Groove to Nobody’s Business.”
Becoming an Internet phenomenon after posting a no-frills music video on YouTube, Tay Zonday has followed up with an advertisement for Dr Pepper.
Amid the financial pressures facing the newspaper industry, investigative journalism has been hit hard.
Mark Twain’s previously unproduced play, which is making its Broadway debut, has a remarkably sprightly step.
New releases from Beanie Sigel, The-Dream and Wu-Tang Clan.
Louis Rossetto, the co-founder of Wired magazine, is applying the language of high-technology business to chocolate making.

On June 6, Meryl Fenster, a retired public school teacher, arrived home to find a letter from her landlord taped to her front door. It said that her building — the last one on the Upper West Side to offer subsidized rental apartments under the state’s Mitchell-Lama program — was being sold to a private developer.

GIROUX--Vera, of Manhattan, died peacefully December 7, 2007. Beloved wife of the late John Giroux, adored mother of Paul and Noelle of Manhattan and Leigh of Rye, New York. She is also survived by five grandchildren, James, Hilary, Alexandra, Charlotte and Olivia and her sister Nancy Craigmyle of Carmel, California. Selfless, loving, known to all as ''Saint Vera,'' she will be deeply missed. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the NY Times Neediest Fund.

KRAMER PERLMUTTER-Mildred S. ''Millie'', 81, passed away peacefully at home in Sunrise, FL, after a courageous battle with COPD on December 7, 2007. Millie was predeceased by her first husband Sam. She is survived by her second husband Bob Perlmutter, daughter Elyse Dodgson, grandchildren Tamsin and Matthew and greatgrandchildren Lucas and Amelia. She also had stepchildren and a step-grandson. Millie was loved by all who met her and was exceptionally dear to her family and friends. She enjoyed a teaching career for 30 years in the New York Public School System. She spent the majority of her life in Brooklyn, NY then partially in Florida. The family will receive friends Tuesday, December 11, 1pm at Norman L. Jeffer Community Chapels, 718-333-1155.

MORAN--Tarja Kati, age 54, died suddenly on December 7th after a wonderful evening among loved ones. She introduced the beautiful customs of her native Finland to her adopted home of New York City. Kati warmed and enriched the lives of all who knew and loved her. She will be sorely missed. She leaves her husband, Dr. Thomas M. Moran, professor of microbiology at Mount Sinai Medical Center; beloved daughter, Maarit Moran, a recent McGill University graduate; mother-in-law, Mrs. Ruth Moran; sister-in-law, Barbara Moran of Connecticut; and many dear friends to mourn her loss. Go Yankees. The wake will be held Tuesday December 11th from 2-5 and 7-9pm and Wednesday, December 12th from 2-5pm McNulty Funeral Home. Full eulogy at www.fawnet.org

Are all the debates this campaign season helping voters decide which candidate to support? A recent poll suggests that they are. The poll, conducted by the Pew Research Center from Nov. 20-26, found that more than two-thirds of Americans said the debates were helpful, including one in four who called them very helpful.

MUNTER--Naomi Roth, January 3rd, 1917 to December 8th, 2007. Loving, beloved wife and mother. Adoring, cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Devoted, treasured sister, aunt, friend. We hold you in our hearts.

Francis Ford Coppola's ''Youth Without Youth'' opens on Friday. Heavy with symbolism and meditations about life, it is almost the opposite of his last film in 1997, the courtroom drama ''John Grisham's 'The Rainmaker''' (above, starring Claire Danes and Matt Damon). ''Youth,'' is a mix of genres, filmed in Romania with local actors, partly dubbed, philosophically ambitious and low budget. As the director told A. O. Scott in an interview in September, he wanted to have a new beginning with the film: ''I wanted to make a movie the way a film student would.'' SHELLY FREIERMAN

Jane Rule, a prominent Canadian writer whose first novel, ''Desert of the Heart,'' is considered a landmark work of lesbian fiction, died on Nov. 27 at her home on Galiano Island in British Columbia. She was 76. The cause was complications of liver cancer, said Deborah Windsor, executive director of the Writers' Union of Canada.

ActBlue, the Web site that helps anyone raise money for Democratic candidates, is asking the Federal Election Commission for permission to broaden its operations. Having helped raise more than $33 million since 2004 for Democratic candidates from individual donors, it now wants the commission's permission to help union, corporate and other membership political action committees that want to raise money.

The Democratic and Republican presidential candidates are holding debates in Iowa this week. After an eight-month blur of debates, that might not seem like stop-the-presses news. But these are the last debates before the Iowa caucuses. And they are taking place three weeks before Republicans and Democrats assemble to caucus on Jan. 3.

FORTOUL--Paul, 49, of New York City, died Saturday December 8th, 2007, after an all too short battle with kidney cancer. He is survived by his parents, Selma and Jose Fortoul, his sister Karen Fortoul, sister-in-law Kate Goodale, nephew Jamie Fortoul, niece Nora Fortoul, as well as cousins, an aunt, and an uncle. Andrew Imbrie, a prolific composer and influential teacher best known for his harmonically rugged but appealingly lyrical 1976 opera, ''Angle of Repose,'' and for a rich catalog of chamber, vocal and symphonic scores, died on Wednesday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 86. His death was announced by Robert Commanday, the retired chief music critic of The San Francisco Chronicle and a longtime friend.

OLIAN--Howard, North Shore Country Club records with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Howard Olian. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. N. Barry Ross, President Jeffrey Levy, Secretary OLIAN--Howard. We mourn the passing of our very dear friend, Howard -yet want to honor his wonderful but productive life. He was a man of many parts -truly loved by us and our families. Joan and Richard Bernhard Willa and Robert Bernhard Cecile and Jerry Shore OLIAN--Howard, of Sands Point, NY, died on December 7, 2007. Devoted husband of JoAnne, loving father of Jane and Pat, father-in-law and dear friend of Jerry Weintraub, adoring grandfather of Amy Rose Olian Weintraub; he is also survived by his loving sister, Evelyn Mollet and a close group of nieces and nephews. A graduate of Johns Hopkins University and Harvard College, he served honorably in the U.S. Navy during WWII in the Pacific attaining the rank of Lieutenant J. G. An enthusiastic entrepreneur, he established Westwood, Inc., an international textile concern. He was an avid fly fisherman, top-notch bridge player and championship golfer. Tough and crusty by nature, with an incisive mind, he was also the most generous and charitable of men. He will be dearly missed by all those fortunate enough to have known him. Funeral services will be held on Monday December 10 at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st Street. Contributions may be made to the Olian Foundation in memory of Howard Olian.

For all the hoopla that Oprah Winfrey brought to Senator Barack Obama's campaign yesterday at a football stadium in Columbia, S.C., it was one simple statement of fact that drew far and away the most explosive applause. That was when Mr. Obama declared, ''The name George W. Bush will not be on the ballot.'' There were other big moments, too. One was when Ms. Winfrey, to the tune of Aretha Franklin's ''Think,'' first stepped on the stage. The crowd, estimated by the Obama campaign at more than 29,000, went wild. (Mr. Obama said the crowd was the largest at any event this campaign season; it was also one of the largest seen before even a general election.)

Perhaps you missed it, but Saturday marked the 10th annual New York City SantaCon. On a single day each December, an informal, secretive, debauched and merry band of people dressed up as Santa Claus converge on the city for drinking and celebration. As the event’s not-safe-for-work-or-small-children Web site makes clear, the event has some strict rules. The organizers are anonymous. (“Who’s in charge? Santa.”) Press inquiries are not welcome.

In a front-page article, William Neuman examines some of the more unusual ideas being considered by the state commission studying how to mitigate traffic congestion in Manhattan. The ideas include banning the hailing of cabs in Manhattan below 86th Street, and instead installing taxi stands where cabs would be allowed to pick up passengers only at these stands scattered throughout the area; imposing license-plate rationing, under which, say, drivers with a license plate ending in 5 would be prohibited from entering the busiest parts of Manhattan on the 5th, the 15th or the 25th of every month; and significantly raising the cost of street parking, which could cost as much as parking in a garage.

The City Council issued a report today arguing that many residents above age 60 skip meals, go hungry or worry about how they are going to feed themselves. The report recommends expanding the number of senior centers that serve breakfast; allowing them to serve a second free meal; increasing financing so they can stay open seven days a week; and expanding the availability of home-delivered meals.

Bloomberg’s much-debated congestion pricing proposal mostly come from outside the city and on average have substantially higher incomes than other motorists.

In the 20 years I've been covering global warming, it's been hard to find a lot of laughs. There have been a few moments -- like when I was standing too close to an open-water gap in the floating sea ice at the North Pole, until a bearlike Russian camp worker pulled me back, explaining in broken English that a tourist had fallen into the 14,300-foot-deep, 28-degree water that way the year before. That's about as funny as it gets on my beat. I snapped the picture above as he was rushing over toward me.

At the turn of the last century, while working a flight from New York to Miami, I pushed the meal cart up the aisle and stopped to serve the first row of main-cabin passengers. Instead of cheese omelets with hash brown potatoes or Special K cereal and a banana, as had been our custom, the cart was loaded with bagels. I served one to a female passenger who looked up at me in disbelief. "Is that all?" she cried. "Is this breakfast?"

It took place in the plush 18th Century concert hall called the Casino de Paris, and was attended by hundreds of people, including racers and team members from every level in France from go-karting up to Formula One.

Critics have been lavish in their praise of "There Will Be Blood," Paul Thomas Anderson's reinvention of the Western, and the New Yorker's David Denby is no exception. Like many of his peers, Mr. Denby goes over the top and stays there in counting the ways in which the movie succeeds:

In 1948, Sayyid Qutb began his unhappy education in the United States. He arrived at a hinge moment in the evolution of American power, the dizzying, go-go, post-World War II days. Modernity - in the form of rising affluence, movies and sexually liberated women - hit Qutb in the face, and the sheer godlessness of the place overwhelmed him. He came on a scholarship to study at the Colorado State College of Education in Greeley, but during his two years there he also traveled to New York and California, the coastal pillars of American dynamism and technological progress. By the time he left in 1950 to return to Egypt, he had had his fill of American depravity - and had concluded that "Islam and modernity were completely incompatible." He was brimming with rage.

Still, Dom Bonvissuto of SI.com gleaned a few things from the game, like how the Saints don't need Reggie Bush and how Chris Redman is not the answer for the Falcons either.

The web site Eater.com reported this week that Death & Co., a popular East Village cocktail lounge, was in trouble and had closed temporarily, though it's expected to reopen in less than a week. There are apparently mistakes and problems with its liquor license. And it's long faced some community opposition.

Bobby Bowden gave his support to naming the Florida State offensive coordinator Jimbo Fisher his successor-in-waiting, which will help smooth the Seminoles' eventual transition to the post-Bowden era, writes Steve Ellis of the Tallahassee Democrat. David Whitley of the Orlando Sentinel writes that the move should help Florida State begin to attract high-profile recruits again.

For an object lesson in the dilemma facing investment banks these days, consider Cowen Group. Late Monday, the boutique investment bank said it had decided to raise the amount of its revenue set aside for compensation and benefits to 65 percent from 60 percent. On Tuesday, Cowen's stock slumped more than 10 percent.

But at the same time, the Globes become a piñata, whacked over and over for alleged hackery and excessive fanboy tendencies.

The Russian presidential campaign has ended before it began. That seems to be the dominant opinion of the Russian news media, a day after President Vladimir Putin endorsed the candidacy of his slight, soft-spoken protégé, Dmitri Medvedev, to succeed him in the country's top office.

DES MOINES -- We're using split-screens today, one watching an ice storm as it moves its way through the Midwest and possibly complicates the travel plans of candidates, and the other attuned to the presidential campaign as it pops up and down on the television during the early morning news here. The Republican candidates are beginning to return here in preparation for their debate on Wednesday; the Democrats' turn comes on Thursday -- and it's the last debate in this state before the Jan. 3 caucuses.

The retired first baseman David Segui said yesterday that he used steroids and purchased shipments of the drug from the former Mets clubhouse attendant Kirk Radomski, The Baltimore Sun reported on its Web site last night.Segui also repeated his June 2006 admission to ESPN that he used human growth hormone with a prescription. He told The Sun that he refused to talk to George J. Mitchell, the former senator whose report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball is expected soon. Segui said he did not want to betray the trust of other players.“I have nothing to hide. I have no problem talking about what I have done,” said Segui, who spent eight of his 15 major league seasons with the Baltimore Orioles. “But I never want any other players to think I was out there talking about their business.”.
Jeff Schultz and Quintin Laing scored in the second period last night to help the Washington Capitals to a 3-2 victory over the visiting Devils.
Citigroup’s board was locked in debate over its new leader Monday, with no clear consensus over who would be tapped.
Preventing relationships with employees from going sour - or worse yet, leading to legal action - often comes down to common sense.
Aaron White, 20, took the stand Monday in Suffolk County Criminal Court and told a jury that a group of white teenagers screeched up to his house and screamed profanities and anti-black epithets.

The China Petrochemical Corporation, known as Sinopec, signed a $2 billion agreement to develop Iran’s Yadavaran oil field. The field would produce 85,000 barrels a day in four years and an additional 100,000 barrels a day three years after that, China’s official Xinhua news agency reported, citing the Iranian oil minister, Gholam Hossein Nozari, above.

A Russian steel maker, the Evraz Group, announced its second acquisition in the United States this year, the purchase of Claymont Steel Holdings, a steel-plate maker based in Delaware, for $564.8 million. Evraz, Russia’s largest steel maker by domestic volume, said it would pay $23.50 a share for Claymont, valuing the company at a 6.8 percent premium to its close on Friday of $22.

Axel Springer, the European newspaper publisher, agreed to sell its 12 percent stake in the broadcaster ProSiebenSat.1 Media to the private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Permira Advisers for 509.4 million euros ($749.5 million). Kohlberg Kravis, based in New York, and Permira, based in London, are paying an average of 19.40 euros a share for the Springer stake. The two companies agreed last December to acquire 50.5 percent of ProSiebenSat.1 for 3.1 billion euros. Axel Springer is based in Hamburg, Germany.

Prudential Financial, the life insurer, acquired Round Hill Capital Partners Kabushiki Kaisha, a Japanese real estate management firm. Round Hill, established in 2001, previously provided asset management services to Prudential Real Estate Investors, Prudential said. Round Hill has arranged 19 investments for Prudential real estate totaling $1.5 billion. Terms were not disclosed. Prudential is based in Newark, N.J.

Jimbo Fisher will succeed Bobby Bowden as Florida State’s next coach — someday. Bowden, who has the most victories in major college football, has agreed to a deal for next season, his 33rd, with options to stay longer. But T. K. Wetherell, the university president, designated Fisher, the offensive coordinator, as “head-coach-in-waiting,” then skipped out of a somewhat unusual news conference without answering questions about the contracts, which are not yet completed.

The Balco founder Victor Conte Jr. is ready to meet with Dick Pound, the outgoing chairman of the World Anti-Doping Agency, to “provide detailed information involving a history of rampant drug use at the elite level of sport.” Conte, who pleaded guilty to operating a steroids distribution ring at the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative, said in an e-mail message that he planned to meet with Pound tomorrow in New York.

The main security budget of more than a billion dollars for the 2012 London Summer Games will be supplemented by a contingency of $486.8 million, monitored by the British parliament and the Metropolitan Police. Tessa Jowell, Britain’s Olympics minister, released a written ministerial statement yesterday, giving the government a detailed budget for the Games. She said she did not expect the $19 billion total budget announced in March to be exceeded.

Marion Jones’s relay teammates will get a chance to argue their case for keeping their Olympic medals, and the Greek sprinter Katerina Thanou will have to wait a few more months to learn whether she will get the gold that Jones won in the 100 meters. The International Olympic Committee said yesterday it would delay a decision on the reallocation of Jones’s five medals — three gold and two bronze — from the 2000 Sydney Games. In October, Jones admitted in federal court that she started using steroids before the Olympics. She has returned the medals.
The window washer who survived the fall Friday remained in critical condition Monday as relatives gathered to mourn his younger brother, who died in the fall.
A 37-seat commuter jet arriving at Kennedy Airport nearly collided with a Boeing 747 cargo jet on Sunday afternoon.
Kia Vaughn had 13 points and 15 rebounds to help sixth-ranked Rutgers defeat No. 11 California Monday night, 56-51, in Piscataway, N.J.
Most people in Village of Island Park do not even know about the $5.4 million fine in a federal civil rights case that has been hanging over their heads for 10 years.

The City of San Francisco filed a lawsuit claiming negligence by the owners and operators of the cargo ship that caused last month’s oil spill in San Francisco Bay. The suit accuses the ship’s owners and its pilot, John J. Cota, of violating state law by sailing the vessel under dangerous conditions. It also maintains that they failed to respond quickly enough to prevent a spill when the ship struck a bridge. The city is seeking compensation for the cost of dealing with the spill and damages for the economic impact on beaches, wildlife, fishing and tourism.

Nearly eight billion miles away, the Voyager 2 spacecraft has passed through a sonic boom of solar wind particles in the outer part of the solar system, NASA scientists said. On Aug. 30, the craft detected the speed of charged particles from the Sun passing it abruptly slowing from 700,000 miles per hour to 350,000 miles per hour. Over the next two days, the spacecraft passed through the boundary four more times as the solar system’s “termination shock” bubble expanded and contracted. Voyager 2’s twin, Voyager 1, passed through the boundary three years ago, in the opposite hemisphere and about a billion miles farther from the Sun. The new data confirm a squashed shape for the magnetic bubble enveloping the solar system, which has been pushed inward in the southern hemisphere. Both spacecraft will eventually exit the solar system, perhaps as soon as 7 to 10 years from now.

The federal Mine Safety and Health Administration has warned 20 companies that they may face sanctions as repeat violators of health and safety rules. The list includes coal operations in Kentucky, Tennessee, Virginia and West Virginia, as well as a cement plant in Kentucky. Each received a letter giving them 90 days to make significant improvements or face a temporary shutdown. The companies are the second group warned this year by the agency for repeated violations. Similar warnings were sent to eight operators in June.

The state should compensate nearly 41,000 Palm Beach County residents whose citrus trees were cut down during a failed decade-long effort to eradicate a harmful bacterium, a county circuit judge ruled. The destruction of the trees constituted a “taking” under the Florida Constitution, “requiring full and just compensation,” Judge Robin Rosenberg wrote. The class-action suit was filed against the State Agriculture Department on behalf of David and Lillian Mendez of Boca Raton, who had their citrus trees cut down in 2001 as the state tried to stop the spread of canker. A jury trial is set for March 31 to determine how much the state owes the plaintiffs.

The state attorney general has admitted having an affair with a former staff member, and the governor said he should resign if accusations including workplace sexual harassment were proved. The former staff member last month filed a civil rights claim against the attorney general, Paul Morrison, with the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. According to her account, the affair began in September 2005 and lasted about two years. The staff member, Linda Carter, also accused him of trying to influence a federal lawsuit involving a political opponent. Mr. Morrison, who is married and has three children, said Sunday that many of Ms. Carter’s claims were “patently false,” but he confirmed that they had had a relationship.
The investment bank became the latest to seek a lifeline from the East as it wrote down $10 billion in mortgage-related assets.
Harvard said that it would significantly increase the aid it offered students in the middle and upper middle classes.
Wildlife agencies are re-examining some longstanding approaches to cultivating waterfowl populations.
The two suspected leaders of a violent campaign of ethnic expulsions and killings, including the 1995 massacre of Muslims in the Bosnian enclave of Srebrenica are still fugitives.
Conrad M. Black was sentenced to 6 1/2 years in prison for fleecing shareholders of Hollinger International out of millions of dollars.
A clandestine branch of the C.I.A. gave advance approval for the destruction of videos of interrogations.
A 10-year-old indigenous girl was gang raped in her home community. Her nine rapists had not been given prison sentences partly because the judge found that the victim “probably agreed” to have sex.
A convicted rapist who has been in and out of prisons for decades has confessed to nine murders, including those of five women in Cape Girardeau, Mo.
While N.F.L. officials are proud of their program, antidoping experts say the framework and timing of N.F.L. testing allows players ample room to outmaneuver the tests.

LANDSMAN--Rebeline. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Rebeline Landsman. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memories bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, President Robert A. Calinoff, Secretary
FEDERMAN--Sheila. December 11, 1987. Mommy, you are in Jacob's eyes, Isabel's smile, Philip's spirit, my heart; but still I miss you. Jaime

FRIEDMAN--Hilda. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Hilda Friedman, beloved mother of Stephen Friedman and mother-in-law of Barbara Friedman, who have set a profound example of philanthropic leadership through their dedication and commitment to UJA-Federation and in so many other ways. The Friedman family has left a legacy of hope for countless individuals touched by their generosity through their continued involvement in the New York Jewish community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Hilda's children, Stephen and Barbara, Phyllis and Brad, and Richard and Joanna; to her grandchildren; to her great-grandchildren; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

EISING--Marie. The Board of Trustees, management and staff of the Jewish Home & Hospital mourn the passing of Life Trustee, Marie Eising. Marie was a strong supporter and good friend to both Sarah Neuman Center for Healthcare and Rehabilitation, where she became a Trustee in 1973, and The Jewish Home & Hospital. Her passion was always the quality of life for our elders. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her daughter, Susan E. Serphos of Mamaroneck, and Richard A. Eising, Jr., and their families. We will all miss her. Gene D. Resnick, M.D. Chairman of the Board Audrey S. Weiner, DSW President & CEO

FORTOUL--Paul. We deeply mourn the loss of Coach Paul Fortoul. His extraordinary intelligence and unfailing kindness motivated us; his friendship inspired us. SMITH--David William, 63, died on December 5, 2007, as the result of a cycling accident in New York City. Recording engineer of the town hall and president of Triton Sound. Survived by his son Christopher Nalla Smith, sister Jacqueline, brother Stephen, and companion the Reverend John W. Moody. Memorial service at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street on Tuesday, December 11th, at 1:30pm. Contributions in David's memory can be made to a charity of your choice.
SWEIG--Marc B. Beloved husband of Hillary, devoted father of Samara and Marissa, dear brother of Harvey. Service is on Tuesday, 11:30am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Avenue.
GILBERT--Zena, we will miss your calm and grace, your full backswing and giggle when you walloped the ball, your positive attitude and zen approach to golf and life. Your golfing pals at Atlantic.
MARSH--Penelope C. ''Penny''. 2/14/41-12/11/04. Remarkable lady. Remembered with love. -Val

10 P.M. (WE) TWISTER SISTERS Bag the Oz jokes. Melanie Metz and Peggy Willenberg (from left above) are more hard core than Dorothy could dream of being. In 2003, after meeting on a Web site for storm chasers, they joined forces to form a company that takes visitors on severe-weather safaris throughout Tornado Alley. This new series starts with a journey from Liberal, Kan., to Amarillo, Tex. Alongside the Twister Sisters are David and Dellene Gill, who despite being divorced have booked the trip with their 16-year-old daughter, Destiny. 8 P.M. (BBC America) LIFE ON MARS Sam Tyler, the time-traveling detective played by John Simm, is still trying to figure out the meaning of his life -- and extract himself from the 1970s -- in the premiere of this BBC show's second and final season. Could the answer lie with some ghosts from his present -- make that future -- that have shown up in his past? David E. Kelley's adaptation of the series is expected to be shown on ABC during the 2008-9 season.

Investigators found a body in a garbage bag yesterday afternoon in a first-floor apartment on East 222nd Street in Willamsbridge, the police said. Officers responding to a call about a foul odor in the building found the body. The victim's identity and the cause of death were unknown, the police said. The body was taken to the medical examiner's office for an autopsy.
POMERANTZ--Belle. December 11, 1907-January 24, 1994. Happy 100th Birthday. You will always be the ''Belle of the Ball''. Love, Rhoda

KRAMER--Seymour. Be loved and dedicated husband of Rhoda, father of Samuel and Harry, father-in-law of Debra and Molly, grandfather of Caroline, Ben, Jeremy and Emma, died peacefully at home on December 8th, 2007. Known to his friends as Jake, he always liked to remind us, with a smile, that: ''It's a Barnum and Bailey World, Just as Phony as It Can Be''.

BECKER--Stanley R. Died December 8, 2007 at age 89. Loving husband of Zelma Becker and father of Hilary Oran, Joni Becker and Betsy Salinger. Devoted husband of Betty Ann and stepfather of Michael and Kim; loving grandfather to Olivia, Gannon, Gregory, Avery, Oliver, Holly and Anna. Served as a Naval Officer in World War II on the U.S.S. Maumee fueling Allied conveys in the Atlantic. Graduated from Union College in 1940, and maintained a 65 year relationship contributing to the revitalization of the school's infrastructure and providing financial support for the education of numerous students. A successful real estate developer, he retired to pursue his love affair with the sea. An adventurous offshore sailor, he sailed across the Atlantic, and at age 70 survived an encounter with Hurricane Grace in the Perfect Storm. Interested in education and healthcare, he served on the Boards of Southampton Hospital and The East Hampton Heathcare Foundation. A memorial service will be held at 12pm on Wednesday, December 12, at Yardley & Pino, 94 Pantigo Road, East Hampton, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The East Hampton Healthcare Foundation, 200 Pantigo Place, East Hampton, NY 11937 and UJA-Federation of New York.

Department of Education officials announced yesterday that they were closing Canarsie High School in Brooklyn, which received an F report card under the new schools' grading system. According to education officials, the school had a graduation rate of roughly 32 percent in the 2006-7 school year. The school will stop accepting freshmen next year and will be phased out over four years. It joins a list of 13 other schools whose closings were announced in the past week.

''I've been very close to him for more than 17 years and fully and completely support this candidacy.'' PRESIDENT VLADIMIR V. PUTIN of Russia, endorsing a protégé, Dmitri A. Medvedev, as his successor.

FRISCHLING--Louis B. On December 9, 2007. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Cherished father of Melissa, Elisa, Craig and father-in-law of Janet. Father-in-law to be to Marvin. Loving grandfather of Dani, Robbie, Ariel, Julia and Elana. Brother of Reggie and Saul. Brother-in-law of Joan and Christine. Adored uncle, nephew, cousin and friend. Leader, visionary and co-founer of Lipo Chemicals, Inc. and affiliated companies worldwide. Lou was an innovator and respected entrepreneur who touched the lives of many with his creativity and passion. Services were held Monday at Temple Sinai of Long Island. In Lou's memory contributions may be made to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation. www.multiplemyeloma.org FRISCHLING--Louis. We mourn the loss of our beloved member, devoted supporter, and pillar of strength. Temple Sinai of L.I. Carole Neely, Steven Blaustein, Co-Presidents Rabbi Paula Winnig

A brief art review in Weekend on Friday about paintings by Konrad Klapheck, at the Zwirner & Wirth gallery on East 69th Street, misstated the history of his shows in New York. He had one at the Edward Thorp Gallery in 1993; the Zwirner & Wirth show is not his first in New York since his debut at the Sidney Janis Gallery in 1969.
BALL--Bill, 2 years today. I remember you -You're the one who made my dreams come true, a few kisses ago. Ol

An influential Democratic legislator asked Attorney General Anne Milgram yesterday to investigate the estranged brother-in-law of a former companion of Gov. Jon S. Corzine. The request, made by State Senator John H. Adler, focuses on Rocco Riccio, a former state employee whose sister-in-law is Carla Katz, an influential labor leader whom Mr. Corzine dated from 2002 to 2004. Earlier this year, after questions were raised about whether Mr. Riccio had been sifting through tax returns for political purposes, Corzine administration officials asked Mr. Riccio to resign. Later, Mr. Corzine gave Mr. Riccio $10,000, and one of Mr. Corzine's lawyers gave him $5,000. Officials say Mr. Corzine was merely trying to help Mr. Riccio, who was in financial peril.

The chief of staff to the deputy mayor for economic development has announced that he will leave the city government and accept a post in private business in January. The official, James Whelan, will join Muss Development, a real estate developer, as senior vice president for public affairs, the company said yesterday. Mr. Whelan served under Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff, who recently announced that he was leaving city employment to become president of Bloomberg L.P. in February.

KAHGAN--Marc Paul, M.D., on December 6, 2007. Left us calmly and quietly. His last words were ''I Love You'' and he knew we loved him. He was a brilliant man, a graduate of M.I.T. and Tulane medical school, who abandoned a science career to become a psychiatrist and healer. He was loved by all and much appreciated by his colleagues and patients. He was the beloved son of Jack Kahgan and sister Caren Kahgan, and stepson to Ruth Kahgan, who cherished him as well.
BERNSTEIN--Ray. 12/11/05. It's 2 years, and forever in our hearts. Milton
ZIFF--Charles Elliot, 12.11.1949 to 7.4.1992. The conqueror of my heart, I have always loved and will love you forever. Joel

A former drug dealer who ordered the killings of an 8-year-old boy and his mother in 1999 was formally sentenced to death yesterday at an emotionally charged hearing in State Superior Court. The defendant, Russell Peeler Jr., was convicted in 2000 of ordering his younger brother to kill Karen Clarke and her son, Leroy Brown Jr., in their Bridgeport duplex. The boy was expected to be the key witness against Mr. Peeler in the fatal shooting of Ms. Clarke's boyfriend. In court yesterday, a shouting match erupted between Mr. Peeler and Ms. Clarke's brother Oswald Clarke.

(Nancy Schwartz), fond grandmother of Scott (Gail), loving greatgrandmother of Ashley, beloved aunt of many nieces and nephews. The family will receive friends at The Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, NY, on Wednesday, December 12th, at 11am. Religious services will follow 12 noon at the funeral home. Interment, Sharon Gardens Cemetery. Shiva will be observed at the family residence on Thursday, from 10am to 8pm and Friday, 10am to 6pm. KRAMER--Isabel. My dear sister, Isabel Kramer, a very special person. Loved by all and will be missed by all. Rest in peace. With all my love, Lillian KRAMER--Isabel Ruth, of Manhattan (formerly of Hewlett and Brooklyn, NY), beloved mother, grandmother and sister, passed away suddenly on Monday, December 10, 2007 at age 90. Born on January 27, 1917, Isabel grew up in Brooklyn, NY, and Scranton, PA. After marrying Sol Kramer, her husband of 46 years, they managed Ben & Sol's Deli near Ebbets Field for many years. Isabel is survived by her sister, Lillian, her children, Joan and Michael, her grandchildren, Sharon, David, Jason, Rob and Adam, and scores of greatgrandchildren, nieces and nephews. She was dearly loved and will be deeply missed. Funeral at Riverside Chapel (76 and West End) on Wednesday at 11:15am.

A man who was charged in May with fatally stabbing his companion, Claudette Marcellus, and wounding her son was charged yesterday with another killing, prosecutors in Brooklyn said. The Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, announced yesterday that the man, Jacques Dorcinvil, 31, was also charged with killing another former companion, Maria Santiago, 34, in 2003. Prosecutors say that Mr. Dorcinvil stabbed Ms. Santiago in the neck because he thought she had stolen money from him.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer appointed a panel yesterday to develop policies to discourage sprawl and promote better land use. The group will consist of officials from environmental conservation, transportation and economic development agencies, officials said. The governor has already started efforts to control sprawl in the Lower Hudson Valley, the Adirondacks and the central Catskill region.

The Pleasantville Board of Education president, James A. Pressley, left, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to attempted extortion, admitting that he accepted more than $40,000 in bribes from federal agents posing as businessmen seeking contracts with the Pleasantville School District. Mr. Pressley, 23, admitted that he took bribes in exchange for assistance in obtaining contracts for a fictitious roofing company and for his votes on a fictitious insurance contract. He was arrested on Sept. 6 with 10 current and former public officials.

STRAUSMAN--Edward. Dear Poppa, you are the strongest man I know. I know you are at peace now with grandma Belle. I thank you for all your unconditional love. You and I shared such a wonderful understanding of each other and always made one another smile. Words cannot express how much you mean to me. Thank you for being such a wonderful dad to Jonny. You meant the world to him. I am still here holding your hand, I love you forever. Your daughter, Eve STRAUSMAN--Edward, in his 90th year. Loving husband of Gabriela. Loving father of Eve (Jonathan) Winston, Lisa (Gregg) Fortunoff and Victoria Shapiro. Dear grandfather of Paris, Parker, Skye, Benjamin and Oliver. Loving brother of George (Nancy) Strausman. Dear uncle of Samuel Strausman, Susan Rietti and David Strausman. As much as he loved all of us, we love him even more. Veteran of World War II, Chairman of Strausman Construction Company. He will be greatly missed, but our memories of his sense of humor and good deeds will live on in our hearts. Funeral services will be Wednesday, December 12th at 1:30pm, at Temple Emanuel, Hicks Lane in Great Neck. The family will be sitting shiva at 160 West Shore Rd., in Great Neck, Wednesday and Thursday until 8pm, and Friday until 5pm. STRAUSMAN--Edward. Dear Poppa, we will always remember eating ice cream Sunday night and painting pictures for you. We loved playing in your beautiful garden and will treasure every memory of you. We love you so much. Love Paris, Parker and Skye Winston STRAUSMAN--Edward. Our Papa, you are our strong hero. We thank you for loving all of us so much and taking such good care of us. We love you more than you could have imagined. Love, Lisa, Greg, Benny, and Oliver.

The owner of three seafood restaurants in Lower Manhattan pleaded guilty yesterday to evading $1.1 million in sales and payroll taxes at the restaurants. The Manhattan district attorney's office accused the owner, Eric Tevrow, 51, of failing to report nearly $1 million in sales tax collected at the restaurants -- Shore, Fresh and Coast -- over four and a half years. He was also accused of stealing $133,000 in payroll taxes from Coast and Fresh. Coast closed in 2005 and Shore in 2004, prosecutors said. Mr. Tevrow pleaded guilty to grand larceny in exchange for a sentence of four months in jail and an agreement to pay restitution, as well as what prosecutors said could amount to $1 million more in interest and penalties. His lawyer, Michael Handwerker, said that business had proved difficult near ground zero and that Mr. Tevrow had put all the money he is accused of stealing back into his restaurants.

A 21-year-old woman was found tied up and dead in her apartment in Passaic on Sunday night, the Passaic County prosecutor, James F. Avigliano, said yesterday. An autopsy concluded that the victim, Kimberly Santos, died of asphyxiation, he said. Detectives are investigating the case as a homicide, he said, adding that the last time someone spoke to Ms. Santos was thought to be Saturday evening. Investigators said that Ms. Santos's roommate found her body when she returned from a trip, and alerted Ms. Santos's family, who live nearby and operate a store below the apartment. The parents called the police.

With the New York attorney general conducting a sprawling investigation of the state pension fund, the Spitzer administration sought to shore up Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli’s efforts to improve oversight and internal controls over the $154 billion fund.Under a new regulation issued by the insurance commission — which has special jurisdiction over the comptroller’s office — a new audit committee will be created to review internal and external audits as well as a new actuarial committee to review the assumptions used to calculate the benefits payments the fund will make in the future.

The State Department of Transportation today settled a longstanding lawsuit with Amtrak over a never-completed project to bring high-speed rail to the Albany-New York run. And though the settlement will not itself bring the project to fruition, it may open the door to significant capital and track improvements that could bring down times on the train ride deeply familiar to, among others, Albany lawmakers from downstate districts, who take the train twice a week during much of the year.

The warming Arctic is again making news, with a heap of findings unveiled at the fall meeting of the American Geophysical Union in San Francisco. There's new evidence that polar bears have squeaked through past Arctic warm spells. And there are fresh findings on why the sea ice around the North Pole has seen dramatic summer retreats lately. That's a subject dear to my heart ever since I got to spend three days with a climate team near the North Pole.Bear Facts[UPDATED below, 12/13]The BBC reported Monday on the discovery in Norway's Svalbard archipelago of a polar bear jawbone that appears to be at least 110,000 years old. This is significant because it could confirm genetic hints that the species has lived through at least a couple of protracted warm spells in which Arctic temperatures were likely several degrees warmer than at present. (Polar bear remains are rare because they spend so much time patrolling far from land.) The bone was discovered by Olafur Ingolfsson of the University of Iceland.

Somehow, around 5 tonight, I ended up on Fifth Avenue, in the thick of holiday shoppers. I saw a man carrying a large cream Jimmy Choo bag, his fingertips lightly extended as though it were a basket of eggs; whatever was in the box, it had cost him enough to feel proud and, I suppose, pleased with himself. All those crisp, pleated shopping bags and the sense of having bought something special for someone, or at least having made a decision-it throbbed along the avenue. I was armed myself, with a large silvery white book, appropriately called "Be Dazzled! Norman Hartnell." The 268-page book (Pointed Leaf Press) had come into my office, among others, and as I cracked it open, out came, it seemed, the froth of the British Empire. It's a stunning book, full of information and surprise. Bill Cunningham, as cheery as Santa Claus, stopped by my desk and immediately took notice. "He was at his best for the Queen Mother," Billy said of Hartnell, who began making clothes in the 1920s and died in 1979 (with few material possessions, apparently).

I saw my first iPod vending machine a little over a year ago at Atlanta's Hartsfield-Jackson Airport. It looked pretty much like a vending machine from which you buy Skittles and Doritos, except boxier and you stick in your credit card and out comes a $250 iPod. I've since seen a few more of these at other airports. I've never seen anyone actually buy anything from them, but I often see people gathered around them, the looks on their faces saying, well, here's more evidence that America has finally gone off the rails.

The big question you hear right now if you cover politics for a living - and thus no one thinks you're really good for talking about more interesting things, like, say, the celebrity version of "The Apprentice" - is just what's happening to Hillary Rodham Clinton. A month ago Washington had moved on to speculating about her running mate (my guess if she wins Iowa: Tom Vilsack); now she's in a three-way tie in Iowa and losing her lead in New Hampshire faster than Mitt Romney changes positions. Is she seriously in danger of coming undone? Is she still in command of the race? There is an appropriately Clintonian way to answer these questions, which is yes to both.The first presidential campaign I covered was Bill Bradley's 2000 run against Al Gore. (I met my wife on that campaign, so it wasn't a total loss.) People forget this now, but there was a moment, at about this time in 1999, when Mr. Bradley came stunningly close to stealing the Democratic nomination. Mr. Gore was a sitting vice president, with all of the institutional support in the party, as well as the labor unions and the interest groups and the big-money bundlers and the bulletproof limo and, of course, the prosperity and relative peace of the Clinton years at his back. And yet here was Mr. Bradley, three years removed from his last public office, surging to a lead in New Hampshire and gaining so much ground in Iowa, a state in which he hadn't even planned to compete, that his campaign decided to send dozens of staff there. (It was, in retrospect, a huge tactical blunder, but Iowa is like that, tantalizingly within reach one minute and 56,000 square miles of pure quicksand the next.) In those tense weeks, you could almost hear the monstrous machinery of the Democratic establishment squeak as it teetered away from Gore.

The oddities of the Iowa caucuses make polling Iowa something most pollsters would rather not do. BHP Billiton said on Wednesday it was considering possible next moves in its attempt to open takeover talks with a rival mining company, Rio Tinto, which has so far rebuffed its overtures.
As the credit crisis sweeps wildly through Wall Street, major investment banks face a grim truth about their already-slumping profits: the worst is yet to come.
Classmates Media, which runs the social-networking Web site Classmates.com, withdrew its initial public offering, its parent company, United Online, said Wednesday.
An automatic teller machine operator, Cardtronics, faced difficulty getting cash from the market for initial public offerings in its stock market debut on Tuesday, according to MarketWatch.
The future of the Sparrows Point steel mill remains uncertain as negotiations between the proposed buyer, an international investment group, and the seller drag on for a fourth month.

No, it's not a commentary on the real-estate market. Rather, Daniel Czapiewski's Upside-Down House in Szymbark, Poland, is meant as a rebuke of the Communist era, among other things. From this gallery of odd houses. Also, there's this video:
Shares of ChinaEdu, a Chinese company that offers online degrees, closed 20 percent below their initial public offering price of $10 in their first day of trading on Nasdaq.
Lehman Brothers's chief is getting a tip for successfully guiding the company through the mortgage meltdown.

Scrapblog, the scrapbooking Web site, announced Monday that it had raised an undisclosed amount of funds from Steamboat Ventures, the venture capital arm of Walt Disney, as part of its first round of funding. Along with the investment, David Min, principal of Steamboat Ventures, has joined Scrapblog's board of directors.

REVShare, an 18-year-old television advertising broker, raised $20 million in funding from the Carlyle Group and HIG Ventures. It will use the capital to cash out founders' equity and expand its bidding platform, which allows advertisers to purchase time on a cost-per-action basis similar to Web advertising exchanges, The Deal wrote.

A high-capacity wireless equipment developer, E-Band Communications, raised $10 million to fund continued development and volume production of systems to allow carriers and enterprise customers to transmit high-bandwidth traffic.

Babcock & Brown is pushing deeper into the United States after agreeing to take over MidCon, owner of the Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America, in a deal valuing the business at 7.6 billion Australian dollars ($6.7 billion), including debt.

Xstrata, the world's fourth-largest copper producer, said it is in talks with a "number of parties" on issues including mergers. The talks cover "a range of topics of mutual interest such as industry consolidation," the company said Wednesday.
From a Times article today about a dysfunctional family court in the Bronx that can only be reached via barely functioning elevators:
Delphi filed papers outlining a proposed $447 million sale of its global steering and halfshaft business on Monday, the same day a New York judge entered an order approving its disclosure statement.

The rivals battling for Northern Rock, the troubled British lender, have been whittled down to two after the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management dropped out of the running, according to The Times of London.
The Australian grocery chain Woolworths has had fresh talks with a New Zealand retailer, The Warehouse Group, about a possible takeover offer, according to Reuters.

Crown, an Australian gaming group, has agreed to pay $1.8 billion in cash to acquire Cannery Casino Resorts, which operates three Las Vegas gambling halls as well as a racetrack and casino in Pennsylvania.

JDS Uniphase, a maker of telecommunications equipment, has agreed to buy American Bank Note Holographics, whose holograms are used by MasterCard and Visa, for $138 million in cash and stock, the companies announced Tuesday.

While the influx of free and low-cost video has hurt the sale of pornographic videos, the chief executive of the Penthouse Media Group remains so bullish on the sex-related entertainment industry that he is investing $500 million in a group of social networking sites.

I miss the battle of Quebec. It wasn't uncommon for Nordiques and Canadiens to exchange unpleasantries in warmups. The Battle of Alberta lives on with both teams intact. But it's hardly the same as when Mark Messier and Joel Otto would lean in for a faceoff like two enraged bulls, with Tim Hunter and Dave Semenko snorting along the circle.
Univision Communications faces a new lawsuit that could hinder the auction of its music business, The New York Post reported.

Cerberus Capital Management, the United States-based private equity firm, is considering a takeover of a troubled Belgian imaging technology group, Agfa-Gevaert , according to a report in Belgian daily De Standaard.

As Hong Kong struggles under a daily cloud of noxious fumes from local traffic and nearby factories in mainland China, the Hong Kong Stock Exchange is considering using its financial muscle as part of a solution.

The Securities and Exchange Commission plans to delay for another year the requirement that small companies report on the state of their internal financial controls, the agency's chairman, Christopher Cox, is expected to tell lawmakers Wednesday.

A principal witness in the stock-options backdating trial that ended in a conviction of Gregory L. Reyes, the chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, has told associates her testimony may have been untrue, according to court documents.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil fraud complaint against the former auditor of San Diego on Monday, a rare step reflecting the agency's concern about the quality of the information that governments provide to municipal bond markets.
Richard Breeden, the Securities and Exchange Commission chairman turned activist investor, said Tuesday that H&R Block was determined to take its lumps and "move forward."

How a former governor with no money, no organization and no real policy platform or international know-how — but with lots of religious faith, populist sentiment and folksy friendliness — has changed the dynamics of the Republican presidential race.
“The Perfect Holiday,” directed by Lance Rivera, is that most dispiriting product, a formulaic movie that doesn’t believe in itself.
