Detroit's seven-game winning streak has lifted the Red Wings to the No. 3 slot in the World Top 10. The Motor City side are the only dominant club in the N.H.L., which so far this season has seen unusual parity. (Only 12 standings points separate the overall 3rd-place team from 30th going into Tuesday's games.) But with this latest streak, the Wings threaten to open up a lead as intimidating as Salavat's in the Russian Superliga.

Bobby Petrino quit Tuesday as the Falcons' head coach and, honestly, who can blame him? Well, for starters, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution's Jeff Schulz can. John Czarnecki at Foxsports.com says Petrino would never have lasted in Atlanta and, with Petrino leaving the Falcons with a 3-10 record after their 34-14 loss to the Saints on Monday night, it makes you wonder why N.F.L. teams consider hiring college coaches in the first place. What do the Falcons do now? Exactly what everyone does when a coaching job comes open: Call Bill Cowher. ...As a side note, early in that Monday night loss, Falcons receiver Roddy White scored a touchdown. White, who is having his best pro season without the disgraced quarterback Michael Vick, then lifted up his jersey to reveal a homemade T-shirt with the words, "Free Mike Vick."
Yahoo Finance, the most popular business news Web site, will begin distributing content from the business news channel CNBC on Wednesday.

In recent days, Mike Huckabee, a Republican presidential candidate, has mischaracterized his record and past statements on two subjects: one relating to the federal government's response to the AIDS crisis in the 1990s and another about his lack of knowledge of a report finding that Iran had halted its nuclear weapons program in 2003.
“Nanking” is a swift, incisive documentary about one of the lesser-known horrors of the 20th century.
Rosé Champagne has its say.
A judge upheld a law regulating greenhouse gas emissions from vehicles in another legal defeat for the car industry.
The agency failed to provide full information about videos of Al Qaeda interrogations, Gen. Michael V. Hayden said.
The step would effectively kill Democrats’ hopes of expanding a popular government program aimed at providing insurance to youngsters in lower-income and middle-income families.
Overriding the safety concerns of its regulator, the Canadian government is rushing through legislation to reopen a reactor that produces most of the world’s supply of a diagnostic isotope.
Researchers have found evidence that evolution produced a stronger and more flexible lower spine for women.
The small business lobbying group that had a big part in derailing Hillary Clinton’s effort to overhaul health care in the early 1990’s has staked out its position for the 2008 political season.
A ferocious fire swept through a two-story house in New Jersey early Wednesday morning, killing four people from three generations of a family.
Close to a million homes and businesses in the nation’s midsection remained without power as another winter storm developed.
A new move is the most aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system since the terrorist attacks of September 2001.
The unpredictable nature of the state’s caucuses make polling Iowa something most pollsters would rather not do.
Even though the Nets offered a $10 ticket special, the crowd was one of the smallest of the season for a team that was booed as the 8-12 Clippers pulled away.
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Tuesday that other NATO countries must fill gaps in the alliance’s Afghan mission, because the main focus of the United States had to be on Iraq.
Vikram S. Pandit confronts the daunting task of shoring up the company, which has been brought to its knees by the mortgage crisis.
Even as a reserve, LeBron James sparked the Cleveland Cavaliers.

Because of an editing error, an Agence France-Presse report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about the next music director of the Vienna Opera, Franz Welser-Möst, misstated the most recent action with regard to his appointment. He signed his contract on Sunday; he was not named to the post (that occurred in June). The report also misidentified the man Mr. Welser-Möst is succeeding. He is Seiji Ozawa, not Ioan Holender. (Mr. Holender, the general director of the opera, will be succeeded by Dominique Meyer.).

A front-page article on Monday about the impact of Western creditor lawsuits on the Congo Republic and other heavily indebted developing countries in Africa misstated the size of the Congo Republic’s debt as of December 2004. It was $8.5 billion, not $8.5 million.
A sports article on Monday about the Browns’ 24-18 victory over the Jets referred incorrectly in some copies to a tight end for Cleveland. He is Steve Heiden, not Eric.

A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup on Tuesday about Arsenal de Sarandí’s championship last week in the Copa Sudaméricana misidentified the team it defeated for the title. It was Club América, not Chivas of Guadalajara. (Arsenal defeated Chivas in the quarterfinals.).
An article on Sunday about a 100-year-old Zen master in New Mexico misspelled the name for a Zen meditation hall. It is zendo, not zenda.

A jazz entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about the Jim Hall Trio, at the Village Vanguard this week through Sunday, misidentified the sidemen who are playing with him. The bassist and drummer are Scott Colley and Lewis Nash — not Steve LaSpina and Terry Clarke, who also play with Mr. Hall.

The Well column in Science Times on Dec. 4, about Heather Kuzmich, a former contestant on “America’s Next Top Model” who has Asperger’s Syndrome, misidentified the city in which she got lost in one episode. It was Shanghai, not Beijing.

An Associated Press report in the N.B.A. roundup in some editions on Friday about the Knicks’ status as the league’s most valuable franchise misstated a Forbes magazine assessment of the club’s worth. It is $608 million, not $604 million.

The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about the mental reserves that might help ward off symptoms of dementia, misstated the name of the medical center with which two researchers who study the issue are affiliated. Dr. Nikolaos Scarmeas and Yaakov Stern are at Columbia University Medical Center, not Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. (The name was changed in 2003.).
An article on Sunday about a 100-year-old Zen master in New Mexico misspelled the name for a Zen meditation hall. It is zendo, not zenda.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Tuesday about the Giants’ development into a solid, if unspectacular, team misstated their potential for playing at home in the postseason. They could do so if they are the top wild-card team in the National Football Conference championship game and face the second wild-card team; they would not necessarily play all of their postseason games on the road.

A front-page article on Tuesday about the role of lawyers at the Central Intelligence Agency in approving the 2005 destruction of hundreds of hours of interrogation videotapes gave an incomplete name in some editions for the former chief of the agency’s clandestine branch, who has been described by intelligence officials as having authorized the destruction of the tapes. He is Jose A. Rodriguez Jr.

The House voted unanimously to extend the retirement age for commercial pilots to 65, changing a 1960 Federal Aviation Administration regulation forcing pilots to leave the cockpit at age 60. The bill, if approved by the Senate, would put the retirement age in line with international standards. The International Civil Aviation Organization adopted a retirement age of 65 in November 2006. The House measure would require pilots ages 60 and above to have a medical certificate renewed every six months and to take a flight test known as a line check every six months.

About 7,000 post offices will be open for extended hours during the holiday season, the Postal Service said. The service expects nearly 1 billion cards, letters and packages to be mailed Monday, which would make it the busiest day of the season. In November, the service set a deadline of Dec. 15 for packages sent using the least expensive option, parcel post, to arrive by Christmas. For parcels sent first class or priority mail, the deadline is Dec. 20, and for express mail, Dec. 22.

A public school in Montgomery County is taking steps to protect students against a drug-resistant form of staph infection after a special education teacher died of complications from the bacterium. The teacher, Merry King, had worked at Herbert Hoover Middle School in Potomac for two of the past three years. Ms. King’s classroom was sanitized as a precaution after she died Sunday. A Montgomery County schools spokeswoman said communal areas at the school would also be sanitized with a bleach solution. Ms. King had been absent from the school since Nov. 30 and had been hospitalized since early last week.

Two boys ages 11 and 14 have been charged with trying to rape a 60-year-old woman in her Austin home. The boys wore bandanas when they broke through a window in July, and one tried to sexually assault the woman but stopped when her heart device was set off, the police said. They were charged with burglary with intent to commit sexual assault. Detective Scott Stanfield said the attack was deemed premeditated because the boys had a “rape kit” that included items to restrain the victim.

The gunman who killed four people in two church-related attacks on Sunday committed suicide after being shot “multiple times” by a volunteer security guard at a church in Colorado Springs, the El Paso County coroner said. The man, Matthew Murray, 24, was confronted by the guard, Jeanne Assam, a former police officer and member of the New Life Church, as he entered the building. He fired a single bullet into himself as he lay wounded, the corner said. Mr. Murray killed two people early Sunday at a missionary training center near Denver and had just killed two teenage sisters in the parking lot at New Life, about 12 hours later, before facing Ms. Assam.

NASA will fill the space shuttle Atlantis’s fuel tank next week in hopes of cracking a fuel gauge problem that led to back-to-back launching delays, the agency said. The trouble could be anywhere in the 100 feet of wiring between the four gauges at the bottom of the fuel tank and the shuttle itself, in any of the connectors, or even in the sensors themselves, said N. Wayne Hale Jr., the shuttle program manager. At the same time, engineers will conduct other tests, mostly in laboratories, to try to figure out what is causing the gauges in the Atlantis’s tank to malfunction.
Republicans retained control of two Congressional seats Tuesday in special elections in Ohio and Virginia, thwarting Democratic efforts to expand their control in the House.

Joffrey Lupul scored a hat trick and had 6 points, and R. J. Umberger matched him with three goals to snap Philadelphia’s five-game winless skid at home and lift the Flyers to an 8-2 win over the Pittsburgh Penguins Tuesday night.
Tom O’Connell has been an agent for 10 years, and he represents about 60 baseball players, mostly in the minor leagues. He may have just met his toughest challenge.
New York City is significantly ramping up its efforts to challenge cases in which it pays for private school tuition of children with disabilities.
Bowing to pressure from business leaders, legislators promised on Tuesday to scale back a proposal that would allow employees paid family leave to care for a newborn or a sick relative.

Robert William Pickton was sentenced to life in prison with no chance of parole for 25 years on Tuesday for the murders of six women whose bodies were butchered in the slaughterhouse of his pig farm near Vancouver.
The Nets, who had hoped to move into a new arena near downtown Brooklyn in time for the 2009-10 season, now acknowledge that construction will not be finished until sometime in 2010.
No matter where he coaches, New Mexico’s Steve Alford ends up with his mentor Bob Knight on the schedule.

Lawmakers endorsed an overhaul of the country’s adoption system, ending what critics called a largely unregulated business in which poor mothers were paid to turn over their children to American couples.

Outrage and disbelief continued to spread across Australia over the decision of a local judge to allow nine Aborigines who pleaded guilty to the gang rape of a 10-year-old Aboriginal girl last year to walk free.
A 38-year-old man accused of killing a girlfriend and eating parts of her body was found dead in his cell in Mexico City.

The Bodleian Library at Oxford displayed its four copies of the Magna Carta together for the first time in 800 years and for one day only. Just 13 others survive, and Sotheby’s will sell the only copy in private hands next week.
A committee of the General Assembly for the first time passed an Israeli resolution, one proposing that developed countries make their agricultural know-how more available.

The Foreign Ministry summoned Zimbabwe’s diplomat in Berlin to protest comments by Information Minister Sikhanyiso Ndlovu in a state-controlled newspaper referring to Chancellor Angela Merkel as a “fascist” and “Nazi remnant.”.
A principal witness in the stock-options backdating trial that ended in a conviction of Brocade’s chief executive, Gregory L. Reyes, has told associates that her testimony may have been untrue.
The U.S. Sentencing Commission’s has voted to lighten punishments for some crimes related to crack cocaine.
Gen. Michael V. Hayden said the decision to record and subsequently destroy video of the interrogations of senior Al Qaeda captives was made by previous directors.
Surely the presidential candidates can’t wait to address the latest gun rampages with a detailed plan of action at the very next televised debate.
Vladimir Putin’s chosen successor is seen as a relatively weak figure.  That suggests Mr. Putin will continue to wield power after the March election.
The Supreme Court’s latest rulings on sentencing guidelines strike us as a positive development, one with much potential for advancing justice.

Yulia V. Tymoshenko, a leader of Ukraine’s pro-democracy protests in 2004, on Tuesday fell one vote short of the parliamentary majority needed to become prime minister.
The corner offices of corporate America’s largest companies are increasingly being filled from every corner of the world.

Tiger Woods swept the three biggest annual awards for the seventh time. He received the Jack Nicklaus Trophy for player of the year, the Arnold Palmer award for leading the money list ($10.8 million) and the Byron Nelson award for lowest-scoring average (67.79). Jay Haas was voted Champions Tour player of the year, and Nick Flanagan won the Nationwide award. The other PGA Tour awards went to Steve Stricker, the first player to win comeback player of the year in consecutive seasons, and Brandt Snedeker, who was the rookie of the year.
Nowhere are Hillary Rodham Clinton’s problems on display more than in Iowa.
George J. Mitchell’s report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball will be made public on Thursday.
Assailants on Tuesday shot six young people who had stepped off a school bus, wounding two critically, in a midday attack that followed a fight over a girl at a high school, the authorities said.
An independent analysis of thousands of older people with diabetes found that those treated with the widely used drug Avandia had significantly elevated risks of heart attack and death.
New Jersey Gov. Jon S. Corzine is expected to unveil a new school-financing proposal Wednesday that would change the formula used to distribute aid among school districts.
Alan W. Golder pleaded not guilty to nearly 40 felony counts in connection with two dozen burglaries in which he took nearly $1 million of jewelry.
In announcing the cut, the Federal Reserve signaled its concern that the credit crisis may be damaging the broader economy. The Dow fell nearly 300 points.
Republican presidential candidates are changing their tone on immigration as primary voters say it is one of the most important problems facing the country.

Illicit drug use by teenagers continued to decline gradually this year, but the use of prescription painkillers remained popular among young people, according to a federally financed study.

The Rangers are a point out of first place in their division and looking to contend for a championship this season while the Knicks are struggling to avoid public ridicule.

Starting in 2009, every child born in Maine will be eligible for $500 toward college from the fortune of a shoe magnate who died there last month.
An initiative begun by the Chiefs’ Kyle Turley hopes to persuade N.F.L. players to donate part of their Dec. 23 game paychecks to an organization assisting retired players in need.

It has been the year of the backup quarterback and at least three more will get a chance this week. Fifty-six quarterbacks have made starts this season, including the newcomers Brock Berlin (Rams) and Chris Redman (Falcons) in Week 14. Kyle Orton, who has not thrown a regular-season pass since 2005, has already been announced as the Bears’ starter for Monday night’s game against the Vikings. Shaun Hill appears to be the last man standing for the 49ers, and Todd Collins, No. 15 at right, will get the start for the Redskins in place of the injured Jason Campbell. San Francisco and Chicago will become the sixth and seventh teams to use three starting quarterbacks this season.
The city’s Taxi and Limousine Commission adopted a rule on Tuesday that will require all cabs purchased after Oct. 1, 2008, to get at least 25 miles per gallon.
The agreement came on a day when Chinese and American representatives exchanged heated words over recent trade disputes, according to American officials.
Sometimes people wait for hours to get onto a working elevator and up to court, only to find their hearings have been rescheduled because they did not show up on time.
President Bush granted pardons on Tuesday to carjackers, drug dealers, a moonshiner and an election-laws violator but not to I. Lewis Libby Jr., who was once the top aide to his vice president.
James Watson, the Nobel prize-winning scientist who said that black Africans are not as intelligent as whites, has a significant amount of African DNA in his own genome.
The lame wheel on the NASA Mars rover Spirit has proven an invaluable science tool, turning up evidence of a once habitable environment, scientists said Monday.

The White House has raised last-minute concerns over regulation of automobile emissions and fuel economy that aides said Tuesday could lead to a presidential veto of the energy bill now before Congress.

Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve on Tuesday after the Fed’s monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to lower interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point:.

Wal-Mart Stores failed in its attempt to head off the biggest sexual discrimination case in United States history Tuesday when an appeals court allowed the case to remain a class-action lawsuit.
The company said that job cuts would be associated with the decision but that some people would be reassigned to existing businesses and new projects.
Sony’s chief executive, Howard Stringer, said the electronics and entertainment company has recovered from its past financial problems.
A Congressional committee is investigating Merck and Schering-Plough for their handling of a critical clinical trial of Zetia, their blockbuster cholesterol-lowering drug.
The search for human remains begun in October 2006, after the discovery of bones and bone fragments in an abandoned manhole, is largely completed.
American and Chinese regulators signed an accord on Tuesday to strengthen regulation of drugs and medical devices exported to the United States.

The Department of Defense has identified 3,878 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:.
One of the Chicago area’s richest men is making an ambitious attempt to gain a foothold in the world of commercial real estate by building a large development outside of Chicago.

Two California companies produce good, well-priced caviar, and the new ChikaLicious Puddin’ stays true to its name by serving only pudding.

A two-hour edition of “Deal or No Deal” put NBC on top of the ratings for much of Monday night, but a low-rated episode of “Journeyman” at 10 p.m. meant the network earned a second-place finish over all.
“Jeopardy!” host has heart attack, Welles’s “Kane” Oscar no Rosebud,  British Library buys Pinter papers and more culture news.

Few writers own a city as completely as Raymond Chandler owns Los Angeles. Seen through the eyes of Philip Marlowe, his existentialist detective, its bungalows, courtyard apartment buildings and sunlit anomie cast a spell that acts on his legions of fans like a potent drug.

Don and Chika Tillman, right, who opened ChikaLicious, a dessert cafe, several years ago, have opened a satellite across the street, called ChikaLicious Puddin'. It is only slightly less monomaniacal than the places around town that sell just peanut butter or macaroni and cheese. The menu is limited to warm apple pudding bathed in custard sauce; brioche bread pudding served in a chilled custard; and chocolate pudding on a bed of cookie crumbs, $4.50 a portion. There is a small oval counter for indulging on the spot. Large orders (40 cups or more) should be made six hours in advance. Ms. Tillman said she has no intention of expanding the menu. ''We never change the menu at ChikaLicious either, and everyone is happy,'' she said. The shop, 204 East 10th Street, is open Wednesday through Sunday, 1 p.m. to midnight: (212) 475-0929.

In recent days, Mike Huckabee, a Republican presidential candidate, has mischaracterized his record and past statements on two subjects: one relating to the federal government's response to the AIDS crisis in the 1990s and another about his lack of knowledge of a report finding that Iran had halted its nuclear weapons program in 2003. On ''Fox News Sunday,'' Mr. Huckabee was asked by the program's host, Chris Wallace, if he stood by a 1992 response to a questionnaire in which he ''called for quarantining AIDS patients.''

Ten people have been charged with attacking four subway riders on Friday who had wished fellow passengers Happy Hanukkah, in a case that the Police Department said it was investigating as a possible hate crime. The victims, two men and two women, were on a southbound Q train at 11:15 p.m. Friday when the group of assailants approached them as the train neared the Canal Street station in Manhattan, made anti-Semitic remarks and assaulted them, the police said on Tuesday. One victim was able to pull an emergency cord and officers responded at the DeKalb Avenue stop, in Brooklyn, where the 10 suspects were arrested, the police said. The victims were treated for bruises on the head and face, the police said, two of them at a hospital. The suspects, who were all 19 or 20, face assault and other charges, officials said. Most of them live in Brooklyn.

BIENSTOCK--June Klein of Bayside, NY, born February 26, 1926; died December 10, 2007. Daughter of the late Moe and Sarah Klein; wife of the late Herbert Bienstock (former Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, US Department of Labor); sister of Bernard Klein and sister-in-law of Clara Schneider; mother of Ruth Bienstock Anolik (Robert) and Joshua E. Bienstock, Esq. (Linda); grandmother of Jonathan, Rachel, and Sarah Anolik; aunt, great-aunt; friend to multitudes. An extraordinary and unforgettable woman, she was beloved and will be greatly missed by all who knew her. She was a true eshet chayil: the matriarch of her family, a devoted Jew, and a long-time member of the Young Israel of Windsor Park. The first of her family to attain higher education, she earned a BA from Hunter College and an MA in English Literature from New York University. A life-long New Yorker and a gifted teacher, she taught High School English in the New York City school system from 1946--1981, spending most of her career at Bayside High School in Queens. Like the clerk in Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, she would ''gladly learn and gladly teach,'' and continued her vocation after retiring from Bayside, instructing on the college level and leading informal book groups. After winning her battle against ovarian cancer, she took her love of literature to a new stage, publishing her memoir, ''One Lucky Lady.'' She enthralled her readers and those who attended her book talks. She was, indeed, ''one lucky lady,'' and we were all lucky to have shared her life. May her memory be for a blessing. Services today, 12:15pm, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162 - 05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY. Shivah will be observed Wednesday-Friday morning at the home of June Bienstock. Shivah will resume after Sabbath on Saturday and continue until Tuesday morning, at the home of daughter, Ruth in Penn Valley, Pennsylvania.

KRONISH--Herbert. My dearest Herb, you have enriched my life immeasurably. I cherish the time we had together. I will miss you always. Rest peacefully. Love, Joan KRONISH--Herbert. Cooley Godward Kronish LLP, successor to Kronish Lieb Weiner & Hellman LLP, mourns the passing of Herb Kronish, founding partner of KLWH. Forty-nine years ago, Herb and Dick Lieb decided to practice law together, and, as they say, the rest is history. He was the soul of the law firm: a valued counselor, conciliator, builder and leader, a source of unflagging energy, and a devoted and loyal friend. Above all, he was a humanitarian who made a difference in countless organizations, particularly among Jewish charities here, in the former Soviet Union and in Israel. We extend our deep sympathy to his children Susan and David and to his brother Paul, to their spouses and to the entire family. We will miss his warm smile and big heart forever. May his memory be for a blessing. KRONISH--Herbert. Congregation Ohav Sholom, Merrick, deeply mourns the passing of our Founder and Honorary Life President. He inspired us for 46 years with his vision, kindness, leadership and generosity. He was God's guardian angel -a one of a kind, unforgettable human being. He remains forever in our hearts. Brian Bertan, President Jeremiah Wohlberg, Rabbi KRONISH--Herbert. The Board and staff of the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged (JASA) mourn the passing of Herbert Kronish, beloved brother of our longstanding and esteemed trustee, Paul Kronish. We extend our deepest condolences to Paul, his wife Naomi, their children and grandchildren, and the entire Kronish family. David M. Warren, President Aileen Gitelson, Chief Executive Officer KRONISH--Herbert, my darling brother, passed away December 11, at age 81, after a long battle with pancreatic cancer. My best friend, I will miss our almost daily calls and weekly lunches discussing family, business and worldly topics. Herb was a leader to humankind and always planning for what could be and should be. A futurist to the very end. The Jewish world in particular will miss this unbelievable statesman as well his entire families of children, grandchildren, nieces and nephews. Naomi, Paul and Family KRONISH--Herbert, age 81, passed away on Tuesday, December 11th, 2007 from cancer after several months, during which he courageously used every moment to enjoy his family and many friends. After the death of his loving wife, Doris in 1995, he embraced his role as the devoted father of Susan and Alan, and David and Sara, and the adoring grandfather of Joshua, Dana, El-Ro'ee, Yehonatan, Ashira, Tifferet and Malachi. He was an exemplary son to his parents, the late Ben and Tobie Kronish, a loving brother of Paul and Naomi, a devoted brother-in-law of Martha and Bert Robbins. He held his role as cousin, uncle, granduncle, and friend in the highest esteem and love. Throughout his lifetime, he devoted his vast energy to Israel, Soviet Jewry, and to ways of insuring Jewish continuity. As a Founder and Honorary Life President of Congregation Ohav Shalom in Merrick, LI, through his active involvements with UJA Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, as a Chairman of the Greater NY Conference on Soviet Jewry, and as the Director of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee he demonstrated the strength of his commitment to Judaism. Additionally, he was the founding partner of the law firm Kronish, Lieb, Weiner & Hellman, LLP. To this and all his endeavors, he brought passionate commitment, vision and the pursuit of excellence. Through his untold generosity of spirit, he was a beacon of light, source of compassion, tower of strength and inspiration to countless people, and Jewish communities around the world. His memory will be for a blessing. He has left his family and community with a legacy which will galvanize others to pick up his gauntlet for generations to come. Funeral service will be held at Congregation Ohav Shalom, 145 Merrick Ave., Merrick, LI, Wednesday December 12th, 2007 at 11:00 a.m. Interment to follow at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, LI. Charitable contributions can be made to Congregation Ohav Shalom, Merrick, NY, American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science, Congregation B'nai Jeshuran, NY, or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. KRONISH--Herbert. Larry Holmes, who seemed to always have to justify himself as a champion, was named to the International Boxing Hall of Fame. Joining him in the 2008 class were 11 others boxers and ring personalities chosen by members of the Boxing Writers Association and a panel of international boxing historians. Holmes will be enshrined as the longest reigning world heavyweight champion in boxing history, holding the title for nearly seven years (1978-85). His 20 successful heavyweight title defenses were surpassed by only Joe Louis with 25.Also being inducted June 8 in the modern era category will be the junior welterweight champion Eddie Perkins and the middleweight Holman Williams. The middleweights Len Harvey and Frank Klaus and the welterweight Harry Lewis were honored in the old-timer category, and the 19th-century Irish heavyweight Dan Donnelly in the pioneer class. Joe Koizumi of Ring Magazine and Dave Anderson of The New York Times were honored in the observer category.

A NEW CHIEF AT CITIGROUP Vikram S. Pandit was named chief executive of Citigroup, ending a monthlong scramble to find a new leader for the country's largest bank. Win Bischoff, the company's acting chief executive, was made chairman after Robert E. Rubin declined to remain in the position. MORE FOREIGN BORN C.E.O.'S

If an interest in conservation has inspired you to cross caviar from wild Caspian Sea sturgeon off your holiday shopping list, you still have plenty of choices. Germany, France, Italy, Israel, Dubai and Uruguay are some of the places that have jumped into the business of farming sturgeon for caviar. California was one of the earliest to develop a caviar industry and now, more than 15 years of experience have paid off with consistent quality from the two producers, Sterling and Tsar Nicoulai. They are likely to be the least expensive sources for good caviar this season. Both companies offer several grades from a type of sturgeon called transmontanus, or white sturgeon, from basic black to some with larger beads and paler hints of gold and gray, at higher prices. It all has to do with how the roe is sorted as it is harvested. Samples purchased from www.sterlingcaviar.com and www.tsarnicoulai.com, showed stylistic differences between the products; which to choose is a matter of taste.

A federal judge ruled on Tuesday that a lawsuit against New York City filed by three men whose convictions in the 1989 beating and rape of a jogger in Central Park were overturned in 2002 can proceed to trial. Despite efforts by the city to have the suit dismissed, the judge, Deborah A. Batts of Federal District Court, said in her ruling that claims brought in 2003 by the men -- Kevin Richardson, Raymond Santana Jr. and Antron McCray -- for malicious prosecution, racial discrimination and emotional distress can stand. Their convictions were overturned after DNA evidence pointed to another man, Matias Reyes, who had stepped forward to say he was the sole attacker.

QUINN--Nancy Dallas, 81, of Larchmont, NY, passed away in her sleep December 8, 2007. She was born and raised in La Canada, California, by Frances (O'Shea), a homemaker, and Cleaves A. Jones, a decorated WWI fighter pilot and journalist for the Los Angeles Times. Nancy graduated from Immaculate Heart College with a Bachelor's Degree, and received a master's degree in English from UCLA. While at college Nancy directed several plays and enjoyed singing on state. After graduation Nancy taught at the elementary school level for several years. Nancy moved to Washington, D.C. at the age of 24 and met her soon to be husband, Robert J. Quinn, while both were working at the CBS television affiliate WTOP. Her husband, a graduate of Northwestern University, and WWII veteran stationed in England, was a television News Director at WTOP. The family moved to Larchmont in 1961. The mother of four children and one grandchild, Nancy was involved for over a decade in the activities of the local school board. An avid world traveler, she mixed her love for art with a passion for figure skating. Nancy and her husband wrote and published a book on figure skating pins in 1986. The book, ''Figure Skating Pins,'' was the definitive word on such pins. While Nancy once looked to the theater for her artistic fufillment, it was cooking sophisticated meals that finally satisfied her creative needs. She is survived by her four children: Brigid of Fairfield, Connecticut, Sean and Christopher of Larchmont, New York, and Erin and grandson Sean of Charlottesville, Virginia; and beloved bunny Roger. Visitation Thursday, 2-4 pm and 7-9 pm at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont. Funeral Mass will be held Friday, 10 am at St. Augustine Church. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorn.

The name of the cheese is Tumbleweed, but there is nothing rustic about it. It is a sophisticated cheese from 5 Spoke Creamery, made in the Amish country in Pennsylvania. Beneath a thin white rind is a firm, smooth, deep gold cheese, not unlike a French Cantal fermier. It has a lightly toasted aroma with a hint of new-mown hay. The flavor is mouth-filling and extremely balanced, finishing with a touch of sweetness. Raw milk from grass-fed Holsteins, vegetable rennet and at least eight months of aging are all the production details you need to know. It is around $17 a pound at Murray's Cheese Shop and at Bierkraft in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

A car-theft sting by law enforcement officials on Long Island has resulted in the arrest of 22 suspects, including a man accused of stealing his grandfather's car while his grandmother's wheelchair was in the trunk. Another suspect, a mechanic, is accused of copying customers' keys so he could steal their cars. The Suffolk County district attorney, Thomas J. Spota, said on Tuesday that 15 other people were being sought as a result of the 16-month investigation, and that since August 2006, 92 vehicles worth more than $1.1 million have been recovered.

Funeral services will be held at The Parish of Christ the Redeemer Episcopal Church, 1415 Pelhamdale Avenue, Pelham, New York, this Saturday, December 15, 2007 at 11:00am. A reception will follow. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions be made to Christ the Redeemer Episcopal Church.

A Bronx gang member, Edgar Morales, the first person convicted under the state's terrorism statute, has been sentenced to 40 years to life in prison for fatally shooting a 10-year old girl and wounding a man. Mr. Morales, was convicted of first-degree manslaughter in October for killing the girl, Malenny Mendez, left, and of attempted murder for shooting the man, Javier Tochimani, outside a church in 2002. Justice Michael A. Gross of State Supreme Court sentenced Mr. Morales on Monday to two consecutive prison terms of 20 years to life. Because his crimes were found to have been committed as acts of terrorism, Mr. Morales, 25, could be kept in prison for life, prosecutors said.

MELVILLE--Frank, III. It is with deep sorrow that the American Civil Liberties Union and its Board mourn the death of Frank Melville III, one of our most passionate and committed supporters. Frank was a lifelong and generous friend of the ACLU, especially in our historic endowment campaign. Frank's profound dedication to our mission could always be counted on as a source of moral support and assurance in even the most challenging times. He had a keen intellect and an unwavering passion for fairness and justice. In championing the ACLU, he made an enormous difference in the landscape of civil liberties in this country. The ACLU will celebrate Frank's life by continuing to pursue the ideals that he cherished. His resolute belief in the work we do will sustain us and encourage us to do better.

POST--Rosalind, age 83, died of complications from a stroke at Beth Israel Medical Center on November 23, 2007. She leaves behind a daughter, Hillary Post, and two grandsons, Thomas and Kyle Williams. Born on the Southside of Chicago in 1924, she moved to New York City in 1947 and settled in Chelsea. Her husband, Lester Post predeceased her in 1960. Her brother, Sheldon Smith, died in 2006. She had a long career in public relations for the city of New York and retired in 1994. She will be remembered for her tremendous warmth, snazzy style, generous laugh and pasty chili. Her family will miss her terribly. An informal memorial get together will be held on December 15th, from 1 to 5 at her apartment, 340 W. 28th St. #

The head of a state-run psychiatric hospital and a security guard have been removed from their jobs after the escape of a patient on Sunday who killed himself hours after he was brought back, state officials said on Tuesday. Two other hospital employees were suspended, officials said. The hospital chief, Latanya Wood El, who had run the Ancora Psychiatric Hospital since 2000, has been reassigned, a spokeswoman for the Department of Human Services said. Greg Roberts, the assistant director of state hospital management, has become the acting chief at the hospital, which is southeast of Camden. He previously served as the top manager there, as he has at three of New Jersey's four other state hospitals.

Paul Wulff returned to his alma mater, Washington State, as head coach Tuesday, becoming first alumnus in almost 60 years to lead the Cougars. Wulff, who was coach at nearby Eastern Washington the past eight seasons, is the 31st Washington State coach and the first alum to hold the job since Phil Sarboe from 1945-49.

BECKER--Stanley. The North Shore-LIJ Health System is saddened by the passing of Stanley Becker of East Hampton, NY. Saul Katz, Chairman Michael Dowling, President & CEO

KELLY--Edith B., of Bronxville. Beloved mother of Michael L. Flynn and Adrianne K. Wholey, predeceased by loving husband Robert J. Kelly. Pioneering stockbroker and dear friend, her joyful spirit lives on. Memorial visitation 6-9pm, Thursday; memorial service 11:30am, Friday, McGrath Funeral Home, Bronxville. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Timothy's School, Maryland.

LOEW--Peggy Stollmack (nee Schwab). Married to Ralph Stollmack in 1946, Peggy raised her family in Great Neck, NY. After Ralph's death, Peggy reclaimed her hometown of Los Angeles and later married Marcus Loew II in 1991, where she was embraced by the Loew family. Peggy is survived by her four children and their spouses, four grandchildren and their spouses, and two great-grandchildren as well as Marcus' three children and their spouses, thirteen grandchildren and their spouses, three great - grandchildren and her brother Dore Schwab, and dear cousin Connie Keiter and her entire family. Peggy was most successful at creating a loving and caring family of friends on both coasts. Known for her warmth and genuineness, Peggy made lifelong friends wherever she ventured and inspired those who knew her with her tenacious will to live, love of life and chocolate. Peggy also displayed a unique skill for various card games, Mah-Jongg and high stakes gambling, never once losing at any of these endeavors nor forgetting to forgive her debtors. An informal memorial service for family and friends will be held at Hillcrest Country Club Thursday, December 13, at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, Peggy has requested donations be made to: Loew Vision Rehabilitation Institute, 1880 Century Park East, Suite 1000, Los Angeles, CA 90067.

KRAMER--Isabel Ruth of Manhattan (formerly of Hewlett and Brooklyn, NY), beloved mother, grandmother and sister, passed away suddenly on Monday, December 10, 2007 at age 90. Born on January 27, 1917, Isabel grew up in Brooklyn, NY, and Scranton, PA. After marrying Sol Kramer, her husband of 46 years, they managed Ben & Sol's Deli near Ebbets Field for many years. Isabel is survived by her sister, Lillian, her children, Joan and Michael, her grandchildren, Sharon, David, Jason, Rob and Adam, and scores of greatgrandchildren, nieces and nephews. She was dearly loved and will be deeply missed. Funeral at Riverside Chapel (76 and West End) on Wednesday at 11:15am.

REMPELL--Eleanor T., 85, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Widow of her beloved Irving to whom she was married for 65 glorious years. Devoted mother to Judy Aspes (Ted), Roberta Temes Lyons (David). Grandmother to Karen and Lewis Milrod, Peter and Judy Temes, Lucy and David Pritzker, Jason and Susie Aspes, Adam and Wendi Aspes. Great-grandmother to Katie, Leah, Charlie, Zach, Joe, Abraham, Alyssa, Hannah, Ben, Hudson, Asher. A woman of sterling character whose extraordinary efforts and compassion have made the world a better place.

Two airplanes that reached close proximity at Kennedy International Airport on Sunday were no closer than half a mile apart, the Federal Aviation Administration said on Tuesday. Air traffic controllers complained on Monday that the two planes, a Boeing 747 cargo plane and a 37-seat commuter jet, nearly collided when the cargo plane, which had been assigned to land, aborted the landing and went around for another try, crossing a perpendicular runway where the commuter jet was assigned to land. The smaller plane then also aborted its landing. The planes were at their closest when both were 200 feet above the ground. A spokeswoman for the F.A.A., Laura J. Brown, said that the encounter did not break flight safety rules because the crew of the smaller plane could see the cargo jet and thus avoid hitting it. The controllers argue that the simultaneous use of runways at right angles to each other raises risks.

SAVOIARDO--Maurizio, M.D., January 20, 1921 to December 10, 2007. Into heaven enters a peaceful, patient and gentle man. He was born in Borgetto, Italy, where he lived with his parents and three sisters. During the war there was no money to buy books. He had to hand write, copying the medical textbooks so he could study to become a physician while serving his country during WWII. After the war he came to America. He later became a Pediatrician. During the 1970s when people were unemployed, he treated his patients for no charge. He was an intelligent Diagnostician who many people called for medical advice. He was a loving husband, father, brother, uncle, brother-in-law and friend. He is survived by his wife Carol, two sons, Maurizio and Paul, and daughter Ann Marie. He will never be forgotten. We thank God for giving him to us.

FRANK--Irma R., of Princeton, NJ, died December 10th at the age of 92. She was the loving wife of the late George W. Frank, mother of Susan Daum of Henderson, NV, and George W. Frank Jr. of Hobe Sound, FL. Grandmother of four grandsons and six greatgrandchildren. Active alumni of Mt. Holyoke College, served on boards of Talbot Perkins, NYC, NY, and Family Service Association, LI, NY. A memorial service will be held in January. Memorial contributions may be sent to Princeton Hospice, 208 Bunn Dr., Princeton, NJ 08540.
RUBIN--Gloria. The Board of Governors and members of the Elberon Bathing Club mourn the passing of longstanding member Gloria Rubin. She will be sorely missed. Robert Fagenson Pres

Mike Huckabee had the most-visited campaign Web site among presidential candidates during the first week of December, a first for his site. This spike in online traffic conincides with Mr. Huckabee's recent rise in the polls and increased visibility in the news. Mr. Huckabee and Representative Ron Paul of Texas, whose supporters on the Internet have propelled his campaign forward, lead the more well-known candidates in visits to their sites. ''This election has a lot of big brand names running, so Americans may feel like they know them already and instead are going online to learn more about these other candidates such as Mike Huckabee and Ron Paul as reflected in our data,'' said Matt Tatham of Hitwise, a firm that tracks online traffic.

SHERWOOD--Hugh C., 79, died in White Plains on November 21. He wrote ''How to Invest in Bonds'', and was former editorial officer of Irving Trust. He graduated Yale University and Columbia School of Journalism. He is survived by nephews Eric Olin of Bridgeport, CT, and Dirk Olin of Maplewood, NJ. Donations to Deering Foundation, 1181 Deering Center Rd., Deering, NH 03244.

HARRIS--George De Lancey, of New York, NY, and Port Royal, Nova Scotia, died in New York at age 83 on December 7, 2007. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, Joanna Cochrane Harris, their son, James Harris, and his brother, Thomas L. Harris. Del (as he was widely known) Harris was born in New York City and grew up in Scarsdale and Nova Scotia. He and Mrs. Harris lived in Port Royal, Nova Scotia, five months of the year in a home he decorated and cherished. A veteran of WWII, Del, with his brother Thomas, owned D. P. Harris Hardware and Manufacturing Company. The company, founded by his grandfather, produced Rollfast bicycles. He traveled internationally for many years representing his company. Del, much loved by everyone who knew him, possessed a generous and loving spirit. Predeceased by his daughter, Charlotte, he will be interred, like her, in the Harris family plot in the Annapolis Royal Cemetery, Nova Scotia. A memorial gathering will be held on December 16th.

SOLARZ--Flora, passed away on December 8, 2007. The board of directors and staff of the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network/ United Network for Organ Sharing (OPTN/UNOS) and the New York Organ Donor Network mourn the loss of a dedicated advocate of organ donation. A lung transplant recipient of more than 12 years, Ms. Solarz served as a member of the board of directors and on several committees of these two organizations. We will miss her love of life, professionalism, determination, and most of all, her abiding friendship. Timothy Pruett, M.D., President OPTN/UNOS Dale Distant, M.D., Chairperson New York Organ Donor Network

WEISS--Burton, a New York and London based investment banker, died Sunday of complications from lung disease. He was 77. He had been a Director of SG Warburg, the London merchant bank, and a Senior Vice President, Director and Member of the Executive Committee of Becker Securities Corp, an affiliate of AG Becker & Co, which he joined in 1954. He joined the Board of Directors of Becker in 1968, and in 1974 was a key participant in the formation and leadership of Warburg Paribas Becker. In 1980, he moved to London to join the executive team at SG Warburg. In the mid 1980s, he served as the head of Cowen Asset Management. Born Burton Joseph Weiss in 1930 in Brooklyn, New York, to Ben and Matilda Weiss, Burt Weiss spent most of his youth in Harrisburg, PA, where he graduated valedictorian from the Harrisburg Academy. He went on to study history and international affairs at Princeton University, graduating summa cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa from the Woodrow Wilson School in 1952. He later dabbled in graduate work at the University of London and Harvard, but left the former to travel the European continent, and the latter to start a career on Wall Street. In 1955, he married the former Nan Schleisner, also of Harrisburg. Together they had three children, Margot McClellan, a psychotherapist in Pittsburgh, PA; Jennifer Weiss, a representative in the North Carolina state legislature; and Jonathan Weiss, a banker with Wachovia Securities in New York. A voracious reader, student of history, and lifelong Democrat, Burt Weiss enjoyed his retirement in the Chapel Hill, NC area. He was active in local politics, had a keen interest in the University of North Carolina, served on the boards of the local Interfaith Council for Social Services and Havurah, and volunteered with the Alliance of AIDS Services. He had also served on the Board of Education in Montgomery Township, NJ, where the family lived for many years. In addition to his wife and children, he is survived by six grandchildren, Caroline and Alexis McClellan of Pittsburgh, Max and Anna Hamilton of Cary, NC, and Emily and Ben Weiss of New York City. The family will hold a private burial service. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Burt's memory to the Interfaith Council for Social Services, 110 W. Main St., Carrboro, NC 27510, or the Alliance of AIDS Services, 1700 N. Greensboro St., Carrboro, NC , 27510.

Todd Turner resigned as athletic director at Washington on Tuesday, nearly four years after he was hired to straighten out a department thrown into disarray by scandals. The resignation will take effect Jan. 31. Turner was in the middle of a five-year contract worth $325,000 in base salary and up to $420,000 annually with incentives. The resignation came six days after the university retained Tyrone Willingham as the football coach.

STRAUSMAN--Edward. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Edward Strausman, esteemed philanthropist and cherished friend of the New York Jewish community. The Strausman family strengthens our ability to serve those in need in New York, in Israel, and around the world. The Strausman family's passion and boundless generosity set a shining example of communal devotion. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Edward's wife, Gabriela; to his brother, George, and his sister-in-law, Nancy; to his children; to his grandchildren; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. STRAUSMAN--Edward. Daddy, I'll never forget the first day, Ischia. I'll never forget all that you did and I'll never forget our goodbye. Thank you! May you rest in peace and see all that you have done. I will miss you dearly and always keep you close to my heart. Forever, Victoria STRAUSMAN--Edward, in his 90th year. Loving husband of Gabriela. Loving father of Eve (Jonathan) Winston, Lisa (Gregg) Fortunoff and Victoria Shapiro. Dear grandfather of Paris, Parker, Skye, Benjamin and Oliver. Loving brother of George (Nancy) Strausman. Dear uncle of Samuel Strausman, Susan Rietti and David Strausman. As much as he loved all of us, we love him even more. Veteran of World War II, Chairman of Strausman Construction Company. He will be greatly missed, but our memories of his sense of humor and good deeds will live on in our hearts. Funeral services will be Wednesday, December 12th at 1:30pm, at Temple Emanuel, Hicks Lane in Great Neck. The family will be sitting shiva at 160 West Shore Rd., in Great Neck, Wednesday and Thursday until 8pm, and Friday until 5pm. STRAUSMAN--Edward. Dear Poppa, I miss you terribly but know you are at peace. Words will never express how much I love you. There is a place in my heart that is reserved just for you. And it aches deeply. I will love you forever. You were the best father to Jonny, and I am forever grateful. I know how much you adored him-but words will never describe just how much he loves you. He will forever miss you and the father you were to him. Love, Eve Winston

The Republican candidates for president will battle each other at 1 p.m. in Des Moines on Wednesday in their final debate before the Iowa caucus on Jan. 3. But first, they had to battle an ice storm. Sleet, rain and ice shut down nearly all campaigning by candidates in both parties in Iowa on Tuesday. And it left the Republican candidates scrambling to make it to Des Moines, where the airport was briefly closed, in time for the debate.

The federal prosecutor investigating Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader of the New York State Senate, has been nominated for a position on the federal bench, the White House announced on Tuesday. The prosecutor, Glenn T. Suddaby, has been investigating links between Mr. Bruno's business associates and their dealings with the state. Mr. Bruno has insisted he has done nothing wrong, and no one has been charged in the case. Mr. Suddaby was appointed United States attorney for New York's Northern District in 2002. Mr. Suddaby's nomination is supported by Charles E. Schumer, New York's senior senator and an influential Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee. New York's Northern District stretches from Ulster County in the southern half of the state to the Canadian border, and as far west as Syracuse, where Mr. Suddaby lives. It comprises seven courthouses, including one in Albany.

Forget homo-, bi- or even metro-: the latest prefix in sexuality is vegan-, as in "vegansexual." In a survey of vegan and vegetarians (most women), the questions ranged from attitudes about eating meat to to wearing possum fur to, yes, "cruelty-free sex" - that is, "rejecting meat eaters as intimate partners." Some of the survey respondents volunteered their reluctance to kiss meat eaters. "I couldn't think of kissing lips that allow dead animal pieces to pass between them," a 49-year-old vegan woman said. For some, the resistance is the squeamishness factor. "Nonvegetarian bodies smell different to me," a 41-year-old vegan woman said. "They are, after all, literally sustained through carcasses - the murdered flesh of others." Read more in the Times Magazine ...

The cover of the Times Magazine this Sunday is a profile of Mike Huckabee by Zev Chafets, a writer whose work I've always liked. It's a great portrait, rendered skeptically but without cynicism, and I highly recommend it. What's occurred to me as I've read stories about Mr. Huckabee over these last few months - I've not yet met him - is that you can already see how, should he manage to win the nomination, he would deftly steer himself back toward the political center in time for the convention. The outlines of the post-primary Huckabee storyline have already emerged: he raised some taxes over his own party's objections, he refused to deny scholarships to illegal immigrants (a decision he has refused to back away from "even if it costs me he election"), he came off as too liberal and secular for a lot of his fellow Baptist preachers. These lines from the Huckabee resume have earned him the scorn of some Republican interest groups, most notably the anti-tax Club for Growth, whose idea of state government consists of a couple of prisons and a paving machine, but they would serve him nicely in a general election, where independent voters might shrink from electing another rigid conservative. Campaign reporters always line up to write stories like this, not because they care about making the Mike Huckabees of the world seem kind and gentle, which he may well be, but because we in the media are trained to look for the contradiction of stereotypes - and no one is more gleefully stereotyped in America than the religious conservative. Thus we in the media have historically embraced the story of the Republican governor who, it turns out, isn't as much of a crazy conservative as you might think. Hey, look, the Tin Man has a heart! George W. Bush was a "compassionate conservative" who worked amiably across the aisle with Democrats. Mitt Romney passed a landmark, bipartisan bill to provide healthcare. Even Ronald Reagan enacted a huge tax increase while governor of California. And so on.

Cellphones and cellphone services made news with amazing frequency, making it clear that this service-we-love-to-hate is still in its crude Neanderthal age.

"18 Democrats voted 'nay' or 'present' on a resolution to 'recognize the importance of Christmas and the Christian faith.' There are a number of reasons why Hillary Rodham Clinton has had trouble mastering the intricacies of how the Iowa caucus system works, starting with the fact that her husband - Bill Clinton - never competed in any competitive Iowa caucuses when he ran for president in 1992 and 1996. But here's an arguably even more significant one: Mrs. Clinton's generally very seasoned core of senior advisers back in Virginia is devoid of people who have actually run an Iowa caucus before.

DES MOINES -- Today's debate among the Democratic candidates comes as the tight race among the top three candidates in the party's field has drawn a lot of interest in this state and elsewhere. For the Democrats, what happens here obviously will have a rippling effect through the early nominating states.

"Ought we to forgive Ike Turner?," Farah Jasmine Griffin wrote in a New York Times profile in 2001. "The question isn't whether Mr. Turner owes us an apology; he owes that to Ms. Turner. And only she can truly forgive him."

Shares of Iberdrola Renovables, an owner of wind-driven power plants, were modestly lower in early trading in Madrid after its $6 billion initial public offering priced at the low end of the expected range.
Roger Clemens has “vehemently” denied ever using performance-enhancing drugs, his attorney said Thursday in response to a bombshell baseball report.

Lehman Brothers reported a decline in fourth-quarter profit on Thursday, the first sign of the toll that subprime mortgages will take on investment banks for the quarter. But the firm still managed to beat analysts' expectations.

The Florida Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected an appeal by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, who had asked the court to restore a $1.58 billion verdict against the investment bank Morgan Stanley.
Efforts to rescue Northern Rock, the struggling British lender, appear to be faltering amid a slew of bad news.
Dow Chemical, the largest American chemical maker, said Petrochemical Industries of Kuwait agreed to pay $9.5 billion to form a joint venture producing plastics and chemicals.

The private equity firm Lone Star Funds will sell its 68 percent stake in Tokyo Star Bank of Japan for as much as $1.7 billion to a private equity fund, Advantage Partners, Reuters reported.

Invidi Technologies, an advertising technology company, said on Thursday it raised $25 million in its latest round of funding, led by the advertising holding company WPP Group.
The China Pacific Insurance (Group), the nation's third-largest insurer, may raise as much as 30 billion yuan ($4.07 billion) in the biggest initial public offering ever by a Chinese insurer.

If there is one category of workers who need all the help they can get, it's veterans. That is why I was so pleased to hear about the Creating Futures Program started by CompTIA, a trade association for the technology industry. The program trains people for civilian work in technology. Users can log onto the program from anywhere in the world, as long as they can get to a computer with Internet access. Given that technology is one of the one of the sectors the Labor Department predicts will see the greatest growth in the next 10 years, this seems to be a good matchup between an industry needing people and people in need of job training. The program is free to applicants and sponsored by Ricoh.

Biographies of the Vietnam veterans featured in five clips from the oral history gallery of “In Our Own Words: Portraits of  Brooklyn’s Vietnam Veterans,” an exhibition at the Brooklyn Historical Society.

Bank of America, Wachovia and the PNC Financial Services Group said on Wednesday that losses tied to bad debt would be worse than expected, the latest indication that the credit markets are not returning to normal.

Digital Domain, a special effects firm, wants to raise about $100 million in an initial public offering to pay off debt and maybe produce films, apparently in an attempt to compete with DreamWorks Animation and Walt Disney's Pixar Animation, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

A day after the Federal Reserve disappointed investors with a modest cut in interest rates, central banks in North America and Europe on Wednesday announced the most aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system since the terrorist attacks of September 2001.

Two deals where smaller hedge funds have agreed to fold their operations into those of bigger rivals highlight how the going has gotten tough for the relative minnows of the industry, Breakingviews says.

Merrill Lynch and Citigroup have both put new chiefs at the helm and they considered many of the same candidates in the search process. David Weidner, writing in a commentary on MarketWatch, notes the stark contrast between the two choices -- John Thain and Vikram Pandit, respectively -- and suggests Mr. Thain has the most to lose by far.

The chief executive of Endeavor Acquisition, the special-purpose acquisition company that agreed to buy American Apparel earlier this year, no doubt breathed a sigh of relief Wednesday as the company closed on the deal just three days before its drop-dead date of Dec. 15.
Kraft Foods, the food conglomerate whose brands include Ritz crackers and Velveeta cheese, said in a regulatory filing Wednesday it expects to issue $3 billion of notes.

As DealBook noted earlier this week, now that Citigroup has announced its new chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, attention is increasingly turning to the question of whether he will break-up the financial behemoth.
Rupert Murdoch won his long-coveted prize Thursday when shareholders of Dow Jones & Company gave their blessing to a takeover by Mr. Murdoch's global media empire, the News Corporation.
BlueMountain Capital Management sold an undisclosed stake in itself to an asset manager, Affiliated Manager Group, according to a press release.

Eton Park Capital Management , a hedge fund founded by Eric Mindich, a former partner at Goldman Sachs, has agreed to buy a 5 percent stake in Reliance Capital Asset Management, in a deal that for the first time puts a value on India's largest mutual fund.

The owners of WestLB, a German bank that has been battered by a trading scandal and turmoil in the mortgage markets in the United States, said on Wednesday they would seek merger talks with a publicly-owned counterpart, Helaba.
Alitalia on Thursday put off a decision to pick a buyer until next week after the Italian government failed to choose its preferred bidder for the ailing carrier.
A grim report from the airline industry's leading trade group may force some carriers to pick up the consolidation flag.
Samuel Zell, the real-estate magnate, hopes that the $8.2 billion deal he's leading to take Tribune private will close Dec. 20.

ArcelorMittal said Thursday it had signed an agreement with the China Oriental Group's controlling shareholders to raise its stake in the company to 73.13 percent from 28 percent, in a deal that would make it the first foreign company to take control of a Chinese steelmaker.
The decision by Biogen Idec, the pharmaceutical company, to take down its for-sale sign not only wiped $6 billion off its own value but hit shares of its partner Elan as well.

Representative Joe Barton of Texas said on Wednesday that Google had rebuffed requests by his staff for a meeting as part of an investigation into the company's $3.1 billion acquisition of DoubleClick.
Iomega, an American distributor of computer data storage equipment, said Wednesday that it was entering into a complex $310 million deal to acquire ExcelStor, a Chinese contract maker of disk drives.

The chip maker Advanced Micro Devices said Wednesday that it planned to take a material write-down of the value of its 2006 acquisition of ATI Technologies, a costly bet made to compete better in the market for graphics semiconductors.
Time Warner has quietly hired a prominent media analyst as it reshuffles its executive ranks in the weeks before Jeffrey L. Bewkes takes over as chief executive from Richard D. Parsons.

Microsoft said it had agreed to acquire MultiMap, an online map service based in London, in an attempt to compete more effectively with the search services of Google and to collect more revenue from online and mobile advertising.

When Gucci decided to create its latest fragrance, the house's artistic director, Frida Giannini, set herself quite a task: to create the perfume equivalent of a Niketown flagship, huge and impressive and filled to the brim with everything a fan could possibly dream of asking from a brand. It would distill the essence of Gucci - the label's unrestrained luxury, its blatant carnality, so free of French hauteur, so Italian in its joyful, slightly bad-taste abandon. The name said it all: Gucci by Gucci. Given the amount the house had riding on it, to report that the perfume, which came out in November, succeeds in virtually every way is not merely a relief. It is a pleasure.

Mike Huckabee had the most-visited campaign Web site among presidential candidates during the first week of December, a first for his site. This spike in online traffic conincides with Mr. Huckabee's recent rise in the polls and increased visibility in the news. Mr. Huckabee and Representative Ron Paul of Texas, whose supporters on the Internet have propelled his campaign forward, lead the more well-known candidates in visits to their sites. "This election has a lot of big brand names running, so Americans may feel like they know them already and instead are going online to learn more about these other candidates such as Mike Huckabee and Ron Paul as reflected in our data," said Matt Tatham of Hitwise, a firm that tracks online traffic.
