The most sobering part of Wednesday night's Rangers-Capitals game had nothing to do with the game -- a 5-4 overtime victory by Washington, which was wildly entertaining unless you are a big fan of goalies -- but the lack of people watching in Washington's Verizon Center.

Madison Avenue is growing increasingly excited that new technologies will help advertisers aim commercials at television viewers more precisely. A deal being made by the WPP Group, the giant advertising company, underscores that ardor.
Citigroup said Thursday that it planned to take $49 billion of structured investment vehicles onto its balance sheet, after ratings agencies’ threats to downgrade the debt.
A jury in the trial of seven indigent men accused of plotting to wage an armed jihad against the government acquitted one of the defendants but said they could not reach verdicts for the other six.
The spacewalk to examine a malfunctioning joint would have been performed by astronauts from the shuttle Atlantis if it had taken off on schedule last week.
Lehman Brothers, one of a handful of Wall Street banks to avoid large losses related to subprime mortgages, reported better than expected earnings for the fourth quarter.
The parasites kill so many juvenile wild salmon that they threaten the survival of fish populations in some rivers and streams, Canadian researchers are reporting.
No charges in the full Senate are expected soon for Joshua B. Bolten and Karl Rove.
Movie and television directors said that they were set to begin contract negotiations, jolting the striking writers.
The vote came only after Senator Harry Reid of Nevada agreed to remove provisions that would have meant hefty tax increases for oil companies.
China and the United States ended three days of economic talks with new accords on food safety, energy and environmental cooperation but only modest progress in opening China’s financial markets.
Forecasters said as many as 10 inches of snow could fall in the Boston area while the accumulation in New York City was likely to be 2 to 4 inches.
Global markets were down Thursday despite a plan by five central banks to inject capital into the banking system to ease credit fears.

After 18 years of selling investments in a fictitious Brazilian gold mining operation and using the Internet to sell wholesale merchandise they never delivered, a Rockland County family of five pleaded guilty on Wednesday to charges of defrauding victims across the nation and in Europe of millions of dollars, federal prosecutors said.
The International Truck and Engine Corporation reached a tentative agreement Wednesday with the United Automobile Workers’ leadership on three-year contracts for 3,700 striking workers.
Three days after winning a defensive slugfest against the Devils, the Rangers found themselves in a goal-scoring bonanza, which the Capitals won in overtime.
A one-day strike by unions representing 2.5 million workers brought Athens to a standstill.
A rare December tropical storm left at least 14 people dead in the Caribbean as pounding rains caused floods and landslides.
The International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia sentenced Dragomir Milosevic a former Bosnian-Serb general, to 33 years in prison.
Unesco said that the cyclone that struck southern Bangladesh last month destroyed 40 percent of the Sundarbans, one of the world’s largest mangrove forests and a World Heritage site.
Leaders from the government and the semiautonomous South said that they had resolved most of their differences and that the South’s main political party would rejoin the national unity government.
Twenty-one people were killed in a fire that tore through a 28-story apartment building in eastern Wenzhou.

Russia’s Foreign Ministry ordered Britain to close the cultural offices of the British Council outside of Moscow, saying it had broken tax laws and the Vienna Convention by operating out of British consulates.
Ales Kotalik had a goal and assist, Ryan Miller made 28 saves, and the Buffalo Sabres scored three goals in the second period to beat the visiting Islanders, 5-3, on Wednesday night.
In a report, the watchdog commission that oversees the police recommended that Taser stun guns be used only on people who are “combative or posing a risk of death or grievous bodily harm.”
The authorities said that federal agents raided a house in Tonalá, a suburb of Guadalajara, this week and seized more than $1.1 million in counterfeit $100 bills.
Epiphanny Prince scored 18 points and sparked the decisive run to lead No. 6 Rutgers to its third consecutive victory, 53-48, against host Princeton Wednesday night.
China’s retail sales increased at the quickest rate in at least eight years on rising incomes.
Australia’s largest casino company, Crown Ltd., said it agreed to buy Cannery Casino Resorts for $1.75 billion, expanding its business in Las Vegas.
Microsoft said it had agreed to acquire MultiMap, an online map service based in London, in an attempt to compete more effectively with the search services of Google.
Unemployment in Britain declined to 3.2 percent in November, the lowest level since 1975, as the strength of the economy encouraged companies to take on more workers.

Boys Town, which changed its name seven years ago to Girls and Boys Town, is back to being Boys Town. The home for wayward children dropped “girls” from its name because the longer name never caught on, a spokesman, John Melingagio, said. Mr. Melingagio added that the longer name did help get out the message that the organization cares for girls as well as boys. Boys Town started admitting girls in the 1970s, and the name was changed to Girls and Boys Town in 2000. The director at the time said the new name was intended to reflect the growing influence of girls, who make up about half of Boys Town’s residents. Boys Town was founded in 1917.

Residents of Potrero, a rural community in east San Diego County, voted to oust five members of the town’s planning board who endorsed a bid by Blackwater Worldwide to build a training camp. Three of the board’s nine members have already been removed because Blackwater opponents revealed that they had been improperly appointed. Election officials counted the recall ballots Tuesday night, said Deborah Seiler, registrar of voters for San Diego County. The five board members elected to fill the seats of the recalled board members oppose Blackwater’s development of an 824-acre tract of land near Potrero, close to the Mexican border, people on both sides of the debate said.

A judge has dismissed the final claim in a libel suit against The Atlanta Journal-Constitution filed by Richard Jewell, the former security guard wrongly linked to the 1996 Olympic bombing. Mr. Jewell, left, died of heart disease at age 44 in August. The judge, John R. Mather of State Court, dismissed the final claim Tuesday, said Peter Canfield, a lawyer for the newspaper. The judge had dismissed all but one of 22 claims last year. Mr. Jewell was hailed as a hero after the July 27, 1996, bombing at Centennial Olympic Park in Atlanta. But three days later, the newspaper described him as “the focus” of the investigation.

Civil rights groups filed a new federal lawsuit challenging an Arizona law that would cancel the business licenses of employers found guilty of hiring illegal immigrants more than once in three years. An earlier suit by the groups, including the American Civil Liberties Union, was dismissed on Friday by Judge Neil V. Wake of Federal District Court, who said they had sued the wrong government officials. The groups said they expected the new lawsuit would address the judge’s concerns. The law is to take effect Jan. 1.

An Erie woman convicted of swinging her newborn son like a weapon at her boyfriend and fracturing the infant’s skull was sentenced to 5 to 10 years in prison. The woman, Chytoria Graham, 28, was fighting with her boyfriend, DeAngelo Troop, when she grabbed her son, Jarron, who was 4 weeks old, by his feet and swung him, hitting Mr. Troop. The baby has recovered and is living with Ms. Graham’s family. A jury convicted Ms. Graham in October of aggravated assault and reckless endangerment, among other charges.

Troy Murphy’s most important assist will not show up in the box score. Indiana’s Murphy and Chicago’s Tyrus Thomas were ejected from Wednesday’s game after an altercation. Indiana used it as motivation in a 117-102 win over the visiting Bulls.
ALBANY (AP) — New York State and Amtrak have resolved a contract dispute and a federal lawsuit, officials of the state’s Department of Transportation announced on Wednesday.

ALBANY — The State Senate plans to return here Thursday for a special session, but it appears that lawmakers will accomplish little. Senate Republicans have been negotiating with Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Assembly Democrats over largely the same set of issues for more than six months, but have yet to achieve much in the way of results.

Irked by layoffs, cleanliness problems, customer service complaints and violation of state regulations by the new owner of the Tropicana Casino and Resort, the state Casino Control Commission refused on Wednesday to renew its operating license. The move was only the second time in the 29-year history of legalized gambling in New Jersey that the commission has denied a license. The casino will remain open under the supervision of a retired State Supreme Court justice, Gary S. Stein. But a commission spokesman, Dan Heneghan, said that the Columbia Sussex Corporation, which owns the Tropicana, would have to seek a buyer. Paul O’Gara, a lawyer for Columbia Sussex, said the company was disappointed by the ruling and would appeal.

Response times have not increased since the Fire Department adopted new rules last month requiring fire companies to devote an additional three hours each week to the inspection of high-rise buildings under construction and demolition, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta, left, said at a City Council hearing on Wednesday. The companies now dedicate nine hours a week to inspections. Between Nov. 5 and Dec. 11, firefighters inspected 97 percent of the 468 such high-rise buildings. The average response time for citywide emergencies stood at 4 minutes 46 seconds last month — 5 seconds less than in November 2006 and 13 seconds less than in November 2005, Mr. Scoppetta said.

An employee of the city’s Department of Education was charged on Wednesday with taking cash bribes from at least five school bus companies in exchange for giving them advance notice about city inspections and for granting them favorable bus routes. In a complaint filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the employee, Geoffrey Berger, a borough supervisor in charge of city school bus routes in Westchester County and the Bronx, was charged with taking thousands of dollars of bribes for at least five years. The charges against him arose from a federal investigation into Mafia influence over the city school bus drivers’ union, Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union.

About 8,500 additional patients of a Long Island doctor will be advised to get tested for blood-borne diseases as an inquiry into his practice expands, the state’s Department of Health says. The agency initially told 628 patients of the doctor, Harvey S. Finkelstein, an anesthesiologist with a practice in Plainview, that they might be at risk for hepatitis and H.I.V. Health officials have said he dipped syringes more than once into vials of medicine, contaminating the drugs and infecting at least one person with hepatitis. Dr. Finkelstein says he has changed his technique.

Several thousand janitors, doormen and other employees who help clean and operate New York City’s office buildings voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to authorize a strike on Jan. 1 if the city’s real estate industry does not grant them the substantial raise their union is seeking. Mike Fishman, the union’s president, said that a large raise was warranted because office rents in Manhattan have jumped by more than 25 percent in the past year. Negotiators for the building owners say that the workers are already the nation’s highest paid and that the industry could be hurt by the shaky economy.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer has nominated Ronald Goldstock to be New York State’s commissioner on the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, a bistate agency that certifies dockworkers and polices the waterfront. Mr. Goldstock previously worked as managing director at Kroll Associates, a private security firm, and was director of the New York State Organized Crime Task Force for more than 13 years. If approved by the State Senate, Mr. Goldstock would succeed Michael C. Axelrod. On Oct. 15, Mr. Spitzer issued an executive order instructing the state’s inspector general, Kristine Hamann, to look at “allegations of misfeasance and nonfeasance by personnel of the Waterfront Commission, including allegations of misconduct, conflicts of interest, abuse and waste.”.

Verizon plans to erect 11 cellphone towers near the Adirondack Northway to fill the service gap along a remote stretch where a Brooklyn motorist crashed and froze to death in January, unable to call for help. The Adirondack Park Agency is scheduled on Thursday to consider a staff recommendation to approve the first tower, which would rise 94 feet above Route 9 in North Hudson. Verizon currently has more than 20 cell towers in the Adirondacks, a company spokesman said.
In this city, known for its writers, even Central Park’s benches have stories to tell.
The director of the C.I.A. acknowledged his agency failed to keep Congress fully informed about videotapes of interrogations of suspected Al Qaeda operatives.
Mr. Turner was an R&B musician, songwriter, bandleader, producer, talent scout and the ex-husband of Tina Turner.
A Miami man who brought $800,000 into Argentina was trying to deliver a campaign contribution from the Venezuelan government to Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, American prosecutors said.
A lawyer is claiming that he is owed money and credit for helping the producer David Chase gather the ideas, people and locations for the HBO series “The Sopranos.”
A public opinion poll in Pakistan has found that 67 percent of Pakistanis want President Pervez Musharraf to resign immediately.
The struggle over immigration may seem distant in states like Iowa, but the debate is part of daily life in Storm Lake.
The wife of a police officer who died during a car chase on Staten Island in 2000 has been trying to show that her husband’s supervisors knowingly sent him on patrol in an unsuitable car.
Distrust and racial tension among Hispanics, Asians and blacks in the United States are pressing concerns for all three groups, a new poll shows.
Congressional Democrats said on Wednesday that they would finance the federal government at roughly the amount insisted on by President Bush but shift more money to their favored causes.

A front-page article on Sunday about ethnic tensions in northern Iraq’s oil-rich city of Kirkuk over its uncertain political future misstated the capital of neighboring Turkey, which opposes a desire by Iraqi Kurds to control Kirkuk and wants to safeguard Kirkuk’s Turkmen minority. It is Ankara, not Istanbul. The article also misidentified the area of Turkey where most of its ethnic Kurdish population lives. It is the southeast, not northeast. And the article misstated the ethnic background of Tahsin Kahya, a member of the Kirkuk Provincial Council, who said that a constitutional referendum on Kirkuk’s future, which is supposed to be held before Dec. 31, should be delayed for years. He is a Turkmen, not an Arab.

The Semel Society records with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Jonathan Sogg. We extend heartfelt condolences to his children Cathy Lawrence and Julie Seymour, and his sister Judith Strone, his grandchildren and family. Martin I. Semel, President SOGG--Jonathan Semel, on December 11, 2007. Beloved and loving father of Cathy Lawrence (Chris) and Julie Seymour (John Laird). Adoring and adored Pa of Alexander, Zoe and Charles Lawrence, and Annabel Seymour. Caring brother of Judith Strone. Dear husband of the late Barbara. Founder and President of Semel Sogg Textiles. Services Thursday, December 13, 11:15am at the ''Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Lyon and Fenerbahce won their final group games Wednesday to gain the last two spots in the knockout round of the Champions League. Two late goals by Karim Benzema added to an early one by Sidney Govou in Lyon's 3-0 victory at Rangers, who needed only a tie to advance and eliminate Lyon, the French champion. Fenerbahce trailed against visiting CSKA Moscow after an own-goal by Edu, but turned the game around through its playmaker Alex and two goals by Ugur Boral. Fenerbahce took second place ahead of PSV Eindhoven, which lost by 1-0 at home against the Group G winner Inter Milan.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the sentencing of Conrad M. Black, the former media mogul who was convicted of fraud, misspelled the name of the town where he bought his first newspaper. It is Sherbrooke, Quebec -- not Sherbooke. The article also misstated, in some editions, the proximity of the federal prison camp at Eglin Air Force Base, where Mr. Black is likely to serve his sentence, to his Palm Beach, Fla., home. It is 500 miles away, it is not ''near.''
GOODSTEIN--Colonel Mortimer J. Esquire, 95, of Palm Beach, FL and NYC, passed away peacefully on December 11th, 2007.

MALKIN--Moses M., December 11, 2007, born September 18, 1919, formerly of New Haven. Beloved husband of Hannah (Lacob). They resided between Sun City Center, FL, and Marthas Vineyard. Veteran of WWII. Mechanical Engineer and Pension Actuary. Founder and former President of Professional Pensions of New Haven. A caring, charitable, generous and good man, he was greatly loved by his family and friends. Services at the Levine Chapels, 470 Harvard St., Brookline, MA on Sunday, December 16, at 11:00am. Donations may be made to the charity of choice.

A report by The Associated Press in the Sports Briefing column on Wednesday about the naming of Larry Holmes to the International Boxing Hall of Fame attributed an erroneous distinction to him. Joe Louis -- not Holmes -- remains the longest reigning world heavyweight champion. (Louis held the title for 11 years and 10 months, from 1937-49, though he did not defend the title for several years because he was in the Army. Holmes held the title for nearly seven years, 1978-85.)

Shoveling snow as a boy, Hillel Glazer had what seemed like an obvious idea: adding an electrical heating element to a rubber doormat, to melt the snow so he wouldn't have to shovel the mat. Now Mr. Glazer, 29, has a company called Heat Trak that makes mats up to 25 feet long for commercial sites. They plug into outdoor outlets and heat to 50 degrees above the ambient temperature, melting two inches of snow an hour, he said. Last month he introduced his first residential doormat (around $130), above, and stair mat (around $50). The new mats are sold at Hammacher Schlemmer (hammacher.com), Frontgate (frontgate.com) and Bed, Bath and Beyond (bedbathandbeyond.com); commercial mats are available from Heat Trak at (866) 766-9628 or heattrak.com. ELAINE LOUIE

Former President Bill Clinton is in negotiations to sever his relationship with the Yucaipa Companies, a privately held California investment firm headed by Ronald W. Burkle, according to two people familiar with the discussions. Advisers to Mr. Clinton are negotiating terms with Yucaipa to end his involvement as part of a months-old plan for him to divest himself of holdings that could become a conflict of interest or prove politically embarrassing if his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, wins the Democratic presidential nomination.

Four limited-edition pieces of furniture based on prototypes by the late Danish designer Poul Kjaerholm are on tour. Made in Denmark under a joint venture of the R Gallery and the Sean Kelly Gallery, both in Manhattan, they were exhibited last week at Art Basel Miami Beach and Design Miami, and starting on Saturday will be on display at the two galleries, along with vintage Kjaerholm furniture and contemporary art. The 1953 molded aluminum tripod chair, above, one of the four pieces, is being sold in editions of 25 in each of four colors -- gray, black, yellow and blue -- for $12,000. Through Feb. 2 at Sean Kelly Gallery, 528 West 29th Street, (212) 239-1181, and R Gallery, 82 Franklin Street, (212) 343-7979. MELISSA FELDMAN

The Schlesinger family, Stuart, Linda, Adam, Natasha, Michael, Bari, Lauren and Adam SOLOMON--Amy E. Rosenblatt, M.D. President Shirley Strum Kenny and the entire Stony Brook University Community wish to send condolences to the family of Dr. Amy Rosenblatt Solomon, whose untimely death on December 8, 2007, will be deeply mourned. A pediatrician, Dr. Solomon, 38, was the mother of Jessica (six), Samuel (four) and James (one), the wife of Dr. Harrison Solomon, the sister of Carl and John Rosenblatt, and the daughter of our esteemed colleague, Professor Roger Rosenblatt and his wife, Virginia. We know that Dr. Solomon was a gifted, generous woman who made enormous contributions to the world around her and she will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to her alma mater, NYU School of Medicine; Alumni Relations; 550 1st Ave., NY, NY 10016.

Maybe this is why Duke has perennially struggled: There is nothing in the coach's job description about winning games. All the details are spelled out on the university's human resources Web site, where -- right above an ad for a nursing assistant -- there is a job posting for Head Football Coach. Just click to apply.The listing was posted Nov. 29, three days after Ted Roof was fired, and runs down duties expected of the new coach, such as counseling players in academic and disciplinary matters, preparing budget recommendations and assigning assistants to recruit specific regions of the country. The coach also must represent Duke at civic, charity and alumni events. Despite what Athletic Director Joe Alleva has said, nowhere in job requisition No. 400160742 is it mentioned that the new coach's most important task is winning. The Blue Devils have won just 22 games in 13 years, including three losing streaks of 15 games or worse.

Shoppers who want to do their part for Mother Earth in these environmentally trying times -- or at least not do anything to hasten the old girl to a cindery, burned-out death -- may be interested in a new line of home décor products made from recycled concrete: serving trays, perfect for offering drinks to Al Gore; nesting tables (far right) that have the powerful look of cornerstones but are fortunately equipped with casters (otherwise, at the respective weights of 130 and 200 pounds, it might be difficult to haul these babies, which sell for $250 and $300, around the patio); and coasters, at $5 the perfect stocking stuffer for that insufferable green-police sister-in-law who regards those who still use plastic water bottles as if they were Jack the Ripper. Just introduced by Robin Wilson, an interior designer, for her new Robin Wilson Home line, the products are made of material from demolished bridges and buildings. They come in 14 colors and two finishes, honed and ''artisanal'' (i.e., rough). Smaller pieces include serving trays ($36 to $46) and nesting bowls ($50 for a set of three), above with Ms. Wilson. The bowls can be made with holes to serve as planters. The products are not, she insists, as heavy as one might think, though she agrees that it might be best not to plop the 12-pound, 17-by-13-inch serving tray on the chest of one's bedridden grandma.

MALLEN--Robert S., 91, died December 11, 2007 at Los Robles Hospital, Thousand Oaks, CA. Survived by his beloved wife of 61 years, Mary T. Mallen, son Michael Mallen, daughter-in-law Rochelle Mallen, grandchildren Marc and Sara Mallen. Interment Hillside Memorial Park, in Los Angeles, today.

Hoping for a boost on offense and with ticket sales, Southern Mississippi hired Larry Fedora, the Oklahoma State offensive coordinator, as its new coach Wednesday. Fedora replaced Jeff Bower, who was forced to resign last month after 17 seasons and 119 victories. Fedora told about 1,000 fans, reporters and pep band members that he could squeeze more from a program that had already been a proven winner and Conference USA contender every season. Any Body's Custom Design Embroidery, also known as ABCDE, will personalize towels, blankets, napkins and clothing with embroidery in any of 20,000 designs or 40 typefaces. Simple monograms start at $5; more complicated ones, like a name and address that stretch from one end of a towel to the other, cost about $12. Customers may take in a little drawing to be embroidered on a piece of fabric; the onetime set-up fee for such custom work starts at $50. ABCDE, Pier 17, South Street Seaport; (212) 267-7070 or abcde-embroidery.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

ROCK climbing has become child's play. Proportionally long limbs, light body weights and fearless attitudes make children as young as 6 naturals at the sport. The proliferation of climbing gyms, which present a safe, controlled environment, has encouraged participation among young athletes, too. According to USA Climbing, membership among those age 19 or younger has grown 44 percent since 2004, more than double that of its members age 20 or over. Some climbing-shoe manufacturers have added smaller sizes to adult lines, while others have created shoes specifically for kids. Five Ten adapted a top-selling adult shoe for children by making it lighter and easier to put on, said Charles Cole, the founder and chief executive. Its Mini Mocc, new this month, has a thinner rubber outsole than its adult Moccasym and a Velcro closure. And Mad Rock Climbing introduced its children's Flash Lace shoe this month.

Statistics can be tricky things. Recently some of us at the City section were talking about a Times article by Al Baker detailing how remarkably low crime numbers have fallen in the city. Around the same time, though, we had heard from some Brooklyn residents that they were increasingly nervous lately about street crime. We also got a news release from Anthony Herbert, a candidate for the State Senate in next year’s elections, about a group he is forming called the Downtown Brooklyn Safety Task force, to deal with what he says is an increase in robberies and muggings in the neighborhoods around Downtown Brooklyn.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, while holding raises for other city employees to about 4 percent per year, has given more than 200 members of his staff pay raises ranging from 10 percent to more than 100 percent, Diane Cardwell and Jo Craven McGinty report in a front-page article based on an examination of payroll records. Fifty-seven staff members have received a raise of at least 10 percent more than once. In addition, the number of employees earning $100,000 or more has risen by 59 percent, to 105 from 66 in 2002, with the bulk of that increase coming in 2006, after the mayor won re-election.

Credit card machines have now been installed in about half the city’s nearly 13,100 yellow cabs; all taxis are scheduled to have them by Jan. 31. From time to time, we have heard complaints about drivers refusing to take credit cards, or claiming that the machines were broken (some readers have posted complaints here on City Room). So the Metro Section decided to investigate. We sent out five reporters with instructions to try 20 trips each. They fanned out in Manhattan, boarded cabs and asked cabbies the question, “I’ve only got a credit card, is that O.K.?”

Most visitors to the Unites States will tell you that service in American restaurants and hotels is generally as friendly and as unpretentious as you will find anywhere. I know that because I grew up in England, where every waiter in a rundown cafe greeted me as I were a summons to the police and every worker in an upscale place as if I were a fly that had landed on the duck à l'orange. In Japan, where I now live, service in even a convenience store is efficient, quick and impeccably polite, but you won't get the genuine laughs or banter that you often find in even a bank in New York. Democracy finds its vindication, I often think, in the cheerful, ungrudging attention you get across what is perhaps the world's most open nation.

As you probably know by now, I'm a big fan of stepping away from traditional models of work in favor of customized methods of defining success. Here are three concepts I like a lot:

The announcement that JetBlue, the struggling discount carrier, sold a 19 percent stake in its business to Lufthansa of Germany for $300 million Thursday, seemed to leave many analysts scratching their heads.

The sale of the Italian government's stake in Alitalia took a bizarre twist Thursday after the company said it had received an 11th-hour approach from a group that included Singapore Airlines - a claim that the Asian carrier swiftly and categorically denied.

Citigroup said Thursday it would rescue seven affiliated investment funds, holding $49 billion worth of assets, which have been upended by the running crisis in housing-related debt. The decision, which came just two days into Vikram S. Pandit's tenure as the bank's chief executive, is likely to shift billions of dollars' worth of securities from the troubled vehicles onto Citi's own balance sheet early next year.
The Federal Communications Commission chairman, Kevin J. Martin, has rejected a senator's request to delay a vote on a change in media-ownership rules.
A new hedge fund run by the Carlyle Group reportedly lost almost 10 percent of its value in October while rival funds on average rose by 3 percent.
NewsGator Technologies, a developer of RSS software for consumers and corporate users, has snared a $12 million funding round led by new investor Vista Ventures, the company said Thursday.
BlackRock's co-founder and chief investment officer of fixed income, Keith Anderson, has quit to start his own debt fund, in an attempt to take advantage of volatile credit markets.
After getting tripped up by the mortgage mess, industry insiders as well as observers are wondering how this year's bonus season on Wall Street will play out.
Lehman Brothers' chief Richard Fuld deserves his raise, despite the 14 percent drop in the investment bank's share price during its most recent fiscal year, argues Breakingviews.
From Friday's Times:
Amid all the doom and gloom in the financial markets these days, the Man Group, the publicly traded British hedge fund, sees a silver lining.

Biogen Idec executives with pre-arranged stock trading programs accelerated their sales of company stock options and other restricted shares within days of an Oct. 12 announcement that the biotech firm would seek a buyer, according to TheStreet.com, which cited an independent report analyzing insider stock sales.

Analysts seemed divided on the results reported by Lehman Brothers, which ushered in a bleak earnings season for Wall Street on Thursday by saying quarterly profit fell 12 percent, reflecting a slump in its core fixed-income business. But while some analysts were disappointed, others were relieved.
From Reuters:

Vikram Pandit's appointment to Citigroup's top post was big news on Wall Street earlier this week. The news also caused quite a stir in Mr. Pandit's native India, where his family has been besieged by the media.

Leaders of the New York Board of Trade voted Thursday to close most of the exchange's 137-year old trading floor and move trading in commodities such as coffee, sugar and cocoa to the computer screen.
Spanish property company Inmobiliaria Colonial has held preliminary merger talks with French real estate firm Gecina, but no formal deal is on the table, it said on Friday.

Online education provider K12, founded by former U.S. Secretary of Education William Bennett and backed by former junk-bond king Michael R. Milken, rose sharply a day after raising $108 million in an initial public offering that priced at the top of expectations.
School recess isn't what it used to be, as this school in Connecticut attests:
ON Semiconductor agreed to buy chipmaker Amis Holdings for $915 million agreement, driven in part by depressed stock valuations and the specter of a down cycle in the chip industry.
Shares of Medassets, a supplier of software and services to hospital and healthcare systems, surged nearly 28 percent Thursday in their first trading day.

Temasek, the Singapore state investment agency, said Thursday that it raised its stake in Sorak Financial, the main shareholder in Bank Internasional Indonesia, from just over 50 percent to 75 percent.

Zeugma Systems, a post-bubble telecom start-up, raised $22.5 million in a second round of funding to complete testing and launch commercial sales of carrier equipment for high-speed broadband networks.

Fledgling British buyout shop Darwin Private Equity announced its first transaction on Thursday, acquiring Maximuscle, a Watford, England-based sports nutrition company, for 75 million pounds ($154 million).

London buyout shop Barclays Private Equity announced the sale Thursday of its factory outlet chain, Original Factory Shop, to crosstown rival Duke Street Capital for 68.5 million pounds ($139.8 million), making 2.4 times its money.

As part of a new campaign to educate American investors, Finra, the private regulator for securities firms and stockbrokers, points people to its huge database that tracks brokers who have run into trouble with customers.

Market euphoria over trans-Atlantic action by central banks to fix the global credit crisis wore off quickly Thursday, with investors saying they expect the injection of cash to do little to solve long-term problems.

Boston Scientific, the maker of medical devices, said on Thursday that it had agreed to sell its fluid management and venous access businesses for $425 million to the private equity firm Avista Capital Partners.

The owners of Discovery Communications, Advance/Newhouse and Discovery Holding, have agreed in principle to combine their stakes and turn the company, an operator of cable TV channels, into an independent, publicly traded company.

For the fourth time in two weeks, John Edwards held a town-hall-style event in Iowa on Thursday night, this time addressing a hall of waiting supporters in Indianola. But just beforehand, he slipped into a side room, away from reporters, for a closed-door meeting with another group he wants to court: the undecided.

Some months ago, my colleague Nicola Clark had great ideas about how to have fun with kids in Paris. So now I'll take up the baton. My two children -- today both fans of Rome -- used to start each day with the declaration "We'll go anywhere but churches and museums." OK (deep breath).

When Iowans caucus on Jan. 3, the state's college students will be spread far and wide on winter break. But some colleges are trying to make it easy for their students to give up home cooking for a few days and head back to campus early to help nominate the next president.

The exclusion of Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio and Mike Gravel from the Democratic debate on Thursday stung those candidates and their supporters. But what made the situation puzzling was the presence on Wednesday at the Republicans' version of The Des Moines Register debate of Alan Keyes, who had until then been nearly invisible in this campaign.
“Youth Without Youth” is a narratively ambitious, visually sumptuous surrealist enterprise that tries to bend time and space together as neatly as the folds in an origami swan.
“A Walk Into the Sea” is Esther B. Robinson’s documentary about Danny Williams, a former Harvard student who was a part of Andy Warhol’s Factory scene.
Can singing change history? “The Singing Revolution,” a documentary by James Tusty and Maureen Castle Tusty about Estonia’s struggle to end Soviet occupation, shows that it already has.
“Look,” an unsettling, rudely funny but not entirely credible feature by the writer and director Adam Rifkin, is an ensemble narrative for the age of public surveillance.
In spite of its third-act collapse into obviousness and sentimentality, “I Am Legend” is among Will Smith’s better movies.
In both novel and film form, “The Kite Runner” recounts a simple yet shrewd story about that favorite American pastime: self-improvement.
For his poetic fourth feature, “Half Moon,” Bahman Ghobadi returns to the desolation of the Kurdish borderlands and the enduring optimism of his people.
Hollywood continues its tired milking of old television properties with “Alvin and the Chipmunks,” a slick updating of the musical-cartoon franchise.
In “Arranged” two devout Brooklyn schoolteachers clutch hands across the religious divide as their respective families prepare to marry them off.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Mike Huckabee apologized to rivals this week, but their campaigns kept the original slurs alive afterward.
Maintaining the Bush tax cuts, as G.O.P. candidates have promised, would require running faster and faster to stay in place.

President Bush said Friday that he was troubled by the report linking many prominent baseball players to performance-enhancing substances.
The Ethiopian government, a top American ally in Africa, is forcing civilians to fight rebels, according to Western officials, refugees and defectors.
Democrats' fund-raising advantage over the G.O.P. could be offset by independent conservative groups.
The pick-up in prices will complicate efforts by the Fed as it tries to stave off a slowdown in economic growth.
President Evo Morales put this nation’s armed forces on a state of alert on Thursday as four of Bolivia’s provinces prepared declarations seeking greater autonomy from the central government.

A memorial service Thursday marked the 30th anniversary of an airplane crash that killed 29 people, including the entire Evansville men’s team. A wreath with purple and white flowers was placed at a crash memorial monument on a campus plaza.The team plane, a twin-engine DC-3, crashed in rain and heavy fog on Dec. 13, 1977, after takeoff from Evansville Dress Regional Airport to Murfreesboro, Tenn..
Confidence in business conditions at major Japanese companies fell from three months ago dampening expectations of an interest rate increase and clouding the outlook for the world’s No. 2 economy.
Five men were charged on Thursday in connection with a brush fire that destroyed dozens of homes in Malibu in November.
Bill Guerin snapped a scoreless tie in the second period and added a goal in the third to lift the host Islanders to victory in a matchup of the N.H.L’s lowest-scoring teams.

The Pasadena Journal article on Wednesday, about a Texas homeowner, Joe Horn, who killed two men breaking into a house next door, misstated the surname of Mr. Horn’s lawyer. He is Charles T. Lambright, not Lambrecht.

A film review in Weekend last Friday about “The Band’s Visit,” using information provided by the film’s public relations firm, referred incorrectly to the actor Sasson Gabai, who plays the band’s leader. He is an Israeli Jew, not an Israeli Arab.

The Saturday Interview column in Business Day last week, about the turnaround efforts of the retailer Eddie Bauer, misstated one achievement, based on a comment by its chief executive, McNeil S. Fiske Jr., of the company’s founder. While Eddie Bauer was an outdoorsman and athlete, he did not climb Mount Everest.

Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on Thursday about a promised gift of 130 artworks from Janice and Henri Lazarof to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art included an outdated reference to tax law governing partial donations. (The museum now owns a small percentage of each work, and the remainder is to be transferred over time.) Under the current law, the tax deduction for partial gifts does not rise from year to year if works appreciate in value. Thus donors no longer benefit from bigger deductions for such appreciation.

The Pasadena Journal article on Wednesday, about a Texas homeowner, Joe Horn, who killed two men breaking into a house next door, misstated the surname of Mr. Horn’s lawyer. He is Charles T. Lambright, not Lambrecht.

An article on Saturday about two brothers who plunged 47 stories while preparing to wash windows on a Manhattan building misspelled, in some editions, the surname of a neighbor of the brothers in Linden, N.J., who described the men as industrious and family-oriented. She is Iwona Roszkowska, not Rosckowski.
The Federal Communications Commission chairman, Kevin J. Martin, has rejected a senator’s request to delay a vote on a change in media-ownership rules.

A news analysis article on Nov. 29 about the diplomatic style of Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, including her handling of the Middle East, referred incorrectly to President Bush’s position on the fate of Palestinian refugees in his remarks on Nov. 27 at the Middle East peace conference in Annapolis, Md. While Mr. Bush called Israel “a homeland for the Jewish people,” this was an implicit support for Israel’s view that Palestinians should not be guaranteed a right of return to their former homes inside Israel. Mr. Bush did not “explicitly” take on that issue and side with Israel.
Maybe, just maybe, the New York region is going to have a real winter. The question is what it will be like.
Manuel Antonio Noriega will get a new hearing in Miami to try to avoid extradition to France from the United States.
The government detained five leaders of an ethnic Indian organization under a strict and rarely used security law after they were accused of threatening national security.
Ludmil Dionissiev, an oil trader, was sentenced in New York to two years of probation and a $5,000 fine for his role in a conspiracy to defraud the United Nations oil-for-food program.
The popular right-wing Swiss People’s Party, Switzerland’s biggest, pulled out of the coalition cabinet, ending nearly a half-century of consensus government.
The Brazilian Senate refused to renew an unpopular tax on financial transactions like checks and A.T.M. withdrawals.
A bomb tore through a New Delhi-bound high-speed train traveling in northeast Assam State, killing five passengers.
President Robert G. Mugabe’s party nominated him as its candidate in the presidential election in March, demonstrating his continuing influence despite Zimbabwe’s economic collapse.
A fan at Wednesday’s Knicks game claims that he was told that he would be ejected from Madison Square Garden if he did not stop yelling criticism at Isiah Thomas.
A pizzeria operator charged with hiring assassins to kill a Genovese crime family associate in Brooklyn in 1994 was cleared of the charges Thursday night for a second time.

Eastern Michigan University will pay $2.5 million to the family of a student raped and killed in her dorm room a year ago, university and family representatives said. The settlement does not include any admission of liability on the part of the university. The slaying of student, Laura Dickinson, 22, of Hastings, drew attention to security at the university in Ypsilanti. The university’s president was fired in the wake of a cover-up of information about the slaying. Ms. Dickinson was found dead on Dec. 15, 2006. A fellow student, Orange Taylor III of Southfield, was charged, but his first trial ended in a hung jury. He is awaiting a second trial.
Carbon dioxide in the air is turning the oceans acidic, and without a reduction in emissions, coral reefs may die away by the end of the century, researchers warn in the journal Science.

A Mexican citizen legally in the United States has sued the Maricopa County Sheriff’s Office, claiming its aggressive immigration enforcement has led to ethnic profiling. The lawsuit, filed Wednesday in federal court, outlines several instances where Sheriff Joe Arpaio and his deputies are accused of overstepping their authority. Sheriff Arpaio called the suit frivolous and said it was an effort to intimidate him before his office begins enforcing a new law on Jan. 1 that threatens employers with penalties if they hire illegal workers. The suit seeks a judgment that Sheriff Arpaio’s actions are unconstitutional and the disbanding of the Illegal Immigration Interdiction unit. The suit is based on the claims of Manuel de Jesus Ortega Melendres, a retired teacher, who was stopped by deputies on Sept. 26 in suburban Cave Creek.

A federal appeals court in San Francisco upheld an 2002 injunction barring three California marijuana clubs from giving the drug to medical patients with a prescription. The ruling by judges on the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit sided with the Justice Department, which first sued the dispensaries in 1998 to stop sales of medical marijuana to patients with a doctor’s approval, as allowed under a California law approved by voters in 1996. The law has been at the heart of a series of legal battles over state and federal drug laws, which categorize marijuana as illegal. The ruling was likely the last legal recourse for the clubs. In 2001, the United States Supreme Court heard the case and ruled against the California cooperatives.

Seven Western states have signed an interstate water-sharing agreement that officials hail as a way to blunt the impact of drought on states that draw from the Colorado River. Interior Secretary Dirk Kempthorne also signed the agreement at a ceremony at the Colorado River Water Users Association meeting in Las Vegas. Mr. Kempthorne called the pact the most important agreement since the states began sharing water from the river in 1922. The 20-year operations plan involves Arizona, California, Colorado, Nevada, New Mexico, Utah and Wyoming.
Three philanthropic groups plan to give $17.5 million for public schools in New Orleans.
Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Rhode Island will pay $20 million but avoid criminal charges after a federal investigation into improper lobbying of state legislators by its executives.
Rudolph W. Giuliani’s consulting firm says a deal it conducted in 2002 did not violate a federal law that prohibits payment of a commission in return for a federal contract.
Shareholders of Dow Jones & Company gave their blessing to a takeover by Rupert Murdoch’s global media empire, the News Corporation.
Past personal and political catastrophe has become part of the narrative of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign.
Arizona’s law to address illegal immigration could test states’ ability to crack down on the countless businesses that have relied on illegal workers.
Lufthansa’s investment in JetBlue, the struggling discount carrier, is the latest example of a foreign company’s taking advantage of the weak dollar to invest in a prominent American company.
Citigroup moved on Thursday to rescue seven affiliated investment funds that have been upended by the running crisis in housing-related debt.
The New York Times Company announced the promotion of two executives on Thursday.
The oil industry and utilities succeeded in stripping out provisions that would have cost them billions of dollars.
Movie and television directors said Thursday that they were prepared to begin bargaining toward a new contract with production companies after the New Year holiday.
A midcareer comedian got a call to become the sportscaster on the ballyhooed return-of-Imus broadcast.
Two big manufacturers said Thursday that they expected stronger growth next year despite the slowing economy.
An audio exhibition at the Historical Society in Brooklyn Heights features recorded stories from Vietnam veterans.

A Queens Village man has been charged with abducting and raping a college student after she left a party celebrating her birthday on Saturday night, prosecutors said on Thursday. The suspect, James Moye, 19, was arraigned on Thursday on charges of rape, second-degree kidnapping and sexual assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Prosecutors charge that Mr. Moye and an accomplice chased the woman after she left the party and forced her into a van at gunpoint. After raping the woman in the van, prosecutors said, the two men drove to Jamaica Center and told her to get out.

The scaffold that collapsed atop an Upper East Side building last week, sending two window washers plunging 47 stories in an accident that killed one of them, was cited in the summer for 10 violations by a State Labor Department inspector. The 10 violations were relatively minor, a department spokesman said on Thursday, and the inspector did not have to order the scaffold shut down. A spokesman for the Solow Management Corporation, which owns the building at 265 East 66th Street, said the violations had been corrected and had nothing to do with the accident. The window washer who survived, Alcides Moreno, remained in critical condition at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital.

The Senate convened Thursday for a special session, but accomplished little beyond reinforcing how far apart state leaders remain on a number of issues. The Senate, dominated by Republicans, passed a largely symbolic bill granting state judges their first raises in nearly a decade, but Senate officials privately acknowledged that the move was made largely to antagonize Democrats. Lawmakers have not had a raise since 1999, and Assembly Democrats in particular have insisted that they receive a raise along with judges. The issue, however, has become tied up among a number of measures being negotiated between the houses and Gov. Eliot Spitzer. Lawmakers earn a base salary of $79,500 but often make much more from stipends for leadership and committee positions.

A man who prosecutors claim led an international heroin-smuggling operation has been extradited from Austria to face charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan, prosecutors said Thursday. The man, Hussein Karimi, an Iranian then living in Romania, was arrested in March as he tried to enter Azerbaijan, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Garcia said Mr. Karimi was charged after a joint investigation between the Drug Enforcement Administration and Romanian law enforcement officials into a smuggling operation that sent millions of dollars of heroin to Europe, Canada and the United States.

The New York State Board of Regents announced on Thursday that it had been awarded more than $6 million in grants from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the Wallace Foundation to improve the way it keeps track of graduation rates from high schools and colleges. A new system will track student progress through college. The system is intended to streamline the way school districts and state and city colleges keep track of student success. Currently, each district and college keeps track of its own statistics, making it difficult to make comparisons or know how well each student is performing after elementary, middle or high school. The grants will also finance a $3 million contract to study the effectiveness of the State Department of Education.

Students at the Glen Oaks School campus were confined to their classrooms for about two hours and kept beyond their normal 2:30 p.m. dismissal after a note threatening seven students was found on Thursday, the police said. Two girls in 11th grade at the High School of Teaching, Liberal Arts and Sciences, one of five public schools on the campus, in Bellerose, were arrested Thursday night in connection with the note, but investigators declined to identify them and said that the exact charges were still being determined. The police said the note, signed “Anonymous,” included a suicide threat and was found about 1:45 p.m. in a mailbox outside the office of an assistant principal. The police were immediately called, and all students were ordered to remain in place until they were dismissed without incident at 3:50 p.m.

A federal prosecutor on Thursday said the government would end its oversight of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey on Dec. 31, two years and two days after federal officials took control of the troubled school. Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney in New Jersey, said the monitor, Herbert J. Stern, would end his duties the same day. Monitoring was imposed after it was discovered that the university double-billed for services covered by Medicare. Mr. Stern oversaw day-to-day operations and the school’s $1.6 billion budget, and said he found more than $400 million in waste, fraud and abuse. Compiled by John Sullivan.
Nintendo has been unable to keep up with demand for the Wii, its intensely popular video game machine, costing the company hundreds of millions of dollars in potential sales.
Former Prime Minister Brian Mulroney acknowledged to a parliamentary committee that he had accepted large cash payments from a German-Canadian arms dealer and lobbyist beginning in 1993.
Americans are notoriously uninformed about faiths other than their own, and they are particularly perplexed about Mormon beliefs.
A man charged with plotting to blow up the Sears Tower was acquitted, and a mistrial was declared for six others.

The United States and China ended three days of intense economic talks with accords on food safety, energy and environmental cooperation, but with only modest progress in opening Chinese financial markets.

A prison’s basketball court was turned into a court of law after no courthouse was deemed secure enough for a hearing about the state’s death penalty.

As befits a place that sometimes takes pride in its otherness and even in its relative isolation, Staten Island has evolved a lexicon of words and phrases that require explanation to off-islanders.

Law enforcement officials said Thursday that there was strong evidence that the imprisoned rapist who confessed this week to murdering six women more than 25 years ago in Cape Girardeau, Mo., and Carbondale, Ill., also killed women in as many as three other jurisdictions.
A free online service allows investors to check up on brokers to see if they have had run-ins with regulators or clients. But hundreds of complaints are erased each year.

American astronauts aboard the International Space Station said Thursday that they would perform an extra spacewalk next week to examine malfunctioning joints that turn a set of solar power panels.

Less than three months after Microsoft lost a landmark antitrust case in Europe, a Norwegian software company filed a new complaint Thursday, challenging the software giant’s bundling of its Web browser with its Windows operating system.

Several months after shocking Michigan, Appalachian State is competing for its third consecutive national championship in the Football Championship Subdivision.
Senate and House Democrats attacked the Republican-led National Labor Relations Board at a Congressional hearing on Thursday, saying its recent decisions had favored employers over workers.

LAS VEGAS (AP) — An 18-year-old man was arrested Wednesday night in connection with a shooting at a school bus stop that wounded six people on Tuesday, the police said. The authorities continued searching Thursday for a second gunman.

The outlook for New York City’s 2009 elections shifted on Thursday when Adolfo Carrión Jr., the Bronx borough president, announced that he would not run for mayor — as he had long planned — but for comptroller instead.

Because of a transcription error, a brief art review in Weekend on May 8, 1987, about an exhibition of paintings by Charles G. Shaw at the Richard York Gallery on East 65th Street, misstated the location of a small painting from 1942, whose date did not fit with those of the other paintings, which were made in the 1930s. It was displayed in the vitrine near the receptionist's desk, not the latrine. (The reviewer called the error to editors' attention this week while doing research.)

GRINSTEIN--Alexander. The Board of Directors of Sigmund Freud Archives deeply mourns the death of our illustrious past President, Alexander Grinstein, M.D., at the age of 89. Dr. Grinstein was also past President of the Michigan Psychoanalytic Institute and Clinical Professor of Psychiatry at Wayne State University Medical School. Rendering distinguished service to our entire field, he was an eminent scholar, clinician, teacher and author of many notable books. Dr. Grinstein is survived by his wife Adele, sons David and Richard, his sister Louise Richman and six grandchildren. Harold P. Blum, M.D., Executive Director Eugene Halpert, M.D., President

'PETER AND THE WOLF' Lots of holiday shows rope in their victims with false promises of ''fun for all ages.'' But it's hard to see how a theatrical event that includes miniature paper sculptures of animals, George Manahan conducting the Juilliard Ensemble and (this is important) Isaac Mizrahi could fail to delight anybody. Mr. Mizrahi, the wickedly charismatic fashion designer, will be narrating ''Peter and the Wolf'' as part of the Works and Process series at the Guggenheim Museum, and will be topping off his outsize personality with a wolf's hat designed by Kelly Christy. The Prokofiev classic is only a half-hour long, and people are encouraged afterward to wander around the Peter B. Lewis Theater, which will be filled with an installation (above, a detail) by the young Brooklyn artist Andrew Scott Ross. The consulting producer, Charles Fabius, hopes to start a ''Peter and the Wolf'' holiday tradition, with a different artist each year; he mentioned Jeff Koons as having an interest in a future project.
WADE GUYTON Friedrich Petzel Gallery

Liza Minnellicollapsed while walking offstage after finishing a song on Wednesday in Goteborg, Sweden, and was flown to the United States on Thursday for medical treatment, The Associated Press reported. ''As she walked down the steps, she passed out,'' said Zlatko Nedanovski, a spokesman for the concert organizers. ''She was taken immediately to her hotel, where a doctor was waiting.'' Liz Rosenberg, the spokeswoman for her, said Ms. Minnelli, 61, ''had complained of dizziness'' before performing with several Swedish entertainers in ''A Classic Christmas Night,'' the fourth and last show in a four-concert series in Sweden, ''and became very ill after the show began.''

CHILDREN'S READING SERIES While Charlotte Jones Voiklis and Léna Roy were growing up, they were sometimes allowed into what their grandmother called the Ivory Tower, her work room in her Connecticut house. To keep the girls quiet, she would have them read the projects she was drafting. Though such a strategy would rarely succeed in the average home office, this grandmother was no ordinary professional: She was Madeleine L'Engle. On Saturday Ms. Voiklis, 38, and Ms. Roy, 39, will allow another generation a glimpse into their grandmother's creative life when they present ''A Wrinkle in Time at 45,'' the first event in the new Children's Reading Series at the 92nd Street Y. The Newbery Medal-winning ''Wrinkle in Time'' spins a complex tale of three children on an interplanetary quest that pits them against an all-controlling evil. Ms. Voiklis said she and her sister would probably read much of the novel's climax.

Yet another brand-name architect has been added to the roster of designers who will be contributing to a cultural complex in Abu Dhabi. The British architect Norman Foster has been selected to build the Sheikh Zayed National Museum on Saadiyat Island, which lies just offshore from Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates. Mr. Foster was chosen from four finalists after a seven-month competition; the others were Snohetta, Shingeru Ban and Moriyama & Teshima. The museum will be part of the cultural district, which is to include the Guggenheim Abu Dhabi, designed by Frank Gehry, and the Louvre Abu Dhabi, designed by Jean Nouvel. The institution is named after Sheikh Zayed Bin Sultan Al Nahyan, the founder and longtime ruler of the United Arab Emirates, who died in 2004. Its galleries are to include exhibitions on ''The Transformation of the Emirates,'' the environment and the area's heritage. Mr. Foster, winner of the Pritzker Prize, recently completed a courtyard atrium at the Smithsonian Institution's American Art Museum and National Portrait Gallery in Washington and the Hearst Tower in New York City.

The exclusion of Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio and Mike Gravel from the Democratic debate on Thursday stung those candidates and their supporters. But what made the situation puzzling was the presence on Wednesday at the Republican's version of The Des Moines Register debate of Alan Keyes, who had until then been nearly invisible in this campaign. But Mr. Keyes met The Register's full criteria for participation. He filed as a presidential candidate with the Federal Election Commission, and he received 2 percent in The Register's poll in October. Participants needed to show at least 1 percent.

Damien Hirst has donated to the Tate museum in London four of his works, including a bisected cow and calf in formaldehyde and a canvas of dead flies, Bloomberg News reported. As prices for contemporary art have soared over the last decade, museums have been struggling to buy works by leading figures including Mr. Hirst, who, at 42, is Britain's wealthiest artist, with assets, including art, estimated at $265 million by The Sunday Times of London. The Tate said his donation was the first part of a ''major gift of works.'' The donations include a 2007 exhibition copy of ''Mother and Child Divided,'' comprising the cow and calf; the 2002 fly painting ''Who Is Afraid of the Dark?,'' ''The Acquired Inability to Escape'' (1991), a large vitrine with cigarette stubs and ''Life Without You'' (1991), a seashell arrangement on a desk. ''It means a lot to me to have works in the Tate,'' Mr. Hirst said in a statement. ''I've been in negotiations with the Tate for a few years to make sure they get the right pieces to represent me properly.''

Six major European ice hockey nations decided to renegotiate the current agreement regulating player transfers to the N.H.L. from Europe. At a meeting in Zurich, the Czech Republic, Finland, Germany, Slovakia, Sweden and Switzerland decided to exercise their right to revisit the deal between the International Ice Hockey Federation member associations, their leagues and the N.H.L. The federation said the move was mutual because the N.H.L. decided Dec. 11 to exercise the same right.European members are concerned that North American teams are hurting the quality of their domestic leagues by luring away too many undeveloped players. Of the 59 European players who signed N.H.L. deals before this season, 6 were good enough to play in the N.H.L., seven returned to European clubs, and 46 were assigned to minor leagues in North America.

Madonna is headed for the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. She will join John Mellencamp, the Ventures, Leonard Cohen and the Dave Clark Five in the class selected by a panel of 600 industry figures; the performers will be inducted in ceremonies on March 10 in New York, The Associated Press reported. To be eligible for a place in the hall, in Cleveland, an artist must have issued a single or album at least 25 years before induction. Madonna Louise Ciccone, who signed with Sire Records in 1982, became one of MTV's first stars with ''Like a Virgin'' in 1984.

A South African magistrate postponed the case against the former dormitory matron accused of abusing students at Oprah Winfrey's Leadership Academy for Girls, Reuters reported. The magistrate, Arend van Wielligh, rescheduled the case for Jan. 16 to give the defendant, Virginia Mokgobo, 27, time to consult with her lawyer. She is accused of indecent assault, common assault, soliciting a minor to perform indecent acts and verbal abuse. A trial date is to be set at the next hearing.

INGRID MICHAELSON A year ago Ingrid Michaelson was an aspiring singer-songwriter on Staten Island with a MySpace page and a dream. And along with her soulful, idiosyncratic music, that's all she needed. After being discovered online by a music licensing company, four of her songs were included on ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy,'' and an Old Navy commercial showcased her song ''The Way I Am'' (a k a the Sweater Song), which combines whimsical lyrics, '60s girl-group harmonies and a lilting Caribbean beat. ''You hear it once and you instantly connect,'' Rick Krim, the executive vice president for music and talent at VH1, said of ''The Way I Am.'' Currently Ms. Michaelson, above, is featured on that channel's new-artist program, ''You Oughta Know,'' which has also spotlighted Amy Winehouse, Feist and James Blunt. It's the first time VH1 has played an unsigned artist. Mr. Krim said he and his colleagues were making an exception because of their passion for Ms. Michaelson's music. ''People are playing it on the radio because they love it,'' he said. ''The way it used to be in the old days.''

SIGNS OF A REBOUND Government reports showed surprising resilience in the economy. Retail sales rose 1.2 percent in November; wholesale prices surged, indicating strong demand; and unemployment claims fell by 7,000. A BAILOUT BY CITIGROUP Citigroup moved to rescue seven affiliated investment funds that have been upended by the running crisis in housing-related debt. Citigroup is likely to shift billions of dollars' worth of securities from the troubled structured investment vehicles onto its own balance sheet early next year. [C1.]

PICK UP PERFORMANCE COMPANY David Gordon's latest dance-theater feat, ''Uncivil Wars: Collaborating With Brecht & Eisler,'' is a dizzying experience, immediately plunging viewers into a thicket of overlapping references, realities and characters (not to mention artistic forms). A typically agile, bare-bones Gordon set of folding chairs, ladders and scaffolding swirls around the action, manipulated by members of his Pick Up Performance Company, above, even as they deliver their lines. The original play is ''The Roundheads and the Pointheads'' (translated by Michael Feingold, with music by Hanns Eisler), but, as is his wont, Mr. Gordon has edited and played with Brecht's script a good deal. The resulting creation is deliciously heady. Part rumination on artistic ownership, part elaboration of his continuing critique of current American politics, part something else entirely, ''Uncivil Wars'' functions via Mr. Gordon's singular physical and linguistic logic. The delicate rhymes and cadences embedded in the songs and dialogue carry you along, as does the ceaseless but never busy movement of set and cast.

HOLIDAY FESTIVITIES Ah, the holidays: the perfect time to relax with friends and family and watch nearly naked dancers twirl their pasties, hear a lipsticked man with the voice of a teenage girl croon about death, and wear your favorite cowboy hat. Well, why not? As an antidote to the saccharine tang of the season, a slew of bitter (and bitterly funny) original holiday shows are filling clubs and theaters. This weekend the drag king comedian Murray Hill -- the self-proclaimed ''hardest-working middle-aged man in show biz'' -- brings ''A Murray Little Christmas,'' his annual spectacle of burlesque, cabaret, off-color humor and too-tight clothing, to the Zipper Theater. At St. Ann's Warehouse in Brooklyn, the Tiger Lillies, an accordion, stand-up bass/ musical saw and drum trio, present ''Suicide for Christmas.'' Led by Martyn Jacques, a self-trained opera singer with a castrato-type voice, this London group performed ''Shockheaded Peter,'' a sort of demented children's play, here to rave reviews over the last several years; the new show brings its Gypsy-punk-Weimar style to an adult audience.

'REVOLUTION' Not long ago hardly any galleries in Chelsea were showing Asian contemporary art. Now there are dozens, including those specializing in Asian artists. Chinese art dominates, partly because the current market is boiling and partly because, simply, some of the best art being made today is from China. For evidence you might visit ChinaSquare, a new gallery dedicated to Chinese art and located high in the Chelsea Arts Tower. Inside the gallery is a spirited group show put together by Fang Lei and Jonathan Goodman, featuring the work of a dozen contemporary Chinese artists, among them emerging talents like Cao Xiaodong, Shen Jingdong and Jing Kewen, as well as the veterans Zhang Hongtu and Li Luming. ''Revolution'' is the overarching theme, with the central idea being to spotlight the influence of propaganda imagery from the Cultural Revolution (about 1966-76) in the work of contemporary artists. It's imagery that was made to serve political ends and promote revolutionary spirit among the Chinese people.

A single volume of five fairy tales by J. K. Rowling, handwritten on translucent vellum and illustrated by her, sold for $3.97 million at auction at Sotheby's in London, Agence France-Presse reported. The book, ''The Tales of Beedle the Bard,'' above, bound in leather and covered with silver and jewels, sold for about 40 times its pre-sale estimate. ''The price achieved today stands as the highest price ever achieved at auction for a modern literary manuscript, an auction record for a work by J. K. Rowling and an auction record for a children's book,'' a Sotheby's spokeswoman said in a statement. The winning bidder was the fine-art dealer Hazlitt, Good & Fox of London. Only seven copies of the book were produced; the author gave six to people associated with her Harry Potter tales. Proceeds from the sale will go to Children's Voice, a charity Ms. Rowling helped found, to help children in Europe.

A painting by Winston Churchill inherited by Margaret Truman Daniel, the daughter of President Harry S. Truman, sold for $955,459 at Sotheby's in London, Bloomberg News reported. KRONISH--Herbert. Cooley Godward Kronish LLP, successor to Kronish Lieb Weiner & Hellman LLP, mourns the passing of Herb Kronish, founding partner of KLWH. Forty-nine years ago, Herb and Dick Lieb decided to practice law together, and, as they say, the rest is history. He was the soul of the law firm: a valued counselor, conciliator, builder and leader, a source of unflagging energy, and a devoted and loyal friend. Above all, he was a humanitarian who made a difference in countless organizations, particularly among Jewish charities here, in the former Soviet Union and in Israel. We extend our deep sympathy to his children Susan and David and to his brother Paul, to their spouses and to the entire family. We will miss his warm smile and big heart forever. May his memory be for a blessing. KRONISH--Herbert. The Directors and staff of Bryant Park Management Corporation mourn the passing of Herbert Kronish, a longtime member of our Board. For the fourth time in two weeks, John Edwards held a town-hall-style event in Iowa on Thursday night, this time addressing a hall of waiting supporters in Indianola. But just beforehand, he slipped into a side room, away from reporters, for a closed-door meeting with another group he wants to court: the undecided. For months heading toward the Democratic caucuses on Jan. 3, Mr. Edwards has been spending some quality time with groups of 20 to 30 people, all handpicked by his Iowa campaign, who have identified themselves as undecided voters. The voters have said they have questions for Mr. Edwards, and he spends about a half-hour answering them, in an informal setting.

A picture caption on Dec. 5 with the ''What's on Tonight'' television highlights misstated the given name of the actress shown with Henry Fonda in a scene from ''The Ox-Bow Incident,'' one of the films shown by Turner Classic Movies that night as part of a tribute to the director William Wellman. She was Mary Beth Hughes, not May.

GRAUER--Michael Trichter, M.D., 40, of Phoenix, AZ, formerly of Syosset, NY, died December 10, 2007. Adored husband of Tara, beloved father of Mason, Riley and Presley. Greatly loved and loving son of Seymour and Theodora Grauer, brother to Edward (Karine) Grauer and Robert (Arinne) Grauer. Uncle to Julian Grauer, Ray Grauer, Ben Bottiglieri and Aaron Bottiglieri. Dear sonin-law to Richard and Sharon Brodkin. Brother-in-law to Erika (Richard) Bottiglieri and Michael Brodkin. Michael was a graduate of Union College and The Sackler School of Medicine. As much as he loved all of us, we love him even more. Michael will be greatly missed, but our memories of his sense of humor and huge heart will stay with us forever.

SIDEL--Nancy Jarmon, born December 6, 1939 in New York City. Survived by her loving sons John and Henry, their wives Eva-Lotta Hedman and Beth Levison, and her adoring grandchildren, Matilda, Ben and Gabe. Also survived by her dear companion of many years Patrick McCormick. She amazed her family, friends and doctors with her resilience, optimism and determination in the face of cancer. Ultimately she passed in peace. Her professional life included teaching English literature at the Lycee Francais, heading up the Bank of New York's new business for private banking and serving as Director of Development at the Hudson River Museum. She was passionate about reading, classical music, travel, swimming, walking, her family and her bridge game. Even throughout her illness she played consistently and became a Lifetime Silver Grandmaster. Her energy and spark will be missed forever. Memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell at 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., 3:30pm on Sunday, December 16th. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in memory of Nancy J. Sidel to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center at P.O. Box 27106, NY, NY 10087-7106 or the New York Society Library at 53 East 79th St., NY, NY 10021
STEINBERG--Richard. 12/14/18-1/22/01. Today we should have started planning next year's bash. How I wish we could. Miss you so much, Dad. Love, Vicki

This 2,427-square-foot ranch is on a wooded double lot and has views of the University Tower and the lights of downtown Austin. The house has an ''in-law layout,'' with a master bedroom and two other bedrooms at one end of the house and another bedroom and bathroom at the opposite end. There are three bathrooms and a spacious living and dining area that leads to a large deck. Agent: Roya Johnson, Keller Williams Realty, (512) 472-1000; www.royanet.com

LANE--Erna (nee Apisdorf), age 91, passed away on December 10, in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Preceded in death last year by her husband of 63 years, Sidney Lane. Loving mother of Jeff (Trish) Lane and grandmother of Jonathan Lane. Sister of Rena Berger of Israel. Further survived by other relatives and friends. Erna was born in Vienna, Austria, and was eternally grateful to the late Harold Apisdorf for helping her come to the United States in 1940. She lived in New York City until she moved to Milwaukee in 2004. A disciplined, caring and strong woman who volunteered for many organizations in her younger years, she truly enjoyed what life had to offer. She will be deeply missed. Burial in Milwaukee on December 14.

When Iowans caucus on Jan. 3, the state's college students will be spread far and wide on winter break. But some colleges are trying to make it easy for their students to give up home cooking for a few days and head back to campus early to help nominate the next president. For instance, Grinnell College's chapter of the College and Young Democrats of Iowa is organizing car pools for out-of-state students who want to caucus, said the group's president, Alec Schierenbeck.

Brian Mulroney, the former prime minister, acknowledged to a parliamentary committee that he had accepted large cash payments from a German-Canadian arms dealer and lobbyist beginning shortly after he left office in 1993. Mr. Mulroney said that his action showed ''an error in judgment'' but he strenuously denied that it was illegal. He was summoned to explain what he had done in exchange for the money, which was turned over to him in $1,000 bills in hotel rooms, by the arms dealer and lobbyist, Karlheinz Schreiber. Mr. Schreiber said Mr. Mulroney was supposed to help him lobby for Thyssen, the German company now called ThyssenKrupp, which hoped to make a deal with the government to build a factory in Canada for light-armored vehicles. Mr. Mulroney said he promoted the vehicles at meetings with officials and politicians in other countries, but never in Canada.

This 1,279-square-foot house, built in 1955, has a large backyard and is on a cul-de- sac close to a protected estuary with hiking trails. It has two bathrooms, new double-pane windows and an attached two-car garage. San Rafael is in Marin County halfway between San Francisco and California's wine country.
