The Exelon Corporation said it would replace the Wackenhut Corporation with an in-house security force at its 10 nuclear power plants after the discovery about two months ago that guards at a Pennsylvania plant were sleeping on the job. Exelon, based in Chicago, said it was acting even though a review of security at its other plants found “no significant deficiencies.” The change is to be made by July. Exelon has 17 reactors at 10 plants, including in Illinois, Pennsylvania and New Jersey. Officials at Wackenhut have characterized the apparent lapses as “an anomaly.”.

A man accused of being the Phoenix Baseline Killer was sentenced to 438 years in prison for the sexual assaults of two sisters. The man, Mark Goudeau, 43, a former construction worker, still faces trial in the killings of eight women and a man in 2005 and 2006. He has pleaded not guilty. Mr. Goudeau was convicted in September on charges of raping one woman and sexually attacking another as they walked home from a park. During the two-month trial, both sisters identified Mr. Goudeau as their attacker, and DNA evidence also linked him to the rape.

Three bodies were found in a sport utility vehicle in Phoenix, and the police are investigating the case as homicide. An officer who thought the Ford Explorer looked suspicious found the bodies in the back of the vehicle, which had been parked in front of an apartment complex, Sgt. Andy Hill said.

A Republican environmental advocate who arranged the lobbyist Jack Abramoff’s entree to the Interior Department was sentenced to two months in a halfway house and four years of probation. The activist, Italia Federici, who pleaded guilty in June to tax evasion and obstructing a Senate investigation, was spared prison only because she has become a key witness in the Justice Department’s continuing corruption investigation. Ms. Federici has admitted acting as a link between Mr. Abramoff and J. Steven Griles, the former deputy Interior Department secretary who for five years was her boyfriend. Mr. Griles provided Mr. Abramoff with advice and internal information, sometimes directly and sometimes through Ms. Federici.

Two men accused of plotting in prison to attack military sites, synagogues and other targets pleaded guilty to conspiring to wage war against the United States. The men, Kevin James, 31, and Levar H. Washington, 28, pleaded guilty to seditious conspiracy charges. Mr. Washington also pleaded guilty to using a firearm to further that conspiracy. The authorities say Mr. James, Mr. Washington and two others were part of a California prison gang cell of radical Muslims. The police said they uncovered the plot in July 2005 while investigating gas station robberies that they say were committed to finance the attacks.

Paul Pierce scored a season-high 32 points and Kevin Garnett had an easy 15 with 7 rebounds Friday night as the Boston Celtics overcame Ray Allen’s absence to beat the visiting Milwaukee Bucks, 104-82. They matched a franchise record with a 12-0 start at home.
Eddy Curry was not benched in his hometown Friday night and thus avoided one major indignity. But he appears to have lost some of his coach’s faith, which may be a greater long-term concern.

The Weekend Explorer column on Friday, about the Upper East Side, referred imprecisely to the architectural style of the mansion Andrew Carnegie built at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 91st Street and of the town house Woody Allen bought on East 70th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues. They were built after the death of the last King George of Britain in 1830, and thus are Georgian style, not Georgian. The column also misstated the year Carnegie moved into the mansion. It was 1902, not 1901.

An article on Wednesday about the abuse of women in Brazil’s prison system described incorrectly the origin of a study about the subject. It was a report to the Organization of American States by a group of private organizations in São Paulo that formed the Study and Working Group on Women in Prison that led to increasing public and government attention to the problem. It was not a study commissioned by the government.

A Spare Times listing in Weekend on Friday about events at the 92nd Street Y misstated the date for a dance party with instruction. It is tonight; it was not Friday night.

A subheading in the NYC column on Friday, about the absence of urban and suburban issues as a topic in the Democratic and Republican presidential debates, referred incorrectly to the type of community that is home to more than 80 percent of the nation’s population. That proportion lives in metropolitan areas, which include cities and suburbs; the 80 percent figure does not represent urban dwellers only. (About 50 percent of the population is in the suburbs and 30 percent in cities.).

A picture caption with the continuation of a front-page article on Thursday about a collective malaise in Italy misspelled the name of the city where Beppe Grillo, a performer who has given voice to the country’s mood, was shown preparing for a performance. It is Novara, not Novarra.
An article in Business Day on Friday about billionaires who push for social change in poorer countries misspelled the surname of one such entrepreneur. He is Warren E. Buffett, not Buffet.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a hearing on a claim by death row inmates in Connecticut that the state’s death penalty discriminates against minorities misstated the timing of the last execution in the state. Michael Ross, a serial killer, was executed by lethal injection in May 2005; it has not in fact been “decades” since the state executed anyone.

An article on Thursday about a visit to Bethlehem by Tony Blair, the former prime minister of Britain and now an international envoy for Palestinian development, described incompletely Israel’s policy about the presence of its citizens in the West Bank. While Israeli citizens cannot freely visit Palestinian towns there, tens of thousands of Israelis do live in settlements in the territory.

A picture caption on Thursday with an obituary of the musician Ike Turner, using information provided by Getty Images, misstated the date of the photograph of Ike and Tina Turner. While Getty says it does not know the precise date of the picture, it says that it is from 1970 or later, not “around 1960” and thus not from the early days of the Ike and Tina Turner Revue.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about plans by the Securities and Exchange Commission to delay requiring small companies to adhere to some auditing requirements under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act left the incorrect impression that the S.E.C. chairman, Christopher Cox, was leaving the door open for an indefinite stay of the requirements. As the article noted, testimony prepared for Mr. Cox to deliver to a Congressional panel did not explicitly say that he wanted the commission to require small companies to obey the law after the delay. His testimony, however, did include a reference to a time “when, eventually, smaller public companies do come into full compliance” with the law.

A private van that the police said was illegally carrying a group of children to school collided with a city bus in Queens, critically injuring a 9-year-old girl and sending six other children to hospitals.

A Marine reservist, Lance Cpl. Delano Holmes, 22, of Indianapolis, was sentenced to a bad-conduct discharge and reduced in rank to private, a day after being convicted at Camp Pendleton, Calif., of negligent homicide in the 2006 stabbing death of an Iraqi soldier he stood watch with at a guard post in Falluja. He has served 10 months in a military prison and will not spend any more time in custody. The lance corporal’s lawyer has said that the killing was in self-defense. Prosecutors contended that he killed the Iraqi and then set up the scene to support his story. He was also found guilty of making a false official statement.

A group calling itself the Nationalist Revolutionary Army Faction says it has blown up at least seven speed cameras on French roads and has demanded money from the government to stop, the police said. The radio station RTL said the group had asked for a significant sum, along with tax cuts and “less repression.”.

The United Nations confirmed that 17 of its staff members died in the bombing of two of its buildings in Algiers on Tuesday, which the government said killed 37 people. Marie Okabe, a spokeswoman for Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, said the earlier toll of 11 dead had risen after more bodies were dug out from the rubble. The United Nations said that all but three of the dead — a Dane, a Filipino and a Senegalese — were thought to be Algerians.

An autopsy found a large quantity of cyanide in the blood of Héctor Febres, a former coast guard officer and the only suspected torturer at the notorious Navy Mechanics School in Buenos Aires during the 1976-83 military dictatorship whose case has made it to trial. He was found dead in his cell before breakfast on Monday, four days before an expected verdict and a possible sentence of life in prison. An investigation is under way, and the police have detained his wife and two grown children, who reportedly dined with him the night before his body was found.

Some 4,000 delegates of the African National Congress are descending on Polokwane in northern Limpopo Province for a five-day conference that starts Sunday, to decide whether President Thabo Mbeki will remain leader of the party of Nelson Mandela or whether the job should go to Jacob Zuma, the man he fired as deputy president. The conference is being described as the most significant political event in the country since the first democratic elections after the collapse of apartheid in 1994. Mr. Zuma looks set to win, which would virtually assure him of the country’s presidency in the 2009 election because of the party’s wide support. Mr. Mbeki is legally barred from seeking a third term as president, and losing the helm of the party could hurt his authority in his last two years as president.

Bosnia has deported the first of dozens of Muslim former fighters identified as threats to security after investigations requested by the United States after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the newspaper Nezavisne Novine reported. Atau Mimun was deported to Algeria, where he was born. He was among hundreds of foreign volunteers who arrived in Bosnia during the 1992-95 war to fight alongside Muslims against Serbs and Croats, and who stayed on after marrying local women.

ROSE--Sonia, 86, of Brooklyn, passed away on December 12, following a brief illness. A women of strength, dignity and generosity. Remembered for her WWII service, her career in the NYC Board of Ed, her volunteerism at her Co-op union, and her effort in establishing a senior shuttle bus in the Brooklyn Heights area. Loving friend to many. Her first love was always her family, beloved sister, Elaine Buckwald, devoted aunt to Forrest, Claudia and Scott. She was a generous donor to many charities. The closest to her heart was HIP (Heightened Independence & Progress), where contributions may be made, 131 Main St., Hackensack, NJ 07601. Services on Sunday, December 16, 12:30pm at Shermans Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.

Fabio Capello was appointed coach of England's national team Friday by the Football Association. He replaces Steve McClaren, who was fired last month after England failed to qualify for the 2008 European Championships. Capello signed a four-and-a-half-year contract, through the 2012 European Championships, and will begin work Jan. 7, the association said. His first game will be the Feb. 6 exhibition against Switzerland at Wembley Stadium. His contract is estimated to be worth $12.2 million a year.

A subheading in the NYC column on Friday, about the absence of urban and suburban issues as a topic in the Democratic and Republican presidential debates, referred incorrectly to the type of community that is home to more than 80 percent of the nation's population. That proportion lives in metropolitan areas, which include cities and suburbs; the 80 percent figure does not represent urban dwellers only. (About 50 percent of the population is in the suburbs and 30 percent in cities.)

Bode Miller was back on the World Cup podium Friday for the first time since breaking from the United States Ski Team. He finished second in a super-G in Val Gardena, Italy, only two-hundredths of a second behind Didier Cuche of Switzerland.Miller left the United States team before this season to train and race on his own.Cuche finished in 1 minute 36.62 seconds. Benjamin Raich, who was seventh, leads the standings with 441 points.

Mike Huckabee's campaign was crippled for about 24 hours by an e-mail breakdown that began just after the Republican debate on Wednesday. Reporters, or anyone else for that matter, trying to contact the campaign about the debate -- or about Mr. Huckabee's apology to Mitt Romney for a remark about Mormonism -- got replies saying their messages had been delayed. The glitch was fixed Thursday night. The breakdown underscored just how far the campaign has to go to ramp up its infrastructure to match Mr. Huckabee's newfound stature. Mr. Huckabee's press secretary, Alice Stewart, said Friday that she was unsure what caused the problem. The campaign has had to upgrade its Web server multiple times over the last few months to accommodate a surge in traffic on its site.

The United States Anti-Doping Agency lost an arbitration case for the first time Friday, when a three-person arbitration panel ruled in favor of the sprinter LaTasha Jenkins, a 2001 world track medalist who had been sanctioned for using the steroid nandralone.Usada is now 36-1 since it started prosecuting athletes for doping violations seven years ago. The arbitration panel ruled that the results of Jenkins's drug test from a track meet last year in Belgium were compromised because the European labs testing her sample violated international standards requiring that the tests be run by two different technicians.

KOHNSTAMM--Lee W. The Virginia Dare Extract Company, Brooklyn, deeply mourns the loss of our Vice President International. Lee was responsible for the company's international business and was a highly respected and a well known person in the American beverage industry. He was involved in many trade associations and was instrumental in the activities of the Society of Soft Drink Technologists, the New England Bottlers Association, and the I.B.D.E.A. He authored the Beverage Industry Annual Manual. He was born April 3rd, 1936 and graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. Lee was always willing to share his knowledge, and was a friend to all. He will be sadly missed.

Elizabeth Edwards is back on the campaign trail after nearly a month's absence -- getting ready for the holidays, she said -- but she has wasted no time making her presence known. Since arriving in Iowa on Thursday, Mrs. Edwards has conducted television interviews, talked to voters, posed for pictures after taking her children, Jack, 7, and Emma Claire, 9, sledding -- and, in her usual no-nonsense fashion, frequently interrupted her husband, John Edwards, while he was on stage. On Friday, after going shopping and skipping most of Mr. Edwards's town-hall-style forum in Manchester, Iowa, she slipped into the steakhouse where he was speaking and stood in the back of the room.

Scottie Reynolds scored 17 of his 21 points in the second half Friday night for 23rd-ranked Villanova, which pulled away for a 103-75 victory over visiting Hartford.The Wildcats (8-1) scored more than 100 points in consecutive games for only the second time in team history. They scored at least 100 in three straight games in the 1969-70 season.Joe Zeglinski led Hartford (5-7) with 20 points, and Warren McLendon added 19. Villanova led, 66-63, midway through the second half when Corey Fisher started a 14-1 run with a 3-pointer. He hit four 3-pointers and scored 18 points.

STRIKE ENDS IN RUSSIA The Ford Motor Company and a union representing part of its Russian employees agreed to end a strike that was corroding Ford's profit in one of Europe's hottest markets. Already, two-thirds of Ford's assembly line employees at a plant in Vsevolozhsk, outside St. Petersburg, had broken ranks with the union and returned to work since the strike began Nov. 22. On Friday, the remaining union employees also agreed to return beginning with the late shift on Sunday, though negotiations on salaries and benefits in the 2008 contract continue, according to a statement from Ford. Russia, awash in oil money, is projected to surpass Germany as the largest car market in Europe by the end of the decade. ANDREW E. KRAMER A SALE FOR BOEING The Boeing Company said AWAS, an airplane leasing company in Ireland, has ordered 31 of its single-aisle 737-800 jets. While specific deal terms were not disclosed, Boeing said the order was worth $2.3 billion at list prices, although airlines typically negotiate discounts. AWAS owns and manages 315 airplanes. (AP)

But more than anything else, I have learned to never, ever underestimate how much people simply hate to fly.

I spent the month of November in New York, and for part of that time I hung out at the Museum of Television and Radio (now the Paley Center for Media), doing research for a book I'm writing on the '60s TV show "The Fugitive." When I wasn't reading reviews and cover stories in old issues of TV guide, I was going to galleries, listening to concerts and seeking out movies that would probably not make it up to Delaware County. The movie I found was "Starting Out in the Evening," described in the reviews as a "small film," which means not only that there are no special effects, but that almost nothing happens (a point of criticism on the part of some reviewers).

Penn State played near-perfect volleyball in its N.C.A.A. run, winning its second national title while dropping only two games in six tournament matches. The scrappy Nittany Lions even found a way to stun top-seeded Stanford Saturday night in Sacramento, getting 26 kills from Megan Hodge and 19 from Nicole Fawcett against the same university they beat for their first title in 1999.Fawcett served on match point and Penn State capped its 26th straight victory on another powerful kill by Hodge, the tournament’s most valuable player, winning by 30-25, 30-26, 23-30, 19-30, 15-8 exactly three months to the day after losing a five-game thriller to the Cardinal — the last defeat for the Nittany Lions.

Division III championship game.Beaver, the Gagliardi Trophy winner as the best player in Division III, overcame a costly fumble, leading the Warhawks to a 31-21 victory Saturday in the Amos Alonzo Stagg Bowl in Salem, Va.The Warhawks won their first national title after losing, 35-28, to Mount Union in the 2005 championship game.Wisconsin-Whitewater (14-1) ended Mount Union’s 37-game winning streak and deprived the Purple Raiders (14-1) of their 10th national title in the last 15 years.

Gabe Le ran for 116 yards and 2 touchdowns to help Carroll College of Montana beat the defending champion Sioux Falls, 17-9, in Savannah, Tenn., for Carroll’s fifth N.A.I.A. title in the last six years.

Joe Namath received his diploma from Alabama, where he won a national championship with the Crimson Tide in 1964. Namath, 64, completed a 30-hour program over the last five years to earn a Bachelor of Arts in interdisciplinary studies.

Nascar has approved Penske Racing’s request to transfer owner points to Sam Hornish Jr. from Kurt Busch, a move that locks Hornish, a three-time IndyCar Series champion, into the first five Nascar races of next season. Hornish, a former Indianapolis 500 winner, is leaving the IndyCar Series for Nascar next season.

Scratch Gary Pinkel’s name off other universities’ wish lists. Pinkel, the Missouri coach, has become a bit of a hot commodity in his seventh season, leading the Tigers to a No. 1 ranking before they lost to Oklahoma in the Big 12 championship game. But on Saturday, as the team returned to practice for the Cotton Bowl, Pinkel said he was staying put.“I’m going to stay at Missouri,” Pinkel said. “I’m very committed here. We’ve made a lot of gains this year, and I’m just going to try to keep working hard and keep building the program.”The 55-year-old Pinkel said he would like to end his career at Missouri.

Michael Terry scored a touchdown with 22 seconds left and Valdosta State beat Northwest Missouri State, 25-20, for the N.C.A.A. Division II championship in Florence, Ala. Terry’s 1-yard touchdown run capped an eight-play, 37-yard drive fueled by Willie Copeland’s four straight completions for 27 yards. Valdosta (13-1) overcame a 14-3 halftime deficit in dropping Northwest Missouri to 12-2.

Chanelle Price of Easton Area High School in Pennsylvania, the national indoor and outdoor 800 meter champion, posted a meet record of 2 minutes 47.85 seconds Saturday in winning the 1,000 meters at the Bishop Loughlin Games at the New Balance Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. Price, a senior who has committed to attending Tennessee next year, led from the start, running a blistering 62.9 seconds for the first 400 and a fast 2:12.1 at the 800 mark in erasing the meet record of 2:50.37.
Although football sits atop soccer in the pecking order at Ohio state, the soccer program just may beat the football team to a championship when the Buckeyes face Wake Forest on Sunday.
Fredrik Sjostrom scored twice and Martin Hanzal had a goal and three assists Saturday to lead the Phoenix Coyotes to a 4-1 victory over the Devils in Newark.
Meg Bulger scored 19 points and No. 13 West Virginia rolled to a 93-26 victory Saturday against Presbyterian, which is in its first year as a Division I program.
Charron Fisher had 30 points and 14 rebounds Saturday to help Niagara beat host St. John’s, 77-73, for the Purple Eagles’ first victory against the Red Storm since 1963.

Four of Bolivia’s wealthiest provinces celebrated efforts to seek greater autonomy from the central government on Saturday.

Oliver Wilson of England shot a five-under-par 67 and led by one stroke after three rounds of the South African Open. Wilson was at four-under 212 heading into the final round, with the halfway leader, James Kingston, in second place. Garth Mulroy was two shots back after a 64, the day’s best round. Greg Norman shot a 72 and was at 217. The defending champion, Ernie Els, was at 224.

West Virginia Coach Rich Rodriguez refused to discuss Michigan’s vacant coaching job at a news conference. Rodriguez said at the opening of a previously scheduled news conference on No. 11 West Virginia’s trip to the Fiesta Bowl that he would only talk about preparations to face No. 3 Oklahoma.Sporting News Radio reported Friday, citing unidentified sources, that Rodriguez and his agent were in Toledo, Ohio, meeting with Michigan Athletic Director Bill Martin and the university president, Mary Sue Coleman.

Iben Tinning of Denmark shot a five-under-par 67 to take a one-shot lead after three rounds of the Dubai Ladies Masters, the season-ending tournament on the Ladies European Tour. She was at nine-under 207 entering Sunday’s final round, with Annika Sorenstam, Laura Davies and Veronica Zorzi at 208.

To the Editor:.
There is a substantial risk of a recession in 2008. Whether that occurs will depend on a variety of forces, including monetary policy and a possible fiscal stimulus.
The current recession is all about the coming capitulation of the American consumer — whose spending now accounts for a record 72 percent of G.D.P.
As to the factual question of whether we are in a recession given the data in hand, the unambiguous answer is no.
Whether economic growth is turning negative, pushing the economy into a recession that would hurt tens of millions, remains unclear.
The economists and politicians ask, “What happened to America’s dynamic economy?” The answer: It’s wrapped in coils of debt.

To the Editor: Regarding “36 Hours: Oaxaca” (Nov. 25): Beth Greenfield writes, “Although it’s known as a hotbed for social justice rallies (including a large-scale teachers’ strike in 2006), the city’s infectious zeal goes far beyond the political.” This characterization underrepresents the political reality of Oaxaca, and tourists should know this when they decide to travel.

To the Editor: Thank you for “Class Conflict” (Nov. 25) on the woes of travelers in economy class. We don’t expect elaborate meals or lay-down seats, and I don’t think most expect gracious service. But travelers do have a right to expect attentive treatment, space that permits medically sound space and movement, adequate and clean bathrooms and like “amenities.” Many wags have noted that the absence of food service represents an improvement, so that’s not the issue.

YAGLOM--Akiva, a world renowned physicist, mathematician, bibliophile and former Soviet political dissident passed away on December 13, 2007 in Boston, Massachusetts at the age of 86. He is mourned by his wife June, his daughters Julia and Masha, his sons-in-law Michael and Gideon, his grandchildren Naomi, Levy Natan, Shimon Ezra and Batya Bracha, his nephews Menahem and Michael and many disciples, friends and fellow scientists all over the world.

PAYSON--Benjamin A., M.D., decorated for heroism at Omaha Beach, Normandy, France, on D-Day, Dr. Benjamin A. Payson died on December 15th, 2007 in Boca Raton, FL. His professional career as attending surgeon at Beth Israel Medical Center and Beekman Downtown Hospital in New York City spanned over 40 years. He touched the lives of thousands of patients, doctors and nurses who remember Ben as a compassionate healer, gifted teacher and kind human being. Ben lived every day to its fullest. His passions were his family, his professional life, classical music and golf. He will be forever in the hearts and memories of his loving family: his wife Anita, his late wife Selma, his children Renee Panoff, Arthur Payson and Paula PaysonWolosky, his daughter-in-law Janice, his son-in-law Mark, his late son-in-law Gary, and grandchildren: Jesse, Max, Spencer, Sophie, Samuel and Ross. Services Monday, December 17th, at Frank E. Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue, please call for time, 212-288-3500. Interment will be at Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.
Theater Jesse Green

HOROWITZ--Kayla. The Board of Directors, volunteers, consumers and families of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City send our heartfelt condolences to the family of Kayla Horowitz, a longtime volunteer and past president of Tova League. Begun in Brooklyn before UCP/NYC was founded in 1946, Tova's hundreds of members early on chose to focus their fund raising exclusively on UCP and Tova members were to come from all five boroughs of New York City, Long Island, New Jersey and Florida. Kayla was always ready to volunteer and to recruit others with a cheery ''come and do it with me.'' We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire family, but especially to her husband Herbert and daughters Janet and Reeves. Jerome Belson, President Edward R. Matthews, Executive Director Ronald J. H. KOCZY--Rosemarie Inge 68, of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, internationally renowned artist, succumbed on December 12, 2007 to inflammatory breast cancer. Born March 5, 1939 in Reckling-hausen, Germany to Jewish parents, she was deported in 1942 and survived two concentration camps. In 1959 she left Germany for Geneva to study art at the Ecole des Arts Decoratifs. Graduating with distinction in 1965, she soon gained recognition throughout Europe as a tapestry maker. A chance encounter with Peggy Guggenheim in Venice in 1973 led to an abiding friendship (and the commissioning of a tapestry) and contact with then Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum director Thomas Messer. By the mid-1970's the unexpressed trauma of her early years forced a change of direction in her work toward an open acknowledgment of the Holocaust. By the time Koczy accepted a fellowship to the MacDowell Colony in 1980 at Messer's invitation, she had already begun to create the signature pen and ink drawings memorializing the victims of the Shoah reverenced today throughout the world. In addition to hundreds of paintings, wood sculptures and other works, they alone numbered over 12,000 at the time of her death. Of them she wrote: ''The drawings I make every day are titled 'I Weave You A Shroud.' They are burials to those I saw die in camps.'' Esteemed in both mainstream and outsider art worlds but in the moral dimension apart from both, Koczy's work renowned in the Guggenheim, the Collection de l'Art Brut in Lausanne and Jerusalem's Yad Vashem, to give partial sense of its reach. Rosemarie Koczy's first marriage (which brought her Swiss citizenship) ended in divorce. She wed composer Louis Pelosi in 1984 and became an American citizen in 1989. She is survived by her husband, a sister Gisela and a half-brother Walter, both of Germany. She was interred at Bethel Cemetery, Croton on December 14. Her gravestone will read: ''I weave you a shroud...of love.''

SIMKIN--Edward R., 96, of Lenox, MA and Nyack, NY died peacefully December 10th, 2007. Loving and devoted husband of 67 years to Selma Simkin, father of Mark, Linda and Diana Simkin, father-in-law to David Kritchman, grandfather to Ian Salsberg. A dear friend to many. He graduated from Brooklyn College in 1936, then founded Simkin's in Haverstraw in 1944 selling toys and music. He then pursued a career in finance, becoming Vice President at the Dreskin, Advest, and Gruntal companies. He worked as a financial advisor well into his 90s. In ''retirement'', he was a enthusiastic follower of international emerging markets. His keen intelligence, lively sense of humor, love of music and generous heart enriched our lives. He will be deeply missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to charities that filled the world with music and grace.

Mike Huckabee walked into the lobby of the Des Moines Marriott at 5:30 a.m. on Dec. 3, deposited an armful of dirty laundry at the desk and checked to make sure he was being credited with Marriott Rewards points toward his next stay. Then, accompanied by his wife, Janet, his daughter, Sarah, and his press secretary, Alice Stewart -- who doubles as his Boston Marathon trainer -- he walked into the dark, freezing morning, climbed into a waiting S.U.V. and headed for Central College in Pella, Iowa. Huckabee, a former Arkansas governor, was in a buoyant mood on three hours of sleep. The night before, his commercial flight suffered a long Chicago holdover on the way from Boston, but he had reason to hope that his days at the mercy of the airlines might be numbered. A Des Moines Register opinion poll had just shown Huckabee passing Mitt Romney to take the lead in the run-up to the Jan. 3 caucus. His picture, he already knew, was on the front page of that morning's USA Today. Now he was headed to Central College, to appear, surrounded by enthusiastic students, on ''The Early Show'' on CBS. This kind of momentum, he hoped, would finally produce enough cash to allow him to charter his own plane. The governor was especially happy that morning about an impending endorsement he expected (and received the following day) from Tim LaHaye, the author of the apocalyptic ''Left Behind'' series of novels. ''Left Behind'' is wildly popular among evangelicals, who have bought more than 65 million copies, making LaHaye a very rich man and one of the few writers who is also a major philanthropist. Recently he donated a hockey rink to Jerry Falwell's Liberty University, although some members of the faculty there deride ''Left Behind'' as science fiction. Huckabee, an ordained Southern Baptist minister, has no such reservations. He considers the ''Left Behind'' books, in which the world comes to a violent end as Jesus triumphs over Satan, a ''compelling story written for nontheologians.''

GRUNBERG--Alex V., 69, died peacefully in his home in Riverdale on December 8, 2007. Beloved husband of Susan M. Fauls. Beloved son of the late Simon and Dana Grunberg. A brief film review in Weekend on Dec. 14 about ''The Singing Revolution,'' a documentary about Estonia's struggle to end Soviet occupation, misidentified the site of the Estonian song festival. It is in Tallinn, the capital not Tartu, where some festivals were held in the 19th century. The review also referred incorrectly to the songs performed at the festival that are shown in the film. They were written by composers; they are not folk songs.

KRAUT--Harry, 74, of Key West, Florida, formerly of New York City, died December 11, 2007. He was the longtime business manager and producer for Leonard Bernstein. He attended Brooklyn schools, earned degrees at Harvard College and Harvard Business School, and served in the U.S. Army. Following military service, he was Associate Director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and Administrator of the Tanglewood Music Center, and won two Primetime Emmy Awards for producing television shows of Bernstein concerts. Survivors include sister Margaret Thompson and husband Palmer; niece Maralee Striker and husband Francis; grand-niece and nephew Abigael and Thor Striker, and friends around the world. Contact 305-292-3341 RE plans to remember Harry. KRAUT--Harry. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague. We'll miss you dearly. Alexander , Jamie and Nina Bernstein The Leonard Bernstein Office

To the Editor: Re ''The Dollar Is Falling, and That's Good News'' (Economic View, Dec. 2):

THE NEWS Federal judges have broad discretion to set aside sentencing guidelines and impose sentences they think are reasonable in criminal cases, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday in deciding two cases involving drug convictions. BEHIND THE NEWS In each case, an appeals court overturned a sentence imposed by a trial judge that was lighter than called for by the federal guidelines, after prosecutors had complained. In one of the cases, the trial judge disagreed with guidelines that require much harsher sentences for crack-cocaine possession than for the possession of an equivalent amount of powdered cocaine.

MENIKOFF--Alan, 60, of Brooklyn, NY and Weston, CT died Monday December 10th, 2007 after a heroic battle with cancer. He is survived by his wife Carla Daichman, children Robin and Alexander, brother Peter, sister Jean. After many years devoted to mental health administration and psychiatric rehabilitation he turned his attention to his passion for photography. He never failed to see the good in people or help those in need. He continued his volunteer work and long associations with various organizations in Connecticut and New York. We will all miss his intellectual curiosity, quick wit, grace and compassion. He leaves a void in the hearts of all who had the privilege of knowing him. His family gives thanks for the honor of being part of his world. In recognition of his love of nature and concern for its future, contributions to The Natural Resources Defense Council may be made in his memory.
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

WANG--Kenneth, died peacefully in his home, in Cove Neck, on December 14th, surrounded by his family. He was born in China in 1914. He was the beloved husband of Mary, and cherished father of Anthony, Charles and Francis and their wives, Lulu, Nancy and Laura. He was much beloved by his seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He was also the much loved brother of Hsiang-Ming Hsia. He graduated from Soochow University School of Law in 1938. He practiced law in Shanghai until 1945 when he was recruited to be a judge of the Court of Appeals for Shanghai. In 1947 he was awarded a fellowship by Harvard University School of Law where he earned an LLM degree. He returned to China in 1948 to resume his law practice and to teach at Soochow University Law School. In 1949 he became President of Aurora College for Women. In 1952 Professor Wang and his family moved to the U.S. and he joined the faculty of St. John's University School of Law in New York City. He was invited to serve as Visiting Professor of Law at Michigan University Law School in 1963. In 1964 he was invited by President Lyndon B. Johnson to participate in the White House Conference on International Law and International Cooperation. In addition to his professorship at St. John's, he was also on the panel of Arbitrators of The American Arbitration Association. By the time he retired as Professor of Law at St. John's in 1984, he had taught and inspired generations of young lawyers and future leaders in business and government. After his retirement from St. John's, Professor Wang became the senior partner of Wang and Wang in Taipei, a law firm specializing in transnational law. St. John's honored him in 1984 with the President's Medal, in 1987 with an honorary Doctor of Laws degree, and in 1992 with the Medal of Honor. In 2003, Soochow University honored him with the naming of the Kenneth Wang School of Law. He will always be honored in the hearts of his family, friends and students. Services were private. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be sent to St. John's University School of Law, in support of the Kenneth Wang International Fellowship, at 8000 Utopia Parkway, Queens, NY 11439.

EXPLORING PESHNA CAVE AND THE FORTRESS BUILT, ACCORDING TO LEGEND, BY THE 14TH-CENTURY KING MARKO FOR HIS SISTER, JULY 6, 2007 Alek Gavrilovski, 20, from Skopje, Macedonia, on summer break from his studies at the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta. ''I've studied in the States for three years, and pretty much every summer I go back to Macedonia. I've traveled the world, and I've never really taken a good look at my own country as much as I am now. I'd never been to the Peshna Cave; I'd only heard about it. The castle's actually built inside. It looks exactly like Helm's Deep from 'Lord of the Rings.' It's kind of sad to compare it to that -- but it's actually incredible when there's something you've seen from somebody's fantasy, and then you see this and it's almost exactly the same.'' As told to Austin Considine

LIVEZEY--Lowell W. New York Theological Seminary announces with great sadness the passing on December 9, 2007, of Dr. Lowell W. Livezey, Professor of Urban and Religious Studies and Director of the Ecologies of Learning Project at the Seminary. Dr. Livezey directed large studies of urban congregations, using ethnographic data assembled in collaboration with colleagues and students in Chicago, Boston, and New York. He argued that the ''religion factor'' is more salient than often recognized in the economic, demographic, and spatial restructuring of modern industrial cities. Dr. Livezey received the B.A. from Swarthmore College and the M. Th. and D. Min. degrees from the University of Chicago School of Divinity. He spent two decades in the peace movement before beginning his second career in studying communities, meanings, culture, and social change. In 2005, Dr. Livezey became the founding Director of the Ecologies of Learning Project (EOL) at NYTS, funded through a major grant from Lilly Endowment Inc. Lowell Livezey was a person of immense insight, wisdom and compassion, of great integrity and depth, and an outstanding colleague. He embodied the values of teaching, learning and research that lie at the heart of the scholarly endeavor. He also was a friend, a caring human being, someone around whom community was easily formed. In the language that is familiar to the people of faith, Lowell simply was a blessing to NYTS. Lowell helped us all understand the life and work of the churches and especially the intellectual task of preparation for ministry more clearly. Dr. Craig Dykstra, Senior Vice President, Religion of Lilly Endowment Inc., stated that ''Lowell Livezey's work on religion and urban culture is path-breaking -a permanent contribution. His patient, generous and imaginative work with pastors and other religious leaders in Chicago, Boston and New York, as well as with scholars, will bear great fruit for many years to come.'' Dr. Livezey is survived by his wife, Dr. Lois Gehr Livezey, Director of the Globalization Project of the Center for World Christianity at NYTS. Contributions in Dr. Livezey's memory may be made to the Lowell W. Livezey Fund, Ecologies of Learning, New York Theological Seminary, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 500, New York, NY 10115. A memorial will be held on January 26, 2008, 10:00 am, at The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York City. Dr. Dale T. Irvin, President Dr. Diane T. Ashley, Chair of the Board of Trustees
UNTERBERG--Charles, December 16th, 1957. Beloved husband, adored father, revered by his grandchildren.

Domestic Disturbances We are, we've repeatedly been told in the past week, in the grip of a faith war. There has been a lot of interesting discussion of Mormonism and Evangelical Protestantism, about Mitt Romney and Mike Huckabee outdoing themselves to appeal to Christian conservatives, and about John McCain's belief in a ''Christian nation.'' There has been dismay about a political moment in which it seems a candidate must pass a religious litmus test to gain national viability. There have been comparisons to John F. Kennedy, talk of the founding fathers, of the separation of church and state, and of how the Puritans' rather intolerant vision of religious freedom continues to trickle down to our day.

KOHNSTAMM--Lee W. The Virginia Dare Extract Company, Brooklyn, deeply mourns the loss of our Vice President International. Lee was responsible for the company's international business and was a highly respected and a well known person in the American beverage industry. He was involved in many trade associations and was instrumental in the activities of the Society of Soft Drink Technologists, the New England Bottlers Association, and the I.B.D.E.A. He authored the Beverage Industry Annual Manual. He was born April 3rd, 1936 and graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. Lee was always willing to share his knowledge, and was a friend to all. He will be sadly missed.

KRASNER--Leonard. Passed away from heart attack on November 28, 2007 in Reno, NV at age 82. Leonard Krasner received his Ph.D. in psychology from Columbia University. In a career that spanned more than 50 years, he did much to advance the cause of behavioral therapy and was widely regarded as the intellectual founder of behavior modification. He started the first U.S. clinical psychology training program focused on behavior therapy at Stony Brook in the 1960s. In partnership with many other colleagues, he authored major textbooks on clinical psychology from a behavioral perspective. Born in NYC to Helen and Samuel Krasner on December 17th, 1924, he was a beloved husband, father, grandfather, professor, author and friend. Married to Miriam Krasner (who died in 2002) for almost 55 years, they were role models of a loving, lifelong partnership. Leonard's survivors include his four children Wendy , David, Charlie and Stefanie, five grandchildren Robin, Michelle, Zachary, Henry and Harry, and scores of loving friends. A Leonard Krasner Memorial Award has been arranged through the Association for Behavioral and Cognitive Therapies, formerly known as the Association for Advancement of Behavior Therapy. Donations to this award fund should be made out to ABCT and sent to The Leonard Krasner Memorial Award, ABCT, 305 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10001.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer's polls are looking like a downhill skier's delight and a politician's nightmare. Each new survey puts his popularity at a lower point than the one before, with his foes rejoicing as the man once thought most likely to reform Albany skids publicly into failure. The latest poll from Siena Research Institute shows that even Mr. Spitzer's fellow Democrats are deserting him, with only one in three saying they want him re-elected in 2010.

CHEREN--Melvin. (January 21, 1933-December 7, 2007) Affectionately known as ''The Godfather of Disco'' for his championing of DJs, dance music and club culture from the early days of the Disco Movement, Mel began his five decade career in the music business at ABC/Paramount, where he eventually became Head of Production. He held the same position when he moved to Scepter Records. During his tenure at Scepter he was responsible for many innovations such as the first 12 inch record for DJs and the first instrumental mix on the B-side, earning Scepter the ''Trendsetter of the Year'' Award from Billboard in 1974. With a former Scepter colleague he formed his own company, West End Records in 1976, which has been associated for over 30 years with enduring dance classics like ''Hot Shot'' and ''Heartbeat''. In recent years West End released popular compilation CD's of remixes and live performances by legendary Paradise Garage DJ Larry Levan. Mel was the financial backer of the landmark club created by his former life-partner Michael Brody. This history is well documented in Cheren's autobiography, My Life and the Paradise Garage: Keep on Dancin' published in 2000 and in a recent documentary, The Godfather of Disco. In 2005 Mel was inducted into the Dance Music Hall of Fame with their Lifetime Achievement Award, an honor which meant a great deal to him. For all of his accomplishments in the music industry, Mel was most proud of his work in support of various causes and charities and in particular his efforts in support of the LGBT Community and the fight against AIDS. He was part of the vanguard of gay men who first responded to the AIDS crisis in New York in the early Eighties and gave GMHC their first home in his Chelsea brownstone which he later operated for over 20 years as a successful bed-and-breakfast, the Colonial House Inn. He was the founder of 24 Hours For Life, an AIDS charity that was the fiscal sponsor for LIFEbeat, on whose Board he served as a Charter Director. Mel was also quietly a friend to many friends and strangers in need as well as an accomplished painter. A large number of Mel's works of art memorialize friends lost to AIDS. It is a sad irony that he is a fatality of the same health crisis that he fought so long to eradicate. Even in his last days he took a stand for AIDS prevention in a cautionary interview aired on the LOGO channel throughout the week of World AIDS Day. Mel Cheren is survived and will be greatly missed by many family members, prominent among them being Illya Dekhtyar, Mark Cheren and Barry Cherin, as well as a large extended family of close friends, colleagues and fellow activists. An announcement will soon be made about a memorial service/celebration and various memorial benefit parties taking place over the third weekend in January which would have marked his 75th birthday. Donations in Mel's honor can be made to GMHC, 119 West 24th Street, New York, New York 10011; The LGBT Community Center at 208 West 13th Street, New York, New York 10011; or LIFEbeat, 630 9th Avenue Suite 1010 New York, New York 10036.

SIDEL--Nancy Jarmon, born December 6, 1939 in New York City. Survived by her loving sons John and Henry, their wives Eva-Lotta Hedman and Beth Levison, and her adoring grandchildren, Matilda, Ben and Gabe. Also survived by her dear companion of many years Patrick McCormick. She amazed her family, friends and doctors with her resilience, optimism and determination in the face of cancer. Ultimately she passed in peace. Her professional life included teaching English literature at the Lycee Francais, heading up the Bank of New York's new business for private banking and serving as Director of Development at the Hudson River Museum. She was passionate about reading, classical music, travel, swimming, walking, her family and her bridge game. Even throughout her illness she played consistently and became a Lifetime Silver Grandmaster. Her energy and spark will be missed forever. Memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell at 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., 3:30pm on Sunday, December 16th. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in memory of Nancy J. Sidel to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center at P.O. Box 27106, NY, NY 10087-7106 or the New York Society Library at 53 East 79th St., NY, NY 10021

BERLIN--Edwin Paul. May 12, 1930-December 7, 2007. Edwin Paul Berlin, 77, of Rancho Bernardo in San Diego, CA, died peacefully at his home on December 7, 2007 with his loving wife and son by his side. Born in New York City, he received B.S. and MBA degrees from New York University. A resident of Huntington, L.I., New York for over 18 years, he was a selfemployed advertising/copy consultant and humor writer until he retired and moved to California. Prior to that, he was vice president and copy chief at Dunwoodie Associates, and held advertising manager positions at Sperry Rand Semiconductor Div. (now Unisys) and General Instrument Corp. He served with the U.S. Army in Japan during the Korean War. His humorous articles were published by a number of leading magazines and newspapers and many of his Letters-ToThe-Editor were published in the N.Y. Times. Survivors include his wife of 44 years, Faith Frances Berlin; son, Edwin Berlin, Jr. of Oakland, CA; stepson, Michael Harmon of Laurel, MD; and brother, Martin Berlin of Melville, NY. No funeral or memorial services are scheduled. Gifts honoring his memory and his long struggle with metastatic cancer can be sent to Elizabeth Hospice, Escondido, CA.
Art Ken Johnson

HARRIS--George De Lancey, of New York, NY, and Port Royal, Nova Scotia, died in New York at age 83 on December 7, 2007. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, Joanna Cochrane Harris, their son, James Harris, and his brother, Thomas L. Harris. Del (as he was widely known) Harris was born in New York City and grew up in Scarsdale and Nova Scotia. He and Mrs. Harris lived in Port Royal, Nova Scotia, five months of the year in a home he decorated and cherished. A veteran of WWII, Del, with his brother Thomas, owned D. P. Harris Hardware and Manufacturing Company. The company, founded by his grandfather, produced Rollfast bicycles. He traveled internationally for many years representing his company. Del, much loved by everyone who knew him, possessed a generous and loving spirit. Predeceased by his daughter, Charlotte, he will be interred, like her, in the Harris family plot in the Annapolis Royal Cemetery, Nova Scotia. A memorial gathering will be held on December 16th.

AGUS--Edith. It is with deepest sorrow that we mourn the loss of our dear one, Edith Agus. We have lost a friend whose warmth, intellect, depth, caring and devotion transcended the generations in our family. Loving matriarch of a large and wholesome extended family, she could never possibly be far from our hearts and minds. A unique force of nature, she combined a tremendous joie de vivre balanced by a rock solid practical set of sensibilities. She was a rare combination of qualities: graceful, feminine, yet rooted in fine character. We extend our compassion and understanding to the family. The Bella and Harry Wexner Family

Kulicke, painter, draughtsman, printmaker, frame designer, framemaker, potter, goldsmith, historian, collector, and teacher, on December 14, 2007. Roy Davis, Partner Cecily Langdale, Partner KULICKE--Robert. We give our sincere thanks to and for the Tolstoy Foundation Nursing Home in Valley Cottage, NY. December 14, 1945 was Bob's favorite day of the year when he was released from the Army and ended his tour of duty. While he never forgot his affection for his fellow soldiers, he didn't like regimentation. 52 years later his second tour of duty and its regimen ended at the Tolstoy Foundation. He managed that one, too, with courage and dignity, thanks to the support, professional competence and kindly care of the staff, especially Albina, Anesta, Anne Marie, Billy, Dennis, Janet, Ruby (Head Nurse), Tim and Virginia. With much gratitude, Pam Sheehan, Fredericka Kulicke and Michael Kulicke

VOLPE--Dr. Edmond L. First President of the College of Staten Island, died Friday, December 14th, at Richmond University Medical Center on Staten Island. He was 85. Along with creating the College of Staten Island in 1976, Dr. Volpe was also a prominent literary critic specializing in modern American literature, especially the work of William Faulkner. Prior to becoming president of Richmond College in 1974, he was Chairman of The City College of New York, Department of English. In 1976, he was appointed first President of the College of Staten Island. For funeral service details, contact Casey Funeral Home, Staten Island, 718-447-4242

A brief film review in Weekend on Dec. 14 about ''The Singing Revolution,'' a documentary about Estonia's struggle to end Soviet occupation, misidentified the site of the Estonian song festival. It is in Tallinn, the capital not Tartu, where some festivals were held in the 19th century. The review also referred incorrectly to the songs performed at the festival that are shown in the film. They were written by composers; they are not folk songs.

FOR adoptive parents, bringing a new baby into the home can be a very costly process. Now, one national bank has begun helping such families more easily afford the financial burdens of adoption by tapping into their home equity. Chase, a division of JPMorgan Chase & Company, introduced New Additions last month, a program that offers adoptive parents a discounted home-equity loan. Adoption advocates say it is the first service of its kind and will give the 125,000 families who adopt children each year in the United States significantly more financial flexibility.

How much holiday money should a New Yorker give to the doorman, superintendent, concierge or porter? How about your letter carrier, housekeeper, parking-lot attendant and newspaper distributor? Or your child’s schoolteacher? And how should you deliver it? In a box in the building lobby? In a hand-delivered envelope? In the mail?

The clear matzo ball soup was the same, the blue and brown tile floors were the same, even the hustling waitresses were the same. The waitresses recognized their old customers of the Second Avenue Deli and the old Second Avenue Deli customers recognized them back — even though they had reconvened one mile north and were no longer on Second Avenue. Instead, now they were on East 33rd Street, between a nail salon and a body hair threading place on the south side of the street between Lexington and Third Avenues.

December is nostalgia month for the city’s transportation aficionados, as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is breaking out vintage subway cars and buses for passenger use.Old New York City Transit buses are running on the crosstown routes of M34, M42, and M50 in Manhattan from 7:30 to 10:30 a.m. and from 3 to 6 p.m. And on Sundays in December, subway cars from the 1930s to the 1970s will operate on the V(intage?) line between Queens Plaza and Second Avenue on Sundays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. (The traditional vintage subway program, which is not for normal passenger use, has been questioned for its fiscal appropriateness.)

Todd Herzog, a 22-year-old flight attendant from Utah, became the latest champion of the "Survivor" series on Sunday, as the final episode of the show's 15th edition gave CBS a modest boost in the ratings. Attracting 15.1 million viewers from 8 p.m. to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates, the "Survivor: China" finale garnered slightly better ratings than the show's average this season and matched the ratings for its September premiere, which had been one of the series' lowest-rated debuts.

But rather than wax nostalgic for the good old days when the worst thing a player put into his body before the game was a pint of bourbon, we need to get aggressive and move forward. To use a sports metaphor, "We cannot stop steroids; we can only hope to contain them."

In the end, the conflict that dominated the Bali climate talks was not between developed countries and developing nations. It was the U.S. against the rest of the world. The International Ice Hockey Federation released an interview with its president, René Fasel, to clarify its positions on the reopening of the N.H.L.-I.I.H.F. player transfer agreement. Fasel reiterates the European position we noted earlier: an end to N.H.L. clubs' warehousing of European players in the minor leagues; an earlier transfer deadline than June 15 for N.H.L. transfers; and a way to deal with the plummeting value of the U.S. dollar against European currencies.

John Edwards remains very much in contention in Iowa and in the race for the Democratic nomination, and over the weekend the Edwards camp unveiled a new TV ad titled, "Fight." In it, Mr. Edwards looks into the camera and declares war on inequality. "The moral test of our generation is whether we're going to allow this broken system to go on without a fight or take on corporate greed and stand up for the middle class and American jobs before it's too late," he says. "Saving the middle class is going to be an epic battle, and that's a fight I was born for."

When the human imagination wants to conjure up a fantastical beast for its own entertainment, it often follows the simple but effective recipe of taking a familiar critter and exaggerating it to colossal or minuscule size. Enormous "this-es" and tiny "thats" populate classical myths and campfire stories, high-flown allegorical novels and bait-shop lies about the one that got -- well, you know.

Now that Rich Rodriguez has been introduced as Michigan's new head coach, let's take a look at the various ways in which his move is being viewed. SI.com's Stewart Mandel calls it "college football's most significant hire since Florida landed Urban Meyer." Bob Wojnowski of the Detroit News writes that hiring Rodriguez was "the aggressive, innovative move Michigan had to make." Jim Carty of the Ann Arbor News says the hire is a "home run" for Athletic Director Bill Martin. The folks at MGoBlog.com seem pretty satisfied with the move as well.

Last week, in The Moment's Talk Off column, Nathan Lump, the magazine's Travel Editor, battled the Travel Features Editor Jeffries Blackerby over the merits of airports. After last week's post about time management tricks, I wanted to e-mail Merlin Mann, whose "inbox zero" video I linked to, telling him about the blog post. I don't know Mr. Mann, but I've long admired his blog, 43Folders, and lately I have become a bit of a zealot about his "in box zero" concept of e-mail management. When I got to his site, it was easy enough to e-mail him since his site is well organized and there is a clear "about" page that leads you to a page with information about him. But when I got to that page, I learned that he isn't reading e-mails at the moment because he is on paternity leave until the end of December.

"Production on all but two of the last few scripted prime-time television shows shooting in Los Angeles ground to a halt on Friday as a crippling strike by Hollywood writers neared the end of its sixth week, an industry group said," Reuters reports.

Related Companies, the New York real estate developer, said Monday it would receive $1.4 billion in equity and debt investments from a group including Goldman Sachs, Michael Dell's MSD Capital and Mubadala Development, an affiliate of an investment firm owned by Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates.

Lehman Brothers faces the threat of legal action by municipal councils in Australia over the sale of high-risk collateralized debt obligations by the Wall Street bank's local subsidiary, Grange Securities, according to The Financial Times.

A very odd book, or rather a set of 50 books, has appeared for sale on eBay. They are "My 61 Memorable Games," by Bobby Fischer. According to the listing, Fischer has updated his book, "My 60 Memorable Games," which he published in 1969, and is selling this set and another set of 50 as a "special edition, first print run." The bidding was up to $3,050, as of early Monday morning. One of the odd quirks of the sale is that the buyer has to take the whole set, not just one book.

The Olympic slalom champion Anja Paerson won a women’s World Cup super-G in Switzerland on Sunday for her second victory in 24 hours.Paerson finished the Corviglia course in 1 minute 15.06 seconds to edge Canada’s Emily Brydon by 0.04. Renate Goetschl was third.“It’s just amazing,” Paerson said. “Yesterday, I was just thinking about getting across the finish line because this is such a tough super-G course.”Julia Mancuso lost half a second in the final interval but still posted the top American result, tying for 10th with Canada’s Britt Janyk in 1:15.57.

Kalle Palander of Finland got his third career giant slalom victory on the Gran Risa course in Alta Badia, Italy, and the American Ted Ligety skied the fastest second run to finish fifth.Palander led the first run and his two-run combined time of 2:30.92 was enough to hold off Austria’s Benjamin Raich, the Olympic giant slalom champion, by 0.42 seconds.Ligety, who leads the giant slalom standings, was penalized by the International Ski Federation for showing up four minutes late to Saturday’s public draw. By rule, he was forced to start 46th instead of within the top 15 and was fined $867. (AP).

Alexandr Zubkov of Russia drove his sled to victory in the four-man World Cup bobsled race, a year and a day after crashing on the course at the Olympic Sports Complex in Lake Placid, N.Y.His two-run time of 1 minute 48.79 seconds was 0.05 seconds faster than the American sled piloted by Steven Holcomb of Park City, Utah, who leads the standings with 660 points. Pierre Lueders of Canada, winner of the two-man race Saturday, was third.

Manchester United extended its six-year unbeaten streak at Anfield by defeating Liverpool, 1-0, in an English Premier League match. Carlos Tevez’s goal in the 43rd minute off a corner from Wayne Rooney also sent Liverpool to its second consecutive league defeat after an unbeaten start.

The German speedskater Jenny Wolf broke her world record in the women’s 100 meters with a time of 10.22 seconds at a World Cup race in Erfurt, Germany. That broke the mark of 10.28 she set in Calgary, Alberta, on March 4. Xing Aihua of China was second in 10.59, followed by Judith Hesse of Germany in 10.62.

Kikkan Randall became the first United States woman and the second American to win a World Cup cross-country race when she defeated the world sprint champion Astrid Jacobsen of Norway in the final meters of a 1.2-kilometer freestyle race in Demino, Russia.Randall is the first American to win a World Cup cross-country race since Bill Koch in 1983. She finished in 2:48.7 — seven-tenths of a second ahead of Jacobsen.

A sports article on Dec. 9 about the impact of poor conditions on the women's World Cup downhill in Aspen, Colo., referred imprecisely to the history of downhill races there. WANG--Kenneth, died peacefully in his home, in Cove Neck, on December 14th, surrounded by his family. He was born in China in 1914. He was the beloved husband of Mary, and cherished father of Anthony, Charles and Francis and their wives, Lulu, Nancy and Laura. He was much beloved by his seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He was also the much loved brother of Hsiang-Ming Hsia. He graduated from Soochow University School of Law in 1938. He practiced law in Shanghai until 1945 when he was recruited to be a judge of the Court of Appeals for Shanghai. In 1947 he was awarded a fellowship by Harvard University School of Law where he earned an LLM degree. He returned to China in 1948 to resume his law practice and to teach at Soochow University Law School. In 1949 he became President of Aurora College for Women. In 1952 Professor Wang and his family moved to the U.S. and he joined the faculty of St. John's University School of Law in New York City. He was invited to serve as Visiting Professor of Law at Michigan University Law School in 1963. In 1964 he was invited by President Lyndon B. Johnson to participate in the White House Conference on International Law and International Cooperation. In addition to his professorship at St. John's, he was also on the panel of Arbitrators of The American Arbitration Association. By the time he retired as Professor of Law at St. John's in 1984, he had taught and inspired generations of young lawyers and future leaders in business and government. After his retirement from St. John's, Professor Wang became the senior partner of Wang and Wang in Taipei, a law firm specializing in transnational law. St. John's honored him in 1984 with the President's Medal, in 1987 with an honorary Doctor of Laws degree, and in 1992 with the Medal of Honor. In 2003, Soochow University honored him with the naming of the Kenneth Wang School of Law. He will always be honored in the hearts of his family, friends and students. Services were private. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be sent to St. John's University School of Law, in support of the Kenneth Wang International Fellowship, at 8000 Utopia Parkway, Queens, NY 11439.

LUPE FIASCO ''The Cool'' (Atlantic) Somber string sections and minor keys signal the unabashed seriousness of Lupe Fiasco's second album, ''The Cool.'' Wasalu Muhammad Jaco, who calls himself Lupe Fiasco, is concerned about everything from the state of hip-hop to impending apocalypse in songs that envision a widening spiral of poverty, selfishness and disregard for consequences. Like ''Lupe Fiasco's Food & Liquor,'' his first album, ''The Cool'' moves from the personal and the local to the all-encompassing. But this time around Lupe Fiasco and his producers -- mostly Soundtrakk -- have clarified the lyrics and brought out the hooks. The result is a three-act allegory that's also one of the year's best hip-hop albums.

To the Editor: Re ''High Stakes for Poker as a Learning Tool'' (Education, Dec. 12):

There are many ways to answer the question ''what happened last night?'' For advertisers, a show's viewers are valuable whether they watch a show when first broadcast or as a recording. For ''Dancing With the Stars,'' above, with Helio Castroneves and Julianne Hough, ratings during the week ending Dec. 3 increased to 14.0 for recorded viewings of the Monday prime-time show, from 13.1 for the broadcast, and to 12.7 from 12.1 for the results show.

STEVE LEHMAN ''On Meaning'' (Pi) Intellectual seriousness has apparently never been a scarce commodity for the alto saxophonist Steve Lehman. A former Fulbright scholar and current Columbia University doctoral candidate in music composition, Mr. Lehman comes to his art with an abundance of academic context. It's no accident that the title of his new album suggests a treatise, though on some level it was probably a mistake.

BIRDMAN ''5 Stunna'' (Cash Money/Universal) Talk about a bait and switch. First Lil Wayne said he was releasing a new album at the end of this year. Then he said it would be a compilation, full of the best tracks from his dazzling run of mix tapes. But apparently the plans changed again; instead of a new Lil Wayne CD we get ''5 Stunna,'' a new album from his mentor and spiritual ''daddy,'' Birdman, previously known as Baby.

Some Think Tech Spending Will Grow The big research houses have been trimming their 2008 forecasts for global technology spending lately, mainly because they see a weaker United States market next year. IDC, for example, reduced its growth projection for 2008 last week to a range of 5.5 percent to 6 percent, down from an earlier forecast of 6.6 percent.

MELVILLE--Frank, III, died at Noble Horizons on December 5th after a long illness. He was the husband of Allen Whitley Melville. Born in Brooklyn, NY on October 12, 1923, the son of Ward and Dorothy Bigelow Melville. He attended Princeton University before joining the Navy Air Force during WWII. After the war he worked briefly as a book designer before joining the fledgling History Book Club, from which he retired as president in 1978. He served as a trustee of The Pomfret School and Sarah Lawrence College, and was throughout his life a strong supporter of liberal causes and organizations, particularly the American Civil Liberties Union. After moving from New Canaan to Norfolk in 1980 he was the guiding spirit behind the Melville Charitable Trust from its inception in 1990 and was passionately committed to its goal of putting an end to homelessness in the United States. Predeceased by his older sisters Margaret and Ruth. Besides his wife survived by his four sons, Stephen, Lanning, Gregory and Cameron. A younger brother David, three grandchildren, Geoffrey Melville, Alan Thomas Melville and Erin Benjamin Melville. Contributions: The Association from Frontotemporal Dementias, 100 North 17th St., Suite 600, Philadelphia, PA 19103 or Noble Horizons, 17 Cobble, Salisbury, CT 06068.

8 P.M. (NBC) CLASH OF THE CHOIRS In this live, four-night musical mini-series, Michael Bolton, Patti LaBelle, Kelly Rowland, Blake Shelton and Nick Lachey, above at right with his choir, step out of the spotlight and put their leadership skills to the test as they compete to create ''America's greatest choir.'' Each celebrity will return to his or her hometown to assemble, coach and conduct a group of amateur singers who will meet in a sing-off of holiday classics and current hits across four evenings in New York. Viewers will vote, with the winning choir receiving a prize to help its community: New Haven (Mr. Bolton's hometown), Philadelphia (Ms. LaBelle's), Cincinnati (Mr. Lachey's), Houston (Ms. Rowland's) or Oklahoma City (Mr. Shelton's). 8 P.M. (HBO) HARD AS NAILS Justin Fatica, an unordained Catholic minister, uses a combination of professional wrestling, hip-hop and Scripture to draw troubled teenagers to his youth ministry, called Hard as Nails. He also employs more controversial tactics, like re-enacting Jesus' crucifixion through the simulated nailing and blindfolding of participants, who carry large wooden crosses as others berate them. This documentary from David Holbrooke follows Mr. Fatica as he preaches about drug addiction, sexual abuse, self-mutilation and suicide while dealing with his family, including his mother, Kathleen, and his wife, Mary, who gives birth to their son, Joseph, in the film.

Susan Williams-Ellis, the eccentric designer of Botanic Garden, the popular ceramic tableware pattern featuring bug-infested botanical illustrations, died on Nov. 27 in Portmeirion village in northern Wales, the Italianate dream world built by her father, Sir Clough Williams-Ellis. She was 89. The cause was bronchial pneumonia, said her son, Robin Llywelyn, the managing director of Portmeirion Ltd., which runs the village as a resort.

Adhering to the philosophy that an apple a day may help keep the doctor away, city officials are trying to increase the availability of fresh fruits and vegetables in poor and minority neighborhoods through a sharp increase in vending carts, which they hope will combat the city’s obesity epidemic.The proposal, introduced by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn, calls for 1,500 new permits for fruit and vegetable carts in neighborhoods where consumption of fruits and vegetables is low. Currently, fewer than 10 percent of the 4,100 mobile food carts serve fruits and vegetables. (About half serve processed foods like kabobs and gyros, while most of the remaining serve things like coffee and pretzels.)

Like SoHo and TriBeCa before it, Dumbo has now made its way from neighborhood acronym to historic treasure. Dumbo — the name once stood for Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass but now hardly requires an explanation — was designated New York City’s 90th historic district by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. (The first historic district, designated in 1965, was Brooklyn Heights.)The new historic district is bounded by John Street to the north, York Street to the south, Main Street to the west and Bridge Street to the east, and includes 91 buildings that reflect the industrial heritage of the Brooklyn waterfront.

PARIS -- France has come up with an ingenious way to get consumers to buy more fuel-efficient cars: by giving a rebate to high-mileage cars and charging a surtax on gas hogs. The system is called a "bonus-malus" approach, such as exists in auto insurance. Translated from the Latin, it is a Peter-Paul approach, in which the state robs Peter of 2,600 euros ($3,800) when he buys a Porsche Cayenne Turbo and pays Paul 700 euros ($1,025) when he buys a Mini Cooper D.

A few weeks ago, my cousin sent me an e-mail saying she was in the midst of a moratorium on shopping. Then last week, she e-mailed me a video made by international sustainability expert, Ann Leonard called "The Story of Stuff," which provides some of the reasons (environmental sustainability, wastefulness, exploitation of low-wage workers to name just a few), for her anti-consumption stance. I watched the video this morning and while I'm not sure I can go cold turkey on all shopping, I do expect that I will be thinking twice about how much stuff I can really acquire and whether there are gifts I can give to others that won't contribute to the piles of clutter so many of us are surrounded by these days.

Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, the nation's oldest private commercial bank, will announce Tuesday that it has appointed Douglas A. Donahue Jr. as its new managing partner, the equivalent of a chief executive, The New York Times said.
Alliance Data Systems, the credit-card manager that agreed to be bought by the Blackstone Group, said the $7.8 billion takeover may not be completed by the end of the year.
Silicon Valley real estate mogul Carl Berg on Monday pulled his Mission West portfolio off the market, refusing to budge from his $1.8 billion price tag despite the crisis in the financial markets.

CHRISTMAS HOLIDAY AIR TRAVEL About the same number of people as last year, 47 million passengers, are expected to travel on domestic airlines during this Christmas holiday period, the Air Transport Association says. The four busiest air travel days in the period, which began last Thursday and continues through Jan 2, are expected to be, in decreasing order, Jan. 2, Dec. 21, Dec. 27, and Dec. 26. The least busy travel days are expected to be Christmas Day and Dec. 24, the airline trade group said.

Deputies made nearly two dozen arrests after breaking up a dogfighting operation, Sheriff Bob Buckley of Union Parish said. Sheriff Buckley said that at least six units from his office and from the State Wildlife and Fisheries Office raided the operation about 1 p.m. Sunday in woods on private property about six miles southwest of Farmerville. ''We took 12 vehicles, guns, and 11 dogs were seized,'' Sheriff Buckley said. Some of the dogs were dead, he said. The dogs were taken to the Ouachita Parish animal shelter.

Supporters of what was to be the broadest limit ever on what children can eat and drink at school say they will try again next year, after the Senate failed to approve the plan last week as an amendment to the farm bill. The standards, sponsored by Senators Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, and Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, would have restricted what could be sold in vending machines and would have eliminated foods high in fat and sugar from à la carte menus that supplement school lunches, which are regulated by the Department of Agriculture. A crush of procedural maneuvers kept the amendment from being added to the final version of the bill, which the Senate passed Thursday. But because the plan was written by an unusual alliance of school food reform advocates and food industry representatives, lawmakers and others who worked on it said the ban could be revived as a stand-alone bill or attached to other legislation in 2008.

GUTTU--The Rev. Lyle R., 71, chaplain at Wagner College, Staten Island, died Monday, December 17, after having been struck by a car two days earlier. AGUS--Edith H. (nee Marinbach). The Yeshiva University family is deeply saddened by the passing of an elegant and brilliant Jewish matriarch who was a loyal friend and advocate for our institution. Mrs. Agus was both concerned and generous and encouraged her friends to support the advancement of Jewish education and the training of rabbis, who would serve in the pulpit and in Jewish day schools, at our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) where the Marinbach family has been long involved. Her leadership and friendship will always be recalled with abiding gratitude. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her children, Bertrand (and Shoshana) Agus, Saul (and Marcelle) Agus, and Stephen (and Linda) Agus, to her seven grandchildren and her 23 greatgrandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman, YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman, RIETS Board of Trustees
