Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th Street, Brooklyn, NY. Mass of Resurrection Wednesday, 10:30am, at St. Athanasius R.C. Church. Entombment, St. John's Cloister. Donations to Albert and Dolores Niciforo Scholarship Fund, 2154 61st St, Brooklyn, NY 11204 appreciated.

The Austrian national library announced on Monday that it had bought the papers of the avant-garde Austrian writer Peter Handke for $722,000, Agence France-Presse reported. Culture Minister Claudia Schmied told a news conference in Vienna that the purchase was a way of supporting ''one of Europe's great poets, as well as laying the foundation for an exhaustive center of Handke research.'' The ministry is helping to finance the purchase. Dating back 20 years, the archive includes the manuscripts of a number of novels and plays. Mr. Handke's novels include ''The Goalie's Anxiety at the Penalty Kick'' and ''The Left-Handed Woman.'' In a video message Mr. Handke, above, who has lived since 1991 in Chaville, France, near Paris, said, ''I'm happy that my manuscripts are now safe.''

BULGER--Mr. Arthur C., age 81, of Woodbridge, beloved husband of 53 years to Isabelle T. Bulger passed away on Saturday, December 15, 2007. Arthur was born on March 7, 1926 in Brooklyn, New York. He was a graduate of LaSalle Military Academy and Yale University. Mr. Bulger served during WWII with both the U.S. Army and the U.S. Navy. After graduating from Yale in 1947 with degrees in engineering and accounting, he joined The U.S. Rubber Company in Naugatuck as an industrial engineer. In 1952, he co-founded the Consulting Firm, Bavier, Bulger & Goodyear. The firm operated internationally for over 50 years and was a leader in developing innovative manufacturing methods for Fortune 1000 clients. He was a member of the Board of Directors for Lava Crucible, Saxonburg Ceramics, American Paper Products and Elliptipar, Inc. A life long sailor, Arthur and his wife began sailing together on the schooner Truelove. He cruised and raced extensively, owning a series of boats named Starlight and was a longtime member of The Milford Yacht Club and the Off Sounding Club. In addition to his wife, he leaves three children, Ellen Bulger, A. Christopher Bulger and Jean Pugh, along with six grandchildren, Emmet, Max, Zoe, Kate, Christopher and Alex. He also leaves two sisters, Barbara O'Reilly and Kay Lynch. Friends may call today from 4 to 7pm in the Cody-White Funeral Home, in Milford, CT. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Wednesday at 11am in Our Lady of the Assumption Church, Center Road, Woodbridge, CT. Commital will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the CT Food Bank in New Haven. www.cody whitefuneralservice.com

GELLER--Deborah. BBC producer, documentary filmmaker, author and pop culture maven, she is agonizingly survived by her father Arthur, her sisters Ruth and Miriam, her brother Charles, stepmother Martha, stepbrothers Hans and Milton, and loving family as well as friends too numerous to name on both sides of the Atlantic. Her deep knowledge of New York and its byzantine bureaucracy was a major reason for her professional success during her long tenure with the BBC. Debbie was a blazingly smart, funny, and sensitive person who came to be a symbol of NYC for her London friends and colleagues and a touchstone for her friends and colleagues, here. The funeral will be held today, 11:15am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

Adored and adoring grandmother of Jennifer (Steve), Alexandra (Justin), Eve and Julia. Proud great-grandmother of Emerson. She was the strong and loving center of our family. It turns out she was right about almost everything. Our heartfelt thanks and gratitude to Regina, Rachel, and Connie for their loving care. Funeral services Wednesday, December 19, 12pm, at George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Lecount Place, New Rochelle, 914-632-0324. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the national office of ORT America, 75 Maiden Lane, 10th Floor, New York, NY 10038.

A water-conservation measure that fishermen said would devastate the Florida Panhandle's oyster industry has been delayed, the governors of three drought-stricken Southeastern states said as they pledged to speed talks on sharing water during scarcities. The Bush administration had brokered a plan last month to reduce flows into the Apalachicola River, which feeds a major oyster breeding ground in Florida. That short-term effort to bolster Atlanta's drinking supply drew opposition from oystermen and environmentalists who said it would further damage species already hit hard by one of the region's worst droughts in years. The governors of Florida, Georgia and Alabama and the federal government agreed not to reduce, for now, the minimum amount of water that will flow into Apalachicola Bay. The governors also agreed that their staffs would continue to work together to come up with a plan for doling out the region's water by March 15, faster than had been expected.

John Terry, the captain for Chelsea and the English national team, will be out for up to six weeks after breaking three bones in his right foot. Terry was hurt when he was tackled by Emmanuel Eboue late in the first half of Chelsea's 1-0 Premier League loss to Arsenal on Sunday. The injury is likely to keep Terry out of England's friendly against Switzerland Feb. 6 at Wembley. That will be England's first game under Coach Fabio Capello, who would not say Monday whether he would retain Terry as captain.

Two state parks officials have been cleared of wrongdoing in the shooting deaths of nearly six dozen wild donkeys, according to a Texas Parks and Wildlife Department report. The two officials -- Dan Sholly, a deputy division director with the agency, and Michael Hill, a regional director -- were investigated for animal cruelty charges after shooting 71 feral burros at Big Bend Ranch State Park over the last year. According to the report released this month, Mr. Sholly and Mr. Hill shot the animals as part of an agency plan to rid the park of feral and so-called nuisance animals.

The Weekend Explorer column on Friday, about the Upper East Side, referred imprecisely to the architectural style of the mansion Andrew Carnegie built at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 91st Street and of the town house Woody Allen bought on East 70th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues. They are Georgian style, not Georgian. A correction in this space on Saturday referred incorrectly to the King George of Britain who died in 1830. The king, George IV, was the last King George in the period that gave the architectural style its name, not the last King George of Britain. (George V and George VI reigned in the 20th century.)

A third man charged in a plot to attack Southern California military sites and other targets has pleaded guilty to a terrorism conspiracy charge. The man, Gregory V. Patterson, entered the plea in federal court in Santa Ana, said his lawyer, Winston K. McKesson. Mr. Patterson, 23, faces five years to life in prison. The authorities say Mr. Patterson was linked to a California prison gang cell of radical Muslims who planned attacks in the Los Angeles area. The police uncovered the plot in 2005 while investigating gas station robberies that they say were committed to finance the operation. Two other men charged in the plot pleaded guilty last week.

More than any other candidate, John Edwards has used ActBlue.com, the liberal fund-raising Web site, to solicit donations -- $4.4 million so far. But on Friday, the Federal Election Commission ruled against a request from Mr. Edwards that money raised through ActBlue be used to qualify for federal matching funds. Mr. Edwards is seeking public financing for his Democratic presidential campaign, and the election commission's action could potentially reduce the amount of federal money available to him.

The University of California has agreed to pay the federal government $2.8 million over a security breakdown at the Los Alamos National Laboratory last year. Under the deal, the university will not seek a judicial review of the penalty and has accepted responsibility for the violations, the National Nuclear Security Administration said in a news release. The settlement amount is slightly less than the $3 million civil penalty the security agency imposed in September on the university, which was the sole manager of the laboratory for the Department of Energy until June 2006. The penalty stems from an October 2006 incident in which the police discovered more than 1,000 pages of classified documents and several computer storage devices in a drug bust at the trailer of a former worker for a laboratory subcontractor.

The Bloomberg-for-president buzz machine seems to have shifted into overdrive recently, with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg traveling the world, acting like a statesman and injecting himself into the political debate. Mr. Bloomberg, who traveled to Mexico, Paris and London as well as New Orleans, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Houston, Seattle and St. Louis this year, spent last week in Asia. After promoting his views on the environment and government innovation in Beijing and Shanghai, he spoke in Bali at the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, telling his audience that the next president needed to ''go around the world, make sure that people understand that we are willing to listen -- and actually listen.'' Sort of like he has been doing.

WANG--Kenneth, died peacefully in his home, in Cove Neck, on December 14th, surrounded by his family. He was born in China in 1914. He was the beloved husband of Mary, and cherished father of Anthony, Charles and Francis and their wives, Lulu, Nancy and Laura. He was much beloved by his seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He was also the much loved brother of Hsiang-Ming Hsia. He graduated from Soochow University School of Law in 1938. He practiced law in Shanghai until 1945 when he was recruited to be a judge of the Court of Appeals for Shanghai. In 1947 he was awarded a fellowship by Harvard University School of Law where he earned an LLM degree. He returned to China in 1948 to resume his law practice and to teach at Soochow University Law School. In 1949 he became President of Aurora College for Women. In 1952 Professor Wang and his family moved to the U.S. and he joined the faculty of St. John's University School of Law in New York City. He was invited to serve as Visiting Professor of Law at Michigan University Law School in 1963. In 1964 he was invited by President Lyndon B. Johnson to participate in the White House Conference on International Law and International Cooperation. In addition to his professorship at St. John's, he was also on the panel of Arbitrators of The American Arbitration Association. By the time he retired as Professor of Law at St. John's in 1984, he had taught and inspired generations of young lawyers and future leaders in business and government. After his retirement from St. John's, Professor Wang became the senior partner of Wang and Wang in Taipei, a law firm specializing in transnational law. St. John's honored him in 1984 with the President's Medal, in 1987 with an honorary Doctor of Laws degree, and in 1992 with the Medal of Honor. In 2003, Soochow University honored him with the naming of the Kenneth Wang School of Law. He will always be honored in the hearts of his family, friends and students. Services were private. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be sent to St. John's University School of Law, in support of the Kenneth Wang International Fellowship, at 8000 Utopia Parkway, Queens, NY 11439.

A daughter of Mayor Shirley Franklin of Atlanta pleaded guilty to helping launder money for her ex-husband, who is serving life in prison for his involvement in a drug-dealing operation, prosecutors said. The daughter, Kai Franklin, 35, entered the plea in federal court in Greenville, said Reggie Lloyd, a United States attorney. Her ex-husband, Tremayne Graham, was indicted in 2003 for conspiring to distribute at least 1,000 kilograms of cocaine. After his indictment, Mr. Graham ran from the authorities until his arrest in June 2006. During that time, Ms. Franklin paid $14,000 on the couple's mortgage using postal money orders, Mr. Lloyd said. In court, she admitted to structuring the transaction in an effort to hide it from the Internal Revenue Service.

The 1980 United States Olympians who never had a chance to compete at the Moscow Games are finally officially gold medalists. Not Olympic medals, but rather Congressional Gold Medals that were awarded to the 461 Olympic athletes during the Carter administration. The medals were never officially recorded in the Congressional Record because of technical problems with their production.The United States boycotted the 1980 Olympics to protest the Soviet Union's military operation in Afghanistan. The Congressional Record from that year shows that Congress intended to award the Congressional Gold Medals to the Olympians to record the sacrifice they made -- having trained for games in which they never competed.The United States Mint produced the medals, but because they were expensive, financial constraints forced them to be gold-plated bronze medals instead of solid gold. Because of that difference, the Olympians were never officially documented as having received Congressional Gold Medals. Encouraged by the swimmer Ron Neugent; Representative Todd Tiahrt, Republican of Kansas; and Jim Scherr, the chief executive of the United States Olympic committee, the House had the record corrected.

The Brazilian midfielder Kaka completed a virtual sweep of annual awards Monday by winning FIFA's world player of the year. Kaka, who plays for A.C. Milan, received 1,047 points, to beat out Messi with 504 and Cristiano Ronaldo with 426 in a vote by national team captains and managers. The three were picked as finalists from a list of 30 candidates. Kaka also won European soccer's Golden Ball and World Soccer magazine's player of the year award.On the women's side, Marta of Brazil captured the award with 988 points, ahead of Birgit Prinz of Germany with 507 and Cristiane of Brazil with 150.

Members of Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union voted this afternoon to ratify a contract settlement, ending a 10-day strike that inconvenienced about 9,000 wheelchair users and other people with disabilities who depend on Access-a-Ride, a government-financed van services to get around.About 1,500 drivers and mechanics began their strike on Monday morning, shutting down operations at Atlantic Paratrans, the Maggies Paratransit Corporation, MV Transportation and the Transit Facility Management Corporation. The four companies operate about half of the approximately 20,500 rides provided each average weekday under the paratransit program, which runs door-to-door van service for eligible residents who cannot use regular public transit.

The M.T.A. first announced its intent to order new buses in October, pending approval of the agency's board. The order will increase the number of M.T.A. hybrid-electric buses to nearly 1,700, the largest fleet of hybrid-electrics in the world.

Mitt Romney is out with his ad that will be up in Iowa and New Hampshire into Christmas week, one that pulls off a twofer -- showcasing his executive experience while also offering a glimpse of his humanity.
Is China getting more savvy with its Wall Street deals?
All I know about Time's Man of the Year is that there was a flap in Russia over an alleged resemblance between the president and Dobby the house elf from Harry Potter.

Al Lord is in his second term as chief executive of Sallie Mae, having had to return to the helm thanks to the credit crunch killing the takeover deal (at $60 a share) that would have left him set for life.

Citing deepening problems in the mortgage market, Standard & Poor's on Wednesday cut the rating of one troubled bond insurer, ACA Financial, and assigned a negative outlook to ratings of four other companies that guarantee debts tied to home loans.
BOSTON -- The setting of Senator John McCain's event here was replete with imagery meant to play into his strengths.

Although their primary off-season goal of acquiring a front-line starter remains unfulfilled, the Mets are trying to offset those troubles by bolstering their bullpen. On Tuesday, they signed Matt Wise.

One of the more enlightened things the Cosmos of the old North American Soccer League did in the 1980s was issue players snazzy Ellesse bathrobes in the team's blue and yellow colors. The reason: Because a growing number of female reporters demanded (and deserved) entry into the team's locker room and the Cosmos were not about to alienate anyone.
A survey of soccer Web sites this morning yields an eclectic mix of news, and the off-the-field stuff is quite disheartening:

The verdict is in: Chris Simon of the Islanders has been suspended for 30 games for his skate stomp of Jarkko Ruutu's foot. This is the longest suspension in league history, longer even than the 25 games Simon received for a two-handed slash to the chin of the Rangers' Ryan Hollweg last season. It was Simon's eighth suspension in all.

Headlines on various newspaper Web sites say Chris Simon has received the longest penalty in National Hockey League history. The articles say the length of the suspension for intent to injure by using your skate on a player's leg is 30 games. What are we seeing that the NHL is not?
One of the eeriest photography books of 2007 has got to be Brian Howell's "Fame Us: Celebrity Impersonators and the Cult(ure) of Fame," published by Arsenal Pulp Press.

President Bush has just signed into law an energy bill that could have been even better but still remains an impressive achievement. The long struggle to produce that bill yielded the usual quotient of heroes and villains, but two deserve special mention:

OK, so to recap: When it comes to Christmas ads, Rudy Giuliani has Santa Claus on his side, and Mike Huckabee urges everyone to remember the birth of Jesus. But Barack Obama's holiday greeting has a sugarplum cuteness factor that just might outweigh the other two -- his adorable little girls.

The Writers Guild of America's decision to block writers from working on the Golden Globes and block the Academy Awards' producers from using historical film clips could hurt the two television networks -- NBC and ABC, respectively -- that are set to broadcast the award shows early next year.
NOTE: The Screen Actors Guild nominations have been announced. Here is a full list.
David Poland writes in his blog that for the striking writers, the middle way is fraught with peril.
Warrior Ant Press makes a modest proposal:

Jay Leno and Conan O'Brien of NBC and Jimmy Kimmel of ABC will return to their respective broadcasts on Jan. 2, without writers. David Letterman and Craig Ferguson of CBS want to return the same day ­ but with writers.
John Mack is giving up his bonus in 2007. Will the chief of Morgan Stanley need to give up his job as well?
More of your "late night" jokes (send them via the comment link below):
The Democrats might differ subtly on health care, immigration and education, but Bill Richardson wants voters to remember he's all alone on one issue: Iraq.

At this time of year, fashion magazine editors may have it worse than the general population. Every day we find ourselves surrounded by beautiful objects - falling in love is an occupational hazard. Which is why, come holiday time, making a list is almost impossible. Where do we start? This week several T editors share their material desires. Friends and family: take note! (Yesterday's gift list can be found here.)
Two activist hedge funds took another shot at CSX on Wednesday as they named an alternate slate of directors, in the first sign that they will wage a proxy fight.
In most businesses, customers don't pay for a vendor's mistakes. But when hospitals make errors, they charge patients additional money to fix the problem.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

It has only been two months, but Elevation Partners' investment in Palm has been anything but uplifting so far. Elevation, a private equity firm whose founders include rock star Bono, invested $325 million in Palm in a deal that closed Oct. 24. Since then, Palm's stock has lost nearly half of its value, after adjusting for a special dividend it paid out to shareholders.
On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for "Living With Music," a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

The big news from Iowa Monday was that Mari Culver has endorsed John Edwards. This carries some weight, because Mrs. Culver is married to the state's Democratic governor, Chet Culver, and her father-in-law is John Culver, the former senator. (John Culver also co-wrote a terrific biography of Henry Wallace, which I highly recommend for history or agriculture buffs, but that's beside the point.)
Now Rudolph W. Giuliani's political ads are getting into the Christmas spirit, just like Mike Huckabee.
With a little less than three weeks left until the first in the nation New Hampshire primary be sure to check The Caucus in the morning for an update on all the happenings in the Granite State.

The Lede is following the fire at the Eisenhower Executive Office Building in Washington with frequent updates during the day, in chronological order -- scroll to the bottom of the post for the latest additions.

A half-dozen vineyards have started up in Thailand in recent years, part of the global trend to make wine at non-traditional latitudes. Most of the Thai wine, to be honest, is plonk. But one exception is Chateau de Loei, located on a plateau near the border with Laos. Their best wines are not bargains - upwards of $20 - but they're very drinkable.

Last-minute Christmas shoppers in Bangkok can pick up beautiful silk scarves, home-made jewelry, mulberry-paper greeting cards, cutlery, artisanal soaps, lotions, locally grown tea and coffee, pottery, and lots more handicrafts at the Ambassador Hotel (Sukhumvit Soi 11) on Saturday, Dec 22. The craft fair, which runs from 10am to 2pm, works on the fair-trade concept, only selling things made by Thai artisans; 70 percent of sales revenue goes directly to the people who made the handicrafts.

The FutureGen Alliance finally announced the site of what would be America's first utility-scale zero-emissions coal-powered electrical plant. But there are those who doubt that this magic bullet will ever work.

The FutureGen Alliance -- a partnership of coal producers and users and government -- yesterday announced the Illinois site of what would be America's first utility-scale zero-emissions coal-powered electrical plant. The plant will also, in theory, produce a stream of pure hydrogen fuel and a stream of carbon dioxide in a form ready to pump into the earth for long-term storage so it doesn't heat the climate.

Most political prognosticators have reduced the Iowa caucuses to a two-person field in both parties: Hillary Clinton vs. Barack Obama and Mike Huckabee vs. Mitt Romney. But The Des Moines Register's David Yepsen says it's a mistake to write off John Edwards and Fred Thompson.
From Keith Bradsher, DealBook's colleague in Hong Kong:

These coaches have been going about this whole quitting thing all wrong. Spencer Hall, who is the mind behind Every Day Should Be Saturday, uses his Sporting News column as a forum to dispense educational information about how to correctly leave a coaching job.

For several decades now the chef Peter Hoffman has been a fixture of the downtown dining scene, and he championed a farm-fresh, seasonal approach to cooking and menus before it was a gospel as widely preached -- and a religion as enthusiastically practiced -- as it is today.

I've been alerted to an interesting Boston Globe article about Barack Obama's role, when he was in the Illinois legislature, in the attempt to get the state committed to universal health care. It turns out that the story very much prefigures the debates we're having right now.

Remember the post-9/11 Oscars, when the gowns, the glitter and the gaiety seemed a little beside the point? Salon does, and though Los Angeles is not reeling from a terrorist outrage, it is going to be a bit weird for the place to get its party on, given the pall hanging over the town, which seems to part only for verbal flamethrowing.

Tom O'Neil of The Envelope tells The Associated Press that the writers' strike during awards season may reveal a dark industry secret: "We may finally find out how vapid and empty these stars really are."
Who can make jokes about bongs and erections seem tenderhearted?

David Hudson at GreenCineDaily, who loves movies and all the writing about movies, has come to realize that "The Lives of Others," the drama about the last days of East Germany, is fatally flawed. He ought to know because, it turns out, Mr. Hudson lives in Berlin. And the Bagger thought covering movies from Jersey was tough.
The Second Avenue Deli relocates to the edge of Murray Hill, while a new sake shop, Sakaya, opens its doors in the East Village.

In these final stages of the campaigns in Iowa, some of the candidates have retooled their styles and their speeches on the stump. The Times's Adam Nagourney examines John Edwards's closing argument to Iowa's caucusgoers, voters who know him well.

Every year, the Bagger develops an awards season crush. This time around he's got one on SpoutBlog, which never fails to freak out and amaze him when he gives it a click. Take, for instance, what the blog sees as the scariest thing about "Sweeney."

David M. Rubenstein, chief of the private equity firm Carlyle Group, did some serious holiday shopping on Tuesday -- but he won't be taking his purchase, a 710-year-old copy of the Magna Carta, home with him. Though Mr. Rubenstein won the auction for the document with a $19 million bid ($21.3 million with fees and commissions), he told reporters he was just a "temporary custodian" of the historic piece of parchment, which David Redden, Sotheby's vice chairman, called "the most important document in the world, the birth certificate of freedom."

Ralph Cioffi, the manager of Bear Stearns hedge funds that invested in subprime mortgages, has left the firm as U.S. prosecutors investigate whether he withdrew money from two funds before they collapsed in July, according to Bloomberg News.
Silver Lake Partners has agreed to acquire a quarter of the Gerson Lehrman Group, the upstart Wall Street research firm that has come under scrutiny from regulators, according to The New York Times.

Morgan Stanley posted a fourth-quarter loss, its first-ever quarterly loss, after taking an additional $5.7 billion write-down related to subprime mortgages. The investment bank said it would sell a $5 billion stake to the China Investment Corporation, that country's sovereign wealth fund, to shore up its capital.
Goldman Sachs did it again. Now the question is whether the Wall Street bank can do it again and again.
NetSuite's hotly anticipated initial public offering just keeps getting hotter.

Once part of the sprawling Nabisco cookie complex, the eight-story red-brick building at 450 East 15th Street, just east of 10th Avenue in the meatpacking district of Manhattan, is the epitome of understated warehouse chic, with polished concrete floors and century-old brick walls and frosted windows.

Maybe Wall Street analysts are more honest and less compromised than they were pre-Sarbanes-Oxley, but recent events show that they're still awful at their most important job: predicting bad news, writes Fortune's Geoff Colvin.
British aerospace company Cobham said it had agreed to buy BAE Systems's Pennsylvania-based Surveillance and Attack business unit for $240 million.

Officials from Merrill Lynch, Bear Stearns and other major banks are in talks to bail out a struggling bond insurance company that has guaranteed $26 billion in mortgage securities, according to The New York Times, because the insurer's woes could force the banks to take on billions in losses they had insured against.

Stephen Feinberg, the famously reclusive founder of hedge fund and private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, faced a grilling Tuesday over his decision to pull out of the $7 billion takeover of United Rentals during the first day of trial in the court battle.
Hedge fund Eton Park Capital Management has raised its stake in Goodyear Tire & Rubber to 7.7 percent.

Microsoft, Oracle, I.B.M. and a host of private equity firms helped drive technology mergers and acquisitions to a fourth consecutive record year in 2007. The introduction to The 451 Group's Technology M&A Outlook report lists the year's significant deals, identifies M&A drivers and looks at the outlook for 2008.

Shares in Cadbury Schweppes rose on Tuesday as Nelson Peltz, the activist shareholder, urged a faster rate of change as he warned the British company's sweets and drinks units may become takeover targets.
Distressed and special situations hedge fund firm Harbinger Capital Partners has taken a stake in a struggling media company with a warning to management that it may clean shop.
Internet broadcast start-up Ustream.TV said Tuesday that it completed a $2 million angel round and that former Democratic presidential candidate Wesley Clark joined its board.

Cardiac Dimensions said Tuesday that it has raised $35.5 million in venture capital financing, money it will use for clinical trials for a device that repairs the mitral valve in patients suffering from congestive heart failure.
Milestone AV Technologies postponed plans on Tuesday for an initial public offering because of unfavorable market conditions, an underwriter said.

Tribune executives were sweating out aggressive last-minute questioning Tuesday from bankers reluctant to fund the final portion of a debt-laden $8.2 billion deal to take the company private with Chicago billionaire Samuel Zell, The Chicago Tribune reported.

A coalition opposing Google's $3.1 billion merger with DoubleClick renewed charges of conflicts and threatened possible legal action over a decision by a regulatory chairman not to recuse herself from reviewing the merger.

Seventeen months after filing for an initial stock offering that it never completed, Applied Precision said it had dropped its I.P.O. plans and has sold its semiconductor test-instrumentation business to Rudolph Technologies.

Vivendi's SFR wireless phone unit is in talks with the other main shareholder in Neuf Cegetel in what investors said could be a 5 billion euro ($7.2 billion) purchase of the second-largest fixed-line phone company in France.
Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen has applied to bid in an upcoming U.S. auction of coveted wireless airwaves, according to auction documents released late Tuesday.

The Federal Communications Commission approved two new rules on Tuesday that are likely to reshape the nation's media landscape by setting new parameters for the size and scope of the largest news and cable companies.

The European Central Bank on Tuesday pumped 348 billion euros ($500 billion) into the financial system, easing conditions in credit markets grappling with a global lending squeeze linked to the United States housing downturn and traditional year-end demands for cash.
Accel-KKR said Tuesday that it boosted its stake in iTradeNetwork, a vendor of software for food suppliers, by buying out founding shareholders in a deal of undisclosed size.
Federal prosecutors charged the former outside counsel for the bankrupt commodities brokerage firm Refco on Tuesday with fraud tied to the eventual collapse of the commodities and futures brokerage.
Deutsche Bank has agreed to pay creditors of Enron, the energy trading company, $25 million to settle a lawsuit related to transactions between the companies, Enron said on Tuesday.

Level 3 Communications on Wednesday said it will sell the advertising distribution business of Vyvx to DG FastChannel. Vyvx is a wholly owned subsidiary of Level 3. Under the terms of the deal, Level 3 will receive $129 million payable in cash.

Harmony Gold Mining, Africa's third-largest gold producer, agreed to form a venture and sell a stake in assets including its Cooke uranium ore dump in South Africa to Pamodzi Resources Fund for $252 million.

But a onetime "Pushcart King" is fighting back on behalf of Vietnam vets. Read more.

“Among the many paradoxes of Potomac Land is that it is, ostensibly, the capital of the most egalitarian people on the planet, and yet it has embraced a status system that is both hierarchical and byzantine.”
Spanish real estate giant Inmobiliaria Colonial is in discussions to merge with Gecina, the French property company.
Franklin Getchell

'Tis the season -- when your boss at the newspaper tells you not to use cliches like that. And when the last remaining pieces of the N.F.L.'s playoff tournament are falling into place. For one thing, the Patriots have wrapped up home-field advantage, but is that really going to help them? The N.F.C.'s division titles are locked up, but four teams (Giants, Vikings, Redskins and Saints) remain in the running for the two wild-card spots. The Vikings (8-6) are the team with the hot hand. They have won five in a row (and have the tie breaker over the 9-5 Giants, if it should come to that.) There is less suspense in the A.F.C., where four teams (Steelers, Jaguars, Browns and Titans) are vying for three spots. Incredibly, the Chargers (9-5), who started the season 1-4, have already clinched a spot and it's the Steelers (9-5) who might have to win out to make the playoffs.
Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic contributed to this notebook.
Fred D. Thompson's "hands down" moment in the Des Moines Register Republican debate last week is still resonating throughout his campaign, and keeps popping up on his bus tour this week.
Frank Bruni revisits One if by Land, Two if by Sea in Greenwich Village and Peter Meehan stops by Radegast Hall and Biergarten in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
A business course on cutthroat capitalism disguised as a slacker comedy: That’s the kindest way to describe Michael Lehmann’s “Flakes.”
The Hungarian cartoon feature “The District!” is a last-minute shoo-in for the title of 2007’s most original animated film.
Six books that have much to say to wine lovers.
The Bush administration said it will deny California’s bid to set stricter vehicle emissions standards than federal law required.
The business software company surpassed Wall Street’s projections as the company reported a sharp rise in new software licenses.
The software maker said that quarterly profit rose 35 percent as new software sales soared 38 percent.
By 352 to 64, the House voted to shield about 21 million  Americans from being hit by the alternative minimum tax.
The man who just paid $21.3 million for a 710-year-old copy of the Magna Carta says he wants to keep the copy on display in the United States.
President Bush signed off on a plan that will keep more troops than previously envisioned in Europe and add large numbers of soldiers to bases in Colorado, Georgia and Texas.
The number of flights per hour at Kennedy and Newark will be capped at peak times in an effort to ease congestion.
President Bush’s nominee to be the second-ranking official at the Justice Department refused to say whether he considered the interrogation technique to be “torture.”
In Iowa and New Hampshire, Mitt Romney is subtly shifting away from the more ideological frame that has often times been at the forefront of the campaign.
The Federal Reserve said that it had collected 93 bids on $20 billion in 28-day loans in its first auction of short-term credit.
Dennis J. FitzSimons will step down as chairman and chief executive of Tribune Company as soon as an $8.2 billion takeover deal is completed, the company said.
The move by Standard & Poor’s could force Merrill Lynch, CIBC and other investment banks to write down the value of securities they had bought insurance on by billions of dollars.
The Bush administration said that it had not misled the public about the role of White House lawyers in discussions on whether to destroy interrogation tapes.
The bank said it would sell a $5 billion stake to China’s sovereign wealth fund as it posted a loss after taking a $5.7 billion write-down.
As South Koreans headed to the polls for their country’s presidential election on Wednesday, voters appeared ready to choose Lee Myung-bak, a pro-business candidate.
For the Nets, which fumbled away chances to win in the fourth quarter, the loss was their sixth in seven games and their 10th in 15 games at home.
A 710-year-old copy of the declaration of human rights known as the Magna Carta — the version that became part of English law — was auctioned Tuesday for $21.3 million.
Russell Robinson scored 17 points, becoming the seventh different leading scorer for Kansas in 11 games, and the Jayhawks remained unbeaten with a 71-66 win at Georgia Tech.
Jason Spezza scored two goals to lead the visiting Ottawa Senators to their sixth straight win, 3-2 over the Boston Bruins on Tuesday in a matchup of the Eastern Conference’s top two teams.
The Rangers used Tuesday night’s game to find some missing chemistry and a new top line combination, and to rediscover the kind of defense that carried them earlier this season.
An illustration with the Mind column in Science Times on Tuesday, about seasonal affective disorder, carried an incorrect credit. The artist was Ward Schumaker, not Vivienne Flesher.

An article on Tuesday about the House’s passage of a budget bill misstated the amount approved for two programs. The legislation provides $602 million, not billion, for agricultural drought relief; and $195 million, not billion, for repair of the collapsed highway bridge in Minneapolis.

Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Dec. 11 about the effort to develop a malaria vaccine using live mosquito parasites misstated the timing of research into the mosquito genome. It was decoded in 2002, along with that of the parasite that causes malaria — not “in the ’80s.”.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the laws of physics and nature misstated the time in which Plato was forming his idea of a higher realm of ideal forms. It was in the fourth century B.C.; it was not “a few hundred years” after the fifth century B.C., when the Greek mathematician and philosopher Pythagoras and his followers proclaimed that nature was numbers.
Sasha Vujucic scored 19 points and Lamar Odom added 17 points and 16 rebounds as the Los Angeles Lakers beat the host Chicago Bulls, 103-91, on Tuesday night.

An article on Saturday about the gubernatorial plans of Ronnie Earle, the longtime Democratic district attorney of Travis County, Texas, misstated the year of the next election for the Senate seat held by Kay Bailey Hutchison, who could be the Republican opponent of Mr. Earle in the 2010 governor’s race. The Senate election is in 2012, not 2010.

The software maker Platform Solutions filed a complaint with the European Commission accusing I.B.M. of abusing its market dominance by refusing to share information related to its high-performance mainframe computers. The complaint by Platform Solutions is the latest in a tit-for-tat series of legal moves by the two companies. Platform Solutions accused I.B.M. of violating a prohibition on abuse of market dominance by refusing to supply interface information relating to mainframe computers and refusing to license third parties, a commission spokesman, Jonathan Todd, said in a statement. The commission is in the preliminary stages of examining the complaint. I.B.M., the technology services company based in Armonk, N.Y., said it was confident that the commission would reject the claim.

The South African media group Naspers agreed to acquire Tradus, which operates the largest online auction trader in Poland, for £946 million, or $1.9 billion, adding to its Internet businesses in emerging markets like Eastern Europe. The deal extends Naspers’s reach as it seeks to diversify its revenue, largely dependent on newspapers and magazines. Tradus, based in London, has online auction businesses in Eastern Europe, specifically in the Czech Republic, Bulgaria, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia — and beyond, to Ukraine and Russia.

Cheaper new cars, a result of the surging Canadian dollar, lowered Canada’s core inflation rate last month, Statistics Canada reported. The core portion of the country’s consumer price index, which excludes volatile items like gasoline and mortgage interest, was 1.6 percent in November, compared with 1.8 percent in October. The agency attributed that unexpected decline to a 3.9 percent drop in new car prices and lease rates. Canada’s overall inflation rate grew slightly in November to 2.5 percent, compared with 2.4 percent in October. Much of that was attributed to a 17.6 percent increase in gasoline prices.

A federal judge blocked enforcement of a state law that prevents people from registering to vote if officials cannot match their Social Security or driver’s license numbers to federal or state databases. With six weeks before Florida’s presidential primary, Judge Stephan P. Mickle of Federal District Court in Tallahassee issued a temporary injunction against the law, which is meant to prevent election fraud. “The court recognized that this law is in direct conflict with federal laws designed after the 2000 election debacle to make sure every eligible citizen can have their vote counted,” said Justin Levitt, a lawyer for the plaintiffs who is with the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University. Secretary of State Kurt Browning said he would immediately appeal the injunction.

A top investigator in the internal affairs office of the Citizenship and Immigration Services has been convicted of harboring an illegal immigrant who was his girlfriend. The investigator, Lloyd W. Miner, 49, of Centreville, was convicted by a jury at the federal courthouse in Alexandria. He faces a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison. His girlfriend, originally from Mongolia, was also convicted of conspiracy to commit identification fraud. At the time of his arrest this year, Mr. Miner was the assistant chief of internal affairs investigations for Citizenship and Immigration Services, part of the Department of Homeland Security.
Federal health officials said they were investigating dozens of blood infections in at least two states that have been linked to contaminated medical syringes.

Lawyers have asked the United States Supreme Court to hear the case of a teenager sentenced to 30 years in prison for killing his grandparents when he was 12, arguing that the sentence is cruel. The boy, Christopher Pittman, left, shot his grandparents, Joe and Joy Pittman, with a shotgun in 2001, then set fire to their home in Chester County. In his trial four years later, his lawyers unsuccessfully argued that the killings were influenced by the antidepressant Zoloft, a charge that the maker of the drug vigorously denied. In their brief, lawyers from the University of Texas School of Law argued that the 30-year sentence violates Mr. Pittman’s Eighth Amendment protection from cruel and unusual punishment.

Three current and former Duke lacrosse players, but not the ones indicted in a discredited rape case, sued the university, a disgraced prosecutor and dozens of others, claiming that the prosecution damaged them, too. The players, Ryan McFadyen, Matthew Wilson and Breck Archer, accuse the defendants of pursuing the case despite evidence that the accusations were false. The 389-page lawsuit, filed in Federal Court in Greensboro, names 45 defendants, including Michael B. Nifong, the former Durham County district attorney who was disbarred for misconduct in the case; police investigators; city officials; and nurses who examined the accuser. They seek unspecified damages.
The Supreme Court on Tuesday struck down a law that had appeared to guarantee all seats in the country’s Parliament to the president’s party.
Closing arguments were heard in the case of John. H. White, a black man on trial for manslaughter in the shooting of a white teenager.
Yulia Tymoshenko, who helped lead the street protests that overturned a rigged presidential election three years ago, was narrowly approved by Parliament to be prime minister.
The General Assembly passed, 104 to 54 with 29 abstentions, a nonbinding resolution calling for a moratorium on the death penalty.
Congress legalized gay civil unions in the first nationwide law of its kind in Latin America.
President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela confirmed that he had received a statement from the Colombian rebel group, FARC, saying it would release three hostages to him or whomever he chooses.
Suspected drug traffickers shot at a helicopter carrying a Santa Claus to a Rio de Janeiro slum to distribute toys.
Mad cow disease has been confirmed in a 13-year-old beef cow from Alberta, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency said.
Two actors were shot dead while filming a crime drama on the streets of a crime-ridden suburb of the capital, Luanda.
A crowded passenger train derailed near southern Mehrabpur, killing at least 50 people and injuring dozens more.
An appeals court in Genoa ruled that a couple could not name their son Friday, because it recalled the native servant in Daniel Defoe’s “Robinson Crusoe.”
At least four top White House lawyers took part in discussions with the C.I.A. about whether to destroy videotapes showing the secret interrogations of two Qaeda operatives.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer may bring aboard a prominent financier and Democratic donor to help expand the governor’s relationships with business and labor groups.
The Federal Communications Commission set new rules regulating the size and scope of the news and cable firms.
Under an agreement to be unveiled on Wednesday, New Jersey will offer low-cost health coverage for the children of families who lack insurance but who earn too much for government help.
Senator John McCain said that he would consider greater federal intervention to limit the fallout of the mortgage crisis if current measures fail.
The Iraqi government has made little headway in improving the delivery of electricity, health care and other essential services, a new Pentagon report said.
Walter H. G. Lewin, a physics professor at M.I.T., has found devotees across the country with his online lectures.
While trying to shove a bad bill on electronic spying through the Senate, Majority Leader Harry Reid ended up doing the country a favor.
Governors and legislators ought to be ashamed if their flagship public universities charge more than a high-priced private school like Harvard.
The insurance industry planned to propose a series of steps the companies say would let more individuals obtain coverage.
While New England is 14-0, they are a mere mortal 10-4 against the point spread and, believe it or not, are in a slump.
The money for the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan was added to a sweeping year-end budget bill.
A reputation for fiscal responsibility that got Chriss W. Street elected as the Orange County treasurer is being called into question.
Almost half of the states may have to choose in the years ahead between their pension obligations and other public programs.
Anthony Rumore, the former president of a New York area Teamsters local was arrested on Tuesday on charges that he forced his union members to do work for him personally.
The new rules would force companies to show that customers can realistically afford their mortgages.
Daria Schulha Kira, now 85 and living in an apartment on East Houston Street in Manhattan, lived through one of the worst periods of Stalin’s brutal reign in the Soviet Union.
The 42 executions recorded in 2007 are the fewest since 1994, when there were 31, according to the Death Penalty Information Center, which compiled the report and released it Tuesday.

A state judge on Tuesday denied bail for Natavia S. Lowery, a personal assistant accused of killing her boss, Linda Stein, a real estate broker and former punk rock manager, in Ms. Stein’s Fifth Avenue apartment in October.
Responding to concerns in the food industry, companies developing cloned livestock have come up with a system to track the animals as they move through farms and slaughterhouses.
The legal effort to block what is widely considered the nation’s toughest law against employers who hire illegal immigrants may be headed for a setback.
Voters on Wednesday appeared ready to choose Lee Myung-bak, a pro-business candidate identified with the nation’s economic growth but bedeviled by corruption charges.
This week’s international pledging conference to aid the Palestinian Authority was a huge success. But it will need to be matched by diplomatic progress.
Mr. Smith was half of the R&B duo the Checkmates.
The Yankees formally fired David Szen, their former traveling secretary, on Tuesday after Szen pleaded guilty in United States District Court to filing a false federal income tax return.
New Jersey authorities broke up a partnership between the Luchese crime family and the Bloods street gang that supplied drugs and cellphones to gang members inside a New Jersey prison.
John Edwards’s closing argument may be working in Iowa, but his sharp message has barely a whisper of the optimism he exhibited in 2004.
Baltimore Orioles second baseman Brian Roberts has acknowledged using steroids, but insisted he tried it only once before he realized he had made a “terrible decision.”
A 25-year-old woman and her 6-year-old daughter were found dead in their Bronx apartment Tuesday after friends and relatives grew concerned about their absence.
A review by the Colorado secretary of state left elections officials scrambling to find viable machines in time for next year’s voting.
Nick Clegg narrowly beat his fellow former European lawmaker, Chris Huhne, to lead the third-ranked party, which fiercely opposed the Iraq war.
A newborn girl who was found crying in a commercial trash bin in Queens on Monday night was in stable condition Tuesday.
Mr. Morgan was a jazz saxophonist whose promising career was derailed by drug problems in the 1950s, but had a triumphant comeback 30 years later, which led to an unexpected taste of midlife stardom.
After robbing banks in the same area in quick succession, Orlando Taylor, 26, was captured when he tried to commit his fifth robbery in five days.
Silver Lake Partners has agreed to acquire a quarter of the Gerson Lehrman Group, the upstart Wall Street research firm that has come under scrutiny from regulators.

BALL--Leo. A trumpeter who graced the New York music scene for half a century died of cancer, December 15, age 80. Raised in Brockton, MA, and a World War II Navy veteran, Leo played with the Xavier Cogat, Perez Prado, Billy May and Paul Anka. He also performed in theaters, studios, jazz clubs (Birdland was his favorite hangout) and other venues, until just before his death. In addition, he had been a musical contractor and administered payroll services for Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians since 1990. Survivors include three children, Dr. Joanna Ball of Yonkers, NY; Sondra Sherman of St. Augustine, FL; and Ben Orchart of Glendale, CA; five grandchildren; former wife Nancy Marano of Fort Lee, NJ; and brother Charles, and his wife Harriet, of Brockton. Sons Ronald and Donald Ball predeceased him. Memorial service at ''The Riverside'' at 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Friday, December 21, at 2:15pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Local 802 Emergency Relief Fund, Local 802 AFM, 322 W. 48th St., NY, NY 10036.
STOLZER--Mildred, passed on December 16, at age 95. Loving aunt and great-aunt. Services private.

RADIN--Helen, born December 7, 1933 in NYC, who made all feel welcome in her home and heart, passed suddenly on December 13, 2007. Helen produced documentary films for 35 years. In 1995, she became head of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun's Rabbinic Office. She was a dedicated single mother to two adopted daughters, one of whom she adopted from Bangkok in 1976. Helen is survived by her daughters Jennifer and Jessica; sons-in-law Sanjay Puri and Simeon Fishman; sisters Vivian Salit and Lita Stein; grandchildren Olivia and Aidan Puri.

An obituary on Friday about the ethnomusicologist Henrietta Yurchenco misstated the given name of her former husband. He was Basil Yurchenco, not Boris.

MCQUATTERS--Eugenia. She's a single woman of 103, the last of a loving family of three brothers and three sisters, survived by many nieces and nephews. Born July 14, 1904, passed away Monday, December 10th, 2007 in her home in Manhattan, NY, of colon cancer. She graduated from the University of Southern California. In 1936 she was appointed to the Foreign Service of the Department of State and was sent to Warsaw, Poland. She was confidential secretary to Ambassador A.J. Drexel Biddle, Jr., at which time she continued to work at different appointments with Mr. Biddle until her retirement from Foreign Service. In 1950 she was employed by Mrs. Biddle, former wife of Mr. Biddle, and moved to New York and continued working for Mrs. Biddle until her death in 1956. Memorial service to be held at St. James Church, Madison Ave. and 71st St., after the first of the year. Contributions can be made to the Church or to a charity.

President Bush has approved ''a significant reduction'' in the nation's nuclear weapons stockpile, cutting it to less than one-quarter its size at the end of the cold war, the White House said Tuesday. At the same time, the Energy Department announced plans to consolidate the nuclear weapons complex that maintains warheads and dismantle those no longer needed, saying the complex needs to be made more efficient and more easily secured.

KULICKE--Robert M. The Jewelry Arts Institute celebrates the life of Robert M. Kulicke, whose vision created the school and inspired a generation of goldsmiths. We thank you, Bob. Bessie Jamieson and Staff

TOLLING--Dr. Sven T., 63, passed on December 15th, 2007, in Sweden. His career in Veterinary medicine spanned 36 years, working on pivotal issues concerning animal health, including many years at Pfizer Inc., New York, and as the chairman of the Swedish Equestrian Federation. He was awarded Doctor h.c. at the University of Agricultural Sciences, Uppsala, Sweden in 1999. He touched the lives of many and is remembered as a generous, compassionate, vibrant, and gifted man. Always a passionate advocate of what is righteous and ethical, he will be remembered as a strong leader with a devotion to making a difference. He will be forever in the hearts and memories of his family: his wife, Dr. Kerstin Thoren-Tolling, his son Nils G. Tolling, his daughter-in-law Mina Konishi, and his brother Hans Tolling, with his family as well as many friends and colleagues. Services will be held in Sweden on January 8th. A Memorial Service will be held in Westport, Connecticut, in February. For information, please email: nils@tolling.org

An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the publisher Scholastic's plans for a series of books that it hopes will be its follow-up to the blockbuster Harry Potter series referred incompletely to the involvement of the writer Peter Lerangis in two earlier series. Mr. Lerangis, who is to write the third book in this new series, created the Spy-X and the Watcher series and wrote all the books in them; he has not merely written books in those series.

Dancer Wins Case Against Accuser For making false allegations and seeking to extort money, the woman who accused the dancer Michael Flatley of sexual assault has been ordered to pay him $11 million, The Associated Press reported. In Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Michael L. Stern ruled that the woman, Tyna Marie Robertson, a real estate agent, had defamed and inflicted emotional distress on Mr. Flatley, who starred in ''Riverdance'' and ''Lord of the Dance.'' Ms. Robertson accused Mr. Flatley of raping her in a Las Vegas hotel in 2002 and threatened to sue unless he agreed to a ''seven figures'' settlement. The police declined to bring criminal charges against the dancer, who said the sex was consensual. She then sued him for $33 million, alleging sexual assault. The suit was dismissed. Mr. Flatley responded with a lawsuit against Ms. Robertson and her lawyer D. Dean Mauro. The Supreme Court of California ruled in July 2006 that Mr. Mauro committed extortion; he settled by making ''a substantial payment'' to Mr. Flatley, according to the dancer's lawyer, Richard P. Cestero.

COMBEMALE--Pamela Woolworth, of Monmouth, ME, died peacefully at home with family at her side on Sunday, December 16, 2007. A prominent socialite and cofounder of Dragon films with Douglas Fairbanks, Jr., Mrs. Combemale maintained homes in New York City, Paris and Bailleul, France, Monmouth, Maine, and Port Antonio, Jamaica. Mrs. Combemale is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Pamela and Paul Murphy, of Buenos Aires, Argentina, a son and daughter-in-law, Christopher and Magdalene Combemale of London, England, a daughter and son-inlaw, Natalie and William Matt of Columbus, OH, and a son and daughter-in-law, Nicolas and Eve Combemale of Bridgehampton, NY, the father of her children, Bernard Combemale of Normandy, France, a brother, Robert Frederick Woolworth of Monmouth, ME, and thirteen grandchildren, Sumner, Delphine and Elektra Murphy, Mallory and Christopher Combemale, William, Sebastian, Eliza, Charlotte and Sophie Matt, and Olivia, Ian and Cecilia Combemale. A memorial and burial service will be held at the Velma Woolworth Chapel at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY, on Saturday, December 22, at 11am. Contributions in memory of Mrs. Combemale may be made to the Monmouth Museum, 749 Main St, Monmouth, ME 04259 or the Theater at Monmouth, P.O. Box 385, Monmouth, ME 04259. Services are in the care of Roberts Funeral Home, 62 Bowden St., Winthrop, Maine 04330. www.khrfuneralhomes.com

HERMANN--Sister Marie (Sr. Marie de Lourdes), died on December 17, 2007 at 80. She was born in Brooklyn, NY. She was a Sister of the Good Shepherd for 50 years. She was a chaplain in prison ministry in NYC. Funeral services are with Fitzgerald & Collins in Marlboro, MA.

Hauser Chocolatier of Westerly, R.I., whose Chinese black vinegar truffles had me hooked three years ago, has now introduced blueberry port wine truffles. They are filled with a ganache made with a blueberry port that Lucille and Ruedi Hauser Sr., the company's founders, discovered on the North Fork of Long Island last summer. The truffles are enrobed in semisweet chocolate, 64 percent cacao, and dusted with dried blueberries for a delectable after-dinner nibble. A four-ounce box (nine truffles) is $12.75 at the company's shops in Bethel, Conn., and in Westerly, and from (888) 599-8231 and hauserchocolates.com.

Arsenal and Tottenham survived red cards Tuesday to reach the semifinal of the League Cup, with the Gunners winning by 3-2 at Blackburn and Spurs by 2-0 at Manchester City. Arsenal played the 30 minutes of extra time with 10 men after the Brazilian midfielder Denilson was sent off in the 90th minute. But Eduardo da Silva scored his second goal of the game as the Gunners reached the semifinals for the fourth time in five years. Tottenham's Didier Zokora was ejected after 20 minutes, but goals by Jermain Defoe (fifth minute) and Steed Malbranque (82nd) ended City's streak of 10 consecutive league and Cup home victories under Sven-Goran Eriksson.

REMY--Ronald A., M.D., age 71, of Jupiter, FL, (formerly of Cresskill and Loveladies NJ), on December 17, 2007 after a courageous battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Phyllis (nee Giering). Loving son of Rose (Florio) and the late Ramon. Devoted father of David and his wife Terri, John and his wife Christine. Adoring grandfather of Paul, Cecilia, Nicholas and Matthew. Dear brother of Russell and his wife Carol. Born in New York City and raised in Hoboken, Dr. Remy graduated from Rutgers University in 1958 and was first in his class upon graduating from NJ College of Medicine in 1962. Dr. Remy completed his surgical residency at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan where he had the honor of serving as Chief Resident in his fourth year. Dr. Remy served in the U.S. Navy in Vietnam (196768) receiving the Navy Commendation Medal with Combat V. He also served at St. Albans VA Hospital (1968-69). Dr. Remy practiced surgery at Holy Name Hospital, Teaneck, NJ, from 1969-1998 serving as Chief of Surgery (1986-1992) and Director of The Department of Surgery (1990-1996). His skill as a surgeon was matched only by his unflinching dedication to his patients and their families. After retirement he volunteered his surgical skills in Guyana, Haiti, Mexico and Guatemala, and other locations without access to surgery. When creating the surgical roster for his visits, Dr. Remy had one rule he never broke - children first. Dr. Remy was a Diplomat of the American Board of Surgery, Fellow of the American College of Surgeons, and a member of The Society of Surgeons of NJ. Dr. Remy was a man of many interests. He was well read, enjoyed fishing, sailing, hiking, golf, music, photography and practiced physical fitness. He was a lifelong Yankee's and Giants fan. He will be greatly missed by family and friends. Visitation is on Wednesday 79pm, and Thursday 2-4 and 79pm, at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ. Funeral Mass Friday, 10am, Mt. Carmel Church, Tenafly, NJ. Interment Brookside Cemetery, Englewood, NJ. Donations in Dr. Remys memory may be made to Calvary Hospital Fund, 1470 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461. For directions visit: www.barrettfuneralhome.net

An article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day last Wednesday about an ambitious commercial real estate project being built west of Chicago referred incorrectly to a company that was among those that built campuslike projects in the area in the 1970s and '80s. It was Amoco -- not British Petroleum, which Amoco merged with in the late '90s, ultimately to become BP.

An article on Saturday about the gubernatorial plans of Ronnie Earle, the longtime Democratic district attorney of Travis County, Texas, misstated the year of the next election for the Senate seat held by Kay Bailey Hutchison, who could be the Republican opponent of Mr. Earle in the 2010 governor's race. The Senate election is in 2012, not 2010.

VARTANIAN--Angel, of Medina, WA, formerly of Forest Hills, NY, died December 16, 2007. She and her son, Alvin, owned Rev2, a distinctive men's clothing store in Greenwich Village, for many years. An aficionado of linguistics and history, she enjoyed reading, traveling, and debating current events. Angel volunteered her time and resources to various local and national non-profit organizations. Her generosity and warmth of spirit will live on in the memories of all who knew her. Private services will be held Friday, December 21st, at Haven of Rest Cemetery, Gig Harbor, WA. In lieu of flowers, donations in Angel and Alvin's name can be made to Village Care of NY, 154 Christopher Street, NY, NY 10014, 212-337-5750. Joy, Errol, and Melanie Vartanian

The United States was drawn Tuesday to play Cuba, Panama and Honduras in its qualifying group for the men's tournament at next year's Olympics. The United States will play March 11, 13 and 15 at Tampa, Fla., in Group A of the qualifying tournament, which is for under-23 teams. Mexico will be joined by Canada, Guatemala and Haiti in Group B, which will be contested at Carson, Calif. The top two teams in each group advance to the semifinals in Nashville, on March 20, and the semifinal winners will represent the North and Central American and Caribbean region in the 16-nation field in Beijing.

GIANOPULOS--Mary Aristea (nee Hadzopoulous), passed peacefully at her home in Los Angeles, December 16, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Nicholas; adored mother of James, Despina and Peter; loved and loving grandmother of Mimi, Alexa, Niki and Sophia; and cherished mother-in-law of Ann Gianopulos (nee Thompson), Jay Landers and Christina Gianopulos (nee Liviakis). Mary was born in New York City, on April 30, 1925, to Demetrios, who arrived in New York in 1908, and Despina, who was raised and educated in a suburb of Constantinople, and came to America in 1923 as one of the heralded ''transport brides'' of that era. Active in Greek cultural and church activities throughout her youth and adult life, Mary wed Nicholas in 1951. She pursued a successful career in women's fashion in New York, working on many collections for the couture designer, Mary McFadden, taking time from her vacation to raise her three dear children to be immersed in the Greek culture and language. The children and grandchildren enjoy frequent trips to Greece, where their fluency in the language is a constant reminder of their mother's love and devotion. Mary retired in 1986, enojoying 10 years with her beloved husband before his passing. Mary moved to Los Angeles in 2003, where her greatest joy was derived from spending time with her adoring grandchildren, for whom she cooked in the Greek style, preparing their favorite dishes at ''Yiayia's'' house. Her warm presence, loving touch, embracing hospitality and her many kindnesses to family and friends will be missed, and cherished. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Thursday, December 19th, 6-9pm, 1076 Madiscon Avenue at 81st Street, New York, NY 10028. Telephone: 212-288-3500. Interment will be held at 12:30pm, Willow Hill Cemetary, Main Rd., Southold, NY 11971. 631765-3850. In lieu of flowers, or gifts, the family requests that donations be made to The Mary Gianopulos Memorial Fund, (Fund #

Amy Winehouse Is Arrested in London The singer Amy Winehouse was arrested on Tuesday as part of an investigation into ''perverting the course of justice,'' the London police said. Ms. Winehouse, 24, who recently canceled the rest of a tour after her husband was detained in an assault case, was arrested after reporting to the police, Agence-France Presse reported. The police gave no further details. Ms. Winehouse's husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, has been in custody for several weeks on charges of trying to pervert the course of justice in relation to an assault case. He is accused of assaulting the proprietor of a London pub in June last year, and was accused, with three other men, of later trying to bribe the landlord to drop the case and leave the country. Ms. Winehouse, recently nominated for six Grammys, is one the brightest stars of Britain, but has had a troubled year, including a hospital stay and confused and chaotic concert performances.

Lindsay Davenport's comeback will include representing the United States in the Fed Cup. Davenport, 31, a three-time Grand Slam singles champion, agreed to play for the United States team that faces Germany in the Fed Cup quarterfinals at La Jolla, Calif., on Feb. 2-3. Davenport, 31, did not play on the tour for nearly a year while she was having her first child, a son who was born in June. She returned to competition in August by playing doubles at New Haven, then went 13-1 the rest of the season at three singles tournaments, winning two titles.

de Seve--Paula M., 57, of East Hampton, NY, on December 15, 2007 of complications of lymphoma. She is survived by her husband Paul C. Ray, her daughter Allison, and siblings Nicholas, Roger, Gillian, Peter and Philip.

It has been just about two years since the Second Avenue Deli closed in a rent dispute, after 52 years in the East Village. It is now back in business, at the edge of Murray Hill. The second Second Avenue Deli is largely the work of Jeremy Lebewohl, 25, a son of Jack Lebewohl, who ran the restaurant after 1996 when his brother, Abe, was shot and killed on his way to make a bank deposit. The younger Mr. Lebewohl said he could not imagine the family without the deli, and to make rent disputes a thing of the past he and his brother, Joshua, 27, a lawyer, bought the current building. The restaurant is about half the size of the original and though the design is similar, it seems spiffier, with shiny white tile, a copper ceiling, glass dividers and contrasting dark wood trim. The menu has changed slightly, too, with the addition of smoked fish. The takeout counter is larger and there is a full bar, at which imbibers can munch on chicken cracklings, called gribenes, with fried onions. The restaurant is kosher, but not glatt. It is open around the clock, seven days a week: 162 East 33rd Street, (212) 689-9000.

The Miami defensive coordinator Tim Walton was fired by Coach Randy Shannon after the Hurricanes allowed more than 300 points this season for the first time since 1984. Shannon announced the firing Tuesday, a day after informing university officials of the decision. Shannon, who was promoted from defensive coordinator to head coach after the 2006 season, picked Walton to succeed him.

Anna Chakvetadze of Russia was tied up by masked robbers who broke into her home Tuesday and stole money and goods worth hundreds of thousands of dollars, her father said. Chakvetadze was bound for 30 minutes in her home outside Moscow but was not seriously hurt, NTV television reported. Six assailants approached the home before dawn, tied up a maid in another building and forced her to hand over a remote control enabling them to enter the house through the garage, Dzhamal Chakvetadze, Anna's father, told NTV.

50 Cent in Kosovo The rapper 50 Cent drew a crowd of thousands on Monday when he became the first high-profile artist to perform publicly in Kosovo, the breakaway Serbian province, The Associated Press reported. More than 25,000 tickets were snapped up for his concert in a soccer stadium in the capital, Pristina, where fans joined in his raps and fireworks illuminated the skyline. ''I came to entertain the world,'' 50 Cent told The Associated Press during his 10-hour visit, steering clear of Balkan politics and the question of whether Kosovo should become an independent country. ''It's not for me to decide; my job is to put on a great show,'' he said.

GOLDEN--Alice deWolfe, of Southbury, CT. January 3, 1912-December 16, 2007, widow of Eugene P. Golden. Beloved mother of Richard A. Golden, and three grandsons, Richard Alexander, Maximilian and Henryk (Harry). She was a unique woman who lived her life on her own terms and was intimately involved in the reconstruction of post war Europe, working for the U.S. government in Japan and Europe. Mass Wednesday, December 19th, at 10am at Sacred Heart Church, Southbury. Interment in St. Johns Cemetery, Queens, NY at 1pm.

In an age of gadgetry, what you have and use may provide some small insight into who you are. As part of a series about the personal tastes of the candidates, The Associated Press asked them to share their favorite electronic gadgets. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York, former Senator John Edwards of North Carolina and former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee all cited their iPods. But former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York not only likes his music old school -- he's a self-described opera fanatic -- he also likes it the old-fashioned way: He mentioned his CD player.

Are you up on your junmai daiginjo? Your namazake? Your genshu? At Sakaya, a new shop, these are among the 85 types of sake on hand. Rick Smith, who owns the simple cedar-paneled store with his wife, Hiroko Furukawa, is ready to explain and guide the neophyte as well as to discuss the fine points of the rice brew with the connoisseur. Mr. Smith will suggest food pairings and usually has a few sakes open for tasting. Prices range from $10 to $162.99 a bottle. His recommendation for an all-purpose sake is Dassai 50, or Otter Fest, a light, slightly fruity brew, $24.99 for 720 milliliters. The shop also has a few brands of shochu, a stronger spirit often made from rice: 324 East Ninth Street (First Avenue), (212) 505-7253.

A sports article on Tuesday about the successful girls basketball team at Sequoyah High, a small Oklahoma school, referred imprecisely to an accomplishment of Sequoyah, the Indian for whom the school was named. He is credited with creating the Cherokee syllabary or alphabet, not the language itself. A picture caption misstated, in some copies, the surname of a sister of the player Angel Goodrich, the first Division I athletic scholarship recipient in Sequoyah's history. She is Nikki Lewis, not Goodrich. (Nikki is a sophomore guard who is on college recruiters' radar.)

FED PROPOSES MORTGAGE RULES The Federal Reserve proposed restrictions on exotic mortgages and high-cost loans for consumers with weak credit. New rules would force lenders to show that customers can realistically afford their mortgages. The number of groundbreakings for new homes fell 3.7 percent in November, and economists said that they expected the housing market to worsen. [C7.]

Eugene Wilson's 5-yard interception return against the Jets on Sunday made him the 21st Patriots player to score a touchdown this season, tying the N.F.L. record shared by the 2000 Broncos and the 1987 Rams. Getting to 22 could be difficult, though, because every player on the Patriots' active roster who has gained at least a yard this season has already scored. The return by Wilson, near right, was the Patriots' sixth defensive touchdown. They have also scored twice on kick returns, each time by Ellis Hobbs.

LAPTOOK--Pauline, age 96, died December 17, 2007, in New York, NY. Beloved wife of the late Philip. Loving mother of Kenneth and Laura. Cherished mother-in-law of Robert and Diana. Adored and adoring grandmother of Jennifer (Steve), Alexandra (Justin), Eve and Julia. Proud great-grandmother of Emerson. She was the strong and loving center of our family. It turns out she was right about almost everything. Our heartfelt thanks and gratitude to Regina, Rachel, and Connie for their loving care. Funeral services Wednesday, December 19, 12pm, at George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Lecount Place, New Rochelle, 914-632-0324. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the national office of ORT America, 75 Maiden Lane, 10th Floor, New York, NY 10038.

Good News for NBC ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams'' was the top-rated evening newscast last week, beating ABC's ''World News With Charles Gibson'' by nearly half a million viewers, Nielsen Media Research reported. Mr. Gibson's evening newscast has attracted more total viewers than Mr. Williams's for much of the year. But NBC has bounced back in recent months, narrowly winning first place in the November sweeps. For the week, ''NBC Nightly News'' averaged 9.30 million viewers, while ''World News'' delivered 8.86 million and the ''CBS Evening News With Katie Couric'' recorded 6.82 million. In the demographic of adults 25 to 54, NBC averaged a 2.2 rating, ahead of ABC's 2.1 and CBS's 1.8. Last week's victory reflected NBC's largest lead over ABC so far this season, save for an unusual Thanksgiving ratings week. Meanwhile, two years after Howard Reig, the veteran announcer of ''NBC Nightly News,'' the newscast has a new voice for the ''from NBC News'' introduction: the actor Michael Douglas. His voice-over made its debut on Monday. BRIAN STELTER

The veteran striker Romário was suspended 120 days Tuesday for failing a doping test after a Brazilian league game two months ago. Members of Brazil's top sports tribunal voted, 3-2, to suspend Romário after he tested positive for the banned substance finasteride after Vasco's 2-2 draw against Palmeiras on Oct. 28. Romário, 41, who did not attend the hearing in Rio de Janeiro, said he had been using a medicine to prevent hair loss. Finasteride is the active ingredient in the anti-balding medication Propecia.

Cases of norovirus — commonly known as the stomach flu — have spiked in recent weeks, the city’s Health Department announced this morning. Emergency room visits for vomiting and diarrhea — the virus’s most common symptoms — have jumped to 500 a day from 300 a day in November.

Nearly two weeks after FreshDirect let go of scores of immigrant workers, political leaders, labor organizers and other supporters of the workers rallied outside the company’s warehouse and headquarters in Long Island City, Queens, this afternoon, accusing the company of ousting the workers to foil a coming unionization vote.

It’s not every day that a community rallies in support of a chain store. But that is what a group of Lower East Side and Chinatown residents did today, in support of the Pathmark at 227 Cherry Street. Call them YIMBY’s. Yes in my backyard.Of course, they are opposed to something — namely, the possibility that the supermarket will be sold for $250 million to make way for luxury condos. About 100 demonstrators armed with petitions gathered at the store, holding signs that read “Stop Gentrification!” and chanting, “$250 million for condos we can’t live in, that’s crazy!”
This must be the day for pre-holiday protests.

It was a quixotic open casting call made via e-mail: Have your moving silhouette, iPod-ad-style, be immortalized as part of an exhibition on online dating for the Museum of Modern Art in February. R.S.V.P. to a gmail address, then show up in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, with props for banal everyday activities like brushing your teeth, drinking water or reading a book. The filming of some 1,000 silhouettes images began today and continues Friday.The project, called “I Want You to Want Me” (not, apparently, named after the 1977 song by Cheap Trick), is a creation of Jonathan Harris and Sep Kamvar. The pair combined art, emotion and statistical combing of the Internet in their last project, “We Feel Fine,” which crawled blogs and online postings and aggregated statements about people’s emotional states. The new project is one of a handful commissioned by MoMA to be part of the “Design and the Elastic Mind” exhibition, an exploration of how disruptive technology has been incorporated into everyday lives. The show will be on view from Feb. 24 to May 12.

First she made bodysuits chic. Now Donna Karan is taking aim at portable USB drives... T's fashion editors were momentarily baffled this week when a chrome and rubber memory stick arrived in the mail from Donna Karan's publicists. Turns out it's a digital look book - a high-tech iteration of the runway-fashion flipbook that designers send to editors. The Donna PR team hails its gizmo as a paperless ecological breakthrough. All I know is it saves fashion assistants (like me) the hassle of Web surfing for digital images and alphabetizing the books. Like a good DVD, there's even bonus material: there are detail images, still lifes of shoes (love that) and even back-stage footage from the Spring '08 show. Next season, I'm hoping Donna will invent clothes that steam themselves.
