Pittsburgh (9-5) has a short week to deal with a disappointing loss to Jacksonville on Sunday. The Steelers suddenly find their division lead in jeopardy and are in a fight for playoff positioning. A game against St. Louis (3-11) would seem to be a nice break after tough losses to the Patriots and the Jaguars. But the Steelers' other three losses were on the road: to Arizona, Denver and the Jets, which all have losing records. Before allowing 117 yards to the Jets' Thomas Jones in Week 11, the Steelers had not allowed a 100-yard rusher in two years. But they allowed 147 yards to Fred Taylor last week as the Jaguars rushed for 224, and the Rams' Steven Jackson is coming off his best game of the season, with 143 yards against the Packers. This is the first time the Rams have played host to the Steelers since moving to St. Louis in 1995.

During my first few weeks in New York, the most striking surprise was that my New York friends, when emerging from the subway, always knew which direction was downtown. As if possessing the magnetic receptors of migratory birds, they'd stalk off in the correct direction without even a momentary pause at the top of the entrance stairs. This, it seemed to me, was the cultural inheritance of the native New Yorker.

Karl Rove's Campaign Reform: American presidential campaigns are both too long, too short and then too long again, Karl Rove (yes, that Karl Rove) suggests in The Wall Street Journal.

DES MOINES - Former Senator Bob Kerrey has apologized to Senator Barack Obama, praising his judgment and experience to serve as president. He said he did not intend to offend Mr. Obama or contribute to misinformation about his family's Muslim heritage.

The SAGS are in and "Hairspray" and "3:10 to Yuma" both get into the ensemble category. "There Will Be Blood" and "Sweeney Todd" don't make the cut. Read more on the Bagger's take on the nominations and how SAG tends to go its own way.
Countdown: 19 days until the primary.

Long live the Queen, indeed. Just past teatime in London today (or about 10 a.m. Eastern time), Elizabeth II will become the oldest monarch in Britain's history, surpassing Victoria, who was 81 years, 7 months and 29 days old when she died in 1901.
Elida Fernández, 53, is being treated for breast cancer. The Neediest Cases Fund helped to pay $500 towards the monthly cost of her medication.

After months of single-digit polling, Tom Tancredo, the Republican candidate who campaigned largely on an anti-immigration platform, will drop out of the presidential race during a news conference in Des Moines later today. The Denver Post examines the Colorado congressman's decision.

If you want to snack on something nutritious while awaiting the SAG announcements, head over to Awards Daily for some prefatory analytics. Among other insights/guesses, Sasha Stone, veteran awards seer, thinks that Daniel Day Lewis will get a nomination for "There Will Be Blood," and that he will likely go the distance and win all the best actor marbles at the Oscars. She also makes a pretty educated guess at the best ensemble performance nominees, which is SAG-speak for best picture:

Nothing like some data points to break through the strike-born gloom here at Bagger H.Q. At 9:00 a.m. E.S.T., the Screen Actors Guild will announce their nominees for the SAG Awards, which will give the Bagger and all his ninny friends a lot to chew on. For example:
Bear Stearns reported a steep loss for its fourth quarter, its first ever in its eight-decade history, as the investment bank was stung by the mortgage crisis that has swept markets across the globe.

Morgan Stanley portrayed Wednesday's decision to take a $5 billion infusion from China as a strategic move, and not a desperate act. Still, the announcement came as the firm reported the first quarterly loss in its 72-year history and as a joke about foreign investments was making the rounds on trading floors: "Shanghai, Dubai, Mumbai or goodbye."

Navistar International, an Illinois-based maker of trucks and diesel engines, is expected to announce Thursday that it is buying General Motors' medium-duty truck business, according to The New York Times.
Business software isn't the most glamorous of businesses, and December isn't the greatest time for initial public offerings -- but none of that seemed to matter to NetSuite.

Silicon Valley, the wellspring of the digital technologies fueling globalization, is itself a collection of remarkably local clusters based on industry niches, skills, school ties, traffic patterns, ethnic groups and even weekend sports teams, The New York Times says.
How do you know if a company you want to work for, or are already working for, is doing good things in the world? Here are a couple of new resources:
Southwest Airlines chief executive Gary Kelly doesn't have any offers out to buy another airline, but he expects Southwest to jump in when the consolidation fun begins.

Eaton, the world's second-largest maker of hydraulic equipment, will buy Moeller Group of Germany and Phoenixtec Power Company of Taiwan for about $2.8 billion as revenue growth in the United States slows.
Nissan Motor, Japan's third-largest carmaker, is in talks with Chrysler on a possible manufacturing agreement, Nissan's chief executive, Carlos Ghosn, said.
As hedge-fund analysts, Holden Karnofsky and Elie Hassenfeld made six-figure incomes deciding which companies to invest in. Now they are doing the same thing with charities, for a lot less pay.

A day before an $8.2 billion deal is expected to take Tribune private, Dennis J. FitzSimons said Wednesday that he would step down as chairman and chief executive as soon as the transaction was done, clearing the way for the real estate billionaire Samuel Zell to assume control of the media conglomerate.

Investment banks Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers are among the bidders for a stake in Japanese house builder Daito Trust Construction, which may lead to a multibillion-dollar buyout, Reuters reported.
A perfume's becoming a wild financial success seems to engender the assumption that it is inferior. This is snobbery.
The Blackstone Group is planning a $9 billion commercial mortgage-backed securities offering backed by Hilton Hotels next quarter, according to a Credit Suisse research note.
Barclays Bank accused Bear Stearns on Wednesday of loading one of its hedge funds with about $500 million in troubled assets just weeks before it and another Bear Stearns fund collapsed.

The Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that it had collected bids from 93 financial institutions in its first auction of short-term credit, a turnout that suggested banks might be more inclined to borrow from the Fed under its auction-based system.
Biffa, a British landfill operator and trash collector, said Wednesday that it's prepared to accept a proposed 1.22 billion-pound ($2.46 billion) takeover from Montagu Private Equity and HgCapital.
Shares of Umbro, the seller of soccer-related goods, rose Wednesday after a major shareholder said he may support Nike's 285 million pound ($569 million) bid for the company.
Verso Paper, which Apollo Management bought from International Paper last year for $1.4 billion, filed with regulators Thursday to raise as much as $345 million in an initial public offering.

Although companies now have a chance for the first time in the California stem-cell institute's three-year history to apply for a slice of its $3 billion pot, they may wind up having to share some of their revenue and research.

Euronext, the European stock exchange grouping of NYSE Euronext, plans to launch a private equity index early next year, to be published alongside its market benchmarks, a senior exchange official said Wednesday.

The late-night comedians may have made an early exit from the scene, but fortunately there was no shortage of political punch lines in 2007. From tapping toes and UFO encounters to prostitution scandals and $400 haircuts, it was a year in which politicians did their best to satirize themselves. As a salute to our nation's fine public servants, here's a look back at the year's most memorable feats and foibles. The envelopes, please.
French mobile operator SFR has agreed to buy Neuf Cegetel for around 2.05 billion euros ($2.95 billion) to bolster its investment capacity in high technology, notably fiber optics.

BSkyB, the British satellite broadcaster controlled by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, should cut its stake in broadcaster ITV to below 7.5 percent because it reduces competition in the TV market and works against the public interest, the British Competition Commission said Thursday.

The heavily funded Seattle mobile services company 3Guppies has lost the support of its primary venture backer, forcing it to cut a significant portion of its staff.

Following his efforts to break-up soft-drink maker and confectioner Cadbury Schweppes, Mr. Peltz is now reportedly eyeing a big slice of The Cheesecake Factory, the casual dining chain known for the eponymous dessert.
Akela Pharma said on Thursday it would not go ahead with its U.S. public offering, citing unfavorable market conditions for small and micro-cap companies.

The Federal Communications Commission on Wednesday approved the $16.4 billion buyout of satellite company Intelsat a group led by a London private equity firm, BC Partners.
Nanotechnology companies, nurtured on billions of dollars in government grants and venture investments through most of this decade, are getting ready to go public.

There's something in the air every December in the N.F.L., and it's not just playoff talk or calls for Matt Millen to be fired. It's blame. Sometimes it is being assigned, sometimes it is being accepted, but as three-quarters of the league's teams prepare to watch the playoffs instead of participating in them, it's about time fans in every city figure out whose fault it is.

The Bank of Japan kept interest rates steady on Thursday in its first unanimous decision since June, after a drop in business confidence signaled that companies were bracing for slower growth.

Boston Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling called on Roger Clemens to give up the four Cy Young Awards he won after 1997 if he cannot clear his name from allegations that he used steroids to prolong and enhance his career.
The mother of a veteran NASA astronaut who is now on board the International Space Station died Wednesday when her car was struck by a freight train in a Chicago suburb.
Chauncey Billups hit two free throws with one-tenth of a second left and the Detroit Pistons handed the Celtics their first home loss of the season, 87-85, Wednesday night in Boston.

Maxim Afinogenov scored with 2 minutes 17 seconds left in the third period, just as Buffalo’s sixth power play ended, and Ryan Miller made 42 saves to lift the Sabres to a 2-1 victory over the host Islanders on Wednesday night.

Tyler Hansbrough scored 27 points and showed no ill effects from a weekend concussion to help No. 1 North Carolina defeat visiting Nicholls State, 88-78, on Wednesday night.
Education officials released report cards on Wednesday for several charter schools, with the majority receiving A’s and B’s, but one school in Queens getting an F.

A pop music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about Ian Hunter, at the Music Hall of Williamsburg, misidentified the bass player in his Rant Band. He is Paul Page — not Graham Maby, who has played with Mr. Hunter.

An obituary on June 30, 2000, about Tobin Rote, a championship quarterback for the Detroit Lions in the 1950s, misstated his full name, referred incorrectly to a relative in the list of survivors and omitted the names of two others. He was Tobin Cornelius Rote Sr. — not Jr.

The subheading with a front-page headline on Wednesday for an article about discussions between four top White House lawyers and the Central Intelligence Agency over whether to destroy videotapes showing secret interrogations of members of Al Qaeda referred imprecisely to the White House’s position thus far on the matter. While Bush administration officials have acknowledged some discussions leading up to the destruction of the tapes in November 2005, as the article noted, the White House itself has not officially said anything on the subject, so its role was not “wider than it said.” (A related article appears today on Page A6.).

More than 60 Christian, Jewish and Muslim leaders have signed a call to the American government and the religious authorities in Iran to open direct negotiations and stop planning for war. The statement, “A Pax on Both Our Houses” (“pax” is Latin for “peace”) says the war in Iraq demonstrates how war wastes lives and resources, and violates human rights. The statement was released Wednesday in Des Moines, to remind the presidential candidates and reporters now crisscrossing Iowa that many religious constituencies are still focused on foreign policy, organizers said. The full text of the statement is available on interfaithpeacecommittee.org.

A front-page article last Thursday about a major confrontation between the Congolese Army and a renegade general that is increasing the risk of war in Congo and threatening to undermine the fledgling democratic state misidentified the country’s first democratically chosen government. It was the one that took power at independence in 1960; it is not the current government, in office for a year.

A Web site that rates lawyers the way Zagat rates restaurants, by number, is protected by the First Amendment, a federal judge in Seattle ruled Tuesday. Saying the ratings assigned by the Web site, Avvo, are opinions rather than facts, the judge, Robert S. Lasnik of Federal District Court, dismissed a lawsuit brought by two disgruntled lawyers, John Henry Browne and Alan J. Wenokur, who claimed their low rankings had cost them clients and money. “Rather than seeing the Avvo ratings for what they are — ‘that and $1.50 will get you a ride on Seattle’s new South Lake Union Streetcar’ — plaintiffs Brown and Wenokur want to make a federal case out of the number assigned to them,” Judge Lasnik wrote.

Congress passed a bill inspired by the Virginia Tech shootings that would more easily flag prospective gun buyers who have documented mental health problems. The measure would also help states with the cost. Passage by voice votes in the House and Senate came after months of negotiations between Senate Democrats and the lone Republican, Senator Tom Coburn of Oklahoma, who had objected. The measure would clarify what records should be reported to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System. The attorney general could penalize states if they failed to meet compliance targets.
Two city police officers were arraigned Wednesday on charges of misconduct and falsifying records in connection with the disappearance of 11 bags of cocaine.

While Bush administration officials have acknowledged some discussions leading up to the destruction of the tapes in November 2005, as the article noted, the White House itself has not officially said anything on the subject, so its role was not “wider than it said.” (A related article appears today on Page A6.).

The authorities named a ninth victim of a man who had previously confessed to killing eight women from 1977 to 1982. Police officials in Paducah, Ky., said the man, Timothy W. Krajcir, 63, had admitted to the 1979 kidnapping and murder of Joyce Tharp, 29. Earlier this month, officials announced that Mr. Krajcir, who has been imprisoned since 1983, had confessed to the killings of five women in Missouri, two in Illinois and one in Pennsylvania. Sexual assault accompanied many of the killings. Mr. Krajcir, who has yet to be charged in three of the killings, awaits extradition from Illinois to Missouri, where he faces multiple life sentences.

Explosions and fires at a chemical plant in Jacksonville killed four people, injured at least 14 and sent debris flying several stories into the air, fire officials and witnesses said. It was not clear what caused the explosions about 1:30 p.m. at the T2 Laboratories plant, which makes chemical solvents and fuel additives, said Tom Francis, a fire rescue spokesman. Everyone at the plant was accounted for by Wednesday evening. Hospitals reported one patient in critical condition, three fair and five good. Conditions for the rest were unknown.

STAMFORD, Conn. — The letters that began arriving at a woman’s childhood home in Bridgeport, Conn., in May 2006 were as macabre as they were childish looking. One had a tombstone with her name on it and a drawing of a heart with a bite taken from it. Another had stick figures of grade-school children, a severed head and the warning “Prepare yourself.” The police traced the letters to an address in Minnesota, where they found tragedy waiting to happen.

She is Rosi Kerr, not Kerry, and she works in sales for an energy company; she is not an energy consultant.

8 P.M. (TCM) OVER 21 (1945) Irene Dunne, a five-time Oscar nominee who attacked melodrama and screwball comedy with equal passion, is Turner Classic Movies' Star of the Month and is receiving a continuing 28-film salute. Tonight's rollicking fare: ''Over 21,'' based on the play by Ruth Gordon about an aging newspaper editor (Alexander Knox) who joins the Army to experience war firsthand; when he no longer has time to write his weekly editorials, his wife (Dunne) secretly pitches in. At 10 Dunne plays a small-town church organist who writes steamy novels on the side in ''Theodora Goes Wild'' (1936). (Above, Dunne with Melvyn Douglas in the movie.) The hilarity continues with ''The Awful Truth'' (1937) with Cary Grant at 11:45; ''Joy of Living'' (1938) with Douglas Fairbanks Jr. at 1:30 a.m.; ''My Favorite Wife'' (1940), with Grant again, at 3:15; and ''Never a Dull Moment'' (1950) with Fred MacMurray at 4:45. 7 P.M. (Discovery) LAST ONE STANDING The athletes travel to Cikaramat, an Indonesian village in West Java, where they take part in pencak silat, a martial art designed to kill. At 8 they journey to the tiny South Pacific island of Wala in Vanuatu and race canoes at sea.

If you've just begun an affair with a billionaire and are wondering how much he likes you, you might want to suggest a few nights at the Carlyle hotel's new Empire Suite, a Deco-inspired duplex, right, that's available for $15,000 a night. The 29th-story master bedroom has sweeping views of the city and cashmere-covered walls, and the sheets will be monogrammed with your initials. And none of those chintzy little miniatures here: The booze comes in full-size bottles. Is it included? James W. McBride, the hotel's managing director, was asked.

With the primary campaign homestretch overlapping the holidays, just how are the candidates going to balance the season's spirit with getting their messages out? They have given clues in their Christmas-themed advertisements, which ranged from the gauzy to the humorous. Some are more earnest. John Edwards of North Carolina has a serious offering about poverty, referring only indirectly to ''the season of miracles, of faith, of love.'' Mike Huckabee of Arkansas, a Republican for whom the support of evangelicals is crucial, says, ''What really matters is the celebration of the birth of Christ.''

GIANOPULOS--Mary Aristea (nee Hadzopoulous), passed peacefully at her home in Los Angeles, December 16, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Nicholas; adored mother of James, Despina and Peter; loved and loving grandmother of Mimi, Alexa, Niki and Sophia; and cherished mother-in-law of Ann Gianopulos (nee Thompson), Jay Landers and Christina Gianopulos (nee Liviakis). Mary was born in New York City, on April 30, 1925, to Demetrios, who arrived in New York in 1908, and Despina, who was raised and educated in a suburb of Constantinople, and came to America in 1923 as one of the heralded ''transport brides'' of that era. Active in Greek cultural and church activities throughout her youth and adult life, Mary wed Nicholas in 1951. She pursued a successful career in women's fashion in New York, working on many collections for the couture designer, Mary McFadden, taking time from her vacation to raise her three dear children to be immersed in the Greek culture and language. The children and grandchildren enjoy frequent trips to Greece, where their fluency in the language is a constant reminder of their mother's love and devotion. Mary retired in 1986, enojoying 10 years with her beloved husband before his passing. Mary moved to Los Angeles in 2003, where her greatest joy was derived from spending time with her adoring grandchildren, for whom she cooked in the Greek style, preparing their favorite dishes at ''Yiayia's'' house. Her warm presence, loving touch, embracing hospitality and her many kindnesses to family and friends will be missed, and cherished. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Thursday, December 19th, 6-9pm, 1076 Madiscon Avenue at 81st Street, New York, NY 10028. Telephone: 212-288-3500. Interment will be held at 12:30pm, Willow Hill Cemetary, Main Rd., Southold, NY 11971. 631765-3850. In lieu of flowers, or gifts, the family requests that donations be made to The Mary Gianopulos Memorial Fund, (Fund #

Campaigns use music at rallies for two purposes. The first is to pump up the crowd, with exciting anthems intended to stir the soul and get the adrenaline flowing. (That, by the way, is the real reason U2 exists.) But the second is to underline the candidate's message. Bill Clinton did this famously in 1992 with the Fleetwood Mac song ''Don't Stop,'' with its ''Thinking About Tomorrow'' chorus. And now John Edwards of North Carolina is using a rather eclectic -- and musically speaking, fairly admirable -- selection of music to underscore his pugnacious closing argument speech to Iowans as the Jan. 3 caucuses approach.

LEVENSON--Marvin. With heavy hearts we announce the passing of our dear dad, Marvin Levenson, AH, of Brighton (and Nantasket), MA. Marvin dedicated his life to voluntary community service and was beloved by all who knew him. He was a modest man whose pure life embodied great ethics. Marvin is survived by his loving children, Mark of West Orange, NJ, Susan Wolf of Alon Shvut, Amy of Englewood, NJ, and David of Manhattan, brother David of Framingham, MA, and 15 grandchildren. He will be greatly missed by all who were blessed by his kind heart and generous soul.

EHRLICH--Simon B., of Norwalk, CT, age 86, died peacefully December 15. Born February 19, 1921, youngest child of Abraham and Rose Ehrlich, he was a graduate of Boy's High School, Brooklyn, 1938 and NYU, 1948. A WWII veteran who served in the U.S. Merine Corps, 4th Division, he fought in the battles for Iwo Jima, Saipan and Tinian. A Norwalk resident since 1955 and a City Selectman from 1972-1976, he was appointed Chairman of the Norwalk Draft Board in 1967. He was a Vice President of Brown Harris Stevens, Property Management division. An avid sailor, he enjoyed the woods, pond and wildlife on his property. He will be deeply missed by his beloved wife of 57 years, Phyllis, a retired New York Times reporter and editor, daughters Susanna B. Ehrlich of Potomac, Abigail M. Ehrlich of Manhattan, grandchildren Emily, William and John Talbot of Potomac, and Samuel Cohen of Manhattan, and sons-in-law James Talbot and Mark Lyons.

A picture caption on Monday with the Zurich Journal article, about efforts by Zurich's chocolatiers to make the Swiss eat more chocolate, misidentified the street on which the Teuscher chocolate emporium, shown in the photograph, is located. It is on the Storchengasse, not the Bahnhofstrasse.

Tom Osborne lost the interim tag and is Nebraska's athletic director. Harvey Perlman, the university's chancellor, announced that the 70-year-old Osborne would remain as athletic director until June 30, 2010. Ten years removed from his coaching career, Osborne returned to the university as the interim athletic director Oct. 16, the day after Steve Pederson was fired. Since then, Osborne has fired Bill Callahan as the football coach, hired Bo Pelini and helped in recruiting.

RIDING a lift is only one way to the top of a snow-covered mountain. For skiers who prefer to earn their turns, climbing into the backcountry with specialized alpine touring equipment provides unparalleled access to pristine terrain. Bindings allow skiers to ascend with heels up (for better propulsion) and descend with heels down (for more stability). The latest bindings, lighter and more durable than their past counterparts, make it even easier to climb up and ski down.

Luca Toni scored four goals Wednesday to send Bayern Munich into the next round of the UEFA Cup with a 6-0 rout of Greece's Aris. Konstantinos Chalkias, the Aris goalkeeper, made errors on Toni's goals in the 25th, 38th, 64th and 66th minutes. Christian Lell and Philipp Lahm also scored for Bayern, which won its final group game and topped Group F. Bayern's biggest UEFA Cup victory came in 1983, when it defeated Anorthosis Famagusta, 10-0.Bolton, Braga, Getafe, Anderlecht and Galatasaray also advanced Wednesday. The six final games of the round are Thursday.

The Florida assistant Doc Holliday was back in Gainesville on Wednesday, one day after interviewing for the top job at West Virginia. Holliday, Florida's safeties coach and associate head coach, met with West Virginia officials about succeeding Rich Rodriguez.

The Osage County plates, a set of six porcelain dishes that recall classic souvenir plates, were conceived by Barbara Jakobson, a New York art collector who enjoys spending time in that Oklahoma county. They commemorate the state's centennial this year. Made in an edition of 100, each one is decorated with a different image of the Oklahoma landscape selected from the Osage County series (including ''Wynona,'' above) by Grant McClintock, a photographer, and signed by Mr. McClintock. The plates are dishwasher and microwave safe; a set of six can be ordered directly from the photographer for $500.

An obituary last Thursday about the Hollywood producer and talent agent Freddie Fields misidentified the mother of his daughter Kathy Fields Lander. She is Edith Fellows, Mr. Fields's first wife -- not Polly Bergen, his second wife.

Four years after leaving college football amid controversy and a lawsuit at Washington, Rick Neuheisel is resurfacing as a candidate to coach U.C.L.A. Neuheisel, the former Bruins quarterback and now the offensive coordinator for the Baltimore Ravens, confirmed Wednesday that his alma mater has contacted him about replacing the fired Karl Dorrell. Neuheisel, 46, said it would be his dream job. He has not been in the college game since Washington fired him in 2003 for participating in a betting pool on the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. He sued for wrongful termination from Washington and settled in March 2005 with the university and the N.C.A.A. for $4.5 million.

Bernard Lagat and Craig Mottram, who staged an exciting finish to the Wanamaker Mile in last February's Millrose Games, will meet again in the indoor track meet Feb. 1 at Madison Square Garden. Lagat ran down Mottram on the final lap and won in 3 minutes 54.26 seconds, an exceptional time for the small and tight track. Lagat, a Kenyan native and now an American citizen, went on to win the 1,500 and 5,000 meters in the world championships in August and September in Osaka, Japan, the first man to achieve that double. Lagat has won the Wanamaker Mile five times. Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland holds the record, seven.

VOLPE--Edmond. The City University of New York deeply mourns the loss of Dr. Edmond Volpe, the first President of the College of Staten Island, who provided exemplary academic and administrative leadership for four decades, beginning with his professorship at CCNY in 1954. Chosen to head the former Richmond College, an upper division institution on Staten Island in 1974, he oversaw the merging of Richmond in 1976 with Staten Island Community College and developed it with vision and tremendous energy into the College of Staten Island. He later played a key role, working with government leaders, in securing and building the modern Willowbrook campus that was completed in 1994. An acclaimed scholar in modern American literature, a respected national education expert, author of two books on creating a college, a prominent civic leader who strengthened the link between CSI and the community, he leaves an enduring legacy. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Rose, and his family. Benno C. Schmidt, Jr., Chairman Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

Michelle Brand, who calls herself an eco-designer, makes screens, room dividers and pendant lights like the 14-foot-long Cascade, above, out of used plastic soda bottles. Ms. Brand collects most of her material -- about 100 to 150 bottles a week -- from institutions like St. Mary's Hospital for Women & Children, near her home in Manchester, England. Back at her studio, she uses a machine to slice the bottoms off the bottles, at a rate of about 120 an hour. Ms. Brand washes and disinfects the cut-off pieces, which resemble flowers, by hand, while the leftover parts are sent to a landfill. The result: surprisingly ethereal fixtures like Cascade, which comes in 10 lengths, from one foot ($600) to 14 feet ($7,600). Information: (505) 872-1929 or lisafontanarosa.com. ELAINE LOUIE

How to describe London's Paint and Paper Library? David Oliver, its Australian-born director, is a sort of rock star of color who has, for a decade or so, been intent on making paint and wallpaper as desirable as couture to a rarefied crowd that includes clients like Chelsea Clinton, Tony Blair and Kylie Minogue. He has created colors with evocative names like Silken Flank and Quench the Gloom, and produced high-end wallpapers designed by himself and decorators like Allegra Hicks. His own best-seller, a paper called Liberation that recalls Russian Constructivist graphics, is a riff on the layout of the French newspaper Libération. Mr. Oliver's new book, ''Paint and Paper in Decoration'' (Rizzoli, $45), lets you in on his inspirations, although his exposition is somewhat confusing. That's O.K.: the point of the book is to excite the eye, and he does that nicely by pairing Paint and Paper Library colors with extraordinary interior and exterior photos. Here a pink Mexican wall, far left, and red Roman bathroom illustrate a rhapsodic chapter about the colors lavender and rose. PENELOPE GREEN

BREED--Henry Eltinge, died at home on December 8, 2007, aged 92, after a brief illness. A physicist who specialized in acoustics and in optics, Dr. Breed taught, wrote, lectured, and consulted widely in these fields for over 40 years. A fellow of the American Optical Society, he also served on the boards of a large number of other professional societies. He was the widower of Dr. Helen Illick Breed. Survivors include two sons: Henry Eltinge Breed III of Manhattan, and Joseph Illick Breed of Tokyo.

E.P.A. BLOCKS STATE AUTO LAWS The Environmental Protection Agency denied California and 16 other states the right to set their own standards for carbon dioxide pollution from automobiles, declaring that the rules were made moot by the energy bill signed by President Bush. [A1] MORGAN REPORTS A LOSS Morgan Stanley reported the first quarterly loss in its 72-year history, as the company took a $9.4 billion charge on subprime-linked investments. It also said it would sell a $5 billion stake to a Chinese investment fund to shore up its capital.

This week, 20 Anthropologie stores across the country will begin selling ''bankstoels,'' recycled-wood benches created by Ronel Jordaan, a South African textile designer. Plain wood benches are a common sight throughout South Africa, but they become works of art when topped with an arrangement of felt petals individually hand shaped and dyed, then sewn into a lively, spongy cushion. Ms. Jordaan, who started her felting business in 2005 hoping to provide jobs for local tribeswomen, now has 30 employees; a single bankstoel takes several of them more than a week to complete. One Felt Flower Bench ($1,600), right, and one Felt Succulent Bench ($1,200) will be available per store. Information: (800) 309-2500. JULIE SCELFO

The left-handed reliever Ron Mahay and the Kansas City Royals reached a preliminary agreement on a two-year, $8 million contract. Mahay, 36, was 3-0 with a 2.55 earned run average in 67 innings last year with Texas and the Atlanta Braves, who acquired him July 31 with first baseman Mark Teixeira.

Inside the pressure cooker of live television, the name Barack Obama apparently becomes tricky. Mr. Obama's name has been confused with that of the terrorist leader Osama bin Laden on separate occasions on CNN recently. Glenn Beck, the host of shows on radio and CNN Headline News, was on Monday the latest to make the mistake, catching himself midword when he started to say ''Osama'' in a discussion of presidential candidates on ABC's ''Good Morning America.''

A sports article on Wednesday about academic cheating involving the Florida State University football team misstated the year in which the Seminoles last won the Atlantic Coast Conference title. It was 2005, not 2003.

A NUMBER of midcentury modern chairs that have long been out of production -- some of them for decades -- are being produced again, some by new manufacturers. Ralph Pucci, a furniture manufacturer and gallery owner who is reissuing several Jens Risom pieces, described them as ''timeless, quality work that needs to be reintroduced.'' He pointed out that new materials and workmanship today are often better than those used in the originals.

While it is nice to have a big-screen HDTV in the living room, these behemoths are not intended to keep up with high-end game consoles and PCs. Now, however, there's the Sharp Aquos LC-32GP3U, a high-definition television created especially for gamers. The 32-inch TV displays images in full 1080p (1,920 by 1,080 pixel resolution) and has a 6-millisecond response time. That is the time it takes for the image to refresh with new information; by comparison, the average liquid-crystal-display or plasma TV has a 16-millisecond response time, a lag that is noticeable during game play.

Here is a slide show of 11 photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the reincarnation of the Second Avenue Deli, a visit to the Cloisters museum in Fort Tryon Park and the annual Candlelight Carol Festival on the Upper West Side.

Writing about Marvin Franklin, the artist whose work is on view at the New York Transit Museum from this week through March, it feels natural to focus on the details of his premature and unsettling death — Mr. Franklin was a 55-year-old subway track worker who was killed by a train in March – and on the profound effect that his passing has had on the friends and family he left behind. (A subsequent review found numerous safety lapses and prompted the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to order a series of reforms.)

Taking advantage of the weak dollar, foreign tourists are keeping brokers busy with their eagerness to buy Manhattan apartments, which many see as investments, according to a front-page article by Christine Haughney, who also reports that “Manhattan brokers are waking before dawn to talk by phone with European buyers about amenities and closing costs and working late advising foreign buyers in town on the best places to shop for gadgets and clothes.”

Updated, Dec. 23 | FreshDirect announced on Sunday afternoon that an effort to unionize hundreds of workers at its warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, had failed. Jim Moore, the company’s vice president for business affairs, said in a statement:

As of Jan. 1, the New York Water Taxi is suspending its ferry service on the East River route serving points in Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan for four months, citing a combination of rising fuel costs and the low ridership during the winter season. While the company’s tourist service has been profitable, ferry companies have long struggled with the economics of ferry service. It will reopen in May.Fuel costs have doubled in 2007 alone, said Tom Fox, the president of New York Water Taxi. Even so, the company’s East River route broke even for the first time in 2007 during the fall, spring and summer seasons. But ridership declines by about 30 percent in the winter because of a fall in tourism, and the commuters are not profitable.

A bit more on trade -- hey, I'm getting to share some preliminary research in real time! In a previous post I showed the dramatic growth in imports of manufactured goods from developing countries as a % of GDP. (No, services outsourcing isn't included.) I'm working on a Brookings Paper updating work on the effects of trade on income distribution. And I thought I'd share a fairly striking picture. This chart shows US imports of manufactured goods from advanced countries and developing countries, measured as a percentage of US GDP. We used to say that imports from low-wage developing countries couldn't have that large an effect on wages here, because they were small compared with the economy. Well, you can't say that anymore.

My column this week is on small island states and why they have taken the lead in issues related to climate change. I'm talking about places like the Maldives, the Seychelles, and Caribbean Islands -- which will literally be swallowed up by 1.5 meters of sea level rise. Aggressive action on climate change is a matter of survival for them.

An article on Thursday about the selection of Jacob Zuma as the new leader of South Africa’s governing party, the African National Congress, gave the incorrect age in some copies in describing when he was sent to prison by the former apartheid government. He was 21, not 24.
An article on Thursday about charter schools that received their grades under New York City’s new report card system misstated the number of charters that were graded. It was 14 out of 60 — not 13.

An article and a picture caption on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about the office market in Manhattan misstated the address of the Milk Studios Building, which recently sold for more than $160 million. It is at 450 West 15th Street, not East 15th Street.

An article in Business Day on Thursday about the social networking of technology start-ups in California misidentified the location of the part of Sand Hill Road where Silicon Valley venture capital firms are concentrated. It is in Menlo Park, not Palo Alto.

A pop music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend last Friday about Ian Hunter, at the Music Hall of Williamsburg, misidentified the bass player performing with him there. While he did not play at the Music Hall, he is still a member of Mr. Hunter’s Rant Band.

A monastery in Moncks Corner will halt its egg farming business after claims by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals that the Trappist monks mistreated hens. The Rev. Stan Gumula of Mepkin Abbey said in a statement late Wednesday that pressure from PETA made it difficult for the monks to live a quiet life of prayer, work and sacred reading. The egg farm business will be phased out over the next 18 months, according to the statement. Father Gumula told the National Catholic Reporter that the abbey produced about nine million eggs a year, and that the product was delivered to retailers in the Charleston area. PETA began its criticism of Mepkin Abbey in February, saying it had videotape of thousands of hens crammed into small cages.
Denzel Washington is donating $1 million to Wiley College, featured in his new movie “The Great Debaters,” to re-establish its debate team.

A jury awarded $15.5 million to a woman and her husband who spent months in jail on charges he killed their daughter before he was freed by DNA evidence. The couple, Kevin and Melissa Fox, sued four sheriff’s detectives, the estate of a fifth detective and Will County in federal court. Kathleen Zellner, a lawyer for Mr. Fox, said during closing arguments on Monday that Will County sheriff’s detectives arrested Mr. Fox even though they knew he did not kill his 3-year-old daughter, Riley. Mr. Fox, 30, testified that he lost hope during a long interrogation and gave a false story when promised leniency. Hikers found Riley’s body in a creek four miles from her Wilmington home on June 6, 2004. The case remains unsolved.

Seven people have been fired over electrical shocks given to two teenagers at the direction of what turned out to be a prank caller, the operator of the group home where the incident occurred said. A state agency concluded that six staff members at the residence in Stoughton had ample reason to doubt the orders. The staff members and a video surveillance worker were fired, a school spokesman said. On Aug. 26, a caller posed as a supervisor and ordered the punishments for the two teenagers, 16 and 19, because he said they had misbehaved. One received 77 shocks, and the other received 29. A report released Wednesday by the Massachusetts Department of Early Education and Care said the caller was a former resident of the center.
Some 5,500 pounds of basil grown in Mexico and sold in the United States was recalled because of fears that it might be infected with salmonella.

Passports will not be necessary for Americans entering the United States by land until mid-2009, a year later than planned, if a budget bill passed by Congress is approved by President Bush. A provision of a budget bill pushes back the plan by the Department of Homeland Security to require passports from border crossers from Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean as a way of strengthening national security. Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, said he expected Mr. Bush to sign the bill, despite the administration’s insistence on carrying out the passport requirement next summer. The passport requirement has been a sore point in border states.
The classroom wing at Virginia Tech where a student gunman killed 30 people and himself and wounded two dozen others in April will be turned into a place to study peace.

Rich Rodriguez fired Michigan’s assistants Thursday, his second day as an employee of the university. Lloyd Carr, who is retiring, will coach Michigan on Jan. 1 against Florida in the Capital One Bowl.

The ownership of the Breeders’ Cup Classic winner Curlin has changed again. Jess Jackson bought out another partner and now has an 80 percent interest in Curlin, a 3-year-old colt. Jackson, who owns Stonestreet Stables, bought out the investment banker George Bolton. Jackson’s spokesman Kevin McGee would not provide details. Curlin is the favorite to be named Horse of the Year in 2007.

Michelle Wie may start her season in Hawaii, but not at the Sony Open. Wie, who has played the PGA Tour event every year since 2004, did not receive one of the four unrestricted sponsor exemptions, the tournament director Ray Stosik said Thursday. The swing coach David Leadbetter said Wie may ask for exemptions at one or both of the L.P.G.A. events in Hawaii that open the women’s season in February.

The authorities have charged two women and a man with a weekend attack on three North Carolina football players, which police said was motivated by robbery and included the sexual assault of at least two players. The police said the players were attacked early Sunday at their off-campus apartment.

Coach Bobby Bowden said he did not think Florida State would have to forfeit games for using ineligible players this season. “We didn’t know anyone was ineligible,” he said Thursday. Bowden has 373 career victories, the most in major college football history. About two dozen Florida State players have been suspended for the Music City Bowl against Kentucky for cheating on an online exam.

Centre County District Attorney Michael Madeira said District Judge Carmine Prestia erred when he dropped the charges.

Amid calls to resign for being “Germany’s laziest M.P.,” as the press called him, Count Carl-Eduard von Bismarck, left, the 46-year-old great-great-grandson of the Iron Chancellor, Otto von Bismarck, has quit Parliament after a two-and-a-half-year term.

Heat-seeking golfers who favor Scottsdale, Ariz., will encounter a curious phenomenon this winter: What’s old is new. November witnessed extreme makeovers applied to two of the Sonoran Desert’s “must-play” destinations, Troon North and the TPC Scottsdale. Troon North’s tweaks are the more subtle. Its Saguaro-laced Monument and Pinnacle courses have been rated as Arizona’s top two public-access tracks for than 10 years, but the layout routed players in confusing directions. After much soul-searching, Troon Golf executives split up the vaunted Monument layout, pairing its old back nine with the old back nine of the Pinnacle to form a “new” Pinnacle course. The “new” Monument course is comprised of the old front nines. Original designer Tom Weiskopf resurfaced the greens and reworked the bunkers to achieve a consistent look throughout. The result is better flow. Gone are the “Where-in-the-world-am-I-going” cart rides that slowed up play considerably. Monument is the more spectacular of the two, with gigantic rocks and elevation changes at every turn, but Pinnacle is tougher — and, in a rarity for the desert, is a walkable course, even if it’s ninth hole doesn’t return to the clubhouse.

REMSEN--Anne Powell, of Jupiter Island, Florida on December 18. Beloved wife of Richard; loving mother of Rick, Jay, and Lita; cherished grandmother of Nick, Zach, Maggie, Billy, Emma, and Lucy; and dear sister of Jane Powell and Lois Cheston. She attended Westover School and Vassar College, graduating in 1952. Taylor & Modeen Funeral Home, Family Owned & Operated (561) 744-2030, Jupiter, FL.

In three minutes a Picasso painting valued at $50 million and another work valued at $5.5 million were stolen at dawn on Thursday from the Museum of Art in São Paulo, Brazil, Reuters reported. The paintings, taken from separate rooms on the second floor of that city's leading art museum, were Picasso's ''Portrait of Suzanne Bloch'' (1904), left, a Blue Period oil, and ''The Coffee Worker'' (1939), by the neorealist Brazilian artist Candido Portinari. A security camera captured the movements of the thieves when they broke through the main door at 5 a.m. The newspaper Globo said the police were questioning guards on duty at the time. The museum said that it would be closed for a few days. Its collection is considered the most important in Latin America.

HOLIDAY PARTIES If it weren't for the cabs, New York on Christmas Eve would feel as underpopulated as it does in ''I Am Legend.'' There's no big parade here, and many institutions that schedule interesting activities close up shop, presumably so that you can spend time with friends and family, listen to a beatific choir or participate in the contact sport known as last-minute shopping. But for those seeking an escape from G-rated holiday entertainment, a few parties have arrived to bring you real cheer. On Monday two events conceived as alternatives to the gargantuan Jewish singles affair called the Matzo Ball are back by popular demand. Heebonism, a creation of Heeb Magazine, is a party that's essentially ''a bunch of wild and crazy Jews running around -- and non-Jews too,'' said Brian Abrams, a writer who says his official position at Heeb is dreidel hustler. In addition to sets by D.J. Krowd Pleezr and others, the thousand or so who are expected to attend can take part in Christmas carol karaoke and strip dreidel, a variant on the dreidel game that Mr. Abrams says involves shedding garments instead of chocolate. (Above, Heebonism 2006 at Bed in Chelsea.)

FOR CHILDREN BEST OF NEW YORK INTERNATIONAL CHILDREN'S FILM FESTIVAL (Saturday and Sunday) Where can young cinephiles see independent film that's refreshing and creative but still age-appropriate? This festival has always been a reliable source, and this weekend and next it will present programs of highlights at Symphony Space. At 11 a.m. ''Kid Flix Mix 2,'' for ages 3 to 8, offers 12 shorts, including Bill Plympton's ''Fan and the Flower,'' an unusual animated love story, and Sheldon Cohen's ''I Want a Dog,'' whose title explains it all. At 2 p.m. ''N.Y.I.C.F.F. Party Mix'' caters to ages 8 to 16 with selections like ''The Ten Steps,'' Brendan Muldowney's brief and bloodless but deliciously spooky thriller. At the Leonard Nimoy Thalia, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 349-0330, gkids.com; $10; $8 for children; $6 for members.

DOWNER--Joseph Platt, who retired in 1986 as Vice Chairman of the Atlantic Richfield Company, died December 19th of natural causes at Peconic Landing in Greenport, NY. He was 85 years old. Raised in an United States Army family, his father being a career officer, Joe Downer was born in Koblenz, Germany in 1922. He often proudly explained as a young man that, in addition to Europe, he had lived in six states across America and attended five schools prior to entering Harvard College, from which he graduated in January 1943. Following three years of service in World War II, largely as an Artillery officer in the 10th Mountain Division, including its combat experience in Italy, he returned to the Harvard Business School and received his masters degree in 1948. Mr. Downer's nearly four decade oil industry career began in that year with the Continental Oil Company in Ponca City, Oklahoma. He later joined Sinclair Oil Corporation in New York and rose to become Executive Vice President and Director of that company. In 1969 he played a prominent role in the union of Sinclair and Atlantic Richfield, which up to that time was among the largest industrial mergers in United States business history. Over the next seventeen years, including the development of the Prudhoe Bay Field in Alaska and the Trans Alaska Pipeline, Mr. Downer served as Executive Vice President and Director, and later Vice Chairman and Director of Arco. In addition to the Sinclair and Atlantic Richfield boards, Mr. Downer was at various times a director of the Anaconda Company, Lockheed Corporation, Fiduciary Trust Company International and Cherokee Resources Company. Always close to Harvard University, which he had attended as a scholarship and G. I. Bill student, he served during the academic year 1983-1984 as President of the Harvard Alumni Association, and for many years as a member of the Committee on University Resources and the Visiting Committee of the Kennedy School of Government. Among other volunteer posts which he held over his career were Vice Chairman KCET Public Television in Los Angeles, Trustee of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, Trustee of the Foreign Policy Association of New York, a member of the Grace Commission on the Cost of Government during the Reagan Administration, and a vestry member of St. John's Episcopal Church. Mr. Downer is survived by his wife Louise Swenson Downer; a daughter, Jannett Downer Sayre of Cherry Hills Village, CO, and two sons, William Tucker of Hoboken, NJ and John Ashton (Tony) of Stamford, CT, three stepchildren and six grandchildrne. His marriage to Jannett Tucker Downer of New York City, who also survived, ended in divorce. Donations may be made to Harvard College or St. John's Episcopal Church of Cold Spring Harbor, NY.

The headlines have dogged Rudolph W. Giuliani's presidential campaign for weeks. ''Security costs for trysts draw attention,'' said one. The articles questioned whether, as mayor, Mr. Giuliani tried to hide his visits to Judith Nathan in the Hamptons by burying the associated security costs in the budgets of obscure mayoral agencies like the Loft Board. The answer is not likely, according to a review of the city records originally cited as the basis for the assertion.

The National Endowment for the Arts is announcing a program aimed at rescuing plays from development hell, er, helping nonprofit theaters bring new plays to full production. In its inaugural phase, the program, to be administered by Arena Stage in Washington, will select two projects, giving up to $90,000 each to their advance development, including at least one full production at a nonprofit theater. Five projects will receive up to $20,000 each for the early stages of development. An existing agency program for play development that focused on supporting projects by resident playwrights and was administered by Theater Communications Group, will conclude in 2009. ... Broadway sages looked at the title ''The Drowsy Chaperone'' and gave the production a few months at most. But ''Drowsy,'' the musical within a musical, managed to stick it out for a year and a half. It will close after the Sunday evening performance on Dec. 30, when it will have played 674 regular performances and 32 previews.

A day after resigning as the antiquities chief of Greece for health reasons, Christos Zahopoulos, 54, was hospitalized in critical condition on Thursday after leaping from his fifth- floor apartment in central Athens, Agence France-Presse reported. Greek news media reported that Mr. Zahopoulos, a close friend of Prime Minister Costas Karamanlis, had a difficult time under the new culture minister, Michalis Liapis, who was said to have sidelined him from duties related to archaeology after taking over the ministry in September.

A man accused of stealing a Goya painting from an unattended truck en route to the Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan pleaded guilty on Thursday to conspiracy to commit theft, The Associated Press reported. Under a deal with federal prosecutors in Newark, the man, Steven Lee Olson, 49, of Carlstadt, N.J., faces a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a fine of $250,000. Prosecutors said that his neighbor, Roman Szurko, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to the same charge. Mr. Olson was charged in October with stealing ''Children With a Cart,'' left, a 1778 Goya insured for $1 million. The painting was stolen from a truck taking it from the Toledo Museum of Art to the Guggenheim in November 2006. Mr. Olson had initially said that he found the painting in his basement. The artwork was recovered and returned undamaged to the Toledo museum.

'A KID'S LIFE' What would ''Sesame Street'' be like without Oscar the Grouch? A possible answer is ''A Kid's Life,'' which recently opened at the York Theater Company. Although this production also has upbeat songs, cheery lessons in the workings of the world and adults dressed in oversize fuzzy costumes, it features little of the inspired wit and occasionally acerbic observations that have made ''Sesame Street'' so ingenious. While clouds sometimes gather over that neighborhood, the nameless little town in ''A Kid's Life'' is virtually all sunshine, all the time. Not that children under 7 are likely to mind. Even though they were absent from the performance I attended (bad weather had caused school audiences to cancel), it was easy to imagine them enthralled. ''A Kid's Life'' follows a small boy named Zack (Carlos Avilas, above right) and his dog, Starsky (Yoav Levin), as they meet Zoe (Ashley Wallace) and introduce her to the neighborhood. Over the course of an hour little theatergoers have the opportunity to bat balloons through the audience, clap and sing to the music and shout instructions to the actors.

A suicide attacker detonated a bomb early Friday at a residential compound of Pakistan's former interior minister as he received visitors on an Islamic holiday, killing at least eight people and wounding dozens, the police said. The politician, Aftab Khan Sherpao, was not hurt in what appeared to be the second such attack on him in eight months. The blast went off near the mosque in his residential compound in Sherpao, a village about 25 miles northeast of the city of Peshawar, a police officer, Khalid Khan, said.

People Jones Day, the international law firm, named Willis J. Goldsmith as partner in charge of its New York office. Mr. Goldsmith succeeds Dennis W. LaBarre, who served as partner in charge for 21 years and will continue as a partner.

Six Australian businessmen face the possibility of millions of dollars in fines in a new civil case connected with huge bribes paid to the government of Saddam Hussein. They could also face criminal proceedings. The six are former managers of the Australian Wheat Board, which an inquiry last year found had paid some $250 million in bribes to secure contracts to supply wheat under the United Nations oil-for-food program.

CATHERINE LEE: 'THE MARK PAINTINGS 1977-79' It is not often that a gallery presents a body of work that an artist created 30 years ago, especially when much of it was never shown. It is even rarer that the artist agrees to the show. But that is what Galerie Lelong has unveiled for the holiday season: a survey of drawings and paintings by the Minimalist Catherine Lee produced in New York from 1977 to 1979. Back then artists weren't trying to earn a million dollars in their first year out of art school, or flirting at Art Basel Miami Beach with the next Whitney Biennial curatorial team. They were busy reducing art to its essences, to words, spaces, lines and marks. Ms. Lee was among them, producing tightly pared-back, serial paintings using obsessive and repetitive markings laid down in a strict grid structure, never deviating from the mission or allowing her imagination or emotion to enter the creative process (left, a detail of ''Painting #3,'' 1978). The concentration required to produce the two dozen works here was phenomenal, though the images themselves can at times look a little monotonous.

The Federal Election Commission certified the first matching money of the 2008 presidential election on Thursday, and the biggest beneficiary will be John Edwards, a Democrat, whose campaign will receive about $8.8 million. To qualify for matching funds, candidates must abide by strict limits on where they spend their money, and how much they spend, with a cap of about $50 million for the primaries. Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, both Democrats, are expected to spend more than that in the primaries.

Andrew Lloyd Webber, below, will make his debut as an actor early next year on the British soap opera ''Hollyoaks,'' the BBC reported. In three episodes of the Channel 4 show focused mainly on young people and a fictional community college, Mr. Lloyd Webber, playing himself, will be stalked by an aspiring actress seeking an audition for one of his musicals. ''I've blurred fiction with fact all my life, but never on national television,'' Mr. Lloyd Webber said.

'C'EST DUCKIE!' Sometimes you need a little kitsch and cabaret to get through the holidays. In addition to all of New York's delicious homegrown acts, this year brings the United States premiere of ''C'est Duckie!,'' presented by Performance Space 122 at an alternate location, the Clemente Soto Vélez Cultural Center. The two-hour spectacle by the Duckie collective of performance artists, above, billed as an ''interactive nightclub performance experience,'' has already won an Olivier Award in its native London, and played to sold-out houses in Berlin, Sydney and Tokyo. Each table of patrons receives a supply of Duckie dollars for buying selections from the show's menu of acts, which includes everything from burlesque to ventriloquism to the Stilettos of Death, performed by intriguingly named artists like Miss High Leg Kick. You can even pay for the pleasure of having a Duckie star sit at your table and insult you, something many New Yorkers have gotten from strangers, free, at some point or another.

Russia announced on Thursday that it was canceling plans to exhibit 120 works from its museums at the Royal Academy of Art in London beginning Jan. 26, as Britain pledged to speed up legislation that would safeguard loans of art, Reuters reported. Roskultura, the state cultural agency, said it feared that British courts could seize the art on behalf of descendants of people who owned the paintings before they were confiscated after the Russian revolution of 1917. A spokesman for the British Embassy in Moscow said assurances already given were sufficient for the safety of the art planned for the exhibition, ''From Russia: French and Russian Art Masterpieces of 1870-1925.'' But, he added: ''We also believe that cultural relations between Britain and Russia are of tremendous importance. In this regard, we will be bringing forward the enactment of new legislation already in process.'' (The exhibition is at the Museum Kunst Palast in Düsseldorf, Germany, through Jan. 6.)

JOHN ELLIS: 'DREAMSCAPES' When the saxophonist and bass clarinetist John Ellis was selected as one of six artists in the Jazz Gallery's commission-oriented Composers' Series, he took to heart a suggestion that this was the time to try something new. ''Dreamscapes,'' the chamberlike suite that he unveils this weekend, marks his first attempt at writing music for strings. It's also his most conceptually oriented work, inspired not only by dreaming itself but also a set of dream-related poems contributed by Andy Bragen, a friend and playwright. Mr. Ellis, above, has been composing successfully on a smaller scale for more than a decade. But his best work dates from the last few years, when he left a sideman post with the guitarist Charlie Hunter and decisively struck out on his own. ''By a Thread'' (Hyena), his most recent album, features nine refreshingly uncontrived pieces for a modern jazz quintet; some of them, like ''Umpty Eleven,'' sound effortless despite their convolutions. The style echoes Mr. Ellis's easygoing but assertive instrumental voice, informed by his studies in North Carolina, New Orleans and New York.

On a night of mostly low-rated repeats, the third installment of ''Clash of the Choirs'' gave NBC a modest bump in the ratings on Wednesday, when a two-hour episode led the 8 p.m. time slot among adults 18 to 49. Nielsen estimated that it drew an average of 8.3 million viewers. At 9, however, that choral competition ranked second in the hour behind a repeat of CBS's ''Criminal Minds'' (11.6 million). NBC ranked second for the night over all, trailing in third at 10 with ''Journeyman'' (4.6 million), which finished behind ABC's special ''Holiday Celebration at Ford's Theater'' (4.9 million) and CBS's ''CSI: NY'' rerun (11.2 million). CBS led the night over all. ABC and Fox shared third and fourth place, with Fox faring slightly better in the 18-to-49 set.

''Into the Wild,''Sean Penn's film about a doomed young adventurer, captured a leading four nominations on Thursday when the Screen Actors Guild issued its list of contenders for its 14th annual awards. The prizes will be presented at the organization's 75th-anniversary ceremony in Los Angeles on Jan. 27. Emile Hirsch, as the adventurer, was nominated for best actor; Hal Holbrook for male actor in a supporting role and Catherine Keener for female actor in a supporting role. The film was also nominated for outstanding performance by a cast in a motion picture. Other best-actor contenders were George Clooney (''Michael Clayton''), Daniel Day-Lewis (''There Will Be Blood''), Ryan Gosling (''Lars and the Real Girl'') and Viggo Mortensen (''Eastern Promises''). Leading-actress nominees were Cate Blanchett (''Elizabeth: The Golden Age''),Julie Christie (''Away From Her''), Marion Cotillard (''La Vie en Rose''), Angelina Jolie(''A Mighty Heart'') and Ellen Page (''Juno'').

'JOAN BLONDELL: THE BOMBSHELL FROM 91ST STREET' She was never the biggest star or the most celebrated, but Joan Blondell, who started as a contract player for Warner Brothers in 1930, helped provide early talkies with an indelible heroine: the quick-witted city girl who knows the score and her way around a wisecrack. To that template Blondell added her own no-nonsense decency and warmth. ''We were showing something different,'' she said of herself and her frequent co-star James Cagney, ''something fast and to the point.'' In ''Joan Blondell: The Bombshell From 91st Street,'' the Museum of Modern Art pays tribute to her long career with a series of 13 films. On Friday ''Footlight Parade,'' a rapid-fire musical, and the very rarely shown ''Blue Veil'' will be introduced by Matthew Kennedy, the author of a new biography, ''Joan Blondell: A Life Between Takes.''

COLUMBUS, Ohio -- While listening to Florida Coach Billy Donovan after his team got trounced Saturday by Ohio State, 62-49, I couldn't help but think he was going to channel his old mentor Rick Pitino. As he refused to use his team's inexperience as an excuse, I could almost hear that famous Pitino line while he was coach of the Boston Celtics: "Larry Bird is not walking through that door, fans. Kevin McHale is not walking through that door. Robert Parish is not walking through that door. If you expect them to walk through that door, they're going to be gray and old."

The Vikings are riding a five-game winning streak, during which they have won in ways great and small. They beat Oakland with trick plays and the running of Chester Taylor. They pounced on turnovers to rout the Giants and the 49ers. They dominated the Lions. They rallied in the fourth quarter against the Bears. They have won with Adrian Peterson out for two games and running for 100 yards in only one of the other three.

During his time as the quarterback in San Francisco, Jeff Garcia set about writing his name into the record books of the 49ers, a team that has featured Y. A. Tittle, John Brodie, Joe Montana and Steve Young. In 2000, Garcia set team records for completions (355) and passing yards (4,278) in a season, and his 32 touchdown passes in 2001 were the third most in team history.

Re "A Semi-Nude Minor? In The Times?" (Dec. 16): While I can appreciate the fact that T magazine might not have been the most appropriate venue for this photo editorial, it is interesting to see how it has been perceived by so many people.It is also fascinating that people think that they have the right to judge so severely and with such vengeance.Perhaps these are the same people who would not enter an art museum unless the statues were covered in drapes. In Europe, the pictures in question would never elicit the least bit of controversy.There is nothing "minor" about Ali. She is an old soul who is an extremely intelligent, focused, disciplined, responsible young lady. She is as beautiful on the inside as she is on the outside. While she is a few months shy of her 18th birthday, she is more mature than most adults twice her age.She has had the good fortune to work with some of the world's best-known photographers over the past two years, including Paolo Roversi. He is an icon in the fashion industry. While I am with Ali every step of the way, it is not up to me to choose which photographs are to be published. I do not have control over that decision-making process. That said, there is nothing remotely sexual or pornographic about the pictures in the T. In my eyes, they portray a sense of innocence and beauty.To those who have responded to your column by criticizing my daughter and me so vehemently: Please understand that I have my viewpoint, and you have yours. I have to get into the habit of reading the new CBO director's blog -- really important stuff. Anyway, Peter Orszag alerts us to a new study on the VA system, which confirms the system's amazing performance -- high and rising quality (I'm sure someone will chime in with a horror story, but you can find those in any system), delivered relatively cheaply.

Today we have answers to reader questions from Yu Jie, following the ninth article in the series on the the transfer of heavy industry to China from the West. Yu Jie is China Program Advisor for the Heinrich Böll Foundation in Beijing.

The League of Conservation Voters generated quite a bit of buzz on environmental (and journalism) blogs this week after it launched a new campaign pressing America's most-watched political reporters to bring up global warming more often on all those influential Sunday talk shows. The group reviewed videotape of more than 120 interviews of presidential contenders by Chris Wallace, Tim Russert, George Stephanopoulos, Wolf Blitzer and Bob Schieffer this year.
The Sunni Awakening has helped calm one of the most violent provinces of Iraq. But it faces an uncertain future.

The year was about to end without a front-running entry on my list of Most Idiotic Press Releases of the Year. But suddenly a clear winner emerged, a Dec. 14 howler from the Competitive Enterprise Institute. It is entitled, "Senate's New Auto Fuel Standards Will Cost Lives."

OSKALOOSA, Iowa - Senator Barack Obama called on his rival, John Edwards, to distance himself from outside groups that are gearing up to run television ads to promote his candidacy, saying here today: "You can't just talk the talk."
Our final best seller list for political books this year may provide some last-minute gift ideas for those of you with shopping still left to do.

The on-again, off-again pursuit of the Mexican striker Jared Borgetti by Major League Soccer was apparently on again ... until it was off again.

In celebration of the season, T commissioned several artists to create short films on the theme of "giving." The final video to arrive is "How Much to Go to the trees?" Story by Andy Spade, the founder of the Jack Spade men's line; directed by Red Bucket Films.
About a year ago, a college senior and Facebook veteran taught me how to share intimate information on social networks. His first rule was ironclad: "You gotta be transparent about your love life."
