Two reruns of "CSI" and an encore of "Without a Trace" pushed CBS into first place over all in the ratings on Thursday night.
Countdown: Twelve days until Caucus Day. Three shopping days until Christmas. Happy birthday, Paul D. Wolfowitz.
Security and control at the once-contentious border between Germany and Poland ease further, but divisions remain.
Raila Odinga is the leader of Kenya's opposition party, and according to recent polls, he may win the election for president on Dec. 27.
Massive free trade zones like those in Dubai are being used by counterfeiters to smuggle fake drugs from China to Europe and the United States.
Some Kurds say they were pushed to move back to Kirkuk to ensure a high turnout for a referendum whose deadline is about to pass.

KPMG's Golf Advisory Practice has released another round of its Golf Benchmark surveys, covering the state of golf in different regions of the world. The first round included a report on eastern Europe, the fastest growing market in Europe.
The New York Times took another step - a small and unannounced one - into the Internet age last week by eliminating dates from datelines.

We don't really get this in North America, where our pro leagues are chopped up into different little divisions and have elaborately unbalanced schedules. But euro hockey fans and soccer fans everywhere know about those special nights when No. 1 in the league plays No. 2.
By Jon Frosch
Joseph Weisberg has used some of what he learned while training to be a case officer with the Central Intelligence Agency to write his latest novel, “An Ordinary Spy.”
Blake Comeau scored his first career goal to give the Islanders the lead midway through the third period and help his team shake off a recent slump.
Wojtek Wolski tapped in the winning shot 1 minute 16 seconds into overtime Friday night and Milan Hejduk scored twice for the Colorado Avalanche in its 4-3 victory against the visiting Rangers.
Fresh off one of their most inspired victories of the season, and hoping to win two in a row for the first time in nearly a month, the Knicks instead reverted to previous form.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday about two Hollywood producers accused of bribing a Thai official to get contracts to run the Bangkok International Film Festival misidentified the Patricia Green who was arrested with her husband, Gerald. She is Patricia T. Green — not Patricia M. Green, a writer and producer, whose television credits include “Chicago Hope,” “China Beach” and “L.A. Law.”.
On a night Julius Erving and Philadelphia’s 1983 championship team were honored, Andrew Bynum and the Los Angeles Lakers stole the show.

Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich’s chief campaign fund-raiser pleaded not guilty to tax charges and must get treatment for his gambling problem to remain free on bond. The fund-raiser, Christopher Kelly, a roofing contractor, is accused of using his company’s money to pay gambling debts to Las Vegas casinos and Chicago-area bookmakers and of misinforming the Internal Revenue Service about that and other reported misspending, according to the indictment. Mr. Kelly is a friend of Mr. Blagojevich, a Democrat, and was once his point man on Illinois gambling issues, but he was not on the governor’s staff.

Members of the Congressional Black Caucus called on Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco to pardon Mychal Bell and five other teenagers known as the Jena Six. Representative Sheila Jackson-Lee, Democrat of Texas, said in a letter to Ms. Blanco this week that Mr. Bell and the other teenagers have paid their debt to society and should be immediately pardoned. “They and their families have suffered enough, as has the state of Louisiana and the town of Jena,” the letter reads. Fourteen other members of the caucus joined Ms. Jackson-Lee in urging Ms. Blanco to support releasing Mr. Bell, who was sentenced on Dec. 3 to 18 months in a juvenile facility for his role in an assault last year on Justin Barker, a white student at Jena High School. Ms. Blanco’s press secretary, Marie Centanni, said in a statement that the governor could not grant a pardon or a commutation without a recommendation from the State Pardon Board.

A circuit judge struck down a citywide smoking ban in Louisville, saying that an exemption for Churchill Downs was unconstitutional and that the entire ordinance, therefore, was illegal. “Only after voting that Churchill Downs would keep its exemption did the Council pass the smoke-free law,” Judge Steven Ryan wrote. “The converse of this fact is that the Council would not have passed a smoke-free law devoid of said exemption.” A group of business owners, the Metro Louisville Hospitality Coalition, sued to overturn the ban.

A federal judge agreed to let the Bush administration keep secret the lists of visitors to the White House until an appeals court decided whether the documents were public records. The judge, Royce C. Lamberth of Federal District Court, granted the White House request five days after ordering the Secret Service to turn over the records to a liberal watchdog group that sought them under the Freedom of Information Act. The logs, being sought by Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, relate to White House visits regarding nine conservative religious commentators, including James Dobson, Gary Bauer and the Rev. Jerry Falwell.

A military dog wounded in Iraq in the same rocket attack that killed its marine handler was adopted by the slain marine’s family. The family of the marine, Cpl. Dustin Lee, planned to take home the bomb-sniffing dog, an 8-year-old German shepherd named Lex who was granted early retirement. “Nobody can do anything to replace the void in this family,” said Col. Christian Haliday, commander of the Marine Corps Logistics Base in Albany, where Corporal Lee and Lex were assigned. “We hope Lex can bring a small piece of his spirit and help maintain his memory.” Corporal Lee, 20, was killed and Lex was wounded on March 21 in Anbar Province. Corporal Lee’s mother, Rachael, said she believed that her son’s spirit would live on through the dog because of their close bond and because they were together during the final moments of her son’s life. “It was blood on blood,” she said. ”We can’t get Dustin back, but we have Lex.”.
The work of Jay Salpeter, a former New York City homicide detective, was crucial in winning a new trail for a man imprisoned half his life.
The police arrested a group of men planning to attack holy sites around Mecca during the hajj, the annual Muslim pilgrimage, the Interior Ministry said.
The minister of defense caused a media squall after joking about invasions by space aliens and movie monsters.

An Indian doctor once accused of involvement with terrorist bombers in Britain was given back his Australian visa, in the latest chapter in a case that has embarrassed the police, prosecutors and the government.

The British police organization said it was suspending the use of a form of DNA testing criticized by a judge who acquitted the only person charged with murder in Northern Ireland’s deadliest terrorist attack.
A 17-year-old Hamas fighter was shot to death in Gaza near the border with Israel, but the Israeli Army denied that it had anything to do with it.
A DC-3 aircraft chartered by the National Science Foundation crashed while taking off from a remote research site in West Antarctica.
Two men posing as deliverymen entered a building on the Upper West Side on Friday and robbed the occupants of an apartment at gunpoint, the police said.
Sid Fernandez and Pete Rose Jr. became the last two players of note linked to the former Mets clubhouse attendant who provided performance-enhancing drugs to major league players.
When 2012 hits, stores will no longer be able to sell the cheap but inefficient incandescent light bulbs that are fixtures in most homes.
Marsh & McLennan Companies, the insurance broker, said it would replace its embattled chief executive, Michael G. Cherkasky.
Prosecutors say a disbarred Chappaqua lawyer pulled over on a darkened road and “shot his wife once in the back of the head.”
One Equity Partners agreed to sell its stake in Quintiles Transnational, a big manager of clinical drug trials, to its C.E.O. and two buyout firms.
Goldman Sachs agreed to buy a $260.5 million stake in the First Marblehead Corporation, shoring up the troubled student-loan company and sending its stock soaring.

An article on Dec. 5 about the distinctions between Iran’s civilian and military nuclear programs referred incorrectly to an assessment in the new United States national intelligence estimate that Tehran’s nuclear program is now entirely civilian in nature. The document says that American intelligence agencies have moderate — not high — confidence in that judgment.
With more than 100 different patterns of camouflage now available, the American hunter has a lot more thinking to do about his or her appearance in the field.
A brazen robbery and kidnapping ended as just another bungled crime when a group of would-be robbers couldn’t figure out how to remove the cargo containers from the truck they stole.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced the pardon on Friday of a 54-year-old Brooklyn man convicted of robbery 16 years ago, saying the pardon would spare the man from being deported to Jamaica.
Pakistanis need to turn out in force on Election Day to ensure that everybody — not just Pervez Musharraf — can have a say in Pakistan’s future.
Shares of the electronics retailer Circuit City Stores fell sharply after the company reported a wider-than-expected loss.
After announcing plans to mount protests, the president of Pakistan’s Supreme Court Bar Association was hurled into a police truck and told that his son could be shot.
In a victory for Cerberus Capital Management, a  judge  ruled against United Rentals’ petition to force the private equity firm to complete its $4 billion buyout.
A state appeals court overturned the conviction of Martin H. Tankleff in the grisly murders of his parents in 1988.
Rooting out philanthropic hawkers is going to be tough, especially in the age of Internet retailing. For now, the direct route to charity seems best.
A funeral service for Ike Turner followed the same arc as his career. It was all about the music, except in the moments when it was overshadowed by accusations of domestic abuse.
A rich record of employee discontent emerges from question-and-answer sessions at US Airways.
There have been several examples to show that Mitt Romney is prone to exaggeration, taking what is essentially a kernel of truth and stretching it to bolster his case.
The board of the Goldman Sachs Group awarded a $67.9 million bonus to the chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, for 2007, according to a filing with regulators.
Stock markets ended the week with a surge on reports of a possible foreign investment in Merrill Lynch and an uptick in consumer spending.
Lawyers for a dozen Yemeni prisoners being held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, had filed a motion seeking an inquiry that would force the government to explain why it destroyed the tapes.

Harris Mansell scored 15 points — including the go-ahead basket in the final minute — to give Rider a 61-57 victory at Rutgers on Friday night.
Oregon Coach Mike Bellotti, approached by U.C.L.A. in its search for a football coach, said Friday that he was staying put.

With any injury, player safety is our foremost concern. Our approach to treating concussions is conservative and involves a team of specialists including a neurologist, neuropsychologist, and neuroradiologist. No player has been allowed to return to a game unless he is entirely without symptoms; has normal mental status testing; and has a normal neurological examination. Most recently any player who has loss of consciousness is not allowed to return to play regardless of symptoms, results of mental status testing or neurological examination. Medical staff and coaches continue to follow the player through the game and if the status of the player changes, he is removed. Players are expected and encouraged to report their symptoms, both on the day of the game and thereafter. However, in-game decisions are only one component of the process.
A soft-spoken Barry Bonds told a federal judge Friday that he wanted to keep his legal team intact despite a potential conflict of interest.
The 14 people detained were described as Islamic extremists. Belgian authorities said raids in 15 locations, mostly in Brussels, had turned up explosives and arms.
The case of Oscar Ayala-Cornejo is familiar to many illegal immigrants who grew up in the U.S. thinking of themselves as Americans only to have their status catch up with them later in life.

President Bush should provide more financial support to the Food and Drug Administration, which presently has few resources to oversee food safety.

Mr. Capra Jr., the son of the noted Hollywood director Frank Capra, never wanted to go into his father’s business but found in the end he could not resist its pull.

Call it reform or call it revenge, but Congress has just passed a measure to tackle flaws in the Freedom of Information Act process.
Chad Pennington and Laveranues Coles make for an unlikely pair. But somewhere along the way, they became more like brothers than teammates.
Frances Fragos Townsend, who has kept a low political profile as the president’s chief terrorism adviser, will leave office without the battle scars of her West Wing colleagues.
The lawyer for one of the four men charged with killing Sean Taylor said Friday that he was talking with prosecutors about a plea agreement that may include testifying against the others.
Even as the Wall Streeters are high-fiving and ordering up record shipments of Champagne and caviar, the American dream is on life-support.
Four years after being undrafted out of college, left tackle Jason Peters has become a Pro Bowl caliber player for a Bills offensive line that hasn’t given up a sack in three games.
What happened to all the lead-tainted products that have been recalled recently? Most, it turns out, may still be in consumers’ hands.
The leader of a French aid group accused of trying to kidnap 103 African children in Chad told a court that France’s government knew from the start about plans to rescue war orphans from Darfur.
As the N.H.L. tries to promote diversity in the game, the organization has turned to Willie O’Ree, who in 1958 became the N.H.L.’s first black player.
A man who is already serving 74 life sentences in state prison for kidnapping two boys and holding one of them for four years was sentenced Friday to 170 years in federal prison.
Cowboys at Panthers.
A jury Thursday found Harold Berbick, 21, guilty of murder and Kenton Gordon, 19, guilty of manslaughter in the death of former heavyweight champion Trevor Berbick, 54.
Devotional candles, kindled by anyone with a wish or a prayer,  are a lucrative niche in the $2 billion candle market in the United States.
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice issued an unusually sharp rebuke to Taiwan, pointedly calling its planned referendum on United Nations membership “provocative.”
The Internal Revenue Service has banned a year-end investment strategy used to get around the so-called wash sale rules on harvesting tax losses.
There are several examples of how, as governor of Arkansas, Mike Huckabee bristled at public criticism of his clemency decisions.
The Cincinnati Reds traded Josh Hamilton to the Texas Rangers on Friday for pitchers Edinson Volquez and Danny Herrera.
The Long Island jury hearing the manslaughter trial of a black man charged with shooting a white teenager told the judge that it was “hopelessly deadlocked.”
Mike Huckabee produced a legacy in Arkansas like few other Republican governors in the South, but he tended to freeze out anyone who disagreed with his plans.
Officer Alexis Chaparro of the N.Y.P.D. was arraigned on a second-degree murder charge in the shooting death of his fiancée, Officer Sonia Garcia.

Lindsey Vonn of the United States won a women's World Cup downhill Friday at St. Anton am Arlberg, Austria, despite skiing off the course in the first part of the race. Vonn overcame her error and finished the Karel Schranz course in 1 minute 32 seconds for her second victory of the season. Vonn, who won the season-opening downhill in Lake Louise, Alberta, extended her lead in the downhill standings. Kelly Vanderbeek of Canada was second, her best World Cup result, 0.36 of a second behind, and Vonn's teammate Julia Mancuso was third, another 0.02 back.''I don't know what happened,'' Vonn said. ''I had so many mistakes early on and never thought I would post the fastest time. I can't believe this. After five gates I really thought it was all over. But I stayed cool and just tried to go down full speed.''

BUCK--Herbert, 74, died peacefully at home December 19th, 2007. Loving companion of Orlando Rodriguez. Loving father and father-inlaw of James and Alice Buck. Beloved grandfather of James and Allyse. Loving uncle of Lisa, Rick, Christopher and Sarah Greenleaf. Beloved son and brother of the late Gustav and Betty Buck, and Helen Weiss. Wonderful friend to many. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him.

GUGGENHEIM--Hannelies, nee Feibelmann, 86, died Thursday, December 20th in New Rochelle, NY. Loving mother of Steven (Susan), Allan (Lucy) and Ralph (Marsha), grandmother of Abra (Eric), Cynthia and Josh, great-grandmother of Ella. A handweaver, lover of the arts and literature, gifted linguist and avid supporter of Jewish causes, her energy and dedication will be greatly missed. She treasured her entire family and was cherished by them all. Funeral will be Sunday, December 23rd at 10am at Beth El Synagogue, Northfield Road and North Avenue in New Rochelle. Shiva will be observed following the burial Sunday until 8pm and Monday through Wednesday from 2 to 8pm at 110 Bon Air Avenue in New Rochelle. Donations in her memory can be made to the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society (HIAS), Brandeis University National Womens' Committee or the Jewish Guild for the Blind.

The former Olympic ski champion Stein Eriksen remained hospitalized Friday after breaking several bones when he collided with a 9-year-old boy Sunday while skiing in Park City, Utah. A day earlier, 350 people celebrated Eriksen's 80th birthday at the Deer Valley lodge that bears his name.Eriksen, who won a gold and a silver medal for Norway at the 1952 Oslo Olympics, fractured a collarbone and needed wrist surgery, his friend Mark O. Haroldsen told The Salt Lake Tribune. He is at University of Utah Hospital, but his family requested that no other information be released, the hospital spokesman Phil Sahm told The Associated Press on Friday.The accident happened at Deer Valley resort, where Eriksen is the director of skiing.

MINKOFF--Bernard ''Bernie,'' passed away December 19, 2007 after a year long battle with cancer. He graduated from Brooklyn Law School after returning from service in WWII and was an attorney on Long Island until his retirement 11 years ago. Bernie was a long time board member of Temple Beth El in Bellmore, NY. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Sandra; his son Ira, and his wife Lisa; and his grandchildren Perry, Rachel, and Leanne. He was deeply loved and will be missed by all.

(Cinemax) THE GOOD SHEPHERD (2006) Matt Damon, left, plays Edward Wilson, the original company man, in this chilly drama about a spy catcher in the early years of the Central Intelligence Agency. The top-drawer cast includes Angelina Jolie as Wilson's aggrieved wife, Robert DeNiro as one of the agency's founders, William Hurt as its head and Alec Baldwin as an agent for the F.B.I. There are hard questions at the heart of the film, ''but they are also too big, too complex and perhaps too painful,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, ''for even this ambitious (2 hours 37 minutes) project, which can only elude and insinuate, not enlighten and inform.'' 4 P.M. ALCOA TO SELL DIVISIONS Alcoa said late Friday that it will sell its consumer and packaging divisions, which make Reynolds Wrap among other products, to the Rank Group of New Zealand for $2.7 billion in cash. Alcoa said in April that it was considering shedding the units, which have felt a pinch from the same rising commodities prices that have driven profits in the aluminum giant's core operations. And amid massive consolidation within the industry, some analysts have said that overseas rivals with bulging coffers may take advantage of the weaker dollar and acquire the 119-year-old company. The sale may be aimed at warding off would-be buyers. The divisions generated about $3.2 billion in revenue last year, or 10 percent of Alcoa's overall revenues. They employ about 10,000 people in 22 countries. The Rank Group is the investment vehicle of Graeme Hart, one of New Zealand's richest businessmen. It already owns some packaging companies, like Carter Holt Harvey and Evergreen Packaging. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

FORD--Ludlow Boyd, 94, adored and adoring wife of the late Norbert M. Ford, died in peace on December 2, 2007 in Bloomingdale, NJ. Elegant gracious and a careful listener, Luddie was selfless to a fault and devoted her life to family and friends. She laughed easily and made life richer for all who met her. Cherished and dearly loved, her memory will be held deeply in our hearts as an inspiration. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to The Arthritis Foundation or charity of your choice. Memorial Service to be announced.

Will Joba Chamberlain be back in the bullpen for the start of next season? Hank Steinbrenner said Friday that he did not think so, saying that the ''plan at this point is to start him out as a starter.'' An ESPN.com report Friday said the Yankees were leaning toward having Chamberlain spend the first part of next season doing what he did so well in 2007 -- pitching in relief and often serving as the setup man for Mariano Rivera. The report said keeping Chamberlain in the bullpen for part of next season would help limit his innings in his first full year in the majors. Steinbrenner, however, said that was not what he was hearing.

BUSHNELL--Douglas Fountain, passed away peacefully at his home in Hopewell, New Jersey, on December 16, 2007. Born December 4, 1920 in Browntown, New Jersey, he graduated from Rutgers College, and served in a bomb disposal unit in the Navy in World War II. He worked for many years for the American Express Company. He married Margaret Meeker in 1946. After her death in 1970, he married Betty Wold Johnson in 1978. In addition to his wife Betty, he is survived by his sons David and Michael, their spouses Kim and Vera, his daughter, Rebecca, and her spouse John, and his stepchildren Robert, Elizabeth, and Christopher Johnson, and his wife Jane, and 17 grandchildren. Life, for him was a great adventure, and he enjoyed everything he did. He will be remembered by his family and friends for his extraordinary kindness and thoughtfulness. Equally at home on his tractor or the dance floor, he was a consummate gentleman. There will be a memorial service at Princeton University Chapel on December 27, at 2:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made, in his name, to SAVE Princeton Small Animal Rescue League, 900 Herrontown Rd, Princeton, NJ 08540 (www.save - animal s.org) or the charity of your choice. Services are under the direction of the MatherHodge Funeral Home, Princeton.

A review of classified documents by former members of the Sept. 11 commission shows that the panel made repeated and detailed requests to the Central Intelligence Agency in 2003 and 2004 for documents and other information about the interrogation of operatives of Al Qaeda, and were told by a top C.I.A. official that the agency had ''produced or made available for review'' everything that had been requested. The review was conducted earlier this month after the disclosure that in November 2005, the C.I.A. destroyed videotapes documenting the interrogations of two Qaeda operatives.

If global warming is a chief concern for many voters in the 2008 presidential race, an early bout of wintry weather is a chief frustration for many candidates. Iowa was beset Friday by a heavy blanket of fog, which caused the cancellation of several campaign events. Airplanes carrying Senator Barack Obama and former President Bill Clinton circled over Iowa before being diverted to different locations. Mr. Obama wound up in Chicago and drove more than four hours back to eastern Iowa, calling supporters along the way. Mr. Clinton was linked by telephone to an event he could not attend, his voice crackling over the loudspeakers.

MARSHALL--James H. Hofstra University is profoundly saddened by the death of James H. Marshall, president emeritus and former member of the Hofstra University Board of Trustees. Mr. Marshall, an alumnus of Hofstra College and a successful businessman, joined the University's Board of Trustees in 1967, and served until 1975. On September 1, 1972, he assumed the presidency, serving until he welcomed Robert L. Payton as president at a Board meeting on June 20, 1973. When he was designated President Emeritus on May 15, 1975, the trustees noted an ''appreciation for your momentous service to the University in a time of need, for your willingness to accept the heavy responsibilities of the office of President, without compensation and without condition'' and ''your loyalty to the University at a time when it needed such loyalty most of all.'' In tribute to President Emeritus Marshall, all flags have been lowered to half-staff. John D. Miller Chair, Board of Trustees Stuart Rabinowitz President Hofstra University MARSHALL--James Harper/d, born in New York City on July 21, 1931, died on December 16th after a sudden illness. He was a graduate of Hofstra University with a B.A. in English and served in the Korean War. He became a member of Hofstra's Board of Trustees and subsequently served as its President. He was honored to then be named President Emeritus. He held the University in great affection and pride. Jim had a remarkable life, pursuing a wide variety of interests from boxing to business. He was a strong athlete and an accomplished skin diver, working with the TV series ''Flipper''. He enjoyed diving for recreation and exploration, which included the discovery of a train wreck dating from the Civil War off the coast of Eleuthera. He had a deep and abiding interest in golf. His principal career was as a creative financial and investment adviser. His talents were sought by various companies, as well as by individuals. He was a political adviser to the campaign of Robert F. Kennedy for the U. S. Senate in New York in 1964. He was Secretary of Pine Valley Golf Club in New Jersey and a member of Ballybunion in Ireland and Bonita Bay, Quail West and Lake Nona Clubs in Florida. He was formerly a member of Sleepy Hollow Country Club inScarborough, NY. Jim is survived by his wife, Donna Ensign Marshall, and their daughter, Lee Harper Marshall. His extraordinary generosity in myriad forms and his wit and wisdom will be deeply missed by them, joined by a host of his friends, associates and acquaintances. Jim's rare and gentle spirit touched so many. A celebration of his life is being planned by his family for a later date. Please no flowers. If desired, contributions may be made to Hofstra University, Hempstead, NY 11549 or The Summer Station Foundation of Pine Valley Golf Club, Pine Valley, NJ 08021.

A harness driver was convicted of trying to fix a race last year at Cal Expo in Sacramento and faces up to three years in prison and a lifetime ban from horse racing. Daniel Maier, 23, is to be sentenced next month. He was convicted Thursday of bribery, conspiracy and grand theft.Maier did not drive in the race, but he made more than $3,000 in bets, mostly in trifecta combinations. To win a trifecta, a bettor must pick the top three finishers in correct order. Maier was convicted of bribing other drivers to arrange how the horses would finish.

FREUND--Philip. Fordham University Professor Emeritus Philip Freund, a novelist, short-story writer, documentary film writer, television dramatist, essayist and literary critic, died on December 20 at the age of 99, after a short illness.

In a year-end message posted on the International Olympic Committee's Web site, Jacques Rogge, the organization's president, said he wanted tougher action in 2008 against doping and illegal sports betting. Rogge also said that the focus on political and social issues in China would probably increase leading to the Beijing Olympics, with the Games acting as a ''powerful catalyst.''Rogge said he took issue with the notion that sports was losing the fight against drugs because of the many high-profile doping cases in 2007. ''The fact that so many instances of unfair play were revealed, and that more athletes admitted responsibility, tells us that we are on the right track,'' he said.Rogge also cited illegal betting as a threat to the credibility of sports. ''It must be fought in the same aggressive way in which we are fighting against doping,'' he said.

Whatever vulnerability Mike Huckabee has with voters who remain wary of his record as governor of Arkansas he tried to dispel Friday with tough talk about terrorism suspects being held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. Mr. Huckabee, according to CBS News, said how ''disappointing'' it was to learn during a visit he made to Guantánamo that meals for military personnel cost an average $1.60 while the detainees' Halal meals cost more than $4 each.

Ohio State beat Florida, 62-49, in a game so forgettable that the only intriguing subplot was whether the Gators would surpass 46 points, the lowest total since Billy Donovan became coach in 1996.
Thirty-six Florida State players will not be traveling to the Music City Bowl because of an academic cheating scandal, violations of team rules, injuries or other reasons.
A blinding snowstorm blew across the Plains on Saturday, causing at least two deaths and dozens of injuries in numerous multicar pileups and forcing the closing of parts of several major highways.
The FedEx Corporation said it was facing taxes and penalties related to an I.R.S. ruling regarding the classification of independent contractors at its FedEx Ground unit.

Stefan Gimpl of Austria won a Big Air snowboarding World Cup event Saturday in Sofia, Bulgaria. Janne Korpi of Finland, the overall standings leader, was second. The competition was on man-made snow under the lights at a square in Sofia, the capital. “It was a great evening and a great Christmas present for me and my family,” Gimpl said.

Thomas Morgenstern of Austria won the large-hill event Saturday in Engelberg, Switzerland. He is the first ski jumper to open a World Cup season with six victories in a row. He had jumps of 132.5 and 133.0 meters for 260.4 total points, finishing ahead of his compatriot Andreas Kofler.Morgenstern is tied with Janne Ahonen and Matti Hautamaki, each of Finland, for most consecutive victories at any point in a season. He can claim the record for himself Sunday, in another large-hill event.
The A.T.P. suspended Italians Potito Starace and Daniele Bracciali on Saturday for making bets — some as little as $7 — on tennis matches involving other players.

The General Assembly approved a two-year budget of $4.17 billion, with the U.S. casting the only vote against the measure because it included financing for a conference the U.S. felt would be prejudicial to Israel.
Senator Barack Obama urged John Edwards to distance himself from outside groups that are gearing up to run a blitz of television ads promoting his candidacy.
In its third cross-border attack into Iraq within a week, Turkey that its warplanes had killed hundreds of separatist Kurdish rebels. Iraq says no one had been wounded or killed.
Rudolph W. Giuliani provided the most detailed account yet of the health scare that led to his recent hospitalization, saying that he suffered a “terrible headache” but did not black out.

The freshman Kalin Lucas scored a career-high 18 points, including an acrobatic layup to ignite a key first-half run, to lead No. 9 Michigan State to a 78-72 victory against No. 4 Texas on Saturday night in Auburn Hills, Mich.

The ATP suspended the Italians Potito Starace and Daniele Bracciali Saturday for making bets — some as little as $7 — on tennis matches involving other players.The Italian federation denounced the penalties by the governing body as an injustice, and the players said they have been made scapegoats.Starace, ranked 31st, was suspended for six weeks and fined $30,000, the federation said. Bracciali, ranked 258th, was banned for three months and fined $20,000. Both suspensions take effect Jan. 1.The federation said Starace made five bets for a total of $130 two years ago, and Bracciali made about 50 bets of $7 each from 2004 through 2005.

Lindsey Vonn of the United States moved to the top of the women’s World Cup overall standings by winning her second consecutive event, a super-combined Saturday in St. Anton Am Arlberg, Austria.Her teammate Julia Mancuso was third for the second straight race.Vonn, who won the downhill Friday, was the leader after the downhill leg of the combined. She retained the lead with her slalom run and had a total time of 2 minutes 20.28 seconds. She has three World Cup victories this season.Maria Riesch of Germany took second, 0.63 seconds back, and Mancuso was 0.65 behind.Vonn, who had been fourth in the standings, took the lead with 474 points, ahead of Nicole Hosp of Austria (419) and Riesch (389). Mancuso was sixth (364).

Thirty-four Florida State players will not be going to the Dec. 31 Music City Bowl against Kentucky because of an academic cheating scandal, other violations of team rules or injuries.Linebacker Dekoda Watson, cornerback Patrick Robinson, who had six interceptions, and three top defensive tackles were among the players sidelined either as a result of the investigation into an academic cheating scandal at the university or some other violation of team rules.“It is very important that the media make clear that those missing the bowl trip are not included because of either injury or for a violation of team policy,” the associate athletic director Rob Wilson said in a statement accompanying the travel list. “It would be irresponsible to imply or state that any or all of the student-athletes will miss the trip for one particular reason.” The junior quarterback Xavier Lee, who started three games for the Seminoles, was among offensive players not traveling. The offensive line was also hit hard with tackle Caz Piurowski, offensive tackle Damon Rose and guard Jackie Claude not making the trip.A violation of team rules could range from poor class attendance to a run-in with the law or failing a drug test, among many other things.
A judge said there was too little evidence to hold the 14 men accused of plotting to free a supporter of Al Qaeda. Prosecutors said the investigation would continue.

A headline last Sunday with the Ping column, about research partnerships between universities and corporations, referred incorrectly to the status of Bell Labs. Although it is no longer part of AT&T, it has not been discontinued; it is now the research arm of Alcatel-Lucent. An article last Sunday about travelers who seek destinations that they think are ecologically endangered misspelled the surname of the editor in chief of Travel & Leisure. She is Nancy Novogrod, not Novograd.

An article last Sunday about the suicide of Megan Meier, who was the target of a hoax on MySpace, referred incorrectly to statements made by Lori Drew, a neighbor, through her lawyer. An article on Dec. 9 about Moscow as a new luxury destination misstated the cost of a ticket on the city’s metro system in United States currency. The ticket, at 17 rubles, is about 70 cents, at the exchange rate of 25 rubles to the dollar; it is not 7 cents. A picture caption also misidentified the location of a Rolex billboard. It is in the plaza leading to Red Square; it is not in Red Square.

To the Editor: I was terribly disappointed by your piece “Is Bulgaria Really Skiing’s Next Hot Spot?” (Dec. 2). Having traveled extensively in Eastern Europe, I can say with great pride that Bulgaria is exquisitely beautiful: one-third of the country is blessed with mountains, the food is superb — delicious cheese and yogurts, foods laced with nuts and garlic, grilled meats, fresh fruit (above) — and, most importantly, it is home to a most hospitable and generous people.

WELLINGTON--Patricia B., Longtime resident of Locust Valley, NY, died on Thursday December 20, 2007 at the age of 87. Beloved wife of the late Herbert G. Wellington Jr. She is survived by her sons Charles, James (Julie), and William; her sister Elizabeth B. Noyes (David); and her grandchildren Robin, Michael, James and Emily. Service and interment are private.

FORD--Ludlow Boyd, 94, adored and adoring wife of the late Norbert M. Ford, died in peace on December 2, 2007 in Bloomingdale, NJ. Elegant gracious and a careful listener, Luddie was selfless to a fault and devoted her life to family and friends. She laughed easily and made life richer for all who met her. Cherished and dearly loved, her memory will be held deeply in our hearts as an inspiration. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to The Arthritis Foundation or charity of your choice. Memorial Service to be announced.

New York's comptroller, Thomas DiNapoli, one of the most powerful people in the state, came to office in the wrong way. His friends and colleagues in the State Assembly anointed him over numerous more qualified contenders. Nevertheless, Mr. DiNapoli has worked hard to make up for the way he was chosen, devoting his first year in office to reforming his own job in ways that serve the public interest. As things stand now, the comptroller's office can easily be used for the wrong reasons and the wrong purposes. The comptroller is the sole trustee of the state pension funds, now valued around $155 billion. There was a time when investment choices were comparatively simple. Now they are as complex as the economy itself, yet comptrollers operate with little oversight or public notice.

9 P.M. (CBS) IN GOD'S NAME The brothers Jules Naudet, near left, and Gedeon, flanking Imam Muhammad Sayed Tantawi, grand sheikh of Al-Azhar University, focus on spirituality through interviews with 12 of the world's most influential spiritual and religious leaders in this two-hour documentary. The Naudets, who filmed the Emmy Award-winning documentary ''9/11,'' solicited opinions on terrorism and war, as well as on faith, tolerance, unity and peace, from a variety of sources, including Pope Benedict XVI; the Dalai Lama; Alexy II, the head of the Russian Orthodox Church; Grand Ayatollah Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, a Shiite leader; Yona Metzger, Ashkenazi chief rabbi of Israel; Joginder Singh Vedanti, the Sikhs' highest authority; and Dr. Rowan Williams, Archbishop of Canterbury and head of the Church of England. 4 P.M. (NBC) WYNONNA: TRIBUTE ON ICE Kimmie Meissner, the reigning United States figure skating champion, performs to music by Wynonna Judd in this event taped on Nov. 20 in Chicago. Ms. Judd's mother, Naomi, and the skaters Brian Boitano and Evan Lysacek provide backup.

MARSHALL--James H. Hofstra University is profoundly saddened by the death of James H. Marshall, president emeritus and former member of the Hofstra University Board of Trustees. Mr. Marshall, an alumnus of Hofstra College and a successful businessman, joined the University's Board of Trustees in 1967, and served until 1975. On September 1, 1972, he assumed the presidency, serving until he welcomed Robert L. Payton as president at a Board meeting on June 20, 1973. When he was designated President Emeritus on May 15, 1975, the trustees noted an ''appreciation for your momentous service to the University in a time of need, for your willingness to accept the heavy responsibilities of the office of President, without compensation and without condition'' and ''your loyalty to the University at a time when it needed such loyalty most of all.'' In tribute to President Emeritus Marshall, all flags have been lowered to half-staff. John D. Miller Chair, Board of Trustees Stuart Rabinowitz President Hofstra University

DURKIN--Robert B., on December 21st, 2007, of New Hyde Park, NY. Beloved husband of Carol. Loving father of Bobby, John, Christine Durkin and Marion Lindenauer and son-in-law Scott. Caring grandfather of three. Fond brother of Thomas Durkin, Kay Noone and Sheila Mulvey. Robert was an educator for many years. Friends may visit on Saturday and Sunday 2-4:30pm and 7-9:30pm at the New Hyde Park Funeral Home, 506 Lakeville Road, New Hyde Park, NY 11040. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 9:15am, Notre Dame R.C. Church, New Hyde Park, NY. Interment to follow, Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, NY. NHPFH.com. Robert dedicated his life to education and the betterment of today's young people. Robert started his teaching career in Harlem in 1966 and followed up with various posts in schools in Queens. In March of 1992 he became Principal of Washington Irving High School where he managed to transform a faltering institution to a New York City school system success story. He lived by the motto: ''Its all about the kids'' and his family and friends. ''To know Bob Durkin was to love Bob Durkin''.

PICKHOLZ--Esther, 83, on December 22nd, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Rabbi Morris. Devoted mother Sheli, Cheryl Mindy (Howie) and Gary. Bubbie to eight. Professor and Rebbetzin to thousand in New York and Florida. Loving big sister to Rabbis Moshe, Joseph, and Sholom Tendler. Services Sunday 1pm, Riverside Great Neck, 55 North Station Plaza.

OKUN --Daniel A. University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Professor of Environmental Sciences and Engineering, died December 10, 2007, age 90. Okun was hailed worldwide for his groundbreaking work in water supply management, pollution control, and water reuse. His work brought him to 89 countries to contribute to environmental engineering education, training programs, and consulting on a wide range of water projects. Okun was a member of both the National Academy of Engineering and the Institute of Medicine, and he received major awards from every professional organization in water resources and environmental engineering. In August 1999, Engineering NewsRecord named him one of the top 125 engineers who ''singularly and collectively helped shape this nation and the world.'' Survived by his wife Beth; brother, Milton Okun; son, Michael Okun; daughter, Tema Okun; grandsons Will and Joedan Okun. Donations in his memory may be made to the Dan Okun Scholarship Fund at the UNC School of Public Health. For details, www.sph.unc.edu

BORKO--Miriam, died on December 22, 2007 one day shy of her 92nd birthday, after a long illness. Beloved wife of Abraham, loving mother of Diane and Susan, cherished sister and sister-in-law of Arthur and Irene, Samuel and Dorothy, Irving and Irma and Herman and Lillian, adored aunt, great-aunt, and greatgreat-aunt, and special friend to all who knew her. Funeral services Monday December 24, 2007 at Schwartz Brothers Chapel 114-03 Queens Boulevard at 11am. Shiva at her home, Monday night through Sunday afternoon December 30, 2007. Donations to Parkinson's Foundation.

HEIMANN--Margaret (nee Fechheimer), born November 28, 1930, in Cincinnati, Ohio. Died December 22nd. Beloved mother of Joshua and Eliza, grandmother of Alex, Carson, Rachel, Jake and Isabel, mother-in-law of Karen and Jon, former wife of John G. Heimann. Sister of Martha Beerman, Ellin Isenberg, and Nathan Fechheimer. Graduate of Radcliffe 1952, one of the first women editors of the Harvard Crimson and the first Radcliffe Bureau Chief. Her professional career included positions in the administration of Governor Hugh Carey, and the Department of Housing and Community Renewal. She was a passionate advocate and volunteer for the causes she loved most dearly: the United Farm Workers, Central Park and the Big Apple Circus. Memorial service to be held on Friday, January 4th at 2pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street).

Jay Leno, Jon Stewart and other TV comics are returning to work in the new year, their networks have announced -- and without writers if their strike isn't settled. Meantime, Laugh Lines readers have been writing their own jokes: So, there's been all this talk lately about Bush being ''the worst president ever.'' And President Bush is getting pretty steamed about it. Sick of it. He said, ''I don't know about this 'worst president ever' stuff. I mean, come on. They used to say that about Herbert Hoover. Yeah, Hoover, worst president ever. Well -- they don't say that about him anymore.''

AT 10:30 on a blustery cold Saturday morning three and a half weeks before Christmas, the Jones Family Christmas Tree Farm in Shelton is packed with hundreds of cars. Dan and Pam Collins of Rockaway Beach, Queens, with their friend Nicole Twomey and a gaggle of children, are already dragging freshly cut evergreens down the wind-whipped hillside that leads from the farm's 200 acres of trees. ''I just like the whole atmosphere of the park,'' said Ms. Collins, who calculated that she had been coming to cut trees for about 10 years. ''We love the ornaments, we love the winery.''

EHRLICH--Simon B., of Norwalk, CT, age 86, died peacefully December 15. Born February 19, 1921, youngest child of Abraham and Rose Ehrlich, he was a graduate of Boy's High School, Brooklyn, 1938 and NYU, 1948. A WWII veteran who served in the U.S. Marine Corps, 4th Division, he fought in the battles for Iwo Jima, Saipan and Tinian. A Norwalk resident since 1955 and a City Selectman from 1972-1976, he was appointed Chairman of the Norwalk Draft Board in 1967. He was a Vice President of Brown Harris Stevens, Property Management division. An avid sailor, he enjoyed the woods, pond and wildlife on his property. He will be deeply missed by his beloved wife of 57 years, Phyllis, a retired New York Times reporter and editor, daughters Susanna B. Ehrlich of Potomac, Abigail M. Ehrlich of Manhattan, grandchildren Emily, William and John Talbot of Potomac, and Samuel Cohen of Manhattan, and sons-in-law James Talbot and Mark Lyons.

KESEND--Michael, of New York City and Cragsmoor, NY, died Wednesday, December 18th, in his home after a valiant struggle with cancer. Beloved older brother to Ellen and Samuel; son of the late Estelle and Harry; beloved husband of Margaretha and Joyce, both deceased, and ex-wife and constant friend Ursula Bender-Kesend; dear and loyal friend to Alan Damsky, Denise Freiman, John Martin, and people all over the world. Michael was President of Michael Kesend Publishing. He loved life and inspired all who knew him to suck the juice out of it. He traveled the world with boundless curiosity, entertaining people with his stories and lighting up their lives with his laugh, his smile, and his Aegean eyes. We have all been made richer by his presence. A memorial service is planned for January 20th. Donations in Michael's honor may be made to: The Thyroid Cancer Research Fund, Thyroid Cancer Survivors' Association, Inc., P.O. Box 1545, New York, NY 10159-1545 and the Cragsmoor Free Library, P.O. Box 410, Cragsmoor, New York 12420.

STANG--Robert, died on December 14, in his home in Rye, NY age 93. Prior to retiring, he taught in the Marketing Dept of Pace University in Pleasantville. Before that, he earned an MBA at Pace, after a long career in the high fidelity industry in the New York area, both as CEO of United Audio Products and as president of Stang Sales Corp. During the War, he had served as a civilian engineer in the Signal Corps. He was known for his intelligence and quick wit. He is survived by his son, Donald Stang, and daughter - in - law, Helen Wickes, of Oakland, CA; his daughter, Rae, of Mt. Tremper, NY; his son, Michael, of New York, NY; his brother, Arnold, and his wife, JoAnne; and several nieces and nephews. Services were held December 17.

MARSHALL--James Harper, born in New York City on July 21, 1931, died on December 16th after a sudden illness. He was a graduate of Hofstra University with a B.A. in English and served in the Korean War. He became a member of Hofstra's Board of Trustees and subsequently served as its President. He was honored to then be named President Emeritus. He held the University in great affection and pride. Jim had a remarkable life, pursuing a wide variety of interests from boxing to business. He was a strong athlete and an accomplished skin diver, working with the TV series ''Flipper''. He enjoyed diving for recreation and exploration, which included the discovery of a train wreck dating from the Civil War off the coast of Eleuthera. He had a deep and abiding interest in golf. His principal career was as a creative financial and investment adviser. His talents were sought by various companies, as well as by individuals. He was a political adviser to the campaign of Robert F. Kennedy for the U. S. Senate in New York in 1964. He was Secretary of Pine Valley Golf Club in New Jersey and a member of Ballybunion in Ireland and Bonita Bay, Quail West and Lake Nona Clubs in Florida. He was formerly a member of Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, NY. Jim is survived by his wife, Donna Ensign Marshall, and their daughter, Lee Harper Marshall. His extraordinary generosity in myriad forms and his wit and wisdom will be deeply missed by them, joined by a host of his friends, associates and acquaintances. Jim's rare and gentle spirit touched so many. A celebration of his life is being planned by his family for a later date. Please no flowers. If desired, contributions may be made to Hofstra University, Hempstead, NY 11549 or The Summer Station Foundation of Pine Valley Golf Club, Pine Valley, NJ 08021.

With Terrell Owens watching the second half from the locker room, the Dallas Cowboys had to depend on their running game and their defense to avoid a second consecutive upset loss. Tony Romo threw for 257 yards and a touchdown Saturday night and the Cowboys overcame the loss of Owens to a left ankle injury in a 20-13 victory against the Carolina Panthers.

FRIELING--Walter. Each obituary written by New York City newspapers on December 19, 1957, was career-oriented. Today's printed words are in memorial of my father. Only I can write them, knowing well that when finished, it can never be sufficient. Nothing could be. By necessity I must confine myself to a flyspeck perspective of a man with formidable combinations. By nature my father was affable, accommodating, an inveterate optimist -a ''Lebenskunstler''... how else could he have survived those twenty years, from the Great Depression until a few years after WWII, as a registered architect (in Florida, New York and Pennsylvania) with the U.S. building industry flat on its back? He was a man of cheerful humor, who delighted in his family, humanity, life ... and limericks. As a Pied Piper his limber-fingered magic tricks not only astounded children, they also taught them about physics. This music lover was a devotee of symphonic works, grand opera, operettas and was an accomplished pianist. My father was adroit with languages: English (adopted 1907 as his first language,) French, German (his mother tongue,) Latin, ancient Greek, and Nez Perce. An antiquity buff, he met every fortnight, eventually only once a month, with friends (Arnold Brecht, Irwin Edman, Ernest Fox, Gunter Keil, Theodore de Postels, etc.) to sight translate Latin and/or ancient Greek texts. Besides a multitude of other interests he was a devoted husband and a truly splendid parent. His modesty, polished manners, gallantry, unstinting time for his ''two girls'', is what my mother, Rosa Louise Frieling, nee Thollembeek (+ 04-12-02), and I missed most when he suddenly died of a massive heart attack fifty years ago. He gave us anchorage, perspective, and direction. To you, Dad, a fusillade of thank-yous -I shall always follow your tenets.
Razing Trouble in Bernards Township
NEW YORK GOVERNMENT OFFICES Closed.

Faced with a question, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton often begins her answers with a single word: ''Well.'' (As in, ''Well, I've spent 35 years of my life...'') It is hard to tell if it is a verbal tic, a one-syllable pause as she prepares a response, or a Midwesternism that has survived Wellesley, Yale, Arkansas, Washington and New York. Watching Mrs. Clinton's five-day swing across Iowa that has been called her ''likability tour,'' and trying to assess What It All Means for the Democratic presidential candidate, one answer comes easily to mind:
Television Mike Hale

IN 1928 my grandparents built a summer house in northwestern Connecticut, on a wooded hillside overlooking a small lake. Trees cluster closely about its dark rough clapboards and massive chimneys; a stone porch looks out toward the water. It's a refuge, knitted smoothly into the natural world around it. My grandparents left the house to their three children, and while I was growing up, my family always spent a summer month there. Now I own it, and my husband and I are putting in insulation, heat. We're changing little else: it's still the family house, still represents my grandparents, my mother.

Escaped the Holocaust to Scotland with her late husband George Z. Whitehead. Mother of Douglas, Richard, and Roger. Grandmother and great-grandmother to many adoring offspring. A stoic woman. Her memory will remain with all who knew her.

Designed to get across the message that untreated mental disorders hold children ''hostage,'' the ads were made to look like ransom notes. Their texts began ''We have your son''; ''We have your daughter.''

THE NEWS The Federal Reserve proposed barring lenders from making subprime mortgage loans without verifying that borrowers can realistically afford to make the payments, in addition to imposing other checks on risky practices. BEHIND THE NEWS For years, the Fed was reluctant to rein in the dubious lending practices that fueled the housing boom, only to have its hand forced by the collapse of the subprime market this summer. The rules would restrict the use of ''no-doc'' loans, meant originally for self-employed people and others whose income was inconvenient to document. These loans came to be used to push through mortgages with onerous terms for people with little income.

PADOW--Marilyn (nee Rubin), died at the age of 65, on November 24 while hospitalized for a hemorrhagic stroke in Mission Hills, California. Survived by sons Jeremy and Charlie; sister Sarah Schwartz. Donations can be made to Temple Ahavat Shalom, 18200 Rinaldi Place, Northridge, CA 91326.

To put this in terms that Arthur Blank, a founder of Home Depot and now the Atlanta Falcons' owner, may appreciate, he must feel as if he has been hit in the head with a hammer. Over and over again. Blank, a graduate of Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, is by all accounts a nice guy. His great fault may be that he is too trusting, and that he trusted all the wrong people with his team. The fall of the Falcons is complete, in less than two weeks. About as bad a day as Blank could imagine. Michael Vick, the quarterback he loved so much that he lavished a $130 million contract on him, made him the face of the franchise and pushed his wheelchair when he was injured -- is sentenced to 23 months in a federal prison. Vick, above, had lied to Blank's face about his involvement in dogfighting.
BORAS--Stan. On your Birthday, missing you as usual. Arthur, Lindsay, Jon, Bonnie and Sharyn

For families that become homeless in New York City, it is a hard road from shelter back to home. Even after an apartment is found, it must still be turned into a stable home. Parents worry about the toll that it took on their children, the loss of their possessions, and making enough money to safeguard their families in the future.

Rogues Gallery: The recycled T-shirts that are at the core of the Rogues Gallery men's-wear line are sorted, processed, printed and reworked in a warehouse in Portland, Me., by a crew whose backgrounds have little to do with fashion. ''People who gravitate to the project don't really fit in at proper, standard organizations,'' says the Rogues designer, Alex Carleton, a former visual merchandiser for Ralph Lauren who left New York City in search of a heartier lifestyle. ''There's no superficiality, just kids who like to get dirty and listen to loud music and spill paint and dye shirts and make products.'' The Rogues aesthetic is an amalgamation of New England coastal life: the sludgy seascape, the local Slayer fans, Stephen King's American gothic (he was born in Portland) and the woodsy communal feasts Carleton holds in the backyard of his weathered fisherman's cottage. ''People talk about how men's wear is cleaning up,'' says Carleton, who will open the line's first store on the city's waterfront in February. ''Maybe in the urban bubble, but when you get away from that, guys are still grungy. That's interesting to me.'' Alabama Chanin ''I'm as proud of this system as I am of the designs,'' says Natalie Chanin, the woman behind Alabama Chanin, a line of richly embroidered recycled shirts and dresses that are cut, painted and sewn by hand in rural Florence, Ala. Her stitchers, some of whom quilted alongside her grandmothers, are part of a cottage-industry style of manufacturing in which people work out of their homes. ''These ladies can take care of parents or children, or have regular full-time jobs, and stitch in their spare time,'' she says. ''When I was in design school, I would never have told you in a million years that I would be busying myself with labor law,'' she adds. But it hit her that the clothes she envisioned were influenced by her past. ''And if I wanted to get these shirts sewn, the best thing to do would be to come home and find people who knew how to quilt.'' Chanin's headquarters are a pine-paneled office in a brick ranch house that she rents from her aunt; from its windows, she can see the house her grandfather built and where she grew up.

To the Editor: Re ''An Old Master, Still in Development'' by Charles Rosen [Dec. 9]:

KRAIS--Frederick V., Jr. A National Tennis Titlist who won more than 200 sanctioned tournaments during his lifetime, including the USTA National Boys 18 Indoor Championship with Richard Shipp in 1939 and the USTA Eastern Father-Son Championships with his father Frederick V. Krais, Sr. in 1954 and 1957, died Tuesday, December 11th at his home in Lighthouse Point, FL. He was 85 years old. The cause was congestive heart failure. Krais was born on December 2nd, 1922 in Mount Vernon, NY. He was the son of Frederick V. Krais, Sr., a founding member of the United States Lawn Tennis Umpires Association, and his wife Emily Baker Lovell Krais, a descendant of George F. Baker, who was the founder of the First National Bank of New York. Krais was raised in Pelham Manor, NY and began playing tennis at the Pelham Country Club. He won many tournaments as a Junior in both New York and New England, where his family maintained a summer home in Rockport, MA, including the New York State Championship in 1940. He also represented the United States in Junior Davis Cup Competition. Krais graduated from Hackley School in Tarrytown, NY and Fordham University in New York, where he was both Captain and MVP of their outstanding tennis team. He also competed in the National Championships at Forest Hills. Prior to graduating college, Krais served in the Fifth Army in Italy during WWII, for which he received four battle stars. When the war was over, he and Budge Patty paired to win the Mediterranean Doubles Championship, the precursor to the Italian Open which was played in Rome in 1945. After completing college in 1947, Krais spent a year in Florida playing tennis exhibitions, often organized by his cousin Jack March, a close friend of Fred Perry's and well known promoter of the sport, and played with such tennis greats as Donald Budge, Bobby Riggs and Alice Marble. He also won the Bermuda Championship at the Coral Beach Club in 1960. Krais then pursued a career in media sales, working for ABC Network and the Detroit News. He moved to Lighthouse Point, FL in 1983 and retired as President of Communications Publishers, Inc. in 1992. He was a 50 year member of the New York Athletic Club. He was also an active member of the First Presbyterian Church in Pompano Beach, FL, where he served as an Elder, a Stephen Minister and on the Council of the Presbytery of Tropical Florida. A descendant of Captain Benjamin Hallett, who served in the Revolutionary War, and the pilgrim John Howland, Krais was a member of the Sons of the American Revolution; the Society of Colonial Wars; the General Society of the War of 1812; and was serving as Governor of the Isaac Allerton Chapter of the Society of the Mayflower descendants in Palm Beach, FL at the time of his death. He is survived by his daughter, Christine Krais Schott, of Forest Hills Gardens, NY; two grandchildren, Whitney Lovell Schott and Meredith Baker Schott; and his companion of 35 years, Frances Perry Weigel, of Lighthouse Point, FL. His marriage to the former Janet McCarthy ended in divorce. A private graveside service was held on December 14th at the Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, by the Reverend Jack Noble; with Military Honors provided by the Veteran Corps of Artillery in the state of New York, of which Krais was also a longtime member.
Riverdale $265,000 5444 Arlington Avenue, Bronx

ARLT--May MacClaire, reluctantly surrendered life at age 97, on December 21 in Rye, New York. A spirited wife, mother, grandmother and great - grandmother who loved business, politics and art. A retailer at heart, she retired as an account coordinator for Estee Lauder. Wife of the artist Paul Arlt who predeceased her; sister of Catherine M. Courtney of Callao, Virginia and the late Dorothy M. Surrey; mother of Ronay (and son-in-law Richard) Menschel of New York City; grandmother of Charis Drant (and Ryan), Sabina and Celene Menschel; and greatgrandmother of Rowan Drant. MacClaire was a long time resident of Washington, D.C. and summer resident of Nantucket. She will be missed by her family and long remembered for her generosity and determination in life. Services will be private.

Q I recently moved into a brand-new house in a development in Queens. Most houses have the electrical outlets positioned with the opening for the ground pin below and the openings for the two flat prongs above that. But in my house, all the electrical outlets have the ground-pin opening above the opening for the two prongs. The builder tells me that there is no correct way to position the outlets but that having the ground-pin opening on top can prevent shorts. Is this true?
Freedom House's Record To the Editor:

KIMBREL--William Wayne, Jr., Ph.D., literature professor, of South Hadley, MA, Davenport, FL, the world. In Doha, Qatar, on 9 November 2007, age 55. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Loving son of Wanda and Wayne. Dearest brother of Lee, Lynn, Paul, Steve. Deeply valued friend, colleague, teacher. Hemingway and biography specialist. Attended LSU, UMass-Amherst, Oxford University. U.S. Army 1971-1974; ACC deacon; NEH and Fulbright recipient. 30 years teaching in USA, China, FYRM, UAE, TRNC, Lebanon, Kuwait. Co-edited ''Confrontations'' with John Wall: ''The principle of negotiation itself, if conducted on the basis of equality, allays fears and has the potential to forestall violence. It is what philosophical discourse refers to as 'good infinity.''' Funeral was November 20 in Florida. Tentatively 29 February 2008 for Massachusetts memorial. May there truly be a good infinity.

AT 10:30 on a blustery cold Saturday morning three and a half weeks before Christmas, the Jones Family Christmas Tree Farm in Shelton, Conn., is packed with hundreds of cars. Dan and Pam Collins of Rockaway Beach, Queens, with their friend Nicole Twomey and a gaggle of children, are already dragging freshly cut evergreens down the wind-whipped hillside that leads from the farm's 200 acres of trees. ''I just like the whole atmosphere of the park,'' said Ms. Collins, who calculated that she had been coming to cut trees for about 10 years. ''We love the ornaments, we love the winery.''
'We Are as Gods' To the Editor:

As a former Op Ed columnist for this paper and a longtime voice of liberalism who is now 80 years old, you're about to publish an incisive book on the First Amendment, ''Freedom for the Thought That We Hate.'' Why would you write a book about an amendment we already know and love so well? We need to celebrate and understand our unique freedom, and it is unique in this country -- this freedom of speech and press. And I don't actually think we understand it well. Your book recounts the many times the First Amendment has taken a hit, starting with the Sedition Act of 1798, which made it a crime to publish criticism of President Adams. The Federalist Party said the law was needed to prevent French Jacobin terrorists from slipping into the United States. But the real reason was to prosecute pro-Jefferson newspaper editors.

Please call the chapel at 212362-6600 for more information. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Civil Liberties Union, New York Chapter.

Brought to You By . . . To the Editor:

ALGRANT--Roland, on December 19, 2007, peacefully, at the age of 79, in Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. Rolly was a distinguished publisher and dedicated human rights activist, a good and gentle man who lived his life according to the noblest precepts, always with charm, grace and a sense of humor. He will be greatly missed by his wife, Christine, his sons Joseph and Daniel, his daughters-in-law, Lynne and Elise, and his grandchildren Angus, Owen, Isabel and Haley. A memorial service will be held in January 2008. Donations in his memory may be made to the Roland Algrant Fellowship at the Childrens' Rights Division at Human Rights Watch.
To the Editor: Re ''Decongesting the Skies'' (editorial, Dec. 21):

January seems to be a time when everyone escapes to the Caribbean, but we'd like to go off the beaten path and were thinking of Morocco. What will the weather be like in mid-January? And what's the best way to travel among cities in Morocco, particularly for travelers like us, who plan to arrive in and depart from Marrakesh? -- Arlene Fletcher, Washington
GROSS--Fred, on December 21, 2007. Beloved husband of Merle, loving father/stepfather of Sindy and Bruce, Todd and Jill and 12 grandchildren. Loved by all who knew him.

LOUNGING AT THE FAIRY CHIMNEY INN, GOREME, AUG. 16 Michael Holmes, right, 34, an accountant from London, with Kulwinder Singh, 34. ''Two university friends and I were traveling in Turkey for a week. We had heard about Cappadocia's amazing scenery, and the more laid-back pace there provided a perfect counterpoint to Istanbul. One of the highlights of the day was to have a beer and relax on the hotel balcony while watching the sunset over the 'fairy chimney' landscape. The hotel also had its own religious dog who would often sit out with us and would howl in accompaniment to the mosques' call to prayer. At this moment we had just returned from a tour of the area's underground cities. I loved burrowing through the narrow tunnels, although it was harder going for the taller member of our party, who had retired to bed when this picture was taken.''

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Dec. 8, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Perennial sellers are not actively tracked. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

ISESON--Ida. The Yeshiva University Women's Organization is saddened by the loss of Mrs. Ida Iseson, mother of our past National President Judy Kirshenbaum Milstein and Jerry Iseson. Mrs. Iseson and her daughter Judy were honored this year at our Spring Luncheon with the Dor V'Dor Award for outstanding service to YUWO. May her entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dinah Pinczower National Chairman of the Board Harriet Muss and Rebecca Steindecker National Presidium

FremantleMedia, the production company behind "The Price Is Right" and the British version of "American Idol," wants to cash in on recent interest in Web-to-television programming deals.

The finale of ABC's week-long series "Duel" earned a disappointing 6.1 million viewers on Sunday, according to Nielsen's estimates, and ABC ranked third for the night in the ratings. "Duel" was a game show that asked contestants trivia questions and gave them poker-style chips with which to bet on the certainty of their answers.
French luxury goods company LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton said Monday it had concluded a deal with Britain-based media group Pearson to buy France's leading financial newspaper Les Echos.

A Citigroup analyst left a lump of coal for Och-Ziff Capital Management, the hedge fund that went public last month. The analyst, Prashant Bhatia, began covering the fund with a "hold" rating, writing in his research note that Och-Ziff might be facing headwinds for the forseeable future.

-- With the late-night shows sidelined by the writers' strike for another week, Hollywood publicists who have "long regarded late-night television as one of the most important marketing tools" for new movies are suffering from the "couch crunch," Brooks Barnes reports in today's Times. Morning shows and daytime talk shows have taken on even more importance.

In a game that was anything but pretty, the Bengals played the role of spoiler during the Browns' inspiring season. The Columbus Dispatch provides a slideshow of the game, which was more about who made fewer mistakes than who actually played better. Despite the ugly loss, Mary Kay Cabot of The Cleveland Plain-Dealer writes that Browns tight end Kellen Winslow is sure his team is superior to the Titans and should be in the playoffs.

Thanks to everyone for the lively and informative discussion about stores, especially to Llooped for the mention of the Louis stores in Tokyo, as well as the Prada shop (a favorite of mine for its landscape connections), and to Javiello for Moss (true, true), and Jennevive for the San Fran update. And, Georgianna, I couldn't agree with you more about Kiliwatch in Paris. I first saw the name in a Paris Vogue caption and then went to investigate. The place is always mobbed with people (a good sign) and I often find oddball T-shirts and great jeans (for pretty good prices, I might add).

Maxjet Airways said on Monday that it had filed for bankruptcy protection, taking what the all-business class airline called a "drastic measure" because of soaring fuel prices and the deteriorating credit market.

The major source of Merrill Lynch's $6.2 billion cash infusion, announced Monday, was fairly unsurprising: Singapore. It is just the latest Asian country to invest in a troubled financial firm, following China's decision to pour $5 billion into Morgan Stanley.

As 2007 draws to a close, so does the second month of Dot Earth. This 100th post is two things -- a season's greeting and a call for suggestions (more on the suggestions below).

Here at The Caucus, we like holiday carols as much as the next person, but we like politics even more. That's why we want to pass along a few, let's say, alternate holiday songs about the candidates that we found online.

Almost exactly a year after shareholders approved its $17 billion going-private transaction, Harrah's Entertainment said Monday that it has received all the necessary regulatory approvals to complete the deal. Monday's announcement sets the stage for the largest casino operator in the world to delist from the New York Stock Exchange and come under the control of Texas Pacific Group and Apollo Management, two private equity firms.

Merrill Lynch said Monday it will take $6.2 billion in investments from the Singapore government and a mutual fund manager to shore up its capital base, as many analysts expect the investment bank to announce a second consecutive quarterly loss next month.

Can Bo Pelini concentrate on stopping Ohio State's offense as defensive coordinator of L.S.U. while also preparing to restore Nebraska's tradition as the program's new head coach? Cory McCartney of SI.com reports on the challenges Pelini is facing while he momentarily works two jobs.

It's questionable whether the candidates really will be taking a holiday respite this close to the Iowa caucuses, or if their Christmases will be full of behind-the-scenes strategy sessions. Democrats and Republicans alike tried to shake as many hands as possible, the last day before the brief break. The Times's Jeff Zeleny writes that Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton hit the trail especially hard.

People used to hand you a business card and announce their preferred method of communication. They'd say things like this: "The card has my e-mail, but I am much better by phone" or "Even though the office number is there, I really only respond by cell, so let me write it down."
Analysts predict that next year's initial public offerings will include a steady stream of activity, including credit card issuer Visa's $10 billion I.P.O., Reuters reported.
Merrill Lynch, in an effort to raise cash amid mounting mortgage losses, agreed Monday to sell the majority of its capital finance business to General Electric for an undisclosed amount.
Wall Street powerhouse Goldman Sachs has done it again.
In his latest column in The New York Times, Ben Stein, the lawyer, actor and economist, takes another shot at Goldman Sachs for "betraying" its clients' trust.
Hedge funds are scrutinizing their levels of exposure to bank defaults, in a telling reversal of conventional risk management concerns, according to a report in The Financial Times.
Switzerland's banking regulator will investigate how UBS ran up losses in the credit crisis requiring billions of dollars of writedowns, a spokesman for the body was quoted as saying on Sunday.
For Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, one of the leading investors in green tech and a partner with Al Gore, it hasn't exactly been a completely smooth year, CNet News.com says.
Goldman Sachs on Friday agreed to buy a $260.5 million stake in First Marblehead, shoring up the troubled student-loan company and sending its stock soaring.
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts on Friday unveiled a 593 million pound ($1.2 billion) offer for British human resources software maker Northgate Information Solutions despite recent concerns about its debt.

Porsche's takeover of Volkswagen - which began with a surprise 20 percent investment in 2005 and is likely to be completed with a majority stake next year - has inspired all sorts of bromides in the German news media: a David-and-Goliath tale, an audacious power play, a collision of mass and class.
Some of the country's biggest banks have pulled the plug on a plan backed by the Treasury Department to rescue troubled investment vehicles that were leveled by the subprime mortgage crisis.

Rusal, a Russian miner controlled by billionaire Oleg Deripaska, agreed Friday to buy a 25 percent stake, worth about $13 billion, in OJSC MMC Norilsk Nickel and launch a takeover of the business that would create the world's largest aluminum miner.

Two of three former Merrill Lynch executives will be retried as scheduled next month on fraud and conspiracy charges linked to a 1999 deal with Enron, but the third will go it alone at a later date, a federal judge ruled Friday.

While it remains unknown whether Shari Redstone will succeed her father, Sumner Redstone, as chairman of Viacom and CBS, she is stepping up at Chicago-based Midway Games, the struggling video-game publisher he controls.
Alitalia recommended Friday that Air France-KLM, the world's largest airline, should buy the Italian state's controlling stake in the carrier.
Takeover target the Montreal Exchange will become the majority owner of the Boston Options Exchange, in a $52.5 million cash deal announced Friday.

Linn Energy, the Houston-based energy company that doubled its reserves this year by the purchase of Dominion Resources's gas deposits, will buy unspecified oil and gas assets from Lamamco Drilling for $552 million.

York Capital Management, a New York-based hedge fund, is pushing for the sale of Toronto's FNX Mining, amid unprecedented wave of mergers and takeovers in the sector. York, which owns nearly 20 percent of FNX's shares, has now hired investment bankers to find a buyer for the nickel and copper miner.

Lilliputian Systems, a notoriously secretive company developing matchbook-sized fuel cells, has landed $18 million in new funding, according to recent documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The long-awaited and oft-delayed initial public offering of Vietnam's largest state-owned bank is finally under way. The deal for Vietcombank is expected to raise $600 million - or more than the entire market capitalization of the Ho Chi Minh Stock Exchange just two years ago.
Dell, the computer maker, said Friday it agreed to buy The Networked Storage Company, a privately held data-storage consulting firm based in the United Kingdom. Financial terms were not disclosed.
ArcelorMittal, the world's largest steelmaker, announced on Monday two deals, including one in Europe and at least its third in South America this month.

The News Corporation said it would sell eight of its owned-and-operated Fox network affiliated television stations to private equity investment firm Oak Hill Capital Partners for about $1.1 billion in cash.

European venture firm Atlantic Bridge Ventures will have some extra money for Christmas shopping as it notched its second exit of the year, selling portfolio company GloNav to chipmaker NXP Semiconductors for $110 million.
Vermont regulators on Friday rejected a $2.7 billion plan by FairPoint Communications to buy Verizon's landlines in northern New England.

Sheikh Majed Al-Sabah, this week's guest blogger on The Moment, is fashion royalty. Not only is Majed, as he is better known, a member of Kuwaiti royal family (his father is the first cousin of the emir of Kuwait; his mother is the emir's sister), but he is a retail visionary, whose Villa Moda store in Kuwait is the crown jewel in a luxury company that now spans five countries in the region. These days, Majed is a front-row fixture at the fashion shows, but as he recalls in his first post, there was a time when he was lucky to have standing room tickets.

The way the NHL schedule has been set up the last three years, the Eastern and Western Conferences are almost like separate leagues that play only a handful of interlocking games. That arrangement will change next year. Nevertheless, this season the Western Conference has been clearly better in interleague, er, interconference play.

It turns out that next week will not just be about the Patriots' pursuit of perfection.
