The Florida State offensive coordinator Jimbo Fisher said Sunday night that he will stay with the Seminoles, ending speculation that he could become the next coach at West Virginia.“I am a native of West Virginia and I love the state, but I want to make clear that I am staying at Florida State,” Fisher said in a statement.It was announced on Dec. 10 that the 42-year-old Fisher would become the head coach at Florida State after Bobby Bowden, who also had his contract extended for a year.

Missouri Coach Gary Pinkel will receive a $550,000 annual raise, boosting his guaranteed compensation to $1.85 million a year, Athletic Director Mike Alden announced. Pinkel also gets a one-year extension through 2012. Late last season, he was given a $225,000 raise and three-year extension. The announcement comes as No. 7 Missouri (11-2) prepares to face No. 25 Arkansas (8-4) in the Cotton Bowl on Jan. 1 in Dallas.Pinkel, 55, is in his seventh season at Missouri, which was briefly ranked No. 1 in the Bowl Championship Series standings before losing the Big 12 title game to Oklahoma in December.Pinkel is 48-37 at Missouri and 121-74-3 in 17 seasons over all.
Highways were hazardous for holiday travelers on Sunday, and thousands of homes and businesses had no electricity in the Midwest as heavy snow and howling wind swept through the region.
Laveranues Coles said he sat down with Coach Eric Mangini last week, and that Mangini told him that he wanted him to remain a Jet.

Thomas Morgenstern of Austria failed to win a record seventh consecutive event in World Cup ski jumping after finishing third in Engelberg, Switzerland.Morgenstern, the Olympic champion, was beaten by Andreas Kuettel of Switzerland, who won with jumps of 411 feet 9 inches and 446-3 in the large hill for 252.7 points.Austria’s Gregor Schlierenzauer was second with 248.9 points after jumps of 408-6 and 446-3.Morgenstern was third with 408-6 and 442-11 for 246.6 points.Going into the meet, he had become the first skier to post five consecutive victories to start a season.Morgenstern leads the World Cup standings with 660 points.

Real Madrid won, 1-0, at archrival Barcelona to extend its lead in Spanish soccer’s Primera Liga to 7 points.Madrid midfielder Julio Baptista’s 36th-minute goal separated the teams in front of a crowd of 98,000 at the Camp Nou, where Barcelona had won its previous 11 matches this season.“We are playing in a style that allows us to win matches,” Real Madrid Coach Bernd Schuster said in comments posted on his team’s Web site. “We are in a great position right now, but titles are won at the end of the campaign.”Defending champion Madrid enters the midseason break with 41 points from 17 matches. Barcelona has 34 points, with Espanyol a point further back. Villarreal has 32 points and Atletico Madrid 31 points. Espanyol won, 2-1, at Atletico, and Villarreal was held to a 1-1 home draw by Recreativo Huelva.

Alabama Coach Nick Saban’s car struck a downed tree this weekend, but he and his wife were not injured in the one-vehicle accident. The Tuscaloosa police said Saban and his wife, Terry, were driving near the entrance of their neighborhood when their car hit the tree. A police spokesman, Capt. Greg Kosloff, said officers arrived on the scene Saturday night and a report was filled out.

Outfielder So Taguchi, who hit .290 for St. Louis last season, signed a one-year contract with Philadelphia on Sunday.The 38-year-old Taguchi led all National League pinch-hitters with a .406 (13 for 32) batting average.Taguchi played all three outfield positions for the Cardinals in 2007, starting 41 times in center field, 21 times in left field and twice in right.“Taguchi gives our team more defensive versatility in the outfield,” the Phillies assistant general manager Ruben Amaro Jr. said in a statement. “And he has proven over his career that he can get key hits in big situations.”As a member of the World Series champion Cardinals in 2006, Taguchi hit .400 with two homers and four runs batted in in the playoffs. He started three of the five World Series games.

Cristiano Ronaldo scored an 88th-minute penalty to give Manchester United a 2-1 victory against Everton at Old Trafford. The victory kept United within a point of Arsenal, the Premier League leader.Arsenal, which beat Tottenham Hotspur, 2-1, on Saturday, leads the standings with 43 points. United has 42, and Chelsea is third with 34.

An article on Dec. 15 about a construction accident in Manhattan in which an architect, Robert Woo, was seriously injured referred incorrectly, based on information from a neighbor, to his family life. A Miró painting kept in a bank vault for 40 years sold in Paris on Friday for $16.7 million, the highest price ever for one of his works, Agence France-Presse reported, citing the auction house Drouot. The painting, ''Blue Star'' (1927), above, was part of an auction of 10 works by artists including Picasso, Juan Gris and Fernand Léger that fetched a total of $31.3 million. ''Blue Star'' had been expected to bring $7.1 million to $10 million. The works came from the collection of André Lefèvre, a banker and patron of the arts in the first half of the 20th century. According to Drouot they were bought by European collectors.

''National Treasure: Book of Secrets,'' starring Nicolas Cage (right, with Helen Mirren, center, and Diane Kruger) as the heroic archaeologist Ben Franklin Gates, led the way as three new films elbowed into the Top 5 moneymakers at North American theaters on the last weekend before Christmas. ''Treasure'' (distributed by Disney) grossed $45.5 million, according to estimates by the box-office tracking company Media by Numbers. ''Charlie Wilson's War'' (Universal), starring Tom Hanksas a pleasure-loving congressman having a hot time while fighting the cold war, finished in fourth place with $9.6 million, and the third of the newcomers, ''Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street'' (DreamWorks/Paramount), with Johnny Depp as the throat-slitting tonsorial artist, finished fifth with $9.3 million. Second and third places went to two of last week's debutants: ''I Am Legend'' (Warner Brothers) grossed $34.2 million, bringing its two-week total to $137.4 million, and ''Alvin and the Chipmunks'' (Fox) took in $29 million.

Another cloud drifted across plans for a major exhibition of Russian art in London next month. A representative of one of the participating Russian museums said time might run out before Britain could adopt legislation to safeguard the works from lawsuits by descendants of some Russian collectors contending the art was confiscated by the new government after the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917, Agence France-Presse reported, citing the Interfax news agency. In Moscow, Marina Elzesser, the deputy director of the state-run Tretyakov Gallery, said that unless legislation was adopted by early January, it would be impossible to meet the planned Jan. 26 date for the exhibition, ''From Russia: French and Russian Master Paintings 1870-1925,'' at the Royal Academy of Art. The 120 works by French and Russian painters are now on view in Düsseldorf, Germany. ''There is little time,'' Ms. Elzesser said, adding that if the paintings returned to the four museums in Russia that lent them, they would be difficult to reassemble for a London exhibition. ''It's hardly possible,'' she said. Britain's government and the Royal Academy said on Friday that they expected the show to open on time after early passage of the legislative safeguard.

9 P.M. (Sundance) TOUCH THE SOUND (2004) By the time she was a teenager, Evelyn Glennie, right, a piano student, had lost much of her hearing. But instead of abandoning music, she decided to become a percussionist after a teacher suggested she remove her hearing aids and learn to ''feel'' musical intervals by pressing her head to a wall and allowing the vibrations to flow into her hands and arms. This documentary from Thomas Riedelsheimer follows the Grammy Award-winning Ms. Glennie as she plays a snare drum in Grand Central Terminal; jams with the guitarist Fred Frith in Germany and taiko drummers in Japan; and teaches hearing-impaired students in her native Scotland. ''Hearing is a form of touch,'' she says. ''You feel it through your body, and sometimes it almost hits your face.'' 6:45 P.M. (TCM) A CHRISTMAS CAROL(1938) The plummy Dickens classic, with Reginald Owen as Ebenezer Scrooge; Gene Lockhart and his real-life wife, Kathleen, as Bob and Mrs. Cratchit; Terry Kilburn as Tiny Tim; and Lionel Braham, Ann Rutherford and D'Arcy Corrigan as the spirits of Christmas present, past and future, respectively. GARRATY--John A. The American Council of Learned Societies mourns the passing of Professor John A. Garraty, who died in Sag Harbor, New York on December 19th at the age of 87. As the first General Editor of the American National Biography, he helped create one of the premier resources for the study of American history. His enduring contributions to scholarship and learning also include acclaimed textbooks, monographs, and articles, as well as the generations of students whom he taught and inspired. Pauline Yu, President Steven Wheatley, Vice President Mark Carnes, General Editor, American Nat'l Biography

VELAZQUEZ--Alexandria. In loving memory of my beloved mother, Alexandria Velazquesz, born September 18, 1963, who died Thursday, December 20, 2007, of complications from a massive desmoid sarcoma in the chest and neck. Her death followed an on-again, off-again battle with this cancer that began in 1978. In particular, the last three years of her life had been spent continuously fighting this cancer with only one lung, she remaining happy and active against all prediction, until it at last took her life at the mere age of 44. Despite her disease, she remained loving and supportive of her son, literally without fail, regardless of her own struggles. She is greatly missed by her son, Shane Austin Velazquesz, and those who knew her, who could always count on her compassion and understanding. ''Goodnight, sweet dreams, God bless you, I love you.'' Shane

With cheers, tears and Champagne, tens of thousands of fans crowded along 12 blocks of one of the widest boulevards in the world to watch Julio Bocca, the internationally renowned Argentine ballet star, dance into retirement on Saturday night in Buenos Aires, The Associated Press reported. Ending a quarter-century run, Mr. Bocca, 40, above, performed on an open-air stage on Avenido 9 de Julio, reprising classical roles, as well as samba, jazz and tango routines. Organizers estimated the crowd at 300,000 as Mr. Bocca, joined by Eleonora Cassano, his dance partner of 18 years, and accompanied by Mercedes Sosa, Diego Torres and others, fulfilled his plan to end his professional career after a yearlong farewell tour of 11 countries that began in January. ''You reach a certain age where it becomes a lot harder,'' he said in an interview with The Associated Press. At the end he donned a frayed robe from his days with American Ballet Theater as he hugged and kissed friends onstage. He said he intended to continue to direct the Ballet Argentino troupe he established in 1990.

The new year, and all those New Year's resolutions, are just around the corner. Publishers stand ready: ''The Spectrum'' by Dean Ornish, and ''The GenoType Diet'' by Peter J. If resolutions fail, as they often do, people can turn to ''How Not to Look Old: Fast and Effortless Ways to Look 10 Years Younger, 10 Pounds Lighter, 10 Times Better,'' by Charla Krupp, which will be published by Springboard Press in January. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Did you think things couldn't get any more intense in this race for the presidency? Just wait until the day after Christmas. It is hard to imagine a more challenging time for the candidates than the period from Dec. 26 through the Iowa caucuses on Jan. 3. By every measure, many Iowans have not made a final decision about whom to support. So with all that campaign activity about to be packed into a superheated week, any small move -- a good speech or pithy put-down, a misstep or error by a supporter -- could have an outsized impact on the final outcome. If you want to find the candidates after Christmas Day, there really is only one place to look: Iowa. Even two Republicans who had until now made only token efforts in the state -- Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator John McCain -- are planning to spend a few days there.

A wealthy art collector is believed by the police in São Paulo, Brazil, to have commissioned the theft of paintings by Picasso and the Brazilian artist Candido Portinari from Brazil's leading museum of modern art last week, The Associated Press reported. Like the rest of the 8,000 works in the collection of the Museu de Arte Moderna, Picasso's ''Portrait of Suzanne Bloch'' and Portinari's ''Coffee Worker'' were uninsured. ''Insuring all them would be financially unviable,'' Eduardo Cosomano, the museum's spokesman said. Although the police say they believe that the predawn theft by robbers armed with only a crowbar and automobile jack was commissioned, they have not commented further ''so as not to jeopardize the investigation'' said Adriano Monetta, a spokesman for the São Paulo State Public Safety Department. Mr. Cosomano said the museum would reopen on Wednesday and that two international exhibitions would open on schedule, on Jan. 11.

Pulling in $131.9 million, the reunion tour of the Police was the top concert attraction in North America in 2007, Reuters reporting, citing the music industry trade publication Pollstar. But despite that reunion and high-earning reunion tours by Van Halen and Genesis, preliminary data indicated that the results for the year were the worst since 1994. In 2007 the Top 20 tours generated $996 million, a drop of 15.6 percent from 2006. After the Police, this year's top draws were the country star Kenny Chesney ($71.1 million) and the pop idol Justin Timberlake ($70.6 million). They were followed by Celine Dion, whose engagement at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas brought in $65.3 million, and Van Halen ($56.7 million). A bonanza for scalpers, the Hannah Montana tour, starring Miley Cyrus, finished 15th, with $36 million.

Like the campaigns, most pollsters are taking a break for Christmas, making this a good time to evaluate where Iowa voters stand. Though Iowa remains the trickiest of states for polling, two new statewide telephone polls released last week found that both races were tight, but that considerable numbers of likely caucusgoers were still undecided. Among the Republicans, Mike Huckabee and Mitt Romney are leading by a significant margin, according to polls by CNN and ABC News/The Washington Post.

Globalization may have been the buzzword of the nineties, but for a select few, the world was a very small place several decades earlier. Poolside With Slim Aarons (Abrams) gives a voyeuristic peek into the lives of the jet-lagged jet-set at play, in the days before budget airlines and package holidays. C.Z. Guest, Lilly Pulitzer, Peter Beard and Cheryl Tiegs make suntanned appearances, but the real stars are the locations: private summer residences in Palm Beach, Porto Ercole, Puerto Vallarta, Monaco, and Costa Smeralda, as well as famous hotels like Acapulco's Las Brisas and La Concha, the Hotel du Cap in Antibes and Villa d'Este on Lake Como.

Five million Americans are living with Alzheimer's disease, and at least 66,000 die of it every year, making Alzheimer's the nation's sixth leading cause of death. By 2050, as many as 16 million Americans may be afflicted, yet, as the Times reports, researchers have been unable to find even modestly effective treatments.

Sheikh Majed Al-Sabah, this week's guest blogger on The Moment, is fashion royalty. Not only is Majed, as he is better known, a member of Kuwaiti royal family (his father is the first cousin of the emir of Kuwait; his mother is the emir's sister), but he is a retail visionary, whose Villa Moda store in Kuwait is the crown jewel in a luxury company that now spans five countries in the region. In today's post, he looks at the commodification of youth culture in the Arab-speaking world.

North Carolina State point guard Farnold Degand is out for the season with a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee. Degand, a sophomore, had started all 10 games for the Wolfpack (7-3) this season and was averaging 6.9 points, 3.2 rebounds and 28.6 minutes. He led the Wolfpack in assists and 3-point shooting.

San Jose forward Ryane Clowe was arrested early Monday morning on suspicion of drunken driving in Los Gatos, Calif. Clowe, who has been out of the lineup after having knee surgery, is the second Sharks player in two seasons to be arrested on that charge, despite a policy to reimburse Sharks players or staff members for a taxi or car service if they need transportation.

Defensive end Jonal Saint-Dic and linebacker SirDarean Adams, both seniors, are among five Michigan State players who will sit out the Champs Sports Bowl on Friday against No. 14 Boston College because of academic or other violations.The Spartans said Monday that Saint-Dic was academically ineligible, along with wide receiver and return specialist Terry Love, wide receiver/cornerback T. J. Williams and offensive guard Abre Leggins. Adams violated unspecified team rules.

The injured Louisville center David Padgett has been cleared to work out and could be back when the Cardinals face West Virginia next month, Coach Rick Pitino said Monday. Padgett, a fifth-year senior who fractured his right knee Nov. 18, was expected to miss up to 10 weeks and possibly the entire season.

After an absence of nearly four years, the Connecticut women’s basketball team is back at No. 1 in the rankings. The Huskies received 49 of the 50 first-place votes in the Associated Press poll after being No. 2 all season. Tennessee had been No. 1 since the preseason poll, but lost to Stanford, 73-69, in overtime Saturday night.The Lady Vols fell to No. 3. Stanford received the other first-place vote, moving to No. 2 from No. 5.Connecticut last held the top spot Feb. 23, 2004. The time away from the top ranking was the longest drought in Coach Geno Auriemma’s career, since Connecticut first reached No. 1 on Jan. 17, 1995. Connecticut has now held the top spot 95 times. Only Tennessee has held it more. The Huskies (9-0) have been winning by an average of 40 points this season.

Rhode Island made it into the Associated Press men’s college basketball poll for the first time in nine years, entering at No. 25 after the program’s best start since the 1991-92 season. The Rams (11-1) were last ranked briefly in November 1998.For the fourth consecutive week, North Carolina, Memphis and Kansas were the top three teams in the rankings. Losses last week by No. 4 Texas, No. 5 Georgetown and No. 6 Duke moved Washington State (11-0) up three spots to No. 4, the highest ranking in team history.
It is all but certain that the Knicks tandem of Eddy Curry and Zach Randolph will be broken up - a move that many say should have happened long ago.

The online game operator Giant Interactive Group said that it would buy back up to $200 million worth of American depositary shares. The company plans to fund the repurchases from available working capital, it said in a statement.

Air Canada said it had been included in the European Commission’s investigation into price fixing on freight services. The airline added that it might suffer a liability as a result. Air Canada, Canada’s biggest airline, said it was cooperating with investigators. It said it had received an official charge sheet, which sets out the commission’s preliminary assessment in its investigation into suspected anticompetitive cargo pricing activities. The activities include the levying of certain fuel surcharges by a number of airlines and cargo operators in breach of antitrust laws. The European Commission last week charged several airlines, including British Airways , Lufthansa and SAS, with fixing freight service prices. Cathay Pacific and Singapore Airlines said they too had received a notice from the commission.

Temasek Holdings, the biggest shareholder in Standard Chartered, increased its stake in the British bank to 18 percent, increasing the financial services investments in its $100 billion portfolio. Temasek bought 12 million shares of Standard Chartered, raising its holding by one percentage point, the bank said in a filing. Standard Chartered gets most of its profit from Asia and spent more than $2.7 billion since 2006 on acquisitions, including Hsinchu International Bank in Taiwan and Union Bank Ltd. in Pakistan. The shares purchased by Temasek, worth £220 million ($436 million), lift the total holding to 253.7 million shares.

An agreement has been reached on the sale of Cheyne Finance, a structured investment vehicle now known as S.I.V. Portfolio, to bidders including Goldman Sachs, the fund’s receivers, Deloitte & Touche said. The $7 billion S.I.V. Portfolio, managed by the hedge fund Cheyne Capital Management, went into receivership in September. The agreement comes after talks with a number of bidders over the last few weeks and consultation with the informal creditors’ committees, Deloitte said. Under the deal, certain reinvestment opportunities will be offered to some existing creditors of the company. S.I.V.’s, held by banks, hedge funds or other institutions, issue a mixture of short-term debt and capital and buy longer-term assets, which may pay more interest than the amount they pay on their notes. The vehicles encountered trouble in August when liquidity in the credit markets dried up as investors faced exposure to the subprime market.

Home prices in Britain fell the most in three years in December, and the threat of more declines may cause the property market to seize up in 2008, said Hometrack Ltd., a London-based research group. The average cost of a home in England and Wales slipped for a third month, dropping 0.3 percent to £175,200 ($348,350). “The second half of the year has seen a major reversal in confidence,” Richard Donnell, director for research at Hometrack, said in a statement. “Just as the financial markets have faced a liquidity squeeze, so the housing market is in danger of facing its own liquidity squeeze.” Prices increased 3 percent from a year earlier, the least in 18 months, Hometrack said.

The country’s banking regulator is planning to find out how UBS racked up $10 billion in write-downs related to the subprime lending problems in the United States. “We have to look how the situation got so far” into a loss, a spokesman for the Federal Banking Commission, Alain Bichsel, said. “It’s our job.” On Dec. 10, UBS announced the largest subprime write-downs by any European bank and said it would raise $16.8 billion to improve its financial strength. Mr. Bichsel said that the bank’s response to the losses was “very good” and that UBS would not face an “investigation in the legal sense.” There is no evidence of any wrongdoing by UBS, Europe’s largest bank by assets, he added. A spokesman for UBS, Serge Steiner, declined to comment.

The Canadian National Railway Company extended its reach further into Alberta’s oil sands region with a deal to buy and rebuild the struggling Athabasca Northern Railway. CN Rail will pay 25 million Canadian dollars for Athabasca Northern and pay 135 million Canadian dollars over the next three years to rebuild the 202-mile rail line under a long-term agreement with three major shippers. The Athabasca Northern had been threatened with abandonment because of deteriorating tracks. It was owned by Cando Contracting.
At the Church of the Transfiguration in Chinatown an Italian-American priest reviewed his homily, to be delivered in Cantonese and English – just two of the languages spoken there.
Two dead Bengal tiger cubs have been found in a refrigerator at a zoo in China, where the animals’ body parts are prized as medicine.
Islam A. Karimov won a third seven-year term as president with 88 percent of the vote in weekend voting, Uzbek election officials said.
Four members of a French family, including two children, were killed by gunmen during a robbery in eastern Mauritania, the police said.
The Turkish police prevented a bomb attack in Istanbul, arresting a 25-year-old man with explosives in his backpack outside a subway station, the city’s governor said.
A 38-year-old man appeared in a London court, charged with preparing a terrorist attack.
This fall, the Neediest Cases Fund also helped Jay, a 17-year-old former gang member, with his rent so he could make ends meet with only one job, leaving him time to study for school.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the selection of a new leader by the Liberal Democrats in Britain misstated the span over which the country’s two main parties have dominated the government. Since 1922 — not 1992 — every British election has been won by either Labor or the Conservatives.

The California Supreme Court ruled Monday that privately owned shopping malls cannot stop protesters from demonstrating there to urge a boycott of one of the tenants.

Toy retailers across the country have largely pushed sleds and toboggans off their shelves and out of their catalog pages, victims of warmer weather and the changing taste of children.

Air France-KLM Group, the world’s largest airline, agreed to buy the regional carrier VLM Airlines to expand its business travel to London. Air France is buying the airline from Panta Holdings.
Maxjet Airways, which flew between London and three United States cities, took what it called a “drastic measure” because of soaring fuel prices and the deteriorating credit market.

SHANGHAI — Morgan Stanley, the investment bank, and the Chinese government said Monday that the bank had determined the range of prices to be used when China’s international investment fund converts $5 billion in securities into Morgan Stanley stock.

HOLIDAY TRAVEL More than 65 million Americans will travel 50 miles or more from home during the Christmas-New Year’s holiday period, about the same as last year, AAA says. The automobile club said that that gas prices and air fares would be “well above last year’s levels.” Domestic air fares are averaging more than 15 percent higher than fares at the same time last year, and gas prices are up an average of 70 cents a gallon. Rates at midlevel hotels are 4 percent higher than they were at Christmas last year and 9 percent higher than at New Year’s. But average car-rental rates are 4 percent lower this Christmas and are expected to be 13 percent lower for New Year’s, AAA said.
American military officials said there was an understanding that Turkey would notify the American Embassy in Ankara before attacking Kurdish rebels. And in this case, that did not happen.

KASLOFF--Steven, 55, of Los Angeles, formerly of Manhattan, on December 23, 2007. Partner of Anthony Mendez. Son of Lawrence and Yvette Reiser Kasloff. Brother of Stewart Kasloff and Nadine Bennett. Funeral to be announced at Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, NJ.

A true force who outlived early adulthood, the Depression, several wars, three siblings and evolving parenting techniques. Funeral services to be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Rockville Centre, Long Island, at 11:30am on December 26. A fighter till the end, she lived as she wanted to always. May she dance with Edward again soon.

Tofias and Alissa E. Tofias, great-grandfather to Zoe Asher Sward. He is also survived by his sister Sylvia Levy, his two sisters-inlaw, his brother-in-law and many nieces and nephews. He will be greatly missed by all who were fortunate to know him. Funeral will be Wednesday, December 26, at 12:30pm at Temple Israel Center, 280 Old Mamaroneck Road, White Plains, NY. Donations to Sarasota Memorial Hospital or White Plains Hospital.

Podcast: Scheduled to appear this week are Barry Day, the editor of ''The Letters of Noel Coward''; Brad Stone on unmasking Fake Steve Jobs; Rachel Donadio on the Naples Mafia; and Dwight Garner with best-seller news. Peter Gabriel is restarting his record label, Real World, with a new collaborative album and a slew of reissues. Newly distributed in the United States by Ryko, Real World will make its entire catalog available online and rerelease some of its albums on CD, with bonus material. The label's first new project is Big Blue Ball, a group that includes Mr. Gabriel and Karl Wallinger of World Party. The album, due in May, has been in the works for 15 years, and the first single, ''Whole Thing,'' went on sale on iTunes last Tuesday. Real World's catalog includes albums by Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan, Sheila Chandra, the Blind Boys of Alabama, Papa Wemba and others.

A sports article on Sunday about the evolving relationship of Kobe Bryant with his Los Angeles Lakers teammates referred incorrectly in some copies to a criminal case he was involved in four seasons ago. He faced a sexual-assault charge, which was eventually dropped -- not a sexual harassment charge.

Columnist for Parents Magazine and owner of America House Gallery in Tenafly, NJ, she also volunteered for land preservation groups in Rhode Island and at Planned Parenthood of New Jersey for many years. Memorial service at Christ Episcopal Church, Westerly, RI, December 27, at 1pm. Donations to South County Conservency, P.O. Box 1387, Charlestown, RI 02813, or to: www.nrdconline.org

Thieves made off with two statues from a high-security cargo area at the international airport in Dhaka, Bangladesh; they were to be flown to France for an exhibition, The Associated Press reported on Monday. The terra-cotta statues of Vishnu, among the most revered Hindu deities, were stolen late on Sunday, said Ayub Quadri, Bangladesh's cultural affairs adviser. Mr. Quadri said the government was tightening controls along the border with India to prevent the statues, believed to be about 1,500 years old, from being smuggled out of the country. They were among 143 artifacts that Bangladesh had agreed to send to France for an exhibition at the Guimet Museum in Paris. Police detained 12 airport employees for questioning after the theft, including cargo handlers and airport security staff. Two of those detained were later released. The statues -- a bust and a full-length depiction of Vishnu -- were housed at the National Museum in Dhaka.

A group of scientists is making an unusual foray into presidential politics, calling on the candidates, Republican and Democratic, to hold at least one debate focusing on the environment, medicine and health, technology policy and other science-related subjects. The group, ScienceDebate2008, said in a statement that voters needed to know candidates' views on science, given that ''science and technology lie at the center of a very large number of the policy issues facing our nation and the world.''

MORE AID FROM ABROADMerrill Lynch has agreed to sell $5 billion in new stock to an investor from Singapore and a smaller stake to a domestic firm, joining other companies hurt by the mortgage crisis that are seeking financial help from foreign governments. DEAL HELPS STOCKS RISE That billion-dollar deal by Merrill Lynch with the Singapore government set off a small rally among financial companies, pushing stock markets higher and increasing hopes that America's investment firms will find comfort in the form of wealthy foreign investors. The Dow Jones industrial average rose nearly 100 points, or 0.73 percent, to close at 13,549.33. [C1.]

Trevor Nunn, director of the forthcoming musical based on ''Gone With the Wind,'' has cast his Scarlett O'Hara, Playbill reported. She is Jill Paice, below, an American actress currently starring on Broadway in ''Curtains.'' Based on Margaret Mitchell's novel, ''Gone With the Wind,'' it is scheduled to open in London at the New London Theater on April 22. Ms. Paice created the role of Laura Fairlie in Mr. Nunn's production of ''The Woman in White,'' based on the novel by Wilkie Collins, which ran at the Palace Theater in London and on Broadway.

ZIRN--Benjamin Howard, of Highland Park, Illinois, age 82, died peacefully on December 23rd, 2007. Born February 16th, 1925, in Brooklyn, New York, eldest son of the late Bertha and Abraham Zirn. He was a graduate of Erasmus Hall, Brooklyn, New York and Syracuse University (B.I.E., M.B.A.). A decorated WWII Veteran, he served in the Engineering Combat Battalion in the Central Europe and Rhineland Campaigns. He will be deeply missed by his beloved wife of 50 years, Marilyn (Rosenthal). He was the proud father of Dr. Jonathan (Lauren), Ruth Hillary (Robert) Rosenfeld, and Alison Zirn (Scott Greenberg) who will forever remember him with love and admiration. He will be adored always by his cherished grandchildren Nicholas, Juliet, and Micah Zirn and Hannah, Jeremy, Eve, and Liza Rosenfeld. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Pl. SW, Washington, D.C., 20024 or to the Jewish United Fund of Metropolitan Chicago, 30 S. A post in The Medium that appeared on Monday about the Republican presidential candidate Ron Paul and his purported adoption by white supremacist and neo-Nazi groups contained several errors. Stormfront, which describes itself as a "white nationalist" Internet community, did not give money to Ron Paul's presidential campaign; according to Jesse Benton, a spokesman for Paul's campaign, it was Don Black, the founder of Stormfront, who donated $500 to Paul. The original post also repeated a string of assertions by Bill White, the commander of the American National Socialist Workers Party, including the allegation that Paul meets regularly "with members of the Stormfront set, American Renaissance, the Institute for Historic Review and others" at a restaurant in Arlington, Va. Paul never attended these dinners, according to Benton, who also says that Paul has never knowingly met Bill White. Norman Singleton, a congressional aide in Paul's office, says that he met Bill White at a dinner gathering of conservatives several years ago, after which Singleton expressed his indignation at the views espoused by White to the organizer of the dinner. The original post should not have been published with these unverified assertions and without any response from Paul.

My sentiments are less for the players -- who are compensated well enough that holiday work is hardly too much to ask -- but for the people who work in arenas across the country for more meager salaries. A few years ago, I covered an N.F.L. game on Christmas (in Detroit, no less) and watched as hundreds of folks directed cars in the frigid parking lot and pulled hot dogs from boilers and thought, this is so not a good way to make them spend a holiday.

The Wizard of Odds has highlighted an interesting story regarding the soap opera surrounding Rich Rodriguez's departure from West Virginia. Last week, John Pruett, a sports columnist for The Huntsville Times in Alabama wrote a column that basically said boosters should not be a part of the hiring process for a coach. Pruett later received a call from Ken Kendrick, the managing general partner of the Arizona Diamondbacks and a prominent West Virginia graduate and booster. Kendrick was extremely critical of the Mountaineers' athletic department, saying that incompetence and stonewalling had led to Rodriguez's departure, not greed on Rodriguez's account.

DAVIS--John H, of Alpine, NJ, died December 19 after a long battle with cancer. He was 80. Born in Marion, IL, to Sofia and Chester Davis, he graduated from the University of Illinois and served in the US Army in the Philippines. One of the most influential and admired people in academic publishing, John began his career with Prentice-Hall, Inc., where he rose from sales rep to President of the College Division. Following the acquisition of Prentice-Hall by Simon & Schuster, John was named President of its Education Group. He then joined Thomson Corp. as Chairman and CEO of International Thomson Publishing. John served as Chairman of the Board of Columbia University Press and was the first recipient of the Association of American Publishers Frank Enenbach Award. He is survived by his wife, Melinda Davis; by his children, Christopher, Alan, Emory, and Stuart Davis; by his grandchildren, Rebecca and Madeleine Davis; and by his stepdaughter, Andrea Kimball. A memorial service will be held on January 19, 2008. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Salvation Army, c/o Nancy Wellbrock, P.O. Box 3170, Union, NJ 07083.

Lunch with a view of Bryant Park and the Public Library can now be had without braving the cold, at Café Zaiya, on the second floor of the Kinokuniya bookstore, which opened a couple of months ago at 1073 Avenue of the Americas (41st Street). The cafe is a branch of the larger Café Zaiya at 18 East 41st Street. Minimalist and modern in décor, it offers Japanese bento box lunches (vegetarian, chicken, fish; $5.25 to $6.75), simple sandwiches (ham, egg salad, B.L.T.; $2.95 to $3.95) and more elaborate combos like smoked salmon with avocado and wasabi mayonnaise on baguette ($6.95).

Lodge, the restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that has an adjoining General Store, has expanded its empire with Urban Rustic near McCarren Park. This large store displays its merchandise on hand-milled wood shelving, contributing to its countrified pedigree. There is an emphasis on organics, produce labeled with the local farms that grew it, cheeses from the Northeast and Hardwick grass-fed beef from New England. Baked goods are made in-house or come from Amy's Bread. A counter for sandwiches ($4.50 to $9) and, in the back, bare wood tables for eating in complete the picture: 236 North 12th Street (Driggs Avenue), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 388-9444.

The French have figured out how to get olive oil into a creamy state that can be spread on bread or toast. The secret is the addition of monoglycerides, emulsifiers that give the oil its smooth, semisolid texture. A L'Olivier makes the spreads, which have no trans fats, in four styles: plain with a bit of green olive bite; garlic and herb, which is perfect for making garlic bread; deeply herbaceous basil; and lemon, my favorite, with a delicious bright flavor. A dollop of any of these would be a nice last-minute addition to a plate of pasta.

Hall (94 years), niece of Sr. Joan Fitzgibbons, loving sister to Tim, Judy and Toby, died at her home in Brooklyn at age 63. She will be missed greatly by all of the faculty and staff and by the generations of students who benefited from her extraordinary teaching and mentoring.

The Titans' playoff formula is straightforward. If they win Sunday night at Indianapolis, they're in. Indianapolis is expected to offer an assist of sorts by resting some starters. ''They have a No. 2? For real? I've never seen that guy.''

As mixes go, the Barefoot Contessa's Homemade Marshmallow Mix makes more demands on a cook than most. A heavy-duty stand mixer is essential, unless you want to hold a portable electric mixer for 10 minutes or so. A candy thermometer, or some familiarity with the stages that sugar passes through as it boils, is also necessary. Most of the ingredients, like gelatin, sugar, salt and confectioners' sugar, are pantry staples that are on the ingredient list in most marshmallow recipes. But this package saves you the trouble of measuring to make nearly 100 cloudlike confections to float in your cocoa or to toast lightly -- they're less sturdy than the store-bought kind.

ACKERMAN--Beatrice. We mourn the passing of Bea, mother of Bill, our partner, and grande dame of all the Ackermans. We will miss this great lady. Ackerman, Levine, Cullen, Brickman & Limmer ACKERMAN--Beatrice M. A New Yorker by birth, a ''Vermonter'' by choice, this 97 year old lived her life to its fullest and enjoyed her three children and their spouses, ten grandchildren, sixteen great-grandchildren up to her last days. She loved her family, loved poetry, nature and her home on Lake Dunmore, Vermont where she summered for over 60 years. Widow of Sidney Ackerman, together they were active members of the Jewish Center of Jackson Heights where she served as President of the Sisterhood. More recently she spent her winters in Boca Raton where she was a past president of Amit and an active member of Hadassah. She most recently resided at the Atria in Riverdale where in a short time her sense of humor and friendliness earned her some new friends and afforded the opportunity to enjoy visits from loving children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, all of whom will feel the loss of their beloved ''Nana''/''Gigi''.

FEERICK--Raymond J., 65, BS, MA. Beloved father, grandfather, and teacher died in New York City on December 22, 2007. Having given almost 40 years of his life to Saint David's School, most recently as Assistant to the Headmaster and Chair of the Religion Department, Ray was still working when he began to lose ground against the cancer that had plagued him for 6 years. He finally succumbed to his disease at Calvary Hospital. His family is relieved that his suffering is over. In his last moments, he worried about how to tell his preschool grandchildren, Shannon and Quinn, that he was dying. After he had passed away, Shannon seemed to understand: ''Well,'' she said, ''we'll see him again in Heaven, right?'' He would have answered her with a resounding ''Yes.''

DANN--Louise C. (Weasie), of Pound Ridge, NY and New York City, died December 25, 2007. Beloved wife of Michael Dann; adored mother of Peter Hess (Debbie), Tom Hess (Georgi) and Jill Hess (Jim); stepmother of Jon, Patty and Priscilla Dann (Joe). Cherished grandmother of Rachel, Sara, Carly, Camey, Allie and Jamie. Born in New York City on April 21, 1927, daughter of Norman and Janet Cohen, Weasie attended Horace Mann and Bradford Junior College. Despite a childhood bout with polio, Weasie became a versatile athlete, a passionate world traveler, a superb chef and a talented artist who loved teaching at the Isabel O'Neil Studio Workshop for the Art of the Painted Finish. A caring and loving wife, mother and grandmother--and devoted friend to many--Weasie had a natural gift for being interested in what others had to say and bringing family together. The tremendous courage she demonstrated in her three year battle with post-polio syndrome and cancer is an inspiration to us all. She will be in our hearts forever. Services at Temple Emanu-El, One East 65th Street, on Friday, December 28th at 10 am.

COFFEE--Mary Morse, 88, died December 25, 2007. For over 65 years, the devoted wife of J. Collins Coffee, mother of John, Robert and Richard, grandmother of Megan, Kerry, Clark and John Barton. A civic and community leader in the Manhasset area, she was the first woman trustee of the Village of Plandome, a director of the first economic development and antipoverty corporation established in the Town of North Hempstead, and a longtime leader and Director Emeritus of the Plandome Womans Club. Born in Troy, New York, in 1919, she graduated from Albany High School and St. Rose College and proudly traced her ancestry back to the Morse family that settled in New England in the mid-17th century. Relied upon by many, she gave much more than she received.

New York City is headed toward having fewer than 500 homicides this year, by far the lowest number in a 12-month period since reliable Police Department statistics became available in 1963, when there were 548 killings. It was only minutes after the gunshots that killed Benazir Bhutto rang out on a street in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, that word of the assassination began to spread through the quiet blocks of Midwood, a Brooklyn neighborhood with a significant Pakistani population.From house to house, corner to corner, the news circulated through streets where Urdu signs hang in storefront windows and bakeries serve sweet Pakistani cakes. Some people called relatives in Karachi or Islamabad to hear firsthand reports of civil disturbances that followed the assassination. Others gathered in Pakistani restaurants to watch news broadcasts that showed the turbulence.

I set to work last night at 11 p.m. -- I'm a perennially early sleeper -- with my lunch happily digested a few minutes before. I still had five solid hours before I'd get sleepy, I knew (I tend to go to bed every evening at around 9 p.m.); and with everyone around me asleep, or on their way to dreams, I felt I had the whole world to myself. It's become the shadow present that gives itself to me every holiday season -- or at least the challenge that I, like many of us, have to try to turn into a blessing.

Sheikh Majed Al-Sabah, this week's guest blogger on The Moment, is fashion royalty. Not only is Majed, as he is better known, a member of Kuwaiti royal family (his father is the first cousin of the emir of Kuwait; his mother is the emir's sister), but he is a retail visionary, whose Villa Moda store in Kuwait is the crown jewel in a luxury company that now spans five countries in the region. In today's post, Majed shows how luxury in the Middle East is a nebulous concept that extends beyond the shopping mall.The nomadic Arabs called "The Bedouins" were pastoralists who moved their herds from place to place in search of water, securing spots throughout the Arabian Peninsula. They lived in small, tightly-knit hereditary tribes. They were known for their hospitality, pride, courage and endurance. Their precarious, wandering existence demanded these traits, given that they had to tend to their sheep, camels and goats, as well having to protect their extended family and honored tribal rules. They lived in Sadu tents made out of camel wool, which the Bedouin women wove, and they survived on the livestock and the dairy products they carried with them.
The Times remembers some of the most notable figures who passed from the scene in 2007.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Wednesday about Broadway box office grosses for the week ending Dec. 16 referred incompletely to the gross for “The Homecoming,” at the Cort Theater. Although the play grossed just $165,679 and saw an attendance rate of less than 40 percent, it was in previews until Dec. 16. (In the week ending Dec. 23 its gross increased nearly 50 percent, to $247,572, and attendance was just over 50 percent of capacity, an increase of 30 percent over the previous week. ).

Because of an editing error, a sports article by The Associated Press on Saturday about convictions in the October 2006 killing of the former heavyweight boxing champion Trevor Berbick misidentified the location where his body was found. It was in the parish of Portland, Jamaica — not in Portland, Ore. (The article carried a dateline of Kingston, Jamaica.).

A unit of Bayer AG recalled diabetes test strips used with its Contour TS Blood Glucose Meter because they may result in 5 percent to 17 percent higher blood glucose readings, the Food and Drug Administration said. Bayer Diabetes Care said that the strips were produced on new equipment and that the company had fixed the problem. Fifty-three production lots were affected by the recall, totaling 230,000 bottles of strips, a Bayer spokeswoman said. Details about the strips’ product code and lot numbers were posted on the Food and Drug Administration’s Web site, www.fda.gov/oc/po/firmrecalls/bayer12_07.html.

Paris Hilton’s potential inheritance sharply diminished after her grandfather Barron Hilton announced plans to donate 97 percent of his $2.3 billion fortune to charity. That wealth includes $1.2 billion Mr. Hilton stands to earn from the recent sale of the Hilton Hotels Corporation and the pending sale of the world’s biggest casino company, Harrah’s Entertainment Inc. That money will be placed in a charitable trust that will eventually benefit the Conrad N. Hilton Foundation, raising its total value to about $4.5 billion, the foundation said. Paris Hilton was not immediately available for comment.

A federal judge has struck down a key provision of a new San Francisco program to provide basic health care for uninsured residents. The city was set to begin requiring employers with more than 20 workers to start subsidizing the health plan on Jan. 2. But the judge, Jeffrey Wright of Federal District Court, ruled that the mandate would violate a 1974 federal law designed to prevent inconsistencies in the coverage afforded employees who work for the same company but live in different jurisdictions.

Hawkins, left state care, with his father saying the boy would “have to stand or fall on his own.” A judge released case worker reports, a psychological evaluation, a letter to the court from Mr. Hawkins’s father, Ron Hawkins, and 11 transcripts of Mr. Hawkins’s earlier court proceedings after motions were filed by several news organizations. GRIPPED by last-minute holiday fever, shoppers thronged Macy’s on the weekend before Christmas, pouncing on the announcement that the store would stay open around the clock. Visitors, and even a few rebellious staffers, were tricked out for the occasion like 24 Hour Party People. Tweaking a store tradition that asks employees to dress in black, Jose Benavidez (below, second from left) brightened up his uniform with a fuchsia scarf he had bought on the street. His colleague, JJ Martin (far left, middle), patrolled the makeup counter wearing fingerless gloves, a studded cuff and a generous daub of lip gloss. Plaid caps and Peruvian knitwear were de rigueur. But one dapper gent (far left, top) broke with form by flaunting a rep tie and a rakish beret. “I dress this way every day of my life,” he said. “I’m a fashion designer in my heart.”.

ROESSNER--Gilbert G., of Spring Lake, NJ, a longtime resident of Summit, NJ and North Palm Beach, FL, died Sunday, December 23, at the age of 89. The former chairman and CEO of CityFed Financial Corp., he was a noted authority on housing, education and health policy, and served on numerous boards and commissions at both the state and national levels. He was a chairman of the New Jersey Board of Higher Education, a director of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, and a president of Overlook Hospital in Summit. Mr. Roessner also represented the U.S. State Department as an international housing consultant to the governments of Jordan, Ivory Coast and Columbia. He is survived by his loving wife, Dorothy Hector Roessner, of Spring Lake, and their six children: D. Anne Roessner Atherton (and her husband Rick Atherton) of Nantucket, MA; Martha M. Roessner of Brandford, CT; Gilbert G. Roessner Jr. (and his wife Sue Roessner) of Basking Ridge, NJ; Jane Roessner of Newton Highlands, MA; Barbara T. Roessner of West Hartford, Conn and Katherine K. Roessner of Mystic, CT. He also leaves fifteen grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Born in Irvington, NJ, to the late Emma D. and John K. Roessner, he grew up in Union, NJ, and attended Union public schools before earning a degree in Business Administration from Rutgers University. During Word War II Mr. Roessner was a commanding officer in the U.S. Navy, serving in both the Atlantic and Pacific theaters after graduating from U.S. Navy Midshipman School In New York City, Sub Chaser Training School in Miami, and Fleet Sound School in Key West, FL. After the war, he began his banking career as a mortgage officer at City Federal Savings and Loan Association in Elizabeth, NJ. He retired as chairman and CEO of CityFed Financial Corp. in 1986. Long active in New Jersey politics and civic affairs, Mr. Roessner's public service included the following: president, Union County Park Commission, 1963-1964; delegate, Republican National Convention, 1968; chairman, Commission on Fine Arts, Kean College, 1970 - 1971; chairman, Governor's Commission on Professional Health Services, 1979; chairman, Governor's Commission for Pension Study, 19821983. He also held many leadership positions within the banking industry, including president of the National Council of Savings Institutions from 1972-1974, and member of President Ronald Reagan's Housing Policy Task Force in 1980. An avid sailor, Mr. Roessner was a member of the the Edgartown Yacht Club on Martha's Vineyard, Mass., and the New York Yacht Club in Manhattan and Newport, RI. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held Thursday, December 27, at 9:30am, at St. Catharine's Cathedral in Spring Lake. Interment will follow at 2pm at St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Cemetery in Summit. Donations may be made in Mr. Roessner's name to the Overlook Hospital Foundation, 36 Upper Overlook Road, P.O. Box 220, Summit, NJ. 07902. Services by William A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, Chatham, NJ.

SOBHANI--Reverend SeyedAgha (Peter), 92, passed on Christmas, after a lifetime of service to the Iranian Christian community. Born in Shiraz, Iran, he converted to Christianity as a young man. He served as an evangelist with the Presbyterian Evangelical Church of Iran, in Tehran and throughout Iran, and as evangelist at the Christian Hospital of Isfahan. He later served as Pastor of the Presbyterian Evangelical Church in Tehran. Due to religious persecution after the Islamic Revolution, he left Iran. In 1982, the US granted him humanitarian parole to settle in New York, where he was ordained as a Presbyterian Minister and later became a US citizen. Reverend Sobhani continued to serve the Iranian Christian community in America for the next 25 years. He is survived by his wife, Hilda, of 60 years, and by three daughters, six grandchildren and three great - grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, White Plains, NY on Thursday, December 27, 2007 at 2:00pm.

A caring and loving wife, mother and grandmother--and devoted friend to many--Weasie had a natural gift for being interested in what others had to say and bringing family together. The tremendous courage she demonstrated in her three year battle with post-polio syndrome and cancer is an inspiration to us all. She will be in our hearts forever. HIGH-END hockey skates made the leap from ice age to space age about five years ago when high-tech composites, new nylons and sophisticated synthetics began replacing the leather and plastic of yore. Air Astana, a venture between the Kazakh government and BAE Systems, agreed to buy nine Airbus and Boeing jetliners to help meet surging travel demand in Kazakhstan. DRESSLER--Fred M., A prominent and well-regarded executive in the cable industry, died on December 24, 2007, after several months of battling pancreatic cancer. He was 66. Recently retired as Executive Vice President of Programming at Time Warner Cable, Mr. Dressler first joined the cable TV business in 1976 and spent the next 30 years in various executive positions with Time Warner Cable and its predecessor company, American Television & Communications Corporation (ATC). In his early years in the business, he managed cable systems in Shreveport, LA, Fresno, CA and Denver, CO before rising through the executive ranks at the company's corporate offices. He had a reputation as a tough, but honest and fair negotiator with programming networks seeking distribution on cable, which earned him various sobriquets within the industry, including the dean of MSO programming executives. Many in the cable industry also regard Mr. Dressler as a mentor. When he retired at the end of 2006, Mr. Dressler was toasted at multiple industry gatherings and continued to consult and advise for a variety of media firms, including the BBC, Crown Media Holdings, MusicNet, Retirement Living TV, and Univision. According to Andy Heller, Turner Network Sales President of Domestic Distribution, ''Fred was quite simply a great teacher, mentor and friend. His continuous acts of selflessness have left their mark on me and countless others in the industry. He constantly thought about my personal and professional growth. He always gave me the tools and the opportunity to prove myself and then stepped back in the shadows, giving me the platform to shine on my own. I will continue to strive to be the same kind of mentor to others as he was to me.'' Mr. Dressler's stance on programming issues was often regarded as the blueprint which others in the cable business followed. One of the areas in which Mr. Dressler led the industry was on establishing a dedicated digital sports tier on cable for high-priced sports networks. He became one of cable's most vocal and consistent critics on the rising costs of sports rights. Negotiating opponents and colleagues seem to agree that Mr. Dressler simply loved the game. Mr. Dressler helped champion many of the new technologies that provided additional ways to serve up video content to consumers. He is credited with helping push Time Warner Cable faster into video-on-demand, personal video recorders and high-definition programming than other major cable operators. Many cable networks owe their creation, at least in part, to Mr. Dressler, who championed unique content and niche programming throughout his 20-year tenure heading up Time Warner Cable's programming operation. He was a founder of E! Entertainment, Sun Sports Network in Florida, SportsNet New York and the In-Demand Network. Mr. Dressler was also active at his alma mater, Syracuse University, where he graduated in 1963. He served as chairman of the advisory board of the S.I. Newhouse School of Public Communications. In May 2005, he was awarded a Lifetime Achievement Award from the school. On that occasion, New Yorker magazine writer Ken Auletta noted that ''Many of you are here tonight to honor Fred Dressler, and theres actually a good reason for it. The reason is fear. If you want to get on TV, be nice to this cable godfather.'' Prior to entering the cable business he also had a distinguished career in the newspaper, wire service, radio and television business ranging from writer, editor and on-air journalist to executive producer. It was during his early days covering Denver City Hall that Mr. Dressler got introduced to Bill Daniels, a legendary cable pioneer, which connected him up with ATC, the cable company that would later become Time Warner Cable. He was born and raised in New York City, the son of Martin and Anne Dressler. His father was in the advertising business and it was presumed he might follow that course. The news business, however, attracted his attention while still a student at Syracuse University. Mr. Dressler was an avid tennis player and devoted sports fan. At one point, soon after college, he tried out for the Philadelphia Phillies major league baseball team. Mr. Dressler is survived by his wife Patricia Armstrong Dressler, who produces educational programs through EduCable L.L.C. He is also survived by his parents, Anne and Martin Dressler of Marlboro, NJ; a sister, Susan Dressler of New York City; his son Douglas and daughter-in-law Terra of Denver; son Kevin and daughter-inlaw Courtney, also of Denver; and three grandchildren: Lauren, six, Katharine, two and Hailey, one. The family asked that friends and family wishing to make donations on his behalf direct their contributions to Syracuse University's S.I. Newhouse School, the Smilow Cancer Hospital, which will be part of the YaleNew Haven Hospital complex, or the American Cancer Society. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service for friends and family will be announced at a later time.

Robert Kuo, a Los Angeles artist known for his cloisonné and lacquer work, has just opened a 4,000-square-foot furniture and decorative accessories store in SoHo. Designed by New York-based TEK Architects, the showroom has 18-foot ceilings, huge street-level windows and a one-and-a-half-ton wall of copper repoussé, a hand-hammered relief technique that can be seen in many of Mr. Kuo's cabinets and tables. The store carries playful decorative objects like giant lacquer vegetables and copper-and-lacquer snails, as well as contemporary furniture like the H-Shaped Arm Rest Chair ($9,450), top right, covered with 60 coats of lacquer, and the cream lacquer Dong Shan tables ($4,500), above left.

Once upon a time, autocratic types like Millicent Fenwick, the Vogue editor responsible for the 1948 Vogue Book of Etiquette, provided exhaustive information on how to live and behave. Mrs. Fenwick, for example, had strong ideas about what she deemed undesirable, including table lighters in the shape of airplanes or Scotties, lamps with tassels on the light cord and Tudor mullioned windows (''a very tea-shoppe touch''). Who knows what she might have made of the coffee body scrub recipe given by Colin Cowie, the South African party planner who has joined the ranks of Martha Stewart, Alexandra Stoddard and Mrs. Fenwick herself, with a new book, ''Colin Cowie Chic: The Guide to Life as It Should Be'' (Clarkson Potter; $30). Mr. Cowie's modern etiquette primer also includes instructions on what color to paint your kitchen (deep red or chocolate brown), how to fire an employee and how many chickens to keep in your freezer (12, organic). Also what kind of ice cubes to put in what drinks (star-shaped ones in mixed drinks and ''long sexy cylinders for vodka and tequila''). PENELOPE GREEN

The deadly steam pipe explosion that shook Midtown Manhattan on July 18 was caused by a combination of heavy rainfall, leaks in underground water and sewer pipes and debris that clogged two critical devices intended to let water out of the steam main, according to an extensive investigation by two consulting companies hired by Consolidated Edison.

When I told a friend I was writing about one of the guys who maintains the light bulbs on the Brooklyn Bridge, he replied, “Oh, like the Gay Talese story about the guy who runs the Times Square news ticker?” That article carried no byline and was published on the editorial page on Nov. 2, 1953, so I hadn’t read it, but it offers an interesting lesson: for so many city icons that you imagine have always been the way they are, there is somebody behind the scenes keeping them going.

Yesterday, I hung out for a good portion of the day at Comme des Garcons, talking to folks. Despite the impression of surprise and playfulness left by the Comme des Garcons shops, which are designed by Rei Kawakubo and Toshiaki Oshiba (a collaboration that goes back more than 30 years), the headquarters are a no-frills, no-nonsense workspace: cutting tables, mannequins, offices, what you might expect. Tao Kurihara is warm, thoughtful, slightly impish and easy to talk to. She is no pushover, I felt. Tao giggled with something like alarm when I casually asked what she's planning for her fall show. Such information is a secret at Comme des Garcons; nobody knows what the different studios are working on until their respective shows, in Paris, and everybody at CdG respects that.

I'm still trying to get used to blogging, and the part that's most difficult is knowing that sometimes I'll just be flat wrong. At the magazine, we have a team of outstanding fact-checkers and a ton of time (and, even then, small mistakes happen); with the blog, it's often just my memory and me. The cool thing is that you have instantaneous feedback from readers who keep you honest, and that was the case yesterday, when a few commenters pointed out-rather gently, I thought-that Arkansas is not in fact between the Mississippi and the Missouri rivers. Bodies of water are always the clues that doom me in the Sunday crossword puzzle, so I should have known enough to consult a map. Anyway, my sincere thanks for pointing out the error.

In 1980, a woman I knew in Detroit reported her Ford Pinto stolen. Her insurance company turned down her claim for reimbursement of its value on what I considered novel grounds: No one would steal a car that ugly. That turned out to be a smart call by her insurance adjuster. She later confessed that she and some friends had pushed it into the Detroit River. (At least in a watery grave, it was no longer a danger to explode.) I guess in Detroit, the car theft capital of the world, the insurance industry is savvy enough to know what is worth stealing, and what is not.

A front-page article on Dec. 13 about a collective malaise in Italy misspelled the surname of a columnist for Corriere della Sera, a leading Italian newspaper, who commented that many people feel helpless about the country’s problems. The columnist is Beppe Severgnini, not Severnigni. The article also referred imprecisely to the 102 cabinet ministerial appointments made by Prime Minister Romano Prodi last year. While that number was a record and reflected the unwieldy nature of Mr. Prodi’s nine-party coalition, as the article noted, the 102 appointments included deputy ministers, not just cabinet ministers.

An article in The Arts on Dec. 17 about the radio host Michael Savage and a call for advertisers to boycott his program because of remarks he made about Muslims referred incorrectly to a telephone call he took in 2003 in which he said he hoped the caller, who had identified himself as gay, would die of AIDS. The call was made to the television show Mr. Savage had on MSNBC; it was not made to his radio show.

An article in Business Day on Thursday about the digitizing of government documents misstated the background of Pierre Omidyar, whose Omidyar Network is helping to finance the project. He is the sole founder of eBay, not “one of the founders.”.

An article in The Arts on Dec. 12 about the announcement of a trip by the New York Philharmonic to North Korea in February referred imprecisely to a work by the composer John Adams that was alluded to by Zarin Mehta, the orchestra’s president, when he commented on the program for the concert in North Korea. While some themes in the work, “The Chairman Dances,” are also heard in Mr. Adams’s opera “Nixon in China,” it is not an excerpt from the opera.

The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about corporate philanthropy in Minneapolis-St. Paul, misstated the names of two organizations involved in charitable work in the area. They are the Minnesota Council on Foundations, not the Minneapolis Council on Foundations and Twin Cities Rise, not Twin Cities Rising. The column also referred incorrectly to financing of a pedestrian bridge over an interstate highway. The bridge — the Irene Hixon Whitney Bridge, which crosses I-94 to connect the Walker Art Center to the city’s park system — was built with donations from the Whitney family and others. Dayton-Hudson, a predecessor to the Target Corporation, did not build the bridge.

Last year, three million to four million people filed in January using those forms, it said.

A teenager who pleaded guilty to killing one man and wounding another in a series of 2006 Indiana highway sniper shootings was sentenced Thursday to 42 years in prison. Defense lawyers tried to portray the defendant, Zachariah Blanton, 18, as troubled and the victim of teasing, but the judge said his emotional problems were no excuse for killing someone he had never met. Prosecutors said Mr. Blanton fired his hunting rifle into Interstate 65 traffic on July 23, 2006, from an overpass about 60 miles south of Indianapolis, killing Jerry L. Ross, 40, of New Albany. An Iowa man traveling in a pickup truck was injured. Mr. Blanton pleaded guilty this month to voluntary manslaughter with a deadly weapon and criminal recklessness.

DANN--Louise C. (Weasie), of Pound Ridge, NY and New York City, died December 25, 2007. Beloved wife of Michael Dann; adored mother of Peter Hess (Debbie), Tom Hess (Georgi) and Jill Hess (Jim); stepmother of Jon, Patty and Priscilla Dann (Joe). Cherished grandmother of Rachel, Sara, Carly, Camey, Allie and Jamie. Born in New York City on April 21, 1927, daughter of Norman and Janet Cohen, Weasie attended Horace Mann and Bradford Junior College. Despite a childhood bout with polio, Weasie became a versatile athlete, a passionate world traveler, a superb chef and a talented artist who loved teaching at the Isabel O'Neil Studio Workshop for the Art of the Painted Finish. A caring and loving wife, mother and grandmother--and devoted friend to many--Weasie had a natural gift for being interested in what others had to say and bringing family together. The tremendous courage she demonstrated in her three year battle with post-polio syndrome and cancer is an inspiration to us all. She will be in our hearts forever. Services Friday, December 28th, 10 am at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street. DANN--Louise. We miss you and love you. You will always be in our heart. Alice and Lou Weiss

WOLFSIE--Joan. A life-long resident of New Rochelle passed away Tuesday December 25th, 2007, she was 89 years old. Joan was born on December 12th, 1918 in New Rochelle and was the loving wife of the late Arnold Wolfsie. She is survived by her three devoted children, Dick Wolfsie of Indianapolis, IN, Linda Simon of Great Neck, NY, Peter Wolfsie of New Rochelle, NY and her loving grandchildren Barry Simon, Erica Simon and Brett Wolfsie. Contributions can be made to the charity of your choice.

The Sydney yacht Wild Oats XI became the first yacht in nearly 60 years to win the Sydney to Hobart race three times in a row. Wild Oats, skippered by Mark Richards, crossed the line at Constitution Dock in Hobart on Friday to finish the 628-nautical-mile (723-mile) race in 1 day 21 hours 24 minutes. The finish was closer than expected, with the second-place British yacht City Index expected to finish about 30 minutes behind after trailing during the race by up to 20 nautical miles.The Australian yacht Ichi Ban was expected to finish third and Skandia, the 2003 line honors winner, which broke its mast overnight Thursday, fourth. The American yacht Rosebud, owned and skippered by Roger Sturgeon, was expected to finish fifth later Friday.

TRIO DA PAZ Effervescence comes easily to Trio da Paz, a coalition of Brazilians in New York established more than 15 years ago. The group's members -- Romero Lubambo on guitar, Nilson Matta on bass and Duduka Da Fonseca on drums -- bring high spirits and spring-heeled grace to the prospect of samba jazz. (The hybrid term is theirs.) In performance, even more strikingly than on a handful of winsome albums, they deliver the sort of virtuoso intensity that lights up the best bebop. If the playing weren't so thoughtful and so seemingly effortless, it might even be too much. Each musician in the band has made his mark on the New York jazz scene as a sideman and a leader. Mr. Da Fonseca has a brisk and rewarding album called ''Samba Jazz in Black & White'' (Zoho), and Mr. Matta recently released a guest-laden showcase, ''Walking With My Bass'' (Blue Toucan). Mr. Lubambo, one of the most dynamic nylon-string guitarists working anywhere in the vicinity of jazz, has done especially fine work with vocalists, including Luciana Souza and Dianne Reeves. (He figures prominently on Ms. Souza's exquisite ''Brazilian Duos'' and its equally fine sequel, both on Sunnyside.)

KREZ--Denice Rassas, 60, of New York City, formerly of Winnetka, IL, died at home December 25, 2007. Partner in the New York law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft. Former Neonatal Nurse Administrator at Presbyterian-St. Luke and Prentice Women's Hospitals in Chicago and Neonatal Nurse at Georgetown University Hospital. Beloved daughter of Frances (nee McGuire) and the late George J. Rassas, Sr. Dear sister of Most Reverend George J. Rassas, Jr., Auxiliary Bishop of Chicago Nicholas C. Rassas, Margot F. Rassas, Kevin (Susie) Rassas and Deirdre R. (Justin F., Sr.) Zubrod. No visitation. Funeral mass 10:30am Saturday, December 29 at S. S. Faith, Hope & Charity Church, Winnetka, IL (www.faithhope.org). Interment -All Saints Cemetery, Des Plaines, IL. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Elizabeth Seton Pediatric Center, 590 Avenue of the Americas, NY, NY 10011. KREZ--Denice R. The attorneys and staff of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft LLP mourn the passing of our partner and colleague, Denice R. Krez, and extend sincere condolences to her family and friends. A trusted advisor to hospitals, nursing homes, home health agencies, managed care organizations, and associations of health care providers, Ms. Krez provided legal counsel on a broad spectrum of complex transactions and reimbursement, quality of care, and compliance matters. A neonatal intensive care nurse for more than 12 years prior to entering the legal profession, Ms. Krez was committed to her clients and the patients they serve. Her caring and compassion impacted us all. We will miss her vigor, friendship, and dedication.

Outfielder Darin Erstad signed a one-year contract Thursday worth $1 million plus incentives with the Houston Astros. The 33-year-old Erstad, a two-time All Star in 11 seasons with the Angels, hit .248 with 4 homers and 32 runs batted in last season in 87 games for the Chicago White Sox. He is a career .284 hitter with 118 home runs and 657 R.B.I.Erstad is the latest addition to a revamped outfield. Center fielder Hunter Pence is moving to right to make room for Michael Bourn, acquired from Philadelphia. The Astros dealt right fielder Luke Scott to Baltimore in the trade for Miguel Tejada. Carlos Lee is in left.

Fox's broadcast of the movie ''Christmas With the Kranks'' attracted 7.2 million viewers on Wednesday, Nielsens estimated, a relatively small audience but enough to lead the other networks among adults 18 to 49. NBC ranked second in that demographic while edging past Fox in total viewers. NBC got a boost from repeats of ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' at 9 p.m. (7.8 million) and 10 (8.7 million). CBS finished third as its broadcast of the ''30th Annual Kennedy Center Honors'' from 9 to 11 p.m. drew 6.2 million viewers, down sharply from the 10 million who tuned in a year ago. Ratings for the gala paled in comparison to CBS's 8 p.m. rerun of ''Criminal Minds'' (9.1 million). ABC was a distant fourth for the night.

Warwick Valley High School of Orange County, N.Y., swept the distance medley events Thursday at the Marine Holiday Classic at the Armory Track and Field Center in New York. Warwick's boys quartet was first in 10 minutes 22.89 seconds, with the anchor Brad Ackerman posting a 4:20.65 mile. The Warwick girls foursome finished first in 12:21.04, with a 5:16.04 final leg mile by Tori Pennings. Other winning performances were registered by Charlene Lipsey, a Hempstead, N.Y., junior, in the girls' 800 meters in 2:12.40; Khaliff Featherstone of Philadelphia's Simon Gratz in the boys' 800 in 1:58.09; Boys & Girls of Brooklyn in the girls' 4-200-meter relay in 1:43.61, and Westlake of Maryland in the boys' 4x200 relay in 1:28.85.

DeANGELIS--James, 97, December 26, at Wallingford, CT. He was the last of Yale's Ironmen, the 11 players who upset undefeated Princeton in 1934 and played the entire game without substitutions. DeAngelis later coached football at Yale and four other colleges; served as a Naval officer in World War II and was an automobile and concrete pipe sales manager before retirement in 1991. Funeral mass 10am, Saturday, December 29, St. Aedan's Church, 115 Fountain Street, New Haven, CT.

Bette Davis, who won Academy Awards for her roles in ''Dangerous'' (1935) and ''Jezebel'' (1938), has been chosen by the United States Postal Service to appear on a 41-cent stamp, left, that will be the 14th in its Legends of Hollywood Series, The Associated Press reported.

The governing body of men's tennis confirmed Thursday that the Italians Potito Starace and Daniele Bracciali bet on tennis matches. The ATP said it found that Starace wagered on matches in 2006 from Feb. 21 to May 23. Bracciali's bets were from May 17, 2004 through Jan. 24, 2005. Starace made five bets totaling $130 and Bracciali made about 50 bets of $7, the Italian tennis federation said. The federation said both players bet on matches involving others and were unaware the wagers violated A.T.P. regulations. Starace, ranked 31st, was suspended for six weeks and fined $30,000. Bracciali, ranked 258th, was barred for three months and fined $20,000. The suspensions begin Monday. The Italian federation last week called the penalties an ''injustice.''

Egypt plans to copyright the Pyramids, the Sphinx and various museum pieces and use the royalties from copies to pay for the upkeep of its historic monuments and sites, The Guardian of London reported. Zahi Hawass, the secretary general of the Supreme Council of Antiquities, said that legislation approved by a ministerial committee will be presented to the Egyptian Parliament, where it was expected to pass. The copyrights would then apply anywhere in the world, he said, although he gave no explanation of how Egypt would pursue infringements. He said the proposed law would apply to full-scale precise copies of museum objects and ''commercial use'' of ancient monuments. The Egyptian newspaper Al-Wafd recently published a report saying that more people visit the pyramid-shaped Luxor Hotel in Las Vegas each year than Luxor itself. The newspaper suggested that the hotel share some profits with Luxor, Egypt.

CHRISTINE FALLSby Benjamin Black. A broodingly atmospheric period piece and a credit to its author, John Banville, who needn't have used a pseudonym. AWAYby Amy Bloom. Alive with incident and unforgettable characters, this brief but epic novel illuminates as brilliantly as it entertains.

LEVENTHAL--David, died in Manhattan on December 25th, 2007 at age 89. His wife Elizabeth H. Leventhal and son Robert S. Leventhal wish to express their appreciation to the Visiting Doctors Program of Mt. Sinai Hospital and The Visiting Nurse Service of New York for the kind care and personal attention that allowed David to die at home peacefully and with dignity. We especially want to thank Drs. David Muller and Joanna Scheinfeld for their support, his nurse Ann Harper Campbell, whose professional care and personal visits gave him comfort and joy, and his devoted aides Carla Peixoto, Romain Barrow Colon, Surita Ramnarime, Hilma Hill Lawrence and Lucille Cyrille, for their selfless ministrations and loving service. David, born in Brooklyn, NY, on October 16, 1918, died peacefully in Manhattan on December 25, 2007 at 89. Beloved and revered husband of Elizabeth and Barbara (deceased), kindred spirit of brother Harold (deceased), devoted father of Robert (Janet) Leventhal of Charlottesville, VA, loving grandfather of Chelsea and Alethea Leventhal and wonderful step-grandfather to Miran (James) Perkins of Arlington, VA. A 1939 graduate of Syracuse University, an Army Air Force flight instructor during WWII and a pilot for TWA after the war, a businessman and an intelligently selective investor. He is also survived by his daughter Susan Rome of Boston, MA, son John Leventhal of Boulder, CO, and grandsons Justin and Matthew Rome. He loved his family, to travel, and to laugh, host and entertain. He will be deeply missed by all of those who he touched with his warmth, sense of humor and generosity, among them his mother-in-law, sisters-in-law, nephews and nieces, and most especially his housekeeper of 30 years, Martha Spada, who loved and respected him, and was part of his extended family. Funeral services will be held Friday, 11am, at Frank E. Campbell, 1078 Madison Ave at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Jewish Home for the Aged, 120 West 106 St, NY, NY 10025.
