Eight suspects were under arrest in Bangladesh on Thursday as the authorities carried out raids in an effort to recover two 1,500-year-old terra-cotta statues of the Hindu god Vishnu stolen from a high-security cargo area at the international airport in Dhaka, The Associated Press reported.Local television reports said the statues, insured for a total of $65,000 and bound for exhibition at the Guimet Museum in Paris before they disappeared on Sunday, may have been demolished. Outcry over the thefts prompted the government to decide not to send other artifacts to Paris for the show and to seek the return of those already sent.

Shelly was a nationally renowned equestrienne. She passed away unexpectedly, while on her horse, pursuing her passion. In addition to her competitive successes, she also bred horses and was a compassionate animal-lover, who cared for animals of all kinds. Most importantly, she leaves a wide circle of friends and family who admired and loved her. A memorial service will be planned for the early part of 2008.

Marvel Comics will release a special issue of the Fantastic Four on Friday. The story, ''Isla de la Muerte,'' above, will be available in English and Spanish, a first for a major American comic-book publisher. ''Hispanics don't only mark the fastest-growing segment of the population but also one of our fastest-rising readership segments,'' Joe Quesada, the editor in chief of Marvel, said in a statement. He added: ''With this in mind, we felt it was an ideal time to develop a special title for the Hispanic audience that would be available in multiple languages and spotlight the culture as well.'' In the story the superhero quartet visits Puerto Rico -- from Old San Juan to the rain forest -- and battles chupacabras, mysterious creatures that bite and drain the blood from small animals. ''It was very fun to write,'' said Tom Beland, the cartoonist behind the story.

'NORVAL MORRISSEAU: SHAMAN ARTIST' Using watercolor and ink on slabs of birch bark or buffalo hide, and later acrylic paint on paper and canvas, the Anishinaabe Indian artist Norval Morrisseau, from Canada, produced some of the most original contemporary Indian art of the 20th century. The retrospective at the Smithsonian National Museum of the American Indian is a handy reminder of the genius of Mr. Morrisseau, who died earlier this month. (He was thought to be 75.) More than 50 paintings and drawings spanning his career have been assembled by Greg A. Hill, a curator at the National Gallery of Canada in Ottawa. One highlight is the monumental, six-panel ''Man Changing Into Thunderbird'' (1977), a colorful narrative painting referencing spiritual transformation, creation stories, shamanistic practices and a pantheon of religious figures, cultural heroes and celebrated ancestors. Linear and graphic imagery of animals, plants and spirits dominates the rest of the work in the show, but rarely are the paintings repetitive or formulaic. (''Shaman Rider,'' 1972, is above.) Their great appeal partly derives from Mr. Morrisseau's marrying of an understanding of Indian spirituality with his own formal ambitions as a painter. But he is also a gifted colorist who somehow manages to combine the most eye-popping hues: One painting is colored purple with lime green and bright yellow. New York has many museums with countless exhibitions, but it's been a long time since I saw a show of such potent spirituality, warmth and feeling. (Through Jan. 20, National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Heye Center, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, 212-514-3700, americanindian.si.edu.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

'CUT TO THE CHASE' At the start of Parallel Exit's latest production, you may be reminded of ''Let's Make a Deal.'' Three closed doors face the audience with enigmatic promise. But while the shows have other similarities -- crazy costumes, squealing and placards held aloft -- no one is asked to make a fateful choice among doors. At the end of this hour everyone goes home a winner. The doors, slammed open and shut, are the shifting gears in a comedy that's largely wordless (except for a few songs). Inspired, as are all the company's works, by the films of Buster Keaton and Charlie Chaplin, this vaudeville is actually about vaudeville. It presents a ragtag troupe: Dilly (Laura Dillman, above), a diminutive usher; Dobson (Mike Dobson), a percussionist; the Great Jeske (Joel Jeske, above), impresario and M.C.; Julietta Massina (Juliet Jeske, married to Mr. Jeske), the singing diva; Kasper (Ryan Kasprzak), a gentle buffoon; Little Angela (Andrea Kehler), an overgrown Shirley Temple; and Roland Derek (Derek Roland), a suave magician. The similarity between the characters' names and the actors' makes you suspect that the performers have a certain cozy closeness with their fictional personalities.

FOR CHILDREN BEST OF NEW YORK INTERNATIONAL CHILDREN'S FILM FESTIVAL (Saturday and Sunday) Where can young cinephiles see independent film that's refreshing and creative but still age-appropriate? This festival has always been a reliable source, and this weekend it will present programs of highlights at Symphony Space and at the IFC Center. At 11 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday at Symphony Space, ''Ugly Duckling and Me,'' recommended for ages 6 to 12, offers an animated reinterpretation of ''The Ugly Duckling,'' starring a sleazy talent agent named Ratso (a rat), who adopts an odd-looking egg that hatches to become you know who. At 2 p.m. on both days Symphony Space will also present ''Viva Cuba!,'' a haunting tale, in Spanish with English subtitles, about a boy and a girl, about 10 or 11, who run away in an attempt to prevent the girl's mother from taking her out of the country and destroying their friendship. On Saturday and Sunday at 11 a.m. at the IFC Center, children 3 to 8 can enjoy ''Kid Flix Mix 2,'' a program of 12 shorts, including Bill Plympton's ''Fan and the Flower,'' an unusual animated love story, and Sheldon Cohen's ''I Want a Dog,'' whose title explains it all. Symphony Space programs are at the Leonard Nimoy Thalia, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street; $10; $8 for children; $6 for members. IFC programs are at 323 Avenue of the Americas, at Third Street, Greenwich Village; $11; $7.50 for children. Information for both: (212) 349-0330, gkids.com.

NEW YORK CITY BALLET With 40 ballets, 57 performances and 13 distinct programs over eight weeks, New York City Ballet's winter season, which starts Wednesday, may seem a bit overwhelming. Balletomanes can happily exist on a diet of toe shoes and tulle for two months, but the rest of the dancegoing population will want to pick and choose. A Feb. 10 farewell for the divine principal dancer Nikolaj Hubbe, retiring from the stage to lead the Royal Danish Ballet, should top your to-do list, along with a new ballet by Christopher Wheeldon, the resident choreographer. Having its premiere on Feb. 7, it will be Mr. Wheeldon's last for City Ballet before he leaves to lead his new company, Morphoses. Balanchine classics like ''Serenade'' and ''Mozartiana'' should not be missed, nor should Wheeldon gems like ''Liturgy'' and ''Carousel (A Dance).'' Of course you could tackle the season week by week, as casting is announced. This week the radiant Ashley Bouder, above, will almost certainly shine in the ''Emeralds'' section of Balanchine's ''Jewels.'' She will also perform in Jerome Robbins's ''Brandenburg'' (1997), along with the principal dancer Gonzalo Garcia, an exciting new import from the San Francisco Ballet, in a role debut. Another Robbins ballet, ''The Concert,'' also features a host of debuts. Finally the retired City Ballet star Jock Soto will make a rare guest appearance, as Lord Capulet in Peter Martins's ''Romeo and Juliet''; but keep your eye on another star, a rising one: Robert Fairchild, a young and dashing Romeo. (The season runs Wednesday through Feb. 24, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, 212-870-5570, nycb.org.) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

Mary J. Blige had strong sales last week for her new album, but not enough to bump Josh Groban from No. 1 on the Billboard chart. Mr. Groban's ''Noël'' (Reprise) remains in the top spot for the fifth straight week, with 757,000 sales last week, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Ms. Blige's ''Growing Pains'' (Geffen) sold 629,000. Alicia Keys is at No. 3; the Eagles at No. 4; and Miley Cyrus, No. 5. Among the new releases to move high on the charts were Jaheim's ''Makings of a Man'' (Atlantic) at No. 11 and ''The Cool'' (Atlantic) by Lupe Fiasco at No. 15. Sales for the week that ended on Sunday were 18 percent lower than for the same week last year.

ASHBY--Jerome. The New York Philharmonic deeply mourns the untimely passing of Jerome Ashby, 51, on December 26, 2007, after a prolonged battle with prostate cancer. Mr. Ashby, whose last performance with the Orchestra was on December 1, joined the Philharmonic on August 6, 1979, and served as its Associate Principal Horn as well as Principal Wagner Tuba. He made his Philharmonic solo debut on April 19, 1982. A native of Charleston, South Carolina, Mr. Ashby attended the High School of Performing Arts in New York and The Juilliard School, was an active recitalist and chamber musician, and served on the faculties of Juilliard, Manhattan School of Music, The Curtis Institute, and the Aspen Music Festival School. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Patricia; his mother, Miriam; his daughters Elizabeth, Juanita, Violeta, and Melody; and grandson, Jerome. Lorin Maazel, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Zarin Mehta, Pres./Exec. Dir. Members of the Staff

'CITY LIGHTS' Talking pictures were old news by 1931, when Charlie Chaplin released ''City Lights,'' a ''comedy-romance in pantomime'' that he had begun filming when silents still reigned. Chaplin, one of the few stars who could afford to ignore the talkie revolution, was understandably reluctant to give up the form. After all, in his hands silent comedy had become something like a universal language, and it had brought him an almost unprecedented fame. Technically ''City Lights'' -- showing at Film Forum in a new 35-millimeter print in honor of the 30th anniversary of Chaplin's death -- isn't a silent film. A jack of all cinematic trades, Chaplin (who also directed) composed the buoyant score, and he deploys sound effects as another weapon in his comic arsenal. A politician's words come out as kazoo squawks; Chaplin's Tramp swallows a whistle, making a case of the hiccups a symphony of squeaks.

DRESSLER--Fred. The faculty, staff and Advisory Board of the S.I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse University mourn the passing of alumnus and friend Fred Dressler 1963, of Stamford CT. As chair of the school's Advisory Board from 2002-2007, Mr. Dressler was the force behind ambitious and successful industry events including the School's 40@40 Anniversary celebration, that raised more than $1.6 million for scholarships, and the Mirror Awards, a national competition recognizing the best journalism about the media. Mr. Dressler served on the executive committee that led the Newhouse School to the successful completion of its first capital campaign. On September 19, 2007 the School dedicated a third building in its complex, and Mr. Dressler gave the alumni toast at the gala. A tireless leader, beloved colleague and generous benefactor, he will be constantly missed, but never forgotten.

''Back to the Future,'' ''Bullitt,'' ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind,'' ''Dances With Wolves,'' ''Now, Voyager'' and the 1933 Disney cartoon ''Three Little Pigs'' were among the 25 motion pictures chosen by James H. Billington, the librarian of Congress, for the National Film Registry of the Library of Congress. Under the National Film Preservation Act of 1992, the librarian of Congress, advised by the National Film Preservation Board, names 25 films yearly to the registry, to be preserved for their cultural, historical or aesthetic significance. Among the other films chosen were ''Days of Heaven,'' ''Grand Hotel,'' ''The Naked City,'' ''Oklahoma!,'' ''Twelve Angry Men,'' ''The Women'' and ''Wuthering Heights.''

NEW YEAR'S EVE RIDE For the 10th consecutive year, Time's Up!, an environmental advocacy organization dedicated to promoting bike riding, is organizing a two-wheeled entry into the new year. Cyclists will congregate under the arch in Washington Square Park at 10:30 p.m. on Monday for a free, leisurely commute to Belvedere Castle in Central Park, where they'll eat, drink, dance and watch fireworks. (Above, a past ride, where bikers stopped at Tavern on the Green.) There are also meet-up points in Brooklyn, Queens and elsewhere in Manhattan, with times adjusted accordingly. ''It's a very festive ride,'' said Bill DiPaola, the director of Time's Up! ''People are singing and screaming and cheering'' the whole way. Usually there are a few ''sound bikes,'' which blast tunes for people to sing along to, Mr. DiPaola said. But this year, for the first time, there will be live musical accompaniment: the members of the Rude Mechanical Orchestra will perform (arrangements were being made for them to transport their instruments via bike, Mr. DiPaola said). Some lazy types walk to the party site and bring their dogs as an excuse, but Time's Up! is welcoming, especially if guests bring food or drink to share. And what about tipsy riding? Is there some kind of Champagne-delivery cycle? ''I don't drink and ride, and Time's Up! does not recommend it,'' Mr. DiPaola said. ''But if people spike their water bottles, that's up to them.'' Dress warmly. (212-802-8222, times-up.org) MELENA RYZIK

The Washington Redskins can earn a playoff berth by beating the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday. But like several other matchups on the final day of the regular season, the outcome will hinge as much on who does not play as on who does.The Cowboys (13-2) clinched home field in the National Football Conference playoffs last Sunday. They have little to gain by going all out against Washington (8-7) and will probably limit the risk to injured players like Tony Romo (thumb).One player who will not be taking part is Terrell Owens, who sustained a high ankle sprain last week. Owens scored all four touchdowns in the Cowboys' Week 11 victory against the Redskins (highlights here), taking advantage of a secondary weakened by the absence of safety Sean Taylor. Taylor, who missed the game with a knee injury, was shot and killed a week later. His death, and a season-ending injury to quarterback Jason Campbell, might have led the Redskins to pack it in.Instead, they won three in a row. Now, buoyed by the steady play of Todd Collins, who has not thrown an interception, and Clinton Portis, who has 376 yards from scrimmage in the last three games, the Redskins control their playoff destiny."I don't know of a team - I haven't been a part of one - that's overcome this much," Coach Joe Gibbs told reporters. "It's almost like they're going to overcome whatever's out there."

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Dec. 20 about the quarterly earnings of Oracle referred incorrectly to its market position as a software producer. It is the second-largest software company after Microsoft, not SAP.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about families and caregivers who cope with Alzheimer’s patients included an outdated reference to a book on the subject. The latest edition of “The 36-Hour Day,” by Nancy L. Mace and Peter V. Rabins, was published in 2006 by Johns Hopkins University Press, not in 2001 by Grand Central Publishing.

An article on Sunday about Rudolph W. Giuliani’s most detailed account yet of the health scare that led to his recent hospitalization referred incorrectly to the date that Senator Paul E. Tsongas, a 1992 presidential candidate, died of cancer. Had Mr. Tsongas been elected president, his death on Jan. 18, 1997, would have been two days before the end of his first term — not two days before the beginning of his term in 1993. (The error also appeared on Nov. 24, 2000, in an article about Dick Cheney’s heart attack and the health of presidential candidates.).

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Friday about the late blitz of political advertisements in Iowa misidentified the state where the Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards lives. It is North Carolina — not South Carolina, where he was born.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Wednesday about the showing of the original uncut version of Ingmar Bergman’s “Fanny and Alexander” at the IFC Center in Manhattan starting Jan. 2 misstated the address. It is 323 Avenue of the Americas, at West Third Street.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Friday about the late blitz of political advertisements in Iowa misidentified the state where the Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards lives. It is North Carolina — not South Carolina, where he was born.

Because of an editing error, the On Baseball column on Dec. 18, about concerns over the Mitchell report on performance-enhancing drugs in Major League Baseball, miscalculated the number that equals 85 percent of the league’s roughly 850 players. It is nearly 725, not “about 680.”.
An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Merrill Lynch’s sale of a $5 billion stake to an investor from Singapore misstated the company’s closing stock price on Monday. It was $53.90, not $58.90.

A brief film review in Weekend on Dec. 14 about “The Singing Revolution,” a documentary about Estonia’s struggle to end Soviet occupation, misidentified the site of the Estonian song festival. It is in Tallinn, the capital — not Tartu, where some festivals were held in the 19th century. The review also referred incorrectly to the songs performed at the festival that are shown in the film. They were written by composers; they are not folk songs.

An article in Business Day on Friday about a health insurer’s decision to curtail payment for propofol, an anesthetic sometimes used in colonoscopies, misstated the class of Versed, another drug often administered for the procedure. Versed is a sedative, not a narcotic.

A federal appeals court overturned a $156 million award against three Islamic charities based in the United States for involvement in the terrorism death of an American teenager in the West Bank more than a decade ago. The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit said the judge in the case had failed to require the parents of the teenager, David Boim, 17, to properly show a link between his death and the fund-raising activities of the charities. Because of that error, the court sent the case back for a possible new trial. David Boim, a yeshiva student, was shot to death in 1996 while waiting with other students at a bus stop in Beit El, on the West Bank. All the defendants denied financing terrorism.

State health officials warned consumers not to drink milk produced by a Massachusetts dairy, saying it was the most likely source of a bacterial illness that killed two men and sickened two others. The dairy, Whittier Farms, suspended operations and distribution, said Dr. Alfred DeMaria, the state director of communicable disease control. Most of the dairy’s customers live in Worcester County. The pasteurization process at the dairy appears to be working properly, Dr. DeMaria said, meaning that the listeria bacteria could have entered the dairy’s milk supply after it was pasteurized. Listeriosis is a kind of food poisoning that can be dangerous to the elderly, newborns, pregnant women and people with chronic medical conditions.

Police officials in San Francisco said that an investigation had “found absolutely no evidence of an intentional release” of the Siberian tiger that escaped its enclosure at the city’s zoo on Tuesday, killing a young man and seriously injuring two others. The police said investigators had yet to determine whether “other criminal conduct” occurred either before or after the mauling. Zoo officials announced that the zoo would remain closed until Jan. 3, but said they had not determined whether the lion and tiger exhibit would reopen then.

Nine tanker cars, eight carrying ethanol and one liquid propane, derailed in western Pennsylvania, causing at least two cars to catch fire, officials said. No injuries were reported. The cars were part of a 42-car train when they derailed around 1:45 p.m. about 50 miles east of Pittsburgh, said Rudy Husband, a spokesman for Norfolk Southern, which owns the train. The line has been temporarily taken out of service, Mr. Husband said, and the cause of the derailment is under investigation. The Emergency Management Agency of Indiana County said on its Web site that firefighters and a hazardous materials team were on the scene.

Some elk in Rocky Mountain National Park will be tested for chronic wasting disease and given birth control starting next month to see how well the two procedures work. Most tests for wasting disease in elk are done only on dead animals. This will be the first time the test has been tried on live, free-ranging elk, the officials said. Any of the 120 captured elk found to have the disease will be killed. Sixty of the elk will also be given a fertility control agent called GonaCon to test its effectiveness. The efforts will be done in conjunction with a plan to thin the park’s elk herd to 1,600 to 2,100 from the current 3,100. Officials say that in the absence of natural predators, park elk have become too numerous and are devouring aspens, willows and other native plants.

Hit-and-run accidents are a frequent occurrence on the streets of New York. But even in a town famous for its boldness, it is not very often that a witness chases after the driver, forces him into a cab and turns him over to the police. On Friday, after a deadly hit-and-run on a busy street in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, the police arrived at the scene and discovered that a good Samaritan had provided them with exactly that lucky break.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Sunday about the stabbing death of a Queens woman and the fatal shooting of a Brooklyn man paraphrased incorrectly in some copies a police account of comments by Mohammad Solaiman, the husband of the Queens woman, to a neighbor after the stabbing. According to the police, Mr. Solaiman, who has been charged with murder, showed up at his neighbor's door covered in blood and said his wife was dead; he did not say he had just killed her. Also because of an editing error, the article misstated the surname of the Brooklyn man at one point in some copies. He was Marvelle Jackson, not Miller.

MOGAL--Doris Pick, died peacefully on the evening of December 26, 2007, at her home in Manhattan. Doris was the proud mother of Sally Wigutow, David Rubin and Joshua Mogal, the mother-inlaw of Dan and Katy, the proud grandmother of Jesse and Emily Wigutow, Ben and Eli Rubin and the mother in law of Karen. Doris was the spirited daughter of Max and Ruth Pick and the sister of her beloved brother, Billy. She was predeceased by her husbands, Alexander Rubin and Solomon Mogal. Doris was a graduate of Vassar College, Class of 1939, a fearless traveler, a great reader and a great thinker. The family will be receiving at Frank E. Campbell's, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY, Saturday, December 29, 2007, from 5:00pm to 7:30pm. The funeral service will be on Sunday at 11:00am at Campbell's. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to the United Jewish Appeal.

Colin Wilson scored twice to lead the United States to a 4-2 victory against Switzerland on Friday and move it atop Group B at the Under-20 World Ice Hockey Championship in Liberec, Czech Republic. The victory gave the United States 6 points and the edge on Russia on goal difference entering their showdown Saturday.Also on Friday, Mikael Backlund and Tony Lagerstrom each scored two goals and Robin Figren added his third of the tournament to rally Sweden from an early deficit for a 10-1 victory against Denmark. The victory moved Sweden atop Group A with 6 points, ahead of Canada on goal difference heading into their game Saturday.

Patrick Valenzuela, whose career has been marred by a history of substance abuse and suspensions, has been stripped of his conditional jockey license after being arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence of alcohol. A notice of the termination of Valenzuela's license was issued Friday by the California Horse Racing Board. Valenzuela, 45, had been scheduled to ride in four of Friday's eight races at Santa Anita but was taken off those mounts as well as those on Saturday, Sunday and Monday. Valenzuela rode Sunday Silence to victory in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes in 1989.

2007 served up a full plate of food research. Looking unexpectedly good, health-wise: a beer a day, three cups of coffee or more, a spoonful of honey and being chubby. Looking worse than ever: trans fats, beef and drinking binges. The following is a month-by-month guide to what we learned about nutrition and health over the year.

BIGHAM--Thomas J., Jr. (Jake), of Portland and Rowena, Oregon, died accidentally while windsurfing, one of his great passions, in extreme conditions off the coral reef at Cabo Pulmo, Baja, Mexico on December 22, 2007. Beloved husband of Judith O'Connor and devoted father of Raina, Louisa, and Idabelle. Born July 26, 1957 and raised in New York City. Son of the late Rev. Thomas J. Bigham and Julia Scribner Bigham. Graduated from Salisbury School, Hamilton College and the University of Oregon School of Architecture. Architect in Portland and the Columbia River Gorge. Board member and former chairperson of the Oregon Investment Board for the protection and support of the Columbia River Gorge economy. He was recently appointed a trustee of the Northwest Academy in Portland. Those who knew him appreciated his ever-present sense of humor and ability to lift the spirits of those around him. He was a true leader whose absence will leave a permanent void in the lives of his family and many friends. Survived by his sisters Hildreth McCarthy, M.D., of New Orleans, LA, Mary Binks of Nairobi, Kenya, and Anda Hutchins of New Canaan, CT. A memorial service will be held in Hood River, OR, on Sunday, December 30th, and burial will be in New Marlboro, MA, in the summer. Donations may be made to Columbia River Keeper at www. columbiariverkeeper.org.

The assassination of Benazir Bhutto and the outbreak of violence in Pakistan has raised concerns for cricket teams touring the country. Australia is scheduled to tour Pakistan in March. Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd said Friday that his government would monitor developments, although a decision on the tour will be left to Cricket Australia, the country's governing body of cricket. Bhutto died Thursday in an attack at a political rally in Rawalpindi.

ASHBY--Jerome. Manhattan School of Music mourns the loss of Jerome Ashby, a genuine artist, great teacher and true friend to so many of us in our community. His performances as Associate Principal Horn of the New York Philharmonic and as a chamber music performer were inspirations to audiences, his musical colleagues and his students. Mr. Ashby joined the faculty of Manhattan School of Music in 1991 as a founding teacher of the schools Graduate Program in Orchestral Performance, and his devotion and invaluable service to that program and the School will be sorely missed. His personal dignity and integrity served as a model to all who knew him. We extend our deepest sympathies to the members of his family. David A. Rahm, Chairman Robert Sirota, President ASHBY--Jerome/d. The Juilliard Community mourns the untimely death of Jerome Ashby, a distinguished member of Juilliard's French horn faculty from 1990 to present and accomplished alumnus of the school. A dedicated and talented performing artist and teacher, his students and his colleagues always held Jerry in the highest regard. His generous and gentle personality will be deeply missed by us all. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Patricia and his entire family. Bruce Kovner, Chair Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean

The former agent for the sprinter Marion Jones has been suspended by USA Track and Field for two years. The penalty dates to March 22, when the agent Charles Wells pleaded guilty to bank fraud in a money laundering case that also ensnared Jones; her ex-boyfriend, the sprinter Tim Montgomery; and her former coach Steve Riddick. The suspension was ordered by the agents screening committee, a spokeswoman for the organization said. It means Wells will not be listed as an authorized athlete representative. Track agents are not required to be approved by U.S.A.T.F., the group that oversees the sport in the United States. Wells must apply to be reinstated to the list.

CHIEF SELLS SHARES The chief executive of Bear Stearns, James E. Cayne, sold $15.4 million of the company's stock this month, at the end of a year in which he found himself at the forefront of a global credit crisis. Mr. Cayne exercised and sold 172,621 shares of stock vested under a capital accumulation plan on Dec. 21, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. He was paid $89.01 a share, according to the filing. The stock he sold was acquired in 2002 through a grant of units that were converted into stock this year. A spokeswoman for the company said executives who acquire such shares typically sell them for tax purposes. (AP) ALLERGY DRUG IS APPROVED Mylan said its Mylan Pharmaceuticals unit received final approval from health regulators in the United States for its generic version of Pfizer's allergy drug Zyrtec. The approval is for cetirizine hydrochloride tablets, 5 mg and 10 mg, and the tablets will be shipped immediately, the company said. Zyrtec had sales in the United States of about $1.4 billion for the 12 months ended Sept. 30. (REUTERS) DEAL IN PATENT DISPUTE The Vonage Holdings Corporation, a provider of Internet phone service, said it had agreed to pay AT&T up to $7.8 million a year to settle a patent dispute. Vonage said as part of the settlement, it agreed to make a payment of $1.95 million to AT&T in January and then pay $650,000 per month over the life of the five-year contract. In addition, Vonage said AT&T had granted it non-exclusive rights to AT&T patents related to voice-over-Internet protocol and dual-mode wireless services. (REUTERS) NASDAQ ERRS IN STATEMENTThe Nasdaq Stock Market said it erroneously distributed a statement announcing that the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, an interagency panel of the federal government, had approved Borse Dubai's plan to take a stake in the company, paving the way for its acquisition of OMX AB. ''A formal announcement will be distributed when appropriate,'' Nasdaq said. Nasdaq shareholders approved the $4.72 billion deal to buy a controlling stake in Stockholm-based OMX this month, capping a two-year European expansion effort that included a failed bid to buy the London Stock Exchange. A spokeswoman for Nasdaq declined to comment beyond the statement.

8:10 P.M. (Sundance) SHADOW OF A DOUBT (1943) Sundance serves up four spine-tinglers from Alfred Hitchcock, including this thriller about a small-town girl, Charlie (Teresa Wright), right, who begins to suspect that her beloved uncle, Charles (Joseph Cotton), right, is a serial killer. Hitchcock called it his favorite film; critics said it was his best. Gordon McDonnell earned an Oscar nomination for best original story, and none other than Thorton Wilder wrote the screenplay. Hitchcock had wanted Joan Fontaine for the role of Charlie but couldn't get her, so he settled on Wright, who had understudied the role of Emily in Wilder's ''Our Town'' on Broadway. The tribute begins at 6 with ''Marnie'' (1964), starring Tippi Hedren and Sean Connery as a kleptomaniac bride and her sleuthing spouse, and continues with ''Rope'' (1948), with James Stewart as a professor who unwittingly inspires two of his former students to commit the perfect murder, at 10, and ''Saboteur'' (1942), about an aircraft worker (Robert Cummings) on the lam after being wrongly accused of starting a fire that killed his best friend, at 11:30. 6:30 P.M. Britain's Channel 4 News has broadcast new video of the attack on Benazir Bhutto "apparently contradicting the official version of events, which insists that Benazir Bhutto was not shot." UPDATE, 11:20 p.m.: The Tennessee Titans, despite losing quarterback Vince Young to an injury in the third quarter, defeated the Indianapolis Colts, 16-10, to clinch the sixth and final playoff spot in the A.F.C. Naturally, in a season of backup quarterbacks, Kerry Collins led the Titans on the tying and winning drives in the third and fourth quarters. (Kerry Collins is no relation to Todd Collins, the backup quarterback who led Washington to a playoff-clinching win earlier Sunday.) The Titans will face the third-seeded San Diego Chargers next Sunday afternoon.

Phil O’Donnell, the captain for Motherwell of the Scottish Premier League, died Saturday after he collapsed during a game as he was about to leave the field for a substitute.O’Donnell, a 35-year-old midfielder, fell to the ground at Fir Park in Motherwell. He was carried off on a stretcher and taken to a hospital. The Motherwell club chairman, Bill Dickie, said that O’Donnell had a seizure, but did not elaborate. He said there would be an autopsy.The teams completed the game, apparently unaware of O’Donnell’s condition. Motherwell won, 5-3.

Tobias Forsberg scored with seven seconds left Saturday to give Sweden a 4-3 victory over Canada in a world junior championship game in Pardubice, Czech Republic. The victory ended a 20-game winning streak in the world junior tournament for Canada, the three-time defending champion.In Liberec, the United States improved to 3-0 in Group B when Tyler Ruegsegger, James vanRiemsdyk and Mike Carman scored in a 3-2 victory over Russia. In other games, the Czech Republic beat Slovakia, 5-2, and Finland defeated Kazakhstan, 5-0.

The Texas freshman Gary Johnson, sidelined this season because of an unspecified heart condition, can play his first game Jan. 2 against Texas Christian.Johnson was “cleared to participate in all physical activity at the University of Texas,” the trainer Fred Burnett said in a statement Saturday.Johnson, a 6-foot-7 forward who was the Longhorns’ top recruit, has been monitored for the past six months by Dr. James Willerson, president-elect of the Texas Heart Institute and president of the university’s Health Science Center in Houston. University officials released no other details on his condition, which was diagnosed in May.Texas (11-2) lost to Wisconsin, 67-66, on Saturday.

Meghann Shaughnessy, filling in for Serena Williams, was a winner in her match, then Mardy Fish clinched a victory for the United States over India in the opening round of the mixed-teams Hopman Cup in Perth, Australia. Shaughnessy won the last five games to defeat Sania Mirza, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3. Fish secured the victory with a 6-2, 6-4 win over Rohan Bopanna. Mirza and Bopanna won the mixed doubles, 6-4, 6-4.Williams, recovering from a knee injury, was expected to arrive in Perth in time for the United States’ match Monday against the Czech Republic.

Jon Dorenbos, a long snapper, signed a five-year contract extension Saturday with Philadelphia. Dorenbos, 27, was signed late last season after Mike Bartrum was injured. He has played 22 games with the Eagles. He previously played for Buffalo and Tennessee.

The Philadelphia 76ers acquired guard Gordan Giricek and a first-round draft pick from the Utah Jazz for guard Kyle Korver on Saturday.The 6-foot-5 Giricek averaged 4.3 points in 22 games for the Jazz this season and has career average of 9.8 in six seasons.“We are excited about acquiring a player of Gordan’s ability, as well as an additional asset in the form of a first-round draft pick,” 76ers General Manager Ed Stefanski said. “This move will provide us with increased salary-cap flexibility this off-season and also allows us to continue our evaluation and development of the young talent we have on this team.”Korver averaged 10 points in 25 games with the 76ers and was their top 3-point threat. In four seasons with Philadelphia, Korver averaged 10.5 points and shot 42 percent.“I want to thank Kyle for the positive impact he has made on this team and the city of Philadelphia through his play on the court and, even more importantly, his philanthropic efforts off of it,” Stefanski said.

A review on Dec. 2 about “Aldous Huxley: Selected Letters,” edited by James Sexton, misstated the time by which Huxley “was dabbling in Scientology.” It was 1950, not the end of World War II. (Only in 1950 did L. Ron Hubbard publicly introduce the principles of Dianetics, which were later expanded into the basis for Scientology.).

A review on Dec. 2 about “The History of the Snowman,” by Bob Eckstein, misstated the name of a cartoon cited in the book and misspelled the surname of the painter and graphic artist who drew it. The cartoon is “Snowman,” not “The Snowman”; it was drawn by Frank Frazetta, not Franzetta.

PASTORE--Richard Steel, died December 27, 2007 in Old Greenwich, CT at age 75. Born in Brooklyn, NY, on September 25, 1932, he attended Chatham High School in New Jersey. He graduated with honors in History from Amherst College in 1954. After serving in the U.S. Army, he graduated with a law degree from Columbia University. He spent his career practicing law in Greenwich, CT. He is survived by his wife, Joanna Matthews Pastore, his five children Michael, John, Anna, Thomas and Richard, his twelve grandchildren, and three siblings, Susan Rollinson, Grace Boyd, and John Pastore.

ART has always followed war -- articulating and making indelible the shadow it leaves behind. As the war in Iraq continued through its fifth year, filmmakers, playwrights, songwriters, visual artists and television producers scrambled to grab hold of it, to say something, maybe to change something. Much of the art failed; it is not easy to capture a story that isn't over. But much did not. A number of films dived directly into the ugliness of the battlefield. In others, the general unease created by the war seeped into tales far removed from Iraq datelines. Can torture be justified? At least one movie made us think about it.
Hoboken, Dec. 19.

ASHBY--Jerome. The Juilliard Community mourns the untimely death of Jerome Ashby, a distinguished member of Juilliard's French horn faculty from 1990 to present and accomplished alumnus of the school. A dedicated and talented performing artist and teacher, his students and his colleagues always held Jerry in the highest regard. His generous and gentle personality will be deeply missed by us all. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Patricia and his entire family. Bruce Kovner, Chair Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean

ALGRANT--Roland. Human Rights Watch mourns the loss of a loyal supporter from our inception and a tireless activist for human rights. In 1975, Roly was a founding board member of the Fund for Free Expression, which later became Human Rights Watch. He conducted fact-finding missions from Cuba to Turkey, and at the time of his death was an active member of the advisory board of HRW's Childrens Rights Division. Roly's keen insight, infectious humor, and warm conviviality will be sorely missed by fellow board members and staff. Some people are irreplaceable and Roly was one such person.
BARKIN--Paula Lee. Always and Forever. Thank you for watching over us. Love, Joel, Daniel & Robert

SCHARFMAN--Edward L., M.D., age 57, passed December 29, 2007 after a difficult struggle with cancer. Beloved husband of Rochelle, adored father of Emily and Brian, beloved brother of Ronnie and Joe, Gerald, Barry and son-inlaw of Estelle, beloved uncle of Andrew and Nancy, Rachel, Ethan and Rachel, and Zach. He was a physician admired and respected by peers and colleagues, an award-winning teacher and mentor to generations of psychiatric residents, and a devoted doctor to his patients. He ardently loved and supported the state of Israel as well as numerous Jewish charitable and educational institutions. He was active in his synagogue where he assumed many positions of leadership. He was a dear and true friend to dozens who knew him and he touched everyone. We will all miss him.

Endorsing Huckabee In his illuminating article, Zev Chafets (Dec. 16) ends with a discussion of Mike Huckabee's possible interest in second place on the Republican ticket. He quotes the Republican consultant Mike Murphy as saying ''vice presidents become presidents.'' In fact, since Martin Van Buren succeeded Andrew Jackson to the presidency in 1837 no sitting vice president was elected to the presidency until the election of George H. W. Bush in 1988. Recently, except for Bush 41, all sitting vice presidents running for the presidency -- Nixon, Humphrey, Mondale and Gore -- have been defeated.

He was the retired Vice Chairman, President and CEO of Conde Naste Publications. Friends may call on Sunday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st. Mass of Christian burial Monday, 10am, St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Ave. at 84th.

THE NEWS With polls showing the outcome of the Jan. 3 Iowa caucuses up in the air, the top Democratic presidential candidates sharpened their appeals. BEHIND THE NEWS An extremely tight race among Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama and John Edwards put the focus on the many likely caucusgoers who were undecided. Mrs. Clinton said she alone had the necessary experience and was ''ready to be president on Day 1.'' Mr. Obama portrayed himself as an avatar of change and urged voters not to ''get caught up in the same old nonsense that has come to pass as politics.'' Mr. Edwards promised to take on special interests, warning: ''Corporate greed is killing the middle class.''

POSEN--Richard, a generous and loving husband, father, son, nephew and cousin. He exemplified devotion, consideration and honor. We offer our deepest condolences to his wife Sharri, children Danielle and Jonathan, sonin-law Alex, parents Warner and Susan, and brothers Dennis and Micheal. Rudi &Janet de Winter, Deborah & Phillip Sussman, Jim & Jennifer de Winter, and Julia & Scott Stein POSEN--Richard L. Rick/d, for 35 years you have been my friend, advisor and confidant. For me as for so many others, you have set the standard for integrity, decency and values that matter. My life has been enriched by your friendship. I will miss you the rest of my life. Rest in peace. Don, Mindy, Spencer and Taylor POSEN--Richard L/d. It is with great sadness that the partners, counsel and associates of Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP and all of our staff mourn the passing of our beloved partner Richard L. Posen. Rick was the head of our Litigation Department and was part of the fabric of our firm from the day he joined us after graduating from New York University Law School and throughout his 33 year tenure at the firm. Rick was a wise leader, invaluable advisor, cherished colleague, and loyal friend. He will be sorely missed by us all. Our condolences go to Rick's wife, Sharri, his daughter and son, Danielle and Jonathan, his mother and father, Susan and Warner, and his brothers, Dennis and Michael.

HITCHCOCK--H. Wiley, September 28, 1923-December 5, 2007. The Charles Ives Society mourns the passing of H. Wiley Hitchcock, who activated the Society in 1973, served as President for 19 years, and was Chairman for the last 15 years. He conceived the Society's central project, producing scholarly editions of Charles Ives' music, and masterfully edited Ives' 129 Songs. He was our mentor, guide, and inspiration. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Janet and family. J. Peter Burkholder, President James M. Kendrick, Secretary

Ears and wrists sparkled with carat-heavy diamonds; sculptured lips nibbled on comfort food. Below, what they were wearing then.

EXPLORING THE SUN TEMPLE, MARCH 3, 2007 Richard Heaton, 41, at left, a government legal adviser from London, on a guided tour through a 13th-century black granite temple in Konarak in the eastern state of Orissa. ''I go to India by myself most years because I love the country. I like the history and the culture. From the photograph you get an idea of what an extraordinary structure this is, with the big wheels representing the chariot of the sun god, Surya. What's really fascinating about India -- and you really get this when you're by yourself -- is noticing the small things. The detail in India is extraordinary, in the way people dress, the way people store their things and mend things, and the paradoxes: nothing is quite as it seems. So, intellectually, mentally, it's this constantly fascinating display of language and architecture and objects and craft. It's all around you. Your senses are constantly being bombarded with little details, which is fantastic.'' As told to Austin Considine

FUTTERMAN--Claire Frances, nee Savine, of Phoenix, AZ, formerly NYC. Age 99, died peacefully March 30, 2007. Born December 19, 1907. Hunter College, MA, 1932, Ph.D. Studies NYU. Adored wife of the late Sidney; devoted mother of Alex and Vickie; grandmother of Jessica and Louise and mother-in-law of Suzy. Admired for her articulate intelligence, this generous, remarkably strong, independent, highly principled woman -will be missed by all who knew her.

To the Editor: I have lived in Seattle now for 10 years and was an avid symphonygoer before I arrived here. I am still avid, but I refuse to go to Seattle Symphony concerts conducted by Gerard Schwarz, and I refuse to donate to the orchestra.

''Scratch-off tickets are to the lottery what crack is to cocaine.'' Eliot Shapleigh, a state senator in El Paso, Tex. Scratch-off tickets account for more than 75 percent of lottery sales in Texas, the first state to introduce a $50 scratch-off game.

VIERTEL--Joseph M., is deeply mourned by the employees of Presidential Realty Corporation. He built his family's real estate concern into a publicly traded company while publishing four novels. He died on December 11 at the age of 92. Born in New York City in 1915, he graduated Magna Cum Laude from Harvard in 1936. In 1939, he married Janet Man in a ceremony conducted by then mayor Fiorello LaGuardia and then joined his father in the construction business, known as M. Shapiro & Sons, building homes and apartments from New England to Kansas, housing 150,000 people in fifteen states. At the end of a decade in business, he published his first novel, The Last Temptation, which was a New York Times bestseller and a main selection of the Literary Guild. During the succeeding thirty years he built M. Shapiro and Sons into Presidential Realty Corporation, a multi-faceted publicly traded real estate company, serving at various times as Chairman of its Finance Committee, its Executive Committee and as President. In that period, he produced three more major novels, To Love and Corrupt (1962), Monkey on a String (1968), and Life Lines (1982); each was a selection of a major book club. He also found time to sit on the boards of many other corporations, and was a leader of the Human Rights Commission in Stamford, Connecticut during the most intense period of the civil rights struggles in the 1960s. For many years he lived in Stamford and St. Croix, in the U.S. Virgin Islands, where his wife was an underwater photographer. In 1992, Janet Viertel died after 54 years of marriage. He subsequently married the former Joy Brandt, who survives him, as does a brother, Robert Shapiro, Chairman of the Board of Presidential, two sons, Tom and Jack, both Broadway producers, and a daughter, Alice Krieger, who is Associate Executive Director of LEAP, an arts and education organization in New York City. He is also survived by six grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren.

AGNEW--Beatrice W., of Nyack, NY, died December 26th, 2007. Devoted mother of Jean-Christophe and Kim Dominique Agnew; proud grandmother of Alex and Jesse Cohen and Winnie Agnew; beloved aunt of Philippe Heilbronn, Christophe Woog, Nathalie Woog de Cacqueray of France. She is also survived by daughter-in-law, Rita Rack and son-in-law, Kenneth Cohen. Born in Paris, daughter of painters Raymond Woog and Violette Picard, she came to the U.S. after WWII, where she raised her two children with her husband, the late William R. Agnew. She brought her boundless energy, vision, and love of books to her work at the Palisades Library, where she was Director since 1968. The community she served and the family she loved deeply mourn her passing. Details of her memorial to be announced later. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to the Friends of the Palisades Library, 19 Closter Road, Palisades, NY 10964.

LYNCH--Maureen, died from a malignant brain tumor on December 21, 2007. She had recently retired as Director of Communications at Fordham University's Graduate School of Business where she worked for over 20 years. During her tenure at Fordham she received 18 national awards for publications she generated. Prior to joining Fordham's administration, Ms. Lynch was President of Maureen Lynch & Company, a firm specializing in marketing, public relations and writing copy for magazines in the health, beauty and fashion industries including New Woman, Family Circle and Women's Day and manufacturers Del Labs, Guerlain and Ellesse. As an editor of consumer magazines, her name was nationally by-lined for 16 years, the last eight of which were as Senior Editor, Fashion and Beauty for Ladies Home Journal magazine. Maureen Lynch lived in New York City for her entire career and was quite active in community affairs. She was a decades long member of The Blue Hill Troupe, a Gilbert & Sullivan society that performs to benefit New York charities such as the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association and the Burden Center for the Aging. She twice served on the Troupe's Board of Directors, as well as, the Boards of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills and The Fashion Group International. Ms. Lynch was awarded her Bachelor of Arts from Rosemont College in Pennsylvania and pursued graduate studies in social anthropology at the New School for Social Research. Her brothers Vincent of Mamaroneck, New York; Dennis of Hanover, New Hampshire; and Tom of South Dartmouth, Massachusetts, and their families survive her. Her designated charity is Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd. in New York City.

Beloved by her husband Andy, father and mother David and Joyce Tai, and sisters Gloria, Erika and Jordan. Memorial services 1pm on January 6th, 2008, at SGI-NY, 7 West 15th St., 2nd Floor, NY, NY 10003.

From 1941 to 1976, some 200 winners of the Miss Subways contest smiled down at riders. Three years ago, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority celebrated the centennial of the subway by reviving the idea, renamed ''Ms. Subways.'' Many New Yorkers know of Ellen Hart Sturm, a former Miss Subways (March-April 1959) and the owner of Ellen's Stardust Diner. But the M.T.A. revival inspired Fiona Gardner, a New York photographer, to track down some less well-known winners, pose them with commemorative sashes and, with Amy Zimmer, discover a little about what their lives have been like since then.
Hartsdale, Dec. 24.

The Broncos (6-9) have allowed at least 30 points in three of their last five games.

FROM dance enclaves in the Bronx to roving, artist-run collectives, showcases for ''emerging choreographers'' -- that fuzzy, mutable category -- are a dime a dozen these days. But this week one of the pioneers, the Fresh Tracks series at Dance Theater Workshop in Chelsea, reaches an important milestone: 500 artists presented, counting a few double appearances. Fresh Tracks, which will present work by seven choreographers on Friday and next Saturday, has run, in one guise or another, since Dance Theater Workshop was founded as an artists' collective by Jeff Duncan, Art Bauman and Jack Moore in 1965. The list of participants, chosen through open auditions, is a Who's Who of contemporary dance, including Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker, Wendy Perron, Doug Elkins, Reggie Wilson, David Parsons, Meredith Monk, Bebe Miller, Tere O'Connor and Maria Hassabi. Deborah Jowitt, the dance historian, teacher and longtime Village Voice critic who has reviewed so many Fresh Tracks evenings, performed in the very first program.

BECKER--Benjamin, Ph.D. We remember our beloved Benjamin Becker who died at age 89 on September 15, 2005 in Fort Wayne, Indiana, after a long and courageous battle with Parkinson's Disease. Born in New York City, he grew up and settled in South River, New Jersey, where he was vice-president of Congregation Anshe Emeth. He earned his B.S. in 1937 and his Ph.D. in 1965, both from Rutgers University. At the Rutgers Institute of Microbiology he was research assistant to Nobel prize-winner, Dr. Selman A. Waksman. In a widely published discovery, Becker found that the drip-pans of refrigerators caused allergies in humans. He also contributed to the fields of lung disease, cancer and actinomycetes. His most important research, ''Rapid Differentiation of Streptomyces from Nocardia by Paper Chromatography'', was published in ''Applied Microbiology''. From 1965-1969 he taught microbiology and biochemistry at Hamilton College in Clinton, NY. He served as Professor Emeritus of microbiology and biochemistry at Indiana Purdue University-Fort Wayne from 1969-1981. During his tenure, he also coached the IPFW women's tennis team. Dr. Becker was a member of honorary societies Sigma Xi and Phi Lambda Upsilon; American Chemical Society, American Society for Microbiology; Jewish War Veterans and Congregation Achduth Vesholom. He served as a master sergeant in the U.S. Army Air Corps in New Guinea in WWII and was a Disabled American Veteran. He married Grace Auerbach on May 6, 1951 in New York City. They had a wonderful marriage lasting 37 years until her death on September 7, 1986. Also preceding him in death are his brothers Seymour Becker, David D. Becker and Harry Becker, and his parents, Morris and Rose (Lasofsky) Becker. He is survived by his loving companion, Margaret Ann Dunwell of Fort Wayne; daughters, Rosalie Becker of Fort Wayne and Suzanne Becker Bronk of Napa, California; grandchildren, Rachael and Joshua Bronk; sons-in-law, Franck Hagendorf and James B. Bronk, M.D. Contact: bnjmnbc@aol.com We miss you. Rosalie and Suzanne, family and friends

THE Hope Now alliance, a coalition of mortgage industry executives that is coordinating a response to the foreclosure crisis, features 14 large mortgage companies, counseling agencies, investors, trade groups and one prominent whip, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. But banking regulators in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut said the alliance was missing some important pieces: namely, them. The lack of a coordinated local response, they said, could hinder the financial recovery of thousands of struggling homeowners.

BIGHAM--Thomas J., Jr. (Jake), of Portland and Rowena, Oregon, died accidentally while windsurfing, one of his great passions, in extreme conditions off the coral reef at Cabo Pulmo, Baja, Mexico on December 22, 2007. Beloved husband of Judith O'Connor and devoted father of Raina, Louisa, and Idabelle. Born July 26, 1957 and raised in New York City. Son of the late Rev. Thomas J. Bigham and Julia Scribner Bigham. Graduated from Salisbury School, Hamilton College and the University of Oregon School of Architecture. Architect in Portland and the Columbia River Gorge. Board member and former chairperson of the Oregon Investment Board for the protection and support of the Columbia River Gorge economy. He was recently appointed a trustee of the Northwest Academy in Portland. Those who knew him appreciated his ever-present sense of humor and ability to lift the spirits of those around him. He was a true leader whose absence will leave a permanent void in the lives of his family and many friends. Survived by his sisters Hildreth McCarthy, M.D., of New Orleans, LA, Mary Binks of Nairobi, Kenya, and Anda Hutchins of New Canaan, CT. A memorial service will be held in Hood River, OR, on Sunday, December 30th, and burial will be in New Marlboro, MA, in the summer. Donations may be made to Columbia River Keeper at www. columbiariverkeeper.org.

HEARD--Edwin Anthony Jr., died December 28, age 81, from complications of Parkinson's Disease. He was born in New York City and graduated from the Trinity School in 1944. He served as a Lieutenant (j.g.) in the Navy, and graduated cum laude from Princeton University in 1948 where he was elected to the Phi Beta Kappa society. His career began at the Irving Trust Company in New York in 1948. He joined the United States Trust Company in 1971, and served there as vice chairman from 1976 until his retirement in 1988. He was a director of National Life of Tennessee from 1974-1982 and also served as President of Excelsior Income Shares, Inc. from 1989-1992. He moved from New York to Nashville in 1991. Mr. Heard was devoted to supporting education, serving as a trustee of Collegiate School, Trinity Pawling School, and Trinity School, including a term as president of the board. He was an Elder of West End Collegiate Church in New York from 1961-1991. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Phyllis Gregory Heard; a daughter, Elizabeth Heard Gambee and a son, E. Anthony Heard III; and grandchildren, Robert Gregory Gambee, Claire Elizabeth Gambee, Robert Anthony Heard, Emily Wallace Heard and Margaret Allison Heard. A memorial service will be held in the spring in New York City. In lieu of flowers, please direct gifts to Doctors Without Borders or the charity of your choice.

Since tenants' adjusted gross income must exceed $175,000 for two consecutive years for an apartment renting for more than $2,000 to be deregulated, my question is: Which two years are considered? Will they be 2008 and 2009, or 2007 and 2008?

MUNSON--Dr. Suzanne Frances. The house staff and faculty of the Departments of Psychiatry and Medicine at the New York Presbyterian Hospital-Weill Cornell Medical Center and Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center mourn the loss of our beloved colleague, Dr. Suzanne Frances Munson. A graduate of Princeton University and the Medical College of Virginia, Suzanne also completed a research fellowship at the National Institute of Mental Health. Suzanne's dream was to be a child psychiatrist. In her too brief time as an intern in psychiatry, medicine and neurology at Weill Cornell, Suzanne inspired us with her gifts as a physician and as a warm and devoted friend. She was a passionate and dedicated doctor with a unique ability to connect with patients and families. We will never forget Suzanne's extraordinary courage during her own illness. Our hearts go out to Suzanne's friends everywhere and to the Munson family, Fran, Peter, and John.

WINE enthusiasts love to discuss the aromas of wine -- the raspberries, the leather, the fresh-cut grass -- but are we ignoring a prevailing whiff of petroleum? With some wines emitting three times their weight in greenhouse gas, the answer is yes. Wine, like virtually every consumer product, has a ''carbon footprint'' -- that is, a certain amount of carbon dioxide is emitted in its production and transportation. And although the difference between organically and conventionally grown vineyards is relatively small in terms of carbon intensity, the journey that wine takes from the winery to the shop is not. Indeed if your New Year's resolution for 2008 is to reduce your carbon footprint, don't serve wine from California at your New Year's Eve party. Instead, try wines from the tri-state region.

STERNSTEIN--Rabbi Joseph. The Board of Directors of Jewish National Fund mourns the passing of Rabbi Joseph Sternstein, a renowned force in the Jewish community. The only person to have been both President and CEO of JNF, his steadfast devotion to Israel and to Zionism brought about great awareness and support for Israeli causes and concerns and is the legacy he leaves for all. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. STERNSTEIN--Rabbi Joseph P/d. Past President and CEO of the Jewish National Fund, Hadassah's partner since 1926 in conservation and reforestation projects in Israel. A towering figure in the Zionist world, a true, loyal friend to Hadassah and its leaders, he was the driving force behind decades of JNF/Hadassah projects to improve the land of Israel. He will be sorely missed by all. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Nancy Falchuk, National President Morlie Levin, National Executive Director Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America

BEIJING -- The authorities have detained a prominent Chinese human rights advocate on suspicion of subversion, escalating a crackdown on dissent during the West's holiday season. The police detained the advocate, Hu Jia, 34, at his home in Beijing on Thursday. They gave his wife a warrant stating that he was suspected of ''incitement to subvert state power,'' a catchall charge often used against people whom the authorities deem threatening to their power, a friend of Mr. Hu said.

There is a 26,000-acre national park on the edge of New York City, its nearest point less than an hour from Times Square. But while two million people visit parts of it every year, the park seems forlorn and is plainly in need of help -- from Washington, Albany and the city. The park is the Gateway National Recreation Area, one of the more discombobulated units in the national park system. Created in 1972, a century after Yellowstone, it encompasses uplands, wetlands and estuaries in three segments connected by water: Jamaica Bay, Staten Island and Sandy Hook in New Jersey.

DRESSLER--Fred. The faculty, staff and Advisory Board of the S.I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse University mourn the passing of alumnus and friend Fred Dressler 1963, of Stamford CT. As chair of the school's Advisory Board from 2002-2007, Mr. Dressler was the force behind ambitious and successful industry events including the School's 40@40 Anniversary celebration, that raised more than $1.6 million for scholarships, and the Mirror Awards, a national competition recognizing the best journalism about the media. Mr. Dressler served on the executive committee that led the Newhouse School to the successful completion of its first capital campaign. On September 19, 2007 the School dedicated a third building in its complex, and Mr. Dressler gave the alumni toast at the gala. A tireless leader, beloved colleague and generous benefactor, he will be constantly missed, but never forgotten.

AJAY--Betty, on December 7, 2007, died at her home in Connecticut. She was 89 years old. Mrs. Ajay was born in Burlingame, CA in 1918, the daughter of Walter and Evangeline Raymond. She had two brothers predeceased. Mrs. Ajay graduated from the University of California, Berkeley, her graduate work was done at Colombia. As a young woman she was employed as a research worker, a diamond cutter, and a model in NYC. Mrs. Ajay found her career in landscape design. She married Abe Ajay, the artist, in 1947. He died in 1998. They lived in an 18th-Century farmhouse in Bethel, CT, which they bought in 1950 and restored. Mrs. Ajay was very successful as a landscape designer and worked performing upscale projects in Westport and Greenwich, CT as well as Westchester County, NY, among others. They were considered excellent achievements. In 1970, McGraw-Hill Published, ''Betty Ajay's Guide to Home Landscaping''. She was especially gifted in the designing of beautiful stone walls and gardens. She loved her work and therefore excelled in it. She is survived by her daughter Robin, two stepsons Alex and Stephen Ajay, three granddaughters and a grandson, four great-grandchildren, and her niece and nephew.

The top American military commander in Iraq said Saturday that violent attacks in the country had fallen by 60 percent since June, but cautioned that security gains were ''tenuous'' and ''fragile,'' requiring political and economic progress to cement them. Petraeus, said the ''principal threat'' to security remained Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, the homegrown insurgent group that American intelligence officials say is foreign led.

There is, we have it on ecclesiastical authority, ''a time to every purpose under the heaven: a time to be born, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to pluck up that which is planted.'' Indeed, for those vacationing near a beach, there is even ''a time to cast away stones, and a time to gather stones together.'' (And for those considering a run for the presidency, ''a time to keep silence, and a time to speak.'') As 2007 draws to a close, however, it is time to cast our minds back on the incidents and accidents, alarums and excursions that populated the year. This is a test. No conferring. Well, perhaps a little. (Answers will be published Monday.)

RUDERMAN--Dorothy, age 92, suddenly passed away on December 24, 2007. She was the beloved wife of Harry, who passed the century mark and is a retired maritime attorney. She was the beloved mother of Marvin, a neurologist, and the beloved grandmother of Avi, Noah and Rachel. She is also survived by nieces Rhoda Braff, Dani (Gary) Wohl, Nora Hochman and nephew Barry, and his wife Barbara. She was a speech therapist in the New York school system and was deeply involved in sculpture, for which she had great talent. She had a wonderful zest for life and lived it accordingly. She was loved and respected by all who knew her. This was a great loss to her family and friends.

GLASS--Elizabeth Marie Marjorie Louise Picot de Vauloge, 83, of Bloomfield, formerly of Farmington, widow of Edgar Toll Glass Jr., passed away peacefully Thursday, December 20th. Born in Laussane, Switzerland, daughter of the late Vicomte and Vicomtesse Robert de Vauloge. Mrs. Glass is survived by her three children, Edgar Glass of Old Lyme, CT; Katharine Hayes of Falls Church, VA; and Peter Glass of Parker, CO, her grandchildren, Elizabeth Dale of Arlington, VA; Robert Dale of Savannah, GA; Ian Glass and Graham Glass of Parker, CO, her niece Anita Saman of Geneva, Switzerland, greatniece Olivia Saman and great-nephew Alexandre Saman. She was predeceased by her sister Katharine Alig. She leaves a large extended family in Europe where she spent the first 16 years of her life. Funeral services will be held on April 19, 2008 in St. James Church, Farmington, CT. Burial will be in Riverside Cemetery, Farmington, CT. A reception will follow. In lieu of flowers, a gift to the Nature Conservancy, 55 High Street, Middletown, CT 06457 would be appreciated.

As I was recently reminded, there is no day of the year better for flying than Christmas Day. The roads are relatively clear, even in Los Angeles, and the planes are seldom full. Those unfortunates on duty in the airport and the skies join with those eccentrics who choose to take to the air in place of family festivities and make the terminal itself, the jet, a site for celebration. One year, on Christmas Day, a British Airways gate agent gave me, and even the friend who came to see me off, a free pass to the First Class lounge and an invitation to go wild. Few immigrations officers or security personnel (other than sniffer dogs) want to be cast as Scrooge, and gifts acquire a special meaning when they come from strangers.

KEOKUK, Iowa - There are usually a dozen television cameras and DV cameras recording Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign events, and one wonders if some of her remarks - taken out of context - could end up in a Republican attack ad someday.

Barack Obama has always excited big Labor and other Democratic constituencies, even if they weren't necessarily ready to endorse him for the presidency. Now, though, as Mr. Obama goes all out to undermine a surging John Edwards in the final days before the Iowa caucuses, that cordial relationship is being put to the test. Mr. Obama has essentially charged that Mr. Edwards is a hypocrite because, while Mr. Edwards has said he favors banning unregulated campaign money from outside groups, his campaign is getting millions of dollars worth of assistance from outside contributors - namely unions. What's remarkable about this line of attack is that, while Mr. Obama is aiming squarely at Mr. Edwards, he also risks alienating some of the most powerful interest groups in Democratic Washington. In case you haven't been paying attention, here's what's going on: several state chapters of the mighty Service Employees International Union have endorsed Mr. Edwards and set up an independent entity - the kind of so-called 527 that Edwards himself has decried in the past - to run ads on his behalf. They even hired his 2004 campaign manager, Nick Baldick, to oversee the operation. (The state and municipal workers union and Emily's List are also in Iowa, dropping a lot of cash in support of Hillary Clinton.) Mr. Obama, the only one of the three leading candidates who hasn't received a big union endorsement, has repeatedly called on Mr. Edwards to ask his labor friends to stand down. Mr. Edwards has responded by saying that he still opposes such groups in theory, but that he isn't involved in the union effort and is powerless to control it.

A tighter, stronger Washington Redskins team has emerged from a turbulent season, and the reward is a trip to the postseason.
After World War II, Huntsville, Ala., was transformed by Wernher von Braun’s rocket program. Now it has one of the country’s highest concentrations of scientists and engineers.
Thomas Morgenstern of Austria turned in the best overall performance Sunday to win the first stop of the prestigious Four Hills ski jumping tournament in Oberstdorf, Germany.
The phenomenon is a testament to the Communist-run island’s severe housing shortage, but also to Cubans’ ability to stay friendly — or at least civil — under the most awkward circumstances.
Fifty-three children under the age of 6 live inside a prison in Mexico City with their mothers, who are serving sentences for crimes from drug dealing to kidnapping to homicide.
The Jets season officially ended on Sunday evening on an overtime field goal in an almost empty stadium, in the rain, to a mixed soundtrack of more jeers than cheers.
The University of Tennessee’s football team is in a difficult position after a handful of players were declared academically ineligible for the Outback Bowl because of grades.
Georges St. Pierre won to take the interim welterweight title Saturday night in the mixed martial card UFC 79, while Chuck Liddell won a light-heavyweight showdown by unanimous decision.
North Korea has not met its commitment to account fully for its nuclear activities by the end of 2007 under a disarmament agreement, the U.S. said.
Mr. Navarra was a retired New York Fire Department lieutenant who coordinated the starts of the last 26 New York City Marathons.
A conservative group began running a new advertisement in Iowa over the weekend that attacks Mitt Romney for changing positions on abortion and urges voters to back Mike Huckabee.
Liverpool missed a chance to close in on the Premier League leader when it played Manchester City to a 0-0 tie Sunday.
Dr. Wachman was president of Lincoln and Temple Universities and interim president of two other Pennsylvania colleges.
Khary Orr, an employee of the Newark Division of Public Buildings whom Newark’s mayor called “the pride of our city,” was shot to death Sunday.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is growing increasingly enchanted with the idea of making an independent presidential bid.
Coach Isiah Thomas’s latest desperation move to break his team’s funk was to keep Eddie Curry out of the starting lineup for the first time in two years. The result was another rout.
The winter holidays, the subway and the tooth fairy make appearances in this week’s reader-contributed tales.

Releasing tear gas instead of fog as planned, a Berlin theater sent its audience fleeing from a performance based on the 1928 German children’s book “Emil and the Detectives,” Agence France-Presse reported. The mistake took place on Saturday afternoon at the Volksbühne theater in central Berlin, where about 100 people were watching the show. Several had to be treated for eye problems.

The death of three former contestants in an automobile accident on Saturday night brought a sudden cancellation of the Serbian version of the “Big Brother” reality show, Agence France-Presse reported on Sunday, citing the producer and broadcaster. After the fatal crash near Belgrade , the remaining seven housemates were taken from the home that is the setting for the show and told the news off-camera. The contest was to have ended on Jan. 5.

The French short film “La Danse, l’Art de la Rencontre” (“Dance and the Art of Encounters”) won first prize at the first Baghdad international film festival held in the Iraqi capital since 2005, Agence France-Presse reported. Directed by Domenica Hervieu, the documentary is a poetic exploration of the world of dance. Tight security surrounded the festival, held at the Palestine Hotel, where 63 films from around the world were screened.

The pop singer Kylie Minogue and the actor Ian McKellen were among the names on the traditional New Year’s honors list issued by Queen Elizabeth II, according to Reuters and the BBC. Ms. Minogue, who returned to the stage late last year after surgery and chemotherapy for breast cancer, becomes an officer of the Order of the British Empire. Mr. McKellen, a Shakespearean actor perhaps best known for his portrayal of the wizard Gandalf in the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy, was made a Companion of Honor, restricted to 65 members. Among others on the honors list were the Jethro Tull frontman Ian Anderson, the actors Richard Griffiths and Julie Walters, the novelist and playwright Hanif Kureishi and Nicholas Kenyon, managing director of the Barbican Center and former director of the BBC Proms. The list was the first to be recommended to the queen by Prime Minister Gordon Brown.

A judge has ordered mediation in a lawsuit brought by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to bar the public sale of two Oscars awarded to the silent-film star Mary Pickford (1892-1979), above, and one presented to her husband Buddy Rogers (1904-99), The Associated Press reported. The defendant is Rogers’s second wife, Beverly Rogers. The academy argues that under its bylaws, it gets the first chance to buy the Oscars, for $10 each. If mediation fails, the dispute is scheduled to go to trial next year.
“National Treasure: Book of Secrets” remains a gold mine, Queen Elizabeth II honors pop singer Kylie Minogue and the actor Ian McKellen, along with more cultural news.

Citing insufficient evidence, prosecutors in Los Angeles have decided not to charge the Grammy Award-winning singer and actress Brandy, below, in connection with a car crash in December 2006 that killed a 38-year-old woman, Reuters reported. The police had recommended that Brandy, 28, whose real name is Brandy Norwood, be charged with vehicular manslaughter in the accident, involving four vehicles. A lawyer for Ms. Norwood, who starred in the television comedy “Moesha,” said she was “extremely pleased” at the prosecutors’ conclusion. Relatives of the dead woman, Awatef Aboudihaj, have filed a $50 million wrongful-death lawsuit against Ms. Norwood.

Five of James Brown’s children are seeking to invalidate his will on grounds that former advisers seeking to profit unduly influenced Brown, below, to create charitable trusts, The Associated Press reported, citing court documents. The children of Brown, the soul singer, were largely excluded from the financial part of the will, which left the bulk of Brown’s money to trusts to educate his grandchildren and needy youngsters. Five of the Brown children are challenging the will in Aiken County Probate Court in South Carolina. One of the former advisers, Albert H. Dallas, denied the accusations and called efforts to void the will “an act of desperation.” One grandchild whose tuition would be paid by trusts created under the will accused his relatives of trying to break the charities to get the money. Most of Brown’s estate, including his home in Beech Island, S.C., and rights to his image, name and music, would go to the James Brown “I Feel Good” Trust for the education of needy children in South Carolina and Georgia, as well as to a family trust to educate Brown’s grandchildren younger than 35. He died at 73 on Christmas Day 2006.

“National Treasure: Book of Secrets” (distributed by Disney) dominated North American box offices for a second consecutive weekend, holding the No. 1 ranking by taking in an estimated $35.6 million at 3,832 theaters for a two-week total of $124 million. “Alvin and the Chipmunks” (Fox), starring Jason Lee as the surrogate father of the animated musical ’munks, clambered up the ladder to second place from third last week on a gross of $30 million at 3,484 theaters, bringing its three-week total to $142.3 million, according to the box-office tracking company Media by Numbers. Although “I Am Legend” (Warner Brothers), with Will Smith, dropped to third place from second, it attracted $27.5 million at 3,636 theaters to push its three-week total to $194.6 million. “Charlie Wilson’s War” (Universal), starring Tom Hanks as a conniving congressman, held on to fourth place, with $11.7 million at 2,575 theaters. Fox Searchlight’s well-received “Juno,” with $10.3 million from 998 theaters, finished fifth. On a per-screen basis, Paul Thomas Anderson’s “There Will Be Blood” (Paramount Vantage), starring Daniel Day-Lewis as a monstrous oilman, was the weekend’s winner, averaging $92,763 on each of two screens.

Who may be bigger in Spain than J. K. Rowling? None other than Ken Follett, best known for his thrillers. About 525,000 copies of the Spanish translation of his new historical novel, “World Without End,” sold out within hours of being put on sale on Friday, Agence France-Presse reported. The daily newspaper El Mundo said Mondadori, the publisher, had ordered a rush reprint of 175,000. The publisher said that the single-day sales were unsurpassed, even by Ms. Rowling’s “Harry Potter” books. The publisher said that “The Pillars of the Earth,” a 1989 prequel to “World Without End,” had sold 5.5 million copies as the novel most read by Spaniards in the last 20 years.

In the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, 45 percent said they were aware of how candidates for president are doing in the opinion polls; 54 percent said they were not.
