The major sporting and television advertising events on New Year's Day are the collection of college football games. Tuesday's lineup includes the Rose Bowl, Cotton Bowl, Sugar Bowl, Gator Bowl, Outback Bowl and the Capital One Bowl. The N.C.A.A. has a stand-alone title game in the Bowl Championship Series to choose the national champion. Advertisers spent $63 million on last year's title game, above, when Florida beat Ohio State, 41-14.

Kerry Collins waited all season to prove his value in Tennessee. The Titans would not have been celebrating Sunday night without him. Collins rescued his teammates in the most precarious of circumstances, leading them to three second-half field goals in relief of the injured Vince Young and helping Tennessee rally for a 16-10 victory over the Indianapolis Colts that produced cheers in Nashville and moans in Cleveland.

Larry Fitzgerald caught 11 passes for 171 yards and 2 touchdowns in the Cardinals' 48-19 victory over the Rams. It was Arizona's highest-scoring game in 30 years. Andre' Davis returned two kickoffs for touchdowns in the Texans' 42-28 win over the Jaguars. He is the seventh player with two in one game. One was for 97 yards, the other for 104.

BUTTERWORTH--Olga, Beloved lifeline and counselor in the Unity movement, passed suddenly December 26th at home In Greenwich, CT. She was 87. The widow of Eric Butterworth, she and her world-renowned late husband together formed the Unity Center in New York City, and in more than 30 years developed it from a tiny congregation into one of more than 7,000 congregants, holding weekly services in Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center. Olga, an ordained minister, continued to serve Unity, delivering her last meditation on December 23rd, the Sunday before Christmas. May Divine Love transform a challenging ending into a joyously fulfilled new beginning. ''So be it,'' as Olga would say. Survivors include her beloved nieces Pauline Fiorita of Greenwich, Lucille Glascow of East Windsor, NJ, nephew Paul Bacco of Wilton, CT., and a stepson, Tom Butterworth of Seattle, WA. Also surviving is her adored Mignon, a Pappilion. Burial services are private. An open memorial is planned for a later date, which will be announced. Contributions may be made to the Eric Butterworth Foundation, Box 1501, Greenwich, CT 06836 or The Unity Center, 213 West 58th Street, New York, NY 10019.

The Advertising column in Business Day on Thursday about RedPlum.com, a Web site for product coupons, contained an imprecise reference to practices on two competing sites, CoolSavings.com and Eversave.com. Both sites offer printable coupons to users without the need to register by name, address, e-mail address, birth date or gender. While both sites request this information -- and require it for some services, like free samples -- users may opt out of divulging such information and still print out coupons.

LIVINGSTON--Alexander Abraham, 23 April 1912-13 September 2007. Brooklynborn to immigrant parents, graduated from NYU in Law 1935, wounded in Normandy 1944, wed 1946, Alex retired from the Bar in 1993. Tried skeptic, faithful liberal, stern yet forgiving judge, he cherished learning and the arts lifelong. Now rejoining Selma, beloved wife of 48 years, he leaves us bereft of his trusted guidance and singular character.

Serena Williams began preparations for her Australian Open title defense with a 6-0, 2-6, 7-5 win over Lucie Safarova on Monday in the Hopman Cup mixed-teams tournament in Perth, Australia. The win gave the United States a 1-0 lead over the Czech Republic.Williams arrived in Perth late because of a stomach ailment and did not play in the Americans' opening match, a 2-1 victory against India on Saturday.

The Board and staff of the 92nd Street Y express deepest sympathy on the loss of Michele Arnhold, sister-in-law of devoted trustee Jody Arnhold, sister of John Arnhold and aunt of Paul and Julia. Many candidates in the crowded race for president are looking beyond the caucuses on Thursday in Iowa to the New Hampshire primary just five days later. That could produce a logistical nightmare, with a cast of thousands moving all at once from Des Moines to Manchester, N.H. The possibility that no candidate will emerge with a decisive victory on either the Democratic or Republican side, combined with the unusually tight turnaround time, means that some campaigns will pull up stakes Thursday night before the caucus results are even announced.

The 2008 presidential race is filled with candidates making their second effort to win the White House. So why then are Senator Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle, suggesting to voters that this campaign could be Mr. Obama's best -- or possibly only -- shot at the office? ''One of the things I offer in this race is that we still remember what it means to be normal,'' Mr. Obama, Democrat of Illinois, told an audience in Iowa late last week. ''My wife and I were talking the other day, and she said, 'We're not doing this again.'''

The Chiefs' Tony Gonzalez broke Shannon Sharpe's N.F.L. record for receptions by a tight end, catching his 816th pass in the third quarter against the Jets. Devin Hester of the Bears broke his own record for returns for touchdowns, with his sixth. The league's 42 return touchdowns this season is also a record.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and George Stephanopoulos go way back, and Mrs. Clinton reminded viewers of that Sunday, as Mr. Stephanopoulos interviewed her on the ABC program ''This Week.'' Mr. Stephanopoulos was at the Clintons' side through the 1992 presidential campaign. He joined them in the White House and then left in 1996, becoming a commentator for ABC News and writing a tell-some memoir in which he wrote of President Bill Clinton's ''shamelessness'' and how Mrs. Clinton lambasted her husband while he ate his cereal.

With the hot, dry Santa Ana winds acting as bellows, wildfires in Southern California in October destroyed hundreds of homes, killed 10 people and prompted mass evacuations. The disaster led to debate, once more, on whether growth should be regulated and restricted in fire-prone areas.

The pop singer Kylie Minogue and the actor Ian McKellen were among the names on the traditional New Year's honors list issued by Queen Elizabeth II, according to Reuters and the BBC. Ms. Minogue, who returned to the stage late last year after surgery and chemotherapy for breast cancer, becomes an officer of the Order of the British Empire. Mr. McKellen, a Shakespearean actor perhaps best known for his portrayal of the wizard Gandalf in the ''Lord of the Rings'' trilogy, was made a Companion of Honor, restricted to 65 members. Among others on the honors list were the Jethro Tull frontman Ian Anderson, the actors Richard Griffiths and Julie Walters, the novelist and playwright Hanif Kureishi and Nicholas Kenyon, managing director of the Barbican Center and former director of the BBC Proms. The list was the first to be recommended to the queen by Prime Minister Gordon Brown.

PUGH--Billy G. 83, passed away after a short battle with pancreatic cancer. He is preceded in death by his daughter, Patricia Martin, parents, John W. and Nannie Pugh, his brothers, Sonny Pugh and J W. Pugh, and his sister Dortha Baker. Billy is survived by his wife, Linda J. Pugh, son, Bill Pugh Jr., daughter Linda Beth Bartlett, brother, Robert Pugh, and his three god children, Courtney Nicole Tilton, Grayson Edward Tilton, and Christopher Lancaster. He is also survived by numerous grandchildren, nieces, nephews, and his special friends, Laura Tilton, Jennifer Hawn Caldwell, and James C. Storm Jr. Pallbearers are Jim Storm Jr., Judge Jack Hunter, John L. Kingston, Butch Weed, George Hawn, and Doug Allison. Honorary pallbearers Courtney and Grayson Tilton. Visitation was held on Friday, December 28, 2007 at Seaside Funeral Home Chapel. A funeral service was held on Saturday, December 29, 2007 at Church of The Good Sheppard. Interment was at Seaside Memorial Park. Donations can be made to M.D. Anderson Cancer, Gastrointestinal Center in the name of Billy Pugh. 1515 Holcombe Blvd. Houston, TX 77030.

An article in Business Day on Friday about Apple Inc.'s agreement with 20th Century Fox for digital movie rentals rendered incorrectly the name of Apple's annual exhibition. It is Macworld, not MacWorld.
BROWN--Vita, died on December 29, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of Ronald Brown and Robert and Marjorie Brown. Cherished grandmother of Emily.

Quarterback Derek Anderson hurt the pinky finger on his throwing hand but returned to the Browns' 20-7 win over the 49ers. ''We kissed it and rubbed some aspirin on it,'' Coach Romeo Crennel said. ... Running back Ryan Grant (stinger) and cornerback/punt returner Will Blackmon (foot) left the Packers' win. ... Saints receiver Marques Colston hurt his left wrist against the Bears.
GORMAN--Jack. December 31, 1914. Happy Birthday Dad. We miss you and we will be toasting you tonight! Love, Linda and Doug, Abby and Matt and Richard and Meredith

Who may be bigger in Spain thanJ. K. Rowling? None other than Ken Follett, best known for his thrillers. About 525,000 copies of the Spanish translation of his new historical novel, ''World Without End,'' sold out within hours of being put on sale on Friday, Agence France-Presse reported. The daily newspaper El Mundo said Mondadori, the publisher, had ordered a rush reprint of 175,000. The publisher said that the single-day sales were unsurpassed, even by Ms. Rowling's ''Harry Potter'' books. The publisher said that ''The Pillars of the Earth,'' a 1989 prequel to ''World Without End,'' had sold 5.5 million copies as the novel most read by Spaniards in the last 20 years.

KLIMERMAN--David, 91, on December 27, 2007, husband of Dorothy for 71 years; father of Edward (Janet); grandfather of Allison (Mark), Caroline (Patrick), Matthew and Alex; great-grandfather of Jonah and Gabriel. Services 12:30pm today at Sanctuary of Abraham & Sarah Mausoleum Chapel, Paramus, NJ.

Quarterback Vinny Testaverde took his last snap in the same city where he began his N.F.L. career 20 years ago. Testaverde, the first pick in the 1987 draft by the Buccaneers, entered Carolina's game at Tampa Bay on Sunday with 35 seconds remaining. He received polite applause from what was left of a crowd of 65,609, then took a knee on the last play.

LASKIN--Bruce, 51. It is with profound sorrow that we mourn the sudden and untimely passing of our dear friend, Bruce Laskin. Perhaps because he was orphaned at an early age Bruce was mature beyond his years and one of the most capable people we have ever met. Bruce was a wonderful husband and father. He was calm, he was non-judgemental, he was positive, he was a teacher, he was also hilarious. Our hearts go out to Sandy, Michael and David. Bruce, we will dearly miss you. Marsha and Leon Wagner LASKIN--Bruce Steven, passed away suddenly on December 28, 2007 at age 51. Born in Forest Hills to Michael and Lillian Laskin. He will be remembered as a loving, kind and nurturing individual. Survived by his wife Sandy, and children Michael and David. For information, Zion Memorial Chapel, 914381-1809. LASKIN--Bruce. The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of our esteemed member. We express deepest sympathy to his wife Sandy, his sons Michael and David and the entire family. Aubrey L. Glazer, Rabbi Norton D. Shargel, Rabbi Emeritus Paul Hendler, President Karen Goldstick, Chairman

PHOTO: PAKISTAN'S SPIRAL: Supporters of Benazir Bhutto being arrested outside her home in Islamabad in November, after martial law was declared. Weeks later, she was killed in a suicide attack. (PHOTOGRAPH BY TOMAS MUNITA FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)
Washington is always a place of change, but with the end of the Bush administration in sight, there was more upheaval than usual in 2007.
A look at the stage work of actress Fiona Shaw.

DES MOINES _ Mike Huckabee held a little event here on Tuesday to thank the roughly 700 bloggers who, he said, were responsible for keeping his campaign alive. Because he had no money and initially got very little media attention, he said, he could not have kept going without their dedication.
A defunct railway on the far West Side of Manhattan is destined to become a park in the sky.

NEW ORLEANS -- After a day of watching bowl games, it's nice to get settled in the press box here at the Superdome. Players are milling around on the field during pregame warm ups. The Georgia fans just roared in approval as some of their players ran onto the field.
In June 2006, at the invitation of The Times, I spent a month writing a daily online column on matters evolutionary. I called it The Wild Side.

DES MOINES -- The Des Moines Register poll, which showed Senator Barack Obama pulling away from Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and former Senator John Edwards, had some interesting numbers below the top line. (To refresh your memory: Mr. Obama had 32 percent, Mrs. Clinton 25 percent and Mr. Edwards 24 percent.)
The crisis over the disputed elections in Kenya worsened.

Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas Governor, is again making misleading statements about how long he was unaware of a National Intelligence Estimate finding that Iran was not pursuing nuclear weapons.

Ron Paul supporters, already infamous for their avid online presence, are absolutely enraged that their candidate is being left out of the Fox News G.O.P. candidate debate on Sunday, and there's a chance Mr. Paul could be left out of Saturday's ABC forum, too.

The Winter Classic just ended with a Sidney Crosby shootout goal. The game's more thrilling moments involved stops in play when the ice doctors patted and sprayed problematic patches of ice. Would it hold out? As the snow fell more densely, stick handling involved more flakes than puck.

Salavat Yulaev Ufa, the top team in Russia and, until this week, the World Club Top 10, did not exactly cover itself in glory over the holiday break. The Bashkir club lost twice to a team of European-based Canadians at the Spengler Cup tournament in Davos, Switzerland, including a defeat in the championship game. Even though both losses were by a single goal, Salavat's performance can only be counted as an embarrassment to what had been considered the strongest side on the continent.

AMES, Iowa - Call it post-New Year's fun or pre-caucus jitters, but Hillary Rodham Clinton's sense of humor - which her friends often recommend when trying to "humanize" her - was clearly on display today.
Pakistanis made fitful attempts to return to normal life in Karachi, the hometown of Benazir Bhutto, after her assassination last week touched off an outbreak of violence.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa - Representative Dennis Kucinich urged his Iowa followers today to select Senator Barack Obama as their second choice at the caucuses on Thursday if his support is not strong enough to be viable in the 1,781 precincts across the state.
CLIVE, Iowa-Mitt Romney has added a new favorite word, freighted with meaning in the context of his back and forth with rival Mike Huckabee, to his political lexicon today: serious.

IOWA FALLS, Iowa - Any reporter who spends time on a press bus rolling down the byways of Iowa will tell a willing listener why the experience, in a word, stinks: long hours on narrow bus seats, cold dinners eaten out of clamshells over a laptop with a dying battery, a different and unremarkable motel every night. (We found seven different room keys in the bottom of our purse this morning.)
Zion's Bancorpororation is taking more losses from an off balance sheet investment vehicle. This is the second time in two weeks that Zions has done that.
Standing in a trailer of wood shavings at the Cotton Bowl, Arkansas mascot Tusk II was in hog heaven this morning as fans took photos of him eating white grapes.

Court TV has always served up gritty stuff, like courtroom dramas and crime and justice shows. The cable channel's new name, truTV, is designed to reflect that, according to Marc Juris, the network's executive vice president and general manager.

Updated For most of the candidates, the fourth quarter was more about stumping than fund-raising. Not so for Representative Ron Paul of Texas, who has achieved that Howard Dean-esque feat of turning fervent netroots support into cold, hard cash. The libertarian-leaning Republican raked in $19.5 million over the last three months, which is likely to be more than any other G.O.P. candidate's haul. (As the campaign points out in its release this morning, the figure is over $9 million more than any Republican raised in the third quarter.)

This week Loden Dager writes from the road as they journey to Atlanta in search of inspiration.

It has finally arrived. The stretch run of this unbelievable college football season is upon us as we enter the new year. New Year's Day always brings a glut of college football games, and the B.C.S. games that follow over the next few days should be a good way to wrap up a crazy season. It also provides us with one last opportunity to prove how much, or how little, we know. So, as always, feel free to disagree and provide your own picks. As this season has taught us over and over again, you never know what's going to happen.
A weak dollar draws shoppers across the Atlantic.

Day 1 of the N.F.L. postseason is usually one of cleaning house. But in that respect, Monday was a relatively slow day. Brian Billick was fired by the Baltimore Ravens after a 5-11 season that included a nine-game losing streak. Rick Maese of The Baltimore Sun said the move was bold but necessary. Len Pasquarelli of ESPN writes that Billick lost his offensive touch. Adam Schefter of the NFL Network suggests Rex Ryan, Baltimore's defensive coordinator; Kirk Ferentz, University of Iowa head coach; and Mike Singletary, the 49ers' assistant head coach, as possible replacements.
International Herald Tribune reporter Katrin Bennhold on President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, who made his first official visit to Washington.

This fall, an ancient architectural gem called Trajan's Market (Mercati Di Traiano), re-opened after a two year renovation. Unearthed from Rome's hills only during the Mussolini era (1920s-30s) there is no proof that the structure ever actually functioned as a market. No matter.
In a new book, David Wilcove urges conservation of species and their ways, still so little understood.
Mr. Sottsass, an éminence grise of postmodern design, was responsible for the familiar bright red plastic Olivetti typewriter.
Allen Raymond’s tell-all book, “How to Rig an Election: Confessions of a Republican Operative,” should be a wake-up call.
Researchers have uncovered one secret to the Argentine ant’s success at invading new territory: dietary flexibility.
The lip of one pitcher plant species is slippery only when wet.
New software can identify individual whale sharks by analyzing individual patterns of spots and stripes on the fish’s skin.
Thanks to availability entrepreneurs, misinterpreting the weather is getting easier and easier.
To the Editor:.
As Mitt Romney, Fred S. Thompson and Mike Huckabee hit points all over Iowa in a closing flurry before Thursday’s caucuses, it can seem as if they are campaigning in three entirely different worlds.
The results of the Des Moines Register’s final poll of Iowa caucus-goers continued to reverberate across the campaign trail as the clock ticked toward the caucuses.
A 3-year-old girl was grazed by a bullet as she rode in the back of a car driven by her father in the Bronx Monday.

Hawaii, the only undefeated team remaining in this most volatile of college football seasons, is reaping the benefits of Boise State’s Fiesta Bowl win last year by playing in perhaps the most anticipated bowl game of this season.
A man suspected of killing a customer and wounding a manager at a Knoxville restaurant on Saturday was shot and killed by the police on Sunday.
Gil H. Jamieson, whose tenure as administrator of Gulf Coast recovery included controversies over formaldehyde in FEMA trailers and financing delays, will retire Thursday.
The new law toughens the Freedom of Information Act, requiring that agencies respond to requests within 20 days.
Deep, restful sleep may be important for keeping Type 2 diabetes at bay, researchers reported.
People with restless legs syndrome are twice as likely to have a stroke or heart disease and those with the most severe symptoms are at greatest risk, researchers said.

Philips Electronics said it had completed the sale of 800 million shares in the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company valued at about $1.5 billion. The sale of the shares will give Philips proceeds of about 980 million euros ($1.4 billion), and will result in a nontaxable net gain of about 530 million euros in its fourth-quarter results, Philips said. Philips still holds about 1.3 billion shares of Taiwan Semiconductor, or about 5 percent of the company.

The Boeing Company said that the budget airline Jeju Air Company had ordered five 737-800 airplanes, valued at $370 million at list prices. In a statement, Boeing said it had recorded orders for more than 4,400 737s, and has unfilled orders for more than 1,900 airplanes worth more than $140 billion at current list prices.
Continuing a 15-year trend, the murder rate in New York City has gone lower than many would have imagined.

Singapore’s economy expanded 7.5 percent in 2007, at the lower end of the government’s forecast range, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said. Growth eased from 7.9 percent in 2006 and is expected to slow further to as little as 4.5 percent next year. Mr. Lee, left, warned that the United States economy may enter a recession next year amid financial market turmoil. “A U.S. downturn would affect Asia too, but the impact on us would be offset somewhat by the strong momentum in the dynamic Asian economies,” Mr. Lee said. The full-year growth figure suggests that the $132 billion Southeast Asian economy may have contracted in the fourth quarter on an annualized basis, analysts said.

Italy’s economics minister promised to discuss the future of Milan’s Malpensa airport with local officials to defuse tensions over the expected downsizing of the airport if the carrier Alitalia is sold to Air France-KLM. Air France-KLM said that if it took over the money-losing Alitalia it would significantly scale down Malpensa, keeping Leonardo da Vinci Airport in Rome as its sole international hub in Italy. The plan has drawn fierce protests from officials in Lombardy, the region that includes Milan. Malpensa is 33 miles from downtown Milan, while the other city airport, Linate, is just six miles away. Since its reopening as an international hub in 1998, Malpensa has been plagued by flight delays, logistical difficulties and a scandal years ago when some employees were accused of stealing from luggage.

Shares of Baidu.com, owner of China’s most popular Internet search site, fell after the death of its chief financial officer, Shawn Wang. Mr. Wang died in an accident on Thursday, the company said in a statement on Saturday. A group of senior managers will take on his duties until a successor is named. Under Mr. Wang, Baidu’s shares soared past $400 in the United States last month, a 15-fold gain from their initial price of $27. The company has expanded its market share in China, taking 61 percent of Web queries to Google’s 24 percent, according to Analysys International in Beijing. Baidu fell $9.07, to $389.80 in New York. Baidu is the only Chinese company in the Nasdaq 100 index, which consists of the 100 biggest nonfinancial companies by market value listed on the Nasdaq.

The Royal Bank of Canada’s proposed $1.6 billion acquisition of Alabama National BanCorp was challenged by a group that claimed the Canadian bank engages in discriminatory lending. A financial advocacy group for poor consumers, Fair Finance Watch, said it asked the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, Va., in a letter for hearings and all documents relating to the proposed buyout. The Royal Bank agreed on Sept. 6 to buy Alabama National for cash and stock. Fair Finance Watch claimed that in 2006 Royal Bank’s RBC Centura unit denied mortgage refinance applications in Charlotte, N.C., to blacks 4.4 times more frequently than whites. The group said in the Atlanta area, RBC Centura denied home improvement mortgage applications of blacks 4.2 times more frequently than whites. A bank spokeswoman, Judi Levita, said “the lending practices of RBC Centura satisfactorily comply with all applicable requirements.”.
There is a possibility that this Knicks team could end up being branded the worst in franchise history, even worse than Larry Brown’s notorious 23-59 team from two years ago.

Stephon Marbury again practiced with the team, but did not talk with reporters. The Knicks said he would not speak publicly until after he plays his next game. He has had three stints of bereavement leave. ... Jamal Crawford practiced but was limited to shooting and drills as he wore a protective glove. He is questionable for Wednesday.

The Quotation of the Day on Monday, taken from a front-page article about the selection of Benazir Bhutto’s son to head Pakistan’s largest political party, carried an incorrect attribution in some editions. It was Asif Ali Zardari, the widower of Ms. Bhutto, who was killed on Thursday, who said: “It’s not an easy chair to sit on. A, she leaves me. B, she ties me in this. To say the least, it’s overbearing.” The comment was not by Ms. Bhutto’s son, Bilawal Bhutto Zardari.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about Nintendo’s video game consoles misstated the capabilities of one of the devices. A statement about movie-playing should have referred to the PlayStation Portable or PSP, made by Sony, not to the hand-held Nintendo DS. (The DS does not play movies.) The article also misspelled the surname of the president and chief operating officer of Nintendo of America. He is Reggie Fils-Amie, not Fils-Aimee.

An obituary on Monday about Marvin Wachman, the former president of Lincoln and Temple Universities, misstated the date of his death and misspelled the given name of his wife and the middle name of his daughter. Dr. Wachman died on Dec. 23, not Dec. 22. His wife is Adeline Wachman, not Adelina, and his daughter is Lynn Alison Wachman, not Lynn Allison. The obituary also omitted the cause of death. Dr. Wachman died of congestive heart failure, his wife said.

An article on Thursday about John McCain’s relationship with his children misstated, in some editions, the site of a graduation ceremony for Mr. McCain’s son Jimmy, which was attended by several siblings. Jimmy McCain graduated from Marine boot camp; there is no Marine Academy.

Andrei Kirilenko had 14 points, 8 rebounds and 7 assists, and the Utah Jazz finally ended Portland’s near-perfect December on Monday night, defeating the visiting Trail Blazers, 111-101, to end their 13-game winning streak.
Marc-Andre Bergeron had two goals and an assist, and the Islanders scored three goals in a 3-minute-39-second stretch of their 4-1 victory against the Carolina Hurricanes on Monday night.

A jumps race at Tramore in southeast Ireland on Monday ended in farce with nine of the jockeys being barred for five days. All 14 riders left the course before completing the final lap. Five eventually realized their mistake and finished. The jockey Andrew McNamara won the race on Mr Aussie by six lengths. The jockeys were penalized for not giving their mounts the best finish possible.

The Scottish Premier League match Wednesday between Glasgow rivals Celtic and Rangers was postponed Monday after the death of the Motherwell captain, Phil O’Donnell, over the weekend. Motherwell’s next two games had already been called off, but Celtic asked for Wednesday’s match to be rescheduled out of respect for O’Donnell, a former Celtic player.

Fabrice Santoro, the oldest singles player competing regularly on the ATP Tour, began what may be his last season Monday at the Qatar Open. Santoro, a 35-year-old Frenchman, beat Andreas Seppi of Italy, 6-4, 1-6, 6-2. Assuming that Santoro remains healthy before the Australian Open, which begins Jan. 14, he will break Andre Agassi’s record of playing in 61 Grand Slam events.

The United States and Sweden advanced to the semifinals of the world junior championship Monday in Liberec, Czech Republic.Colin Wilson had a hat trick for the United States, which also got goals from Tyler Ruegsegger and James van Riemsdyk, in a 5-3 victory over Finland. Jeremy Smith made 10 saves and Joe Palmer added 8.The Americans automatically advanced to the semifinals by taking first place in Group B, going 4-0 to earn 12 points. The only other time the United States won its first four games was in 2004, when it captured its only gold medal in the event.Sweden beat host Czech Republic, 4-2, to go 4-0 and win Group A.

DaJuan Summers had 15 points and 9 rebounds, Jonathan Wallace became Georgetown’s career leader in 3-pointers and the seventh-ranked Hoyas (10-1) closed out their non-conference schedule with an 82-55 victory against visiting Fordham on Monday.
North Korea remained silent as the last hours of 2007 passed and it missed a year-end deadline to give a full accounting of its nuclear weapons.

A ban on smoking in hotels, bars, restaurants and cafes went into effect at the start of the new year on Tuesday. Smoking was already banned in offices, schools, airports, hospitals, train stations and other public places. Health Minister Roselyn Bachelot has repeatedly warned that the cafe ban will be strictly enforced.
It is the humble and ubiquitous lottery that looks like the most insidious form of gambling.

Prime Minister Ehud Olmert has sent a letter to defense, housing and agriculture ministers, saying that his and the defense minister’s authorization would be required for any new building, planning or land expropriation for Jewish settlements in the West Bank.
Bhutan held its first elections as part of its transition from an absolute monarchy to a constitutional democracy. The vote was for 15 of the 25 seats of the upper house of Parliament.
Five Palestinians were killed and about 30 were wounded in armed clashes between Fatah supporters and Hamas policemen, according to news agency reports.
Slovenia is set to become the first former Communist state to hold the European Union’s rotating presidency as it takes over the six-month post from Portugal on Tuesday.
United States military deaths reached 110 in 2007, the highest since the American-led invasion in 2001, according to a count by The Associated Press.
The 11-year-old Queens boy who was shot in the chest on Sunday night is in stable condition. His brother believes the crime may be related to an earlier shooting.
Despite missing 23 scholarship players due to suspension and injury, Florida State played with verve and passion behind a feisty Coach Bobby Bowden but came up short Monday.
For the N.H.L., the Winter Classic is an opportunity to make a good impression on a network television audience in the United States, where the sport has languished behind other major sports.
Hundreds of local governments are unable to access money they deposited in a statewide investment pool.
South Korea has become one of the world’s most credit-card-friendly countries. With cards everywhere, however, the challenge is to attract consumers.
Scouring remote regions for plants, oils and extracts can yield cures — and big profits — for pharmaceutical companies and indigenous tribes.
What better way to ring out college football’s Year of the Upset than with the Rose Bowl pairing of Southern California and Illinois, teams who helped give the year its identity?
Even a report that showed sales of existing homes had been nudged up in November failed to lift the market as traders closed their books on the year.
Jonathan Stewart set a Sun Bowl record with a career-high 253 yards rushing and Justin Roper threw four touchdown passes in his first start as Oregon beat South Florida, 56-21, on Monday in El Paso.
The candidates drove home their final messages to Iowa voters, while calibrating expectations on how they will perform in the caucuses on Thursday.
Some hope the oil industry will prompt business and workers to return to the state.
Details of jury deliberations emerge in the case of John H. White. He was found guilty last month of second-degree manslaughter in a racially charged shooting.
Sunday’s wild-card playoff game against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers represents the next big moment for the franchise and Eli Manning, the quarterback who serves as the face of it.
It seems impossible that 1968, the most incredible year of a most incredible decade, was 40 years ago.
In what may become an A-list booking-war blitz, David Letterman has landed comedian Robin Williams as the first guest when “The Late Show” returns to CBS.
States get millions from the legal settlement struck with the big tobacco companies nine years ago. But the money, for the most part, is not being spent on smoking prevention.
Mr. Grima came to prominence in the 1960s with an organic style that captured the mood of a new generation of postwar fashion designers.
The Nets announced Monday that they had hired Kiki Vandeweghe to become a special assistant to Rod Thorn and Vandeweghe could eventually become the team’s next general manager.
Quarterback Chad Pennington was the last of the Jets to leave the locker room Monday. He exited toward an uncertain future, unsure if he will return next season.
Spurred by a Supreme Court decision, independent groups are committing resources as never before.
Money could smooth the way toward getting on the ballot in all 50 states as an independent candidate.
David Beckham played sparingly for the L.A. Galaxy, but was marketed brilliantly and ceaselessly.
A number of polls have suggested that the Democratic caucus on Thursday night could end up more or less a tie.
Sara Jane Moore, a 1970s radical who tried to assassinate President Gerald R. Ford, was released Monday.
Warren E. Buffett may not be called to testify in the criminal trial of Ronald E. Ferguson.
After being treated for an anthrax infection and enduring a four month cleanup of his home, a Connecticut drum maker and his family start fresh.
The day after the N.F.L. regular season ended, the Baltimore Ravens decided they would have better success next season without Brian Billick, who was fired Monday after the Ravens finished 5-11.
The past two months challenged Mitt Romney to adapt to a rapidly changing political situation as he grappled with Mike Huckabee’s lead in Iowa.
The way that Detroit auto executives have been talking, 2008 will be a bad year to sell cars and trucks in the United States.
Pakistan’s ambassador to the U.S. said his government would not endorse a separate inquiry modeled after one carried out by the U.N. after the assassination of Rafik Hariri of Lebanon in 2005.
A Venezuelan-led mission to release three hostages held by a Colombian rebel group seemed to be breaking down with accusations of sabotage on both sides.
Mike Huckabee got free publicity for his message against Mitt Romney while claiming the moral high ground.
Bigger is better, right? Not so fast. Corporate America appears to have had second thoughts in 2007.
Gusting winds, blowing snow and the threat of avalanches forced the closing of a 70-mile stretch of mountain highway just west of Denver.
As of Tuesday, commuters in Queens and Brooklyn will no longer be able to skip the subway and cross the river on scheduled boat service.
A federal judge ruled that the wireless chip maker Qualcomm could sell through January 2009 some chips whose designs infringe patents held by the Broadcom Corporation.
The Texas High School Baseball Coaches Association said Monday that Roger Clemens was still welcome at its convention, which begins Jan. 10.
Faced with fines from the city’s Sanitation Department, building maintenance workers are left the dirty job of separating recyclables that have been mixed with regular trash.

PLAYER The Italian Fabio Capello, 61, was only the second non-British coach to take over England’s national team. England has not won a major tournament since playing host to the World Cup ... in 1966. Capello has won league titles with A.C. Milan, Real Madrid, Roma and Juventus (and played for Italy in the 1974 World Cup). He faces the unenviable task of dealing with the ravenous English tabloids.
Nasdaq Stock Market obtained clearance to sell a stake to Borse Dubai, paving the way for Nasdaq’s eventual acquisition of the OMX exchange in Stockholm.
A federal judge has refused to suppress evidence in a case accusing Hollywood private investigator Anthony Pellicano of illegally wiretapping stars.
Kenya sank deeper into trouble, with a curfew imposed in Kisumu, the country’s third-largest city, ethnic fighting intensifying and more than 100 people killed in election-related violence.
The single-family home builder M/I Homes said that it had sold some Florida land to reduce debt, and is exiting the West Palm Beach market in that state.
Sales of previously owned homes nudged up in November, but that was not enough to improve the broader picture of a market racked by record-high foreclosures.

BATTERY RESTRICTIONS Beginning Tuesday, airline passengers cannot pack any loose lithium batteries in checked bags, though the batteries are permitted if contained within laptops, cellphones or other electronic devices, according to a new rule by the Transportation Department. The department said that loose lithium batteries can short-circuit and create a fire hazard in cargo holds. The new rule also limits to two the number of large-size spare lithium batteries that may be brought on in carry-on bags, but a department spokeswoman says that restriction applies mostly to professional and industrial-use batteries and does not affect most lithium batteries used in consumer electronics like laptops and cellphones.

MEYER--Leonard B., composer, author, philosopher and esteemed and honored humanities professor died on December 30, 2007. He was 89. He contributed major works in the fields of aesthetic theory in music, and compositional analysis and was one of the first to explore the relationship between Game Theory and musical composition. His books include Emotion and Meaning in Music, The Rhythmic Structure of Music (with Grosvenor Cooper), Some Remarks on Value and Greatness in Music, Style and Music: Theory History and Ideology (General Editor), The Spheres of Music : A Gathering of Essays, as well as numerous articles and other scholarly works. His writings address such diverse subjects as musical emotion, the psychology of music, musical analysis and theory, aesthetics, information theory, the anthropology of art, and art and neuroscience. Meyer studied at Bard College, Columbia University (B.A. in Philosophy, M.A. in Music) and the University of Chicago (Ph.D. in History of Culture). As a composer, he studied under Stefan Wolpe and Aaron Copland. He taught at the University of Chicago for 29 years. He was a Fellow at the Center for Advanced Studies at Wesleyan University, a Guggenheim Fellow and was elected to the American Academy of Arts and Letters. In 1975, he was named Benjamin Franklin Professor of Music and Humanities at the University of Pennsylvania. He was beloved by generations of music and humanities students. Born in New York City, Professor Meyer lived a full life devoted to his family, his students, colleagues, and the humanities. During World War II, he fought with the front line infantry at the Ardennes and the Battle of the Bulge. A great wit, Meyer regaled friends and family with recitations from Gilbert & Sullivan and Shakespeare, and frequent puns. He asked that his tombstone be engraved with the musical pun in Hamlet's dying words: The rest is silence. He will be deeply missed by his loving daughters, Muffie (Ronald Blumer), Carlin (Peter Bienstock) and Erica (Potter Palmer), granddaughters, Emma and Molly, his first wife and mother of his children, Lee Meyer of Chicago, his sister-in-law Karen Levy and his care givers, Pauline Whitehill, Sandra Jones and Brigid Nicholson. He was pre-deceased by his second wife, Janet Levy, and his brother, Daniel Meyer, and sister, Carolyn Meyer. There will be a memorial service at Riverside Memorial, 76th and Amsterdam, on January 13th at 2:00pm. Donations in lieu of flowers: NY Gilbert & Sullivan Players or American Musicological Society.

NBC scored a victory in the ratings on the last Sunday of 2007 thanks to its prime-time football coverage, which delivered about 14 million viewers, according to Nielsen's overnight estimates. CBS finished second and Fox finished third, with both networks benefiting from overruns of their own football coverage from the afternoon that extended well into the 7 p.m. hour. Following CBS's football overrun of approximately 45 minutes, the network broadcast new episodes of ''60 Minutes'' and ''The Amazing Race,'' giving it an average of 11 million viewers from 7 to 10 p.m. ABC tied Fox for third on the night in total viewers while finishing a distant fourth among adults 18 to 49. ABC's broadcast of the movie ''The Sound of Music'' drew 7.7 million viewers from 7 to 11 p.m.

British legislation took effect on Monday to safeguard a pending London exhibition of art on loan from four Russian museums against possible lawsuits claiming ownership of the paintings, The Associated Press reported. Russian authorities had threatened to scuttle the show, ''From Russia: French and Russian Master Paintings, 1870-1925, From Moscow and St. Petersburg,'' scheduled to begin on Jan. 26 at the Royal Academy of Arts, unless they were assured the works were protected from seizure to satisfy possible claims that some of the 120 paintings had been confiscated by the state after the 1917 revolution. But moving up the date of the legislation, previously scheduled to take effect in February, appeared to satisfy Russian concerns. Anatoly Vilkov, deputy director of Rosokhrankultura, the Russian cultural heritage watchdog, said, ''I can say that with the early adoption of this law, our federal agency will grant permission for the temporary export of these paintings.'' Mikhail Kamynin, a spokesman for the Russian Foreign Ministry, told the Itar-Tass news agency that officials must still study details of the law but called it ''a step in the right direction.''

Vandals did substantial damage to the farm where Robert Frost summered from 1939 to 1963, The Associated Press reported. The destruction at Homer Noble Farm, above, a national historic landmark, on a dead-end road in Ripton, Vt., was apparently inflicted during an underage drinking party attended by as many as 50 people, said a police sergeant, Lee Hodsden. After breaking a window to gain entry, the intruders demolished tables, chairs, pictures, light fixtures and dishes. They smashed wicker furniture and dressers and burned them in a fireplace, presumably to warm the unheated structure. Sergeant Hodsden said empty beer bottles and cans and cellophane believed to have been used to hold marijuana were also found; two fire extinguishers were also set off inside. He said no arrests had been made, although the police have tracked down some partygoers. The damage was discovered on Saturday by a hiker who notified the police at Middlebury College, which maintains the site. The police said the cabin had last been visited by a caretaker at 10 a.m. on Friday.

For the first time in recent memory, Germans spent less time in front of their television sets than the year before, Reuters reported. According to preliminary results of an annual study by the television research institute GfK-Nürnberg, average viewing per day in 2007 dropped to 208 minutes from 212 in 2006. Among young people, perhaps distracted by Web sites like MySpace.de and iTunes.de, the decline was 178 minutes to 184.

JOHNSON--Ron, died Sunday, December 30th in his home in Upper Nyack, NY at 49 years old. He leaves behind his wife, Jacqueline Pack-Johnson, and his son, Matthew Pack. He was the son of Irene Ware and the late Fred Ware. Ron was born and raised in Mobile, AL. He graduated with a degree in Business Administration from Georgia State University and began a career in banking in Atlanta, GA. In 1989 he left his position as Vice President of Special Assets Group for First Union Corporation of Georgia to begin his career in the record industry. A position at Polygram Label Group brought Ron and his family to New York in 1992. He held subsequent positions at Island, Mercury, and Motown Records. In April 2007 he left his position as Executive Vice President of Atlantic Records to join Capitol Music Group as Executive Vice President and head of Urban Music. Ron suffered from Arteritis believed to be caused from Kawasaki Disease contracted in childhood. He became aware of his condition in March 2006 after suffering a heart attack. He faced his condition head on without fear. He was an avid runner and was training for his first marathon. Ron loved his family, turkey burgers and Guinness beer, Porsche sports cars, playing golf, and his dog Lucy. In addition to his wife and son he is survived by his mother, Irene, Ausbon Johnson (father), his brothers Darryl Johnson and George Johnson (Robin), his nieces and nephews Monique Thomas (Corey), Darron Johnson, Brian Johnson, Brianna Johnson, Brittaney Johnson and his godchildren Shavara and Shane Rice. He will be deeply missed by all. A funeral mass will be held on Saturday, January 5th at 10am at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church at 16 Jefferson Street in Nyack, NY. In addition, a wake/memorial service will be held on Friday, January 4th from 5-9pm, also at St. Ann's Church. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Emory University Dr. Wendy Book Adult Congenital Research Fund (Ron's favorite charity) or St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church, 16 Jefferson St., Nyack, NY 10960. The Atlanta Braves lost their best fan.

BROWN--Benjamin I., died peacefully on December 29, 2007 in Pittsburgh, PA in his 100th year. Raised on a Jewish farming community in Utah, he finished high school in Detroit. He graduated from UCLA in 1930, a member of Phi Beta Kappa with honors in economics. Moving to New York, he lead the marketing arm for a national farmers cooperative. He served as a Lieutenant in the US Navy during World War II. In Mt. Vernon, NY, his home for 35 years, he was active in local politics, including being a leading advocate for school integration. He was a delegate to the 1968 National Democratic Convention. After retiring, Sarasota, Florida became his home for 35 years. There he served as President of the local Democratic Club. He founded and led the Sarasota chapter of Americans for Peace Now for which he was honored by the national organization in 2005. He was loved and respected by family and friends for his integrity, keen intellect, loyalty, generosity and tenacious commitment to social and economic justice. Three loving wives predeceased him: Esther Bogdanoff Brown, Sylvia Einbender Brown, and Elsie Michaels Brown. He is survived by his two children, Lauren Resnick of Pittsburgh, PA, and Donald B. Brown, of NYC and their spouses, Daniel Resnick and Susan Shimmerlik, along with their children, Jeremy and Paul Resnick, and Tanya and Rachel Brown. Also surviving are six stepchildren: Deborah, Daniel, and Paula Einbender, and Stuart, Sarah, and Kate Michaels; four siblings: Lillian Vogel of Ukiah, CA, Saul Brown of Los Angeles, CA, Daniel Brown of Annapolis, Maryland, and Seyom Brown of Dallas, Texas as well as grandchildren, great-grandchildren, nieces and nephews with whom he was close throughout his life. Another brother, Eugene Brown, predeceased him. He is also survived by a companion of nine years, Gertrude Kasle, of Sarasota. Tax exempt contributions may be made in his name to Americans for Peace Now at 202-728-1893 or at www.peacenow.org

BROOKS--Colonel J.H., Retired Vice President, Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. Colonel James Hall Brooks (U.S. Army, retired) of Charlottesville, Virginia, died Monday, December 30th, at Hospice of the Piedmont after a long illness. Brooks was born in Jacksonville, Florida, in 1916, the younger son of Henry Candler and Clara Hall Brooks. A Harvard graduate (1938), Brooks attended Yale Law School (1939-1941) and New York University Law School (1942-43). Drafted in 1941, Brooks served in the US Army until 1946 when he separated in grade of Major. He joined the U.S. Army Reserve in 1946 and served continuously for 28 years until he retired in 1974. Admitted to the New York Bar in 1946, Brooks was a practicing attorney before joining J.P. Morgan & Co. in 1951. Brooks was a member of the American Bar Association and a member of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. He is survived by his wife, the former Cornelia Prouty McMurray whom he married in 1948, their daughter Emily Brooks Trier and their son Candler Prouty Brooks. Graveside funeral service, with full military honors, will be conducted Wednesday, February 20th, at Arlington National Cemetery at 1:00pm.

MUNSON--Dr. Suzanne Frances. We are deeply saddened by the untimely loss of our dear friend and colleague Dr. Suzanne Frances Munson, an intern in psychiatry, medicine and neurology at NewYorkPresbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center. A graduate of Princeton University and the Medical College of Virginia, Suzanne had recently completed a research fellowship at the National Institute of Mental Health. In her too-brief time with us, Suzanne inspired us with her gifts as a passionate physician and devoted friend. On behalf of the NewYorkPresbyterian Hospital community, we extend our heartfelt sympathies to the entire Munson family. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President & CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital & Healthcare System Steven J. Corwin, M.D. Executive V.P. & COO NY-Presbyterian Hospital

BUTTERWORTH--Olga, Beloved lifeline and counselor in the Unity movement, passed suddenly December 26th at home In Greenwich, CT. She was 87. The widow of Eric Butterworth, she and her world-renowned late husband together formed the Unity Center in New York City, and in more than 30 years developed it from a tiny congregation into one of more than 7,000 congregants, holding weekly services in Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center. Olga, an ordained minister, continued to serve Unity, delivering her last meditation on December 23rd, the Sunday before Christmas. May Divine Love transform a challenging ending into a joyously fulfilled new beginning. ''So be it,'' as Olga would say. Survivors include her beloved nieces Pauline Fiorita of Greenwich, Lucille Glascow of East Windsor, NJ, nephew Paul Bacco of Wilton, CT., and a stepson, Tom Butterworth of Seattle, WA. Also surviving is her adored Mignon, a Pappilion. Burial services are private. An open memorial is planned for a later date, which will be announced. Contributions may be made to the Eric Butterworth Foundation, Box 1501, Greenwich, CT 06836 or The Unity Center, 213 West 58th Street, New York, NY 10019.

The Quotation of the Day on Monday, taken from a front-page article about the selection of Benazir Bhutto's son to head Pakistan's largest political party, carried an incorrect attribution in some editions. It was Asif Ali Zardari, the widower of Ms. Bhutto, who was killed on Thursday, who said: ''It's not an easy chair to sit on. A, she leaves me. B, she ties me in this. To say the least, it's overbearing.'' The comment was not by Ms. Bhutto's son, Bilawal Bhutto Zardari.

An article on Dec. 21 about California's response to a decision by the Environmental Protection Agency to block the state from imposing new standards on greenhouse gas emissions from tailpipes misattributed a quotation. It was Terry Tamminen, the former environmental adviser to Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, who said, ''Californians will realize again that maybe it's time to secede from the Union.'' The comment was not by Hal Harvey, environment director for the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation.

SCHULER--Robert Charles. President of Celebrity International, Inc. A Personal Memorial from his wife, Metropolitan Opera star, Patrice Munsel Schuler, his children and grandchildren. My husband, Robert Charles Schuler, was the handsomest -funniest -most adventurous man I have ever known. He was a great business man, a fabulous father to our four children, Heidi, Rhett, Scott and Nicole, and grandfather to two wonderful grandsons, Stefan and Aleksander, all of whom have inherited his great sense of humor and adventurous spirit. His friends, both famous and infamous, were friends for life. Bob attended Cotter Prep, St. Mary's College, University of Minnesota, Northwestern University, and was a proud member of the Alpha Tau Omega (Gamma Nu Chapter) fraternity. He studied at Max Reinhardts Theater School, and with Lee Strassberg at the American Theatre Wing. His first job was as an advertising copy writer at Sears Roebuck in Chicago. Hating the cold in the Windy City, he told his boss he was leaving, and that same day drove to California, where he settled in the Colony at Malibu, and founded the Malibu Theatre. He played bit parts in movies (''The Canterbury Ghost'' was one of them) for MGM, Columbia, and Universal Studios, became assistant Advertising Manager of Western Airlines, was Associate Producer of the Broadway play, ''Laura'', and conceived and was Executive Producer of ''The Patrice Munsel Show'' on the ABC-TV Network in the 1950's. At the Young & Rubicam Advertising Agency in Manhattan, he was a Director and TV Casting Director. For 15 years, before his retirement, he was President of the prestigious Public Relations firm, Celebrity International, Inc. in New York City. A superb writer, he freelanced for ''Details'' Magazine, submitted numerous pieces for high profile clients in the society columns, and he wrote eight travel books called, ''The Little Book: Dare to Do It Yourself'' series. One of his proudest accomplishments is the wonderful book he wrote about our crazy and wonderful 55 years of life together entitled, ''The Diva And I''. Our Dad's enthusiasm for childlike excitement led us on a lot of wonderful adventures together, some exotic, some cheap fun...all zany! He gave us a love of skiing, snorkeling, exploringand excitement for Life! He was a big bear that taught us to love, be compassionate, honest and kind. We love him for that. Our grandfather, ''Big Dado'' was one of the greatest and most influential men in our lives. If we could be half the man that he was, we'll have lived a very full and meaningful life. He showed us the world with new eyes. At noon on Christmas day 2007, in the snow covered Adirondack Mountains, at his home, Robert Charles Schuler, born in Winona Minnesota, left on his greatest adventure. He is survived by his wife, Patrice Munsel Schuler, his children, Heidi Schuler Bright, Scott Schuler, Nicole Schuler, and his grandsons, Stefan Kocev and Aleksander Kocev. His son Rhett Schuler died in 2005. He is also survived by a brother, William Schuler, and a sister, Mary Lou Safranek. For my husband and our father and grandfather, Life was a big box of chocolates. Robert Charles Schuler 1917-2007. We Love You!

A revised version of the Anthony Davis opera ''Amistad'' is to be presented at the 2008 Spoleto Festival USA in Charleston, S.C., The Associated Press reported. ''Amistad,'' produced by the Chicago Lyric Opera in 1997, will be performed under the direction of Sam Helfrich at the Memminger Auditorium, constructed in the 1930s as a reproduction of a Colonial-era theater and recently renovated at a cost of $6 million. The festival, from May 23 to June 8, will include 45 productions and 140 performances.

To the Editor: Re ''A Question of Blame When Societies Fall'' (Dec. 25): The conference designed to discredit Jared Diamond highlights the worst of what goes on in contemporary academia. The organizers' failure to invite Mr. Diamond might be attributed to elementary rudeness were it not for a more damning explanation: they were afraid he would give the lie to their glib accusation that because his work is widely read, it must be oversimplified. These anthropologists' beef with Mr. Diamond clearly has less to do with the content of his thesis than with the fact that he tries to understand why things happen rather than writing a morality play conforming to their lefter-than-thou politics.

FREE--Marcella, born on September 17, 1920 in Oakland, California, died at the age of 87 in Rye, New York, after a brief illness. Founding partner at the advertising firm of Avrett, Free and Ginsburg, Mrs. Free was well respected and acknowledged as one of the industry's leading copywriters. A pioneer for women in the advertising business she was the first female Creative Director at N.W. Ayer in Philadelphia in the 1940's. With her former husband, William Free, she created memorable campaigns for companies such as Nescafe, Coca Cola, Purina, National Airlines, Pfizer and Gillette, to name but a few. She received several Clio awards for her creative work. She once advised her daughter that the only way for a woman to have a lifelong career in the advertising business was to have her name on the door. Following her retirement to her beloved home in Watermill, New York, she devoted herself to her garden, entertaining and a variety of local environmental and animal rights causes. In her last few years, she completed a memoir entitled ''Somewhere Warm'' of her time spent in post war Europe, writing and painting with fellow ex-pats. She is fondly remembered for her sharp wit, her enduring attachment to her manual typewriter, her loyalty to her small circle of friends, and her determination to master the only thing that ever eluded her -fluency in the Italian language. She is survived by her three children, Abigail Free of Katonah, Adam Free of Pound Ridge and Molly Free of Guilford, CT, and five grandchildren, Lucas and Molly Natali, Madeline Free and Jack and Kate McClement. A memorial service will be held at a future date to be announced. Donations may be made to The Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons, Daniel's Hole Road P.O. Box 901 Wainscott, NY 11975.

Jennifer Garner, below, may have been born in Texas, but she is the 2007 West Virginian of the Year, The Associated Press reported. The newspaper said it chose Ms. Garner for her dedication, hard work and services to West Virginia as an ambassador and role model. BRENT--George of Manhattan and Lakeville, CT, died peacefully on Wednesday, January 2, after a long and courageous battle with heart disease, surrounded by loving family and friends under the care of the wonderful team at Mount Sinai Heart. He was born in Budapest, Hungary on January 7, 1937 as George Gottlieb. At the age of six he survived the Holocaust, fleeing Budapest with his mother and living in hiding for two years. He returned to Budapest after the war, but by age 19 he was no longer willing to tolerate living within the oppressive Communist regime. He escaped the city by foot in late November 1956, one day after planned (he overslept). On the way out of Hungary, he evaded gunfire, slept in a barn and waded through a small freezing river. After reaching Austria, he was chosen to serve as the leader and spokesperson for a group of Hungarian students being housed by an Austrian Count. Although he had the opportunity for relatively easy passage to a variety of countries, he was determined to get to the United States and specifically to New York City. He arrived in New York Harbor in February 1957 on a U.S. Navy transport ship with no money and no knowledge of English, but an uncompromising determination to build a home and embrace life in a place that protects and celebrates individual freedom. He went to Columbia on a scholarship, where he studied engineering and economics. He began a career in advertising and media working for ad agencies and then directly for a client. Ultimately he moved into media sales, working at WPIX, Fox 5 and NBC's PAX Television, building a sales career that spanned more then 35 years, thousands of avails and many, many lunches. In 1974, he married Chickie Bucco, whom he adored (a fact that aggravated him to no end). He was the proud father of Andrew and loving father-in-law to Erin. He was a passionate and talented chef and wine connoisseur. He also loved renovating his country house, gardening, Giants, Rangers and Yankees games, bragging about his son, and, maybe most of all, entertaining and celebrating life with family and friends. In addition to Chickie, Andrew and Erin, George is survived by his Aunt Giselle, cousins of Hungary, and the entire Bucco family. Service Monday January 7, 11:30am Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Memorial Visitation Sunday January 6, 59pm Campbell Funeral Chapel. Family sitting Shiva at his home Monday January 7, 59pm and Tuesday January 8, 12-9pm. The family is asking that any donations be made to Mount Sinai Heart in memory of George Brent with the deepest respect for Dr. Raymond Matta. Donations should be send to Mount Sinai Heart, Box 1049, 1 Gustave Levy Place, NY, NY 10029.

An obituary on Monday about Marvin Wachman, the former president of Lincoln and Temple Universities, misstated the date of his death and misspelled the given name of his wife and the middle name of his daughter. Dr. Wachman died on Dec. 23, not Dec. 22. His wife is Adeline Wachman, not Adelina, and his daughter is Lynn Alison Wachman, not Lynn Allison. The obituary also omitted the cause of death. Dr. Wachman died of congestive heart failure, his wife said.

CLERY--Howard K., Jr. (1930 -2008) Security On Campus, Inc. co-founder and former CEO of Rapidforms, Inc. died peacefully at his Florida home January 1st , age 77. A man of great character, Howard never allowed adversity to defeat him: his many accomplishments, family and friends who love him dearly are testament to the life of a good man. May all who love him find comfort in their memories of Howard. In 1991, Dartmouth Alumni awarded Howard Clery the Class of 1953 Award commenting: ...our brightest young people, our best hope for the future of this great nation are safer and more secure because of him. Howard and Connie cofounded Security On Campus, Inc. following the brutal murder of their daughter on Lehigh Universitys campus in 1986. After the 1987 conviction of their daughters murderer, Howard and Connie devoted their lives to making college and university campuses safer places for students. They secured passage of more than 30 State and Federal Laws requiring colleges to disclose crime information and guarantee victims rights, including the Federal Jeanne Clery Act which is named in memory of their daughter. President George H. Bush honored the Clerys for their crime victims rights work in a 1990 Rose Garden ceremony, noting: their campaign to build an America where every victim of every crime is treated with the dignity and the compassion they deserve. As CEO of Rapidforms, Howard successfully built a regional printer of labels, business forms and stationery into a national direct mail company, growing the business from 25 employees and $2 million in sales (1971) to 280 employees and $40 million in sales (1987). Howard was always quick to credit his association with CSS Industries, executive colleagues and the employees of Rapidforms for the companys accomplishments. Prior to his business success at Rapidforms, Howard held executive positions at Safeguard Industries, Raytheon, and Royal McBee, beginning his career as Gillette Company's first management trainee. Howard was educated at Dartmouth College, earning a B.A. Degree in 1953 and an MBA in 1954 from the Amos Tuck Graduate School of Business Administration. He was elected Vice President of his freshman class, President of his sophomore class, and Vice President of the Student Council during his senior year. Howards years at Dartmouth not only provided an excellent education, it was the formative place where he made life-long friendships which he cherished throughout his life. Life presented many difficult challenges for Howard Clery. Born in Boston, Howards father died in 1941 when he was 11 years old. He became a very competitive athlete at Arlington High School playing varsity football when he was stricken with polio during practice in 1945. Despite a year of rehabilitation at Warm Springs, GA. he would wear a heavy steel leg brace and walk on canes for the remainder of his life. The family will receive visitors from 7:00pm to 9:00pm on Monday, January 7th at McConaghy Funeral Home, 328 West Lancaster Avenue, Ardmore, PA. A funeral mass will be held at 10am on Tuesday, January 8th in the St. Thomas of Villanova Church University Campus, Villanova, PA. Interment will follow at Calvary Cemetery, Old Gulph Rd., Conshohocken, PA. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Security on Campus, Inc., 133 Ivy Lane, Suite 200, King of Prussia, PA 19406-2101 will be most gratefully received. www.mcconaghyfuneral home.com

DOROFF--Benjamin H., of Syracuse, New York, died peacefully on Sunday, December 30th, 2007. Born on July 4th, 1918 in Syracuse to the late Jennie Frank Doroff and Jacob Doroff. Benjamin graduated from Syracuse University and served with the U.S. Military in Germany during WWII. Mr. Doroff was a retail advertising executive at J.W. Wanamakers in Philadelphia, PA, Joseph Horne in Pittsburgh, PA, and Flah's in Syracuse. He was predeceased by his wife of 56 years, Shirley Frank Doroff in 2004. Survived by his sons; H. Frank (Stephanie) Doroff and Stephen (Elaine) Doroff, and grandchildren; Sarah, Daniel and Sydney Doroff. Graveside services and burial will be private. Contributions may be made to Cancer Care, 275 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10001.

RYLEE--Robert Tilman, II, 77, of Sarasota, FL and Memphis, TN passed away on December 25, 2007, surrounded by his family. He was revered by all who knew him as a loyal friend, a generous benefactor, a gifted businessman and above all a humble and principled gentleman. He will be greatly missed by his family and many friends across the country. He is survived by his wife, Kay Bolin Rylee, of Sarasota, FL a son and daughter-in-law, Robert and Leslie Rylee of New York, NY, a daughter, Linda J. Rylee of Austin, TX, two stepsons, John Rylee of Memphis, TN and Craig Chism of Sarasota, FL, as well as four grandchildren, Ava and Preston Rylee of New York, NY and Daniel and Noah Chism of Sarasota, FL. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Salvation Army, 1701 South Tuttle Avenue, Sarasota, FL 34239.

A TUMULTUOUS YEAR Stocks fell, ending a year that left some financial firms wounded but other parts of the market and the world with huge gains. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ended the year up 3.5 percent, slightly less than inflation. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 6.4 percent for the year. [C1.] THE MEDICINE HUNTER Chris Kilham, an ethno-botanist from Massachusetts who calls himself the Medicine Hunter, has searched faraway lands for three decades for plants, oils and extracts that can heal -- to the benefit of Western pharmaceutical companies, a few unknown indigenous communities and Mr. Kilham himself. [C1.]

GRAY--William E. Jr., M.D. 51, of New York City, formerly of Boston and Washington, DC died in his sleep on December 23, 2007. Dr. Gray was a graduate of Ursinus College and Georgetown Medical School. For over 25 years he was a Senior Executive in the pharmaceutical industry for Astra, Pfizer and Forest Research Labs. Most recently, he was Vice President for Drug Surveillance and Information at Boehringer Ingelheim Pharmaceuticals. Dr. Gray will be remembered for his dedication and kindness in his profession as well as a caring son, brother and friend. He leaves behind a long series of professional accomplishments that made some of the most well known medicines safe for patients who have seen their lives benefit from his humble and unacknowledged contributions and leadership. Dr. Gray is survived by his parents, William E. and Dorothy Gray of Sarasota, and brothers James J. and Robert T. and their families. A private service was held in Sarasota, FL on December 31. Condolences can be sent to 252 7th Ave. #

JEYDEL--Richard, died on December 20th at age 57, survived by his wife Ellen, his son Peter, his daughter Patricia E, his mother Patricia K and his brother Lawrence. Rick was the General Counsel for Kanematsu USA Inc. and worked as an arbitrator and mediator. He graduated from Harvard Law School and served in the U.S. Army JAG Corps. Accepting donations to the Nature Conservancy.

MUDICK--Bertram, passed away on January 2, 2008. Beloved husband of Gilda, loving father of Eric and Stephanie, grandfather of five adoring grandchildren, Dahlia, Lily, Jennifer, Alison, and Sara. Bertram Mudick was one of the most well respected individuals in the shoe industry for over 50 years. He had the foresight to project trends and merchandize brilliantly. His intensity and pulse for fashion was inspired by his worldwide travels. He was honored by the Swedish government for introducing to the United States Swedish designer and couture collections. Revolutionizing the merchandise concept in women's footwear was his game and passion. He brought the accessory business to a dominating new high through women's footwear. That was his life, second to his family. We will all miss him greatly.

The 18th season of NBC’s “Law & Order” opens tonight with the actor Sam Waterston in a new role, that of Manhattan district attorney. Mr. Waterston’s character will be the fourth Manhattan district attorney in the history of the series, which started in 1990 (not counting a pilot episode shot in 1988). But during that time, there has been only one real Manhattan district attorney: Robert M. Morgenthau, elected in 1974.

With Ohio State and Louisiana State having arrived in New Orleans, now is the time to look at 10 story lines worth following heading into the Bowl Championship Series title game Monday.1. The Hat vs. the Vest - L.S.U. Coach Les Miles is nicknamed the Hat because of the stiff brim he wears during games. Ohio State Coach Jim Tressel is known as the Vest because of his typical game-day sweater vest. Miles has become the known as the consummate sideline gambler, and Tressel is usually as conservative as his attire. But few will gives Miles the strategic edge here because Tressel has won too many big games by close margins.2. The Speed Factor - After Florida, like L.S.U. a team in the Southeastern Conference, routed Ohio State in last season's title game, team speed was cited as a strong factor. That came into play especially with the Gators' defensive front seven. Expect the speed factor as an advantage for L.S.U. to be discussed excessively leading up to the game.3. The Imperfect Quarterback - Plenty of observers are going to say that this Ohio State team is better than last season's. Well, it's not. The disparity at quarterback is enough of a reason, as the Buckeyes traded the Heisman Trophy winner, Troy Smith, for the immobile and not-so-accurate Todd Boeckman. L.S.U. has the solid-but-unspectacular Matt Flynn, which means that whichever quarterback makes the least mistakes will probably win.

As I noted earlier this week, some of Barack Obama's comments have been inciting fury among labor leaders and Democrats online, especially now that's he's increasingly taking aim at John Edwards, whose class-warrior message resonates with the party's hyper-partisans. The latest sniping on the blogs centered Mr. Obama's suggestion that Democrats needed to nominate someone whom half the country wouldn't immediately reject, which, according to Mr. Obama, is what they did in 2000 and again in 2004. This comment wasn't significantly different from the electability argument that most of the Democrats have made at one time or another, but Mr. Obama's specific reference to Al Gore and John Kerry was enough to renew dubious allegations that Mr. Obama was, once again, sounding more like a Republican than a Democrat.

When flight attendants get together for drinks, inevitably the conversation turns skyward. We share details about the deranged man who sprinted up the aisle of an Airbus, slapping passengers' heads along the way (true story). We gossip about the shameless couple that had sex in a main-cabin seat (I saw them with my own eyes), the freaked-out-flier who tried to open the emergency exit at 15,000 feet (I grabbed him with my own hands), the hapless pilot who stepped into a dark unlocked lavatory and got his foot caught in a screaming woman's panties. (The captain looked me straight in the eye and recounted his embarrassing experience.)

On my flight back to Des Moines today, I read an interesting piece by my colleagues Michael Falcone and Sarah Wheaton about the upcoming debates in New Hampshire. It seems that both Fox and ABC have taken it upon themselves to winnow the field of candidates by excluding those who don't seem viable at this point. Fox, for instance, is shutting out Ron Paul, despite his having reached fourth place in some recent New Hampshire polls and his having spent a truckload of money on ads in the state. (I swear, you can't drive three miles in New Hampshire without hearing Ron Paul on the radio; he's more overplayed than Fergie, albeit easier to listen to.) ABC has decided that if you don't finish in the top four in Iowa, and you don't reach five percent in New Hampshire or national polls, then you're just cluttering up the stage and should watch at home like everyone else.

There is one topic dominating international soccer headlines during the first few days of the new year: player personnel. The international transfer window is open until Jan. 31 and teams may buy and sell players -- permanently or on loan -- to compensate for injuries, fortify rosters for Champions League campaigns and make up for the loss of key players during the African Cup of Nations.

Peter Barnes, a founder of Working Assets, the fund making "socially responsible" investments, has long studied various bills and proposals for cutting emissions of carbon dioxide to limit global warming. He sees fatal flaws in every one. So he has come up with a new formula that he says uniquely addresses the most inconvenient truth about climate policy: It will be expensive.

Ousting their chief executives and multi-billion dollar write-offs weren't the only thing that Citigroup and Merrill Lynch had in common in 2007. The two banks were the world's top underwriters of stocks and bonds, measured by volume and reported fees, despite being at the epicenter of the global credit crisis.

Merrill Lynch, which a little more than a week ago announced that it would sell a $6.2 billion stake to the Singapore government and a mutual fund manager, is reportedly in fresh talks with Chinese and Middle Eastern sovereign wealth funds to slice off another piece of itself in return for much-needed cash.

Reliance Power of India is set to launch an initial public offering to raise up to $2.97 billion in the country's biggest I.P.O., Reuters reported. The company will issue 260 million shares at an indicated price band of 405 to 450 rupees ($10.30 to $11.40) each, the report said.

An article on Dec. 25 about Turkish airstrikes on Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq misidentified the area on the Iraqi border where the bombing took place. The area is known as Jamju; it is not Hawler, which is the name of a town and a province whose governor spoke about the numbers of refugees and civilian deaths. (Hawler is the Kurdish word for Erbil.).

An article on Dec. 26 about Turkish airstrikes on Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq misidentified the area on the Iraqi border where the bombing took place. The area is known as Jamju; it is not Hawler, which is the name of a town and a province whose governor spoke about the numbers of refugees and civilian deaths. A South Korean boxer who lost consciousness after winning a championship bout last week has been declared brain dead, said Ko Seung-kwan, a spokesman at Asan Medical Center in Seoul. The boxer, Choi Yo-Sam, 33, was found to be brain dead in a preliminary test conducted at Soon Chun Hyang hospital in Seoul before he was transferred on Monday to Asan Medical Center. He fell unconscious after successfully defending his World Boxing Organization intercontinental flyweight title on Dec. 25.He collapsed five seconds before the end of the 12th and final round after the challenger Heri Amol of Indonesia threw a right to his jaw. Choi managed to stand as he was declared the winner but fell into a coma immediately afterward.

John Part, a Canadian, won the Professional Darts Corporation World Championship with a 7-2 victory over the English qualifier Kirk Shepherd at Alexandra Palace in London. Part, 41, who won the British Darts Organization title in 1994 and the P.D.C. crown in 2003, became the fourth person to win the world championship more than twice. He joined the 13-time champion Phil Taylor, Eric Bristow (five titles) and John Lowe (three).

Eduardo da Silva scored his fifth goal in three games to help Arsenal to a 2-0 victory over West Ham that kept the Gunners atop the Premier League. With second-place Manchester United beating Birmingham, 1-0, Eduardo and Emmanuel Adebayor scored to keep Arsenal 2 points ahead. Chelsea stayed in third place with a 2-1 victory at Fulham, while Everton, Portsmouth and Aston Villa also won.
