WRIGHT--Sarah (nee Arthur), 75, died December 22, 2007 at home in Falls Village, CT after a long battle with cancer. Poet, beloved wife of George Wright, adored mother of Benjamin. Memorial service January 5th, 11am at North Cornwall Meeting House, Cogswell Rd. and Town St., Cornwall, CT.

HERO--Byron A., M.D., passed away December 31, 2007. Survived by his wife, Angela; sons Byron Jr. and Basil; daughter-in-law Camille; and grandchildren Alexander Byron, Gabrielle, Alexandra and Ariane. Born in Pelham, New York in 1912, he was graduated from Cornell University and Tufts University Medical School. In 1941, before America's entry into WWII, he volunteered for service at the newly established military hospital at the Base of Command in Newfoundland. He later served as regimental surgeon with the First Army Coast Artillery and was Chief of Surgery at the 117th Evacuation Hospital with the Third and Seventh Armies in France, Germany and Austria. He was discharged with the rank of Lieutenant Colonel and awarded the Bronze Star. In a career that spanned more than fifty years as a surgeon in New York City, he was affiliated with Midtown Hospital (Chief of Surgery), Doctors Hospital, Beth Israel Hospital and Lenox Hill Hospital. He was also Professor of Clinical Surgery at the New York University Medical School. An avid sportsman and accomplished athlete, he enjoyed a lifelong passion for tennis and was an active participant at the New York Athletic Club, the Westchester Country Club and the Meadow Club of Southampton. The family will be receiving friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., NYC, Thursday, January 3, 2008, from 6:00 to 9:00pm. The funeral service will be on Friday, January 4, at 11:00am, at the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Lenox Hill Hospital or Saint Basil Academy, 79 Saint Basil's Road, Garrison, NY 10524.

GRACE--Natalie Watts, of Great Neck and East Hampton, LI, in her 99th year, died peacefully at her home in Great Neck on Sunday December 30, 2007. Beloved daughter of the late Mr. And Mrs. Edward Everett Watts, daughter-in-law of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morgan H. Grace (Ruth Eden) of Kings Point, beloved wife of Morgan H. Grace, Jr., who died in 1995 at age 89 after 57 years of marriage; beloved sister of the late Edward Everett Watts, Jr., the late Louise Watts, and the late Maud Watts Grayson. Cherished mother of Natalie Grace Dejoux Brinckerhoff of Palm Beach, Locust Valley, and East Hampton and Morgan Grace of Washington, D.C., and Southampton; loving sister-in-law of Robert M. Grace and his wife Jane, of Lorraine Grace, widow of Oliver R. Grace, and Isabella Watts of Mattapoisett. Survived by many nephews and nieces including, on the Watts' side, Maud Grayson, Spence Watts Grayson, Elizabeth Watts Boileau, Edward Everett Watts III, and Isabella Watts Cunynghame. Adored grandmother of Edouard Henri Grace Dejoux (Blair Hopkins), Morgan Andre Grace Dejoux (Eleanor Acquavella), and Elizabeth Grace. Devoted great-grandmother to Christine, Hope, Charlotte, William Jacques, and Isabelle Dejoux. A graduate of St. Agatha's School and The Spence School, Class of 1927, where she earned a Classical Diploma, Natalie Watts excelled in all her subjects including Latin. Her completed crossword puzzles in Latin were often posted on the bulletin board. She had a beautiful voice, loved to sing, and sang on the radio in the years before her 1938 marriage. In the early 1930's she was a member of the Blue Hill Troupe, singing in Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, and active as a Young Republican. She was Chairman of the LVIS Fair in East Hampton in 1968: Her first grandson was due the date of the Fair, and all the ladies thought he should be named ELVIS! For many years she was Chairman of Books at both the LVIS Fair in East Hampton (where she turned her small guest cottage into a temporary book store) and, with her dear friend, Eleanor Rawlings, at the All Saints Church Strawberry Festival in Great Neck. During these past few weeks, she hummed and sang Christmas carols, along with the radio and T.V. A cheerful, kind, strong, resilient, and intelligent lady, she knew many of the answers on ''Jeopardy'', ''Wheel of Fortune'' and ''Millionaire'', which she enjoyed watching with her wonderful nurses, her children, grandchildren, and great-children, when they visited. Her household was always a happy one. She was loved and admired by both her sons-in-law, Jacques H. Dejoux, of Lyon and Albon d'Ardeche, France, adored grandfather of her great-grandchildren, and a former Vice-President of Marine Midland Bank, and the late William H. Brinckerhoff, whose great-aunts, the Misses Annie and Mary Brinckerhoff had been her English and Latin teachers at Spence. She loved and was loved by all her nurses, with whom she enjoyed tea and conversation: Brigid Corban, Catherine Byrne, Thelma Clarke, Caroline Grace Casler, niece, Ann De Marco, Anne Flynn, Kathleen Flynn, Helen Gately, Mary Gonzalez, Ginger Hoernig, Dymphna Horan, Debra Kennedy, Renate Low, Arlene Mongiello, Debora Myrick, Katherine Noone, Joan O'Brien, Helen O'Hara, Maureen Pesce, Barbara Palladino, Margaret Ryan, Sharon Schmiemann, Kathleen Tilney, Yvette Warynold, and Helga Woodard, and by her devoted housekeepers, Josefa Briceno, Ligia Florez, and Marta Stark. A former member of the Woman's Club of Great Neck, the Junior League, Devon Yacht Club, the Bath and Tennis Club in Palm Beach, she was a current member of Maidstone Club, which she joined with her husband in 1955. Funeral services will be held at All Saints Episcopal Church, 855 Middle Neck Road, Great Neck, on Saturday, January 5th 2008, at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations in her honor to The Spence School, 22 East 91st St., New York, NY 10128.

LIEBERMAN--Claire. Passed away peacefully on December 30, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Ben. Born November 25, 1921, in Brooklyn. A business pioneer, starting in 1963 selling dresses out of her home and ultimately creating the preeminent Westchester woman's clothing store, which she presided over for more than 25 years. Claire became an active volunteer for Northern Westchester Hospital Center and the North Westchester Center for the Arts. A generous and loving mother to Lewis (Ina), Robin (Jeff), and Mitchell (Lisa), devoted to grandchildren Cali, Remy, Sophia, Atticus, Tori, and Ben. Service today at Riverside, Mt. Vernon, 10am.
An obituary on Sunday about Hugh Massingberd, the innovative British obituaries editor, omitted part of the name of the newspaper for which he worked. It is The Daily Telegraph, not The Telegraph.

MEYER--Leonard B., composer, author, philosopher and esteemed and honored humanities professor died on December 30, 2007. He was 89. He contributed major works in the fields of aesthetic theory in music, and compositional analysis and was one of the first to explore the relationship between Game Theory and musical composition. His books include Emotion and Meaning in Music, The Rhythmic Structure of Music (with Grosvenor Cooper), Some Remarks on Value and Greatness in Music, Style and Music: Theory History and Ideology (General Editor), The Spheres of Music : A Gathering of Essays, as well as numerous articles and other scholarly works. His writings address such diverse subjects as musical emotion, the psychology of music, musical analysis and theory, aesthetics, information theory, the anthropology of art, and art and neuroscience. Meyer studied at Bard College, Columbia University (B.A. in Philosophy, M.A. in Music) and the University of Chicago (Ph.D. in History of Culture). As a composer, he studied under Stefan Wolpe and Aaron Copland. He taught at the University of Chicago for 29 years. He was a Fellow at the Center for Advanced Studies at Wesleyan University, a Guggensheim Fellow and was elected to the American Academy of Arts and Letters. In 1975, he was named Benjamin Franklin Professor of Music and Humanities at the University of Pennsylvania. He was beloved by generations of music and humanities students. Born in New York City, Professor Meyer lived a full life devoted to his family, his students, colleagues, and the humanities. During World War II, he fought with the front line infantry at the Ardennes and the Battle of the Bulge. A great wit, Meyer regaled friends and family with recitations from Gilbert & Sullivan and Shakespeare, and frequent puns. He asked that his tombstone be engraved with the musical pun in Hamlet's dying words: The rest is silence. He will be deeply missed by his loving daughters, Muffie (Ronald Blumer), Carlin (Peter Bienstock) and Erica (Potter Palmer), granddaughters, Emma and Molly, his first wife and mother of his children, Lee Meyer of Chicago, his sister-in-law Karen Levy and his care givers, Pauline Whitehill, Sandra Jones and Brigid Nicholson. He was pre-deceased by his second wife, Janet Levy, and his brother, Daniel Meyer, and sister, Carolyn Meyer. There will be a memorial service at Riverside Memorial, 76th and Amsterdam, on January 13th at 2:00pm. Donations in lieu of flowers: NY Gilbert & Sullivan Players or American Musicological Society.

Candela delle Langhe, a firm, tangy, herbaceous goat cheese from the Piedmont region of northwestern Italy, is covered in golden beeswax into which dried herbs or flowers are embedded. The cheese looks too pretty to cut, but forget aesthetics and dig in. Each cheese round is about seven ounces and costs about $7. Some other cheeses from the region now at Fairway include Castelmagno, firm and a bit crumbly, with the flavor of mushrooms, $23.96 a pound; and runny Pantaleone, a flat, washed rind cheese with a richness similar to reblochon's, $19.16 a pound.
PARKER--Jack. Daddy I can hardly believe it is one year, not a day goes by that I don't miss you and think of you. Nancy

An article in Business Day on Monday about a new Web site that caters to single people without trying to match them up referred incorrectly to the trend in divorce rates in the United States. It is falling, not continuing to climb.

How many people rang in the new year at Times Square on Monday night? The simple answer is: One heck of a lot. The complicated answer is: Perhaps only the Police Department knows for sure, and it won't tell you. ''We have stopped providing official counts'' of large public gatherings ''because no one was ever satisfied with them,'' said Paul J. Browne, the department's deputy commissioner for public information. ''Whatever the count was, it was usually never enough for whatever group was involved.''

BRENER--Bernard J., born January 20, 1925 in Bronx, New York, deceased on December 31, 2007 from cardiac complications. He became an Interpreter at The Nuremberg Trials. Obtained his Masters and Doctoral Degrees in Literature from New York University. Taught German, English, French and Spanish at Long Island University where he became Chairman of the Language Department for many decades. He was a Thomas Mann scholar, an opera lover and an animal lover. Do not send flowers, contributions can be made to the ASPCA.

A picture caption in The Arts on Saturday with an article about Clifton Brown, a dancer with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, misstated the given name and omitted the middle initial of a dancer shown sitting in the background in a photograph of Mr. Brown in Maurice Béjart's ''Firebird.'' 9 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER What took them so long? Jack McCoy (Sam Waterston, above right) is finally promoted to Manhattan district attorney, thanks to the off-screen presidential ambitions of Fred Thompson, who until a few months ago portrayed District Attorney Arthur Branch. There are other changes in this 18th season of television's longest-running crime show, including the addition of Jeremy Sisto as Detective Cyrus Lupo, and Linus Roache, above left, as the chief assistant district attorney, Michael Cutter. In this two-hour season opener, Detective Lupo returns to the United States after four years abroad on terrorist duty to discover that his brother has committed suicide by lethal injection because of an incurable illness. But when another man shows up dead in the same way, all eyes turn to ''Dr. Death,'' a recent parolee, and his daughter (Marin Ireland), who might be a practitioner of her father's medical specialty. 8 P.M. (CBS) POWER OF 10 Think you've got your fellow countrymen pegged? This game show, now in its second season, polls thousands of Americans about a multitude of topics. The contestant who can most accurately predict the results of these surveys gets a chance at $10 million. Drew Carey is host.

HEY, KIDS, LET'S ... Apparently 24-hour plays are too easy. Celia Keenan-Bolger, Rita Wilson, Cheyenne Jackson and Victoria Clark will be among the participants in the first ''24 Hour Musicals,'' creating and performing four new musicals in a day. The production, on Jan. 21 at Joe's Pub, is a benefit for the Exchange, a nonprofit organization that develops new theater work. Other artists involved include David Yazbeck, Kerry Butler, Gavin Creel, Moisés Kaufman, Nellie McKay, Mo Rocca, Denis O'Hare, Tracie Thoms and Ted Sperling, creative director of the production. Information: 24hourplays.com or (646) 502-7453. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

For most of the presidential candidates, the fourth quarter was more about stumping than fund-raising. Not so for Representative Ron Paul of Texas, who has achieved that Howard Dean-esque feat of turning fervent net-roots support into hard cash. Mr. Paul, a libertarian-leaning Republican, pulled in $19.5 million over the last three months, according to his campaign, which is likely to be more than any other Republican presidential candidate's haul. (As his campaign points out in its press release, the figure is over $9 million more than any other Republican raised in the third quarter.)

PALACCI--Juliette Tarika. Beloved mother of Magda Bleier of New York, Rebecca Blechman of Fishkill, NY; Sarah of Monaco; Eliakim, Deborah and Menahem of Brussels. Steadfast widow of Henri. Cherished grandmother of Henry Blechman and Philip Blechman of Fishkill; Henry of Chicago; Olivia of Montreal; Juliette Moise of Paris; Deborah Raffeld and Alexandre of Brussels. Adored great-grandmother of Edward of Chicago; David and Eve Moise of Paris; David and Dana Raffeld and Jacques and Helene of Brussels. WEINSTOCK--David. Born in Poland in 1924; passed away on January 2, 2007, in NYC. David immigrated to the United States after the War to begin Crucible, a business for the design and manufacturer of furniture, for 50 years catering to the design/architectural trade. From the 60s on, his custom seating designs were used in such locations as the Revlon Salon on 5th Avenue, the Crown Room (Fairmount Hotel, San Francisco), the Capitol Building (Santa Fe), and for banks of seating at Kennedy International Airport. At his retirement he was one of a very few furniture manufacturers remaining in NYC. Kind of heart and generous of spirit, he ever helpfully shared both his knowledge and his experience with young designers entering the field

The Market Place column in Business Day on Monday, about the stock performance of newly listed private equity firms and hedge funds, misstated the results of shares in GLG Holdings, a European hedge fund manager, after it went public. Shares rose; they did not decline.

Lindsay Davenport improved to 15-1 in singles since her return to tournament play, beating fifth-seeded Annabel Medina Garrigues, 6-1, 4-6, 6-0, in the second round of the A.S.B. Classic in Auckland, New Zealand. Davenport has won two tournaments and reached the semifinals of another since returning after the birth of her first child. ''I played really well in the first and third sets, but had a bit of a lapse in the second, as I did on Monday,'' Davenport said.Davenport beat a fellow American, Laura Granville, 6-2, 6-3, in her first-round match Monday and looked in similarly confident form against Medina Garrigues, although she had to overcome a brief loss of concentration during the second set.

It was the Museum of Art, not the Museum of Modern Art.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about attacks on abortion and family planning clinics in Albuquerque misstated the day that two suspects were arrested in one attack. It was Thursday, not last Wednesday.

MADONNA AND GUY AND SEAN AND ROBIN Madonna and her husband, the film director Guy Ritchie, rang in the New Year in a remote village in the northern Indian desert state of Rajasthan, popular among Western celebrity tourists, Agence France-Presse reported. The couple drove to a heritage hotel in Dechu village with five friends soon after arriving in the historic city of Jodhpur from the Maldives by chartered plane and were to travel on Tuesday to Jaisalmer, famous for its sprawling sandstone fort and undulating sand dunes, local reports said. . . . Meanwhile, Madonna's ex may not have such a happy new year. Her first husband, the Oscar-winning actor and director Sean Penn, and his wife, the actress Robin Wright Penn, are divorcing after 11 years of marriage; she cites irreconcilable differences as a reason. Mr. Penn's publicist confirmed the divorce to People magazine but gave no details. The couple are seeking joint custody of their two teenage children.

CHODOROW--Julius, November 23, 1917-December 30, 2007. Born in Manhattan, attended DeWitt Clinton High School and CCNY. Lived in the City before moving to Roslyn, New York in 1954. US Army, 1943-1946, then joined the family business, distributing Gulf Oil products in NYC. After the business was sold in 1960, Julie completed a M.A. at Columbia. Became Executive Director of Sponsors for Educational Opportunity, a non-profit devoted to helping educationally disadvantaged children go to college. Also a devoted supporter and President of the Roslyn Public Library. We loved his humor, his stories, his intelligence, his culture. Survived by his wife of 66 years, Doris, by sons Stan (Peggy), Neil (Susie), and Andy (Susan), by grandchildren Adam (Rebel), Eric (Anne), Nicholas, Joshua, Kristina, and by four greatgrandchildren, Aidan, Kelsey, Chloe, and Bennett. We will miss his wit, warmth, and help with the NYT crossword. Graveside service at Old Montefiore Cemetery at 10:30am on January 2, 2008.

A SPORTIER STRAUSS The Vienna Philharmonic added a new instrument -- a referee's whistle -- for its New Year's Day concert, broadcast to tens of millions of viewers in 54 countries, Agence France-Presse reported. As usual the program waltzed with the Strauss family, but this year it included references to the 2008 European soccer championships, to which Austria and neighboring Switzerland will play host in June. Georges Prêtre, above, the first Frenchman to lead the annual concert since it began in 1939, introduced Josef Strauss's ''Sport Polka'' by blowing a whistle and brandishing the official Euro 2008 ball. The concert at the Musikverein hall finished more traditionally with Johann Strauss Jr.'s ''Blue Danube'' waltz, his father's clap-along ''Radetzky March'' and a three-minute standing ovation.

A REVELATORY 50 YEARS As befits the season of Janus, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is looking to both past and future. The company's annual five-week City Center season, which concluded on New Year's Eve, broke box-office records for the troupe, with ticket sales of more than $4 million, said Christopher Zunner, a company spokesman. This year the company is celebrating its 50th-anniversary year with a 26-city United States tour starting on Jan. 29 in East Lansing, Mich.; a June engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, presented by the Joyce Theater; and 18 months of special performances, projects and exhibitions beginning at the end of March, in honor of the company's first New York performance at the 92nd Street YMHA on March 30, 1958. A street sign designating 55th Street between 9th and 10th Avenues as Alvin Ailey Place has been raised on the corner outside Ailey's building.

An article on Dec. 26 about Turkish airstrikes on Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq misidentified the area on the Iraqi border where the bombing took place. The area is known as Jamju; it is not Hawler, which is the name of a town and a province whose governor spoke about the numbers of refugees and civilian deaths. (Hawler is the Kurdish word for Erbil.)

The slender breadsticks at Palio, the Italian restaurant that was once in the Equitable Building in Midtown, were enough to ruin your appetite for the tortellini to come. The chef who developed the recipe, Andreas Hellrigl, died in 1993, and his widow, Maria Pia Hellrigl, sold the restaurant in 2000. Now she has brought back the breadsticks, or grissini, made with olive oil. They are organic and available plain or seasoned with pepper and herbs in five-ounce packages, $6.50 for bite-size ones; $7 for plain long ones; $7.50 for seasoned long ones; and $8 for seasoned long ones in the original box from paliobreadsticks.com and slowdownorganic.com.

Forsyth, loving mother of Robert G. Forsyth of New Jersey, Anthony L. Forsyth and Deborah of East Meadow, NY, Maureen J. Forsyth of Ballston Spa, NY, Brian J. Forsyth and Lisa of Rocky Point, NY and cherished grandmother of seven. A mass of Christian burial was held on January 2, 2008 at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Ballston Spa. In the spring, a memorial mass will be offered at St. Thomas More Church, St. John's University, Jamaica NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to: Memorial SloanKettering Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, P.O. Box 27106 New York, NY 10087.

They look like the kind of chocolate lollipops SpongeBob SquarePants would have in his cupboard. But they are actually Petrossian's hot-chocolate-on-a-stick, a clever way to make the warming winter drink. Scald a cup of milk for each serving, pour into mugs, then give each person a pop, which melts as it is stirred in. This accomplishes two things: you make a cup of hot chocolate without measuring chocolate or cocoa and trying to dissolve it, and by the time the chocolate has melted in, the drink, which is fairly light and not too sweet, is at sipping temperature. You can even use the pops, plain or hazelnut, in hot coffee topped with a dollop of whipped cream.

POST MORTEMS OF VARIOUS KINDS Dr. Kay Scarpetta will be in the public eye as long as Patricia Cornwell's best-selling forensics novels are in print, but the reallife Virginia doctor who served as her model retired on Monday, The Associated Press reported. Dr. Marcella Fierro, 66, left her job as the state's chief medical examiner in a career of more than 30 years, which included the investigation of the Virginia Tech shootings last spring. In 1984 Ms. Cornwell, then an aspiring writer, interviewed Dr. Fierro about her work, and Kay Scarpetta was born. The retirement party was held down the hall from the morgue, The Associated Press said. . . . Speaking of someone you may wish would retire: Lindsay Lohan gave the worst performance by an actress in 2007, say 58 percent of voters in an online poll. America Online Web site Moviefone gave Ms. Lohan that dubious honor for her turn as a woman escaping a sadistic killer in the box-office flop ''I Know Who Killed Me,'' Reuters reported.

WHITTEMORE--Laurence F. A partner with the private banking firm of Brown Brothers Harriman & Co., died December 24, 2007 from complications resulting from a fall on the ice. He was 78 years old and passed away peacefully while surrounded by his entire family. He lived in Greenwich, Connecticut. Mr. Whittemore had a 51-year career with Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. After holding various investment offices, he became a General Partner in 1974. He was a Member of the Steering Committee and a Supervisor of the firm's offices in Chicago, St. Louis, Los Angeles, Dallas, and Naples, Florida, as well as the Institutional Investment and Equity Trading Departments. Born on March 7, 1929 in Bangor, Maine, Mr. Whittemore was the son of John Cambridge Whittemore and Elizabeth Payson Prentiss Whittemore. He received his early education in Portland, Maine and graduated with a B.A. from Yale University in 1951, remaining an active fundraiser for his class and his college, Timothy Dwight. He also received a M.B.A. degree from Harvard Business School in 1953. Mr. Whittemore served as a U.S. Naval Intelligence Officer, U.S. Seventh Fleet and U.S. Taiwan Defense Command in the Western Pacific (1953-1956), and as a Commander, U.S. Naval Reserve. A military history buff, he was Director of the New England Air Museum in Windsor Locks, CT; involved in the preservation of the Intrepid Aircraft Carrier; and contributed to the Robert A. Lovett Professorship of Military History at Yale University. A world traveler, Mr. Whittemore had an avid interest in Asian culture and art. He was a Life Member of the Art Institute of Chicago and a former Member of its Committee on Oriental Art; a Member of the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations; and a Member of the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations. He was also Chairman of the Trustees Emeriti of the Asia Society of New York City. Mr. Whittemore served on a variety of boards including Manhattan Life Insurance, Albany Insurance Company, and the Investment Committee of Union Investment GmbH, Frankfurt, Germany. He was also a Governor of Opportunity International, a global micro-credit organization, and a longtime Trustee of Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, NY, as well as a former Trustee of the American Institute for Contemporary German Studies. Mr. Whittemore is survived by his wife of 49 years, Sarah Arnold Whittemore; four daughters, Arianna Miceli (husband Frank), Gioia Frelinghuysen (husband John), Lia Prentiss Whittemore (partner Manoj Garg), Nike Roberts (husband Wayne); four grandchildren; three step-grandchildren; and sisters Arianna Lynch and Charlotte Swaffield (husband Hart). As the patriarch of a large close-knit extended family, he will be deeply missed. A memorial service will be held at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue and East 73rd Street, New York City, on Monday, January 7, 2008, at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Asia Society, Opportunity International, and The New England Air Museum.

TOPOREK--Larry, past away suddenly on December 30, 2007 at age 51. He is survived by his wife Elizabeth Creel, and sons Jesse and Dylan. He will be remembered as a devoted father, brother, as well as a talented and beloved soccer and baseball coach. Funeral services will be held on Thursday January 3, 2008 10am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. (Amsterdam Ave).

PUSH THE 'PAUSE' BUTTON If you're waiting for James Brown's final recordings, it may be a while. Legal battles over the estate of Brown, the soul singer who died at 73 on Christmas Day 2006, continue to delay their release, his lawyer, Albert H. Dallas, told The Associated Press. Five of Brown's heirs are trying to have his will voided, contending that his advisers, seeking to profit, used undue influence to create charitable trusts. At stake, besides the money from his estate, are an album Brown recorded the summer before his death and 50 to 60 other unreleased songs, said Mr. Dallas, who quit as an estate trustee in November but is trying to be reinstated. ...It's a different sound, but while you're waiting, you may want to consider the country album that Billboard says Jessica Simpson is in the early stages of recording in Nashville for release this year by Columbia Records. Citing Martina McBride, Shania Twain, Faith Hill and Reba McEntire as inspirations, Ms. Simpson said she had always wanted to make a country album but was waiting for the right time. Her last album, ''A Public Affair,'' was on the Billboard 200 for just nine weeks in 2006.

Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas is again making misleading statements about how long he was unaware of a National Intelligence Estimate finding that Iran was not pursuing nuclear weapons. The report was released the morning of Dec. 3 and dominated the news that day. Reporters asked Mr. Huckabee for his reaction to the report on the afternoon of Dec. 4, more than 30 hours after its release, and he said he had not heard about it.

DUSENBERRY--Phil, 71, died Saturday, December 29 of advanced lung cancer for which he was treated over the past year. Former Chairman of the advertising agency BBDO North America, Phil helped create what many observers consider the most creative network in the world. From theme lines like GE's ''We bring good things to life,'' to Pepsi's ''The choice of a new generation,'' Phil created advertising that truly touched the heart. He pioneered the effective use of celebrities as participants, not just pitchmen. His work for Pepsi featured celebrities like Michael Jackson, Michael J. Fox and Madonna, and his long list of awards includes ADDYs, Clios, One Show Pencils, and Gold Lions at Cannes. In recognition of a lifetime of creative achievement, Phil was inducted into the American Advertising Federation Hall of Fame in 2003 and The One Club Creative Hall of Fame in October 2007. Raised in Brooklyn, the son of a cab driver, Phil graduated from Midwood High School. He attended Emory & Henry College in Virginia on an athletic scholarship but left when the athletic program was cancelled. After that, he was mostly and very effectively self-taught. He joined BBDO New York as a copywriter in 1962 and rose to become the agency's Chief Creative Officer, then Chairman and CEO, and finally Chairman of BBDO North America. Under Phil's leadership, BBDO was named ''Agency of the Year'' on four different occasions by the leading industry publications, and the agency enjoyed unprecedented growth with the addition of such renowned brands as FedEx, HBO, Pizza Hut and Cingular, to name a few. ''The work, the work, the work'' became the agency's mantra. Phil's contributions to public service were many and varied. He spearheaded the team that worked with Mayor Giuliani to develop the ''New York Miracle'' campaign, raising New York City's spirits following 9/11. He led the Ad Council's Freedom Corps effort urging volunteerism as well as the Council's more recent ''Don't Almost Give'' public service messages that ran this year. He was Chairman of the 4A's and served on the Boards of the New York Coalition for the Homeless, the Silver Shield Foundation of New York and the Twin Towers Fund. Phil was also a member of the ''Tuesday Team'' that helped reelect Ronald Reagan in 1984. His filmed tribute, ''Final Journey,'' subsequently became a permanent part of the Reagan Presidential Library. A lifelong baseball and die-hard Yankee fan, he cowrote the screenplay for the Robert Redford movie, ''The Natural.'' His philosophy towards business and advertising is best summed up by the title of his 2005 memoir, ''One Great Insight Is Worth a Thousand Good Ideas.'' Phil lived in Manhattan, Sag Harbor, NY and St. Thomas, VI. He was a member of the East Hampton Golf Club and Blind Brook Country Club in Westchester, and an active member of St. Andrew's R.C. Church in Sag Harbor. This September, he received the St. Agnes Medal of Service from the Diocese of Rockville Centre. He is survived by his wife, Susan; his stepson, Ben Procter; a daughter-inlaw, Ilana Sparrow; a brother Harry and wife Marcy; a brother Joseph; a sister Jean Driscoll and husband Jack; and a large extended family. A wake will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street in Manhattan on Thursday evening, January 3rd, from 7pm to 9pm, and Friday, January 4th, from 2pm to 4pm and 7pm to 9pm. A Funeral Mass will be held on Saturday, January 5th at 1pm at St. Ignatius Loyola at 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street in Manhattan. A graveside service will take place on Sunday, January 6th at 11am at Oakland Cemetery in Sag Harbor. Donations may be made in Phil's name to: Coalition for the Homeless, 129 Fulton Street, New York, NY 10038 or St. Jude Children's Cancer Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105.

JOHNSON--Ron, died Sunday, December 30th in his home in Upper Nyack, NY at 49 years old. He leaves behind his wife, Jacqueline Pack-Johnson, and his son, Matthew Pack. He was the son of Irene Ware and the late Fred Ware. Ron was born and raised in Mobile, AL. He graduated with a degree in Business Administration from Georgia State University and began a career in banking in Atlanta, GA. In 1989 he left his position as Vice President of Special Assets Group for First Union Corporation of Georgia to begin his career in the record industry. A position at Polygram Label Group brought Ron and his family to New York in 1992. He held subsequent positions at Island, Mercury, and Motown Records. In April 2007 he left his position as Executive Vice President of Atlantic Records to join Capitol Music Group as Executive Vice President and head of Urban Music. Ron suffered from Arteritis believed to be caused from Kawasaki Disease contracted in childhood. He became aware of his condition in March 2006 after suffering a heart attack. He faced his condition head on without fear. He was an avid runner and was training for his first marathon. Ron loved his family, turkey burgers and Guinness beer, Porsche sports cars, playing golf, and his dog Lucy. In addition to his wife and son he is survived by his mother, Irene, Ausbon Johnson (father), his brothers Darryl Johnson and George Johnson (Robin), his nieces and nephews Monique Thomas (Corey), Darron Johnson, Brian Johnson, Brianna Johnson, Brittaney Johnson and his godchildren Shavara and Shane Rice. He will be deeply missed by all. A funeral mass will be held on Saturday, January 5th at 10am at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church at 16 Jefferson Street in Nyack, NY. In addition, a wake/memorial service will be held on Friday, January 4th from 5-9pm, also at St. Ann's Church. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Emory University Dr. Wendy Book Adult Congenital Research Fund (Ron's favorite charity) or St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church, 16 Jefferson St., Nyack, NY 10960. Perfumers are hired to create perfumes by fashion houses, whose "creative teams," usually a group of marketers, direct the perfumers in making the juices: "a little sweeter, please," "no, less floral," "can you boost the wood in the dry-down?" They also make the final call - "It's this one" - and there's the perfume. Perfume-making thus functions very much according to the weakest link theory: the scent is only as good as any given team member's worst decision.

I started off the year writing about a new plan for making deep, sustained cuts in greenhouse-gas emissions while compensating the public for the hit to pocketbooks from higher energy costs. The plan, called "Cap and Dividend," was conceived by Peter Barnes, an inventor of socially responsible investment funds and author of "Who Owns the Sky?" He says "cap and trade" schemes like the one in the Kyoto Protocol and various climate bills under consideration in Congress do little, if anything, to help the poor and middle class. He also cites problems with a straight tax on carbon content of fuels. (Grist recently explored an earlier iteration of Mr. Barnes's idea.)

How impressive was West Virginia's dismantling of Oklahoma in the Fiesta Bowl? Well, it apparently got Bill Stewart a job. Dave Hickman of the Charleston Gazette reports that West Virginia will announce today that Stewart is Rich Rodriguez's successor. ESPN.com's Pat Forde talked to a source that said if Stewart met certain incentive clauses in his contract, he "could almost make Rod money." Forde also talked to several players who threw their support behind Stewart being hired as the new head coach. Hickman's colleague Mitch Vingle takes time to reflect on the Mountaineers' accomplishment, especially in light of the distractions that surrounded Rodriguez's departure.

"Is it just my long-time Giants loyalty speaking, or is anyone else wondering how the moniker 'L.T.' was so easily transferred to LaDainian Tomlinson?" Bill Brink writes in this week's Play newsletter. "Is it as simple as a decree from 'SportsCenter' or should the standard be higher -- say, like transforming the very way the game is played? That's what the original L.T., Lawrence Taylor, did when he was terrorizing quarterbacks in the 1980's. Tomlinson's superb talent is unquestioned, and he seems sure to eventually join Taylor in the Hall of Fame. But he doesn't have two Super Bowl rings, hasn't willed his team to greatness, and most importantly hasn't fundamentally altered strategy on the other side of the line of scrimmage. Let's reserve that nickname for their rightful owner!"

The number of postponed and canceled flotations in Europe last year was almost five times higher than in the United States, despite the origins of last summer's credit crisis and equity market volatility lying in the United States mortgage market.
Centro Properties Group, Australia's second high-profile victim of a global credit crunch, is attracting interest from the Citadel Investment Group, according to press reports.

News that the activist investor Nelson Peltz and his companies have been cleared by the Federal Trade Commission to buy shares of Marsh & McLennan, the insurance broker, added fuel to speculation that the company might go on the block.

For dozens of retailers that went through leveraged buyouts in the last three years, a lot may be riding on a successful holiday season. Amid a housing slump, high energy prices and growing concern of a possible recession, some highly leveraged companies could face difficulties if consumer confidence ebbs, The Deal.com notes.
Shares of EchoStar Communications's technology unit began trading on Wednesday as part of its founder's plan to raise the valuations of the company's operations.

A week after some investors tried forcing it into bankruptcy, Ritchie Capital defended management of its multi-strategy hedge fund and warned other investors that the group's legal action could "cause further damage to the value of your investment."

Despite the global credit crunch in 2007, new investment in clean energy industries like wind and solar power rose sharply to break through the $100 billion barrier for the first time, a research group, New Energy Finance, said Wednesday.

Ford’s sales fell 12 percent in 2007, allowing Toyota to replace it as the country’s second largest seller of vehicles. It was the first year that Ford was not No. 2, behind General Motors, since 1931.

Firefighters rescued two young girls from a burning apartment in Flatbush on Wednesday, and the man who left them unattended was charged with endangerment, the police said. The girls, who are sisters believed to be 1 and 3 years old, were taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where they were in stable condition after being treated for smoke inhalation. Their mother had left them in the care of her live-in companion, Steven Vassort, 23, but he went out, the police said. He was charged with two counts of child endangerment. The cause of the fire was not immediately determined.

ORLANDO, Fla. (AP) — Jason Kidd just missed having a triple-double and made a key defensive stop as the Nets overcame a 15-point deficit to defeat the Orlando Magic on Wednesday night, 96-95.

Jason Kidd proved again why he is one of the N.B.A.’s most versatile guards, making a key defensive stop and just missing a triple-double Wednesday night to help the Nets overcome a 15-point deficit and beat the Magic, 96-95, in Orlando, Fla.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about an outspoken Saudi blogger who was being detained by the government misspelled the blogger’s given name in one reference. He is Fouad al-Farhan, not Fouah.

Arinze Onuaku scored a career-high 23 points and pulled down 12 rebounds, Donte’ Greene added 22 points, and host Syracuse held off St. John’s, 76-70, in the Big East opener for both teams.

Australia and the United States will start talks within the next six weeks to open up the trans-Pacific aviation route between the countries, Australia’s government said. The transportation minister, Anthony Albanese, left, gave approval for talks to start in Washington next month in a move that may permit more United States airlines to fly to Australia via ports in Asia. A spokesman for Mr. Albanese said the meetings would be held Feb. 12-14. Under the current treaty, airlines based in either country can begin only four weekly flights on the route in the first year.

The German industrial conglomerate Siemens has agreed to buy Morgan Construction of Worcester, Mass., a provider of rolling-mill products used in the metals industry, the two companies said. Siemens said Morgan Construction had annual sales of $180 million and about 1,100 employees in the United States, China, India, Britain and Brazil and would strengthen Siemens’s position in metals technologies. Financial details were not disclosed.

The Boeing Company said that the Brazilian airline GOL Linhas Aéreas had completed an order for an additional 40 Boeing 737 passenger airplanes with a median list value of $3 billion. Boeing said GOL, the parent company of the low-cost airlines GOL Transportes Aéreos and VRG Linhas Aéreas, also confirmed purchase rights for 40 additional 737 aircraft. GOL said last month that it had exercised firm orders for 34 Boeing 737-800 aircraft.

I.B.M. bought an Israeli data-storage provider, XIV, to meet growing demand for digital archiving. Financial terms were not disclosed. I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., has bought about two dozen data-management companies since 2001 to bolster sales of software for storing, gaining access to and analyzing data. XIV, which is privately held, was founded in 2002 by five graduates of Talpiot, an Israeli military technology training program. The company, based in Tel Aviv, has about 50 employees.

Nokia Siemens Networks, a maker of wireless networks, agreed to buy Apertio for about 140 million euros ($206 million) to expand its subscriber data management services. Apertio has 237 employees and had sales of about 28 million euros in 2007, Nokia Siemens said. Nokia Siemens, which is a joint venture of Nokia and Siemens and is based in Espoo, Finland, expects the acquisition to close in the first quarter of this year. Apertio’s products are used by wireless and fixed phone operators. Apertio, based in Bristol, England, has operations in Continental Europe, Asia and the United States.

A former chief financial officer of the nonprofit group the Institute for Cancer Prevention admitted in Federal District Court on Wednesday that he lied to federal agents who were checking on the use of grants awarded to the organization, prosecutors said. The former official, Roy Victor, pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice, Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan, said in a statement. Prosecutors said Mr. Victor admitted that he lied repeatedly to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He faces up to 10 years in prison.

Doctors who care for poor children in New Jersey are receiving an increase in Medicaid reimbursements for the first time in two decades, with payments more than tripling. Under the new rate, which started on Tuesday, physicians are being paid $73.70 from Medicaid for each child’s visit, up from $23.03; dentists will see payments jump to $64 for each exam from $18.02. “It’s a big step toward providing more access for our clients,” said Jennifer Velez, commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Human Services. The new rates will also help the department attract new providers, she said.

The police blamed space heaters for a house fire that killed a married couple in their 80s on Wednesday. Fire officials said the fast-moving fire was fueled by clothing, papers and other clutter piled five feet high throughout the house. The couple, Caroline and Leo Gorynski, were found inside. Deputy Fire Chief John Flynn said that the fire started when space heaters ignited some of the clutter, and that there was clothing on top of the heaters. The Fire Department said the couple had nailed their front door shut, but Chief Flynn said that that did not delay the search for the victims. Ms. Gorynski, 88, was pronounced dead at the scene, and Mr. Gorynski, 87, died a short time later at a hospital.

A Simsbury electrical contractor who told investigators that he gave former Gov. John G. Rowland expensive cigars and Champagne in exchange for access to state business was sentenced on Wednesday to five years in prison for hiding personal assets from a bankruptcy court. The contractor, Kurt Claywell, was convicted in July of conspiracy to commit bankruptcy fraud for attempting to conceal more than $200,000 in assets during a 2005 bankruptcy filing.

A 20-year-old man was shot to death about 8:30 p.m. on Wednesday in an apartment building in Mott Haven, the police said. Officers responding to a 911 call found the man lying in a hallway on the 18th floor of the building, at 360 East 137th Street. The man, whom the police did not identify, suffered multiple gunshot wounds and was pronounced dead at the scene. There were no arrests and no known motive, the police said.

The E-Commerce Report column in Business Day on Monday reported on Kijiji, a free classified ads online service owned by eBay that seeks to compete with Craigslist, the San Francisco-based company that manages classified ad sites in hundreds of cities. The column should have noted that eBay, based in San Jose, Calif., and Craigslist have a financial relationship. EBay bought a 25 percent stake in Craigslist in 2004.

The former Olympic champion Marion Jones said she had been punished enough and should not have to go to prison for lying about steroids and check fraud. In court papers filed Monday, Jones's lawyers asked a federal judge to give her probation when he sentences her next week. ''She has been cast from American hero to national disgrace,'' the papers said. ''The public scorn, from a nation that once adored her, and her fall from grace have been severe punishments.''She has been stripped of her gold medals, her accomplishments, her wealth and her public standing,'' the papers continued.Jones acknowledged in court in October that she lied to federal investigators. She has since relinquished her five Olympic medals. As part of the plea agreement, prosecutors suggested she be sentenced to six months in prison at most. In presentencing papers filed Dec. 21, prosecutors said anything between no time and six months would be appropriate.

ROBINSON--L. Donald, 69, died peacefully at home, December 30, 2007, after a brief, valiant battle with cancer. He is survived by the ''love of his life,'' Dr. Ellen Siroka Robinson, and the family so dear to him: Matthew and Alejandra Siroka, sister-in-law Jane Parver, brother-in-law Tony Klein and his family, his favorite mother-in-law Lillian Klein, and his beloved cat, Disty. Don's illustrious career spanned 45 years as a top broadcaster and media executive. He was President and CEO of Field Spot Sales, Katz Independent Media Television Sales, Media General Broadcast Services and Seltel Media Sales. An industry leader in television station spot sales business, he considered his greatest achievement the development of careers of young people working for him. A ''Renaissance Man,'' Don loved beauty, opera, music, theater, fine art, good food and wine, all of which he joyfully shared with family and friends. He was a runner, tennis player and passionate NY Jets fan. He found solace in his home in East Hampton. He accepted his diagnosis gracefully, fought his illness with unbelievable courage, but left us too soon. Memorial service January 5th, 5:30pm, Campbell Funeral Home.

Jim Leyritz had a suspended license before he was charged with driving under the influence and killing a woman last week in Florida. New York State suspended his Florida license a month before the crash. Florida officials said Leyritz's license was still valid in the state, but they planned to suspend it soon, the state motor vehicles department said. Leyritz was ticketed outside Albany for using a cellphone while driving June 20, and his license was suspended Nov. 23 for failing to answer the summons, according to records.

An article in Business Day on Monday about Nintendo's video game consoles misspelled the surname of the president and chief operating officer of Nintendo of America, and a correction in this space on Tuesday gave another incorrect spelling. He is Reggie Fils-Aime -- not Fils-Amie or Fils-Aimee.

HEDGES--Philip Hall, a retired partner at the New York law firm of White & Case, passed away Sunday, December 30th at his home in Harrison, New York. He was 74. Mr. Hedges was born in Middletown, Connecticut, and grew up in Portland. He later graduated from Wesleyan University and The University of Chicago Law School, Cum Laude. He spent his entire law career at White & Case where he was a senior partner in Corporate Real Estate. He was a loving husband to his wife Edith (Nyman) of 47 years and father to three children, Hames (Michele von Kroemer), Nancy (Joseph Stein) and David (Gretchen Ohlig). He had seven grandchildren who loves and admired him; Eleanor Hedges; Courtney, Emily and Anna Stein; Matthew, Spencer and Payson Hedges. He is also survived by several nieces and nephews. Mr. Hedges was the youngest child of Raymond and Clara (Hall) Hedges of Portland and had two siblings now deceased, Raymond Jr. and Eleanor (Hale). The family will hold a private Episcopal service and burial in Portland on Thursday, January 3rd. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Heart Association, 5 Brookside Dr., Wallingford, CT 06492, or the charity of your choice. There are no calling hours. Services are under the direction of the Portland Memorial Funeral Home 231 Main St., Portland.

The work of Piero Fornasetti is so familiar to design aficionados as to seem ubiquitous. Even though he has been dead for almost 20 years, Fornasetti's studio, now under the supervision of his son Barnaba, keeps churning out products based on his designs. The latest product: rugs. While the elder Fornasetti did not produce rugs during his prolific career, his son claims that is only because ''life is short.'' Mr. Fornasetti, together with Sam Roubini of Roubini Rugs, chose 25 designs from the Fornasetti archive (which is thought to contain more than 11,000 designs) to produce a collection of hand-knotted wool and silk rugs ($2,900 to $24,600). Asked about his favorites, Mr. Fornasetti replied ''the fish, the courtyard, the ribbon with objects and the snake.'' Roubini Rugs, 200 Lexington (32nd Street), (212) 696-4648 or www.roubinirugs.com. Canada rallied to beat Finland, 4-2, to reach the semifinals of the world junior championship Wednesday in Pardubice, Czech Republic, and keep alive its bid for a fourth straight title. Russia defeated the Czech Republic, 4-1, in the other quarterfinal. Canada will play the United States in one semifinal Friday and Sweden will play Russia. The United States and Sweden qualified for the semifinals by winning their preliminary groups.Canada's first three goals came from John Tavares, Steven Stamkos and Brad Marchand. Stefan Legein added an empty-netter with 30 seconds left.

The 4-by-6-inch miniature washing board ($7.25) from Muji is one of those things that many people need -- more often, in fact, than they might think. It is just the right size for hand laundering. A stain on a shirt or a sweater can be washed easily in the sink and scrubbed against this little laundry tool, which fits in one hand and can be stored in almost no space. Muji, 455 Broadway (Grand Street), (212) 334-2002. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

DUSENBERRY--Phil, 71, died Saturday, December 29 of advanced lung cancer for which he was treated over the past year. Former Chairman of the advertising agency BBDO North America, Phil helped create what many observers consider the most creative network in the world. From theme lines like GE's ''We bring good things to life,'' to Pepsi's ''The choice of a new generation,'' Phil created advertising that truly touched the heart. He pioneered the effective use of celebrities as participants, not just pitchmen. His work for Pepsi featured celebrities like Michael Jackson, Michael J. Fox and Madonna, and his long list of awards includes ADDYs, Clios, One Show Pencils, and Gold Lions at Cannes. In recognition of a lifetime of creative achievement, Phil was inducted into the American Advertising Federation Hall of Fame in 2003 and The One Club Creative Hall of Fame in October 2007. Raised in Brooklyn, the son of a cab driver, Phil graduated from Midwood High School. He attended Emory & Henry College in Virginia on an athletic scholarship but left when the athletic program was cancelled. After that, he was mostly and very effectively self-taught. He joined BBDO New York as a copywriter in 1962 and rose to become the agency's Chief Creative Officer, then Chairman and CEO, and finally Chairman of BBDO North America. Under Phil's leadership, BBDO was named ''Agency of the Year'' on four different occasions by the leading industry publications, and the agency enjoyed unprecedented growth with the addition of such renowned brands as FedEx, HBO, Pizza Hut and Cingular, to name a few. ''The work, the work, the work'' became the agency's mantra. Phil's contributions to public service were many and varied. He spearheaded the team that worked with Mayor Giuliani to develop the ''New York Miracle'' campaign, raising New York City's spirits following 9/11. He led the Ad Council's Freedom Corps effort urging volunteerism as well as the Council's more recent ''Don't Almost Give'' public service messages that ran this year. He was Chairman of the 4A's and served on the Boards of the New York Coalition for the Homeless, the Silver Shield Foundation of New York and the Twin Towers Fund. Phil was also a member of the ''Tuesday Team'' that helped reelect Ronald Reagan in 1984. His filmed tribute, ''Final Journey,'' subsequently became a permanent part of the Reagan Presidential Library. A lifelong baseball and die-hard Yankee fan, he cowrote the screenplay for the Robert Redford movie, ''The Natural.'' His philosophy towards business and advertising is best summed up by the title of his 2005 memoir, ''One Great Insight Is Worth a Thousand Good Ideas.'' Phil lived in Manhattan, Sag Harbor, NY and St. Thomas, VI. He was a member of the East Hampton Golf Club and Blind Brook Country Club in Westchester, and an active member of St. Andrew's R.C. Church in Sag Harbor. This September, he received the St. Agnes Medal of Service from the Diocese of Rockville Centre. He is survived by his wife, Susan; his stepson, Ben Procter; a daughter-inlaw, Ilana Sparrow; a brother Harry and wife Marcy; a brother Joseph; a sister Jean Driscoll and husband Jack; and a large extended family. A wake will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street in Manhattan on Thursday evening, January 3rd, from 7pm to 9pm, and Friday, January 4th, from 2pm to 4pm and 7pm to 9pm. A Funeral Mass will be held on Saturday, January 5th at 1pm at St. Ignatius Loyola at 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street in Manhattan. A graveside service will take place on Sunday, January 6th at 11am at Oakland Cemetery in Sag Harbor. Donations may be made in Phil's name to: Coalition for the Homeless, 129 Fulton Street, New York, NY 10038 or St. Jude Children's Cancer Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105.

Caleb Smith won the men's United States skeleton national championship at the Olympic Sports Complex in Lake Placid, N.Y., on Wednesday, securing the third position on the World Cup team. GRACE--Natalie Watts, of Great Neck and East Hampton, LI, in her 99th year, died peacefully at her home, in Great Neck on Sunday, December 30, 2007. Beloved daughter of the late Mr. And Mrs. Edward Everett Watts, daughter-in-law of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morgan H. Grace (Ruth Eden) of Kings Point, beloved wife of Morgan H. Grace, who died in 1995 at age 89, after 57 years of marriage; beloved sister of the late Edward Everett Watts, Jr., the late Louise Watts, and the late Maud Watts Grayson. Cherished mother of Natalie Grace Dejoux Brinckerhoff of Palm Beach, Locust Valley, and East Hampton, and Morgan Grace of Washington, D.C., and Southampton; loving sister-in-law of Robert M. Grace and his wife Jane, Lorraine Grace, widow of Oliver R. Grace, and Isabella Watts of Mattapoisett. Survived by many nephews and nieces including, on the Watts' side, Maud Grayson, Spence Watts Grayson, Elizabeth Watts Boileau, Edward Everett Watts III, and Isabella Watts Cunynghame. Adored grandmother of Edouard Henri Grace Dejoux (Blair Hopkins), Morgan Andre Grace Dejoux (Eleanor Acquavella), and Elizabeth Grace. Devoted great-grandmother to Christine, Hope, Charlotte, William Jacques, and Isabelle Dejoux. A graduate of St. Agatha's School and The Spence School, Class of 1927, where she earned a Classical Diploma, Natalie Watts excelled in all her subjects including Latin. Her completed crossword puzzles in Latin were often posted on the bulletin board. She had a beautiful voice, loved to sing, and sang on the radio in the years before her 1938 marriage. In the early 1930's she was a member of the Blue Hill Troupe, singing in Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, and active as a Young Republican. She was Chairman of the LVIS Fair in East Hampton in 1968: Her first grandson was due the date of the Fair, and all the ladies thought he should be named ELVIS! For many years she was Chairman of Books at both the LVIS Fair in East Hampton (where she turned her small guest cottage into a temporary book store) and, with her dear friend, Eleanor Rawlings, at the All Saints Church Strawberry Festival in Great Neck. During these past few weeks, she hummed and sang Christmas carols, along with the radio and TV. A cheerful, kind, strong, resilient, and intelligent lady, she knew many of the answers on ''Jeopardy'', ''Wheel of Fortune'' and ''Millionaire'', which she enjoyed watching with her wonderful nurses, her children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren, when they visited. Her household was always a happy one. She was loved and admired by both her sons-in-law, Jacques H. Dejoux, of Lyon and Albon d'Ardeche, France, adored grandfather of her great-grandchildren, and a former VicePresident of Marine Midland Bank, and the late William H. Brinckerhoff, whose greataunts, the Misses Annie and Mary Brinckerhoff had been her English and Latin teachers at Spence. She loved and was loved by all her nurses, with whom she enjoyed tea and conversation: Brigid Corban, Margaret Burrascano, Catherine Byrne, Thelma Clarke, Caroline Grace Casler, niece, Ann De Marco, Anne Flynn, Kathleen Flynn, Helen Gately, Mary Gonzalez, Ginger Hoernig, Dymphna Horan, Debra Kennedy, Renate Low, Arlene Mongiello, Debora Myrick, Katherine Noone, Joan O'Brien, Helen O'Hara, Maureen Pesce, Barbara Palladino, Margaret Ryan, Sharon Schmiemann, Kathleen Tilney, Yvette Warynold, and Helga Woodard, and by her devoted housekeepers, Josefa Briceno, Ligia Florez, and Marta Stark. A former member of the Woman's Club of Great Neck, the Junior League, Devon Yacht Club, the Bath and Tennis Club in Palm Beach, she was a current member of Maidstone Club, which she joined with her husband in 1955. Funeral services will be held at All Saints Episcopal Church, 855 Middle Neck Road, Great Neck, on Saturday, January 5th 2008, at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations in her honor to The Spence School, 22 East 91st St., New York, NY 10128.

The Olympic champion sprinter Justin Gatlin will challenge his four-year doping suspension and may take the case to federal court, his lawyer said. A three-member arbitration panel cut Gatlin's suspension in half to four years in a 53-page ruling released Tuesday. Gatlin tested positive for excessive testosterone at the Kansas Relays in April 2006. It was his second offense because he was found to have trace amounts of amphetamine from a prescribed medication at the world junior championships in 2001.

Teresa Chang spent the better part of the last decade perfecting the art of making porcelain teapots. It might seem obsessive, but Ms. Chang, who trained as an architect and then made a name for herself creating dinnerware, believes strongly in the combination of form and function. ''The teapot is the ultimate challenge -- the spout alone has about six different parameters,'' Ms. Chang said from her Philadelphia studio. ''Get one wrong and your tea dribbles.'' Needless to say, Ms. Chang's teapots do not dribble. Then again, she studied under Ah Leon, a Taiwanese ceramist considered by many to be a teapot master. He pushed her to set higher standards, and the result is beautiful and functional handmade teapots meant to be used, not merely displayed on a shelf. The teapot with a bamboo-style handle, above, is $625. Information: (215) 627-4070 or www.teresachang.com. RIMA SUQI

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about an outspoken Saudi blogger who was being detained by the government misspelled the blogger's given name in one reference. He is Fouad al-Farhan, not Fouah.

BEFORE the first iPod-friendly glove for snow sports was released about two years ago, skiers and snowboarders who wouldn't be caught without music on the slopes had to remove their gloves to adjust their players. As anyone who skis or slides in frigid conditions knows, this often meant gloves dropped from chairlifts (or watching as a ski buddy used his nose to adjust a player). Since that time, industry leaders like the North Face have introduced models specifically for the outdoor set, while smaller labels like Pow Gloves have created options for music fiends, photographers and videographers.

ALGRANT--Roland. Mem bers of the International Freedom to Publish Committee of the Association of American Publishers sadly note the death on December 19 of publisher Roland Algrant, a member of our committee for many years and our chair from 1987 to 1990. We remember with great affection his wisdom, humor and leadership and offer condolences to his loving family. Through fact-finding missions and forceful advocacy, he championed the cause of free expression around the world and helped train a new generation of human rights activists. His passion and persistence will continue to inspire us all.

The structure Ronald Zürcher designed at Peninsula Papagayo, a 2,300-acre development on the west coast of the Guanacaste province of Costa Rica, has been likened to the Sydney Opera House or to a place of worship. But it houses neither a musical nor a religious organization. The 28,000-square-foot building with dramatic arches, below, is a golf clubhouse. Mr. Zürcher, an architect based in Costa Rica, found inspiration for his design from a conch shell. ''He drew the initial design on a napkin,'' said Jim Preskitt, senior vice president of Ecodesarrollo Peninsula Papagayo, the company that developed the peninsula. ''I thought it was interesting, but wasn't sure he could pull it off. It came out better than any of us ever dreamed. It's an unbelievable architectural statement.''
WALSEY--Adrienne, Happy Birthday. Forever in my memories. Always, Steven

HERO--Byron A., M.D., passed away December 31, 2007. Survived by his wife, Angela; sons Byron Jr. and Basil; daughter-in-law Camille; and grandchildren Alexander Byron, Gabrielle, Alexandra and Ariane. Born in Pelham, New York in 1912, he was graduated from Cornell University and Tufts University Medical School. In 1941, before America's entry into WWII, he volunteered for service at the newly established military hospital at the Base of Command in Newfoundland. He later served as regimental surgeon with the First Army Coast Artillery and was Chief of Surgery at the 117th Evacuation Hospital with the Third and Seventh Armies in France, Germany and Austria. He was discharged with the rank of Lieutenant Colonel and awarded the Bronze Star. In a career that spanned more than fifty years as a surgeon in New York City, he was affiliated with Midtown Hospital (Chief of Surgery), Doctors Hospital, Beth Israel Hospital and Lenox Hill Hospital. He was also Professor of Clinical Surgery at the New York University Medical School. An avid sportsman and accomplished athlete, he enjoyed a lifelong passion for tennis and was an active participant at the New York Athletic Club, the Westchester Country Club and the Meadow Club of Southampton. The family will be receiving friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., NYC, Thursday, January 3, 2008, from 6:00 to 9:00pm. The funeral service will be on Friday, January 4, at 11:00am, at the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Lenox Hill Hospital or Saint Basil Academy, 79 Saint Basil's Road, Garrison, NY 10524.

During his years as Editor, he expanded the breadth of the Journal to include many articles on international issues. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Officers and Trustees The Copyright Society of the USA

Those willing to expend even the tiniest bit of energy to help save the planet may appreciate ''Green Building & Remodeling for Dummies'' (Wiley Publishing; $21.99). This well-organized book by Eric Corey Freed, an architect who has spent 15 years designing sustainable buildings, aims to help ordinary people make decisions that have a gentler impact on the earth. Tips include everything from what constitutes a green kitchen to macro-level considerations for constructing a house, like whether to build up or out (up is usually cheaper and less damaging to the environment). There's also a chapter on building methods, like creating walls from discarded tires. With every topic, Mr. Freed said, he cut out the technical complexities and described ''just the parts people need to know.'' JULIE SCELFO

SHAPIRO--Dr. William, 82. Dr. William Shapiro died peacefully at Boca Raton Hospital after a long illness, on Tuesday, December 25, 2007, he was 82 years old. The cause was intestinal carcinoma. He is survived by his beloved wife and partner of 60 years, Betty; brother Nathan, son Kenneth and his wife Joni, and grandsons Judson and Reuben, son Raymond, and granddaughters Julia and Alexandra, daughter-in-law Judith, and grandchildren David, Alex and Ilana, and sisterin-law Mildred Ostrowsky, and many devoted friends, nephews and nieces. His son Eric Shapiro, M.D. predeceased him this past April as a result of a Glioblastoma. He survived inhuman treatment as a POW during WWII under the Nazis and successfully graduated college and medical school, with support from the GI Bill. He and his partner Solomon Kaplan practiced Obstetrics & Gynecology in NYC for more than 30 years, gaining the lifelong respect of patients, colleagues, and medical students at the Mt. Sinai Medical Center. At Dr. Shapiro's request, donations in his memory, should be sent to the Eric A. Shapiro, M.D. Memorial Fund: American Jewish World Service, c/o Eric A. Shapiro Memorial Fund, 45 West 36th St., New York, NY 10018.

A fire lieutenant, Lt. John H. Martinson, 40, died on Thursday evening after a full-scale assault on a smoky and blinding fire that enveloped a 25-story apartment building at 1700 Bedford Avenue in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, at the site of the former Ebbets Field. At least four other firefighters and four residents of the apartment building were injured, with the injuries were not considered life-threatening.

Among the cast of characters at this year’s New York National Boat Show: two Oklahoma men who wrestle catfish by grabbing them in their mouths (one had the broken fingers to prove it), Miss Geico (a transvestite version of the insurance company gecko wearing a bikini and a fake eyelashes), two men who created a dolphin-shaped submersible boat named “Sweet Virgin Angel” (“We call it ‘Angel’ for short,” one said), and a boating staff that spent hours simulating fishing with the Nintendo Wii.Boaters can fall either into the stodgy or whimsical lots — and both were evident at the boat show, which started last Saturday and runs through Sunday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg continued to stay mum this morning on his own political aspirations, but continued to assert that the leading candidates for president had failed to be specific enough in their proposed solutions for the nation’s problems. Mr. Bloomberg spoke about a University of Oklahoma conference he plans to attend this weekend, at which participants expect to call for the candidates to renounce what the mayor called “partisan bickering.”

On Saturday and Sunday, New Yorkers will be allowed take their old Christmas trees to 85 parks around the five boroughs for the 12th annual MulchFest — at which tree limbs, branches and trunks are ground into wood chips and turned into vegetation-friendly mulch.Last year, about 12,000 trees were recycled through MulchFest, out of more than 160,000 trees recycled citywide. It turns out that mulch is an important argument in the perennial debate on whether “real” Christmas trees or the artificial, synthetic versions are better.

The hauntingly abandoned, Gothically forbidding Smallpox Hospital on Roosevelt Island — perhaps New York City’s most romantic ruin — turned far less romantic and even more ruined last month when part of its crumbling gray stone facade fell to the ground.The collapse, which seems to have been a matter of gravity picking up where negligence left off, came as the publicly owned landmark hospital was closer than ever to being stabilized and preserved as part of the new Southpoint Park planned on the island.

Although London's iconic black taxis are sometimes in short supply, visitors should steer clear of unlicensed minicabs that cruise the streets looking for business. They are illegal and dangerous. Their drivers are not licensed by Transport for London (TFL) and often drive unsafe, uninsured vehicles. They are unlikely to know their way around the city and probably will overcharge for any journey.

MILFORD, N.H. -- Spontaneous combustion! We're here at the New Hampshire Democratic Party's big dinner and out of the masses of 3,000 people, who have been listening politely to Dennis Kucinich, Hillary Clinton and Bill Richardson, comes a huge surge of people toward the stage for the next speaker -- Barack Obama.
John McCain gets another try at New Hampshire, where he won in 2000 by 18 percentage points.

Joe Stiglitz, today at the American Economic Association Meetings, talking about financial crises: "Once-in-a-hundred-years events occur every 10 years." He's thinking of the stock market crash of 1987, the Long Term Capital Management crisis of 1998, and the current subprime-plus crisis -- all of which involved changes in asset prices that were supposed to be vanishingly unlikely.

I've just returned from the living room with a copy of "Happy Times," the photo collection of gods and goddesses by Jerome Zerbe and Brendan Gill. I wanted to see, or to imagine, what the Golden Globes will look like without television cameras, scripted gags and, perhaps, the red-carpet parade of dresses. In other words, if the Globes are to go on as a closed event, without a telecast (which could well be the only alternative at this stage), will the atmosphere resemble the days when Hollywood seemed spectacularly intimate, its gods and goddesses even more remote and unearthly?

NASHUA, N.H. - It was just about 25 hours ago that Rudolph W. Giuliani addressed a group of Cuban-American supporters in Hialeah, Fla. His warm-up speakers addressed the crowd in Spanish. His wife, Judith, greeted the crowd in Spanish. And his campaign launched a new radio ad in Spanish, and passed out Spanish-language campaign fliers about his "12 Compromisos con el Pueblo Americano.''

When I grew up, in the '60s, leisure air travel was still relatively expensive and exceptional for people -- like us back then -- of modest means. So I was 13 when I took my first flight. By way of contrast, our now-22-month-old is a frequent flier. She took her first flight at six months, to France no less! Nowadays, flying is so cheap and routine that it's those who don't fly frequently who are exceptional.

NEW ORLEANS -- With the generally uninspiring set of bowl games so far, the issue of the future of football's postseason format has emerged as the hot topic of the off-season. The 11 conference commissioners will convene in Miami in late April for meetings that could well change the course of college football.

In addition to Apple, Warner Brothers is now going to throw its weight behind the Blu-ray format for high-definition disks. Warner has been the only major studio to publish its movies in both Blu-ray and HD DVD formats. Today, the studio announced that from now on, it would only issue movies in Blu-ray.
